books.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:1
verses.text: Homilies  of  st.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:2
verses.text: john chrysostom,  Archbishop of Constantinople,  on the  epistle of st.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:3
verses.text: paul the apostle  to the  romans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:4
verses.text: The Argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:5
verses.text: As I keep hearing the Epistles of the blessed Paul read, and that twice every week, and often three or four times, whenever we are celebrating the memorials of the holy martyrs, gladly do I enjoy the spiritual trumpet, and get roused and warmed with desire at recognizing the voice so dear to me, and seem to fancy him all but present to my sight, and behold him conversing with me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:6
verses.text: But I grieve and am pained, that all people do not know this man, as much as they ought to know him; but some are so far ignorant of him, as not even to know for certainty the number of his Epistles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:7
verses.text: And this comes not of incapacity, but of their not having the wish to be continually conversing with this blessed man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:8
verses.text: For it is not through any natural readiness and sharpness of wit that even I am acquainted with as much as I do know, if I do know anything, but owing to a continual cleaving to the man, and an earnest affection towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:9
verses.text: For, what belongs to men beloved, they who love them know above all others; because they are interested in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:10
verses.text: And this also this blessed Apostle shows in what he said to the Philippians; "Even as it is meet for me to think this of you all, because I have you in my heart, both in my bonds, and in the defence and confirmation of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:11
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:12
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:13
verses.text: ) And so ye also, if ye be willing to apply to the reading of him with a ready mind, will need no other aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:14
verses.text: For the word of Christ is true which saith, "Seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:15
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:16
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:17
verses.text: ) But since the greater part of those who here gather themselves to us, have taken upon themselves the bringing up of children, and the care of a wife, and the charge of a family, and for this cause cannot afford to all events aroused to receive those things which have been brought together by others, and bestow as much attention upon the hearing of what is said as ye give to the gathering together of goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:18
verses.text: For although it is unseemly to demand only so much of you, yet still one must be content if ye give as much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:19
verses.text: For from this it is that our countless evils have arisen—from ignorance of the Scriptures; from this it is that the plague of heresies has broken out; from this that there are negligent lives; from this labors without advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:20
verses.text: For as men deprived of this daylight would not walk aright, so they that look not to the gleaming of the Holy Scriptures must needs be frequently and constantly sinning, in that they are walking in the worst darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:21
verses.text: And that this fall not out, let us hold our eyes open to the bright shining of the Apostle's words; for this man's tongue shone forth above the sun, and he abounded more than all the rest in the word of doctrine; for since he labored more abundantly than they, he also drew upon himself a large measure of the Spirit's grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:22
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:23
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:24
verses.text: ) And this I constantly affirm, not only from his Epistles, but also from the Acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:25
verses.text: For if there were anywhere a season for oratory, to him men everywhere gave place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:26
verses.text: Wherefore also he was thought by the unbelievers to be Mercurius, because he took the lead in speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:27
verses.text: (Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:28
verses.text: ) And as we are going to enter fully into this Epistle, it is necessary to give the date also at which it was written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:29
verses.text: For it is not, as most think, before all the others, but before all that were written from Rome, yet subsequent to the rest, though not to all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:30
verses.text: For both those to the Corinthians were sent before this: and this is plain from what he wrote at the end of this, saying as follows: "But now I go unto Jerusalem to minister unto the saints: for it hath pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the poor saints which are at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:31
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:32
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:33
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:34
verses.text: ) For in writing to the Corinthians he says: "If it be meet that I go also, they shall go with me" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:35
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:36
verses.text: ); meaning this about those who were to carry the money from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:37
verses.text: Whence it is plain, that when he wrote to the Corinthians, the matter of this journey of his was in doubt, but when to the Romans, it stood now a decided thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:38
verses.text: And this being allowed, the other point is plain, that this Epistle was after those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:39
verses.text: But that to the Thessalonians also seems to me to be before the Epistle to the Corinthians: for having written to them before, and having moved the question of alms to them, when he said, "But as touching brotherly love, ye need not that I write unto you: for ye yourselves are taught of God to love one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:40
verses.text: And indeed ye do it toward all the brethren" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:41
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:42
verses.text: , ): then he wrote to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:43
verses.text: And this very point he makes plain in the words, "For I know the forwardness of your mind, for which I boast of you to them of Macedonia, that Achaia was ready a year ago, and your zeal hath provoked very many" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:44
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:45
verses.text: ): whence he shows that they were the first he had spoken to about this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:46
verses.text: This Epistle then is later than those, but prior (πρώτη) to those from Rome; for he had not as yet set foot in the city of the Romans when he wrote this Epistle, and this he shows by saying, "For I long to see you, that I may impart unto you some spiritual gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:47
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:48
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:49
verses.text: ) But it was from Rome he wrote to the Philippians; wherefore he says, "All the saints salute you, chiefly they that are of Caesar's household" (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:50
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:51
verses.text: ): and to the Hebrews from thence likewise, wherefore also he says, "all they of Italy salute them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:52
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:53
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:54
verses.text: ) And the Epistle to Timothy he sent also from Rome, when in prison; which also seems to me to be the last of all the Epistles; and this is plain from the end: "For I am now ready to be offered," he says, "and the time of my departure is at hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:55
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:56
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:57
verses.text: ) But that he ended his life there, is clear, I may say, to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:58
verses.text: And that to Philemon is also very late, (for he wrote it in extreme old age, wherefore also he said, "as Paul the aged, and now also a prisoner in Christ Jesus") (Philem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:59
verses.text: ), yet previous to that to the Colossians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:60
verses.text: And this again is plain from the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:61
verses.text: For in writing to the Colossians, he says, "All my state shall Tychicus declare unto you, whom I have sent with Onesimus, a faithful and beloved brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:62
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:63
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:64
verses.text: ) For this was that Onesimus in whose behalf he composed the Epistle to Philemon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:65
verses.text: And that this was no other of the same name with him, is plain from the mention of Archippus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:66
verses.text: For it is he whom he had taken as worker together with himself in the Epistle to Philemon, when he besought him for Onesimus, whom when writing to the Colossians he stirreth up, saying, "Say to Archippus, Take heed to the ministry which thou hast received, that thou fulfil it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:67
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:68
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:69
verses.text: ) And that to the Galatians seems to me to be before that to the Romans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:70
verses.text: But if they have a different order in the Bibles, that is nothing wonderful, since the twelve Prophets, though not exceeding one another in order of time, but standing at great intervals from one another, are in the arrangement of the Bible placed in succession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:71
verses.text: Thus Haggai and Zachariah and the Messenger prophesied after Ezekiel and Daniel, and long after Jonah and Zephaniah and all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:72
verses.text: Yet they are nevertheless joined with all those from whom they stand so far off in time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:73
verses.text: But let no one consider this an undertaking beside the purpose, nor a search of this kind a piece of superfluous curiosity; for the date of the Epistles contributes no little to what we are looking after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:74
verses.text: For when I see him writing to the Romans and to the Colossians about the same subjects, and yet not in a like way about the same subjects; but to the former with much condescension, as when he says, "Him that is weak in the faith receive ye, but not to doubtful disputations; for one believeth that he may eat all things, another, herbs" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:75
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:76
verses.text: , ): who is weak, eateth weak, but to the Colossians he does not write in this way, though about the same things, but with greater boldness of speech: "Wherefore if ye be dead with Christ," he says, "why, as though living in the world, are ye subject to ordinances (touch not, taste not, handle not), which all are to perish with the using, not in any honor to the satisfying of the flesh" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:77
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:78
verses.text: –);—I find no other reason for this difference than the time of the transaction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:79
verses.text: For at the first it was needful to be condescending, but afterwards it became no more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:80
verses.text: And in many other places one may find him doing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:81
verses.text: Thus both the physician and the teacher are used to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:82
verses.text: For neither does the physician treat alike his patients in the first stage of their disorder, and when they have come to the point of having health thenceforth, nor the teacher those children who are beginning to learn and those who want more advanced subjects of instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:83
verses.text: Now to the rest he was moved to write by some particular cause and subject, and this he shows, as when he says to the Corinthians, "Touching those things whereof ye wrote unto me" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:84
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:85
verses.text: ): and to the Galatians too from the very commencement of the whole Epistle writes so as to indicate the same thing; but to these for what purpose and wherefore does he write? For one finds him bearing testimony to them that they are "full of goodness, being filled with all knowledge, and able also to admonish others".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:86
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:87
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:88
verses.text: ) Why then does he write to them? "Because of the grace of God," he says, "which is given unto me, that I should be the minister of Jesus Christ" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:89
verses.text: , ): wherefore also he says in the beginning: "I am a debtor; as much as in me is, I am ready to preach the Gospel to you that are at Rome also;" for what is said—as that they are "able to exhort others also" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:90
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:91
verses.text: , ),—and the like, rather belongs to encomium and encouragement: and the correction afforded by means of a letter, was needful even for these; for since he had not yet been present, he bringeth the men to good order in two ways, both by the profitableness of his letter and by the expectation of his presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:92
verses.text: For such was that holy soul, it comprised the whole world and carried about all men in itself thinking the nearest relationship to be that in God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:93
verses.text: And he loved them so, as if he had begotten them all, or rather showed (so  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:94
verses.text: ) a greater instinctive affection than any father (so Field: all mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:95
verses.text: give "a father's toward all"); for such is the grace of the Spirit, it exceedeth the pangs of the flesh, and displays a more ardent longing than theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:96
verses.text: And this one may see specially in the soul of Paul, who having as it were become winged through love, went continually round to all, abiding nowhere nor standing still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:97
verses.text: For since he had heard Christ saying, "Peter, lovest thou Me? feed My sheep" (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:98
verses.text: ); and setting forth this as the greatest test of love, he displayed it in a very high degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:99
verses.text: Let us too then, in imitation of him, each one bring into order, if not the world, or not entire cities and nations, yet at all events his own house, his wife, his children, his friends, his neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:100
verses.text: And let no one say to me, "I am unskilled and unlearned:" nothing were less instructed than Peter, nothing more rude than Paul, and this himself confessed, and was not ashamed to say, "though I be rude in speech, yet not in knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:101
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:102
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:103
verses.text: ) Yet nevertheless this rude one, and that unlearned man, overcame countless philosophers, stopped the mouths of countless orators, and did all by their own ready mind and the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:104
verses.text: What excuse then shall we have, if we are not equal to twenty names, and are not even of service to them that live with us? This is but a pretence and an excuse—for it is not want of learning or of instruction which hindereth our teaching, but drowsiness and sleep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:105
verses.text: (Acts i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:106
verses.text: ; ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 1:107
verses.text: ) Let us then having shaken off this sleep with all diligence cleave to our own members, that we may even here enjoy much calm, by ordering in the fear of God them that are akin to us, and hereafter may partake of countless blessings through the grace and love of our Lord Jesus Christ towards man, through Whom, and with Whom, be glory to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, now, and evermore, and to all ages, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:4
verses.text: ,  "Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an Apostle, separated unto the Gospel of God, (which He promised afore by His prophets in the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:5
verses.text: )"  Moses having written five books, has nowhere put his own name to them, neither have they who after him put together the history of events after him, no nor yet has Matthew, nor John, nor Mark, nor Luke; but the blessed Paul everywhere in his Epistles sets his own name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:6
verses.text: Now why was this? Because they were writing to people, who were present, and it had been superfluous to show themselves when they were present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:7
verses.text: But this man sent his writings from afar and in the form of a letter, for which cause also the addition of the name was necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:8
verses.text: But if in the Epistle to the Hebrews he does not do the same, this too is after his own wise judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:9
verses.text: For since they felt prejudiced against him, lest on hearing the name at the outstart, they should stop up all admission to his discourse, he subtly won their attention by concealing the name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:10
verses.text: But if some Prophets and Solomon have put their names, this I leave as a subject for you to look further into hereafter, why some of them wished to put it so, and some not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:11
verses.text: For you are not to learn everything from me, but to take pains yourselves also and enquire further, lest ye become more dull-witted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:12
verses.text: "Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:13
verses.text: Why did God change his name, and call him Paul who was Saul? It was, that he might not even in this respect come short of the Apostles, but that that preëminence which the chief of the Disciples had, he might also acquire (Mark iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:14
verses.text: ); and have whereon to ground a closer union with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:15
verses.text: And he calls himself, the servant of Christ, yet not merely this; for there be many sorts of servitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:16
verses.text: One owing to the Creation, according to which it says, "for all are Thy servants" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:17
verses.text: cxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:18
verses.text: ); and according to which it says, "Nebuchadnezzar, My servant" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:19
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:20
verses.text: ), for the work is the servant of Him which made it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:21
verses.text: Another kind is that from the faith, of which it saith, "But God be thanked that ye were the servants of sin, but ye have obeyed from a pure heart that form of doctrine which was delivered unto you: being then made free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:22
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:23
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:24
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:25
verses.text: ) Another is that from civil subjection (πολιτείας), after which it saith, "Moses my servant is dead" (Jos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:26
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:27
verses.text: ); and indeed all the Jews were servants, but Moses in a special way as shining most brightly in the community.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:28
verses.text: Since then, in all the forms of the marvellous servitude, Paul was a servant, this he puts in the room of the greatest title of dignity, saying, "a servant of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:29
verses.text: And the Names appertaining to the dispensation he sets forth, going on upwards from the lowest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:30
verses.text: For with the Name Jesus, did the Angel come from Heaven when He was conceived of the Virgin, and Christ He is called from being anointed, which also itself belonged to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:31
verses.text: And with what oil, it may be asked, was He anointed? It was not with oil that He was anointed, but with the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:32
verses.text: And Scripture has instances of calling such "Christs": inasmuch as the Spirit is the chief point in the unction, and that for which the oil is used.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:33
verses.text: And where does it call those "Christs" who are not anointed with oil? "Touch not," it says, "Mine anointed, and do My prophets no harm" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:34
verses.text: cv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:35
verses.text: ), but at that time the institution of anointing with oil did not yet even exist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:36
verses.text: "Called an Apostle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:37
verses.text: He styles himself "called" in all his Epistles, so showing his own candor (εὐγνωμοσύνην), and that it was not of his own seeking that he found, but that when called he came near and obeyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:38
verses.text: And the faithful, he styles, "called to be saints," but while they had been called so far as to be believers, he had besides a different thing committed to his hands, namely, the Apostleship, a thing full of countless blessings, and at once greater than and comprehensive of, all the gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:39
verses.text: And what more need one say of it, than that whatsoever Christ was doing when present, this he committed to their hands when He departed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:40
verses.text: Which also Paul cries aloud, speaking thereof and magnifying the dignity of the Apostles' office; "We are ambassadors for Christ, as though God did beseech by us;" i-e: in Christ's stead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:41
verses.text: "Separated to the Gospel of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:42
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:43
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:44
verses.text: ) For as in a house, each one is set apart for divers works; thus also in the Church, there be divers distributions of ministrations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:45
verses.text: And herein he seems to me to hint, that he was not appointed by lot only, but that of old and from the first he was ordained to this office; which also Jeremy saith, that God spake concerning himself, "Before thou camest forth out of the womb, I sanctified thee, I ordained thee a prophet unto the nations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:46
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:47
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:48
verses.text: ) For in that he was writing to a vainglorious city, and one every way puffed up, he therefore uses every mode of showing that his election was of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:49
verses.text: For he Himself called him, and Himself separated him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:50
verses.text: And he does this, that he may make the Epistle deserve credit, and meet an easy reception.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:51
verses.text: "To the Gospel of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:52
verses.text: Not Matthew then alone is an Evangelist, nor Mark, as neither was this man alone an Apostle, but they also; even if he be said prëeminently to be this, and they that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:53
verses.text: And he calleth it the Gospel, not for those good things only which have been brought to pass, but also for those which are to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:54
verses.text: And how comes he to say, that the Gospel "of God" is preached by himself? for he says, "separated to the Gospel of God"—for the Father was manifest, even before the Gospels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:55
verses.text: Yet even if He were manifest, it was to the Jews only, and not even to all of these as were fitting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:56
verses.text: For neither did they know Him to be a Father, and many things did they conceive unworthily of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:57
verses.text: Wherefore also Christ saith, "The true worshippers" shall come, and that "the Father seeketh such to worship Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:58
verses.text: (John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:59
verses.text: ) But it was afterwards that He Himself with the Son was unveiled to the whole world, which Christ also spake of beforehand, and said, "that they might know Thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ Whom Thou has sent".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:60
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:61
verses.text: ) But he calls it the "Gospel" of God, to cheer the hearer at the outstart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:62
verses.text: For he came not with tidings to make the countenance sad, as did the prophets with their accusations, and charges, and reproofs, but with glad tidings, even the "Gospel of God;" countless treasures of abiding and unchangeable blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:63
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:64
verses.text: "Which He promised afore by His Prophets in the Holy Scriptures".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:65
verses.text: For the Lord, saith he, "shall give the word to them that proclaim glad tidings with great power" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:66
verses.text: lxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:67
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:68
verses.text: ); and again, "How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel of peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:69
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:70
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:71
verses.text: ; Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:72
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:73
verses.text: ) See here both the name of the Gospel expressly and the temper of it, laid down in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:74
verses.text: For, we do not proclaim it by words only, he means, but also by acts done; since neither was it human, but both divine and unspeakable, and transcending all nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:75
verses.text: Now since they have laid against it the charge of novelty also, He shows it to be older than the Greeks, and described aforetime in the Prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:76
verses.text: And if He gave it not from the beginning because of those that were unwilling to receive it, still, they that were willing did hear it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:77
verses.text: "Your father Abraham," He says, "rejoiced to see My day, and he saw it, and was glad".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:78
verses.text: (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:79
verses.text: ) How then comes He to say, "Many prophets desired to see the things which ye see, and have not seen them?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:80
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:81
verses.text: ) He means not so, as ye see and hear, the Flesh itself, and the very miracles before your eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:82
verses.text: But let me beg you to look and see what a very long time ago these things were foretold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:83
verses.text: For when God is about to do openly some great things, He announces them of a long time before, to practise men's hearing for the reception of them when they come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:84
verses.text: "In the Holy Scriptures".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:85
verses.text: Because the Prophets not only spake, but also writ what they spake; nor did they write only, but also shadowed them forth by actions, as Abraham when he led up Isaac, and Moses when he lifted up the Serpent, and when he spread out his hands against Amalek, and when he offered the Paschal Lamb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:87
verses.text: "Concerning His Son which was made of the seed of David, according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:88
verses.text: What dost, thou, O Paul, that after lifting up our souls so, and elevating them, and causing great and unutterable things to pass in show before them, and speaking of the Gospel, and that too the Gospel of God, and bringing in the chorus of the Prophets, and showing the whole of them heralding forth many years before those things which were to come: why dost thou again bring us down to David? Art thou conversing, oh tell me, of some man, and giving him Jesse's son for a father? And wherein are these things worthy of what thou hast just spoken of? Yea, they are fully worthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:89
verses.text: For our discourse is not, saith he, of any bare man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:90
verses.text: Such was my reason for adding, "according to the flesh;" as hinting that there is also a Generation of the Same after the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:91
verses.text: And why did he begin from that and not from this the higher? It is because that was what Matthew, and Luke, and Mark, began from.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:92
verses.text: For he who would lead men by the hand to Heaven, must needs lead them upwards from below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:93
verses.text: So too was the actual dispensation ordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:94
verses.text: First, that is, they saw Him a man upon earth, and then they understood Him to be God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:95
verses.text: In the same direction then, as He Himself had framed His teaching, did His disciple also shape out the way which leadeth thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:96
verses.text: Therefore the generation according to the flesh is in his language placed first in order, not because it was first, but because he was for leading the hearer from this up to that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:98
verses.text: "And declared to be the Son of God with power, according to the Spirit of Holiness, by the resurrection from the dead, even Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:99
verses.text: What is said has been made obscure by the close-folding of the words, and so it is necessary to divide it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:100
verses.text: What then is it, which he says? We preach, says he, Him Who was made of David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:101
verses.text: But this is plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:102
verses.text: Whence then is it plain, that this incarnate "Person" was also the Son of God? First, it is so from the prophets; wherefore he says, "Which He had promised afore by the Prophets in the Holy Scriptures".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:103
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:104
verses.text: ) And this way of demonstration is no weak one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:105
verses.text: And next also from the very way of His Generation: which also he sets forth by saying, "of the seed of David according to the flesh:" for He broke the rule of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:106
verses.text: Thirdly, from the miracles which He did, yielding a demonstration of much power, for "in power" means this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:107
verses.text: Fourthly, from the Spirit which He gave to them that believe upon Him, and through which He made them all holy, wherefore he saith, "according to the Spirit of holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:108
verses.text: For it was of God only to grant such gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:109
verses.text: Fifthly, from the Resurrection; for He first and He alone raised Himself: and this Himself too said to be above all a miracle sufficient to stop the mouths even of them that behaved shamelessly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:110
verses.text: For, "Destroy this Temple," He says, "and in three days I will raise it up" (John xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:111
verses.text: ); and, "When ye have lifted" Me "up from the earth, then shall ye know that I am He" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:112
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:113
verses.text: ); and again, This "generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given unto it, but the sign of Jonas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:114
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:115
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:116
verses.text: ) What then is the being "declared?" being shown, being manifested, being judged, being confessed, by the feeling and suffrage of all; by Prophets, by the marvelous Birth after the Flesh, by the power which was in the miracles, by the Spirit, through which He gave sanctification, by the Resurrection, whereby He put an end to the tyranny of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:117
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:118
verses.text: "By Whom we have received grace and Apostleship for obedience to the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:119
verses.text: See the candor of the servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:120
verses.text: He wishes nothing to be his own, but all his Master's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:121
verses.text: And indeed it was the Spirit that gave this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:122
verses.text: Wherefore He saith, "I have many things to say unto you, but ye cannot bear them now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:123
verses.text: Howbeit when He, the Spirit of Truth, is come, He will guide you into all truth" (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:124
verses.text: ): and again, "Separate Me Paul and Barnabas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:125
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:126
verses.text: ) And in the Epistle to the Corinthians, he says, that "to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, to another the word of knowledge" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:127
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:128
verses.text: , ); and that It divideth all as It willeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:129
verses.text: And in addressing the Milesians, he says, "Over which the Holy Ghost hath made you shepherds and overseers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:130
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:131
verses.text: ) You see, he calls the things of the Spirit, the Son's, and the things of the Son, the Spirit's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:132
verses.text: "Grace and Apostleship;" that is, it is not we that have achieved for ourselves, that we should become Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:133
verses.text: For it was not by having toiled much and labored that we had this dignity allotted to us, but we received grace, and the successful result is a part of the heavenly gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:134
verses.text: "For obedience to the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:135
verses.text: So it was not the Apostles that achieved it, but grace that paved the way before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:136
verses.text: For it was their part to go about and preach, but to persuade was of God, Who wrought in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:137
verses.text: As also Luke saith, that "He opened their heart" (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:138
verses.text: ); and again, To whom it was given to hear the word of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:139
verses.text: "To obedience;" he says not, to questioning and parade (κατασκευὴν) of argument but "to obedience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:140
verses.text: For we were not sent, he means, to argue, but to give those things which we had trusted to our hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:141
verses.text: For when the Master declareth aught, they that hear should not be nice and curious handlers of what is told them, but receivers only; for this is why the Apostles were sent, to speak what they had heard, not to add aught from their own stock, and that we for our part should believe—that we should believe what?—"concerning His Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:142
verses.text: Not that we should be curious about the essence, but that we should believe on the Name; for this it was which also wrought the miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:143
verses.text: For it says, "in the Name of Jesus Christ rise up and walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:144
verses.text: (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:145
verses.text: ) And this too requireth faith, neither can one grasp aught of these things by reasoning (λογισμᾥ καταλαβεἵν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:146
verses.text: "Among all nations, among whom are ye also the called of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:147
verses.text: What? did Paul preach then to all the nations? Now that he ran through the whole space from Jerusalem to Illyricum, and from thence again went forth to the very ends of the earth, is plain from what he writes to the Romans; but even if he did not come to all, yet still what he says is not false, for he speaks not of himself alone, but of the twelve Apostles, and all who declared the word after them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:148
verses.text: And in another sense, one should not see any fault to find with the phrase, if about himself, when one considers his ready mind, and how that after death he ceaseth not to preach in all parts of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:149
verses.text: And consider how he extols the gift, and shows that it is great and much more lofty than the former, since the old things were with one nation, but this gift drew sea and land to itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:150
verses.text: And attend to this too, how free the mind of Paul is from all flattery; for when conversing with the Romans, who were seated as it were upon a sort of summit of the whole world, he attaches no more to them than to the other nations, nor does he on the score of their being then in power and ruling, say, that they have in spiritual things also any advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:151
verses.text: But as (he means) we preach to all the nations, so do we to you, numbering them with Scythians and Thracians: for if he did not wish to show this, it were superfluous to say "Among whom are ye also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:152
verses.text: And this he does to take down their high spirit (κενὥν τὸ φύσημα) and to prostrate the swelling vanity of their minds, and to teach them to honor others alike to themselves: and so he proceeds to speak upon this very point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:153
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:154
verses.text: "Among whom are ye also the called of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:155
verses.text: That is, along with whom ye also are: and he does not say, that he called the others with you, but you with the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:156
verses.text: For if in Christ Jesus there is neither bond nor free, much less is there king and private man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:157
verses.text: For even ye were called and did not come over of yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:158
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:159
verses.text: "To all that be in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:160
verses.text: See how continually he puts the word "called," saying, "called to be an Apostle; among whom ye also are called; to all that be in Rome, called:" and this he does not out of superfluity of words, but out of a wish to remind them of the benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:161
verses.text: For since among them which believed, it was likely that there would be some of the consuls (ὑπάτων; Ben.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:162
verses.text: consulares) and rulers as well as poor and common men, casting aside the inequality of ranks, he writes to them all under one appellation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:163
verses.text: But if in things which are more needful and which are spiritual, all things are set forth as common both to slaves and to free, for instance, the love from God, the calling, the Gospel, the adoption, the grace, the peace, the sanctification, all things else, how could it be other than the uttermost folly, whom God had joined together, and made to be of equal honor in the greater things, those to divide on account of things on earth? on this ground, I presume, from the very outstart, this blessed Apostle, after casting out this mischievous disease, conducts them to the mother of blessings, humble-mindedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:164
verses.text: This made servants better, since they learnt that they should take no harm from their servitude, while they had the true freedom; this would incline masters to be gentle, as being instructed that they have no advantage in being free, unless the goods of faith have the first place given them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:165
verses.text: And that you may learn that he was not doing this to work confusion, by dashing all things, but still knew the best distinction, he wrote not simply to all that were in Rome, but with a definition added, "beloved of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:166
verses.text: For this is the best discrimination, and shows whence the sanctification was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:167
verses.text: Whence then was the sanctification? from Love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:168
verses.text: For after saying, "beloved," then he proceeds, "called to be saints," showing that it is from this that the fount of all blessings is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:169
verses.text: But saints he calls all the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:170
verses.text: "Grace unto you and peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:171
verses.text: Oh address, that bringeth countless blessings to us! This also Christ bade the Apostles to use as their first word when entering into houses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:172
verses.text: (Luke x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:173
verses.text: ) Wherefore it is from this that Paul also in all places takes his beginning, from grace and peace; for it was no small war which Christ put an end to, but indeed one varying and of every kind and of a long season (τοικίλον καὶ ταντοδαπὸν); and this not from our labors, but through His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:174
verses.text: Since then love presented us with grace, and grace with peace, having set them down in the due order of an address, he prays over them that they may abide perpetual and unmoved, so that no other war may again be blown into flame, and beseeches Him that gave, to keep these things firmly settled, saying as follows, "Grace be unto you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:175
verses.text: See in this passage, the "from" is common to the Son and the Father, and this is equivalent to "of whom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:176
verses.text: For he did not say, Grace be unto you and peace from God the Father, "through" our Lord Jesus Christ; but, "from God the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:177
verses.text: Strange! how mighty is the love of God! we which were enemies and disgraced, have all at once become saints and sons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:178
verses.text: For when he calls Him Father, he shows them to be sons; and when he says sons, he has unveiled the whole treasure of blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:179
verses.text: Let us then keep showing a conversation worthy of the gift, and hold on in peace and holiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:180
verses.text: For other dignities are but for a time, and are brought to an end along with this life present, and may be bought with money (whence one might say they are not dignities at all but names of dignities only, having their strength in the investiture of fine array and the servility of attendants), but this as having been given of God, the gift of sanctification and adoption, is not broken through even by death, but even here maketh men conspicuous, and also departs with us upon our journey to the life to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:181
verses.text: For he that holdeth on in the adoption, and keeps an exact watch upon his holiness, is much brighter and more happy even than he that is arrayed with the diadem itself, and has the purple; and has the delight of abundant peace in the present life and is nurtured up with goodly hopes, and hath no ground for worry and disturbance, but enjoys constant pleasure; for as for good spirits and joy, it is not greatness of power, not abundance of wealth, not pomp of authority, not strength of body, not sumptuousness of the table, not the adorning of dresses, nor any other of the things in man's reach that ordinarily produces them, but spiritual success, and a good conscience alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:182
verses.text: And he that hath this cleansed, even though he be clad in rags and struggling with famine, is of better spirits than they that live so softly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:183
verses.text: So too he that is conscious of wicked deeds, even though he may gather to himself all men's goods, is the most wretched of all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:184
verses.text: For this cause Paul, living in continual hunger and nakedness, and being scourged every day was joyful, and went more softly than they that were then emperors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:185
verses.text: But Ahab though a king, and indulging in a sumptuous luxury, when he had done that one sin, groaned and was out of spirits, and his countenance was fallen both before the sin and after the sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:186
verses.text: If then we wish to enjoy pleasure, above all things else let us shun wickedness, and follow after virtue; since it is not in the nature of things for one to have a share thereof on any other terms, even if we were mounted upon the king's throne itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:187
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul saith, "But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:188
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:189
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 2:190
verses.text: ) This fruit then let us keep growing by us, that we may be in the fruition of joy here, and may obtain the kingdom to come, by the grace and love towards man of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom and with Whom, be glory to the Father, and to the Holy Spirit, now and always, even unto all ages, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:4
verses.text: "First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:5
verses.text: An exordium worthy of this blessed spirit, and able to teach all men to offer unto God the firstlings of their good deeds and words, and to render thanks not only for their own, but also for others' well-doings: which also maketh the soul pure from envy and grudging, and draweth God in a greater measure towards the loving spirit of them that so render thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:6
verses.text: Wherefore also elsewhere he says, "Blessed be God and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, Who hath blessed us with all spiritual blessing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:7
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:8
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:9
verses.text: ) And it is fitting that we render thanks not only when rich, but also when poor, not when in health only, but also when sick, not when we thrive only, but also when we have to bear the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:10
verses.text: For when our affairs are borne onward with a fair wind, to be thankful is not matter of wonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:11
verses.text: But when no small tempests be upon us, and the vessel veers about and is in jeopardy, then is the great time for displaying patience and goodness of heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:12
verses.text: For this cause Job also gained a crown from hence, and the shameless mouth of the devil did he stop, and show clearly that not even when he saw good days was it through his wealth that he was thankful, but through his much love toward God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:13
verses.text: And see too what things he is thankful for: not for things earthly and perishing, as power and authority and glory (for these things are of no account), but for real blessings, faith and boldness of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:14
verses.text: And with how much feeling he gives thanks: for he saith not "to God," but "to my God," which also the Prophets do, so making that which is common to all their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:15
verses.text: And what is there wonderful in the Prophets doing so? For God himself plainly does it continually to His servants, calling Himself the God of Abraham and Isaac and Jacob, as peculiarly theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:16
verses.text: "That your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:17
verses.text: What then, had the whole world heard of the faith of the Romans? Yes, the whole, according to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:18
verses.text: (Or, since that time, πἅσα ἐξ ἐκείνου).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:19
verses.text: And it is not a thing unlikely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:20
verses.text: For the city was not one of no note, but as being upon a sort of eminence it was on every account conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:21
verses.text: But consider, I pray, the power of the preaching, how in a short time by means of publicans and fishermen it took hold upon the very head of all cities, and Syrians became the teachers and guides of Romans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:22
verses.text: He attests then two excellencies in them, both that they believed, and that they believed with boldness, and that so great as that the fame of them reached into all the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:23
verses.text: "For your faith," he says "is spoken of throughout the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:24
verses.text: Your faith," not your verbal disputations, nor your questionings, nor your syllogisms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:25
verses.text: And yet there were there many hindrances to the teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:26
verses.text: For having recently acquired the empire of the world they were elated, and lived in riches and luxury, and fishermen brought the preaching there, and they Jews and of the Jews, a nation hated and had in abomination among all men; and they were bidden to worship the Crucified, Who was brought up in Judea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:27
verses.text: And with the doctrine the teachers proclaimed also an austere life to men who were practised in softness, and were agitated about things present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:28
verses.text: And they that proclaimed it were poor and common men, of no family, and born of men of no family.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:29
verses.text: But none of these things hindered the course of the word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:30
verses.text: So great was the power of the Crucified as to carry the word round everywhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:31
verses.text: "For it is spoken of," he says, "in all the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:32
verses.text: He says not, it is manifested, but, is spoken of, as if all men had them in their mouths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:33
verses.text: And indeed when he bears witness of this in the Thessalonians, he adds another thing also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:34
verses.text: For after saying, "from you sounded out the word of God," he adds, "so that we need not to speak anything".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:35
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:36
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:37
verses.text: ) For the disciples had come into the place of teachers, by their boldness of speech instructing all, and drawing them to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:38
verses.text: For the preaching came not anywhere to a stand, but went over the whole world more rapidly than fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:39
verses.text: But here there is only thus much—"it is spoken of".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:40
verses.text: He well says that "it is spoken of," showing that there was no need to add aught to what was said, or to take away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:41
verses.text: For a messenger's business is this, to convey from one to another only what is told him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:42
verses.text: For which cause also the priest is called a "messenger" (Mal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:43
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:44
verses.text: ), because he speaks not his own words, but those of Him that sent him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:45
verses.text: And yet Peter had preached there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:46
verses.text: But he reckons what was his, to be his own as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:47
verses.text: In such degree, as I said before, was he beyond measure clear of all grudging!  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:48
verses.text: "For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the Gospel of His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:49
verses.text: Words these of an Apostle's bowels of affection, the showing forth this of fatherly concernment! And what is it which he says, and why does he call God to witness? He had to declare his feeling toward them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:50
verses.text: Since then he had not as yet ever seen them, he therefore called no man to witness, but Him Who entereth in the hearts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:51
verses.text: For since he was saying, "I love you," and as a token thereof alleged his praying continually for them, and wishing to come to them, and neither was this self-evident, he betakes himself to the trustworthy testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:52
verses.text: Will then any one of you be able to boast that he remembers, when praying at his house (ἐπὶ τἥς οἰκίας) the entire body of the Church? I think not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:53
verses.text: But Paul drew near to God in behalf not of one city only, but of the whole world, and this not once, or twice, or thrice, but continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:54
verses.text: But if the continually bearing any one about in one's memory would not happen without much love; to have any in one's prayers, and to have them there continually, think what great affection and friendship that implies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:55
verses.text: But when he says, "Whom I serve with my spirit in the Gospel of His Son," he shows us at once the grace of God, and also his own humble-mindedness; the grace of God because He entrusted to him so great a matter; but his own humility, because he imputes it all not to his own zeal, but to the assistance of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:56
verses.text: But the addition of "the Gospel," shows the kind of ministry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:57
verses.text: For there are many and diverse modes of service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:58
verses.text: And as under kings all are ranged under one that beareth kingly power, and all have not to minister (διακονοὕνται) about the same thing, but to one belongeth the ministry of ruling armies and to another that of ordering cities and to another again that of keeping treasures in the storehouses, thus also in spiritual things, one serveth God and laboreth (λατρεύει καὶδουλεύει) in believing and ordering his own life well, and another in undertaking the care of strangers, and another in taking in hand the patronship of them that be in need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:59
verses.text: As even during the Apostle's own time, they of Stephen's company served God in the guardianship of the widows, others (ἄλλοι mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:60
verses.text: , all ὡν) in the teaching of the word, of whom also Paul was serving in the preaching of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:61
verses.text: And this was the fashion of his service: for it was to this that he was appointed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:62
verses.text: On this account, he not only calls God to witness, but also says what he was entrusted with, to show that having so great things put into his hands, he would not have called Him Who trusted them to him to witness what was false.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:63
verses.text: And therewith he wished to make another point out also, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:64
verses.text: that he could not but have this love and care for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:65
verses.text: For that they might not say "who art thou? and, from whence? that thou sayest that thou art anxious over a city so great, and most imperial," he shows that he must needs have this care, if at least the sort of service that was committed to him, was to declare the Gospel: for he that hath this put into his hands, must needs have continually upon his mind them that are to receive the word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:66
verses.text: And he shows another thing besides this by saying, "in my spirit;" that this service is much higher than either the Gentile or the Jewish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:67
verses.text: For the Gentile is both fleshly and in error, and the Jewish is true indeed, yet even this is fleshly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:68
verses.text: But that of the Church is the opposite of the Gentile, but more lofty than the Jewish by a great deal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:69
verses.text: For the mode of our service is not with sheep and oxen and smoke and fat, but by a spiritual soul, which Christ also shows in saying that "God is a Spirit, and they that worship Him must worship Him in spirit and in truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:70
verses.text: (John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:71
verses.text: )  "In the Gospel of His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:72
verses.text: Having said above that it was the Father's Gospel, here he says it is the Son's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:73
verses.text: So indifferent is it to say the Father's or the Son's! For he had learnt from that blessed voice that the things of the Father are the Son's, and the things of the Son are the Father's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:74
verses.text: For "all Mine are Thine, and Thine are Mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:75
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:76
verses.text: )  "That without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:77
verses.text: This is the part of genuine love, and he seems indeed to be saying some one thing, yet states four things even here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:78
verses.text: Both that he remembers, and that he does so continually, and that it is in his prayers, and that it is to ask great things for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:79
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:80
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:81
verses.text: "Making request, if by any means now at length I might have a prosperous journey by the will of God to come unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:82
verses.text: You see him painfully desiring to see them, and yet not enduring to see them contrary to what seemed good unto God, but having his longing mingled with the fear of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:83
verses.text: For he loved them, and was eager to come to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:84
verses.text: Yet he did not, because he loved them, desire to see them, contrary to what seemed good unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:85
verses.text: This is true love, not as we love who err on both sides from the laws of love: for either we love no one, or if we ever do love, we love contrary to what seemeth good unto God, acting in both against the Divine law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:86
verses.text: And if these things be grievous (φορτικὰ) when spoken of, they are more grievous when done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:87
verses.text: And how do we love contrary to what seems good to God? (you will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:88
verses.text: ) When we neglect Christ pining with hunger, and provide our children and friends and relations above their needs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:89
verses.text: Or rather what need to carry the subject further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:90
verses.text: For if any one will examine his own conscience, he will find that this takes place in many things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:91
verses.text: But such was not that blessed person, but he knew both how to love and to love as he ought ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:92
verses.text: omit "as he ought"), and as was fitting, and though exceeding all men in loving, he transgressed not the measures of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:93
verses.text: See then two things thrive extremely in him, fear of God, and also longing towards the Romans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:94
verses.text: For to be praying continually, and not to desist when he obtained not, shows exceeding love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:95
verses.text: But while loving, thus to continue yielding to the will of God, shows intense reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:96
verses.text: In another place, however, having "thrice besought the Lord" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:97
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:98
verses.text: ), he not only did not receive, but on the contrary, when he did not receive, he was very thankful for not having been heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:99
verses.text: So, in all things did he look to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:100
verses.text: But here he received, though not when he asked, but after delay, and neither hereat was he discontented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:101
verses.text: And these things I mention that we may not repine at not being heard, or at being heard slowly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:102
verses.text: For we are not better than Paul, who confesses his thankfulness for both, and with good ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:103
verses.text: For when he had once given himself up to the all-governing Hand, and put himself with as much subjection under it, as clay under the potter, he followed wheresoever God led.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:104
verses.text: Having then said that he desired to see them, he mentioned also the cause of his desire; and what is it?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:105
verses.text: "That I may impart unto you some spiritual gift, to the end ye may be established".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:106
verses.text: For it was not merely as many now go travelling in a needless and profitless way that he also went, but for necessary and very urgent ends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:107
verses.text: And he does not tell them his meaning openly, but by way of hints, for he does not say that I may teach you, that I may instruct you, that I may fill up that which is wanting; but, "that I may impart;" showing, that it is not his own things which he is giving them, but that he was imparting to them what he had received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:108
verses.text: And here again he is unassuming, in saying "some," he means, a small one, and suited to my powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:109
verses.text: And what may this small one be which thou art now going to impart? This it is, he says, "to the end that ye may be established".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:110
verses.text: This then also cometh of grace, namely, the being unwavering and standing fast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:111
verses.text: But when you hear of grace, think not that the reward of resolve on our part is thereby cast aside; for he speaks of grace, not to disparage the labor of resolve on our part, but to undermine (ὑποτεμνόμενος, as piercing a thing inflated) the haughtiness of an insolent spirit (ἀπονοίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:112
verses.text: Do not thou then, because that Paul hath called this a gift of grace, grow supine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:113
verses.text: For he knows how, in his great candor, to call even well doings, graces; because even in these we need much influence from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:114
verses.text: But in saying, "to the end that ye may be established," he covertly shows that they needed much correction: for what he would say is this: Of a "long time I have both desired" and prayed to see you, for no other reason than that I may "stablish, strengthen, fix" you thoroughly in the word of God, so that ye be not continually wavering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:115
verses.text: But he does not express himself so (for he would have shocked them), but in another way he hints to them the same thing, though in a subdued tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:116
verses.text: For when he says, "to the end that ye may be established," he makes this plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:117
verses.text: Then since this also was very irksome, see how he softens it by the sequel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:118
verses.text: For that they may not say, are we wavering, and carried about? and need we speech of yours in order to stand fast? he anticipates and does away any gainsaying of the kind, by saying as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:119
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:120
verses.text: "That is, that I may be comforted together with you by the mutual faith both of you and me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:121
verses.text: As if he said, Do not suspect that I spoke to accuse you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:122
verses.text: It was not with this feeling that I said what I did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:123
verses.text: But what may it be that I wished to say? Ye are undergoing many tribulations, being drenched on every side (by those who persecute you περιαντλούμενοι.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:124
verses.text: mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:125
verses.text: παρενοχλούμενοι, harassed).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:126
verses.text: I desired then to see you, that I might comfort you, or rather, not that I might comfort you only, but that I might myself receive comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:127
verses.text: See the wisdom of the teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:128
verses.text: He said, to the end that "ye may be strengthened;" he knew that what he had said would be heavy and irksome to the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:129
verses.text: He says, "to the end that ye may be comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:130
verses.text: But this again is heavy, not indeed to such a degree as the former, still it is heavy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:131
verses.text: He then pares down what is galling in this also, smoothing his speech on every side, and rendering it easy of acceptance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:132
verses.text: For he does not say barely, "to be comforted," but, "to be comforted together with you;" nor was he content with this but he puts in a further lenitive, when he says, "by the mutual faith both of you and me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:133
verses.text: Oh how great was his humble-mindedness! He showed himself also to be in need of them, and not them only of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:134
verses.text: And he puts the disciples in the position of teachers, not letting any superiority remain upon his own side, but pointing out their full equality.
