verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:135
verses.text: For the gain is mutual, he means, and I need the comfort from you, and you that from me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:136
verses.text: And how comes this to pass? "Through the mutual faith both of you and me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:137
verses.text: For as in the case of fire, if any one gather together many lights, it is a bright flame that he kindles, thus also does it naturally happen with the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:138
verses.text: For when we be by ourselves, torn away from others, we are somehow in worse spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:139
verses.text: But when we see one another, and are entwined with the members of our own selves, great is the comfort we receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:140
verses.text: You must not look to the present time, during which, by God's grace, both in city and in the desert itself, there be many hosts of believers, and all impiety hath been driven out; but consider, in that time, how great a good it was both for disciples to see their master, and for brethren who had come from another city to be seen of brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:141
verses.text: But that I may make what I am saying plainer, let me bring the matter to an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:142
verses.text: For if it should even happen and come to pass (may it never do so!) that we had been carried away to the land of the Persians or Scythians or other barbarians, and had been scattered ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:143
verses.text: "torn asunder") by twos and threes in their cities, and were then suddenly to see any one of those here coming to us, reflect what a harvest of comfort we should reap of it! See ye not those too who are in the prisons, it they see any of their acquaintance, how they revive, and are quite fluttering with the pleasure? But if I compare those days with captivity and imprisonment, count it no wonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:144
verses.text: For these suffered far harder things than those, scattered as they were, and driven about, and dwelling in the midst of famine and of wars, and tremblingly expecting daily death, and suspecting friends and kindred and relatives, and dwelling in the world as in a strange land, aye, and in far harder plight than they who live in another's country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:145
verses.text: This is why he says, "to the end that ye may be established and comforted with us by our mutual faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:146
verses.text: And this he says, not as though himself needed any assistance from them (far from it; for how should the pillar of the Church, who was stronger than iron and the rock, the spiritual adamant, who was equal to the charge of countless cities), but that he should not make his language impetuous and his reproof vehement, he says, that he himself also needs their consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:147
verses.text: But if any one here should say, that the comfort was his gladness at the increase of their faith, and that Paul needed this, he would not be mistaking his meaning in this way either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:148
verses.text: If then thou desire, one might say, and pray, and wilt gain comfort and give comfort by it, what is there to hinder thy coming? By way of dissipating this suspicion then, he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:149
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:150
verses.text: "Now I would not have you ignorant, brethren, that oftentimes I desired to come unto you (but was let hitherto)".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:151
verses.text: Here is a compliance great as that of slaves, and a plain exhibition of his excellent temper (εὐγνωμοσύνης)! For, that he was let, he says, but why, he does not go on to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:152
verses.text: For he does not pry into the command of his Master, but only obeys.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:153
verses.text: And yet one might expect a person to start questions, as to why God hindered a city so conspicuous and great, and towards which the whole world was looking, from enjoying such a teacher, and that for so long a time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:154
verses.text: For he that had overcome the governing city, could easily go on to the subjects of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:155
verses.text: But he that let alone the more royal one, and lay in wait about the dependents, had the main point left neglected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:156
verses.text: But none of these things does he busy himself with, but yields to the incomprehensibleness of Providence, thereby both showing the right tone of his soul, and instructing us all never to call God to account for what happens, even though what is done seem to trouble the minds of many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:157
verses.text: For the Master's part it is alone to enjoin, the servants' to obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:158
verses.text: And this is why he says, that he was let, but not for what cause; for he means, even I do not know; ask not then of me the counsel or mind of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:159
verses.text: For neither "shall the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus?" For why, tell me, do you even seek to learn it? do you not know that all things are under His care, that He is wise, that He doeth nothing at a mere hazard, that He loveth thee more than they who begat thee, and goes exceeding far beyond a father's yearnings of affection to thee, and a mother's anxiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:160
verses.text: Seek then no more, and go not a step further; for this is sufficient consolation for thee: since even then it was well ordered for the Romans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:161
verses.text: And if thou knowest not the manner, take it not to heart: for this is a main feature of faith, even when in ignorance of the manner of the dispensation, to receive what is told us of His Providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:162
verses.text: Paul then having succeeded in what he was earnest about (and what was this? to show that it was not as slighting them that he did not come to them, but because, though greatly desiring it, he was hindered), and having divested himself of the accusation of remissness, and having persuaded them that he was not less desirous to see them than themselves, further shows his love to them by other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:163
verses.text: For even when I was hindered he means, I did not stand aloof from the attempt, but I kept attempting always yet was always hindered, yet never did I stand aloof thus, without falling out with the will of God, still keeping my love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:164
verses.text: For by his purposing it to himself and not standing aloof from it, he showed his affection; but through his being hindered and yet not struggling against it, all his love to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:165
verses.text: "That I might have some fruit among you also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:166
verses.text: Yet he had told them the cause of his longing before, and shown that it was becoming him; but still here also, he states it, clearing away all their suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:167
verses.text: For since the city was conspicuous, and in the whole extent of sea and land had no equal to many even the mere desire of becoming acquainted with it became a reason (πρόφασις) for a journey to it; that they might not think anything of the sort about Paul, or suspect that, merely with a view to glory in claiming them to himself he desired to be present there, he repeatedly lays down the ground of his desire, and before he says, it was that "I may impart to you some spiritual gift," that I desired to see you; but here more clearly, "that I might have some fruit among you also even as among other Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:168
verses.text: The rulers he puts with the subjects, and after the countless triumphs and victories and the glory of the consuls, he puts them with the barbarians, and with good reason too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:169
verses.text: For where the nobility of faith is, there is none barbarian, none Grecian, none stranger, none citizen, but all mount up to one height of dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:170
verses.text: And see him here also unassuming, for he does not say, that I may teach and instruct, but what? "that I might have some fruit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:171
verses.text: And not fruit, simply, but "some fruit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:172
verses.text: Again, depreciating his own share therein just as he had said above, "that I may impart some gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:173
verses.text: And then to repress them too, as I said also before, he says, "even as among other Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:174
verses.text: For, I do not, because you are rich, and have the advantage of others, show less concern about the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:175
verses.text: For it is not the rich that we are seeking, but the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:176
verses.text: Where now are the wise of the Greeks, they that wear long beards and that are clad in open dress, and puff forth great words (τὰ μεγάλα φυσὥντες)? All Greece and all barbarian lands has the tentmaker converted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:177
verses.text: But Plato, who is so cried up and carried about among them, coming a third time to Sicily with the bombast of those words of his, with his brilliant reputation (ὑπσλήψεως), did not even get the better of a single king, but came off so wretchedly, as even to have lost his liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:178
verses.text: But this tentmaker ran over not Sicily alone or Italy, but the whole world; and while preaching too he desisted not from his art, but even then sewed skins, and superintended the workshop.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:179
verses.text: And even this did not give offence to those who were born of consuls, and with very good reason, for it is not their trades and occupations, but falsehood and forged doctrines, which usually render teachers easy subjects of contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:180
verses.text: And for this reason, even Athenians still laugh at the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:181
verses.text: But this man even barbarians attend to, and even foolish and ignorant men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:182
verses.text: For his preaching is set forth to all alike, it knows no distinction of rank, no preëminence of nation, no other thing of the sort; for faith alone does it require, and not reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:183
verses.text: Wherefore it is most worthy of admiration, not only because it is profitable and saving, but that it is readily admissible and easy (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:184
verses.text: "lovable"), and comprehensible to all: which is a main object in the Providence of God, who setteth forth His blessings to all in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:185
verses.text: For what He did in respect of the sun and the moon and the earth and the sea and other things, not giving the rich and the wise a greater share of the benefits of these, and a less to the poor, but setting forth the enjoyment of them to all alike, this also did He with regard to the preaching, and even in a much greater degree, by how much this is more indispensable than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:186
verses.text: Wherefore Paul repeatedly says, "among all the Gentiles," to show that he in no respect favors them, but is fulfilling his Master's command, and sending them away to thanksgiving to the God of all, he says;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:187
verses.text: "I am a debtor to the Greeks and to the Barbarians, both to the wise and to the unwise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:188
verses.text: Which also he said when writing to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:189
verses.text: And he says it, to ascribe the whole to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:190
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:191
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:192
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:193
verses.text: "So, as much as in me is, I am ready to preach the Gospel to you that are at Rome also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:194
verses.text: Oh, noble soul! having taken on him a task laden of so great dangers, a voyage across the sea, temptations, plottings, risings—for it was likely, that one who was going to address so great a city which was under the tyrannic sway of impiety, should undergo temptations thick as snowflakes; and it was in this way that he lost his life in this city, being cut off by the tyrant of it—yet still expecting to undergo so great troubles, for none of these did he become less energetic, but was in haste and was in travail and was ready-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:195
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "So, as much as in me is, I am ready to preach the Gospel to you that are at Rome also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:196
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:197
verses.text: "For I am not ashamed of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:198
verses.text: "What sayest thou, O, Paul? When it were fitting to say, that I boast, and am proud, and luxuriate in it; thou sayest not this, but what is less than this, that thou art "not ashamed," which is not what we usually say of things very glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:199
verses.text: What then is this which he says, and why does he thus speak? while yet he exults over it more than over heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:200
verses.text: At least, in writing to the Galatians, he said, "God forbid that I should glory, save in the Cross of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:201
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:202
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:203
verses.text: ) How then comes he here to say, not that I even glory, but that "I am not ashamed?" The Romans were most anxiously eager about the things of the world, owing to their riches, their empire, their victories; and their kings they reckoned to be equal to the gods, and so they even called them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:204
verses.text: And for this cause too, they worshipped them with temples and with altars and with sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:205
verses.text: Since then they were thus puffed up, but Paul was going to preach Jesus, who was thought to be the carpenter's son, who was brought up in Judea, and that in the house of a mean woman, who had no body guards, who was not encircled in wealth, but even died as a culprit with robbers, and endured many other inglorious things; and it was likely that they were concealing themselves as not as yet knowing any of the unspeakable and great things: for this reason he says, "I am not ashamed," having still to teach them not to be ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:206
verses.text: For he knew that if they succeeded in this, they would speedily go on and come to glorying also: and do you then, if you hear any one saying, Dost thou worship the Crucified? be not ashamed, and do not look down, but luxuriate in it, be bright-faced at it, and with the eyes of a free man, and with uplifted look, take up your confession; and if he say again, Dost thou worship the Crucified? say in reply to him, Yes! and not the adulterer, not the insulter of his father, not the murderer of his children (for such be all the gods they have), but Him who by the Cross stopped the mouths of devils, and did away with their countless juggleries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:207
verses.text: For the Cross is for our sakes, being the work of unspeakable Love towards man, the sign of His great concern for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:208
verses.text: And in addition to what has been said, since they were puffed up with great pomposity of speech and with their cloak of external wisdom, I, he means to say, bidding an entire farewell to these reasonings, come to preach the Cross, and am not ashamed because of it: "for it is the power of God to salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:209
verses.text: For since there is a power of God to chastisement also (for when He chastised the Egyptians, He said, "This is My great power,") (Joel ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:210
verses.text: ) and a power to destruction, (for, "fear Him," He says, "that is able to destroy both body and soul in hell"), (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:211
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:212
verses.text: ) for this cause he says, it is not these that I come to bring, the powers of chastisement and punishment, but those of salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:213
verses.text: What then? Did not the Gospel tell of these things also, namely, the account of hell, and that of the outer darkness, and of the venomous worm? And yet we know of these from no other source than the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:214
verses.text: In what sense then does he say, "the power of God unto salvation?" Attend only to what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:215
verses.text: "To every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:216
verses.text: For it is not to all absolutely, but to them that receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:217
verses.text: For though thou be a Grecian (i-e: Heathen), and even one that has run into every kind of vice, though a Scythian, though a barbarian, though a very brute, and full of all irrationality, and burdened with the weights of endless sins, no sooner hast thou received the word concerning the Cross, and been baptized, than thou hast blotted out all these; and why says he here, "to the Jew first, and also to the Greek?" What meaneth this difference? and yet he has often said, "Neither circumcision is anything, nor uncircumcision" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:218
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:219
verses.text: See Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:220
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:221
verses.text: and vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:222
verses.text: ); how then doth he here discriminate, setting the Jew before the Greek? Now why is this? seeing that by being first he does not therefore receive any more of the grace (for the same gift is bestowed both on this person and that,) but the "first" is an honor in order of time only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:223
verses.text: For he has no such advantage as that of receiving greater righteousness, but is only honored in respect of his receiving it first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:224
verses.text: Since in the case of those that are enlightened (you that are initiated know what is meant,) all run to the baptism, yet not all at the same hour, but one first and another second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:225
verses.text: Yet the first doth not receive more than the second, nor he than the person after him, but all enjoy the same gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:226
verses.text: The "first" then here is an honor in word, not a superiority in grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:227
verses.text: Then after saying, "unto salvation," he enhances the gift further, by showing that it stayeth not at the present point, but proceedeth farther.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:228
verses.text: For this is what he sets forth, when he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:229
verses.text: "For therein is the righteousness of God revealed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:230
verses.text: But he who hath become just shall live, not for the present life only, but for that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:231
verses.text: And he hints not only this, but also another thing along with this, namely, the brightness and gloriousness of such a life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:232
verses.text: For since it is possible to be saved, yet not without shame (as many are saved of those, who by the royal humanity are released from punishment), that no one may suspect this upon hearing of safety, he adds also righteousness; and righteousness, not thine own, but that of God; hinting also the abundance of it and the facility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:233
verses.text: For you do not achieve it by toilings and labors, but you receive it by a gift from above, contributing one thing only from your own store, "believing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:234
verses.text: Then since his statement did not seem credible, if the adulterer and effeminate person, and robber of graves, and magician, is not only to be suddenly freed from punishment but to become just, and just too with the highest righteousness; he confirms his assertion from the Old Testament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:235
verses.text: And first with a short sentence, he lays open a vast sea of histories to one who has a capacity for seeing them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:236
verses.text: For after having said, "from faith to faith," he sends the hearer back to the dispensations of God, which took place thus in the Old Testament, which, when writing to the Hebrews, he explains with his usual great wisdom, showing that both the just and the sinners were justified in that way even then, wherefore also he made mention both of the harlot and of Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:237
verses.text: But then here, after having just hinted at it (for he was running on to another and a pressing subject), he again confirms what he had said from the Prophets, bringing in Habakkuk before them, crying, and saying, that it is not in the nature of things for him who is to live, to live otherwise save by faith; for "the just," he says, "shall live by faith" (Hab.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:238
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:239
verses.text: ), speaking about the life to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:240
verses.text: For since what God giveth transcends reasoning entirely, it is but reason that we need faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:241
verses.text: But the man that thinks meanly of it, and is contemptuous and vainglorious, will not effect anything at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:242
verses.text: Let heretics hearken to the voice of the Spirit, for such is the nature of reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:243
verses.text: They are like some labyrinth or puzzles which have no end to them anywhere, and do not let the reason stand upon the rock, and have their very origin in vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:244
verses.text: For being ashamed to allow of faith, and to seem ignorant of heavenly things, they involve themselves in the dust-cloud of countless reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:245
verses.text: Then oh miserable and painful man, fit object for endless tears, should any one ask thee, how the heaven was made, and how the earth,—and why do I say the heaven and the earth? how thou wert thyself born, how nourished, and how thou grewest, art thou then not ashamed of thine ignorance? But if anything be said about the Only-begotten, dost thou thrust thyself through shame into a pit of destruction, thinking that it is unworthy of thee not to know everything? And yet disputatiousness is an unworthy thing, and so is ill-timed curiosity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:246
verses.text: And why do I speak of doctrines? for even from the corruption in our present life we have escaped by no other means than through the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:247
verses.text: Thus shone also all those aforetime, thus Abraham, thus Isaac, thus Jacob, thus too the harlot was saved, the one in the Old Testament, and likewise the one in the New.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:248
verses.text: For, "by faith," he says, "the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not when she had received the spies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:249
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:250
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:251
verses.text: ) For if she had said to herself, "and how can they that are captives and exiles, and refugees, and live the life of vagabond tribes, get the better of us who have a city, and walls, and towers?" she would have destroyed both herself and them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:252
verses.text: Which also the forefathers of those who were then saved did suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:253
verses.text: For when, upon the sight of men great and tall, they questioned the manner of victory, they perished, without battle or array, all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:254
verses.text: Seest thou what a pit is that of unbelief! what a wall that of faith! For the one carried down endless thousands, the other not only saved a harlot, but made her the patroness of so numerous a people!  Now since we know of these and more than these, never let us call God to account for what is done, but whatsoever He may lay on us, that let us take up with, and let us not run into niceties and curious questions, though to human reasoning the thing commanded appears even amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:255
verses.text: For what, let me ask, looks more amiss than for a father to slay with his own hands his only and legitimate son? (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:256
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:257
verses.text: ) But still when the righteous man was bid do it, he raised no nice scruples about it, but owing to the dignity of the bidder, he merely accepted the injunction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:258
verses.text: And another too that was bidden of God to strike a prophet, when he raised nice scruples about the seeming unreasonableness of the injunction, and did not simply obey, he was punished to the extreme.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:259
verses.text: ( Kings xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:260
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:261
verses.text: ) But he that struck, gained a good report.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:262
verses.text: And Saul too, when he saved men contrary to the decree of God, fell from the kingdom, and was irretrievably punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:263
verses.text: And one might find other instances beside these: by all which we learn, never to require a reason for God's injunctions, but to yield and obey only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 3:264
verses.text: But if it be dangerous to raise nice scruples about aught that He may enjoin, and extreme punishment is appointed for those who are curious questioners, what possible excuse shall they have who curiously question things far more secret and awful than these, as for instance, how He begat the Son, and in what fashion, and what His Essence is? Now as we know this, let us with all kindliness receive the mother of all blessings, faith; that sailing as it were in a still harbor, we may at once keep our doctrines orthodox, and by steering our life safely in a straight course, may attain those eternal blessings by the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom and with Whom be glory unto the Father, with the Holy Ghost, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:4
verses.text: "For the wrath of God is revealed from Heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who hold down the truth in unrighteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:5
verses.text: Observe the discretion of Paul, how after encouraging by the gentler things, he turns his discourse to the more fearful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:6
verses.text: For after saying that the Gospel is the cause of salvation and of life, that it is the power of God, that it gendereth salvation and righteousness, he mentions what might well make them fear that were heedless of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:7
verses.text: For since in general most men are not drawn so much by the promise of what is good as by the fear of what is painful, he draws them on both sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:8
verses.text: For this cause too did God not only promise a kingdom, but also threaten hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:9
verses.text: And the Prophets spake thus with the Jews, ever intermingling the evil with the good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:10
verses.text: For this cause too Paul thus varies his discourse, yet not any how, but he sets first the good things, and after the evil, to show that the former came of the guiding purpose of God, but the latter of the wickedness of the backsliding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:11
verses.text: And in this way the prophet puts the good first, saying, "If ye be willing and will obey me, ye shall eat the good of the land: but if ye be not willing and will not obey me, the sword shall devour you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:12
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:13
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:14
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:15
verses.text: ) So here too does Paul conduct his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:16
verses.text: But observe him; Christ, he means, came to bring forgiveness, righteousness, life, yet not in any way, but by the Cross, which is greatest too and wonderful, that He not only gave such things, but that He also suffered such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:17
verses.text: If then ye insolently scorn the gifts, then will the penalties await you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:18
verses.text: And see how he raises his language, "For the wrath of God," he says, "is revealed from heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:19
verses.text: Whence does this appear? If it be a believer who says this, we will tell him of the declarations of Christ, but if the unbeliever and the Grecian, him Paul silences, by what he says presently of the judgment of God, bringing an uncontrovertible demonstration from the things which were done by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:20
verses.text: And this too is by far the most striking point in him, how he exhibits those who speak against the truth, as themselves bearing witness by the things which they do daily, and say, to the doctrines of the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:21
verses.text: But of this in the sequel: but for the present, let us keep to what is set before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:22
verses.text: "For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:23
verses.text: And indeed even here this often takes place in famines and pestilences and wars: for each individually and all in common are punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:24
verses.text: What will be the new thing then? That the chastisement will be greater, and common to all, and not by the same rules.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:25
verses.text: For now what takes place is for correction; but then for vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:26
verses.text: And this also St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:27
verses.text: Paul showed, when he said, "We are chastened now, that we should not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:28
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:29
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:30
verses.text: ) And now indeed to many such things usually seem to come not of the wrath from above, but of the malice of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:31
verses.text: But then the punishment from God shall be manifest, when the Judge, sitting upon the fearful tribunal, shall command some to be dragged to the furnaces, and some to the outer darkness, and some to other inexorable and intolerable punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:32
verses.text: And why is it that he does not speak as plainly as this, the Son of God is coming with ten thousand angels, and will call each man to account, but says, that "the wrath of God is revealed?" His hearers were as yet novices, and therefore he draws them first by things quite allowed by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:33
verses.text: And besides what is here mentioned, he also seems to me to be aiming against the Greeks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:34
verses.text: And this is why he makes his beginning from this, but afterwards he introduces the subject of Christ's judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:35
verses.text: "Against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who hold the truth in unrighteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:36
verses.text: Here he showeth that the ways of ungodliness are many, and that of truth, one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:37
verses.text: For error is a thing various and multiform and compound, but the truth is one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:38
verses.text: And after speaking of doctrines he speaks of life, mentioning the unrighteousness of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:39
verses.text: For there be various kinds of unrighteousness also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:40
verses.text: One is in money affairs, as when any one deals unrighteously by his neighbor in these; and another in regard to women, when a man leaves his own wife, and breaks in upon the marriage of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:41
verses.text: For St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:42
verses.text: Paul calls this also defrauding, saying thus, "That no man go beyond or defraud his brother in the matter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:43
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:44
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:45
verses.text: ) Others again injure not the wife or property, but the reputation of their neighbor, and this too is unrighteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:46
verses.text: For "a good name is better than great riches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:47
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:48
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:49
verses.text: ) But some say that this also is said of Paul about doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:50
verses.text: Still there is nothing to prevent its having been said of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:51
verses.text: But what it is "to hold the truth in unrighteousness," learn from the sequel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:52
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:53
verses.text: "Because that which may be known of God is manifest in them, for God hath showed it unto them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:54
verses.text: But this glory they invested stocks and stones with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:55
verses.text: As then he which is entrusted with the goods of the king, and is ordered to spend them upon the king's glory, if he waste these upon robbers, and harlots, and witches, and make these splendid out of the king's stores, he is punished as having done the kingdom the greatest wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:56
verses.text: Thus they also who after having received the knowledge of God and of His glory, invested idols therewith, "held the truth in unrighteousness," and, at least as far as was in their power, dealt unrighteously by the knowledge, by not using it upon fitting objects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:57
verses.text: Now, has what was said become clear to you, or must one make it still clearer? Perhaps it were needful to say somewhat more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:58
verses.text: What then is it which is here said? The knowledge of Himself God placed in men from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:59
verses.text: But this knowledge they invested stocks and stones with, and so dealt unrighteously to the truth, as far at least as they might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:60
verses.text: For it abideth unchanged, having its own glory immutable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:61
verses.text: "And whence is it plain that He placed in them this knowledge, O Paul?" "Because," saith he, "that which may be known of Him is manifest in them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:62
verses.text: This, however, is an assertion, not a proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:63
verses.text: But do thou make it good, and show me that the knowledge of God was plain to them, and that they willingly turned aside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:64
verses.text: Whence was it plain then? did He send them a voice from above? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:65
verses.text: But what was able to draw them to Him more than a voice, that He did, by putting before them the Creation, so that both wise, and unlearned, and Scythian, and barbarian, having through sight learned the beauty of the things which were seen, might mount up to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:66
verses.text: Wherefore he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:67
verses.text: "For the invisible things of Him from the Creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things which are made".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:68
verses.text: Which also the prophet said, "The heavens declare the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:69
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:70
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:71
verses.text: ) For what will the Greeks (i-e: Heathen) say in that day? That "we were ignorant of Thee?" Did ye then not hear the heaven sending forth a voice by the sight, while the well-ordered harmony of all things spake out more clearly than a trumpet? Did ye not see the hours of night and day abiding unmoved continually, the goodly order of winter, spring, and the other seasons remaining both sure and unmoved, the tractableness (εὐγνωμοσύνην) of the sea amid all its turbulence and waves? All things abiding in order and by their beauty and their grandeur, preaching aloud of the Creator? For all these things and more than these doth Paul sum up in saying, "The invisible things of Him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things which are made, even His eternal Power and Godhead; so that they are without excuse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:72
verses.text: And yet it is not for this God hath made these things, even if this came of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:73
verses.text: For it was not to bereave them of all excuse, that He set before them so great a system of teaching, but that they might come to know Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:74
verses.text: But by not having recognized Him they deprived themselves of every excuse, and then to show how they are bereaved of excuse, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:75
verses.text: "Because that, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:76
verses.text: This is the one greatest charge; and the second after it is their also worshipping idols, as Jeremy too in accusing them said, "This people hath committed two evils: they have forsaken me the fountain of living water, and have dug for themselves broken cisterns".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:77
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:78
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:79
verses.text: ) And then as a sign of their having known God, and not used their knowledge upon a fit object, he adduces this very thing, that they knew gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:80
verses.text: Wherefore he adds, "because that, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:81
verses.text: And he names the cause through which they fell into such senselessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:82
verses.text: What then is it? They trusted everything to their reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:83
verses.text: Still he does not word it so, but in a much sharper language, "but became vain in their reasonings, and their foolish heart was darkened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:84
verses.text: For as in a night without a moon, if any one attempt to go by a strange road, or to sail over a strange sea, so far will he be from soon reaching his destination, that he will speedily be lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:85
verses.text: Thus they, attempting to go the way leading to Heaven, and having destroyed the light from their own selves, and, in lieu of it, trusted themselves to the darkness of their own reasoning, and seeking in bodies for Him who is incorporeal, and in shapes for Him who hath no shape, underwent a most rueful shipwreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:86
verses.text: But beside what has been said, he names also another cause of their error, when he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:87
verses.text: "Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:88
verses.text: For having some great conceit of themselves, and not enduring to go the way which God had commanded them, they were plunged into the reasonings of senselessness ( ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:89
verses.text: διανοίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:90
verses.text: And then to show and give in outline, what a rueful surge it was, and how destitute of excuse, he goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:91
verses.text: "And changed the glory of the uncorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds, and four-footed beasts, and creeping things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:92
verses.text: The first charge is, that they did not find God; the second was, that it was while they had great and clear (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:93
verses.text: marg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:94
verses.text: "wise") means to do it; the third, that withal they said they were wise; the fourth, that they not only did not find that Reverend Being, but even lowered Him to devils and to stones and stocks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:95
verses.text: Now he takes down their haughtiness also in the Epistle to the Corinthians, but not in the same way there as here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:96
verses.text: For there it is from the Cross he gives them the blow, saying, "The foolishness of God is wiser than men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:97
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:98
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:99
verses.text: ) But here, without any comparison, he holds their wisdom by itself up to ridicule, showing it to be folly and a mere display of vain boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:100
verses.text: Then, that you may learn that when they had the knowledge of God they gave it up thus treacherously, "they changed," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:101
verses.text: Now he that changeth, hath something to change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:102
verses.text: For they wished to find out more, and not bear with the limits given them, and so they were banished from these also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:103
verses.text: For they were lusters after new devices, for such is all that is Grecian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:104
verses.text: And this is why they stood against one another and Aristotle rose up against Plato, and the Stoics blustered (ἐφρυάξαντο  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:105
verses.text: "fenced themselves," ἐφράξαντο: which Field inclines to prefer) against him, and one has become hostile to one, another to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:106
verses.text: So that one should not so much marvel at them for their wisdom, as turn away from them indignant and hate them, because through this very thing they have become fools.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:107
verses.text: For had they not trusted what they have to reasonings, and syllogisms, and sophistries, they would not have suffered what they did suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:108
verses.text: Then, to strengthen the accusation against them he holds the whole of their idolatry up to ridicule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:109
verses.text: For in the first place the changing even were a very fit subject of scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:110
verses.text: But to change to such things too, is beyond all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:111
verses.text: For what then did they change it, and what was it which they invested with His Glory? Some conceptions they ought to have had about Him, as, for instance, that He is God, that He is Lord of all, that He made them, which were not, that He exerciseth a Providence, that He careth for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:112
verses.text: For these things are the "Glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:113
verses.text: To whom then did they ascribe it? Not even to men, but "to an image made like to corruptible man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:114
verses.text: Neither did they stop here, but even dropped down to the brutes, or rather to the images of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:115
verses.text: But consider, I pray, the wisdom of Paul, how he has taken the two extremes, God the Highest, and creeping things the lowest: or rather, not the creeping things, but the images of these; that he might clearly show their evident madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:116
verses.text: For what knowledge they ought to have had concerning Him Who is incomparably more excellent than all, with that they invested what was incomparably more worthless than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:117
verses.text: But what has this to do with the philosophers? a man may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:118
verses.text: To these belongs most of all what I have said to do with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:119
verses.text: For they have the Egyptians who were the inventors of these things to their masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:120
verses.text: And Plato, who is thought more reverend than the rest of them, glories in these masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:121
verses.text: (Plat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:122
verses.text: Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:123
verses.text: B.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:124
verses.text: etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:125
verses.text: ) And his master is in a stupid awe of these idols, for he it is that bids them sacrifice the cock to aesculapius (his last words, Phaedo), where (i-e: in his temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:126
verses.text: So Field from mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:127
verses.text: ) are the images of these beasts, and creeping things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:128
verses.text: And one may see Apollo and Bacchus worshipped along with these creeping things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:129
verses.text: And some of the philosophers even lifted up to Heaven bulls, and scorpions, and dragons, and all the rest of that vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:130
verses.text: For in all parts did the devil zealously strive to bring men down before the images of creeping things, and to range beneath the most senseless of all things, him whom God hath willed to lift up above the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:131
verses.text: And it is not from this only, but also from other grounds, that you will see their chief man to come under the remarks now made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:132
verses.text: For having made a collection of the poets, and having said that we should believe them upon matters relating to God, as having accurate knowledge, he has nothing else to bring forward but the "linked sweetness" of these absurdities, and then says, that this utterly ludicrous trifling is to be held for true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:133
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:134
verses.text: "Wherefore also God gave them up to uncleanness, through the lusts of their own hearts, to dishonor their own bodies between themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:135
verses.text: Hence he shows, that even of the perversion of the laws it was ungodliness which was the cause, but He "gave them up," here is, let them alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:136
verses.text: For as he that hath the command in an army, if upon the battle lying heavy upon him he retreat and go away, gives up his soldiers to the enemies not by thrusting them himself, but by stripping them of his own assistance; thus too did God leave those that were not minded to receive what cometh from Him, but were the first to bound off from Him, though Himself having wholly fulfilled His own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:137
verses.text: But consider; He set before them, for a form of doctrine, the world; He gave them reason, and an understanding capable of perceiving what was needful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:138
verses.text: None of these things did the men of that day use unto salvation, but they perverted to the opposite what they had received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:139
verses.text: What was to be done then? to drag them by compulsion and force? But this were not to make them virtuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:140
verses.text: It remained then, after that, for Him to leave them alone, and this He did too, that in this way, if by no other, having by trial come to know the things they lusted after, they might flee from what was so shameful ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:141
verses.text: add εἰκότως, and with reason).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:142
verses.text: For if any that was a king's son, dishonoring his father, should choose to be with robbers and murderers, and them that break up tombs, and prefer their doings to his father's house; the father leaves him, say, so that by actual trial, he may learn the extravagance of his own madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:143
verses.text: But how comes he to mention no other sin, as murder, for instance, or covetousness, or other such besides, but only unchasteness? He seems to me to hint at his audience at the time, and those who were to receive the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:144
verses.text: "To uncleanness, to dishonor their own bodies between themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:145
verses.text: Note the emphasis here, as it is most severe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:146
verses.text: For they stood not in need of any others, it means, to do insolent violence to them, but the very treatment the enemies would have shown them, this they did to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:147
verses.text: And then, taking up the charge again, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:148
verses.text: "Who changed the truth of God into a lie, and worshipped and served the creature more than the Creator".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:149
verses.text: Things which were matter for utter scorn, he puts down specially, but what seemed of a graver cast than the rest, in general terms; and by all he shows, that serving the creature is Grecian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:150
verses.text: And see how strong he makes his assertion, for he does not say, barely, "they served the creature," but "more than the Creator:" thus everywhere giving fresh force to the charge, and, by the comparison, taking from them all ground of mitigation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:151
verses.text: "Who is blessed forever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:152
verses.text: But by this, he means, He was not any whit injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:153
verses.text: For Himself abideth "blessed for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:154
verses.text: Here he shows, that it was not in self-defence that He left them alone, inasmuch as He suffered nothing Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:155
verses.text: For even if these treated Him insolently, yet He was not insolently treated, neither was any scathe done to the bearings of His glory, but He abideth continually blessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:156
verses.text: For if it often happen, that man through philosophy would not feel the insults men offered him, much less would God, the imperishable and unalterable Nature, the unchangeable and immovable Glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:157
verses.text: For men are in this respect made like unto God, when they do not feel what is inflicted by them who would do them despite, and are neither insulted of others who insult them, nor beaten of them when beating them, nor made scorn of when they make scorn of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:158
verses.text: And how in the nature of things can this be? it may be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:159
verses.text: It is so, yea most certainly it is possible, when thou art not vexed at what is done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:160
verses.text: And how, it may be said, is it possible not to be vexed? Nay rather, how is it possible to be vexed? Tell me now, if your little child were to insult you, would you then reckon the insult an insult? What, but would you be vexed? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:161
verses.text: But and if you were to be vexed, would you not then be ridiculous? Thus too let us then get to feel disposed towards our neighbors, and then we shall have no sense of displeasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:162
verses.text: For they that insult us are more senseless than children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:163
verses.text: Neither let us even seek to be free from insults, but when we are insulted to bear them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:164
verses.text: For this is the only secure honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:165
verses.text: But why so? Because this you are master of, but that, another person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:166
verses.text: Do you not see the adamant reverberating the blows it receives? But nature, you will say, gives it this property.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:167
verses.text: Yet you too have it in your power to become by free choice such, as that happens to be by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:168
verses.text: How? do you not know that the children in the furnace were not burned? and that Daniel in the den suffered no harm? This may even now come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:169
verses.text: There stand by us too lions, anger and lust, with fearful teeth tearing asunder him that falleth among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:170
verses.text: (Plato Rep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:171
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:172
verses.text: ) Become then like that (ἔκεινον  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:173
verses.text: ) Daniel, and let not these affections fasten their fangs into thy soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:174
verses.text: But that, you will say, was wholly of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:175
verses.text: Yes; because the acts of free-will led the way thereto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:176
verses.text: So that if we be willing to train ourselves to a like character, even now the grace is at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:177
verses.text: And even though the brutes be an hungered, yet will they not touch thy sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:178
verses.text: For if at the sight of a servant's body they were abashed, when they have seen the members of Christ, (and this is what we believers are,) how shall they do else than be still? Yet if they be not still, it is owing to the fault of those cast among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:179
verses.text: For indeed many spend largely upon these lions, by keeping harlots, breaking through marriages, taking vengeance upon enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:180
verses.text: And so before ever they come to the bottom of the den they get torn in pieces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:181
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:182
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:183
verses.text: ) But with Daniel this did not so happen, neither yet would it with us, if we were so minded, but even a greater thing would take place than what then happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:184
verses.text: For the lions hurt not him; and if we be sober-minded, then will they that hurt us even profit us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:185
verses.text: Thus then did Paul grow bright out of those that thwarted him and plotted against him, thus Job out of the many scourges, thus Jeremy out of the miry pit, thus Noah out of the flood, thus Abel out of the treachery, thus Moses out of the bloodthirsty Jews, thus, Elisha, thus each of the worthies of old, not out of relaxedness and softness, but out of tribulations and trials, came to be attired with their bright crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:186
verses.text: Wherefore also Christ, inasmuch as He knew this to be the groundwork of a good report, said to His disciples, "In the world ye shall have tribulation, but be of good cheer, I have overcome the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:187
verses.text: (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:188
verses.text: ) What then, they will say, Have not many been turned to flight by these terrors? Yes, but that was not of the nature of temptation, but of their own remissness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:189
verses.text: But He that "with the temptation maketh also an escape, so that ye may be able to bear it" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:190
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:191
verses.text: ), may He stand by all of us, and reach forth His hand, that being gloriously proclaimed victorious we may attain to the everlasting crowns, through the grace and love towards man ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 4:192
verses.text: add the rest and so Field passim) of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom, and with Whom, to the Father be glory, with the Holy Ghost, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:4
verses.text: ,  "For this cause God gave them up unto vile affections: for even their women did change the natural use into that which is against nature: and likewise also the men, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust one towards another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:5
verses.text: All these affections then were vile, but chiefly the mad lust after males; for the soul is more the sufferer in sins, and more dishonored, than the body in diseases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:6
verses.text: But behold how here too, as in the case of the doctrines, he deprives them of excuse, by saying of the women, that "they changed the natural use".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:7
verses.text: For no one, he means, can say that it was by being hindered of legitimate intercourse that they came to this pass, or that it was from having no means to fulfil their desire that they were driven into this monstrous insaneness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:8
verses.text: For the changing implies possession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:9
verses.text: Which also when discoursing upon the doctrines he said, "They changed the truth of God for a lie".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:10
verses.text: And with regard to the men again, he shows the same thing by saying, "Leaving the natural use of the woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:11
verses.text: And in a like way with those, these he also puts out of all means of defending themselves by charging them not only that they had the means of gratification, and left that which they had, and went after another, but that having dishonored that which was natural, they ran after that which was contrary to nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:12
verses.text: But that which is contrary to nature hath in it an irksomeness and displeasingness, so that they could not fairly allege even pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:13
verses.text: For genuine pleasure is that which is according to nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:14
verses.text: But when God hath left one, then all things are turned upside down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:15
verses.text: And thus not only was their doctrine Satanical, but their life too was diabolical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:16
verses.text: Now when he was discoursing of their doctrines, he put before them the world and man's understanding, telling them that, by the judgment afforded them by God, they might through the things which are seen, have been led as by the hand to the Creator, and then, by not willing to do so, they remained inexcusable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:17
verses.text: Here in the place of the world he sets the pleasure according to nature, which they would have enjoyed with more sense of security and greater glad-heartedness, and so have been far removed from shameful deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:18
verses.text: But they would not; whence they are quite out of the pale of pardon, and have done an insult to nature itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:19
verses.text: And a yet more disgraceful thing than these is it, when even the women seek after these intercourses, who ought to have more sense of shame than men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:20
verses.text: And here too the judgment of Paul is worthy of admiration, how having fallen upon two opposite matters he accomplishes them both with all exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:21
verses.text: For he wished both to speak chastely and to sting the hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:22
verses.text: Now both these things were not in his power to do, but one hindered the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:23
verses.text: For if you speak chastely you shall not be able to bear hard upon the hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:24
verses.text: But if you are minded to touch him to the quick, you are forced to lay the naked facts before him in plain terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:25
verses.text: But his discreet and holy soul was able to do both with exactness, and by naming nature has at once given additional force to his accusation, and also used this as a sort of veil, to keep the chasteness of his description.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:26
verses.text: And next, having reproached the women first, he goes on to the men also, and says, "And likewise also the men leaving the natural use of the woman".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:27
verses.text: Which is an evident proof of the last degree of corruptness, when both sexes are abandoned, and both he that was ordained to be the instructor of the woman, and she who was bid to become an helpmate to the man, work the deeds of enemies against one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:28
verses.text: And reflect too how significantly he uses his words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:29
verses.text: For he does not say that they were enamoured of, and lusted after one another, but, "they burned in their lust one toward another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:30
verses.text: You see that the whole of desire comes of an exorbitancy which endureth not to abide within its proper limits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:31
verses.text: For everything which transgresseth the laws by God appointed, lusteth after monstrous things and not those which be customary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:32
verses.text: For as many oftentimes having left the desire of food get to feed upon earth and small stones, and others being possessed by excessive thirst often long even for mire, thus these also ran into this ebullition of lawless love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:33
verses.text: But if you say, and whence came this intensity of lust? It was from the desertion of God: and whence is the desertion of God? from the lawlessness of them that left Him; "men with men working that which is unseemly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:34
verses.text: Do not, he means, because you have heard that they burned, suppose that the evil was only in desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:35
verses.text: For the greater part of it came of their luxuriousness, which also kindled into flame their lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:36
verses.text: And this is why he did not say being swept along or being overtaken, an expression he uses elsewhere; but what? working.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:37
verses.text: They made a business of the sin, and not only a business, but even one zealously followed up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:38
verses.text: And he called it not lust, but that which is unseemly, and that properly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:39
verses.text: For they both dishonored nature, and trampled on the laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:40
verses.text: And see the great confusion which fell out on both sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:41
verses.text: For not only was the head turned downwards but the feet too were upwards, and they became enemies to themselves and to one another, bringing in a pernicious kind of strife, and one even more lawless than any civil war, and one rife in divisions, and of varied form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:42
verses.text: For they divided this into four new, and lawless kinds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:43
verses.text: Since ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:44
verses.text: whence) this war was not twofold or threefold, but even fourfold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:45
verses.text: Consider then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:46
verses.text: It was meet, that the twain should be one, I mean the woman and the man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:47
verses.text: For "the twain," it says, "shall be one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:48
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:49
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:50
verses.text: ) But this the desire of intercourse effected, and united the sexes to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:51
verses.text: This desire the devil having taken away, and having turned the course thereof into another fashion, he thus sundered the sexes from one another, and made the one to become two parts in opposition to the law of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:52
verses.text: For it says, "the two shall be one flesh;" but he divided the one flesh into two: here then is one war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:53
verses.text: Again, these same two parts he provoked to war both against themselves and against one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:54
verses.text: For even women again abused women, and not men only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:55
verses.text: And the men stood against one another, and against the female sex, as happens in a battle by night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:56
verses.text: You see a second and third war, and a fourth and fifth; there is also another, for beside what have been mentioned they also behaved lawlessly against nature itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:57
verses.text: For when the Devil saw that this desire it is, principally, which draws the sexes together, he was bent on cutting through the tie, so as to destroy the race, not only by their not copulating lawfully, but also by their being stirred up to war, and in sedition against one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:58
verses.text: "And receiving in themselves that recompense of their error which was meet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:59
verses.text: See how he goes again to the fountain head of the evil, namely, the impiety that comes of their doctrines, and this he says is a reward of that lawlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:60
verses.text: For since in speaking of hell and punishment, it seemed he would not at present be credible to the ungodly and deliberate choosers of such a life, but even scorned, he shows that the punishment was in this pleasure itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:61
verses.text: (So Plato Theaet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:62
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:63
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:64
verses.text: ) But if they perceive it not, but are still pleased, be not amazed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:65
verses.text: For even they that are mad, and are afflicted with phrenzy (cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:66
verses.text: Soph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:67
verses.text: Aj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:68
verses.text: –) while doing themselves much injury and making themselves such objects of compassion, that others weep over them themselves smile and revel over what has happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:69
verses.text: Yet we do not only for this not say that they are quit of punishment, but for this very reason are under a more grievous vengeance, in that they are unconscious of the plight they are in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:70
verses.text: For it is not the disordered but those who are sound whose votes one has to gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:71
verses.text: Yet of old the matter seemed even to be a law, and a certain law-giver among them bade the domestic slaves neither to use unguents when dry (i-e: except in bathing) nor to keep youths, giving the free this place of honor, or rather of shamefulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:72
verses.text: Yet they, however, did not think the thing shameful, but as being a grand privilege, and one too great for slaves, the Athenian people, the wisest of people, and Solon who is so great amongst them, permitted it to the free alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:73
verses.text: And sundry other books of the philosophers may one see full of this disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:74
verses.text: But we do not therefore say that the thing was made lawful, but that they who received this law were pitiable, and objects for many tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:75
verses.text: For these are treated in the same way as women that play the whore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:76
verses.text: Or rather their plight is more miserable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:77
verses.text: For in the case of the one the intercourse, even if lawless, is yet according to nature: but this is contrary both to law and nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:78
