verses.text: For even if there were no hell, and no punishment had been threatened, this were worse than any punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:79
verses.text: Yet if you say "they found pleasure in it," you tell me what adds to the vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:80
verses.text: For suppose I were to see a person running naked, with his body all besmeared with mire, and yet not covering himself, but exulting in it, I should not rejoice with him, but should rather bewail that he did not even perceive that he was doing shamefully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:81
verses.text: But that I may show the atrocity in a yet clearer light, bear with me in one more example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:82
verses.text: Now if any one condemned a virgin to live in close dens (θαλομευομένην), and to have intercourse with unreasoning brutes, and then she was pleased with such intercourse, would she not for this be especially a worthy object of tears, as being unable to be freed from this misery owing to her not even perceiving the misery? It is plain surely to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:83
verses.text: But if that were a grievous thing, neither is this less so than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:84
verses.text: For to be insulted by one's own kinsmen is more piteous than to be so by strangers: these I say ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:85
verses.text: "I consider") are even worse than murderers: since to die even is better than to live under such insolency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:86
verses.text: For the murderer dissevers the soul from the body, but this man ruins the soul with the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:87
verses.text: And name what sin you will, none will you mention equal to this lawlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:88
verses.text: And if they that suffer such things perceived them, they would accept ten thousand deaths so they might not suffer this evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:89
verses.text: For there is not, there surely is not, a more grievous evil than this insolent dealing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:90
verses.text: For if when discoursing about fornication Paul said, that "Every sin which a man doeth is without the body, but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:91
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:92
verses.text: ); what shall we say of this madness, which is so much worse than fornication as cannot even be expressed? For I should not only say that thou hast become a woman, but that thou hast lost thy manhood, and hast neither changed into that nature nor kept that which thou haddest, but thou hast been a traitor to both of them at once, and deserving both of men and women to be driven out and stoned, as having wronged either sex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:93
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn what the real force of this is, if any one were to come and assure you that he would make you a dog instead of being a man, would you not flee from him as a plague? But, lo! thou hast not made thyself a dog out of a man, but an animal more disgraceful than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:94
verses.text: For this is useful unto service, but he that hath thus given himself up is serviceable for nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:95
verses.text: Or again, if any one threatened to make men travail and be brought to bed, should we not be filled with indignation? But lo! now they that have run into this fury have done more grievously by themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:96
verses.text: For it is not the same thing to change into the nature of women, as to continue a man and yet to have become a woman; or rather neither this nor that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:97
verses.text: But if you would know the enormity of the evil from other grounds, ask on what account the lawgivers punish them that make men eunuchs, and you will see that it is absolutely for no other reason than because they mutilate nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:98
verses.text: And yet the injustice they do is nothing to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:99
verses.text: For there have been those that were mutilated and were in many cases useful after their mutilation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:100
verses.text: But nothing can there be more worthless than a man who has pandered himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:101
verses.text: For not the soul only, but the body also of one who hath been so treated, is disgraced, and deserves to be driven out everywhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:102
verses.text: How many hells shall be enough for such? But if thou scoffest at hearing of hell and believest not that fire, remember Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:103
verses.text: For we have seen, surely we have seen, even in this present life, a semblance of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:104
verses.text: For since many would utterly disbelieve the things to come after the resurrection, hearing now of an unquenchable fire, God brings them to a right mind by things present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:105
verses.text: For such is the burning of Sodom, and that conflagration! And they know it well that have been at the place, and have seen with their eyes that scourge divinely sent, and the effect of the lightnings from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:106
verses.text: (Jude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:107
verses.text: ) Consider how great is that sin, to have forced hell to appear even before its time! For whereas many thought scorn of His words, by His deeds did God show them the image thereof in a certain novel way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:108
verses.text: For that rain was unwonted, for that the intercourse was contrary to nature, and it deluged the land, since lust had done so with their souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:109
verses.text: Wherefore also the rain was the opposite of the customary rain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:110
verses.text: Now not only did it fail to stir up the womb of the earth to the production of fruits, but made it even useless for the reception of seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:111
verses.text: For such was also the intercourse of the men, making a body of this sort more worthless than the very land of Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:112
verses.text: And what is there more detestable than a man who hath pandered himself, or what more execrable? Oh, what madness! Oh, what distraction! Whence came this lust lewdly revelling and making man's nature all that enemies could? or even worse than that, by as much as the soul is better than the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:113
verses.text: Oh, ye that were more senseless than irrational creatures, and more shameless than dogs! for in no case does such intercourse take place with them, but nature acknowledgeth her own limits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:114
verses.text: But ye have even made our race dishonored below things irrational, by such indignities inflicted upon and by each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:115
verses.text: Whence then were these evils born? Of luxury; of not knowing God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:116
verses.text: For so soon as any have cast out the fear of Him, all that is good straightway goes to ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:117
verses.text: Now, that this may not happen, let us keep clear before our eyes the fear of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:118
verses.text: For nothing, surely nothing, so ruins a man as to slip from this anchor, as nothing saves so much as continually looking thereto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:119
verses.text: For if by having a man before our eyes we feel more backward at doing sins, and often even through feeling abashed at servants of a better stamp we keep from doing anything amiss, consider what safety we shall enjoy by having God before our eyes! For in no case will the Devil attack us when so conditioned, in that he would be laboring without profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:120
verses.text: But should he see us wandering abroad, and going about without a bridle, by getting a beginning in ourselves he will be able to drive us off afterwards any whither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:121
verses.text: And as it happens with thoughtless servants at market, who leave the needful services which their masters have entrusted to them, and rivet themselves at a mere haphazard to those who fall in their way, and waste out their leisure there; this also we undergo when we depart from the commandments of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:122
verses.text: For we presently get standing on, admiring riches, and beauty of person, and the other things which we have no business with, just as those servants attend to the beggars that do jugglers' feats, and then, arriving too late, have to be grievously beaten at home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:123
verses.text: And many pass the road set before them through following others, who are behaving in the same unseemly way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:124
verses.text: But let not us so do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:125
verses.text: For we have been sent to dispatch many affairs that are urgent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:126
verses.text: And if we leave those, and stand gaping at these useless things, all our time will be wasted in vain and to no profit, and we shall suffer the extreme of punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:127
verses.text: For if you wish yourself to be busy, you have whereat you ought to wonder, and to gape all your days, things which are no subject for laughter, but for wondering and manifold praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:128
verses.text: As he that admires things ridiculous, will himself often be such, and even worse than he that occasioneth the laughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:129
verses.text: And that you may not fall into this, spring away from it forthwith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:130
verses.text: For why is it, pray, that you stand gaping and fluttering at sight of riches? What do you see so wonderful, and able to fix your eyes upon them? these gold-harnessed horses, these lackeys, partly savages, and partly eunuchs, and costly raiment, and the soul that is getting utterly soft in all this, and the haughty brow, and the bustlings, and the noise? And wherein do these things deserve wonder? what are they better than the beggars that dance and pipe in the market-place? For these too being taken with a sore famine of virtue, dance a dance more ridiculous than theirs, led and carried round at one time to costly tables, at another to the lodging of prostitute women, and at another to a swarm of flatterers and a host of hangers-on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:131
verses.text: But if they do wear gold, this is why they are the most pitiable, because the things which are nothing to them, are most the subject of their eager desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:132
verses.text: Do not now, I pray, look at their raiment, but open their soul, and consider if it is not full of countless wounds, and clad with rags, and destitute, and defenceless! What then is the use of this madness of shows? for it were much better to be poor and living in virtue, than to be a king with wickedness; since the poor man in himself enjoys all the delights of the soul, and doth not even perceive his outward poverty for his inward riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:133
verses.text: But the king, luxurious in those things which do not at all belong to him, is punished in those things which are his most real concern, even the soul, the thoughts, and the conscience, which are to go away with him to the other world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:134
verses.text: Since then we know these things, let us lay aside the gilded raiment, let us take up virtue and the pleasure which comes thereof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 5:135
verses.text: For so, both here and hereafter, shall we come to enjoy great delights, through the grace and love towards man of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom, and with Whom, be glory to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:4
verses.text: "Even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:5
verses.text: Lest he should seem to be hinting at them by delaying in his discourse so long over the unnatural sin, he next passes on to other kinds of sins also, and for this cause he carries on the whole of his discourse as of other persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:6
verses.text: And as he always does when discoursing with believers about sins, and wishing to show that they are to be avoided, he brings the Gentiles in, and says, "Not in the lust of concupiscence, even as the other Gentiles which know not God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:7
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:8
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:9
verses.text: ) And again: "sorrow not, even as others which have no hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:10
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:11
verses.text: ) And so here too he shows that it was to them the sins belonged, and deprives them of all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:12
verses.text: For he says, that their daring deeds came not of ignorance, but of practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:13
verses.text: And this is why he did not say, "and as they knew not God;" but "as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge;" as much as to say, that the sin was one of a perverted determination of obstinacy, more than of a sudden ravishment, and shows that it was not the flesh (as some heretics say) but the mind, to the wicked lust whereof the sins belonged, and that it was thence the fount of the evils flowed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:14
verses.text: For since the mind is become undistinguishing, all else is then dragged out of course and overturned, when he is corrupted that held the reins! (Plat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:15
verses.text: Phaedr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:16
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:17
verses.text: B.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:18
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:19
verses.text: "Being filled with all unrighteousness, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:20
verses.text: See how everything here is intensitive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:21
verses.text: For he says, "being filled," and "with all," and having named maliciousness in general, he also further pursues the particulars, and these too in excess, saying, "Full of envy, murder," for the latter of these comes from the former, as was shown in Abel's case and Joseph's, and then after saying, "debate, deceit, malignity;"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:22
verses.text: "Whisperers, backbiters, haters of God, despiteful," and classing things which to many seem indifferent among his charges, he further strengthens his accusation, going up to the stronghold of their wickednesses, and styles them "boasters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:23
verses.text: For even worse than sinning is it, even though sinning to be haughty-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:24
verses.text: Wherefore also he charges the Corinthians with it, saying, "Ye are puffed up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:25
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:26
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:27
verses.text: ) For if in a good action he that puffs himself up loseth all, if any one do so among his sins, what vengeance is there of which he is not worthy, since such an one cannot repent any more? Next, he says, "inventors of evil things;" showing that they were not content with those already existing, but even invented others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:28
verses.text: And this again is like men that are full purposed and in earnest, not those that are hurried away and forced out of their course; and after mentioning the several kinds of maliciousness, and showing that here too they stood against nature itself (for he says, "disobedient to parents"), he then goes on to the root of the great pestilence, calling them,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:29
verses.text: "Without natural affection, implacable".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:30
verses.text: For this Christ Himself also pronounces to be the cause of wickedness, saying, "When iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:31
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:32
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:33
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:34
verses.text: This too St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:35
verses.text: Paul here says, calling them "covenant-breakers, without natural affection, implacable, unmerciful," and showing that they were traitors even to the gift of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:36
verses.text: For we have a sort of family feeling even by nature towards one another, which even beasts have got towards each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:37
verses.text: "For every beast," it says, "loveth his like, and every man his neighbor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:38
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:39
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:40
verses.text: ) But these became more ferocious even than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:41
verses.text: The disorder then which resulted to the world by evil doctrines, he proves to us by these witnesses, and clearly shows that the malady in either case came of the negligence of them that were disordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:42
verses.text: He shows besides, what he did in the case of the doctrines, that they were here also deprived of all excuse; and so he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:43
verses.text: "Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:44
verses.text: Having assumed here two objections, he in the first place removes them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:45
verses.text: For what reason have you to say, he means, that you know not the things which ought to be done? At best, even if you did not know, you are to blame in having left God who instructs you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:46
verses.text: But as it is by many arguments we have shown that you do know, and transgress willingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:47
verses.text: But are you drawn by passion? Why then do you both coöperate therewith and praise it? For they "not only do such things," he says, "but have pleasure in them that do them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:48
verses.text: Having then put the more grievous and the unpardonable sin first, that he might have done with it (Or "convict you of it," ἵνα ἑλῃ); (for he that praiseth the sin is far worse than even he that trespasseth;) having then put this the first, he by this method grapples more powerfully with him in the sequel, speaking on this wise,  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:49
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:50
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:51
verses.text: "Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man; whosoever thou art that judgest; for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:52
verses.text: These things he says, with an aim at the rulers, inasmuch as that city then had the rule of the world put into its hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:53
verses.text: He anticipated them therefore by saying, Thou art depriving thyself of defence, whoever thou mayest be; for when thou condemnest an adulterer, and thyself committest adultery, although no man condemneth thee, in thy judgment upon the guilty person thou hast also passed sentence against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:55
verses.text: "For we are sure that the judgment of God is according to truth against them who commit such things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:56
verses.text: For lest any should say, until now I have escaped, to make him afraid, he says, that it is not so with God as it is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:57
verses.text: For here (Plato in Theaet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:58
verses.text: et Phaedon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:59
verses.text: ) one is punished, and another escapes while doing the same thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:60
verses.text: But hereafter it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:61
verses.text: That he that judgeth then knoweth the right, he has said: but whence he knoweth it, he hath not added; for it was superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:62
verses.text: For in the case of ungodliness, he shows both that the ungodly was so even with a knowledge of God, and also whence he got that knowledge, namely, from the Creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:63
verses.text: For inasmuch as it was not plain to all, he gave the cause also; but here he passes it over as a thing admitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:64
verses.text: But when he says, "whosoever thou art that judgest," he is not addressing himself to the rulers only, but to private individuals and subjects also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:65
verses.text: For all men, even if they have no chair of state, nor executioners, nor stocks at command, yet even they judge those that offend, in conversations and public meetings (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:66
verses.text: κοινοἵς συλλόγοις) and by the vote of their conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:67
verses.text: And no one would venture to say, that the adulterer does not deserve punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:68
verses.text: But it is others, he says, they condemn, and not themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:69
verses.text: And for this cause he stands forth vehemently against them, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:70
verses.text: "And thinkest thou this" ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:71
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:72
verses.text: this), "O man, that judgest those which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God?"  For since he had shown the sin of the world to be great, from its doctrines, from its doings, and that they did yet sin though wise, and though they had the creation to lead them by the hand, and not by leaving God only, but also by choosing the images of creeping things, and by their dishonoring virtue, and deserting, in spite of nature's drawings back, to the service of vice even contrary to nature: he goes on next to show, that they who do such things are punished too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:73
verses.text: He did indeed at once point out a punishment by mentioning their very practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:74
verses.text: For "they received," he says, "in themselves that recompense of their error which was meet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:75
verses.text: But as they do not perceive that, he mentions another also, which they stood most in fear of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:76
verses.text: And indeed already he chiefly pointed at this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:77
verses.text: For when he says, "That the judgment of God is according to truth," he is speaking of no other than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:78
verses.text: But he establishes the same again upon other further grounds, saying thus, "And thinkest thou this, O man, that judgest them which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God?" Thou hast not been acquitted of thine own judgment, and wilt thou escape through God's? Who indeed would say this? And yet thou hast judged thyself ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:79
verses.text: "and not been acquitted").

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:80
verses.text: But since the rigorousness of the judgment-court was such, and thou wert not able to spare even thyself, how should not God, that cannot do amiss, and who is in the highest sense just, be much surer to do the same? But hast thou condemned thyself, and is God to approve of thee and praise thee? And how can this be reasonable? And all the while thou art deserving of a greater punishment, than he who is of thee condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:81
verses.text: For sinning merely, is not the same thing with falling again into the same sins you have chastised another for committing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:82
verses.text: See, how he has strengthened the charge! For if you, he means, punish a person who has committed less sins, though by it you will put yourself to shame, how shall not God cast you in your suit, and condemn you more severely, who have committed greater transgressions, and this too when He will never make Himself ashamed, and you are already condemned by your own reckoning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:83
verses.text: But if thou say, I know that I deserve punishment; yet through His long-suffering thinkest slightingly of it, and art confident because thou dost not suffer punishment forthwith; this surely is a reason why thou oughtest to be afraid and tremble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:84
verses.text: For the fact that thou hast not yet suffered punishment, will not result in thy not suffering any punishment, but in thy suffering a more severe one if thou abidest unamended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:85
verses.text: And so he goes on to say:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:86
verses.text: "Or despiseth thou the riches of His goodness and forbearance and long-sufferring; not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?"  For after praising God's long-suffering, showing the gain thereof to be very great to them that heeded it (and this was the drawing sinners to repentance); he adds to the terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:87
verses.text: For as to them, who avail themselves of it aright, it is a ground of safety; so to them that slight it, it is conducive to a greater vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:88
verses.text: For whenever you utter this common notion, that God doth not exact justice, because He is good and long-suffering, he says, You do but mention what will make the vengeance intenser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:89
verses.text: For God showeth His goodness that you may get free from your sins, not that you may add to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:90
verses.text: If then thou make not this use thereof, the judgment will be more fearful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:91
verses.text: Wherefore it is a chief ground for abstaining from sin, that God is long-suffering, and not for making the benefit a plea for obstinacy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:92
verses.text: For if He be long-suffering, He most certainly punisheth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:93
verses.text: Whence does this appear? from what is next said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:94
verses.text: For if the wickedness be great and the wicked have not been requited, it is absolutely necessary that they should be requited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:95
verses.text: For if men do not overlook these things, how should God make an oversight? And so from this point he introduces the subject of the judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:96
verses.text: For the fact of showing many who, if they repent not, are liable, yet still are not punished here, introduces with it necessarily the judgment, and that with increase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:97
verses.text: Wherefore he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:98
verses.text: "But after thy hardness and impenitent heart treasurest up unto thyself wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:99
verses.text: For when a man is neither to be softened by goodness nor to be turned back by fear, what can be harder than such an one? For after that he had showed the goodness of God towards men, he then shows His vengeance that it is unbearable for him who does not even so return to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:100
verses.text: And observe with what propriety he uses the words! "Thou treasurest up unto thyself wrath," he says, so making it plain what is certainly laid up, and showing that it is not He that judgeth, but he that is condemned, who is the author of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:101
verses.text: For he says, "thou treasurest up for thyself," not God for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:102
verses.text: For He did all, whatsoever things were fitting, and created thee with a power to discern between good and what was not so, and showed long-suffering over thee, and called thee to repentance, and threatened a fearful day, so by every means drawing thee to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:103
verses.text: But if thou shouldst continue unyielding, "thou treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath and revelation and (so all mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:104
verses.text: but two) the righteous judgment of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:105
verses.text: For lest on hearing of wrath thou shouldest think of any passion, he adds, "the righteous judgment of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:106
verses.text: And he said "revelation" with good reason, for then is this revealed when each man receives his desert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:107
verses.text: For here many men often annoy and practise harm to one without justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:108
verses.text: But hereafter it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:109
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:110
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:111
verses.text: "Who will render to every man according to his deeds, to them who by patient continuance in well doing," etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:112
verses.text: Since he had become awestriking and harsh by discoursing of the judgment and of the punishment that shall be, he does not forthwith, as one might expect, enter upon the vengeance, but turns his discourse to what was sweeter, to the recompense of good actions, saying as follows,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:113
verses.text: "To them who by patient continuance in well doing seek for glory and honor and immortality, eternal life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:114
verses.text: Here also he awakens those who had drawn back during the trials, and shows that it is not right to trust in faith only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:115
verses.text: For it is deeds also into which that tribunal will enquire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:116
verses.text: But observe, how when he is discoursing about the things to come, he is unable to tell clearly the blessings, but speaketh of glory and honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:117
verses.text: For in that they transcend all that man hath, he hath no image of them taken from this to show, but by those things which have a semblance of brightness among us, even by them he sets them before us as far as may be, by glory, by honor, by life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:118
verses.text: For these be what men earnestly strive after, yet are those things not these, but much better than these, inasmuch as they are incorruptible and immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:119
verses.text: See how he has opened to us the doors toward the resurrection of the body by speaking of incorruptibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:120
verses.text: For incorruptibility belongs to the corruptible body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:121
verses.text: Then, since this sufficed not, he added glory and honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:122
verses.text: For all of us are to rise incorruptible, but not all to glory, but some to punishment, and some to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:123
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:124
verses.text: "But unto them that are contentious," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:125
verses.text: Again, he deprives of excuse those that live in wickedness, and shows that it is from a kind of disputatiousness and carelessness that they fall into unrighteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:126
verses.text: "And do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:127
verses.text: See, here is another accusation again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:128
verses.text: For what defence can he set up, who flees from the light and chooses the dark? And he does not say, who are "compelled by," "lorded over by," but who "obey unrighteousness," that one may learn that the fall is one of free choice, the crime not of necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:130
verses.text: "Indignation and wrath, tribulation and anguish, upon every soul of man that doeth evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:131
verses.text: That is, if a man be rich, if a consul, if a very sovereign (so Field: several mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:132
verses.text: and Edd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:133
verses.text: "the emperor himself"), by none of them is the account of the judgment out-faced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:134
verses.text: Since in this dignities have no place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:135
verses.text: Having then shown the exceeding greatness of the disease, and having added the cause, that it was from the carelessness of the disordered, and finally, that destruction awaits them and that amendment is easy, in the punishment also he again gives the Jew the heavier lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:136
verses.text: For he that had enjoyed a larger share of instruction would also deserve to undergo a larger share of vengeance if doing lawlessly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:137
verses.text: And so the wiser or mightier men we are, the more are we punished if we sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:138
verses.text: For if thou art rich, thou wilt have more money demanded of thee than of the poor; and if wiser than others, a stricter obedience; and if thou hast been invested with authority, more shining acts of goodness; and so in the case of all the other things, thou wilt have to bring in measures proportioned to your power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:139
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:140
verses.text: "But glory, honor, and peace to every man that worketh good, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:141
verses.text: What Jew does he here mean? or about what Gentiles is he discoursing? It is of those before Christ's coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:142
verses.text: For his discourse had not hitherto come to the times of grace, but he was still dwelling upon the earlier times, so breaking down first from afar off and clearing away the separation between the Greek and the Jew, that when he should do this in the matter of grace, he might no more seem to be devising some new and degrading view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:143
verses.text: For if in the earlier times when this Grace had not shone forth in such greatness, when the estate of the Jews was solemn and renowned and glorious before all men, there was no difference, what could they say for themselves (τίνα ἂν ἔχοιεν λόγον εἰπεἵν;) now after so great a display of grace? And this is why he establishes it with so great earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:144
verses.text: For when the hearer has been informed that this held in the earlier times, much more will he receive it after the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:145
verses.text: But by Greeks he here means not them that worshipped idols, but them that adored God, that obeyed the law of nature, that strictly kept all things, save the Jewish observances, which contribute to piety, such as were Melchizedek and his (οἱ περὶ), such as was Job, such as were the Ninevites, such as was Cornelius.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:146
verses.text: Here then he is first breaking through the partition between the circumcision and the uncircumcision: and at a distance dissipates this distinction beforehand, so as to do it without being suspected, and to strike into it as compelled by another occasion, which is ever a characteristic of his Apostolic wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:147
verses.text: For if he had showed it in the times of grace, what he said would have had a very suspicious look.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:148
verses.text: But on describing the vice which possessed the world, and where end the ways of wickedness, to pass from that consecutively into the treatment of these points renders his teaching unsuspected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:149
verses.text: And that he means this, and for this purpose so put this together, is plain from hence: for if he were not intent upon effecting this, it were enough for him to have said, "According to thy hardness and impenitent heart thou treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath;" and then to have dropped this subject, since it would have been complete.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:150
verses.text: But in that what he had in view was not to speak of the judgment to come only, but to show also that the Jew had no advantage of such a Greek, and so was not to be haughty-spirited, he advances farther, and speaks of them in order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:151
verses.text: But consider! He had put the hearer in fear, had advanced against him the fearful day, had told him what an evil it is to be living in wickedness, had showed him that no man sinneth of ignorance, nor with impunity, but that even though he suffer no punishment now, yet he certainly will suffer it: then he wishes to make good next that the teaching of the Law was not a thing of great importance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:152
verses.text: For it is upon works that both punishment and reward depend, not upon circumcision and uncircumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:153
verses.text: Since then he had said, that the Gentile shall by no means go unpunished and had taken this for granted, and upon it had made good that he shall also be rewarded, he next showed the Law and circumcision to be superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:154
verses.text: For it is the Jews that he is here chiefly opposing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:155
verses.text: For inasmuch as they were somewhat captiously disposed, first, of their haughtiness, not deigning to be reckoned along with the Gentiles, and secondly thinking it ridiculous if the faith is to do away all sins; for this cause he accused the Gentiles first, in whose behalf he is speaking, that without suspicion and with boldness of speech, he may attack the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:156
verses.text: And then having come to the enquiry concerning the punishment, he shows that the Jew is so far from being at all profited by the Law, that he is even weighed down by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:157
verses.text: And this was his drift some way back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:158
verses.text: For if the Gentile be on this score inexcusable, because, when the creation led him on and his own reasonings, he yet did not amend, much more were the Jew so, who besides these had the teaching of the Law also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:159
verses.text: Having then persuaded him to a ready admission of these reasonings, in the case of other men's sins, he now compels him even against his will to do so in the case of his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:160
verses.text: And in order that what he says may be more readily allowed, he leads him forward with the better things also in view, speaking on this wise: "But glory and honor and peace to every man that worketh good, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:161
verses.text: For here whatever good things a man hath, he hath with fightings, even if he be rich, if a prince, if a king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:162
verses.text: Even if he be not at variance with others, yet is he often so with himself, and has abundant war in his own thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:163
verses.text: But there it is no such thing, but all is still and void of trouble, and in possession of true peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:164
verses.text: Having then made good from what was said above, that they too which have not the Law are to enjoy the same blessings, he adds his reason in the following words:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:165
verses.text: "For there is no respect of persons with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:166
verses.text: For when he says that as well the Jew as the Gentile is punished if he sin, he needs no reasonings: but when he wants to prove that the Gentile is honored also, he then needs a foundation for it also; as it seemed wonderful and extravagant if he who had heard neither Law nor Prophets, were to be honored upon his working good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:167
verses.text: And this is why (as I also said before) he exercises their hearing in the times before grace, that he might afterwards more treatably bring in, along with the faith, the acquiescence in these things also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:168
verses.text: For here he is not at all suspected, as seeming not to be making his own point good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:169
verses.text: Having then said, "Glory and honor and peace to every man that worketh good, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile," he adds, "For there is no respect of persons with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:170
verses.text: Wonderful! What more than victory has he gained! For he shows, by reducing it to an absurdity, that it was not meet with God that it should be otherwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:171
verses.text: For it would then be a case of respecting of persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:172
verses.text: But of such character God is not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:173
verses.text: And he does not say, "for if this were not so, God would be a respecter of persons," but with more of dignity, "For there is no respect of persons with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:174
verses.text: That it is not quality of persons, but difference of actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:175
verses.text: Which He maketh inquisition for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:176
verses.text: By so saying he shows that it was not in actions but in persons only that the Jew differed from the Gentile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:177
verses.text: The consequence of this would be thus expressed; For it is not because one is a Jew and the other a Gentile, that one is honored and the other disgraced, but it is from the works that either treatment comes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:178
verses.text: But he does not say so, since it would have roused the anger of the Jew, but he sets down something more, so bringing their haughty spirit yet lower, and quelling it for the admission of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:179
verses.text: But what is this? The next position.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:180
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:181
verses.text: "For as many," he says, "as have sinned without law shall also perish without law: and as many as have sinned in the law shall be judged by the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:182
verses.text: For here, as I said before, he shows not only the equality of the Jew and the Gentile, but that the Jew was even much burdened by the gift of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:183
verses.text: For the Gentile is judged without law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:184
verses.text: But this "without law" (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:185
verses.text: lawlessly) here expresses not the worse plight but the easier, that is, he has not the Law to accuse him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:186
verses.text: For "without law" (that is, without the condemnation arising from it), is he condemned solely from the reasonings of nature, but the Jew, "in the Law," that is, with nature and the Law too to accuse him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:187
verses.text: For the greater the attention he enjoyed, the greater the punishment he will suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:188
verses.text: See how much greater is the necessity which he lays upon the Jews of a speedy recourse to grace! For in that they said, they needed not grace, being justified by the Law, he shows that they need it more than the Gentiles, considering they are liable to be punished more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:189
verses.text: Then he adds another reason again, and so farther contends for what has been said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:190
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:191
verses.text: "For not the hearers of the law are just before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:192
verses.text: Well doth he add "before God;" for haply before men they may be able to appear dignified and to vaunt great things, but before God it is quite otherwise—the doers of the Law alone are justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:193
verses.text: You see with what advantage he combats, by turning what they said to an opposite bearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:194
verses.text: For if it is by the Law you claim to be saved, in this respect, saith he, the Gentile will stand before you, when seen to be a doer of what is written in the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:195
verses.text: And how is it possible (one may say) for one who hath not heard to be a doer? Not this only, he says, is possible, but what is much more even than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:196
verses.text: For not only is it possible without hearing to be a doer, but even with hearing not to be so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:197
verses.text: Which last thing he makes plainer, and that with a greater advantage over them, when he says, "Thou that teachest another, teachest thou not thyself?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:198
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:199
verses.text: ) But here he is still making the former point good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:200
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:201
verses.text: "For when the Gentiles," he says, "which have not the law, do by nature the things contained in the law, these, having not the law, are a law unto themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:202
verses.text: I am not, he means, rejecting the Law, but even on this score I justify the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:203
verses.text: You see how when undermining the conceit of Judaism, he giveth no handle against himself as villifying the Law, but on the contrary by extolling it and showing its greatness he so makes good his whole position.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:204
verses.text: But whenever he saith "by nature," he means by the reasonings of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:205
verses.text: And he shows that others are better than they, and, what is more better for this, that they have not received the Law, and have not that wherein the Jews seem to have an advantage over them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:206
verses.text: For on this ground he means they are to be admired, because they required not a law, and yet exhibited all the doings of the Law, having the works, not the letters, graven upon their minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:207
verses.text: For this is what he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:208
verses.text: "Which show the work of the Law written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness, and their thoughts the meanwhile accusing or else excusing one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:209
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:210
verses.text: "In the day when God shall judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:211
verses.text: See how he again puts that day before them, and brings it close to them, battering down their conceit, and showing, that those were to be the rather honored who without the Law strove earnestly to fulfil the things of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:212
verses.text: But what is most to be marvelled at in the discretion of the Apostle, it is worth while to mention now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:213
verses.text: For having shown, from the grounds given, that the Gentile is greater than the Jew; in the inference, and the conclusion of his reasoning, he does not state it, in order not to exasperate the Jew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:214
verses.text: But to make what I have said clearer, I will give the very words of the Apostle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:215
verses.text: For after saying, that it is not the hearers of the Law, but the doers of the Law, that shall be justified, it followed to say, "For when the Gentiles, which have not the Law, do by nature the things contained in the Law," they are much better than those who are instructed by the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:216
verses.text: But this he does not say, but he stays at the encomium of the Gentiles, and does not yet awhile carry on his discourse by way of comparison, that so at least the Jew may receive what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:217
verses.text: And so he does not word it as I was doing, but how? "For when the Gentiles, which have not the Law, do by nature the things contained in the Law, these, not having the Law, are a law unto themselves; which show the work of the Law, written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:218
verses.text: For the conscience and reason doth suffice in the Law's stead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:219
verses.text: By this he showed, first, that God made man independent, so as to be able to choose virtue and to avoid vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:220
verses.text: And be not surprised that he proves this point, not once or twice, but several times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:221
verses.text: For this topic was very needful for him to prove owing to those who say, Why ever is it, that Christ came but now? And where in times before was the (most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:222
verses.text: this mighty) scheme of Providence? Now it is these that he is at present beating off by the way, when he shows that even in former times, and before the Law was given, the human race (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:223
verses.text: nature) fully enjoyed the care of Providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:224
verses.text: For "that which may be known of God was manifest in them," and they knew what was good, and what bad; by means whereof they judged others, which he reproaches them with, when he says, "wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:225
verses.text: But in the case of the Jews, besides what has been mentioned, there was the Law, and not reason or conscience only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:226
verses.text: And why does he put the words "accusing or else excusing?"—for, if they have a Law written, and show the work of it in them, how comes reason to be able to accuse them still? But he is not any longer speaking of those only who do well, but also of mankind (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:227
verses.text: the nature) universally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:228
verses.text: For then our reasonings stand up, some accusing and some excusing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:229
verses.text: And at that tribunal a man needeth no other accuser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:230
verses.text: Then to add to their fear, he does not say the sins of men, but the secrets of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:231
verses.text: For since he said, "Thinkest thou, that judgest them that do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God;" that thou mayest not expect such a sentence as thou passest thyself, but mayest know, that that of God is far more exact than thine own, he brings in, "the secrets of men," and adds, "through Jesus Christ according to my Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:232
verses.text: For men sit in judgment upon overt acts alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:233
verses.text: And above too he spake of the Father alone, but as soon as he had crushed them with fear, he brought in the mention of Christ also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:234
verses.text: But he does not do barely this, but even here, after having made mention of the Father, he so introduceth Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:235
verses.text: And by the same things he raises the dignity of his preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:236
verses.text: For this preaching, he means, openly speaks out what nature taught by anticipation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:237
verses.text: Do you see with what wisdom he has bound them both to the Gospel and to Christ, and demonstrated that our affairs come not here to a stand, but travel further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:238
verses.text: And this he made good before also, when he said, "thou treasurest up to thyself wrath against the day of wrath:" and here again, "God shall judge the secrets of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:239
verses.text: Now let each man enter into his own conscience, and reckoning up his transgressions, let him call himself to a strict account, that we be not then condemned with the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:240
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:241
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:242
verses.text: ) For fearful is that court, awful the tribunal, full of trembling the accounts, a river of fire rolls along (ἕλκεται).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:243
verses.text: "A brother doth not redeem: shall man redeem?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:244
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:245
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:246
verses.text: ) Call then to mind what is said in the Gospel, the Angels running to and fro, of the bridechamber being shut, of the lamps going out, of the powers which drag to the furnaces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:247
verses.text: And consider this, that if a secret deed of any one of us were brought forth into the midst, to-day, before the Church only, what could he do but pray to perish, and to have the earth to gape for him, rather than have so many witnesses of his wickedness? How then shall we feel, when, before the whole world, all things are brought into the midst, in a theatre so bright and open, with both those known and those unknown to us seeing into everything? But alas! wherewith am I forced to affright you! with men's estimation! when I ought to use the fear of God, and His condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:248
verses.text: For what, pray, is to become of us then when bound, and gnashing our teeth, we are led away to the outer darkness? Or, rather, what shall we do (and this is the most fearful thought of all) when we offend (προσκρούσωμεν) God? For if any one have sense and reason, he has already endured a hell when he is out of sight of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:249
verses.text: But since this doth not pain, fire is therefore threatened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:250
verses.text: For we ought to smart not when we are punished, but when we sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:251
verses.text: Thus listen to Paul wailing and lamenting over sins, for which he was not to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:252
verses.text: For "I am not meet," he says, "to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:253
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:254
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:255
verses.text: ) Hear also David, when he is set free from the punishment, yet, as thinking that he had offended God, calling vengeance down upon himself, and saying, "Let thy hand be upon me and upon my father's house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:256
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:257
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:258
verses.text: ) For to have offended God is more distressing than to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:259
verses.text: But now we are so wretchedly disposed, that, were there no fear of hell, we should not even choose readily to do any good thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:260
verses.text: Wherefore were it for nothing else, yet for this at least, we should deserve hell, because we fear hell more than Christ (several mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:261
verses.text: God).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:262
verses.text: But not so the blessed Paul, but contrariwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:263
verses.text: But since we feel otherwise, for this reason are we condemned to hell: since, did we but love Christ as we should love Him, we should have known that to offend Him we love were more painful than hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:264
verses.text: But since we love Him not, we know not the greatness of His punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:265
verses.text: And this is what I bewail and grieve over the most! And yet what has God not done, to be beloved of us? What hath He not devised? What hath He omitted? We insulted Him, when He had not wronged us in aught, but had even benefited us with blessings countless and unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:266
verses.text: We have turned aside from Him when calling and drawing us to Him by all ways, yet hath He not even upon this punished us, but hath run Himself unto us, and held us back, when fleeing, and we have shaken Him off and leaped away to the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:267
verses.text: And not even on this hath He stood aloof, but hath sent numberless messengers to call us to Him again, Prophets, Angels, Patriarchs: and we have not only not received the embassy, but have even insulted those that came.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:268
verses.text: But not even for this did He spew us out of His mouth, but like those slighted lovers that be very earnest, He went round beseeching all, the heaven, the earth, Jeremiah, Micah, and that not that He might weigh us down, but that He might speak in behalf of His own ways (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:269
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:270
verses.text: ; Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:271
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:272
verses.text: ; iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:273
verses.text: ; etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:274
verses.text: ; Mic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:275
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:276
verses.text: ): and along with the prophets He went also Himself to those that turned aside from Him, being ready to submit to examination, and deigning to condescend to a conference, and drawing them that were deaf to every appeal into a disputation with Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:277
verses.text: For He saith, "O my people, what have I done unto thee, and wherein have I wearied thee? Answer me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:278
verses.text: (Mic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:279
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:280
verses.text: ) After all this we killed the Prophets, we stoned them, we did them other cruel wrongs without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:281
verses.text: What then? In their place He sent no longer Prophets, no longer Angels, no longer Patriarchs, but the Son Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:282
verses.text: He too was killed when He had come, and yet not even then did He quench His love, but kindled it even more, and keepeth on beseeching us, after even His own Son was killed, and entreating us, and doing all things to turn us unto Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:283
verses.text: And Paul crieth aloud, saying, "Now then we are ambassadors for Christ, as though God did beseech you by us: be ye reconciled to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:284
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:285
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:286
verses.text: ) None of these things however reconciled us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:287
verses.text: Yet not even then did He leave us, but keeps on both threatening hell, and promising a kingdom, that even so He may draw us unto Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:288
verses.text: But we be still in an insensible mood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:289
verses.text: What can be worse than this brutishness? For had a man done these things, should we not many times over have let ourselves become slaves to him? But God when doing so we turn us away from! O what listlessness! O what unfeelingness! We that live continually in sins and wickednesses, if we happen to do any little good, like unfeeling domestics, with what a niggardly spirit do we exact it, and how particular are we about the recompense made, if what we have done has any recompense to come of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:290
verses.text: And yet the recompense is the greater if you do it without any hope of reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:291
verses.text: Why saying all this, and making exact reckoning, is language fitter for an hireling than a domestic of willing mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:292
verses.text: For we ought to do everything for Christ's sake, not for the reward, but for Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:293
verses.text: For this also was why He threatened hell and promised the kingdom, that He might be loved of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:294
verses.text: Let us then so love Him as we ought to love Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:295
verses.text: For this is the great reward, this is royalty and pleasure, this is enjoyment, and glory, and honor, this is light, this is the great happiness, which language (or reasoning) cannot set before us, nor mind conceive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:296
verses.text: Yet indeed I do not know how I was led so far in this way of speaking, and came to be exhorting men who do not even think slightly of power and glory here for Christ's sake, to think slightly of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:297
verses.text: Yet still those great and noble men even attained to this measure of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:298
verses.text: Hear, for instance, how Peter burns with love towards Him, setting Him before soul, and life, and all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:299
verses.text: And when he had denied Him, it was not the punishment he was grieved for, but that he had denied Him Whom he longed for, which was more bitter to him than any punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:300
verses.text: And all this did he show before the grace of the Spirit was given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:301
verses.text: And he perseveringly pressed the question, "Whither goest thou?" (John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:302
verses.text: ) and before this; "To whom shall we go?" (vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:303
verses.text: ); and again; "I will follow Thee whithersoever Thou goest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:304
verses.text: (Luke xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:305
verses.text: ?) Thus He was all things to them, and neither heaven nor the kingdom of heaven did they count of, in comparison of Him they longed for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:306
verses.text: For Thou art all these things unto me, he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:307
verses.text: And why doest thou marvel that Peter was so minded? Hear now what the Prophet says: "What have I in heaven, and what is there upon earth, that I should desire in comparison of Thee?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:308
verses.text: lxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:309
verses.text: ) Now what he means is nearly this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:310
verses.text: Neither of things above nor of things below desire I any, save Thee only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:311
verses.text: This is passion; this is love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:312
verses.text: Can we so love, it will not be things present only, but even things to come, which we shall reckon as nothing compared with that love-charm, and even here shall we enjoy the Kingdom, delighting ourselves in the love of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:313
verses.text: And how is this to be? one may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:314
verses.text: Let us reflect how oft we insult Him after numberless goodnesses, yet He standeth and calleth us to Him, and how often we run by Him, but He still doth not overlook us, but runneth to us, and draweth us to Him, and catcheth us in unto Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:315
verses.text: For if we consider these things, and such as these, we shall be enabled to kindle this longing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:316
verses.text: For if it were a common man that so loved, but a king who was thus beloved, would he not feel a respect for the greatness of the love? Most assuredly he would.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:317
verses.text: But when the case is reversed, and His Beauty (S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:318
verses.text: "that beauty") is unspeakable, and the glory and the riches too of Him that loveth us, and our vileness so great, surely we deserve the utmost punishment, vile as we are and outcasts, who are treated with so exceeding great love by One so great and wonderful, and yet wax wanton against His love? He needeth not anything of ours, and yet He doth not even now cease loving us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:319
verses.text: We need much what is His, and for all that we cleave not unto His love, but money we value above Him, and man's friendship, and ease of body, and power, and fame, before Him who valueth nothing more than us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:320
verses.text: For He had One Son, Very (Lit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:321
verses.text: "true-born") and Only-Begotten, and He spared not even Him for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:322
verses.text: But we value many things above Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:323
verses.text: Were there not then good reason for a hell and torment, even were it twofold or threefold or manifold what it is? For what can we have to say for ourselves, if even Satan's injunctions we value more than the Laws of Christ, and are reckless of our own salvation that we may choose the works of wickedness, before Him who suffered all things for us? And what pardon do these things deserve? what excuse have they? Not one even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:324
verses.text: ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:325
verses.text: οὐδὲ μιἵς.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 6:326
verses.text: ) Let us stop then after this in our headlong course, and let us grow again sober; and reckoning up all these things, let us send up glory unto Him by our works (for words alone suffice not thereto), that we may also enjoy the glory that cometh of Him, which may we all attain unto by the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom, and with Whom, to the Father be glory, with the Holy Spirit, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:3
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:4
verses.text: ,  "Behold,thou art called a Jew, and restest in the Law, and makest thy boast of God, and knowest His will, and approvest the things that are more excellent, being instructed out of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:5
verses.text: After saying that the Gentile wanteth nothing appertaining to salvation if he be a doer of the Law, and after making that wonderful comparison, he goes on to set down the glories of the Jews, owing to which they thought scorn of the Gentiles: and first the very name itself, which was of great majesty, as the name Christian is now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:6
verses.text: For even then the distinction which the appellation made was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:7
verses.text: And so he begins from this, and see how he takes it down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:8
verses.text: For he does not say, Behold, thou art a Jew, but "art called" so, "and makest thy boast in God;" that is, as being loved by Him, and honored above all other men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:9
verses.text: And here he seems to me to be gently mocking their unreasonableness, and great madness after glory, because they misused this gift not to their own salvation, but to set themselves up against the rest of mankind, and to despise them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:10
verses.text: "And knowest His will, and approvest the things that are more excellent".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:11
verses.text: Indeed this is a disadvantage, if without working: yet still it seemed to be an advantage, and so he states it with accuracy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:12
verses.text: For he does not say, thou doest, but knowest; and approvest, not followest and doest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:13
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:14
verses.text: "And art confident that thou thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:15
verses.text: Here again he does not say that thou art "a guide of the blind," but "thou art confident," so thou boastest, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:16
verses.text: So great was the unreasonableness of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:17
verses.text: Wherefore he also repeats nearly the very words, which they used in their boastings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:18
verses.text: See for instance what they say in the Gospels.
