verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:19
verses.text: "Thou wast altogether (ὅλος  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:20
verses.text: ὅλως) born in sin, and dost thou teach us?" (John ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:21
verses.text: ) And all men they utterly looked down upon, to convince them of which, Paul keeps extolling them and lowering the others, that so he may get more hold on them, and make his accusation the weightier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:22
verses.text: Wherefore he goes on adding the like things, and making more of them by different ways of relating them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:23
verses.text: For "Thou art confident," he saith, "that thou thyself art a leader of the blind,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:24
verses.text: "An instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes, which hast the form of knowledge and truth, which is in the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:25
verses.text: Here again he says not, in the conscience and in actions and in well-doings, but "in the Law;" and after saying so, he does here also what he did with regard to the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:26
verses.text: For as there he says, "for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself," so saith he here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:27
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:28
verses.text: "Thou therefore which teachest another, teachest thou not thyself?"  But there he frames his speech with more of sharpness, here with more of gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:29
verses.text: For he does not say, However on this score thou deservest greater punishment, because though entrusted with so great things thou hast not made a good use of any of them, but he carries his discourse on by way of question, turning them on themselves (ἐντρέπων), and saying, "Thou that teachest another, teachest thou not thyself?" And here I would have you look at the discretion of Paul in another case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:30
verses.text: For he sets down such advantages of the Jews, as came not of their own earnestness, but by a gift from above, and he shows not only that they are worthless to them if neglectful, but that they even bring with them increase of punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:31
verses.text: For neither is the being called a Jew any well doing of theirs, nor yet is the receiving of the Law, nor the other things he has just enumerated, but of the grace from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:32
verses.text: And towards the beginning he had said, that the hearing of the Law is valueless unless the doing be thereto added ("for not the hearers of the Law," he says, "are just before God,") but now he shows further still, that not only the hearing, but, what is more than the hearing, the teaching of the Law itself will not be able to screen the teacher, unless he do what he says; and not only will it not screen him, but will even punish him the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:33
verses.text: And he has used his expressions well too, since he does not say, Thou hast received the Law, but "Thou restest in the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:34
verses.text: For the Jew was not wearied with going about to seek what was to be done, but had on easy terms the Law pointing the way leading to virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:35
verses.text: For if even the Gentiles have natural reason (and it is on this ground that these are better than they, in that they do the Law without hearing), yet still the others had greater facility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:36
verses.text: But if you say, I am not only a hearer, but even a teacher, this very thing is an aggravation of your punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:37
verses.text: For because they prided themselves upon this, from this above all he shows them to be ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:38
verses.text: But when he says, "a guide of the blind, an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes," he is speaking their own pompous language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:39
verses.text: For they treated proselytes extremely ill, and these were the names they called them by.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:40
verses.text: And this is why he dwells at large upon what were supposed to be their praises, well knowing that what was said gave ground for greater accusation; "Which hast the form of knowledge and of the truth in the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:41
verses.text: As if any one who had a picture of the king, were to draw nothing after it, and they that were not entrusted with it were to imitate it exactly even without the original.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:42
verses.text: And then after mentioning the advantages they had from God, he tells them of their failings, bringing forward what the prophets accused them of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:43
verses.text: "Thou therefore which teachest another, teachest thou not thyself? Thou that preachest a man should not steal, dost thou steal? Thou that sayest a man should not commit adultery, dost thou commit adultery? Thou that abhorrest idols, dost thou commit sacrilege?" For it was strictly forbidden them to touch any of the treasures upon the idols (so Field from the mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:44
verses.text: : Vulg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:45
verses.text: "in the idol temples") by reason of the defilement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:46
verses.text: But the tyranny of avarice, he says, has persuaded you ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:47
verses.text: and mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:48
verses.text: "us") to trample this Law also under foot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:49
verses.text: Then he brings the far more grievous charge afterwards, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:50
verses.text: "Thou that makest a boast in the Law through breaking the Law dishonorest thou God?"  There are two accusations which he makes, or rather three.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:51
verses.text: Both that they dishonor, and dishonor that whereby they were honored; and that they dishonor Him that honored them, which was the utmost extreme of unfeelingness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:52
verses.text: And then, not to seem to be accusing them of his own mind, he brings in the Prophet as their accuser, here briefly and concisely as it were in a summary, but afterwards more in detail, and here Isaiah, and after that David, when he had shown the grounds of reproof to be more than one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:53
verses.text: For to show, he means, that it is not I who speak these things to your reproach, hear what Isaiah saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:55
verses.text: "For the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles through you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:56
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:57
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:58
verses.text: ; Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:59
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:60
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:61
verses.text: )  See again another double accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:62
verses.text: For they not only commit insolence themselves, but even induce others to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:63
verses.text: What then is the use of your teaching when ye teach not your own selves? Above, however, he merely said this, but here he has even turned it round to the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:64
verses.text: For not only yourselves, but even others, do ye not teach what should be done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:65
verses.text: And what is far worse—ye not only teach not the things of the Law, but ye even teach the opposite, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:66
verses.text: to blaspheme God, which is opposite to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:67
verses.text: But the circumcision, one will say, is a great thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:68
verses.text: Yea, I also confess it, but when? when (So all mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:69
verses.text: S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:70
verses.text: "then, when") it hath the inward circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:71
verses.text: And observe his judgment, in bringing in what he says about it so opportunely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:72
verses.text: For he did not begin straightway with it, since the conceit men had of it was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:73
verses.text: But after he had shown them to have offended in that which was greater and to be responsible for the blasphemy against God, then having henceforth possession of the reader's judgment against them, and having stripped them of their pre-eminence, he introduces the discussion about circumcision, feeling sure that no one will any more advocate it, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:74
verses.text: "For circumcision verily profiteth, if thou keep the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:75
verses.text: And yet, were this not so, a man might have rejected it and said, What is circumcision? for is it any good deed on his part that hath it? is it any manifestation of a right choice? For it takes place at an unripe age, and those in the wilderness too remained uncircumcised for a long time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:76
verses.text: And from many other points of view also, one might look at it as not necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:77
verses.text: And yet it is not on this foot that he rejects it, but upon the most proper ground, from the case of Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:78
verses.text: For this is the most exceeding victory,—to take the very reason for showing it to be of small regard, whence it was held by them in reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:79
verses.text: Now he might have said that even the prophets call the Jews uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:80
verses.text: But this is no disparagement of circumcision, but of those that hold ill to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:81
verses.text: For what he aims at is to show that even in the very best life, it has not the least force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:82
verses.text: This is what he next proves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:83
verses.text: And here he does not bring forward the Patriarch, but having previously overturned it upon other grounds, he keeps him till afterwards, when he brings in what he has to say of faith, on the words—"How then was it reckoned" to Abraham? "when he was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision?" For so long as it is struggling against the Gentile and the uncircumcised, he is unwilling to say aught of this, lest he should be over irksome to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:84
verses.text: But when it comes in opposition to the faith, then he disengages himself more completely for a combat with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:85
verses.text: Up to the present point then it is uncircumcision that the contest is against, and this is why he advances in His discourse in a subdued tone, and says,  "For circumcision verily profiteth if thou keep the Law; but if thou be a breaker of the Law, thy circumcision is made uncircumcision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:86
verses.text: For here he speaks of two uncircumcisions, and two circumcisions, as also two laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:87
verses.text: For there is a natural law and there is a written law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:88
verses.text: But there is one also between these, that by works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:89
verses.text: And see how he points these three out, and brings them before you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:90
verses.text: "For when the Gentiles," he says, "which have not the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:91
verses.text: What Law, say? The written one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:92
verses.text: "Do by nature the things of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:93
verses.text: Of what Law? Of that by works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:94
verses.text: "These having not the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:95
verses.text: What Law? The written one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:96
verses.text: "Are a law unto themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:97
verses.text: How so? By using the natural law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:98
verses.text: "Who show the work of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:99
verses.text: Of what law? Of that by actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:100
verses.text: For that which is by writing lieth outside; but this is within, the natural one, and the other is in actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:101
verses.text: And one the writing proclaims; and another, nature; and another, actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:102
verses.text: Of this third there is need, for the sake of which also those two exist, both the natural and the written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:103
verses.text: And if this be not present they are of no good, but even very great harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:104
verses.text: And to show this in the case of the natural he said, "For wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:105
verses.text: But of the written Law, thus—"Thou that preachest a man should not steal, dost thou steal?" Thus also there are two uncircumcisions, one that of nature, and the second from conduct: and one circumcision in the flesh, and the other from the will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:106
verses.text: I mean for instance, a man has been circumcised upon the eighth day; this is circumcision of the flesh: a man has done all the Law bids him; this is circumcision of the mind which St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:107
verses.text: Paul requires above all, yea rather the Law also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:108
verses.text: See now how having granted it in words, he in deed does away with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:109
verses.text: For he does not say the circumcision is superfluous, the circumcision is of no profit, of no use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:110
verses.text: But what saith he? "Circumcision verily profiteth if thou keepest the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:111
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:112
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:113
verses.text: ; xxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:114
verses.text: ) He approves it so far, saying, I confess and deny not that the circumcision is honorable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:115
verses.text: But when? When it has the Law kept along with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:116
verses.text: "But if thou be a breaker of the Law, thy circumcision is made uncircumcision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:117
verses.text: He does not say, it is no more profitable, lest he should seem to insult it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:118
verses.text: But having stripped the Jew of it, he goes on to smite him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:119
verses.text: And this is no longer any insult to circumcision, but to him who through listlessness has lost the good of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:120
verses.text: As then in the case of those who are in dignified stations and are after convicted of the greatest misdemeanors, the judges deprive them of the honors of their stations and then punish them; so has Paul also done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:121
verses.text: For after saying, if thou art a breaker of the Law, thy "circumcision is made uncircumcision," and having shown him to be uncircumcised, he condemns him after that without scruple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:122
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:123
verses.text: "Therefore if the uncircumcision keep the righteousness of the Law, shall not his uncircumcision be turned into circumcision?"  See how he acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:124
verses.text: He does not say that the uncircumcision overcomes circumcision (for this was highly grating to those who then heard him), but that the uncircumcision hath become circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:125
verses.text: And he next enquires what circumcision is, and what uncircumcision and he says that circumcision is well doing and uncircumcision is evil doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:126
verses.text: And having first transferred into the circumcision the uncircumcised, who has good deeds, and having thrust out the circumcised man that lived a corrupt life into the uncircumcision, he so gives the preference to the uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:127
verses.text: And he does not say, To the uncircumcised, but goes on to the thing itself, speaking as follows: "Shall not his uncircumcision be turned into circumcision?" And he does not say "reckoned," but "turned to," which was more expressive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:128
verses.text: As also above he does not say thy circumcision is reckoned uncircumcision, but has been made so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:130
verses.text: "And shall not the uncircumcision which is by nature judge?"  You see, he recognizes two uncircumcisions, one from nature, and the other from the will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:131
verses.text: Here, however, he speaks of that from nature, but does not pause here, but goes on, "if it fulfil the Law, judge thee, who by the letter and circumcision dost transgress the Law?" See his exquisite judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:132
verses.text: He does not say, that the uncircumcision which is from nature shall judge the circumcision, but while where the victory had been, he brings in the uncircumcision, yet where the defeat is, he does not expose the circumcision as defeated; but the Jew himself who had it, and so by the wording spares offending his hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:133
verses.text: And he does not say, "thee that hast the Law and the circumcision," but yet more mildly, "thee who by the letter and circumcision dost transgress the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:134
verses.text: That is, such uncircumcision even stands up for the circumcision, for it has been wronged and comes to the Law's assistance, for it has been insulted, and obtains a notable triumph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:135
verses.text: For then is the victory decided, when it is not by Jew that Jew is judged, but by the uncircumcised; as when he says, "The men of Nineveh shall rise in judgment against this generation, and shall condemn it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:136
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:137
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:138
verses.text: ) It is not then the Law that he dishonors (for he reverences it greatly), but him that does disgrace to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:139
verses.text: Next, having settled these grounds clearly, he goes on confidently to define what the Jew really is; and he shows that it is not the Jew, nor the circumcision, but he that is no Jew, and uncircumcised, whom he is rejecting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:140
verses.text: And he seemeth indeed to stand up in its behalf, but yet does away with the opinion regarding it, securing men's concurrence by the conclusion he comes to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:141
verses.text: For he shows not only that there is no difference between the Jew and the uncircumcised, but that the uncircumcised has even the advantage, if he take heed to himself, and that it is he that is really the Jew; and so he says:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:142
verses.text: "For he is not a Jew which is one outwardly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:143
verses.text: Here he attacks them as doing all things for show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:144
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:145
verses.text: "But he is a Jew which is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the spirit, and not in the letter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:146
verses.text: By saying this he sets aside all things bodily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:147
verses.text: For the circumcision is outwardly, and the sabbaths and the sacrifices and purifications: all of which he hints in a single word, when he says, "For he is not a Jew which is one outwardly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:148
verses.text: But since much was made of the circumcision, inasmuch as even the sabbath gave way to it (John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:149
verses.text: ), he has good reason for aiming more especially against it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:150
verses.text: But when he has said "in the spirit" he thereafter paves the way for the conversation of the Church, and introduces the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:151
verses.text: For it too is in the heart and spirit and hath its praise of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:152
verses.text: And how cometh he not to show that the Gentile which doeth aright is not inferior to the Jew which doeth aright, but that the Gentile which doeth aright is better than the Jew which breaketh the Law? It was that he might make the victory an undoubted one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:153
verses.text: For when this is agreed upon, of necessity the circumcision of the flesh is set aside, and the need of a good life is everywhere demonstrated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:154
verses.text: For when the Greek is saved without these, but the Jew with these is yet punished, Judaism stands by doing nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:155
verses.text: And by Greek he again means not the idolatrous Greek, but the religous and virtuous, and free from all legal observances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:156
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:157
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:158
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:159
verses.text: "What advantage then hath the Jew?"  Since he has set all aside, the hearing, the teaching, the name of the Jew, the circumcision, and all the other particulars by his saying that "he is not a Jew which is one outwardly, but he which is one inwardly;" he next sees an objection which starts up, and against this makes his stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:160
verses.text: Now what is this objection? If, he means, these things are no use, what reason was there for that nation being called, and the circumcision too being given? What does he then and how does he solve it? By the same means as he did before: for as there, he told, not of their praises, but the benefits of God; nor their well doings (for to be called a Jew and to know His Will and to approve the things which are more excellent, was no well doing of their own, but came of the grace of God: and this the Prophet also says, upbraiding them; "He hath not done so to any nation, neither hath he showed His judgments unto them;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:161
verses.text: cxlvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:162
verses.text: ) and Moses again; "Ask now whether there hath been any such thing as this?" he says, "did ever people hear the voice of God speaking out of the midst of the fire, and live?") (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:163
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:164
verses.text: , ), this then he does here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:165
verses.text: For as, when speaking of circumcision, he did not say, Circumcision is valueless without a good life, but, Circumcision is of value with a good life, pointing out the same thing but in a more subdued tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:166
verses.text: And again he does not say, If thou be a breaker of the Law, thou who art circumcised art no whit profited, but "thy circumcision is made uncircumcision:" and after this again, "the uncircumcision," saith he, shall "judge," not the circumcision, but "thee that dost transgress the Law," so sparing the things of the Law, and smiting the persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:167
verses.text: So he doth here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:168
verses.text: For after setting before himself this objection, and saying, "what advantage then hath the Jew?" he says not, None, but he concurs with the statement, and confutes it again by the sequel, and shows that they were even punished owing to this preëminence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:169
verses.text: And how he does so, I will tell you when I have stated the objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:170
verses.text: "What advantage then," he says, "hath the Jew," or "what profit is there of circumcision?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:171
verses.text: "Much every way: chiefly, because that they were entrusted with the oracles of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:172
verses.text: Do you see that, as I said above, it is not their well doings, but the benefits of God, that he everywhere counts up? And what is the word ἐπιστεύθησαν? (they were trusted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:173
verses.text: ) It means, that they had the Law put into their hands because He held them to be of so much account that He entrusted to them oracles which came down from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:174
verses.text: I know indeed that some take the "entrusted" not of the Jews, but of the oracles, as much as to say, the Law was believed in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:175
verses.text: But the context does not admit of this being held good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:176
verses.text: For in the first place he is saying this with a view to accuse them, and to show that, though in the enjoyment of many a blessing from above, they yet showed great ingratitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:177
verses.text: Then, the context also makes this clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:178
verses.text: For he goes on to say, "For what if some did not believe?" If they did not believe, how do some say, the oracles were believed in? What does he mean then? Why that God entrusted the same to them, and not that they trusted to the oracles: how else will the context make sense? For he farther goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:179
verses.text: "For what if some did not believe?"  And what comes next makes the same point clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:180
verses.text: For he again adds and follows; "Shall their unbelief make the faith of God without effect?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:181
verses.text: "God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:182
verses.text: The word ἐπιστεύθησαν, then, proclaims God's gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:183
verses.text: And I would have you here also note his judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:184
verses.text: For again he does not bring in his accusation of them on his own part, but as it were by way of objection, as if he said, But perhaps you will say, 'What then is the use of this circumcision since they used it not as was fitting, since they were trusted with the Law and were unfaithful to the trust?' And hitherto he is not a severe accuser, but as if to clear God of complaints against Him, he by this means turns the whole of the accusation round upon themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:185
verses.text: For why, he would say, do you complain that they did not believe? and how doth this affect God? For as for His benefit, doth the ingratitude of those benefited overturn it? Or doth it make the honor to be no honor? For this is what the words, "Shall their unfaithfulness make the faith of God without effect," amount to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:186
verses.text: "God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:187
verses.text: As if one should say, I have honored such an one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:188
verses.text: And if he did not receive the honor, this gives no ground for accusing me, nor impairs my kindness, but shows his want of feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:189
verses.text: But Paul does not say this merely, but what is much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:190
verses.text: That not only does their unbelief not leave the soil of complaint upon God, but even shows His honor and love of man to be the greater, in that He is seen to have bestowed honor upon one who would dishonor Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:191
verses.text: See how he has brought them out guilty of misdemeanors by means of what they gloried in; forasmuch as the honor with which God treated them was so great, that even when He saw what would come thereof, He withheld not His good-will toward them! Yet they made the honors bestowed on them a means of insulting Him that Honor them! Next, since he said, "For what if some did not believe?" (while clearly it was all of them that did not believe,) lest by speaking here too as the history allowed him, he should seem to be a severe accuser of them like an enemy, he puts that, which really took place, in the method of reasoning and syllogism, saying as follows: "Yea, let God be true, but every man a liar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:192
verses.text: What he says is something of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:193
verses.text: I do not mean, he says, that some did not believe, but if you will, suppose that all were unbelieving, so waiving what really happened, to fall in with the objector, that he might seem overbearing or to be suspected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:194
verses.text: Well, he says, in this way God is the more justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:195
verses.text: What does the word justified mean? That, if there could be a trial and an examination of the things He had done for the Jews, and of what had been done on their part towards Him, the victory would be with God, and all the right on His side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:196
verses.text: And after showing this clearly from what was said before, he next introduces the Prophet also as giving his approval to these things, and saying, "that Thou mightest be justified in Thy sayings, and clear when Thou art judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:197
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:198
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:199
verses.text: ) He then for His part did everything, but they were nothing the better even for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:200
verses.text: Then he brings forward after this another objection that arises, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:201
verses.text: "But if our unrighteousness commend the righteousness of God, what shall we say? is God unrighteous Who taketh vengeance? I speak as a man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:202
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:203
verses.text: "God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:204
verses.text: He solves one perplexity by another again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:205
verses.text: Yet as this is not clear, we must needs declare it more clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:206
verses.text: What is it then he means? God honored the Jews: they did despite to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:207
verses.text: This gives Him the victory, and shows the greatness of His love towards man, in that He honored them even such as they were.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:208
verses.text: Since then, he means, we did despite to Him and wronged Him, God by this very thing became victorious, and His righteousness was shown to be clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:209
verses.text: Why then (a man may say) am I to be punished, who have been the cause of His victory by the despite I did Him? Now how does he meet this? It is, as I was saying, by another absurdity again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:210
verses.text: For if it were you, he says, that were the cause of the victory, and after this are punished, the thing is an act of injustice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:211
verses.text: But if He is not unjust, and yet you are punished, then you are no more the cause of the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:212
verses.text: And note his apostolic reverence; (or caution: εὐλάβεια); for after saying, "Is God unrighteous Who taketh vengeance?" he adds, "I speak as a man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:213
verses.text: As if, he means, any body were to argue in the way men reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:214
verses.text: For what things seem with us to be justice, these the just judgment of God far exceedeth, and has certain other unspeakable grounds for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:215
verses.text: Next, since it was indistinct, he says the same thing over again:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:216
verses.text: "For if the truth of God hath more abounded through my lie unto His glory: why yet am I also judged as a sinner?"  For if God, he means is shown to be a Lover of man, and righteous, and good, by your acts of disobedience, you ought not only to be exempt from punishment but even to have good done unto you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:217
verses.text: But if so, that absurdity will be found to result, which is in circulation with so many, that good comes of evil, and that evil is the cause of good; and one of the two is necessary, either that He be clearly unjust in punishing, or that if He punish not, it is from our vices that He hath the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:218
verses.text: And both of these are absurd to a degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:219
verses.text: And himself meaning to show this too, he introduces the Greeks (i-e: heathens) as the fathers of these opinions, thinking it enough to allege against what he has mentioned the character of the persons who say these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:220
verses.text: For then they used to say in ridicule of us, "let us do evil that good may come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:221
verses.text: And this is why he has stated it clearly in the following language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:222
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:223
verses.text: "If not (as some affirm that we say,) Let us do evil that good may come? Whose damnation is just".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:224
verses.text: For whereas Paul said, "where sin abounded grace did much more abound" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:225
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:226
verses.text: ), in ridicule of him and perverting what he said to another meaning, they said, We must cling to vice that we may get what is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:227
verses.text: But Paul said not so; however to correct this notion it is that he says, "What then? shall we continue in sin that grace may abound? God forbid!" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:228
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:229
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:230
verses.text: ) For I said it, he means, of the times which are past, not that we should make this a practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:231
verses.text: To lead them away then from this suspicion, he said, that henceforth this was even impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:232
verses.text: For "how shall we," he says, "that are dead unto sin, live any longer therein?" Against the Greeks then he inveighs (κατέδραμεν) without difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:233
verses.text: For their life was exceeding abandoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:234
verses.text: But of the Jews, even if their life seemed to have been careless, still they had great means of cloaking these things in the Law and circumcision, and the fact of God having conversed with them, and their being the teachers of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:235
verses.text: And this is why he strips them even of these, and shows that for these they were the more punished, and this is the conclusion to which he has here drawn his discussion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:236
verses.text: For if they be not punished, he would say, for so doing, that blasphemous language—let us do evil that good may come—must necessarily gain currency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:237
verses.text: But if this be impious, and they who hold this language shall be punished (for this he declared by saying, "whose damnation is just"), it is plain that they are punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:238
verses.text: For if they who speak it be deserving of vengeance, much more are they who act it, but if deserving thereof, it is as having done sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:239
verses.text: For it is not man that punishes them, that any one should suspect the sentence, but God, that doeth all things righteously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:240
verses.text: But if they are righteously punished, it is unrighteously that they, who make ridicule of us, said what they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:241
verses.text: For God did and doth everything, that our conversation might shine forth and be upright on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:242
verses.text: Let us then not be listless; for so we shall be able to recover the Greeks also from their error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:243
verses.text: But when we are in words lovers of wisdom, but in deeds behave unseemly, with what looks shall we face them? with what lips shall we discourse concerning doctrines? For he will say to each of us, How can you that have failed in what is less, claim to teach me about what is greater? you who as yet have not learnt that covetousness is a vice, how can you be wise upon the things in heaven? But do you know that it is a vice? Then, the charge is the greater, because you transgress knowingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:244
verses.text: And why speak I of the Greek, for even our laws allow us not to speak thus boldly when our life has become abandoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:245
verses.text: For to "the sinner," it says, "saith God, what hast thou to do to declare my statutes?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:246
verses.text: l.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:247
verses.text: ) There was a time when the Jews were carried away captive, and when the Persians were urgent with them, and called upon them to sing those divine songs unto them, they said, "How shall we sing the Lord's song in a strange land?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:248
verses.text: cxxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:249
verses.text: ) Now if it were un lawful to sing the oracles of God in a strange land, much less might the estranged soul do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:250
verses.text: For estranged the merciless soul is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:251
verses.text: If the Law made those who were captives and had become slaves to men in a strange land, to sit in silence; much more is it right for those who are slaves to sin and are in an alien community (πολιτεί& ·) to have a curb upon their mouths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:252
verses.text: And however they had their instruments then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:253
verses.text: For it says, "Upon the willows in the midst thereof did we hang our instruments," but still they might not sing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:254
verses.text: And so we also, though we have a mouth and tongue, which are instruments of speech, have no right to speak boldly, so long as we be slaves to what is more tyrannical than any barbarian, sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:255
verses.text: For tell me what have you to say to the Greek, if you plunder, and be covetous? will you say, Forsake idolatry, acknowledge God, and draw not near to gold and silver? Will he not then make a jest of you, and say, Talk to thyself first in this way? For it is not the same thing for a Gentile to practise idolatry, and a Christian to commit this same ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:256
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:257
verses.text: "same") sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:258
verses.text: For how are we to draw others away from that idolatry if we draw not ourselves away from this? For we are nearer related to ourselves than our neighbor is, and so when we persuade not ourselves, how are we to persuade others? For if he that doth not rule well over his own house, will not take care of the Church either ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:259
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:260
verses.text: ), how shall he that doth not rule even over his own soul be able to set others right? Now do not tell me, that you do not worship an image of gold, but make this clear to me, that you do not do those things which gold bids you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:261
verses.text: For there be different kinds of idolatry, and one holds mammon lord, and another his belly his god, and a third some other most baneful lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:262
verses.text: But, "you do not sacrifice oxen to them as the Gentiles do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:263
verses.text: Nay, but what is far worse, you butcher your own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:264
verses.text: But "you do not bow the knee and worship".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:265
verses.text: Nay, but with greater obedience you do all that they command you, whether it be your belly, or money, or the tyranny of lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:266
verses.text: For this is just what makes Gentiles disgusting, that they made gods of our passions; calling lust Venus, and anger Mars, and drunkenness Bacchus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:267
verses.text: If then you do not grave images as did they, yet do you with great eagerness bow under the very same passions, when you make the members of Christ members of an harlot, and plunge yourself into the other deeds of iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:268
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:269
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:270
verses.text: ) I therefore exhort you to lay to heart the exceeding unseemliness hereof, and to flee from idolatry:—for so doth Paul name covetousness—and to flee not only covetousness in money, but that in evil desire, and that in clothing, and that in food, and that in everything else: since the punishment we shall have to suffer if we obey not God's laws is much severer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:271
verses.text: For, He says, "the servant that knew his Lord's will," and did it not, "shall be beaten with many stripes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:272
verses.text: (Luke xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:273
verses.text: ) With a view then to escaping from this punishment, and being useful both to others and to ourselves, let us drive out all iniquity from our soul and choose virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 7:274
verses.text: For so shall we attain to the blessings which are to come, whereto may it be granted us all to attain by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:3
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:4
verses.text: –  "What then have we morethan they?For we have proved both Jews and Gentiles, that they are all under sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:5
verses.text: As it is written, There is none righteous, no, not one: there is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:6
verses.text: They are all gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no not one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:7
verses.text: Their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues have they used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips; whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness: their feet are swift to shed blood: destruction and misery are in their ways: and the way of peace have they not known: there is no fear of God before their eyes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:8
verses.text: He had accused the Gentiles, he had accused the Jews; it came next in order to mention the righteousness which is by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:9
verses.text: For if the law of nature availed not, and the written Law was of no advantage, but both weighed down those that used them not aright, and made it plain that they were worthy of greater punishment, then after this the salvation which is by grace was necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:10
verses.text: Speak then of it, O Paul, and display it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:11
verses.text: But as yet he does not venture, as having an eye to the violence of the Jews, and so turns afresh to his accusation of them; and first he brings in as accuser, David speaking of the same things at length, which Isaiah mentioned all in short compass, so furnishing a strong curb for them, so that they might not bound off, nor any of his hearers, while the matters of faith were laid open to them, might after this start away; being beforehand safely held down by the accusations of the prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:12
verses.text: For there are three excesses which the prophet lays down; he says that all of them together did evil, and that they did not do good indifferently with evil, but that they followed after wickedness alone, and followed it also with all earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:13
verses.text: And next that they should not say, "What then, if these things were said to others?" he goes on:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:14
verses.text: "Now we know that what things soever the Law saith, it saith to them who are under the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:15
verses.text: This then is why, next to Isaiah, who confessedly aimed at them, he brought in David; that he might show that these things also belonged to the same subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:16
verses.text: For what need was there, he means, that a prophet who was sent for your correction should accuse other people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:17
verses.text: For neither was the Law given to any else than you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:18
verses.text: And for what reason did he not say, we know that what things soever the prophet saith, but what things soever the Law saith? It is because Paul uses to call the whole Old Testament the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:19
verses.text: And in another place he says, "Do ye not hear the Law, that Abraham had two sons?" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:20
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:21
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:22
verses.text: ) And here he calls the Psalm the Law when he says, "We know that what things soever the Law saith, it saith to them who are under the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:23
verses.text: Next he shows that neither are these things he said merely for accusation's sake, but that he may again be paving the way for faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:24
verses.text: So close is the relationship of the Old Testament with the New, since even the accusations and reproofs were entirely with a view to this, that the door of faith might open brightly upon them that hear it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:25
verses.text: For since it was the principal bane of the Jews that they were so conceited with themselves (which thing he mentioned as he went on, "how that being ignorant of the righteousness of God, and going about to establish their own righteousness, they submitted not themselves to the righteousness of God") (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:26
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:27
verses.text: ), the Law and the Prophet by being beforehand with them cast down their high thoughts, and laid low their conceit, that being brought to a consideration of their own sins, and having emptied out the whole of their unreasonableness, and seen themselves in danger of the last extremity, they might with much earnestness run unto Him Who offered them the remission of their sins, and accept grace through faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:28
verses.text: And this it is then which St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:29
verses.text: Paul hints even here, when he says,  "Now we know that what things soever the Law saith, it saith to them who are under the Law, that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world may become guilty before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:30
verses.text: Here then he exhibits them as destitute of the boldness of speech which comes of works, and only using a parade of words and behaving in a barefaced way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:31
verses.text: And this is why he uses so literal an expression, saying, "that every mouth may be stopped," so pointing out the barefaced and almost uncontrollable pomposity of their language, and that their tongue was now curbed in the strictest sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:32
verses.text: For as an unsupportable torrent, so had it been borne along.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:33
verses.text: But the prophet stopped it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:34
verses.text: And when Paul saith, "that every mouth may be stopped," what he means is, not that the reason of their sinning was that their mouth might be stopped, but that the reason of their being reproved was that they might not commit this very sin in ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:35
verses.text: "And all the world may become guilty before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:36
verses.text: He does not say the Jew, but the whole of mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:37
verses.text: For the phrase, "that every mouth may be stopped," is the language of a person hinting at them, although he has not stated it clearly, so as to prevent the language being too harsh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:38
verses.text: But the words "that all the world may become guilty before God," are spoken at once both of Jews and of Greeks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:39
verses.text: Now this is no slight thing with a view to take down their unreasonableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:40
verses.text: Since even here they have no advantage over the Gentiles, but are alike given up as far as salvation is concerned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:41
verses.text: For he would be in strict propriety called a guilty person, who cannot help himself to any excuse, but needeth the assistance of another: and such was the plight of all of us, in that we had lost the things pertaining to salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:42
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:43
verses.text: "For by the Law is the knowledge of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:44
verses.text: He springs upon the Law again, with forbearance however (for what he says is not an accusation of it, but of the listlessness of the Jews).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:45
verses.text: Yet nevertheless he has been earnest here with a view (as he was going to introduce his discourse about faith) to show its utter feebleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:46
verses.text: For if thou boastest in the Law, he means, it puts thee to the greater shame: it solemnly parades forth your sins before you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:47
verses.text: Only he does not word it in this harsh way, but again in a subdued tone; "For by the Law is the knowledge of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:48
verses.text: And so the punishment is greater, but that because of the Jew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:49
verses.text: For the Law accomplished the disclosure of sin to you, but it was your duty then to flee it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:50
verses.text: Since then you have not fled you have pulled the punishment more sorely on yourself, and the good deed of the Law has been made to you a supply of greater vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:51
verses.text: Now then having added to their fear, he next brings in the things of grace, as having brought them to a strong desire of the remission of their sins, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:52
verses.text: "But now the righteousness of God without the Law is manifested".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:53
verses.text: Here he utters a great thing, and such as needed much proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:54
verses.text: For if they that lived in the Law not only did not escape punishment, but were even the more weighed down thereby, how without the Law is it possible not only to escape vengeance, but even to be justified? For he has here set down two high points, the being justified, and the obtaining these blessings, without the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:55
verses.text: And this is why he does not say righteousness simply, but the righteousness of God, so by the worthiness of the Person displaying the greater degree of the grace, and the possibility of the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:56
verses.text: For to Him all things are possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:57
verses.text: And he does not say, "was given," but "is manifested," so cutting away the accusation of novelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:58
verses.text: For that which is manifested, is so as being old, but concealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:59
verses.text: And it is not this only, but the sequel that shows that this is no recent thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:60
verses.text: For after saying, "is manifested," he proceeds:  "Being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:61
verses.text: Do not be troubled, he means, because it has but now been given, nor be affrighted as though at a thing new and strange.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:62
verses.text: For of old both the Law and the Prophets foretold it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:63
verses.text: And some passages he has pointed out in the course of this argument, and some he will shortly, having in what came before brought in Habakkuk as saying, "the just shall live by faith" (i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:64
verses.text: ), but in what comes after, Abraham and David, as themselves also conversing with us about these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:65
verses.text: Now the regard they had for these persons was great, for one was a patriach and a prophet, and the other a king and a prophet: and further the promises about these things had come to both of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:66
verses.text: And this is why Matthew in the first beginning of his Gospel mentions both of these first, and then brings forward in order the forefathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:67
verses.text: For after saying, "the Book of the Generation of Jesus Christ" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:68
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:69
verses.text: ), he does not wait after Abraham to name Isaac also and Jacob, but mentions David along with ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:70
verses.text: "after") Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:71
verses.text: And what is wonderful indeed is, that he has even set David before Abraham speaking on this wise, "the Son of David, the Son of Abraham," and then begins the catalogue of Isaac and Jacob, and all the rest in order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:72
verses.text: And this is why the Apostle here keeps presenting them in turns, and speaks of the righteousness of God being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:73
verses.text: Then that no one should say, How are we to be saved without contributing anything at all to the object in view? he shows that we also offer no small matter toward this, I mean our faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:74
verses.text: Therefore after saying, "the righteousness of God," he adds straightway, "by faith unto all and upon all that believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:75
verses.text: Here again the Jew is alarmed by his not having anything better than the rest, and being numbered with the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:76
verses.text: Now that he may not feel this, he again lowers him with fear by adding, "For there is no difference, for all have sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:77
verses.text: For tell me not that it is such and such a Greek, such and such a Scythian, such and such a Thracian, for all are in the same plight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:78
verses.text: For even if you have received the Law, one thing alone is there which you have learnt from the Law—to know sin, not to flee from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:79
verses.text: Next, that they may say, "even if we have sinned, still it is not in the same way that they did," he added, "and have come short of the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:80
verses.text: So that even if you have not done the same sins as others, still you are alike bereft of the glory, since you belong to those who have offended, and he that hath offended belongeth not to such as are glorified, but to such as are put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:81
verses.text: Yet, be not afraid: for the reason of my saying this was not that I might thrust you into despair, but that I might show the love of the Lord (Δεσπότου) toward man: and so he goes on;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:82
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:83
verses.text: "Being justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in His blood, to declare His righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:84
verses.text: See by how many proofs he makes good what was said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:85
verses.text: First, from the worthiness of the person, for it is not a man who doeth these things, that He should be too weak for it, but God all-powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:86
verses.text: For it is to God, he says, that the righteousness belongs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:87
verses.text: Again, from the Law and the Prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:88
verses.text: For you need not be afraid at hearing the "without the Law," inasmuch as the Law itself approves this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:89
verses.text: Thirdly, from the sacrifices under the old dispensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:90
verses.text: For it was on this ground that he said, "In His blood," to call to their minds those sheep and calves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:91
verses.text: For if the sacrifices of things without reason, he means, cleared from sin, much more would this blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:92
verses.text: And he does not say barely λυτρώσεως, but ἀπολυτρώσεως, entire redemption, to show that we should come no more into such slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:93
verses.text: And for this same reason he calls it a propitiation, to show that if the type had such force, much more would the reality display the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:94
verses.text: But to show again that it was no novel thing or recent, he says, "fore-ordained" (Auth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:95
verses.text: Version marg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:96
verses.text: ); and by saying God "fore-ordained," and showing that the good deed is the Father's, he showeth it to be the Son's also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:97
verses.text: For the Father "fore-ordained," but Christ in His own blood wrought the whole aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:98
verses.text: "To declare His righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:99
verses.text: What is declaring of righteousness? Like the declaring of His riches, not only for Him to be rich Himself, but also to make others rich, or of life, not only that He is Himself living, but also that He makes the dead to live; and of His power, not only that He is Himself powerful, but also that He makes the feeble powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:100
verses.text: So also is the declaring of His righteousness not only that He is Himself righteous, but that He doth also make them that are filled with the putrefying sores (κατασαπέντας) of sin suddenly righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:101
verses.text: And it is to explain this, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:102
verses.text: what is "declaring," that he has added, "That He might be just, and the justifier of him which believeth in Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:103
verses.text: Doubt not then: for it is not of works, but of faith: and shun not the righteousness of God, for it is a blessing in two ways; because it is easy, and also open to all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:104
verses.text: And be not abashed and shamefaced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:105
verses.text: For if He Himself openly declareth (ἐνδείκνυται) Himself to do so, and He, so to say, findeth a delight and a pride therein, how comest thou to be dejected and to hide thy face at what thy Master glorieth in? Now then after raising his hearers expectations by saying that what had taken place was a declaring of the righteousness of God, he next by fear urges him on that is tardy and remissful about coming; by speaking as follows:  "On account of the relaxing of sins that were before".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:106
verses.text: Do you see how often he keeps reminding them of their transgressions? Before, he did it by saying, "through the Law is the knowledge of sin;" and after by saying, "that all have sinned," but here in yet stronger language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:107
verses.text: For he does not say for the sins, but, "for the relaxing," that is, the deadness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:108
verses.text: For there was no longer any hope of recovering health, but as the paralyzed body needed the hand from above, so doth the soul which hath been deadened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:109
verses.text: And what is indeed worse, a thing which he sets down as a charge, and points out that it is a greater accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:110
verses.text: Now what is this? That the last state was incurred in the forbearance of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:111
verses.text: For you cannot plead, he means, that you have not enjoyed much forbearance and goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:112
verses.text: But the words "at this time" are those of one who is pointing out the greatness of the power (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:113
verses.text: forbearance) and love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:114
verses.text: For after we had given all over, (he would say,) and it were time to sentence us, and the evils were waxed great and the sins were in their full, then He displayed His own power, that thou mightest learn how great is the abundancy of righteousness with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:115
verses.text: For this, had it taken place at the beginning, would not have had so wonderful and unusual an appearance as now, when every sort of cure was found unavailing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:116
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:117
verses.text: "Where is boasting then? it is excluded," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:118
verses.text: "By what law? of works? Nay, but by the law of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:119
verses.text: Paul is at great pains to show that faith is mighty to a degree which was never even fancied of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:120
verses.text: For after he had said that God justifieth man by faith, he grapples with the Law again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:121
verses.text: And he does not say, where then are the well doings of the Jews? where their righteous dealing? but, "where is then the boasting?" so taking every opportunity of showing, that they do but use great words, as though they had somewhat more than others, and have no work to show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:122
verses.text: And after saying, "Where then is the boasting?" he does not say, it is put out of sight and hath come to an end, but "it is excluded," which word rather expresses unseasonableness; since the reason for it is no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:123
verses.text: For as when the judgment is come they that would repent have not any longer the season for it, thus now the sentence being henceforth passed, and all being upon the point of perishing, and He being at hand Who by grace would break these terrors, they had no longer the season for making a plea of amelioration wrought by the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:124
verses.text: For if it were right to strengthen themselves upon these things, it should have been before His coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:125
verses.text: But now that He who should save by faith was come, the season for those efforts was taken from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:126
verses.text: For since all were convicted, He therefore saveth by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:127
verses.text: And this is why He is come but now, that they may not say, as they would had He come at the first, that it was possible to be saved by the Law and by our own labors and well-doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:128
verses.text: To curb therefore this their effrontery, He waited a long time: so that after they were by every argument clearly convicted of inability to help themselves, He then saved them by His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:129
verses.text: And for this reason too when he had said above, "To declare His righteousness," he added, "at this time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:130
verses.text: If any then were to gainsay, they do the same as if a person who after committing great sins was unable to defend himself in court, but was condemned and going to be punished, and then being by the royal pardon forgiven, should have the effrontery after his forgiveness to boast and say that he had done no sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:131
verses.text: For before the pardon came, was the time to prove it: but after it came he would no longer have the season for boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:132
verses.text: And this happened in the Jews' case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:133
verses.text: For since they had been traitors to themselves, this was why He came, by His very coming doing away their boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:134
verses.text: For he who saith that he is a "teacher of babes, and maketh his boast in the Law," and styles himself "an instructor of the foolish," if alike with them he needed a teacher and a Saviour, can no longer have any pretext for boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:135
verses.text: For if even before this, the circumcision was made uncircumcision, much rather was it now, since it is cast out from both periods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:136
verses.text: But after saying that "it was excluded," he shows also, how.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:137
verses.text: How then does he say it was excluded? "By what law? of works? Nay, but by the law of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:138
verses.text: See he calls the faith also a law delighting to keep to the names, and so allay the seeming novelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:139
verses.text: But what is the "law of faith?" It is, being saved by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:140
verses.text: Here he shows God's power, in that He has not only saved, but has even justified, and led them to boasting, and this too without needing works, but looking for faith only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:141
verses.text: And in saying this he attempts to bring the Jew who has believed to act with moderation, and to calm him that hath not believed, in such way as to draw him on to his own view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:142
verses.text: For he that has been saved, if he be high-minded in that he abides by the Law, will be told that he himself has stopped his own mouth, himself has accused himself, himself has renounced claims to his own salvation, and has excluded boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:143
verses.text: But he that hath not believed again, being humbled by these same means, will be capable of being brought over to the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:144
verses.text: Do you see how great faith's preëminence is? How it hath removed us from the former things, not even allowing us to boast of them?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:145
verses.text: "Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:146
verses.text: When he had shown that by faith they were superior to the Jews, then he goes on with great confidence to discourse upon it also, and what seemed therein to annoy he again heals up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:147
verses.text: For these two things were what confused the Jews; one, if it were possible for men, who with works were not saved, to be saved without them, and another, if it were just for the uncircumcised to enjoy the same blessings with those, who had during so long a period been nurtured in the Law; which last confused them more by far than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:148
verses.text: And on this ground having proved the former, he goes on to the other next, which perplexed the Jews so far, that they even complained on account of this position against Peter after they believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:149
verses.text: What does he say then? "Therefore we conclude, that by faith a man is justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:150
verses.text: He does not say, a Jew, or one under the Law, but after leading forth his discourse into a large room, and opening the doors of faith to the world, he says "a man," the name common to our race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:151
verses.text: And then having taken occasion from this, he meets an objection not set down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:152
verses.text: For since it was likely that the Jews, upon hearing that faith justifieth every man, would take it ill and feel offended, he goes on,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:153
verses.text: "Is He the God of the Jews only?"  As if he said, On what foot does it then seem to you amiss that every man should be saved? Is God partial?
