So showing from this, that in wishing to flout the Gentiles, they are rather offering an insult to God's glory, if, that is, they would not allow Him to be the God of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:154
verses.text: But if He is of all, then He taketh care of all; and if He care for all, then He saveth all alike by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:155
verses.text: And this is why he says, "Is He the God of the Jews only? is He not also of the Gentiles? Yes, of the Gentiles also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:156
verses.text: For He is not partial as the fables of the Gentiles (cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:157
verses.text: Ov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:158
verses.text: Tr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:159
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:160
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:161
verses.text: sqq) are, but common to all, and One.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:162
verses.text: And this is why he goes on,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:163
verses.text: "Seeing it is one God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:164
verses.text: That is, the same is the Master of both these and those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:165
verses.text: But if you tell me of the ancient state of things, then too the dealings of Providence were shared by both, although in diverse ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:166
verses.text: For as to thee was given the written law, so to them was the natural; and they came short in nothing, if, that is, only they were willing, but were even able to surpass thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:167
verses.text: And so he proceeds, with an allusion to this very thing, "Who shall justify the circumcision by faith, and the uncircumcision through faith," so reminding them of what he said before about uncircumcision and circumcision, whereby he showed that there was no difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:168
verses.text: But if then there was no difference, much less is there any now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:169
verses.text: And this accordingly he now establishes upon still clearer grounds, and so demonstrates, that either of them stand alike in need of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:170
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:171
verses.text: "Do we then," he says, "make void the Law through faith? God forbid: yea, we establish the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:172
verses.text: Do you see his varied and unspeakable judgment? For the bare use of the word "establish" shows that it was not then standing, but was worn out (καταλελυμένον).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:173
verses.text: And note also Paul's exceeding power, and how superabundantly he maintains what he wishes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:174
verses.text: For here he shows that the faith, so far from doing any disparagement to the "Law," even assists it, as it on the other hand paved the way for the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:175
verses.text: For as the Law itself before bore witness to it (for he saith, "being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets"), so here this establisheth that, now that it is unnerved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:176
verses.text: And how did it establish? he would say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:177
verses.text: What was the object of the Law and what the scope of all its enactments? Why, to make man righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:178
verses.text: But this it had no power to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:179
verses.text: "For all," it says, "have sinned:" but faith when it came accomplished it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:180
verses.text: For when a man is once a believer, he is straightway justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:181
verses.text: The intention then of the Law it did establish, and what all its enactments aim after, this hath it brought to a consummation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:182
verses.text: Consequently it has not disannulled, but perfected it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:183
verses.text: Here then three points he has demonstrated; first, that without the Law it is possible to be justified; next, that this the Law could not effect; and, that faith is not opposed to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:184
verses.text: For since the chief cause of perplexity to the Jews was this, that the faith seemed to be in opposition to it, he shows more than the Jew wishes, that so far from being contrary, it is even in close alliance and coöperation with it, which was what they especially longed to hear proved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:185
verses.text: But since after this grace, whereby we were justified, there is need also of a life suited to it, let us show an earnestness worthy the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:186
verses.text: And show it we shall, if we keep with earnestness charity, the mother of good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:187
verses.text: Now charity is not bare words, or mere ways of speaking (προσρήσεις) to men, but a taking care (προστασία) of them, and a putting forth of itself by works, as, for instance, by relieving poverty, lending one's aid to the sick, rescuing from dangers, to stand by them that be in difficulties, to weep with them that weep, and to rejoice with them that rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:188
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:189
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:190
verses.text: ) For even this last is a part of charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:191
verses.text: And yet this seems a little thing, to be rejoicing with them that rejoice: nevertheless it is exceedingly great, and requireth for it the spirit of true wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:192
verses.text: And we may find many that perform the more irksome part (πεικρότερον), and yet want vigor for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:193
verses.text: For many weep with them that weep, but still do not rejoice with them that rejoice, but are in tears when others rejoice; now this comes of grudging and envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:194
verses.text: The good deed then of rejoicing when our brother rejoices is no small one, but even greater than the other: and haply not only greater than weeping with them that weep, but even than standing by them that are in danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:195
verses.text: There are many, at all events, that have shared danger with men in danger, but were cut to the heart when they came into honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:196
verses.text: So great is the tyranny of a grudging spirit! And yet the one is a thing of toils and labors, and this of choice and temper only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:197
verses.text: Yet at the same time many that have endured the harder task have not accomplished the one easier than it, but pine and consume away when they see others in honor, when a whole Church is benefited, by doctrine, or in any other fashion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:198
verses.text: And what can be worse than this? For such an one doth not any more fight with his brother, but with the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:199
verses.text: Now consider this, and be rid of the disease: and even if you be unwilling to set your neighbor free, at least set yourself free from these countless evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:200
verses.text: Why do you carry war into your own thoughts? Why fill your soul with trouble? why work up a storm? why turn things upside down? How will you be able, in this state of mind, to ask forgiveness of sins? For if those that allow not the things done against themselves to pass, neither doth He forgive, what forgiveness shall He grant to those who go about to injure those that have done them no injury? For this is a proof of the utmost wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:201
verses.text: Men of this kind are fighting with the Devil, against the Church, and haply even worse than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:202
verses.text: For him one can be on one's guard against.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:203
verses.text: But these cloaking themselves under the mask of friendliness, secretly kindle the pile, throwing themselves the first into the furnace, and laboring under a disease not only unfit for pity, but even such as to meet with much ridicule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:204
verses.text: For why is it, tell me, that thou art pale and trembling and standing in fear? What evil has happened? Is it that thy brother is in honor, and looked up to, and in esteem? Why, thou oughtest to make chaplets, and rejoice, and glorify God, that thine own member is in honor and looked up to! But art thou pained that God is glorified? Seest thou to what issue the war tends? But, some will say, it is not because God is glorified, but because my brother is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:205
verses.text: Yet through him the glory ascendeth up to God: and so will the war from thee do also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:206
verses.text: But it is not this, he will say, that grieves me, for I should wish God to be glorified by me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:207
verses.text: Well then! rejoice at thy brother's being in honor, and then glorified is God again through thee also; and all will say, Blessed be God that hath His household so minded, wholly freed from envy, and rejoicing together at one another's goods! And why do I speak of thy brother? for if he were thy foe and enemy, and God were glorified through him, a friend shouldest thou make of him for this reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:208
verses.text: But thou makest thy friend an enemy because God is glorified by his being in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:209
verses.text: And were any one to heal thy body when in evil plight, though he were an enemy, thou wouldest count him thenceforward among the first of thy friends: and dost thou reckon him that gladdens the countenance of Christ's Body, that is, the Church, and is thy friend, to be yet an enemy? How else then couldest thou show war against Christ? For this cause, even if a man do miracles, have celibacy to show, and fasting, and lying on the bare ground, and doth by this virtue advance even to the angels, yet shall he be most accursed of all, while he has this defect, and shall be a greater breaker of the Law than the adulterer, and the fornicator, and the robber, and the violator of supulchres.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:210
verses.text: And, that no one may condemn this language of hyperbole, I should be glad to put this question to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:211
verses.text: If any one were come with fire and mattock, and were destroying and burning this House, and digging down this Altar, would not each one of those here stone him with stones as accursed and a law-breaker? What then, if one were to bring a flame yet more consuming than that fire, I mean envy, that doth not ruin the buildings of stone nor dig down an Altar of gold, but subverteth and scornfully marreth what is far more precious than either walls or Altar, the Teachers' building, what sufferance would he deserve? For let no one tell me, that he has often endeavored and been unable: for it is from the spirit that the actions are judged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:212
verses.text: For Saul did kill David, even though he did not hit him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:213
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:214
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:215
verses.text: ) Tell me, dost thou not perceive that thou art plotting against the sheep of Christ when thou warrest with His Shepherd? those sheep for whom also Christ shed His Blood, and bade us both to do and to suffer all things? Dost thou not remind thyself that thy Master sought thy glory and not His own, but thou art seeking not that of thy Master but thine own? And yet if thou didst see His then thou wouldst have obtained thine own also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:216
verses.text: But by seeking thine own before His, thou wilt not ever gain even this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:217
verses.text: What then will be the remedy? Let us all join in prayer, and let us lift up our voice with one accord in their behalf as for those possessed, for indeed these are more wretched than they, inasmuch as their madness is of choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:218
verses.text: For this affliction needeth prayer and much entreaty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:219
verses.text: For if he that loveth not his brother, even though he empty out his money, yea, and have the glory of martyrdom, is no whit advantaged; consider what punishment the man deserves who even wars with him that hath not wronged him in anything; he is even worse than the Gentiles: for if to love them that love us does not let us have any advantage over them, in what grade shall he be placed, tell me, that envieth them that love him? For envying is even worse than warring; since he that warreth, when the cause of the war is at an end, puts an end to his hatred also: but the grudger would never become a friend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:220
verses.text: And the one shows an open kind of battle, the other a covert: and the one often has a reasonable cause to assign for the war, the other, nothing else but madness, and a Satanic spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:221
verses.text: To what then is one to compare a soul of this kind? to what viper? to what asp? to what canker-worm? to what scorpion? since there is nothing so accursed or so pernicious as a soul of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:222
verses.text: For it is this, it is this, that hath subverted the Churches, this that hath gendered the heresies, this it was that armed a brother's hand, and made his right hand to be dipped in the blood of the righteous, and plucked away the laws of nature, and set open the gates for death, and brought that curse into action, and suffered not that wretch to call to mind either the birth-pangs, or his parents, or anything else, but made him so furious, and led him to such a pitch of phrenzy, that even when God exhorted him and said, "Unto thee shall be his recourse, and thou shalt rule over him" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:223
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:224
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:225
verses.text: ); he did not even then give in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:226
verses.text: Yet did He both forgive him the fault, and make his brother subject to him: but his complaint is so incurable, that even if thousands of medicines are applied, it keeps sloughing with its own corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:227
verses.text: For wherefore art thou so vexed, thou most miserable of men? Is it because God hath had honor shown Him? Nay, this would show a Satanical spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:228
verses.text: Is it then because thy brother outstrips thee in good name? As for that, it is open to thee in turn to outstrip him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:229
verses.text: And so, if thou wouldest be a conqueror, kill not, destroy not, but let him abide still, that the material for the struggle may be preserved, and conquer him living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:230
verses.text: For in this way thy crown had been a glorious one; but by thus destroying thou passest a harder sentence of defeat upon thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:231
verses.text: But a grudging spirit hath no sense of all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:232
verses.text: And what ground hast thou to covet glory in such solitude? for those were at that time the only inhabitants of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:233
verses.text: Still even then this restrained him not, but he cast away all from his mind, and stationed himself in the ranks of the devil; for he it was who then led the war upon Cain's side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:234
verses.text: For inasmuch as it was not enough for him that man had become liable to death, by the manner of the death he tried to make the tragedy still greater, and persuaded him to become a fratricide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:235
verses.text: For he was urgent and in travail to see the sentence carried into effect, as never satisfied with our ills.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:236
verses.text: As if any one who had got an enemy in prison, and saw him under sentence, were to press, before he was out of the city, to see him butchered within it, and would not wait even the fitting time, so did the devil then, though he had heard that man must return to earth, travail with desire to see something worse, even a son dying before his father, and a brother destroying a brother, and a premature and violent slaughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:237
verses.text: See you what great service envy hath done him? how it hath filled the insatiate spirit of the devil, and hath prepared for him a table great as he desired to see?  Let us then escape from the disease; for it is not possible, indeed it is not, to escape from the fire prepared for the devil, unless we get free from this sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:238
verses.text: But free we shall get to be if we lay to mind how Christ loved us, and also how He bade us love one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:239
verses.text: Now what love did He show for us? His precious Blood did He shed for us when we were enemies, and had done the greatest wrong to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:240
verses.text: This do thou also do in thy brother's case (for this is the end of His saying "A new commandment I give unto you, That ye so love one another as I have loved you") (John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:241
verses.text: ); or rather even so the measure does not come to a stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:242
verses.text: For it was in behalf of His enemies that He did this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:243
verses.text: And are you unwilling to shed your blood for your brother? Why then dost thou even shed his blood, disobeying the commandment even to reversing it? Yet what He did was not as a due: but you, if you do it, are but fulfilling a debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:244
verses.text: Since he too, who, after receiving the ten thousand talents, demanded the hundred pence, was punished not merely for the fact that he demanded them, but because even by the kindness done him he had not become any better, and did not even follow where his Lord had begun, or remit the debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:245
verses.text: For on the part of the servant the thing done was but a debt after all, if it had been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:246
verses.text: For all things that we do, we do towards the payment of a debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:247
verses.text: And this is why Himself said, "When ye have done all, say, We are unprofitable servants, we have done that which was our duty to do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:248
verses.text: (Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:249
verses.text: ) If then we display charity, if we give our goods to them that need, we are fulfilling a debt; and that not only in that it was He who first began the acts of goodness, but because it is His goods that we are distributing if we ever do give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:250
verses.text: Why then deprive thyself of what He willeth thee to have the right of? For the reason why He bade thee give them to another was that thou mightest have them thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:251
verses.text: For so long as thou hast them to thyself even thou thyself hast them not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:252
verses.text: But when thou hast given to another, then hast thou received them thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:253
verses.text: What charm then will do as much as this? Himself poured forth His Blood for His enemies: but we not even money for our benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:254
verses.text: He did so with His Blood that was His own: we will not even with money that is not ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:255
verses.text: He did it before us, we not even after His example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:256
verses.text: He did it for our salvation, we will not do it even for our own advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:257
verses.text: For He is not to have any advantage from our love toward man, but the whole gain accrueth unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:258
verses.text: For this is the very reason why we are bidden to give away our goods, that we may not be thrown out of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:259
verses.text: For as a person who gives a little child money and bids him hold it fast, or give it the servant to keep, that it may not be for whoever will to snatch it away, so also doth God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:260
verses.text: For He says, Give to him that needeth, lest some one should snatch it away from thee, as an informer, for instance, or a calumniator, or a thief, or, after all these are avoided, death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:261
verses.text: For so long as thou holdest it thyself, thou hast no safe hold of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:262
verses.text: But if thou givest it Me through the poor, I keep it all for thee exactly, and in fit season will return it with great increase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:263
verses.text: For it is not to take it away that I receive it, but to make it a larger amount and to keep it more exactly, that I may have it preserved for you against that time, in which there is no one to lend or to pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:264
verses.text: What then can be more hard-hearted, than if we, after such promises, cannot make up our minds to lend to him? Yes, it is for this that we go before Him destitute and naked and poor, not having the things committed to our charge, because we do not deposit them with Him who keepeth them more exactly than any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:265
verses.text: And for this we shall be most severely punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:266
verses.text: For when we are charged with it, what shall we be able to say about the loss of them? what pretext to put forward? what defence? For what reason is there why you did not give? Do you disbelieve that you will receive it again? And how can this be reasonable? For He that hath given to one that hath not given, how shall He not much rather give after He has received? Does the sight of them please you? Well then, give much the more for this reason, that you may there be the more delighted, when no one can take them from you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:267
verses.text: Since now if you keep them, you will even suffer countless evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:268
verses.text: For as a dog, so doth the devil leap upon them that are rich, wishing to snatch from them, as from a child that holdeth a sippet or a cake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:269
verses.text: Let us then give them to our Father, and if the devil see this done, he will certainly withdraw: and when he has withdrawn, then will the Father safely give them all to thee, when he cannot trouble, in that world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:270
verses.text: For now surely they that be rich differ not from little children that are troubled by dogs, while all are barking round them, tearing and pulling; not men only, but ignoble affections; as gluttony, drunkenness, flattery, uncleanness of every kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:271
verses.text: And when we have to lend, we are very anxious about those that give much, and look particularly for those that are frank dealers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:272
verses.text: But here we do the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:273
verses.text: For God, Who dealeth frankly, and giveth not one in the hundred, but a hundred-fold, we desert, and those who will not return us even the capital, these we seek after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:274
verses.text: For what return will our belly make us, that consumeth the larger share of our goods? Dung and corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:275
verses.text: Or what will vainglory? Envy and grudging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:276
verses.text: Or what nearness? Care and anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:277
verses.text: Or what uncleanness? Hell and the venomous worm! For these are the debtors of them that be rich, who pay this interest upon the capital, evils at present, and dreadful things in expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:278
verses.text: Shall we then lead to these, pray, with such punishment for interest, and shall we not trust the same to Christ ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:279
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:280
verses.text: τᾥ) Who holdeth forth unto us heaven, immortal life, blessings unutterable? And what excuse shall we have? For how comest thou not to give to Him, who will assuredly return, and return in greater abundance? Perhaps it is because it is so long before He repays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:281
verses.text: Yet surely He repays even here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:282
verses.text: For He is true which saith, "Seek the kingdom of heaven, and all these things shall be added to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:283
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:284
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:285
verses.text: ) Seest thou this extreme munificence? Those goods, He says, have been stored up for thee, and are not diminishing: but these here I give by way of increase and surplus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:286
verses.text: But, besides all this, the very fact of its being so long before thou wilt receive it, does but make thy riches the greater: since the interest is more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:287
verses.text: For in the case of those who have money lent them, we see that this is what the lenders do, lending, that is, with greater readiness to those who refund a long time after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:288
verses.text: For he that straightway repays the whole, cuts off the progression of the interest, but he that keeps possession of it for a longer time, makes also the gain from it greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:289
verses.text: Shall we then, while in man's case we are not offended at the delay, but even use artifices to make it greater, in the case of God be so little-minded, as on this very ground to be backward and to retract? And yet, as I said, He both giveth here, and along with the reason mentioned, as planning also some other greater advantage to us, He there keepeth the whole in store.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:290
verses.text: For the abundance of what is given, and the excellency of that gift, transcends this present worthless life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:291
verses.text: Since in this perishable and doomed body there is not even the possibility of receiving those unfading crowns; nor in our present state, perturbed and full of trouble, and liable to many changes as it is, of attaining to that unchangeable unperturbed lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:292
verses.text: Now you, if any one were to owe you gold, and while you were staying in a foreign country, and had neither servants, nor any means to convey it across to the place of your abode, were to promise to pay you the loan, would beseech him in countless ways to have it paid down not in the foreign land, but at home rather.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:293
verses.text: But do you think right to receive those spiritual and unutterable things in this world? Now what madness this would show! For if you receive them here, you must have them corruptible to a certainty; but if you wait for that time, He will repay you them incorruptible and unalloyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:294
verses.text: If you receive here, you have gotten lead; but if there, tried gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:295
verses.text: Still He does not even deprive thee of the goods of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:296
verses.text: For along with that promise He has placed another also, to the following effect, That every one that loveth the things of the world to come, shall receive "an hundred-fold in this life present, and shall inherit eternal life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:297
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:298
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:299
verses.text: ) If then we do not receive the hundred-fold, it is ourselves that are to blame for not lending to Him Who can give so much, for all who have given have received much, even though they gave but little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:300
verses.text: For what great thing, tell me, did Peter give? was it not a net that was broken (Luke v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:301
verses.text: , ), and a rod and a hook only? Yet still God opened to him the houses of the world, and spread before him land and sea, and all men invited him to their possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:302
verses.text: Or rather they sold what was their own, and brought it to their feet, not so much as putting it into their hands, for they dared not, so great was the honor they paid him, as well as their profuseness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:303
verses.text: But he was Peter, you will say! And what of this? O man! For it was not Peter only to whom He made this promise, neither said He, Thou, O Peter, only art to receive an hundred-fold, but "every one whosoever hath left houses or brethren shall receive an hundredfold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:304
verses.text: For it is not distinction of persons that He recognizes, but actions that are rightly done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:305
verses.text: But a circle of little ones is round about me, one will say, and I am desirous of leaving them with a good fortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:306
verses.text: Why then do we make them paupers? For if you leave them everything, you are still committing your goods to a trust that may deceive you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:307
verses.text: But if you leave God their joint-heir and guardian, you have left them countless treasures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:308
verses.text: For as when we avenge ourselves God assisteth us not, but when we leave it to Him, more than we expect comes about; so in the case of goods, if we take thought about them ourselves, He will withdraw from any providence over them, but if we cast all upon Him, He will place both them and our children in all safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:309
verses.text: And why art thou amazed that this should be so with God? for even with men one may see this happening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:310
verses.text: For if you do not when dying invite any of your relatives to the care of your children, it often happens, that one who is abundantly willing feels reluctancy, and is too modest to spring to the task of his own accord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:311
verses.text: But if you cast the care upon him, as having had a very great honor shown him, he will in requital make very great returns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:312
verses.text: If then thou wouldest leave thy children much wealth, leave them God's care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:313
verses.text: For He Who, without thy having done anything, gave thee a soul, and formed thee a body, and granted thee life, when He seeth thee displaying such munificence and distributing their goods to Himself along with them, must surely open to them every kind of riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:314
verses.text: For if Elijah after having been nourished with a little meal, since he saw that that woman honored him above her children, made threshing-floors and oil-presses appear in the little hut of the widow, consider what loving caring the Lord of Elijah will display! Let us then not consider how to leave our children rich, but how to leave them virtuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:315
verses.text: For if they have the confidence of riches, they will not mind aught besides, in that they have the means screening the wickedness of their ways in their abundant riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:316
verses.text: But if they find themselves devoid of the comfort to be got from that source, they will do all so as by virtue to find themselves abundant consolation for their poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:317
verses.text: Leave them then no riches that you may leave them virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:318
verses.text: For it is unreasonable in the extreme, not to make them, whilst we are alive, lords of all our goods, yet after we are dead to give the easy nature of youth full exemption from fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:319
verses.text: And yet while we are alive we shall have power to call them to good account, and to sober and bridle them, if they make an ill use of their goods: but if after we are dead we afford them, at the time of the loss of ourselves, and their own youthfulness, that power which wealth gives, endless are the precipices into which we shall thrust those unfortunate and miserable creatures, so heaping fuel upon flame, and letting oil drop into a fierce furnace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:320
verses.text: And so, if you would leave them rich and safe withal, leave God a debtor to them, and deliver the bequest to them into His hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:321
verses.text: For if they receive the money themselves, they will not know even who to give it to, but will meet with many designing and unfeeling people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:322
verses.text: But if thou beforehand puttest it out to interest with God, the treasure henceforward remains unassailable, and great is the facility wherewith that repayment will be made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:323
verses.text: For God is well pleased at repaying us what He oweth, and both looks with a more favorable eye upon those who have lent to Him, than on those who have not; and loveth those the most to whom He oweth the most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:324
verses.text: And so, if thou wouldest have Him for thy Friend continually, make Him thy Debtor to a large amount.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:325
verses.text: For there is no lender so pleased at having those that owe to him, as Christ ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:326
verses.text: God) is rejoiced at having those that lend to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:327
verses.text: And such as He oweth nothing to, He fleeth from; but such as He oweth to, He even runneth unto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:328
verses.text: Let us then use all means to get Him for our Debtor; for this is the season for loans, and He is now in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:329
verses.text: If then thou givest not unto Him now, He will not ask of thee after thy departing hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:330
verses.text: For it is here that He thirsteth, here that He is an hungered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:331
verses.text: He thirsteth, since He thirsteth after thy salvation; and it is for this that He even begs; for this that He even goeth about naked, negotiating immortal life for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:332
verses.text: Do not then neglect Him; since it is not to be nourished that He wishes, but to nourish; it is not to be clothed, but to clothe and to accoutre thee with the golden garment, the royal robe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:333
verses.text: Do you not see even the more attached sort of physicians, when they are washing the sick, wash themselves also, though they need it not? In the same way He also doth all for the sake of thee who art sick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:334
verses.text: For this reason also He uses no force in demanding, that He may make thee great returns: that thou mayest learn that it is not because He is in need that He asketh of thee, but that He may set right that thou needest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:335
verses.text: For this reason too He comes to thee in a lowly guise, and with His right hand held forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:336
verses.text: And if thou givest Him a farthing, He turneth not away: and even if thou rejectest Him, He departeth not but cometh again to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:337
verses.text: For He desireth, yea desireth exceedingly, our salvation: let us then think scorn of money, that we may not be thought scorn of by Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:338
verses.text: Let us think scorn of money, even with a view to obtain the money itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:339
verses.text: For if we keep it here, we shall lose it altogether both here and hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:340
verses.text: But if we distribute it with abundant expenditure, we shall enjoy in each life abundant wealthiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:341
verses.text: He then that would become rich, let him become poor, that he may be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:342
verses.text: Let him spend that he may collect, let him scatter that he may gather.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:343
verses.text: But if this is novel and paradoxical, look to the sower, and consider, that he cannot in any other way gather more together, save by scattering what he hath and, letting go of what is at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 8:344
verses.text: Let us now sow and till the Heaven, that we may reap with great abundance, and obtain everlasting goods, through the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:3
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:4
verses.text: ,  "What shall we then say that Abraham, our father as pertaining to the flesh, hath found? For if Abraham were justified by works, he hath whereof to glory; but not before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:5
verses.text: He had said ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:6
verses.text: εἶπεν), that the world had become guilty before God, and that all had sinned, and that boasting was excluded and that it was impossible to be saved otherwise than by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:7
verses.text: He is now intent upon showing that this salvation, so far from being matter of shame, was even the cause of a bright glory, and a greater than that through works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:8
verses.text: For since the being saved, yet with shame, had somewhat of dejection in it, he next takes away this suspicion too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:9
verses.text: And indeed he has hinted at the same already, by calling it not barely salvation, but "righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:10
verses.text: Therein" (he says) "is the righteousness of God revealed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:11
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:12
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:13
verses.text: ) For he that is saved as a righteous man has a confidence accompanying his salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:14
verses.text: And he calls it not "righteousness" only, but also the setting forth of the righteousness of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:15
verses.text: But God is set forth in things which are glorious and shining, and great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:16
verses.text: However, he nevertheless draws support for this from what he is at present upon, and carries his discourse forward by the method of question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:17
verses.text: And this he is always in the habit of doing both for clearness sake, and for the sake of confidence in what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:18
verses.text: Above, for instance, he did it, where he says, "What advantage then hath the Jew?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:19
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:20
verses.text: ) and, "What then have we more than they?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:21
verses.text: ) and again, "where then is boasting? it is excluded" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:22
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:23
verses.text: ): and here, "what then shall we say that Abraham our father?" etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:24
verses.text: Now since the Jews kept turning over and over the fact, that the Patriarch, and friend of God, was the first to receive circumcision, he wishes to show, that it was by faith that he too was justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:25
verses.text: And this was quite a vantage ground to insist upon (περιουσία νίκης πολλἥς).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:26
verses.text: For for a person who had no works, to be justified by faith, was nothing unlikely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:27
verses.text: But for a person richly adorned with good deeds, not to be made just from hence, but from faith, this is the thing to cause wonder, and to set the power of faith in a strong light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:28
verses.text: And this is why he passes by all the others, and leads his discourse back to this man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:29
verses.text: And he calls him "father, as pertaining to the flesh," to throw them out of the genuine relationship (συγγενείας γνησίας) to him, and to pave the Gentiles' way to kinsmanship with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:30
verses.text: And then he says, "For if Abraham were justified by works, he hath whereof to glory: but not before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:31
verses.text: After saying that God "justified the circumcision by faith and the uncircumcision through faith," and making the same sufficiently sure in what he said before, he now proves it by Abraham more clearly than he promised, and pitches the battle for faith against works, and makes this righteous man the subject of the whole struggle; and that not without special meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:32
verses.text: Wherefore also he sets him up very high by calling him "forefather," and putting a constraint upon them to comply with him in all points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:33
verses.text: For, Tell me not, he would say, about the Jews, nor bring this man or that before me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:34
verses.text: For I will go up to the very head of all, and the source whence circumcision took its rise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:35
verses.text: For "if Abraham," he says, "was justified by works, he hath whereof to glory: but not before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:36
verses.text: What is here said is not plain, and so one must make it plainer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:37
verses.text: For there are two "gloryings," one of works, and one of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:38
verses.text: After saying then, "if he was justified by works, he hath whereof to glory; but not before God;" he points out that he might have whereof to glory from faith also, yea and much greater reason for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:39
verses.text: For the great power of Paul is especially displayed in this, that he turns what is objected to the other side, and shows that what seemed rather to be on the side of salvation by works, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:40
verses.text: glorying or boldness of claim (παρρησιάζεσθαι) belonged much more truly to that by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:41
verses.text: For he that glorieth in his works has his own labors to put forward: but he that finds his honor in having faith in God, has a much greater ground for glorying to show, in that it is God that he glorifieth and magnifieth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:42
verses.text: For those things which the nature of the visible world tells him not of, in receiving these by faith in Him, he at once displays sincere love towards Him, and heralds His power clearly forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:43
verses.text: Now this is the character of the noblest soul, and the philosophic spirit, and lofty mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:44
verses.text: For to abstain from stealing and murdering is trifling sort of acquirement, but to believe that it is possible for God to do things impossible requires a soul of no mean stature, and earnestly affected towards Him; for this is a sign of sincere love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:45
verses.text: For he indeed honors God, who fulfils the commandments, but he doth so in a much greater degree who thus followeth wisdom (φιλοσοφὥν) by his faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:46
verses.text: The former obeys Him, but the latter receives that opinion of Him which is fitting, and glorifies Him, and feels wonder at Him more than that evinced by works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:47
verses.text: For that glorying pertains to him that does aright, but this glorifieth God, and lieth wholly in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:48
verses.text: For he glorieth at conceiving great things concerning Him, which redound to His glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:49
verses.text: And this is why he speaks of having whereof to glory before God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:50
verses.text: And not for this only, but also for another reason: for he who is a believer glorieth again, not only because he loveth God in sincerity, but also because he hath enjoyed great honor and love from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:51
verses.text: For as he shows his love to Him by having great thoughts about Him, (for this is a proof of love), so doth God also love him, though deserving to suffer for countless sins, not in freeing him from punishment only, but even by making him righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:52
verses.text: He then hath whereof to glory, as having been counted worthy of mighty love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:53
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:54
verses.text: "For to him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of grace, but of debt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:55
verses.text: Then is not this last the greatest? he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:56
verses.text: By no means: for it is to the believer that it is reckoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:57
verses.text: But it would not have been reckoned, unless there were something that he contributed himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:58
verses.text: And so he too hath God for his debtor, and debtor too for no common things, but great and high ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:59
verses.text: For to show his high-mindedness and spiritual understanding, he does not say "to him that believeth" merely, but  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:60
verses.text: "To him that believeth on Him that justifieth the ungodly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:61
verses.text: For reflect how great a thing it is to be persuaded and have full confidence that God is able on a sudden not to free a man who has lived in impiety from punishment only, but even to make him just, and to count him worthy of those immortal honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:62
verses.text: Do not then suppose that this one is lowered in that it is not reckoned unto the former of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:63
verses.text: For this is the very thing that makes the believer glorious; the fact of his enjoying so great grace, of his displaying so great faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:64
verses.text: And note too that the recompense is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:65
verses.text: For to the former a reward is given, to the latter righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:66
verses.text: Now righteousness is much greater than a reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:67
verses.text: For righteousness is a recompense which most fully comprehends several rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:68
verses.text: Therefore after proving this from Abraham, he introduces David also as giving his suffrage in favor of the statement made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:69
verses.text: What then doth David say? and whom doth he pronounce blessed? is it him that triumphs in works, or him that hath enjoyed grace? him that hath obtained pardon and a gift? And when I speak of blessedness, I mean the chiefest of all good things; for as righteousness is greater than a reward, so is blessedness greater than righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:70
verses.text: Having then shown that the righteousness is better, not owing to Abraham's having received it only but also from reasonings (for he hath whereof to boast, he says, before God); he again uses another mode of showing that it is more dignified, by bringing David in to give his suffrage this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:71
verses.text: For he also, he says, pronounces him blessed who is so made righteous, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:72
verses.text: "Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:73
verses.text: And he seems to be bringing a testimony beside his purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:74
verses.text: For it does not say, Blessed are they whose faith is reckoned for righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:75
verses.text: But he does so on purpose, not through inadvertency, to show the greater superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:76
verses.text: For if he be blessed that by grace received forgiveness, much more is he that is made just, and that exhibits faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:77
verses.text: For where blessedness is, there all shame is removed, and there is much glory, since blessedness is a greater degree both of reward and of glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:78
verses.text: And for this cause what is the advantage of the other he states as unwritten, "Now to him that worketh is the reward reckoned not of grace;" but what the advantage of the faithful is, he brings Scriptural testimony to prove, saying, As David saith, "Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:79
verses.text: What, he means, is it that you say? Is it that "it is not of debt but of grace that he receives forgiveness?" But see it is this person who is pronounced blessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:80
verses.text: For he would not have pronounced him so, unless he saw him in the enjoyment of great glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:81
verses.text: And he does not say this "forgiveness" then comes upon the circumcision; but what saith he?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:82
verses.text: "Cometh this blessedness then" (which is the greater thing) "upon the circumcision or upon the uncircumcision?"  For now the subject of enquiry is, With whom is this good and great thing to be found; is it with the circumcision or with the uncircumcision? And notice its superiority! For he shows that it is so far from shunning the uncircumcision, that it even dwelt gladly with it before the circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:83
verses.text: For since he that pronounced it blessed was David, who was himself also in a state of circumcision, and he was speaking to those in that state, see how eagerly Paul contends for applying what he said to the uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:84
verses.text: For after joining the ascription of blessedness to righteousness, and showing that they are one and the same thing, he enquires how Abraham came to be righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:85
verses.text: For if the ascription of blessedness belong to the righteous, and Abraham was made righteous, let us see how he was made righteous, as uncircumcised or circumcised? Uncircumcised, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:86
verses.text: "For we say that faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:87
verses.text: After mentioning the Scripture above (for he said, "What saith the Scripture? Abraham believed in God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness,") here he goes on to secure also the judgment of the speakers, and shows that justification took place in the uncircumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:88
verses.text: Then from these grounds he solves another objection which is starting up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:89
verses.text: For if when in uncircumcision, one might say he was justified, to what purpose was the circumcision brought in?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:90
verses.text: "He received it," he says, "a sign and seal of the righteousness that was by the faith, which he had being yet uncircumcised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:91
verses.text: See you how he shows the Jews to be as it were of the class of parasites (i-e: guests), rather than those in uncircumcision, and that these were added to the others? For if he was justified and crowned while in uncircumcision, the Jews came in afterwards, Abraham is then the father first of the uncircumcised, which through faith appertain to him, and then of those in the circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:92
verses.text: For he is a forefather of two lines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:93
verses.text: See you faith lightening up? for till it came the patriarch was not justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:94
verses.text: See you the uncircumcision offering no hindrance? for he was uncircumcised, yet was not hindered from being justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:95
verses.text: The circumcision therefore is behind the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:96
verses.text: And why wonder that it is behind the faith, when it is even behind the uncircumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:97
verses.text: Nor is it behind faith only, but very far inferior to it, even so far as the sign is to the reality of which it is the sign; for instance, as the seal is to the soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:98
verses.text: (See Hom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:99
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:100
verses.text: on  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:101
verses.text: at the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:102
verses.text: ) And why, he says, did he want a seal then? He did not want it himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:103
verses.text: For what purpose then did he receive it? With a view to his being the father alike of them that believe in uncircumcision and in circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:104
verses.text: But not of those in circumcision absolutely: wherefore he goes on to say, "To them who are not of the circumcision only".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:105
verses.text: For if to the uncircumcised, it is not in that he is uncircumcised that he is their father, although justified in uncircumcision; but in that they imitated his faith; much less is it owing to circumcision that he is the forefather of those in the state of circumcision, unless faith also be added.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:106
verses.text: For he says that the reason of his receiving circumcision was that either of us two parties might have him for a forefather, and that those in the uncircumcision might not thrust aside those in the circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:107
verses.text: See how the former had him for their forefather first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:108
verses.text: Now if the circumcision be of dignity owing to its preaching righteousness, the uncircumcision even hath no small preeminence in having received it before the circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:109
verses.text: Then wilt thou be able to have him as a forefather when thou walkest in the steps of that faith, and art not contentious, nor a causer of division in bringing in the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:110
verses.text: What faith? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:111
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:112
verses.text: "Which he had being yet uncircumcised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:113
verses.text: Here again he lays low the lofty spirit of the Jews by reminding them of the time of the justification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:114
verses.text: And he well says, "the steps," that you as well as Abraham may believe in the resurrection of bodies that are dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:115
verses.text: For he also displayed his faith upon this point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:116
verses.text: And so if you reject the uncircumcision, be informed for certain that the circumcision is of no more use unto you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:117
verses.text: For if you follow not in the steps of his faith, though you were ten thousand times in a state of circumcision, you will not be Abraham's offspring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:118
verses.text: For even he received the circumcision for this end, that the man in a state of uncircumcision might not cast thee off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:119
verses.text: Do not then demand this of him too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:120
verses.text: For it was you whom the thing was to be an assistance to, not he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:121
verses.text: But he calls it a sign of the righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:122
verses.text: And this also was for thy sake, since now it is not even this: for thou then wert in need of bodily signs, but now there is no need of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:123
verses.text: "And was it not possible," one might say, "from his faith to learn the goodness of his soul?" Yes, it was possible but thou stoodest in need of this addition also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:124
verses.text: For since thou didst not imitate the goodness of his soul, and wert not able to see it, a sensible circumcision was given thee, that, after having become accustomed to this of the body, thou mightest by little and little be led on to the true love of wisdom in the soul also, and that having with much seriousness received it as a very great privilege, thou mightest be instructed to imitate and revere thine ancestor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:125
verses.text: This object then had God not only in the circumcision, but in all the other rites, the sacrifices, I mean, and the sabbath, and feasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:126
verses.text: Now that it was for thy sake that he received the circumcision, learn from the sequel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:127
verses.text: For after saying that he received a sign and a seal, he gives the reason also as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:128
verses.text: That he might be the father of the circumcision—to those who received the spiritual circumcision also, since if you have only this (i-e: the carnal), no farther good will come to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:129
verses.text: For this is then a sign, when the reality of which it is the sign is found with thee, that is, faith; since if thou have not this, the sign to thee has no longer the power of a sign, for what is it to be the sign of? or what the seal of, when there is nothing to be sealed? much as if you were to show one a purse with a seal to it, when there was nothing laid up within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:130
verses.text: And so the circumcision is ridiculous if there be no faith within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:131
verses.text: For if it be a sign of righteousness, but you have not righteousness, then you have no sign either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:132
verses.text: For the reason of your receiving a sign was that you might seek diligently for that reality whereof you have the sign: so that if you had been sure of diligently seeking thereafter without it, then you had not needed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:133
verses.text: But this is not the only thing that circumcision proclaims, namely righteousness, but righteousness in even an uncircumcised man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:134
verses.text: Circumcision then does but proclaim, that there is no need of circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:136
verses.text: "For if they which are of the Law be heirs, faith is made void, and the promise made of none effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:137
verses.text: He had shown that faith is necessary, that it is older than circumcision, that it is more mighty than the Law, that it establisheth the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:138
verses.text: For if all sinned, it was necessary: if one being uncircumcised was justified, it is older: if the knowledge of sin is by the Law and yet it was without the Law made evident, it is more mighty: if it has testimony borne to it by the Law, and establisheth the Law, it is not opposed to it, but friendly and allied to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:139
verses.text: Again, he shows upon other grounds too that it was not even possible by the Law to attain to the inheritance, and after having matched it with the circumcision, and gained it the victory, he brings it besides into contrast with the Law in these words, "For if they which are of the Law be heirs, faith is made void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:140
verses.text: To prevent them anyone from saying that one may have faith and also keep up the Law, he shows this to be impracticable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:141
verses.text: For he that clings to the Law, as if of saving force, does disparagement to faith's power; and so he says, "faith is made void," that is, there is no need of salvation by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:142
verses.text: For then it cannot show forth its own proper power; "and the promise is made of none effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:143
verses.text: This is because the Jew might say, What need have I of faith? If then this held, the things that were promised, would be taken away along with faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:144
verses.text: See how in all points he combats with them from the early times and from the Patriarch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:145
verses.text: For having shown from thence that righteousness and faith went together in the inheritance, he now shows that the promise did likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:146
verses.text: For to prevent the Jew from saying, What matters it to me if Abraham was justified by faith? Paul says, neither can what you are interested with, the promise of the inheritance, come into effect apart from it: which was what scared them most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:147
verses.text: But what promise is he speaking of? That of his being "the heir of the world," and that in him all should be blessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:148
verses.text: And how does he say that this promise is made of none effect?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:149
verses.text: "Because the Law worketh wrath: for where no Law is, there is no transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:150
verses.text: Now if it worketh wrath, and renders them liable for transgression, it is plain that it makes them so to a curse also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:151
verses.text: But they that are liable under a curse, and punishments, and transgression, are not worthy of inheriting, but of being punished and rejected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:152
verses.text: What then happens? faith comes, drawing on it the grace, so that the promise comes into effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:153
verses.text: For where grace is, there is a remitting, and where remitting is, there is no punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:154
verses.text: Punishment then being removed, and righteousness succeeding from faith, there is no obstacle to our becoming heirs of the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:155
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:156
verses.text: "Therefore it is of faith," he says, "that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:157
verses.text: You see that it is not the Law only that faith establisheth, but the promise of God also that it will not allow to fall to the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:158
verses.text: But the Law, on the other hand, by being kept to unseasonably, makes even the faith of none effect, and hindereth the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:159
verses.text: By this he shows that faith, so far from being superfluous, is even necessary to that degree, that without it there is no being saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:160
verses.text: For the Law worketh wrath, as all have transgressed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:161
verses.text: But this doth not even suffer wrath to arise at all: for "where no Law is," he says, "there is no transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:162
verses.text: Do you see how he not only does away with sin after it has existed, but does not even allow it to be produced? And this is why he says "by grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:163
verses.text: For what end? Not with a view to their being put to shame, but to the end that the promise might be sure to all the seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:164
verses.text: Here he lays down two blessings, both that the things given are sure, and also that they are to all the seed, so gathering in those of the Gentiles, and showing that the Jews are without, if they contend against the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:165
verses.text: For this is a surer thing than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:166
verses.text: For faith doeth thee no hurt (be not contentious), but even now thou art in danger from the Law, it preserves thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:167
verses.text: Next having said, "to all the seed," he defines what seed he meaneth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:168
verses.text: That which is of faith, he says, so blending with it their relationship to the Gentiles, and showing that they must not be proud of Abraham who do not believe as he did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:169
verses.text: And see a third thing which faith effected besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:170
verses.text: It makes the relationship to that righteous man more definite (ἀκρι βεστέραν), and holds him up as the ancestor of a more numerous issue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:171
verses.text: And this is why he does not say merely Abraham, but "our father," ours who believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:172
verses.text: Then he also seals what he has said by the testimony—  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:173
verses.text: "As it is written," he says, "I have made thee a father of many nations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:174
verses.text: Do you observe that this was ordered by Providence from of old? What then, he means, does He say this on account of the Ishmaelites, or of the Amalekites, or of the Hagarenes? This however, as he goes on he proves more distinctly not to be said of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:175
verses.text: But as yet he presses forward to another point, by which means he proves this very thing by defining the mode of the relationship, and establishing it with a vast reach of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:176
verses.text: What then does he say?  "Before (or, answering to, κατέναντι) Him Whom he believed, even God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:177
verses.text: But his meaning is something of this sort, as God is not the God of a part, but the Father of all, so is he also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:178
verses.text: And again, as God is a father not by way of the relationship of nature, but by way of the affiance of faith, so is he also inasmuch as it is obedience that makes him father of us all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:179
verses.text: For since they thought nothing of this relationship, as clinging to that grosser one, he shows that this is the truer relationship by lifting his discourse up to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:180
verses.text: And along with this he makes it plain that this was the reward of faith that he received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:181
verses.text: Consequently, if it were not so, and he were the father of all the dwellers upon earth, the expression before (or answering to) would be out of place, while the gift of God would be curtailed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:182
verses.text: For the "before," is equivalent to "alike with".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:183
verses.text: Since where is the marvel, pray, in a man's being the father of those sprung from himself? This is what is every man's lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:184
verses.text: But the extraordinary thing is, that those whom by nature he had not, them he received by the gift of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:185
verses.text: And so if thou wouldest believe that the patriarch was honored, believe that he is the father of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:186
verses.text: But after saying, "before Him Whom he believed, even God," he does not pause here, but goes on thus; "Who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were," so laying beforehand his foundations for discoursing upon the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:187
verses.text: And it was serviceable also to his present purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:188
verses.text: For if He could "quicken the dead" and bring in "those things that were not as though they were," then could He also make those who were not born of him to be his children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:189
verses.text: And this is why he does not say, bringing in the things which are not, but calling them, so showing the greater ease of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:190
verses.text: For as it is easy to us to call the things which are by name, so to Him it is easy, yea, and much easier to give a subsistence to things that are not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:191
verses.text: But after saying, that the gift of God was great and unspeakable, and having discoursed concerning His power, he shows farther that Abraham's faith was deserving of the gift, that you may not suppose him to have been honored without reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:192
verses.text: And after raising the attention of his hearers to prevent the Jew from clamoring and making doubts, and saying, "And how is it possible for those who are not children to become children?" he passes on to speak of the patriarch, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:193
verses.text: "Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, So shall thy seed be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:194
