verses.text: How was it that he "believed in hope against hope?" It was against man's hope, in hope which is of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:195
verses.text: (For he is showing the loftiness of the action, and leaving no room for disbelieving what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:196
verses.text: ) Things which are contrary to one another, yet faith blends them together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:197
verses.text: But if he were speaking about such as were from Ishmael, this language would be superfluous: for it was not by faith but by nature that they were begotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:198
verses.text: But he bringeth Isaac also before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:199
verses.text: For it was not concerning those nations that he believed, but concerning him who was to be from his barren wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:200
verses.text: If then it be a reward to be father of many nations, it would be so of those nations clearly of whom he so believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:201
verses.text: For that you may know that he is speaking of them, listen to what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:202
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:203
verses.text: "And being not weak in faith, he considered his own body now dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:204
verses.text: Do you see how he gives the obstacles, as well as the high spirit of the righteous man which surmounts all? "Against hope," he says, was that which was promised: this is the first obstacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:205
verses.text: For Abraham had no other person who had received a son in this way to look to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:206
verses.text: They that were after him looked to him, but he to no one, save to God only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:207
verses.text: And this is why he said, "against hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:208
verses.text: Then, "his body now dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:209
verses.text: This is a second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:210
verses.text: And, "the deadness of Sarah's womb".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:211
verses.text: This is a third, aye and a fourth obstacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:212
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:213
verses.text: "But he staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:214
verses.text: For God neither gave any proof nor made any sign, but there were only bare words promising such things as nature did not hold out any hopes of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:215
verses.text: Yet still he says, "he staggered not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:216
verses.text: He does not say, "He did not disbelieve," but, "He staggered not," that is, he neither doubted nor hesitated though the hindrances were so great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:217
verses.text: From this we learn, that if God promise even countless impossibilities, and he that heareth doth not receive them, it is not the nature of things that is to blame, but the unreasonableness of him who receiveth them not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:218
verses.text: "But was strong in faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:219
verses.text: See the pertinacity of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:220
verses.text: For since this discourse was about them that work and them that believe, he shows that the believer works more than the other, and requires more power, and great strength, and sustains no common degree of labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:221
verses.text: For they counted faith worthless, as having no labor in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:222
verses.text: Insisting then upon this, he shows that it is not only he that succeeds in temperance, or any other virtue of this sort, but he that displays faith also who requires even greater power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:223
verses.text: For as the one needs strength to beat off the reasonings of intemperance, so hath the faithful also need of a soul endued with power, that he may thrust aside the suggestions of unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:224
verses.text: How then did he become "strong?" By trusting the matter, he replies, to faith and not to reasonings: else he had fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:225
verses.text: But how came he to thrive in faith itself? By giving glory to God, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:226
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:227
verses.text: "And being fully persuaded that what He had promised, He was able also to perform".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:228
verses.text: Abstaining then from curious questionings is glorifying God, as indulging in them is transgressing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:229
verses.text: But if by entering into curious questions, and searching out things below, we fail to glorify Him, much more if we be over curious in the matter of the Lord's generation, shall we suffer to the utmost for our insolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:230
verses.text: For if the type of the resurrection is not to be searched into, much less those unutterable and awestriking subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:231
verses.text: And he does not use the word "believed" merely, but, "being fully persuaded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:232
verses.text: For such a thing is faith, it is clearer than the demonstration by reasons, and persuades more fully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:233
verses.text: For it is not possible for another reasoning succeeding to it to shake it afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:234
verses.text: He indeed that is persuaded with words may have his persuasion altered too by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:235
verses.text: But he that stays himself upon faith, hath henceforward fortified his hearing against words that may do hurt to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:236
verses.text: Having said then, that he was justified by faith, he shows that he glorified God by that faith; which is a thing specially belonging to a good life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:237
verses.text: For, "Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father Which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:238
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:239
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:240
verses.text: ) But lo! this is shown also to belong to faith! Again, as works need power, so doth faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:241
verses.text: For in their case the body often shareth the toil, but in the faith the well-doing belongeth to the soul alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:242
verses.text: And so the labor is greater, since it has no one to share the struggles with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:243
verses.text: Do you observe how he shows that all that belonged to works attached to faith in a far greater degree, as having whereof to glory before God,—requiring power and labor,—and again, glorifying God? And after saying, that "what He had promised, He is able also to perform," he seems to me to speak beforehand of things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:244
verses.text: For it is not things present merely that He promises, but also things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:245
verses.text: For the present are a type of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:246
verses.text: It is then a sign of a weak, little, and pitiful mind not to believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:247
verses.text: And so when any make faith a charge against us, let us make want of faith a charge against them in return, as pitiful, and little-minded, and foolish, and weak, and no better in disposition than asses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:248
verses.text: For as believing belongs to a lofty and high-born soul, so disbelieving doth to a most unreasonable and worthless one, and such as is sunken drowsily (κατενηνεγμένης) into the senselessness of brutes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:249
verses.text: Therefore having left these, let us imitate the Patriarch, and glorify God as he gave Him glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:250
verses.text: And what does it mean, gave Him glory? He held in mind His majesty, His boundless power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:251
verses.text: And having formed a just conception of Him, he was also "fully persuaded" about His promises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:252
verses.text: Let us then also glorify Him by faith as well as by works, that we may also attain to the reward of being glorified by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:253
verses.text: "For them that glorify Me, I will glorify" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:254
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:255
verses.text: ), He says: and indeed, if there were no reward, the very privilege of glorifying God were itself a glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:256
verses.text: For if men take a pride in the mere fact of speaking eulogies of kings, even if there be no other fruit of it; consider how glorious it must be, that our Lord is glorified by us: as again, how great a punishment to cause Him to be by our means blasphemed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:257
verses.text: And yet this very being glorified, He wisheth to be brought about for our sakes, since He doth not need it Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:258
verses.text: For what distance dost thou suppose to be between God and man? as great as that between men and worms? or as great as between Angels and worms? But when I have mentioned a distance even thus great, I have not at all expressed it: since to express its greatness is impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:259
verses.text: Would you, now, wish to have a great and marked reputation among worms? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:260
verses.text: If then thou that lovest glory, wouldest not wish for this, how should He Who is far removed from this passion, and so much farther above us, stand in need of glory from thee? Nevertheless, free from the want of it as He is, still He saith that He desireth it for thy sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:261
verses.text: For if He endured for thy sake to become a slave, why wonder that He upon the same ground layeth claim to the other particulars also? For He counts nothing unworthy of Himself which may be conducive to our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:262
verses.text: Since then we aware of this, let us shun sin altogether, because by reason of it He is blasphemed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:263
verses.text: For it says, "flee from sin, as from the face of a serpent: if thou comest too near unto it, it will bite thee" (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:264
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:265
verses.text: ): for it is not it that comes to us, but we that desert to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:266
verses.text: God has so ordered things that the Devil should not prevail over us by compulsion (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:267
verses.text: tyranny): since else none would have stood against his might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:268
verses.text: And on this account He set him a distant abode, as a kind of robber and tyrant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:269
verses.text: And unless he find a person unarmed and solitary for his assaults, he doth not venture to attack him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:270
verses.text: Except he see us travelling by the desert, he has not the courage to come near us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:271
verses.text: But the desert and place of the Devil is nothing else than sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:272
verses.text: We then have need of the shield of faith, the helmet of salvation, the sword of the Spirit, not only that we may not get evil intreated, but that ever should he be minded to leap upon us, we may cut off his head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:273
verses.text: Need we have of continual prayer that he may be bruised under our feet, for he is shameless and full of hardihood, and this though he fights from beneath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:274
verses.text: But yet even so he gets the victory: and the reason is, that we are not earnestly set upon being above his blows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:275
verses.text: For he has not even the power to lift himself very high, but he trails along upon the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:276
verses.text: And of this the serpent is a type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:277
verses.text: But if God set him in that rank from the beginning, much more will He now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:278
verses.text: But if thou dost not know what fighting from beneath may be, I also will try to explain to thee the manner of this war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:279
verses.text: What then may this fighting "from beneath" (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:280
verses.text: ) be? It is standing upon the lower things of the world to buffet us, such as pleasure and riches and all the goods of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:281
verses.text: And for this reason, whoever he seeth flying toward heaven, first, he will not even be able to leap so far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:282
verses.text: Secondly, even if he should attempt he will speedily fall.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:283
verses.text: For he hath no feet; be not afraid: he hath no wings; fear not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:284
verses.text: He trails upon the earth, and the things of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:285
verses.text: Do thou then have naught in common with the earth, and thou wilt not need labor even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:286
verses.text: For he hath not any knowledge of open fight: but as a serpent he hideth him in the thorns, nestling evermore in the "deceitfulness of riches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:287
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:288
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:289
verses.text: ) And if thou wert to cut away the thorns, he will easily be put to flight, being detected: and if thou knowest how to charm him with the inspired charms he will straightway be struck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:290
verses.text: For we have, we surely have, spiritual charms, even the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ and the might of the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:291
verses.text: This charm will not only bring the serpent out of his lurking places, and cast him into the fire (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:292
verses.text: ), but even wounds it healeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:293
verses.text: But if some that have said this Name have not been healed, it came of their own little faith, and was not owing to any weakness in what they said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:294
verses.text: For some did throng Jesus and press Him (Luke viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:295
verses.text: , ), and got no good therefrom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:296
verses.text: But the woman with an issue, without even touching His Body, but merely the hem of His garment, stanched a flux of blood of so long standing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:297
verses.text: (So St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:298
verses.text: Aug.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:299
verses.text: Serm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:300
verses.text: LXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:301
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:302
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:303
verses.text: O.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:304
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:305
verses.text: ) This Name is fearful alike to devils, and to passions, and to diseases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:306
verses.text: In this then let us find a pleasure, herewith let us fortify ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:307
verses.text: It was thus Paul waxed great, and yet he was of the like nature with ourselves, so the whole choir of the Disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:308
verses.text: But faith had made him a perfectly different person, and so much did it abound in them, that even their garments had great force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:309
verses.text: (Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:310
verses.text: ) What excuse then shall we deserve, if even the shadows and the garments of those men drave off death (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:311
verses.text: ), but our very prayers do not so much as bring the passions down? What is the reason of it? Our temper is widely different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:312
verses.text: For what nature gives, is as much ours as theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:313
verses.text: For he was born and brought up just as we are, and dwelt upon the earth and breathed the air, as we do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:314
verses.text: But in other points he was far greater and better than we are, in zeal, in faith, and love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:315
verses.text: Let us then imitate him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:316
verses.text: Let us allow Christ to speak through us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:317
verses.text: He desireth it more than we do: and by reason of this, He prepared this instrument, and would not have it remain useless and idle, but wisheth to keep it ever in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:318
verses.text: Why then dost thou not make it serviceable for the Maker's hand, but lettest it become unstrung, and makest it relaxed through luxury, and unfittest the whole harp for His use, when thou oughtest to keep the members of it in full stretch, and well strung, and braced with spiritual salt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:319
verses.text: For if Christ see our soul thus attuned, He will send forth His sounds even by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:320
verses.text: And when this taketh place, then shalt thou see Angels leaping for joy, (σκιρτὥντας) and Archangels too, and the Cherubim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:321
verses.text: Let us then become worthy of His spotless hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:322
verses.text: Let us invite Him to strike even upon our heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:323
verses.text: For He rather needeth not any inviting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:324
verses.text: Only make it worthy of that touch, and He will be foremost in running unto thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:325
verses.text: For if in consideration of their attainments not yet reached, He runneth to them (for when Paul was not yet so advanced He yet framed that praise for him) when He seeth one fully furnished, what is there that He will not do? But if Christ shall sound forth and the Spirit shall indeed light upon us, and we shall be better than the heaven, having not the sun and the moon fixed in our body, but the Lord of both sun and moon and angels dwelling in us and walking in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:326
verses.text: And this I say, not that we may raise the dead, or cleanse the lepers, but that we may show forth what is a greater miracle than all these—charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:327
verses.text: For wheresoever this glorious thing shall be there the Son taketh up His abode along with the Father, and the grace of the Spirit frequenteth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:328
verses.text: For "where two or three are gathered together in My Name," it says, "there am I in the midst of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:329
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:330
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:331
verses.text: ) Now this is for great affection, and for those that are very intimate friends, to have those whom they love on either side of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:332
verses.text: Who then, he means, is so wretched as not to wish to have Christ in the midst? We that are at variance with one another! And haply some one may ridicule me and ask, What is it that you mean? Do you not see that we are all within the same walls, and under the same enclosure of the Church, standing under the same fold with unanimity; that no one fighteth, that we be under the same shepherd, crying aloud in common, listening in common to what is being said, sending up our prayers in common,—and yet mention fighting and variance? Fighting I do mention, and I am not mad nor out of my sober mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:333
verses.text: For I see what I see, and know that we are under the same fold, and the same shepherd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:334
verses.text: Yet for this cause I make the greater lamentation, because, though there are so many circumstances to draw us together, we are at variance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:335
verses.text: And what sedition, it will be said, see you here? Here truly I see none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:336
verses.text: But when we have broken up, such an one accuses such another, another is openly insulting, another grudges, another is fraudulent, and rapacious, and violent, another indulges in unlawful love, another frames countless schemes of deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:337
verses.text: And if it were possible to open your souls, then ye would see all things distinctly, and know that I am not mad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:338
verses.text: Do you not see in a camp, that when it is peace, men lay down their arms and cross over unarmed and undefended into the camp of the enemy, but when they are protected with arms, and with guards and outposts, the nights are spent in watching, and the fires are kept continually burning, this state of things is no longer peace but war? Now this is what may be seen among us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:339
verses.text: For we are on our guard against one another, and fear one another and talk each of us into his neighbor's ear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:340
verses.text: And if we see any one else present, we hold our peace, and draw in all we were going to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:341
verses.text: And this is not like men that feel confidence, but like those that are strictly on their guard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:342
verses.text: "But these things we do (some one may say,) not to do wrong, but to escape having it done us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:343
verses.text: Yea, for this I grieve, that living as we do among brethren, we need be on our guard against having wrong done us; and we light up so many fires, and set guards and out-posts! The reason is the prevalence of falsehood, the prevalence of craft, the prevailing secession of charity, and war without truce.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:344
verses.text: By this means one may find men that feel more confidence in Gentiles (Greeks) than in Christians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:345
verses.text: And yet, how ashamed we ought to be of this; how we ought to weep and bewail at it! "What then, some may say, is to become of me? such and such an one is of ungainly temper, and vexatious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:346
verses.text: Where then is your religion (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:347
verses.text: philosophy)? where are the laws of the Apostles, which bid us bear one another's burdens? (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:348
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:349
verses.text: ) For if you have no notion of dealing well by your brother, when are you to be able to do so by a stranger? If you have not learnt how to treat a member of your own self, when are you likely to draw to you any from without, and to knit him to yourself? But how am I to feel? I am vexed exceedingly almost to tears, for I could have sent forth large fountains from mine eyes (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:350
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:351
verses.text: ), as that Prophet says, seeing as I do countless enemies upon the plain more galling than those he saw.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:352
verses.text: For he said, upon seeing the aliens coming against them, "My bowels! I am pained at my bowels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:353
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:354
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:355
verses.text: ) But when I see men arrayed under one leader, yet standing against one another, and biting and tearing their own members, some for money's sake, and some for glory's, and others quite at random ridiculing and mocking and wounding one another in countless ways, and corpses too worse treated than those in war, and that it is but the bare name of the brethren that is now left, myself feel my inability to devise any lament fitting such a catastrophe as this! Reverence now, oh reverence, this Table whereof we all are partakers! ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:356
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:357
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:358
verses.text: ) Christ, Who was slain for us, the Victim that is placed thereon! (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:359
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:360
verses.text: ) Robbers when they once partake of salt, cease to be robbers in regard to those with whom they have partaken thereof; that table changes their dispositions, and men fiercer than wild beasts it makes gentler than lambs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:361
verses.text: But we though partakers of such a Table, and sharers of such food as that, arm ourselves against one another, when we ought to arm against him who is carrying on a war against all of us, the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:362
verses.text: Yet this is why we grow weaker and he stronger every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:363
verses.text: For we do not join to form in defence against him, but along with him we stand against each other, and use him as a commander for such hostile arrays, when it is he alone that we ought to be fighting with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:364
verses.text: But now letting him pass, we bend the bow against our brethren only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:365
verses.text: What bows, you will say? Those of the tongue and the mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:366
verses.text: For it is not javelins and darts only, but words too, keener far than darts, that inflict wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:367
verses.text: And how shall we be able to bring this war to an issue? one will ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:368
verses.text: If thou perceivest that when thou speakest ill of thy brother, thou art casting up mire out of thy mouth, if thou perceivest that it is a member of Christ that thou art slandering, that thou art eating up thine own flesh (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:369
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:370
verses.text: ), that thou art making the judgment set for thee more bitter (fearful and uncorrupt as it is), that the shaft is killing not him that is smitten, but thyself that shot it forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:371
verses.text: But he did you some wrong, may be, and injured you? Groan at it, and do not rail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:372
verses.text: Weep, not for the wrong done thee, but for his perdition, as thy Master also wept at Judas, not because Himself was to be crucified, but because he was a traitor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:373
verses.text: Has he insulted thee and abused thee? Beseech God for him, that He may speedily become appeased toward him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:374
verses.text: He is thy brother, he is a member of thee, the fruit of the same pangs as thyself, he has been invited to the same Table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:375
verses.text: But he only makes fresh assaults upon me, it may be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:376
verses.text: Then is thy reward all the greater for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:377
verses.text: On this ground then there is the best reason for abating one's anger, since it is a mortal wound that he has received, since the devil hath wounded him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:378
verses.text: Do not thou then give a further blow, nor cast thyself down together with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:379
verses.text: For so long as thou standest thou hast the means of saving him also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:380
verses.text: But if thou dash thyself down by insulting deeds in return, who is then to lift you both up? Will he that is wounded? Nay, for he cannot, now that he is down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:381
verses.text: But wilt thou that art fallen along with him? And how shalt thou, that couldest not support thine own self, be able to lend a hand to another? Stand therefore now nobly, and setting thy shield before thee, and draw him, now he is dead, away from the battle by thy long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:382
verses.text: Rage hath wounded him, do not thou also wound him, but cast out even that first shaft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:383
verses.text: For if we associate with each other on such terms, we shall soon all of us become healthful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:384
verses.text: But if we arm ourselves against one another, there will be no farther need even of the devil to our ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:385
verses.text: For all war is an evil, and civil war especially.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:386
verses.text: But this is a sorer evil than even a civil one, as our mutual rights are greater than those of citizenship, yea, than of kindred itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:387
verses.text: Of old, Abel's brother slew him and shed the blood of his kinsman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:388
verses.text: But this murder is more lawless than that, in that the rights of kinsmanship are greater, and the death a sorer evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:389
verses.text: For he wounded the body, but thou hast whetted thy sword against the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:390
verses.text: "But thou didst first suffer ill".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:391
verses.text: Yes, but it is not suffering ill, but doing it, that is really suffering ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:392
verses.text: Now consider; Cain was the slayer, Abel was the slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:393
verses.text: Who then was the dead? He that after death crieth, (for He saith, "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth to Me,") (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:394
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:395
verses.text: ), or he who while he lived was yet trembling and in fear? He was, assuredly he was, more an object of pity than any dead man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:396
verses.text: Seest thou how to be wronged is better, though a man come even to be murdered? learn that to wrong is worse, though a man should be strong enough even to kill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:397
verses.text: He smote and cast down his brother, yet the latter was crowned, the former was punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:398
verses.text: Abel was made away with and slain wrongfully, but he even when dead accused (comp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:399
verses.text: John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:400
verses.text: ), and convicted and overcame: the other, though alive, was speechless, and was ashamed, and was convicted, and effected the opposite of what he intended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:401
verses.text: For he made away with him because he saw him beloved, expecting to cast him out of the love also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:402
verses.text: Yet he did but make the love more intense, and God sought him more when dead, saying, "Where is thy brother Abel?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:403
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:404
verses.text: ) For thou hast not extinguished the desire towards him by thine envy, but hast kindled it up the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:405
verses.text: Thou hast not lessened his honor by slaying him, but hast made it the more ample.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:406
verses.text: Yet before this God had even made him subject to thee, whereas since thou hast slain him, even when dead, he will take vengeance upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:407
verses.text: So great was my love towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:408
verses.text: Who then was the condemned person, the punisher or the punished? He that enjoyed so great honor from God, or he that was given up to a certain novel and unexpected punishment? Thou didst not fear him (he would say) while alive, thou shalt fear him therefore when dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:409
verses.text: Thou didst not tremble when on the point of thrusting with the sword.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:410
verses.text: Thou shalt be seized, now the blood is shed, with a continual trembling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:411
verses.text: While alive he was thy servant, and thou showedst no forbearance to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:412
verses.text: For this reason, now he is dead, he hath become a master thou shalt be afraid of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 9:413
verses.text: Thinking then upon these things, beloved, let us flee from envy, let us extinguish malice, let us recompense one another with charity, that we may reap the blessings rising from it, both in the present life and the life which is to come, by the grace and love toward man, etc, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:3
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:4
verses.text: "Now it was not written for his sake alone, that it was imputed to him for righteousness; but for us also, to whom it shall be imputed, if we believe on Him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:5
verses.text: After saying many great things of Abraham, and his faith, and righteousness, and honor before God, lest the hearer should say, What is this to us, for it is he that was justified? he places us close to the Patriarch again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:6
verses.text: So great is the power of spiritual words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:7
verses.text: For of one of the Gentiles, one who was recently come near, one who had done no work, he not only says that he is in nothing inferior to the Jew who believes (i-e: as a Jew), but not even to the Patriarch, but rather, if one must give utterance to the wondrous truth, even much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:8
verses.text: For so noble is our birth, that his faith is but the type of ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:9
verses.text: And he does not say, If it was reckoned unto him, it is probable it will be also to us, that he might not make it matter of syllogism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:10
verses.text: But he speaks in authentic words of the divine law, and makes the whole a declaration of the Scripture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:11
verses.text: For why was it written, he says, save to make us see that we also were justified in this way? For it is the same God Whom we have believed, and upon the same matters, if it be not in the case of the same persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:12
verses.text: And after speaking of our faith, he also mentions God's unspeakable love towards man, which he ever presents on all sides, bringing the Cross before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:13
verses.text: And this he now makes plain by saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:14
verses.text: "Who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:15
verses.text: See how after mentioning the cause of His death, he makes the same cause likewise a demonstration of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:16
verses.text: For why, he means, was He crucified? Not for any sin of His own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:17
verses.text: And this is plain from the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:18
verses.text: For if He were a sinner, how should He have risen? But if He rose, it is quite plain that He was not a sinner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:19
verses.text: But if He was not a sinner, how came He to be crucified?—For others,—and if for others, then surely he rose again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:20
verses.text: Now to prevent your saying, How, when liable for so great sins, came we to be justified? he points out One that blotteth out all sins, that both from Abraham's faith, whereby he was justified, and from the Saviour's Passion, whereby we were freed from our sins, he might confirm what he had said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:21
verses.text: And after mentioning His Death, he speaks also of His Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:22
verses.text: For the purpose of His dying was not that He might hold us liable to punishment and in condemnation, but that He might do good unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:23
verses.text: For for this cause He both died and rose again, that He might make us righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:24
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:25
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:26
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:27
verses.text: "Therefore being justified by faith, let us  have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:28
verses.text: What does "Let us have peace" mean? Some say, "Let us not be at variance, through a peevish obstinacy for bringing in the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:29
verses.text: But to me he seems to be speaking now of our conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:30
verses.text: For after having said much on the subject of faith, he had set it before righteousness which is by works, to prevent any one from supposing what he said was a ground for listlessness, he says, "let us have peace," that is, let us sin no more, nor go back to our former estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:31
verses.text: For this is making war with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:32
verses.text: And "how is it possible," saith one, "to sin no more?" How was the former thing possible? For if when liable for so many sins we were freed from all by Christ, much more shall we be able through Him to abide in the estate wherein we are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:33
verses.text: For it is not the same thing to receive peace when there had been none, and to keep it when it has been given, since to acquire surely is harder than to keep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:34
verses.text: Yet nevertheless the more difficult hath been made easy, and carried out into effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:35
verses.text: That which is the easier thing then will be what we shall easily succeed in, if we cling to Him who hath wrought even the other for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:36
verses.text: But here it is not the easiness only which he seems to me to hint at, but the reasonableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:37
verses.text: For if He reconciled us when we were in open war with Him, it is reasonable that we should abide in a state of reconciliation, and give unto Him this reward for that He may not seem to have reconciled untoward and unfeeling creatures to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:38
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:39
verses.text: "By Whom also we have access," he says, "by faith unto this grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:40
verses.text: ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:41
verses.text: add, unto, etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:42
verses.text: )  If then He hath brought us near to Himself, when we were far off, much more will He keep us now that we are near.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:43
verses.text: And let me beg you to consider how he everywhere sets down these two points; His part, and our part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:44
verses.text: On His part, however, there be things varied and numerous and diverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:45
verses.text: For He died for us, and farther reconciled us, and brought us to Himself, and gave us grace unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:46
verses.text: But we brought faith only as our contribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:47
verses.text: And so he says," "by faith, unto this grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:48
verses.text: What grace is this? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:49
verses.text: It is the being counted worthy of the knowledge of God, the being forced from error, the coming to a knowledge of the Truth, the obtaining of all the blessings that come through Baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:50
verses.text: For the end of His bringing us near was that we might receive these gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:51
verses.text: For it was not only that we might have simple remission of sins, that we were reconciled; but that we might receive also countless benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:52
verses.text: Nor did He even pause at these, but promised others, namely, those unutterable blessings that pass understanding alike and language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:53
verses.text: And this is why he has set them both down also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:54
verses.text: For by mentioning grace he clearly points at what we have at present received, but by saying, "And we rejoice in hope of the glory of God," he unveils the whole of things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:55
verses.text: And he had well said, "wherein also we stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:56
verses.text: For this is the nature of God's grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:57
verses.text: It hath no end, it knows no bound, but evermore is on the advance to greater things, which in human things is not the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:58
verses.text: Take an instance of what I mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:59
verses.text: A person has acquired rule and glory and authority, yet he does not stand therein continuously, but is speedily cast out of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:60
verses.text: Or if man take it not from him, death comes, and is sure to take it from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:61
verses.text: But God's gifts are not of this kind; for neither man, nor occasion, nor crisis of affairs, nor even the Devil, nor death, can come and cast us out of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:62
verses.text: But when we are dead we then more strictly speaking have possession of them, and keep going on enjoying more and more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:63
verses.text: And so if thou feel in doubt about those to come; from those now present, and what thou hast already received, believe in the other also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:64
verses.text: For this is why he says, "And we rejoice (καυχώμεθα) in hope of the glory of God," that you may learn, what kind of soul the faithful ought to have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:65
verses.text: For it is not only for what hath been given, but for what is to be given, that we ought to be filled with confidingness, as though it were already given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:66
verses.text: For one "rejoices" in what is already given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:67
verses.text: Since then the hope of things to come is even as sure and clear as that of what is given, he says that in that too we in like manner "rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:68
verses.text: For this cause also he called them glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:69
verses.text: For if it contributeth unto God's glory, come to pass it certainly will, though it do not for our sakes, yet for Him it will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:70
verses.text: And why am I saying (he means) that the blessings to come are worthy of being gloried in (καυχήσεως)? Why even the very evils of this time present are able to brighten up our countenances, and make us find in them even our repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:71
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:72
verses.text: "And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:73
verses.text: Now, consider how great the things to come are, when even at things that seem to be distressful we can be elated; so great is God's gift, and such a nothing any distastefulness in them! For in the case of external goods, the struggle for them brings trouble and pain and irksomeness along with it; and it is the crowns and rewards that carry the pleasure with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:74
verses.text: But in this case it is not so, for the wrestlings have to us no less relish than the rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:75
verses.text: For since there were sundry temptations in those days, and the kingdom existed in hopes, the terrors were at hand, but the good things in expectation, and this unnerved the feebler sort, even before the crowns he gives them the prize now, by saying that we should "glory even in tribulations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:76
verses.text: And what he says is not "you should glory," but we glory, giving them encouragement in his own person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:77
verses.text: Next since what he had said had an appearance of being strange and paradoxical, if a person who is struggling in famine, and is in chains and torments, and insulted, and abused, ought to glory, he next goes on to confirm it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:78
verses.text: And (what is more), he says they are worthy of being gloried in, not only for the sake of those things to come, but for the things present in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:79
verses.text: For tribulations are in their own selves a goodly thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:80
verses.text: How so? It is because they anoint us unto patient abiding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:81
verses.text: Wherefore after saying we glory in tribulations, he has added the reason, in these words, "Knowing that tribulation worketh patience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:82
verses.text: Notice again the argumentative spirit of Paul, how he gives their argument an opposite turn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:83
verses.text: For since it was tribulations above all that made them give up the hopes of things to come, and which cast them into despondency, he says that these are the very reasons for confidingness, and for not desponding about the things to come, for "tribulation," he says, "worketh patience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:84
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:85
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:86
verses.text: "And patience experience, and experience hope; and hope maketh not ashamed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:87
verses.text: Tribulations, that is, are so far from confuting these hopes, that they even prove them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:88
verses.text: For before the things to come are realized, there is a very great fruit which tribulation hath—patience; and the making of the man that is tried, experienced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:89
verses.text: And it contributes in some degree too to the things to come, for it gives hope a vigor within us, since there is nothing that so inclines a man to hope for blessings as a good conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:90
verses.text: Now no man that has lived an upright life is unconfiding about things to come, as of those who have been negligent there are many that, feeling the burden of a bad conscience, wish there were neither judgment nor retribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:91
verses.text: What then? do our goods lie in hopes? Yes, in hopes—but not mere human hopes, which often slip away, and put him that hoped to shame; when some one, who was expected to patronize him, dies, or is altered though he lives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:92
verses.text: No such lot is ours: our hope is sure and unmoveable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:93
verses.text: For He Who hath made the promise ever liveth, and we that are to be the enjoyers of it, even should we die, shall rise again, and there is absolutely nothing which can put us to shame, as having been elated at random, and to no purpose, upon unsound hopes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:94
verses.text: Having then sufficiently cleared them of all doubtfulness by these words of his, he does not let his discourse pause at the time present, but urges again the time to come, knowing that there were men of weaker character, who looked too for present advantages, and were not satisfied with these mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:95
verses.text: And so he offers a proof for them in blessings already given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:96
verses.text: For lest any should say, But what if God be unwilling to give them to us? For that He can, and that He abideth and liveth, we all know: but how do we know, that He is willing, also, to do it? From the things which have been done already.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:97
verses.text: "What things done?" The Love which He hath shown for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:98
verses.text: In doing what? some may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:99
verses.text: In giving the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:100
verses.text: Wherefore after saying "hope maketh not ashamed," he goes on to the proof of this, as follows:  "Because the love of God is," he does not say "given," but "shed abroad in our hearts," so showing the profusion of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:101
verses.text: That gift then, which is the greatest possible, He hath given; not heaven and earth and sea, but what is more precious than any of these, and hath rendered us Angels from being men, yea sons of God, and brethren of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:102
verses.text: But what is this gift? The Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:103
verses.text: Now had He not been willing to present us after our labors with great crowns, He would never have given us such mighty gifts before our labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:104
verses.text: But now the warmth of His Love is hence made apparent, that it is not gradually and little by little that He honors us; but He hath shed abroad the full fountain of His blessings, and this too before our struggles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:105
verses.text: And so, if thou art not exceedingly worthy, despond not, since thou hast that Love of thy Judge as a mighty pleader for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:106
verses.text: For this is why he himself by saying, "hope maketh not ashamed," has ascribed everything not to our well-doings, but to God's love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:107
verses.text: But after mentioning the gift of the Spirit, he again passes to the Cross, speaking as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:108
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:109
verses.text: "For while we were yet without strength, Christ in due time died for the ungodly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:110
verses.text: For scarcely for a righteous man will one die: yet pervadenture for a good man some would even dare to die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:111
verses.text: But God commendeth His love towards us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:112
verses.text: Now what he is saying is somewhat of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:113
verses.text: For if for a virtuous man, no one would hastily choose to die, consider thy Master's love, when it is not for virtuous men, but for sinners and enemies that He is seen to have been crucified—which he says too after this, "In that, if when we were sinners Christ died for us,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:114
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:115
verses.text: "Much more then, being now justified by His Blood, we shall be saved from wrath through Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:116
verses.text: For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son, much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by His life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:117
verses.text: And what he has said looks indeed like tautology, but it is not to any one who accurately attends to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:118
verses.text: Consider then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:119
verses.text: He wishes to give them reasons for confidence respecting things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:120
verses.text: And first he gives them a sense of shame from the righteous man's decision, when he says, that he also "was fully persuaded that what God had promised He was able also to perform;" and next from the grace that was given; then from the tribulation, as sufficing to lead us into hopes; and again from the Spirit, whom we have received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:121
verses.text: Next from death, and from our former viciousness, he maketh this good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:122
verses.text: And it seems indeed, as I said, that what he had mentioned was one thing, but it is discovered to be two, three, and even many more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:123
verses.text: First, that "He died:" second, that it was "for the ungodly;" third, that He "reconciled, saved, justified" us, made us immortal, made us sons and heirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:124
verses.text: It is not from His Death then only, he says, that we draw strong assertions, but from the gift which was given unto us through His Death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:125
verses.text: And indeed if He had died only for such creatures as we be, a proof of the greatest love would what He had done be! but when He is seen at once dying, and yielding us a gift, and that such a gift, and to such creatures, what was done casts into shade our highest conceptions, and leads the very dullest on to faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:126
verses.text: For there is no one else that will save us, except He Who so loved us when we were sinners, as even to give Himself up for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:127
verses.text: Do you see what a ground this topic affords for hope? For before this there were two difficulties in the way of our being saved; our being sinners, and our salvation requiring the Lord's Death, a thing which was quite incredible before it took place, and required exceeding love for it to take place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:128
verses.text: But now since this hath come about, the other requisites are easier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:129
verses.text: For we have become friends, and there is no further need of Death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:130
verses.text: Shall then He who hath so spared his enemies as not to spare His Son, fail to defend them now they are become friends, when He hath no longer any need to give up his Son? For it is either because a person does not wish it, or because though he may wish it perhaps, yet he is unable to do it, that he does not save.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:131
verses.text: Now none of these things can be said of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:132
verses.text: For that He is willing is plain from His having given up His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:133
verses.text: But that He is able also is the very thing He proved likewise, from the very fact of His having justified men who were sinners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:134
verses.text: What is there then to prevent us any more from obtaining the things to come? Nothing! Then again, lest upon hearing of sinners, and enemies, and strengthless ones, and ungodly, thou shouldest be inclined to feel abashed and blush; hear what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:136
verses.text: "And not only so, but we also joy in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom we have now received the atonement".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:137
verses.text: What meaneth the "not only so?" Not only were we saved, he means, but we even glory for this very reason, for which some suppose we ought to hide our faces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:138
verses.text: For, for us who lived in so great wickedness to be saved, was a very great mark of our being exceedingly beloved by Him that saved us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:139
verses.text: For it was not by angels or archangels, but by His Only-begotten Son Himself, that He saved us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:140
verses.text: And so the fact of His saving us, and saving us too when we were in such plight, and doing it by means of His Only-begotten, and not merely by His Only-begotten, but by His Blood, weaves for us endless crowns to glory in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:141
verses.text: For there is not anything that counts so much in the way of glory and confidence, as the being treated as friends (φιλεἵσθαι) by God, and finding a Friend (φιλεἵν) in Him that loveth (ἀγαπὥντα) us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:142
verses.text: This it is that maketh the angels glorious, and the principalities and powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:143
verses.text: This is greater than the Kingdom, and so Paul placed it above the Kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:144
verses.text: For this also I count the incorporeal powers blessed, because they love Him, and in all things obey Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:145
verses.text: And on this score the Prophet also expressed his admiration at them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:146
verses.text: "Ye that excel in strength, that fulfil His Word".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:147
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:148
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:149
verses.text: ) And hence too Isaiah extolleth the Seraphim, setting forth their great excellency from their standing near that glory, which is a sign of the greatest love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:150
verses.text: Let us then emulate the powers above, and be desirous not only of standing near the throne, but of having Him dwelling in us who sitteth upon the Throne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:151
verses.text: He loved us when we hated Him, and also continueth to love us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:152
verses.text: "For He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and on the good and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:153
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:154
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:155
verses.text: ) As then He loveth us, do thou love Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:156
verses.text: For He is our Friend (φιλεἵ γὰρ).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:157
verses.text: And how cometh it, some will say, that one who is our Friend threateneth hell, and punishment, and vengeance? It is owing to His loving us alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:158
verses.text: For all He doeth and is busied with, is with a view to strike out thy wickedness, and to refrain with fear, as with a kind of bridle, thy inclinableness to the worse side, and by blessings and by pains recovering thee from thy downward course, and leading thee up to Him, and keeping thee from all vice, which is worse than hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:159
verses.text: But if thou mockest what is said, and wouldest rather live continually in misery, than be punished for a single day, it is no marvel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:160
verses.text: For this is but a sign of thy unformed judgment (ἀτελοὕς γνώμης), drunkenness, and incurable disorder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:161
verses.text: Since little children even when they see the physician going to apply burning or the knife, flee and leap away screaming and convulsed, and choose to have a continual sore eating into their body, rather than to endure a temporary pain, and so enjoy health afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:162
verses.text: But those who have come to discretion, know that to be diseased is worse than submitting to the knife, as also to be wicked is worse than to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:163
verses.text: For the one is to be cured and to be healthy, the other to ruin one's constitution and to be in continual feebleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:164
verses.text: Now that health is better than feebleness, surely is plain to every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:165
verses.text: Thieves then ought to weep not when they have their sides pierced through, but when they pierce through walls and murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:166
verses.text: For if the soul be better than the body (as it is), when the former is ruined there is more reason to groan and lament; but if a man does not feel it, so much the more reason to bewail it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:167
verses.text: For those that love with an unchastened love ought to be more pitied than those who have a violent fever, and those that are drunken, than those that are undergoing torture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:168
verses.text: But if these are more painful (some may say), how come we to give them the preference? Because there are many of mankind, who, as the proverb saith, like the worse, and they choose these, and pass by the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:169
verses.text: And this one may see happening as well in victuals as in forms of government, in emulous aims of life too, and in the enjoyment of pleasure, and in wives, and in houses, and in slaves, and in lands, and in the case of all other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:170
verses.text: For which is more pleasurable pray, cohabiting with women or with males? with women or with mules? Yet still we shall find many that pass over women, and cohabit with creatures void of reason, and abuse the bodies of males.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:171
verses.text: Yet natural pleasures are greater than unnatural ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:172
verses.text: But still many there are that follow after things ridiculous and joyless, and accompanied with a penalty, as if pleasurable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:173
verses.text: Well but to them, a man may say, these things appear so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:174
verses.text: Now this alone is ground enough to make them miserable, that they think those things to be pleasurable which are not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:175
verses.text: Thus they assume punishment to be worse than sin which it is not, but just the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:176
verses.text: Yet, if it were an evil to the sinner, God would not have added evils to the evil; for He that doeth everything to extinguish evil, would not have increased it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:177
verses.text: Being punished then is no evil to the man who has done wrong, but not being punished, when in that plight, is evil, just as for the infirm not to be cured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:178
verses.text: (Plat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:179
verses.text: Gorg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:180
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:181
verses.text: , sqq.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:182
verses.text: ) For there is nothing so evil as extravagant desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:183
verses.text: And when I say, extravagant, I mean that of luxury, and that of ill-placed glory, and that of power, and in general that of all things which go beyond what is necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:184
verses.text: For such is he who lives a soft and dissolute life, who seems to be the happiest of men, but is the most wretched, as superinducing upon his soul harsh and tyrannical sovereigns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:185
verses.text: For this cause hath God made the present a life of labor to us, that He may rid us of that slavery, and bring us into genuine freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:186
verses.text: For this cause He threatened punishment, and made labors a part of our portion in life, so muzzling our vaunting spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:187
verses.text: In this way the Jews also, when they were fettered to the clay and brick making, were at once self-governed, and called continually upon God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:188
verses.text: But when they were in the enjoyment of freedom, then they murmured, and provoked the Lord, and pierced themselves through with countless evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:189
verses.text: What then, it may be said, will you say to those frequent instances of men being altered for the worse by tribulations? Why, that this is no effect of tribulation, but of their own imbecility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:190
verses.text: For neither if a man had a weak stomach and could not take a bitter medicine which would act as a purgative, but was made even worse by it, would it be the drug we should find fault with, but the weakness of the part, as we should therefore here too with the yieldingness of temper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:191
verses.text: For he who is altered so by tribulation, is much more likely to be affected in this way by laxity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:192
verses.text: If he fails even when splinted, (or tied) (this is what affliction is), much more will he when the bandage is removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:193
verses.text: If when braced up he is altered, much more when in a state of tumor (χαυνούμενος).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:194
verses.text: And how am I, one may ask, to keep from being so altered by tribulation? Why, if thou reflectest that, wish it or not, thou wilt have to bear the thing inflicted: but if thou dost it with a thankful spirit, thou wilt gain very greatly thereby; but if thou art indignant at it, and ragest and blasphemest, thou wilt not make the calamity lighter, but thou wilt render its wave more troublous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:195
verses.text: By feeling then in this way, let us turn what is necessary into a matter of our own choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:196
verses.text: What I mean is this—suppose one has lost his own son, another all his property: if you reflect that it is not in the nature of things for what has taken place to be undone; while it is to gain fruit from the misfortune, though irremediable, even that of bearing the circumstance nobly; and if instead of using blasphemous words, thou wert to offer up words of thanksgiving to the Lord, so would evils brought upon thee against thy will become to thee the good deeds of a free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:197
verses.text: Hast thou seen a son taken prematurely away? Say, "the Lord hath given, the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:198
verses.text: Do you see your fortune exhausted? Say, "naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:199
verses.text: (Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:200
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:201
verses.text: ) Do you see evil men faring well, and just men faring ill and undergoing ills without number, and dost thou not know where to find the cause? Say, "I became even as it were a beast before Thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:202
verses.text: Yet I am ever with Thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:203
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:204
verses.text: lxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:205
verses.text: ) But if thou wilt search out the cause, reflect that He has fixed a day in which He will judge the world, and so you will throw off perplexity, for then every man will meet his deserts, even as Lazarus and the rich man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:206
verses.text: Call to mind the Apostles, for they too rejoiced at being scourged, at being driven about and undergoing numberless sufferings, because they were "counted worthy to suffer shame for His Name's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:207
verses.text: (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:208
verses.text: ) And do thou, then, if thou art sick, bear it nobly, and own thyself indebted to God for it, and thou shalt receive the same reward with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:209
verses.text: But how, when in feebleness and pain, art thou to be able to feel grateful to the Lord? Thou wilt if thou lovest Him sincerely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:210
verses.text: For if the Three Children who were thrown into the furnace, and others who were in prisons, and in countless other evils, ceased not to give thanks, much more will they who are in a state of disease, be able to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:211
verses.text: For there is not, assuredly there is not, anything which vehement desire doth not get the better of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:212
verses.text: But when the desire is even that of God, it is higher than anything, and neither fire, nor the sword, nor poverty, nor infirmity, nor death, nor aught else of the kind appeareth dreadful to one who hath gotten this love, but scorning them all, he will fly to heaven, and will have affections no way inferior to those of its inhabitants, seeing nothing else, neither heaven, nor earth, nor sea, but gazing only at the one Beauty of that glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:213
verses.text: And neither the vexations of this life present will depress him, nor the things which are goodly and attended with pleasure elate him or puff him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:214
