verses.text: Let us then love with this love (for there is not anything equal unto it) both for the sake of things present and for the sake of things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:215
verses.text: Or rather, more than for these, for the nature of the love itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:216
verses.text: For we shall be set free both from the punishments of this life and of that which is to come, and shall enjoy the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:217
verses.text: Yet neither is the escape from hell, nor the fruition of the kingdom, anything great in comparison of what is yet to be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:218
verses.text: For greater than all these things is it to have Christ our beloved at once and our lover.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:219
verses.text: For if when this happens with men it is above all pleasure; when both happen from God, what language or what thought is able to set before one the blessedness of this soul? There is none that can, save the experience of it only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:220
verses.text: That then we may by experience come to know what is this spiritual joy, and life of blessedness, and untold treasure of good things, let us leave everything to cling to that love, with a view as well to our own joy as to the glory of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 10:221
verses.text: For unto Him is the glory and power, with His Only-begotten, and the Holy Ghost, now, and ever, and unto all ages evermore, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:1
verses.text: Homily X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:3
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:4
verses.text: "Wherefore as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin, and so death passed upon (διἥλθεν mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:5
verses.text: εἴς…) all men, for that all have sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:6
verses.text: As the best physicians always take great pains to discover the source of diseases, and go to the very fountain of the mischief, so doth the blessed Paul also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:7
verses.text: Hence after having said that we were justified, and having shown it from the Patriarch, and from the Spirit, and from the dying of Christ (for He would not have died unless He intended to justify), he next confirms from other sources also what he had at such length demonstrated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:8
verses.text: And he confirms his proposition from things opposite, that is, from death and sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:9
verses.text: How, and in what way? He enquires whence death came in, and how it prevailed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:10
verses.text: How then did death come in and prevail? "Through the sin of one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:11
verses.text: But what means, "for that all have sinned?" This; he having once fallen, even they that had not eaten of the tree did from him, all of them, become mortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:12
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:13
verses.text: "For until the Law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed where there is no law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:14
verses.text: The phrase "till the Law" some think he used of the time before the giving of the Law—that of Abel, for instance, or of Noah, or of Abraham—till Moses was born.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:15
verses.text: What was the sin in those days, at this rate? some say he means that in Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:16
verses.text: For hitherto it was not done away, (he would say,) but the fruit of it was yet in vigor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:17
verses.text: For it had borne that death whereof all partake, which prevailed and lorded over us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:18
verses.text: Why then does he proceed, "But sin is not imputed when there is no law?" It was by way of objection from the Jews, say they who have spoken on our side, that he laid this position down and said, if there be no sin without the Law, how came death to consume all those before the Law? But to me it seems that the sense presently to be given has more to be said for it, and suits better with the Apostle's meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:19
verses.text: And what sense is this? In saying, that "till the Law sin was in the world," what he seems to me to mean is this, that after the Law was given the sin resulting from the transgression of it prevailed, and prevailed too so long as the Law existed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:20
verses.text: For sin, he says, can have no existence if there be no law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:21
verses.text: If then it was this sin, he means, from the transgression of the Law that brought forth death, how was it that all before the Law died? For if it is in sin that death hath its origin, but when there is no law, sin is not imputed, how came death to prevail? From whence it is clear, that it was not this sin, the transgression, that is, of the Law, but that of Adam's disobedience, which marred all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:22
verses.text: Now what is the proof of this? The fact that even before the Law all died: for "death reigned," he says, "from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:23
verses.text: How did it reign? "After the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of Him that was to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:24
verses.text: Now this is why Adam is a type of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:25
verses.text: How a type? it will be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:26
verses.text: Why in that, as the former became to those who were sprung from him, although they had not eaten of the tree, the cause of that death which by his eating was introduced; thus also did Christ become to those sprung from Him, even though they had not wrought righteousness, the Provider of that righteousness which through His Cross He graciously bestowed on us all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:27
verses.text: For this reason, at every turn he keeps to the "one," and is continually bringing it before us, when he says, "As by one man sin entered into the world"—and, "If through the offence of one many be dead:" and, "Not as it was by one that sinned, so is the gift;" and, "The judgment was by one to condemnation:" and again, "If by one (or, the one) man's offence death reigned by one;" and "Therefore as by the offence of one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:28
verses.text: And again, "As by one man's disobedience many (or, the many) were made sinners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:29
verses.text: And so he letteth not go of the one, that when the Jew says to thee, How came it, that by the well-doing of this one Person, Christ, the world was saved? thou mightest be able to say to him, How by the disobedience of this one person, Adam, came it to be condemned? And yet sin and grace are not equivalents, death and life are not equivalents, the Devil and God are not equivalents, but there is a boundless space between them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:30
verses.text: When then as well from the nature of the thing as from the power of Him that transacteth it, and from the very suitableness thereof (for it suiteth much better with God to save than to punish), the preëminence and victory is upon this side, what one word have you to say for unbelief, tell me? However, that what had been done was reasonable, he shows in the following words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:31
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:32
verses.text: "But not as the offence, so is also the free gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:33
verses.text: For if through the offence of one many be dead, much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto the many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:34
verses.text: For what he says is somewhat of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:35
verses.text: If sin had so extensive effects, and the sin of one man too; how can grace, and that the grace of God, not the Father only, but also the Son, do otherwise than be the more abundant of the two? For the latter is far the more reasonable supposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:36
verses.text: For that one man should be punished on account of another does not seem to be much in accordance with reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:37
verses.text: But for one to be saved on account of another is at once more suitable and more reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:38
verses.text: If then the former took place, much more may the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:39
verses.text: Hence he has shown from these grounds the likelihood and reasonableness of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:40
verses.text: For when the former had been made good, this would then be readily admitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:41
verses.text: But that it is even necessarily so, he makes good from what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:42
verses.text: How then does he make it good?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:43
verses.text: "And not as it was by one that sinned, so is the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:44
verses.text: For the judgment was by one to condemnation, but the free gift is of many offences unto justification".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:45
verses.text: And what is this that he is speaking of? It is that sin had power to bring in death and condemnation; but grace did not do away that one sin only, but also those that followed after in its train.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:46
verses.text: Lest then the words "as" and "so" might seem to make the measure of the blessings and the evils equal, and that you might not think, upon hearing of Adam, that it was only that sin which he had brought in which was done away with, he says that it was from many offences that an indemnity was brought about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:47
verses.text: How is this plain? Because after the numberless sins committed after that in paradise, the matter issued in justification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:48
verses.text: But where righteousness is, there of necessity follows by all means life, and the countless blessings, as does death where sin was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:49
verses.text: For righteousness is more than life, since it is even the root of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:50
verses.text: That there were several goods then brought in, and that it was not that sin only that was taken away, but all the rest along with it, he points out when he says, that "the gift was of many offences unto justification".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:51
verses.text: In which a proof is necessarily included, that death was also torn up by the roots.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:52
verses.text: But since he had said, that the second was greater than the first, he is obliged to give further grounds again for this same thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:53
verses.text: For, before, he had said that if one man's sin slew all, much more will the grace of One have the power to save.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:54
verses.text: After that he shows that it was not that sin only that was done away by the grace, but all the rest too, and that it was not that the sins were done away only, but that righteousness was given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:55
verses.text: And Christ did not merely do the same amount of good that Adam did of harm, but far more and greater good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:56
verses.text: Since then he had made such declarations as these, he wants again here also further confirmation of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:57
verses.text: And how does he give this confirmation? He says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:58
verses.text: "For if by one man's offence death reigned by one, much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift and (so Field with most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:59
verses.text: ) of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:60
verses.text: What he says, amounts to this nearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:61
verses.text: What armed death against the world? The one man's eating from the tree only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:62
verses.text: If then death attained so great power from one offence, when it is found that certain received a grace and righteousness out of all proportion to that sin, how shall they still be liable to death? And for this cause, he does not here say "grace," but "superabundance of grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:63
verses.text: For it was not as much as we must have to do away the sin only, that we received of His grace, but even far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:64
verses.text: For we were at once freed from punishment, and put off all iniquity, and were also born again from above (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:65
verses.text: ) and rose again with the old man buried, and were redeemed, justified, led up to adoption, sanctified, made brothers of the Only-begotten, and joint heirs and of one Body with Him, and counted for His Flesh, and even as a Body with the Head, so were we united unto Him! All these things then Paul calls a "superabundance" of grace, showing that what we received was not a medicine only to countervail the wound, but even health, and comeliness, and honor, and glory and dignities far transcending our natural state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:66
verses.text: And of these each in itself was enough to do away with death, but when all manifestly run together in one, there is not the least vestige of it left, nor can a shadow of it be seen, so entirely is it done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:67
verses.text: As then if any one were to cast a person who owed ten mites (ὀβόλους) into prison, and not the man himself only, but wife and children and servants for his sake; and another were to come and not to pay down the ten mites only, but to give also ten thousand talents of gold, and to lead the prisoner into the king's courts, and to the throne of the highest power, and were to make him partaker of the highest honor and every kind of magnificence, the creditor would not be able to remember the ten mites; so hath our case been.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:68
verses.text: For Christ hath paid down far more than we owe, yea as much more as the illimitable ocean is than a little drop.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:69
verses.text: Do not then, O man, hesitate as thou seest so great a store of blessings, nor enquire how that mere spark of death and sin was done away, when such a sea of gifts was brought in upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:70
verses.text: For this is what Paul intimated by saying that "they who have received the abundance of the grace and righteousness shall reign in life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:71
verses.text: And as he had now clearly demonstrated this, he again makes use of his former argument, clenching it by taking up the same word afresh, and saying that if for that offence all were punished, then they may be justified too by these means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:72
verses.text: And so he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:73
verses.text: "Therefore as by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of One the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:74
verses.text: And he insists again upon it, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:75
verses.text: "For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of One shall many be made righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:76
verses.text: What he says seems indeed to involve no small question: but if any one attends to it diligently, this too will admit of an easy solution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:77
verses.text: What then is the question? It is the saying that through the offence of one many were made sinners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:78
verses.text: For the fact that when he had sinned and become mortal, those who were of him should be so also, is nothing unlikely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:79
verses.text: But how would it follow that from his disobedience another would become a sinner? For at this rate a man of this sort will not even deserve punishment, if, that is, it was not from his own self that he became a sinner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:80
verses.text: What then does the word "sinners" mean here? To me it seems to mean liable to punishment and condemned to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:81
verses.text: Now that by Adam's death we all became mortals, he had shown clearly and at large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:82
verses.text: But the question now is, for what purpose was this done? But this he does not go on to add: for it contributed nothing to his present object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:83
verses.text: For it is against a Jew that the contest is, who doubted and made scorn of the righteousness by One.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:84
verses.text: And for this reason after showing that the punishment too was brought in by one upon all, the reason why this was so he has not added.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:85
verses.text: For he is not for superfluities, but keeps merely to what is necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:86
verses.text: For this is what the principles of disputation did not oblige him to say any more than the Jew; and therefore he leaves it unsolved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:87
verses.text: But if any of you were to enquire with a view to learn, we should give this answer: That we are so far from taking any harm from this death and condemnation, if we be sober-minded, that we are the gainers even by having become mortal, first, because it is not an immortal body in which we sin; secondly, because we get numberless grounds for being religious (φιλοσοφίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:88
verses.text: For to be moderate, and to be temperate, and to be subdued, and to keep ourselves clear of all wickedness, is what death by its presence and by its being expected persuades us to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:89
verses.text: But following with these, or rather even before these, it hath introduced other greater blessings besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:90
verses.text: For it is from hence that the crowns of the martyrs come, and the rewards of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:91
verses.text: Thus was Abel justified, thus was Abraham, in having slain his son, thus was John, who for Christ's sake was taken off, thus were the Three Children, thus was Daniel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:92
verses.text: For if we be so minded, not death only, but even the devil himself will be unable to hurt us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:93
verses.text: And besides there is this also to be said, that immortality awaits us, and after having been chastened a little while, we shall enjoy the blessings to come without fear, being as if in a sort of school in the present life, under instruction by means of disease, tribulation, temptations, and poverty, and the other apparent evils, with a view to our becoming fit for the reception of the blessings of the world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:94
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:95
verses.text: "Moreover the Law entered: that the offence might abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:96
verses.text: Since then he had shown that the world was condemned from Adam, but from Christ was saved and freed from condemnation, he now seasonably enters upon the discussion of the Law, here again undermining the high notions of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:97
verses.text: For it was so far from doing any good, he means, or from being any way helpful, but the disorder was only increased by its having come in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:98
verses.text: But the particle "that" again does not assign the cause, but the result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:99
verses.text: For the purpose of its being given was not "in order that" it might abound, for it was given to diminish and destroy the offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:100
verses.text: But it resulted the opposite way, not owing to the nature of the Law, but owing to the listlessness of those who received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:101
verses.text: But why did he not say the Law was given, but "the Law entered by the way?" It was to show that the need of it was temporary, and not absolute or imperative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:102
verses.text: And this he says also to the Galatians, showing the very same thing another way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:103
verses.text: "For before faith came," he says, "we were kept under the Law, shut up unto the faith which should afterwards be revealed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:104
verses.text: And so it was not for itself, but for another, that it kept the flock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:105
verses.text: For since the Jews were somewhat gross-minded, and enervated, and indifferent to the gifts themselves, this was why the Law was given, that it might convict them the more, and clearly teach them their own condition, and by increasing the accusation might the more repress them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:106
verses.text: But be not thou afraid, for it was not that the punishment might be greater that this was done, but that the grace might be seen to be greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:107
verses.text: And this is why he proceeds,  "But where sin abounded, grace did much more abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:108
verses.text: He does not say did abound, but "did much more abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:109
verses.text: For it was not remission from punishment only that He gave us, but that from sins, and life also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:110
verses.text: As if any were not merely to free a man with a fever from his disease, but to give him also beauty, and strength, and rank; or again, were not to give one an hungered nourishment only, but were to put him in possession of great riches, and were to set him in the highest authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:111
verses.text: And how did sin abound? some will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:112
verses.text: The Law gave countless commands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:113
verses.text: Now since they transgressed them all, trangression became more abundant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:114
verses.text: Do you see what a great difference there is between grace and the Law? For the one became an addition to the condemnation, but the other, a further abundance of gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:115
verses.text: Having then mentioned the unspeakable munificence, he again discusses the beginning and the root both of death and of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:116
verses.text: What then is the root of death? It is sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:117
verses.text: Wherefore also he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:118
verses.text: "That as sin reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life, through our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:119
verses.text: This he says to show that the latter ranks as a king, the former, death, as a soldier, being marshalled under the latter, and armed by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:120
verses.text: If then the latter (i-e: sin) armed death, it is plain enough that the righteousness destructive hereof, which by grace was introduced, not only disarms death, but even destroys it, and undoes entirely the dominion thereof, in that it is the greatest of the two, as being brought in not by man and the devil, but by God and grace, and leading our life unto a goodlier estate, and to blessings unlimited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:121
verses.text: For of it there will never be any end (to give you a view of its superiority from this also).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:122
verses.text: For the other cast us out of our present life, but grace, when it came, gave us not the present life, but the immortal and eternal one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:123
verses.text: But for all these things Christ is our voucher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:124
verses.text: Doubt not then for thy life if thou hast righteousness, for righteousness is greater than life as being mother of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:125
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:126
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:127
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:128
verses.text: "What then? shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:129
verses.text: He is again turning off to exhortation, yet introducing it not directly, lest he should seem to many to be irksome and vexing, but as if it rose out of the doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:130
verses.text: For if, even so diversifying his address, he was afraid of their being offended at what he said, and therefore said, "I have written the more boldly unto you in some sort," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:131
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:132
verses.text: ) much more would he have seemed to them, had he not done so, to be too harsh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:133
verses.text: Since then he showed the greatness of the grace by the greatness of the sins it healed, and owing to this it seemed in the eyes of the unthinking to be an encouragement to sin (for if the reason, they would say, why greater grace was shown, was because we had done great sins, let us not give over sinning, that grace may be more displayed still), now that they might not say this or suspect it, see how he turns the objection back again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:134
verses.text: First he does it by his deprecation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:135
verses.text: "God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:136
verses.text: And this he is in the habit of doing at things confessed on all hands to be absurd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:137
verses.text: And then he lays down an irrefragable argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:138
verses.text: And what is it?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:139
verses.text: "How shall we," he says, "that are dead to sin, live any longer therein?"  What does "we are dead" mean? Does it mean that as for that, and as far as it goes, we have all received the sentence of death? or, that we became dead to it by believing any being enlightened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:140
verses.text: This is what one should rather say, since the sequel makes this clearly right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:141
verses.text: But what is becoming dead to it? The not obeying it in anything any more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:142
verses.text: For this baptism effected once for all, it made us dead to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:143
verses.text: But this must of our own earnestness thenceforth continually be maintained, so that, although sin issue countless commands to us, we may never again obey it, but abide unmovable as a dead man doth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:144
verses.text: And indeed he elsewhere saith that sin itself is dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:145
verses.text: But there he sets that down as wishing to show that virtue is easy, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:146
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:147
verses.text: ?) But here, as he earnestly desires to rouse the hearer, he puts the death on his side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:148
verses.text: Next, since what was said was obscure, he again explains, using what he had said also in the way of reproof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:149
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:150
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:151
verses.text: "Know ye not," he says, "my brethren, that so many of us as were baptized into Christ were baptized into His death? therefore we are buried with Him by baptism into death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:152
verses.text: What does being "baptized into His Death" mean? That it is with a view to our dying as He did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:153
verses.text: For Baptism is the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:154
verses.text: What the Cross then, and Burial, is to Christ, that Baptism hath been to us, even if not in the same respects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:155
verses.text: For He died Himself and was buried in the Flesh, but we have done both to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:156
verses.text: Wherefore he does not say, planted together in His Death, but in the likeness of His Death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:157
verses.text: For both the one and the other is a death, but not of the same subject; since the one is of the Flesh, that of Christ; the other of sin, which is our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:158
verses.text: As then that is real, so is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:159
verses.text: But if it be real, then what is of our part again must be contributed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:160
verses.text: And so he proceeds,  "That as Christ was raised up from the dead by the Glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:161
verses.text: Here he hints, along with the duty of a careful walk, at the subject of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:162
verses.text: In what way? Do you believe, he means, that Christ died, and that He was raised again? Believe then the same of thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:163
verses.text: For this is like to the other, since both Cross and Burial is thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:164
verses.text: For if thou hast shared in Death and Burial, much more wilt thou in Resurrection and Life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:165
verses.text: For now the greater is done away with, the sin I mean, it is not right to doubt any longer about the lesser, the doing away of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:166
verses.text: But this he leaves for the present to the conscience of his hearers to reason out, but himself, after the resurrection to come had been set before us, demands of us another, even the new conversation, which is brought about in the present life by a change of habits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:167
verses.text: When then the fornicator becomes chaste, the covetous man merciful, the harsh subdued, even here a resurrection has taken place, the prelude to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:168
verses.text: And how is it a resurrection? Why, because sin is mortified, and righteousness hath risen again, and the old life hath been made to vanish, and this new and angelic one is being lived in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:169
verses.text: But when you hear of a new life, look for a great alteration, a wide change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:170
verses.text: But tears come into my eyes, and I groan deeply to think how great religiousness (φιλοσοφίαν) Paul requires of us, and what listlessness we have yielded ourselves up to, going back after our baptism to the oldness we before had, and returning to Egypt, and remembering the garlic after the manna.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:171
verses.text: (Num.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:172
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:173
verses.text: ) For ten or twenty days at the very time of our Illumination, we undergo a change, but then take up our former doings again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:174
verses.text: But it is not for a set number of days, but for our whole life, that Paul requires of us such a conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:175
verses.text: But we go back to our former vomit, thus after the youth of grace building up the old age of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:176
verses.text: For either the love of money, or the slavery to desires not convenient, or any other sin whatsoever, useth to make the worker thereof old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:177
verses.text: "Now that which decayeth and waxeth old is ready to vanish away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:178
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:179
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:180
verses.text: ) For there is no body, there surely is none, to be seen as palsied by length of time, as a soul is decayed and tottering with many sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:181
verses.text: Such an one gets carried on to the last degree of doting, yielding indistinct sounds, like men that are very old and crazed, being surcharged with rheum, and great distortion of mind, and forgetfulness, and with scales upon its eyes, and disgustful to men, and an easy prey to the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:182
verses.text: Such then are the souls of sinners; not so those of the righteous, for they are youthful and well-favored, and are in the very prime of life throughout, ever ready for any fight or struggle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:183
verses.text: But those of sinners, if they receive even a small shock, straightway fall and are undone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:184
verses.text: And it was this the Prophet made appear, when he said, that like as the chaff which the wind scattereth from the face of the earth (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:185
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:186
verses.text: ), thus are they that live in sin whirled to and fro, and exposed to every sort of harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:187
verses.text: For they neither see like a healthy person, nor hear with simplicity, they speak not articulately, but are oppressed with great shortness of breath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:188
verses.text: They have their mouth overflowing with spittle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:189
verses.text: And would it were but spittle, and nothing offensive! But now they send forth words more fetid than any mire, and what is worst, they have not power even to spit this saliva of words away from them, but taking it in their hand with much lewdness, they smear it on again, so as to be coagulating, and hard to perspire through.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:190
verses.text: Perhaps ye are sickened with this description.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:191
verses.text: Ought ye not, then to be more so at the reality? For if these things when happening in the body are disgustful, much more when in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:192
verses.text: Such was that son who wasted out all his share, and was reduced to the greatest wretchedness, and was in a feebler state than any imbecile or disordered person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:193
verses.text: But when he was willing, he became suddenly young by his decision alone and his change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:194
verses.text: For as soon as he had said, "I will return to my Father," this one word conveyed to him all blessings; or rather not the bare word, but the deed which he added to the word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:195
verses.text: For he did not say, "Let me go back," and then stay there; but said, Let me go back, and went back, and returned the whole of that way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:196
verses.text: Thus let us also do; and even if we have gotten carried beyond the boundary, let us go up to our Father's house, and not stay lingering over the length of the journey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:197
verses.text: For if we be willing, the way back again is easy and very speedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:198
verses.text: Only let us leave the strange and foreign land; for this is what sin is, drawing us far away from our Father's house; let us leave her then, that we may speedily return to the house of our Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:199
verses.text: For our Father hath a natural yearning towards us, and will honor us if we be changed, no less than those that are unattainted, if we change, but even more, just as the father showed that son the greater honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:200
verses.text: For he had greater pleasure himself at receiving back his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:201
verses.text: And how am I to go back again? one may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:202
verses.text: Do but put a beginning upon the business, and the whole is done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:203
verses.text: Stay from vice, and go no farther into it, and thou hast laid hold of the whole already.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:204
verses.text: For as in the case of the sick, being no worse may be a beginning of getting better, so is the case with vice also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:205
verses.text: Go no further, and then your deeds of wickedness will have an end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:206
verses.text: And if you do so for two days, you will keep off on the third day more easily; and after three days you will add ten, then twenty, then an hundred, then your whole life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:207
verses.text: (Cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:208
verses.text: Hom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:209
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:210
verses.text: on St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:211
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:212
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:213
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:214
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:215
verses.text: ) For the further thou goest on, the easier wilt thou see the way to be, and thou wilt stand on the summit itself, and wilt at once enjoy many goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:216
verses.text: For so it was when the prodigal came back, there were flutes, and harps, and dancings, and feasts, and assemblings: and he who might have called his son to account for his ill-timed extravagance, and flight to such a distance, did nothing of the sort, but looked upon him as unattainted, and could not find it in him even to use the language of reproach, or rather, even to mention barely to him the former things, but threw himself upon him, and kissed him, and killed the calf, and put a robe upon him, and placed on him abundant honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:217
verses.text: Let us then, as we have such examples before us, be of good cheer and keep from despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:218
verses.text: For He is not so well pleased with being called Master, as Father, nor with having a slave as with having a son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:219
verses.text: And this is what He liketh rather than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:220
verses.text: This then is why He did all that He has done; and "spared not even His Only-begotten Son" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:221
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:222
verses.text: ), that we might receive the adoption of sons, that we might love Him, not as a Master only, but as a Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:223
verses.text: And if He obtained this of us He taketh delight therein as one that has glory given him, and proclaimeth it to all though He needeth nothing of ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:224
verses.text: This is what, in Abraham's case for instance, He everywhere does, using these words, "I am the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:225
verses.text: And yet it was they of His household who should have found an honor in this; but now it is the Lord evidently who does this; for this is why He says to Peter, "Lovest thou Me more than these?" (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:226
verses.text: ) to show that He seeketh nothing so much as this from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:227
verses.text: For this too He bade Abraham offer his son to Him, that He might make it known to all that He was greatly beloved by the patriarch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:228
verses.text: Now this desire to be loved exceedingly comes from loving exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:229
verses.text: For this cause too He said to the Apostles, "He that loveth father or mother more than Me, is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:230
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:231
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:232
verses.text: ) For this cause He bids us esteem that even which is in the most close connection with us, our soul (or, life, v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:233
verses.text: , and John xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:234
verses.text: ), as second to the love of him, since He wisheth to be beloved by us with exceeding entireness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:235
verses.text: For we too, if we have no strong feelings about a person, have no strong desire for his friendship either, though he be great and noble; whereas when we love any one warmly and really, though the person loved be of low rank and humble, yet we esteem love from him as a very great honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:236
verses.text: And for this reason He Himself also called it glory not to be loved by us only, but even to suffer those shameful things in our behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:237
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:238
verses.text: ) However, those things were a glory owing to love only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:239
verses.text: But whatever we suffer for Him, it is not for love alone; but even for the sake of the greatness and dignity of Him we long for, that it would with good reason both be called glory, and be so indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:240
verses.text: Let us then incur dangers for Him as if running for the greatest crowns, and let us esteem neither poverty, nor disease, nor affront, nor calumny, nor death itself, to be heavy and burdensome, when it is for Him that we suffer these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:241
verses.text: For if we be right-minded, we are the greatest possible gainers by these things, as neither from the contrary to these shall we if not right-minded gain any advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:242
verses.text: But consider; does any one affront thee and war against thee? Doth he not thereby set thee upon thy guard, and give thee an opportunity of growing like unto God? For if thou lovest him that plots against thee, thou wilt be like Him that "maketh His Sun to rise upon the evil and good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:243
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:244
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:245
verses.text: ) Does another take thy money away? If thou bearest it nobly, thou shalt receive the same reward as they who have spent all they have upon the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:246
verses.text: For it says, "Ye took joyfully the spoiling of your goods, knowing that ye have in heaven a better and an enduring substance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:247
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:248
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:249
verses.text: ) Has any one reviled thee and abused thee, whether truly or falsely, he weaves for thee a very great crown if thou bearest meekly his contumely; since he too, who calumniates, provides for us an abundant reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:250
verses.text: For "rejoice," it says, "and be exceeding glad, when men say all manner of evil against you falsely, because great is your reward in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:251
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:252
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:253
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:254
verses.text: ) And he too that speaketh truth against us is of the greatest service, if we do but bear meekly what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:255
verses.text: For the Pharisee spake evil of the Publican, and with truth, still instead of a Publican he made him a righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:256
verses.text: (Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:257
verses.text: ) And what need to go into particular instances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:258
verses.text: For any one that will go to the conflicts of Job may learn all these points accurately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:259
verses.text: And this is why Paul said, "God for us, who against us?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:260
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:261
verses.text: ) As then by being earnest, we gain even from things that vex us, so by being listless, we do not even improve from things that favor us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:262
verses.text: For what did Judas profit, tell me, by being with Christ? or what profit was the Law to the Jew? or Paradise to Adam? or what did Moses profit those in the wilderness? And so we should leave all, and look to one point only, how we may husband aright our own resources.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:263
verses.text: And if we do this, not even the devil himself will ever get the better of us, but will make our profiting the greater, by putting us upon being watchful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:264
verses.text: Now in this way it is that Paul rouses the Ephesians, by describing his fierceness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:265
verses.text: Yet we sleep and snore, though we have to do with so crafty an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:266
verses.text: And if we were aware of a serpent nestling by our bed, we should make much ado to kill him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:267
verses.text: But when the devil nestleth in our souls, we fancy that we take no harm, but lie at our ease; and the reason is, that we see him not with the eyes of our body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:268
verses.text: And yet this is why we should rouse us the more and be sober.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:269
verses.text: For against an enemy whom one can perceive, one may easily be on guard; but one that cannot be seen, if we be not continually in arms, we shall not easily escape.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:270
verses.text: And the more so, because he hath no notion of open combat (for he would surely be soon defeated), but often under the appearance of friendship he insinuates the venom of his cruel malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:271
verses.text: In this way it was that he suborned Job's wife, by putting on the mask of natural affectionateness, to give that wretchless advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:272
verses.text: And so when conversing with Adam, he puts on the air of one concerned and watching over his interests, and saith, that "your eyes shall be opened in the day that ye eat of the tree".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:273
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:274
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:275
verses.text: ) Thus Jephtha too he persuaded, under the pretext of religion, to slay his daughter, and to offer the sacrifice the Law forbade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:276
verses.text: Do you see what his wiles are, what his varying warfare? Be then on thy guard, and arm thyself at all points with the weapons of the Spirit, get exactly acquainted with his plans, that thou mayest both keep from being caught, and easily catch him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:277
verses.text: For it was thus that Paul got the better of him, by getting exactly acquainted with these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:278
verses.text: And so he says, "for we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:279
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:280
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 11:281
verses.text: ) Let us then also be earnest in learning and avoiding his stratagems, that after obtaining a victory over him, we may, whether in this present life or in that which is to come, be proclaimed conquerors, and obtain those unalloyed blessings, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:1
verses.text: Homily XI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:3
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:4
verses.text: "For if we have been planted togetherin the likeness of His death, we shall be also in the likeness of His resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:5
verses.text: What I had before occasion to remark, that I mention here too, that he continually digresseth into exhortation, without making any twofold division as he does in the other Epistles, and setting apart the former portion for doctrines, and the latter for the care of moral instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:6
verses.text: Here then he does not do so, but blends the latter with the subject throughout, so as to gain it an easy admission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:7
verses.text: Here then he says there are two mortifyings, and two deaths, and that one is done by Christ in Baptism, and the other it is our duty to effect by earnestness afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:8
verses.text: For that our former sins were buried, came of His gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:9
verses.text: But the remaining dead to sin after baptism must be the work of our own earnestness, however much we find God here also giving us large help.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:10
verses.text: For this is not the only thing Baptism has the power to do, to obliterate our former transgressions; for it also secures against subsequent ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:11
verses.text: As then in the case of the former, thy contribution was faith that they might be obliterated, so also in those subsequent to this, show thou forth the change in thine aims, that thou mayest not defile thyself again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:12
verses.text: For it is this and the like that he is counselling thee when he says, "for if we have been planted together in the likeness of His Death, we shall be also in the likeness of His Resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:13
verses.text: Do you observe, how he rouses the hearer by leading him straightway up to his Master, and taking great pains to show the strong likeness? This is why he does not say "in death," lest you should gainsay it, but, "in the likeness of His Death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:14
verses.text: For our essence itself hath not died, but the man of sins, that is, wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:15
verses.text: And he does not say, "for if we have been" partakers of "the likeness of His Death;" but what? "If we have been planted together," so, by the mention of planting, giving a hint of the fruit resulting to us from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:16
verses.text: For as His Body, by being buried in the earth, brought forth as the fruit of it the salvation of the world; thus ours also, being buried in baptism, bore as fruit righteousness, sanctification, adoption, countless blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:17
verses.text: And it will bear also hereafter the gift of the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:18
verses.text: Since then we were buried in water, He in earth, and we in regard to sin, He in regard to His Body, this is why he did not say, "we were planted together in His Death," but "in the likeness of His Death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:19
verses.text: For both the one and the other is death, but not that of the same subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:20
verses.text: If then he says, "we have been planted together in His Death, we shall be in that of His Resurrection," speaking here of the Resurrection which (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:21
verses.text: be of His Resurrection) is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:22
verses.text: For since when he was upon the subject of the Death before, and said, "Know ye not, brethren, that so many of us as were baptized into Christ were baptized into His Death?" he had not made any clear statement about the Resurrection, but only about the way of life after baptism, bidding men walk in newness of life; therefore he here resumes the same subject, and proceeds to foretell to us clearly that Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:23
verses.text: And that you may know that he is not speaking of that resulting from baptism, but about the other, after saying, "for if we were planted together in the likeness of His Death," he does not say that we shall be in the likeness of His Resurrection, but we shall belong to the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:24
verses.text: For to prevent thy saying, and how, if we did not die as He died, are we to rise as He rose? when he mentioned the Death, he did not say, "planted together in the Death," but, "in the likeness of His Death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:25
verses.text: But when he mentioned the Resurrection, he did not say, "in the likeness of the Resurrection," but we shall be "of the Resurrection" itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:26
verses.text: And he does not say, We have been made, but we shall be, by this word again plainly meaning that Resurrection which has not yet taken place, but will hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:27
verses.text: Then with a view to give credibility to what he says, he points out another Resurrection which is brought about here before that one, that from that which is present thou mayest believe also that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:28
verses.text: For after saying, "we shall be planted together in the Resurrection," he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:29
verses.text: "Knowing this, that our old man is crucified with Him, that the body of sin might be destroyed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:30
verses.text: So putting together both the cause and the demonstration of the Resurrection which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:31
verses.text: And he does not say is crucified, but is crucified with Him, so bringing baptism near to the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:32
verses.text: And on this score also it was that he said above, "We have been planted together in the likeness of His Death that the body of sin might be destroyed," not giving that name to this body of ours, but to all iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:33
verses.text: For as he calls the whole sum of wickedness the old man, thus again the wickedness which is made up of the different parts of iniquity he calls the body of that man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:34
verses.text: And that what I am saying is not mere guesswork, hearken to Paul's own interpretation of this very thing in what comes next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:35
verses.text: For after saying, "that the body of sin might be destroyed," he adds, "that henceforth we should not serve sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:36
verses.text: For the way in which I would have it dead is not so that ye should be destroyed and die, but so that ye sin not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:37
verses.text: And as he goes on he makes this still clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:38
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:39
verses.text: "For he that is dead," he says, "is freed (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:40
verses.text: justified) from sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:41
verses.text: This he says of every man, that as he that is dead is henceforth freed from sinning, lying as a dead body, so must he that has come up from baptism, since he has died there once for all, remain ever dead to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:42
verses.text: If then thou hast died in baptism, remain dead, for any one that dies can sin no more; but if thou sinnest, thou marrest God's gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:43
verses.text: After requiring of us then heroism (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:44
verses.text: philosophy) of this degree, he presently brings in the crown also, in these words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:45
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:46
verses.text: "Now if we be dead with Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:47
verses.text: And indeed even before the crown, this is in itself the greater crown, the partaking with our Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:48
verses.text: But he says, I give even another reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:49
verses.text: Of what kind is it? It is life eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:50
verses.text: For "we believe," he says, "that we shall also live with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:51
verses.text: And whence is this clear?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:52
verses.text: "That Christ being raised from the dead, dieth no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:53
verses.text: And notice again his undauntedness, and how he makes the thing good from opposite grounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:54
verses.text: Since then it was likely that some would feel perplexed at the Cross and the Death, he shows that this very thing is a ground for feeling confident henceforward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:55
verses.text: For suppose not, he says, because He once died, that He is mortal, for this is the very reason of His being immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:56
verses.text: For His death hath been the death of death, and because He did die, He therefore doth not die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:57
verses.text: For even that death  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:58
verses.text: "He died unto sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:59
verses.text: What does "unto sin" mean? It means that He was not subject even to that one, but for our sin, that He might destroy it, and cut away its sinews and all its power, therefore He died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:60
verses.text: Do you see how he affrighteth them? For if He does not die again, then there is no second laver, then do thou keep from all inclinableness to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:61
verses.text: For all this he says to make a stand against the "let us do evil that good may come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:62
verses.text: Let us remain in sin that grace may abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:63
verses.text: To take away this conception then, root and branch, it is, that he sets down all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:64
verses.text: But in that "He liveth, He liveth unto God," he says,—that is, unchangeably, so that death hath no more any dominion over Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:65
verses.text: For if it was not through any liability to it that He died the former death, save only for the sin of others, much less will He die again now that He hath done that sin away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:66
verses.text: And this he says in the Epistle to the Hebrews also, "But now once," he says, "in the end of the world hath He appeared to put away sin by the Sacrifice of Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:67
verses.text: And as it is appointed unto men once to die, and after that the judgment; so Christ was once offered to bear the sins of many, and unto them that look for Him shall He appear the second time without sin unto salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:68
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:69
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:70
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:71
verses.text: ) And he both points out the power of the life that is according to God, and also the strength of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:72
verses.text: For with regard to the life according to God, he showeth that Christ shall die no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:73
verses.text: With regard to sin, that if it brought about the death even of the Sinless, how can it do otherwise than be the ruin of those that are subject to it? And then as he had discoursed about His life; that none might say, What hath that which you have been saying to do with us? he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:74
verses.text: "Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:75
verses.text: He well says, "reckon," because there is no setting that, which he is speaking of, before the eyes as yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:76
verses.text: And what are we to reckon? one may ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:77
verses.text: That we "are dead unto sin, but alive unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:78
verses.text: In Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:79
verses.text: For he that so liveth will lay hold of every virtue, as having Jesus Himself for his ally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:80
verses.text: For that is what, "in Christ," means, for if He raised them when dead, much more when alive will He be able to keep them so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:82
verses.text: "Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:83
verses.text: He does not say, let not the flesh live or act, but, "let not sin reign," for He came not to destroy our nature, but to set our free choice aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:84
verses.text: Then to show that it is not through any force or necessity that we are held down by iniquity, but willingly, he does not say, let it not tyrannize, a word that would imply a necessity, but let it not reign.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:85
verses.text: For it is absurd for those who are being conducted to the kingdom of heaven to have sin empress over them, and for those who are called to reign with Christ to choose to be the captives of sin, as though one should hurl the diadem from off his head, and choose to be the slave of a frantic woman, who came begging, and was clothed in rags.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:86
verses.text: Next since it was a heavy task to get the upper hand of sin, see how he shows it to be even easy, and how he allays the labor by saying, "in your mortal body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:87
verses.text: For this shows that the struggles were but for a time, and would soon bring themselves to a close.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:88
verses.text: At the same time he reminds us of our former evil plight, and of the root of death, as it was from this that, contrary even to its beginning, it became mortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:89
verses.text: Yet it is possible even for one with a mortal body not to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:90
verses.text: Do you see the abundancy of Christ's grace? For Adam, though as yet he had not a mortal body, fell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:91
verses.text: But thou, who hast received one even subject to death, canst be crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:92
verses.text: How then, is it that "sin reigns?" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:93
verses.text: It is not from any power of its own, but from thy listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:94
verses.text: Wherefore after saying, "let it not reign," he also points out the mode of this reigning, by going on to say "that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:95
verses.text: For it is not honor to concede to it (i-e: to the body) all things at will, nay, it is slavery in the extreme, and the height of dishonor; for when it doth what it listeth, then is it bereft of all liberties; but when it is put under restraints, then it best keeps its own proper rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:96
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:97
verses.text: "Neither yield ye your members as instruments of unrighteousness unto sin…but as instruments of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:98
verses.text: The body then is indifferent between vice and virtue, as also instruments (or arms) are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:99
verses.text: But either effect is wrought by him that useth it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:100
verses.text: As if a soldier fighting in his country's behalf, and a robber who was arming against the inhabitants, had the same weapons for defence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:101
verses.text: For the fault is not laid to the suit of armor, but to those that use it to an ill end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:102
verses.text: And this one may say of the flesh too which becomes this or that owing to the mind's decision, not owing to its own nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:103
verses.text: For if it be curious after the beauty of another, the eye becomes an instrument of iniquity, not through any agency of its own (for what is of the eye, is but seeing, not seeing amiss), but through the fault of the thought which commands it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:104
verses.text: But if you bridle it, it becomes an instrument of righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:105
verses.text: Thus with the tongue, thus with the hands, thus with all the other members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:106
verses.text: And he well calls sin unrighteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:107
verses.text: For by sinning a man deals unrighteously either by himself or by his neighbor, or rather by himself more than by his neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:108
verses.text: Having then led us away from wickedness, he leads us to virtue, in these words:  "But yield yourselves unto God, as those that are alive from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:109
verses.text: See how by his bare words he exhorts them, on that side naming "sin" and on this "God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:110
verses.text: For by showing what a difference there is between the rulers, he casts out of all excuse the soldier that leaveth God, and desireth to serve under the dominion of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:111
verses.text: But it is not only in this way, but also by the sequel, that he establishes this; by saying, "as alive from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:112
verses.text: For by these he shows the wretchedness of the other, and the greatness of God's gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:113
verses.text: For consider, he says, what you were, and what you have been made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:114
verses.text: What then were ye? Dead, and ruined by a destruction which could not from any quarter be repaired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:115
verses.text: For neither was there any one who had the power to assist you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:116
verses.text: And what have ye been made out of those dead ones? Alive with immortal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:117
verses.text: And by whom? By the all-powerful God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:118
verses.text: Ye ought therefore to marshal yourselves under Him with as much cheerful readiness, as men would who had been made alive from being dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:119
verses.text: "And your members as instruments of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:120
verses.text: Hence, the body is not evil, since it may be made an arm of righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:121
verses.text: But by calling it an arm, he makes it clear that there is a hard warfare at hand for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:122
verses.text: And for this reason we need strong armor, and also a noble spirit, and one acquainted too with the ways of this warfare; and above all we need a commander.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:123
verses.text: The Commander however is standing by, ever ready to help us, and abiding unconquerable, and has furnished us with strong arms likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:124
verses.text: Farther, we have need of a purpose of mind to handle them as should be, so that we may both obey our Commander, and take the field for our country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:125
verses.text: Having then given us this vigorous exhortation, and reminded us of arms, and battle, and wars, see how he encourages the soldier again and cherishes his ready spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:126
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:127
verses.text: "For sin shall no more have dominion over you; for ye are not under the Law, but under grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:128
verses.text: If then sin hath no more dominion over us, why does he lay so great a charge upon them as he does in the words, "Let not sin reign in your mortal body," and, "yield not ye your members as instruments of unrighteousness unto sin?" What does that here said mean then? He is sowing a kind of seed in this statement, which he means to develop afterwards, and to cultivate in a powerful argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:129
verses.text: What then is this statement? It is this; that our body, before Christ's coming, was an easy prey to the assaults of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:130
verses.text: For after death a great swarm of passions entered also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:131
verses.text: And for this cause it was not lightsome for running the race of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:132
verses.text: For there was no Spirit present to assist, nor any baptism of power to mortify.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:133
verses.text: (John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:134
verses.text: ) But as some horse (Plato Phaedr.
