verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:135
verses.text: §) that answereth not the rein, it ran indeed, but made frequent slips, the Law meanwhile announcing what was to be done and what not, yet not conveying into those in the race anything over and above exhortation by means of words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:136
verses.text: But when Christ had come, the effort became afterwards more easy, and therefore we had a more distant goal (μείζονα τὰ σκάμματα) set us, in that the assistance we had given us was greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:137
verses.text: Wherefore also Christ saith, "Except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the Kingdom of Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:138
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:139
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:140
verses.text: ) But this he says more clearly in the sequel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:141
verses.text: But at present he alludes here briefly to it, to show that unless we stoop down very low to it, sin will not get the better of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:142
verses.text: For it is not the Law only that exhorteth us, but grace too which also remitted our former sins, and secures us against future ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:143
verses.text: For it promised them crowns after toils, but this (i-e: grace) crowned them first, and then led them to the contest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:144
verses.text: Now it seems to me that he is not signifying here the whole life of a believer, but instituting a comparison between the Baptism and the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:145
verses.text: And this he says in another passage also; "The letter killeth, but the Spirit giveth life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:146
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:147
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:148
verses.text: ) For the Law convinceth of transgression, but grace undoes transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:149
verses.text: As then the former by convincing establisheth sin so the latter by forgiving suffereth us not to be under sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:150
verses.text: And so thou art in two ways set free from this thraldom; both in thy not being under the Law, and in thy enjoying grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:151
verses.text: After then he had by these words given the hearer a breathing time, he again furnishes him a safeguard, by introducing an exhortation in reply to an objection, and by saying as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:152
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:153
verses.text: "What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the Law, but under grace? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:154
verses.text: So he first adopted a form of adjuration, because it was an absurd thing he had named.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:155
verses.text: And then he makes his discourse pass on to exhortation, and shows the great facility of the struggle, in the following words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:156
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:157
verses.text: "Know ye not, that to whom ye yield yourselves servants to obey, his servants ye are to whom ye obey; whether of sin unto death, or of obedience unto righteousness?  I do not, he would say, mention hell as yet, nor that great (ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:158
verses.text: Bodl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:159
verses.text: long) punishment, but the shame it is in this world, when ye become slaves, and slaves of your own accord too, and sin's slaves, and when the wages are such as a second death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:160
verses.text: For if before baptism, it wrought death of the body, and the wound required so great attendance, that the Lord of all came down to die, and so put a stop to the evil; if after so great a gift, and so great liberty, it seize thee again, while thou bendest down under it willingly, what is there that it may not do? Do not then run into such a pit, or willingly give thyself up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:161
verses.text: For in the case of wars, soldiers are often given up even against their will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:162
verses.text: But in this case, unless thou desertest of thyself, there is no one who will get the better of thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:163
verses.text: Having then tried to shame them by a sense of duty, he alarms them also by the rewards, and lays before them the wages of both; righteousness, and death, and that a death not like the former, but far worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:164
verses.text: For if Christ is to die no more, who is to do away with death? No one! We must then be punished, and have vengeance taken upon us forever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:165
verses.text: For a death preceptible to the senses is not still to come in this case, as in the former, which gives the body rest, and separates it from the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:166
verses.text: "For the last enemy, death, is destroyed" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:167
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:168
verses.text: ), whence the punishment will be deathless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:169
verses.text: But not to them that obey, for righteousness, and the blessings springing from it, will be their rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:170
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:171
verses.text: "But God be thanked, that ye were the servants of sin, but ye have obeyed from the heart that form of doctrine which was delivered unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:172
verses.text: (Lit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:173
verses.text: "into which ye were delivered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:174
verses.text: )  After shaming them by the slavery, after alarming them by the rewards, and so exhorting them, he again rights them by calling the benefits to mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:175
verses.text: For by these he shows that they were great evils from which they were freed, and that not by any labors of their own, and that things henceforth would be more manageable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:176
verses.text: Just as any one who has rescued a captive from a cruel tyrant, and advises him not to run away back to him, reminds him of his grievous thraldom; so does Paul set the evils passed away most emphatically before us, by giving thanks to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:177
verses.text: For it was no human power that could set us free from all those evils, but, "thanks be to God," who was willing and able to do such great things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:178
verses.text: And he well says, "Ye have obeyed from the heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:179
verses.text: Ye were neither forced nor pressed, but ye came over of your own accord, with willing mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:180
verses.text: Now this is like one that praises and rebukes at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:181
verses.text: For after having willingly come, and not having had any necessity to undergo, what allowance can you claim, or what excuse can you make, if you run away back to your former estate? Next that you may learn that it came not of your own willing temper only, but the whole of it of God's grace also, after saying, "Ye have obeyed from the heart," he adds, "that form of doctrine which was delivered you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:182
verses.text: For the obedience from the heart shows the free will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:183
verses.text: But the being delivered, hints the assistance from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:184
verses.text: But what is the form of doctrine? It is living aright, and in conformity with the best conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:185
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:186
verses.text: "Being then made free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:187
verses.text: There are two gifts of God which he here points out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:188
verses.text: The "freeing from sin," and also the "making them servants to righteousness," which is better than any freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:189
verses.text: For God hath done the same as if a person were to take an orphan, who had been carried away by savages into their own country, and were not only to free him from captivity, but were to set a kind father over him, and bring him to very great dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:190
verses.text: And this has been done in our case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:191
verses.text: For it was not our old evils alone that He freed us from, since He even led us to the life of angels, and paved the way for us to the best conversation, handing us over to the safe keeping of righteousness, and killing our former evils, and deadening the old man, and leading us to an immortal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:192
verses.text: Let us then continue living this life; for many of those who seem to breathe and to walk about are in a more wretched plight than the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:193
verses.text: For there are different kinds of deadness; and one there is of the body, according to which Abraham was dead, and still was not dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:194
verses.text: For "God," He says, "is not a God of the dead, but of the living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:195
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:196
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:197
verses.text: ) Another is of the soul which Christ alludes to when He says, "Let the dead bury their dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:198
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:199
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:200
verses.text: ) Another, which is even the subject of praise, which is brought about by religion (φιλοσοφίας), of which Paul saith, "Mortify your members which are upon the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:201
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:202
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:203
verses.text: ) Another, which is the cause even of this, the one which takes place in baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:204
verses.text: "For our old man," he says, "has been crucified" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:205
verses.text: ), that is, has been deadened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:206
verses.text: Since then we know this, let us flee from the deadness by which, even though alive, we die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:207
verses.text: And let us not be afraid of that with which common death comes on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:208
verses.text: But the other two, whereof one is blissful, having been given by God, the other praiseworthy (cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:209
verses.text: Ar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:210
verses.text: Eth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:211
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:212
verses.text: ), which is accomplished by ourselves together with God, let us both choose and be emulous of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:213
verses.text: And of those two, one doth David pronounce blessed, when he says, "Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:214
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:215
verses.text: ); and the other, Paul holds in admiration, saying, and writing to the Galatians, "They that be Christ's have crucified the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:216
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:217
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:218
verses.text: ) But of the other couple, one Christ declares to be easy to hold in contempt, when He says, "Fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul:" and the other fearful, for, "Fear" (He says) "Him that is able to destroy both body and soul in hell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:219
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:220
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:221
verses.text: ) And therefore let us flee from this, and choose that deadness which is held blessed and admirable; that of the other two, we may escape the one and not fear the other: for it is not the least good to us to see the sun, and to eat and drink, unless the life of good words be with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:222
verses.text: For what would be the advantage, pray, of a king dressed in a purple robe and possessed of arms, but without a single subject, and exposed to all that had a mind to attack and insult him? In like manner it will be no advantage to a Christian to have faith, and the gift of baptism, and yet be open to all the passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:223
verses.text: In that way the disgrace will be greater, and the shame more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:224
verses.text: For as such an one having the diadem and purple is so far from gaining by this dress any honor to himself, that he even does disgrace to that by his own shame: so the believer also, who leadeth a corrupt life, is so far from becoming, as such, an object of respect, that he is only the more one of scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:225
verses.text: "For as many," it says, "as sinned without law, shall also perish without law; and as many as have sinned in the law, shall be judged by the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:226
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:227
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:228
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:229
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Hebrews, he says, "He that despised Moses' law died without mercy under two or three witnesses: of how much sorer punishment, suppose ye, shall he be thought worthy, who had trodden under foot the Son of God?" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:230
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:231
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:232
verses.text: ) And with reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:233
verses.text: For I placed (He might say) all the passions in subjection to thee by baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:234
verses.text: How then comes it that thou hast disgraced so great a gift, and hast become one thing instead of another? I have killed and buried thy former transgressions, like worms—how is it that thou hast bred others?—for sins are worse than worms, since these do harm to the body, those to the soul; and those make the more offensive stench.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:235
verses.text: Yet we perceive it not, and so we are at no pains to purge them out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:236
verses.text: Thus the drunkard knows not how disgustful the stale wine is, but he that is not drunken has a distinct perception of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:237
verses.text: So with sins also, he that lives soberly knows thoroughly that other mire, and the stain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:238
verses.text: But he that gives himself up to wickedness, like a man made drowsy with drunkenness, does not even know the very fact that he is ill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:239
verses.text: And this is the most grievous part of vice, that it does not allow those who fall into it even to see the greatness of their own bane, but as they lie in the mire, they think they are enjoying perfumes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:240
verses.text: And so they have not even the power of getting free, but when full of worms, like men that pride themselves in precious stones, so do they exult in these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:241
verses.text: And for this reason they have not so much as the will to kill them, but they even nourish these up, and multiply them in themselves, until they send them on to the worms of the world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:242
verses.text: For these are providers for those, and are not only providers, but even the fathers of those that never die; as it says, "their worm shall not die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:243
verses.text: (Mark ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:244
verses.text: ) These kindle the hell which never extinguishes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:245
verses.text: To prevent this from happening then, let us do away with this fountain of evil, and extinguish the furnace, and let us draw up the root of wickedness from beneath, since you will do no good by cutting the tree off from above, if the root remains below, and sends up fresh shoots of the same kind again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:246
verses.text: What then is the root of the evils? Learn from the good husbandman (i-e: St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:247
verses.text: Paul  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:248
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:249
verses.text: –), who has an accurate knowledge of such things, and tends the spiritual vine and cultivates the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:250
verses.text: Now what does he say is the cause of all the evils? The love of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:251
verses.text: For the "love of money is the root of all evils".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:252
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:253
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:254
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:255
verses.text: Hence come fightings, and enmities and wars; hence emulations, and railings, and suspicions, and insults; hence murders, and thefts, and violations of sepulchres.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:256
verses.text: Through this, not cities and countries only, but roads and habitable and inhabitable parts, and mountains, and groves, and hills, and, in a word, all places are filled with blood and murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:257
verses.text: And not even from the sea has this evil withdrawn, but even there also with great fury hath it revelled, since pirates beset it on all sides, thus devising a new mode of robbery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:258
verses.text: Through this have the laws of nature been subverted, and the claims of relationship set aside, and the laws of piety itself broken through.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:259
verses.text: For the thraldom of money hath armed, not against the living only, but even against the departed too, the right hands of such men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:260
verses.text: And at death even, they make no truce with them, but bursting open the sepulchres, they put forth their impious hands even against dead bodies, and not even him that hath let go of life will they suffer to be let go from their plotting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:261
verses.text: And all the evils that you may find, whether in the house or in the market-place, or in the courts of law, or in the senate, or in the king's palace, or in any other place whatsoever, it is from this that you will find they all spring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:262
verses.text: For this evil it is, this assuredly, which fills all places with blood and murder, this lights up the flame of hell, this makes cities as wretchedly off as a wilderness, yea, even much worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:263
verses.text: For those that beset the high roads, one can easily be on one's guard against, as not being always upon attack.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:264
verses.text: But they who in the midst of cities imitate them are so much the worse than them, in that these are harder to guard against, and dare to do openly what the others do with secrecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:265
verses.text: For those laws, which have been made with a view to stopping their iniquity, they draw even into alliance and fill the cities with this kind of murders and pollutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:266
verses.text: Is it not murder, pray, and worse than murder, to hand the poor man over to famine, and to cast him into prison, and to expose him not to famine only, but to tortures too, and to countless acts of insolence? For even if you do not do these things yourself to him, yet you are the occasion of their being done, you do them more than the ministers who execute them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:267
verses.text: The murderer plunges his sword into a man at once, and after giving him pain for a short time, he does not carry the torture any farther.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:268
verses.text: But do you who by your calumnies, by your harassings, by your plottings, make light darkess to him, and set him upon desiring death ten thousand times over, consider how many deaths you perpetrate instead of one only? And what is worse than all, you plunder and are grasping, not impelled to it by poverty, without any hunger to necessitate you, but that your horse's bridle may be spattered over with gold enough, or the ceiling of your house, or the capitals of your pillars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:269
verses.text: And what hell is there that this conduct would not deserve, when it is a brother, and one that has shared with yourself in blessings unutterable, and has been so highly honored by the Lord, whom you, in order that you may deck out stones, and floors, and the bodies of animals with neither reason, nor perception of these ornaments, are casting into countless calamities? And your dog is well attended too, while man, or rather Christ, for the sake of the hound, and all these things I have named, is straitened with extreme hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:270
verses.text: What can be worse than such confusion? What more grievous than such lawlessness as this? What streams of fire will be enough for such a soul? He that was made in the Image of God stands in unseemly plight, through thy inhumanity; but the faces of the mules that draw thy wife glisten with gold in abundance, as do the skins and woods which compose that canopy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:271
verses.text: And if it is a seat that is to be made, or a footstool, they are all made of gold and silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:272
verses.text: But the member of Christ, for whom also He came hither from Heaven, and shed His precious Blood, does not even enjoy the food that is necessary for him, owing to thy rapaciousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:273
verses.text: But the couches are mantled with silver on every side, while the bodies of the saints are deprived even of necessary clothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:274
verses.text: And to thee Christ is less precious than anything else, servants, or mules, or couch, or chair, or footstool; for I pass over furniture of still meaner use than these, leaving it to you to know of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:275
verses.text: But if thou art shocked at hearing this, stand aloof from doing it, and then the words spoken will not harm thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:276
verses.text: Stand aloof, and cease from this madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:277
verses.text: For plain madness it is, such eagerness about these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:278
verses.text: Wherefore letting go of these things, let us look up, late as it is, towards Heaven, and let us call to mind the Day which is coming, let us bethink ourselves of that awful tribunal, and the exact accounts, and the sentence incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:279
verses.text: Let us consider that God, who sees all these things, sends no lightnings from Heaven; and yet what is done deserves not thunderbolts merely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:280
verses.text: Yet He neither doth this, nor doth He let the sea loose upon us, nor doth He burst the earth in twain, He quencheth not the sun, nor doth He hurl the heaven with its stars upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:281
verses.text: He doth not move aught from its place, but suffereth them to hold their course, and the whole creation to minister to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:282
verses.text: Pondering all this then, let us be awestruck with the greatness of His love toward man, and let us return to that noble origin which belongs to us, since at present certainly we are in no better plight than the creatures without reason, but even in a much worse one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:283
verses.text: For they do love their kin, and need but the community of nature to cause affection towards each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:284
verses.text: But thou who besides nature hast countless causes to draw thee together and attach thee to the member of thyself; the being honored with the Word, the partaking in one religion, the sharing in countless blessings; art become of wilder nature than they, by displaying so much carefulness about profitless things, and leaving the Temples of God to perish in hunger and nakedness, and often surrounding them also with a thousand evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:285
verses.text: For if it is from love of glory that you do these things, it is much more binding on you to show your brother attention, than your horse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:286
verses.text: For the better the creature that enjoys the act of kindness, the brighter the crown that is woven for such carefulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:287
verses.text: Since now while thou fallest into the contrary of all this, thou pullest upon thyself accusers without number, yet perceivest it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:288
verses.text: For who is there that will not speak ill of thee? who that will not indite thee as guilty of the greatest atrocity and misanthrophy, when he sees that thou disregardest the human race, and settest that of senseless creatures above men, and besides senseless creatures, even the furniture of thy house? Hast thou not heard the Apostles say, that they who first received the word sold both "houses and lands" (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:289
verses.text: ), that they might support the brethren? but you plunder both houses and lands, that you may adorn a horse or wood-work, or skins, or walls, or a pavement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:290
verses.text: And what is worse is, that it is not men only, but women too are afflicted with this madness, and urge their husbands to this empty sort of pains, by forcing them to lay out their money upon anything rather than the necessary things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:291
verses.text: And if any one accuse them for this, they are practised with a defence, itself loaded with much to be accused.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:292
verses.text: For both the one and the other are done at once, says one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:293
verses.text: What say you? are you not afraid to utter such a thing, and to set the same store by horses and mules and couches and footstools, as by Christ an hungered? Or rather not even comparing them at all, but giving the larger share to these, and to Him meting out with difficulty a scant share? Dost thou not know that all belongs to Him, both thou and thine? Dost thou not know that He fashioned thy body, as well as gave thee a soul, and apportioned thee the whole world? but thou art not for giving a little recompense to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:294
verses.text: But if thou lettest a little hut, thou requirest the rent with the utmost rigor, and though reaping the whole of His creation, and dwelling in so wide a world, thou hast not courage to lay down even a little rent, but has given up to vainglory thyself and all thou hast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:295
verses.text: For this is that whereof all these things come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:296
verses.text: The horse is none the better above his natural excellence for having this ornament, neither yet is the person mounted upon him, for sometimes he is only in the less esteem for it; since many neglect the rider and turn their eyes to the horse's ornaments, and to the attendants behind and before, and to the fan-bearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:297
verses.text: But the man, who is lackeyed by these, they hate and turn their heads from, as a common enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:298
verses.text: But this does not happen when thou adornest thy soul, for then men, and angels, and the Lord of angels, all weave thee a crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:299
verses.text: And so, if thou art in love with glory, stand aloof from the things which thou art now doing, and show thy taste not in thy house, but in thy soul, that thou mayest become brilliant and conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:300
verses.text: For now nothing can be more cheap than thou art, with thy soul unfurnished, and but the handsomeness of thy house for a screen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:301
verses.text: But if thou art impatient of hearing me speak in this way, listen to what one of those that are without did, and at all events be shamed by their philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:302
verses.text: For it is said that a certain one of them, who went into a palace that shone with gold in abundance, and glistened with the great beauty of the marbles and the columns, when he saw the floor strewed with carpets in all directions, spat in the face of the master of the house, and when found fault with for it said, that since there was no other part of the house where he could do this, he was obliged to do this affront to his face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:303
verses.text: See how ridiculous a man is, who displays his taste in exteriors, and how little he is in the eyes of all reasonable men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:304
verses.text: And with good reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:305
verses.text: For if a person were to leave thy wife to be clad in rags, and to be neglected, and clothed thy maid-servants with brilliant dresses, thou wouldest not bear it meekly, but wouldest be exasperated, and say that it was insulting in the extreme.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:306
verses.text: Reason then in this way about your soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:307
verses.text: When you display your taste in walls then, and pavement, and furniture, and other things of the kind, and do not give liberally in alms, or practise the other parts of a religious life (φιλοσοφίαν); you do nothing less than this, or rather what is worse than this by far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:308
verses.text: For the difference between servant and mistress is nothing, but between soul and flesh, there is a great disparity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:309
verses.text: But if it be so with the flesh, much more is it with a house or a couch or a footstool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:310
verses.text: What kind of excuse then dost thou deserve, who puttest silver on all these, but for it hast no regard, though it be covered with filthy rags, squalid, hungry, and full of wounds, torn by hounds unnumbered (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:311
verses.text: , ); and after all this fanciest that thou shalt get thee glory by displaying thy taste in externals wound about thee? And this is the very height of phrenzy, while ridiculed, reproached, disgraced, dishonored, and falling into the severest punishment, still to be vain of these things! Wherefore, I beseech you, laying all this to heart, let us become sober-minded, late as it is, and become our own masters, and transfer this adorning from outward things to our souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 12:312
verses.text: For so it will abide safe from spoiling, and will make us equal to the angels, and will entertain us with unaltering good, which may we all attain by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:3
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:4
verses.text: "I speak after the manner of men because of the infirmity of your flesh: for as ye have yielded your members (so  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:5
verses.text: Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:6
verses.text: the members of your flesh) servants to uncleanness and to iniquity unto iniquity; even so now yield your members servants to righteousness unto holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:7
verses.text: Since he had required great strictness of life, charging us to be dead to the world, and to have died unto wickedness, and to abide with no notion towards the workings of sin, and seemed to be saying something great and burdensome, and too much for human nature; through a desire to show that he is not making any exorbitant demand, nor even as much as might be expected of one who enjoyed so great a gift, but one quite moderate and light, he proves it from contraries, and says, "I speak after the manner of men," as much as to say, Going by human reasonings; by such as one usually meets with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:8
verses.text: For he signifies either this, or the moderateness of it, by the term applied, "after the manner of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:9
verses.text: For elsewhere he uses the same word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:10
verses.text: "There hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:11
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:12
verses.text: ), that is, moderate and small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:13
verses.text: "For as ye have yielded your members servants to uncleanness and to iniquity unto iniquity; even so now yield your members servants to righteousness unto holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:14
verses.text: And truly the masters are very different ones, but still it is an equal amount of servitude that I ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:15
verses.text: For men ought to give a much larger one, and so much the larger as this is a greater and better mastership than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:16
verses.text: Nevertheless I make no greater demand "because of the infirmity," and that, he does not say of your free will or readiness of spirit, but "of your flesh," so making what he says the less severe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:17
verses.text: And yet on one side there is uncleanness, on the other holiness: on the one iniquity, and on the other righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:18
verses.text: And who is so wretched, he says, and in such straits as not to spend as much earnestness upon the service of Christ, as upon that of sin and the devil? Hear then what follows, and you will see clearly that we do not even spend this little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:19
verses.text: For when (stated in this naked way) it does not seem credible or easy to admit, and nobody would endure to hear that he does not serve Christ so much as he did serve the devil, he proves it by what follows, and renders it credible by bringing that slavery before us, and saying how they did serve him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:20
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:21
verses.text: "For when ye were the servants of sin, ye were free from righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:22
verses.text: Now what he says is somewhat of this kind, When ye lived in wickedness, and impiety, and the worst of evils, the state of compliance ye lived in was such that ye did absolutely no good thing at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:23
verses.text: For this is, "ye were free from righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:24
verses.text: That is ye were not subject to it, but estranged from it wholly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:25
verses.text: For ye did not even so much as divide the manner of servitude between righteousness and sin, but gave yourselves wholly up to wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:26
verses.text: Now, therefore, since ye have come over to righteousness, give yourselves wholly up to virtue, doing nothing at all of vice, that the measure you give may be at least equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:27
verses.text: And yet it is not the mastership only that is so different, but in the servitude itself there is a vast difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:28
verses.text: And this too he unfolds with great perspicuity, and shows what conditions they served upon then, and what now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:29
verses.text: And as yet he says nothing of the harm accruing from the thing, but hitherto speaks of the shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:30
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:31
verses.text: "What fruit had ye then in those things whereof ye are now ashamed?"  So great was the slavery, that even the recollection of it now makes you ashamed; but if the recollection makes one ashamed, the reality would much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:32
verses.text: And so you gained now in two ways, in having been freed from the shame; and also in having come to know the condition you were in; just as then ye were injured in two ways, in doing things deserving shame, and in not even knowing to be ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:33
verses.text: And this is worse than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:34
verses.text: Yet still ye kept in a state of servitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:35
verses.text: Having then proved most abundantly the harm of what took place then from the shame of it, he comes to the thing in question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:36
verses.text: Now what is this thing? "For the end of those things is death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:37
verses.text: Since then shame seems to be no such serious evil, he comes to what is very fearful, I mean death; though in good truth what he had before mentioned were enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:38
verses.text: For consider how exceeding great the mischief must be, inasmuch as, even when freed from the vengeance due to it, they could not get free of the shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:39
verses.text: What wages then, he says, do you expect from the reality, when from the bare recollection, and that too when you are freed from the vengeance, you hide your face and blush, though under such grace as you are! But God's side is far otherwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:40
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:41
verses.text: "For now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:42
verses.text: Of the former, the fruit was shame, even after the being set free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:43
verses.text: Of these the fruit is holiness, and where holiness is, there is all confidence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:44
verses.text: But of those things the end is death, and of these everlasting life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:45
verses.text: Do you see how he points out some things as already given, and some as existing in hope, and from what are given he draws proof of the others also, that is from the holiness of the life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:46
verses.text: For to prevent your saying (i-e: as an objection) everything lies in hope, he points out that you have already reaped fruits, first the being freed from wickedness, and such evils as the very recollection of puts one to shame; second, the being made a servant unto righteousness; a third, the enjoying of holiness; a fourth, the obtaining of life, and life too not for a season, but everlasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:47
verses.text: Yet with all these, he says, do but serve as ye served it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:48
verses.text: For though the master is far preferable, and the service also has many advantages, and the rewards too for which ye are serving, still I make no further demand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:49
verses.text: Next, since he had mentioned arms and a king, he keeps on with the metaphor in these words:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:50
verses.text: "For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:51
verses.text: After speaking of the wages of sin, in the case of the blessings, he has not kept to the same order (τάξιν, rank or relation): for he does not say, the wages of good deeds, "but the gift of God;" to show, that it was not of themselves that they were freed, nor was it a due they received, neither yet a return, nor a recompense of labors, but by grace all these things came about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:52
verses.text: And so there was a superiority for this cause also, in that He did not free them only, or change their condition for a better, but that He did it without any labor or trouble upon their part: and that He not only freed them, but also gave them much more than before, and that through His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:53
verses.text: And the whole of this he has interposed as having discussed the subject of grace, and being on the point of overthrowing the Law next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:54
verses.text: That these things then might not both make them rather listless, he inserted the part about strictness of life, using every opportunity of rousing the hearer to the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:55
verses.text: For when he calls death the wages of sin, he alarms them again, and secures them against dangers to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:56
verses.text: For the words he uses to remind them of their former estate, he also employs so as to make them thankful, and more secure against any inroads of temptations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:57
verses.text: Here then he brings the hortatory part to a stop, and proceeds with the doctrines again, speaking on this wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:58
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:59
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:60
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:61
verses.text: "Know ye not, brethren, for I speak to them that know the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:62
verses.text: Since then he had said, we are "dead to sin," he here shows that not sin only, but also the Law, hath no dominion over them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:63
verses.text: But if the Law hath none, much less hath sin: and to render his language palatable, he uses a human example to make this plain by.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:64
verses.text: And he seems to be stating one point, but he sets down at once two arguments for his proposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:65
verses.text: One, that when a husband is dead, the woman is no longer subject to her husband, and there is nothing to prevent her becoming the wife of another man: and the other, that in the present case it is not the husband only that is dead but the wife also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:66
verses.text: So that one may enjoy liberty in two ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:67
verses.text: Now if when the husband is dead, she is freed from his power, when the woman is shown to be dead also, she is much more at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:68
verses.text: For if the one event frees her from his power, much more does the concurrence of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:69
verses.text: As he is about to proceed then to a proof of these points, he starts with an encomium of the hearers, in these words, "Know ye not, brethren, for I speak to them that know the Law," that is, I am saying a thing that is quite agreed upon, and clear, and to men too that know all these things accurately,  "How that the Law hath dominion over a man as long as he liveth?"  He does not say, husband or wife, but "man," which name is common to either creature; "For he that is dead," he says, "is freed (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:70
verses.text: justified) from sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:71
verses.text: The Law then is given for the living, but to the dead it ceaseth to be ordained (or to give commands).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:72
verses.text: Do you observe how he sets forth a twofold freedom? Next, after hinting this at the commencement, he carries on what he has to say by way of proof, in the woman's case, in the following way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:74
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:75
verses.text: "For the woman which hath an husband is bound by the Law to her husband, so long as he liveth: but if the husband be dead, she is loosed from the Law of her husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:76
verses.text: So then, if while her husband liveth, she be married to another man, she is called an adulteress: but if her husband be dead, she is free from that law; so that she is no adulteress, though she be married to another man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:77
verses.text: He keeps continually upon this point, and that with great exactness, since he feels quite sure of the proof grounded on it: and in the husband's place he puts the Law, but in the woman's, all believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:78
verses.text: Then he adds the conclusion in such way, that it does not tally with the premiss; for what the context would require would be, "and so, my brethren, the Law doth not rule over you, for it is dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:79
verses.text: But he does not say so, but only in the premiss hinted it, and in the inference, afterwards, to prevent what he says being distasteful, he brings the woman in as dead by saying,  "Wherefore, my brethren, ye also are become dead to the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:80
verses.text: As then the one or the other event gives rise to the same freedom, what is there to prevent his showing favor to the Law without any harm being done to the cause? "For the woman which hath an husband is bound by the Law to her husband as long as he liveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:81
verses.text: What is become now ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:82
verses.text: then) of those that speak evil of the Law? Let them hear, how even when forced upon it, he does not bereave it of its dignity, but speaks great things of its power; if while it is alive the Jew is bound, and they are to be called adulterers who transgress it, and leave it whiles it is alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:83
verses.text: But if they let go of it after it has died, this is not to be wondered at.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:84
verses.text: For in human affairs no one is found fault with for doing this: "but if the husband be dead, she is loosed from the law of her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:85
verses.text: You see how in the example he points out the Law as dead, but in the inference he does not do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:86
verses.text: So then if it be while her husband liveth, the woman is called an adulteress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:87
verses.text: See how he dwells upon the accusations of those who transgress the Law, while it is yet living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:88
verses.text: But since he had put an end to it, he afterwards favors it with perfect security, without doing any harm hereby to the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:89
verses.text: "For if while her husband liveth, she be married to another man, she is called an adulteress".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:90
verses.text: Thus it would have been natural to say next, ye also, my brethren, now the Law is dead, will not be judged guilty of adultery, if ye become married to another husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:91
verses.text: Yet he does not use these words, but what? "Ye are become dead to the Law;" if ye have been made dead, ye are no longer under the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:92
verses.text: For if, when the husband is dead, the woman is no longer liable to it, much more when herself is dead also she is freed from the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:93
verses.text: Do you note the wisdom of Paul, how he points out that the Law itself designs that we should be divorced from it, and married to another? For there is nothing, he means, against your living with another husband, now the former is dead; for how should there be, since when the husband was alive it allowed this to her who had a writing of divorcement? But this he does not set down, as it was rather a charge against the woman; for although this had been granted, still it was not cleared of blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:94
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:95
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:96
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:97
verses.text: ) For in cases where he has gained the victory by requisite and accredited proofs, he does not go into questions beyond the purpose; not being captious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:98
verses.text: The marvel then is this, that it is the Law itself that acquits us who are divorced from it of any charge, and so the mind of it was that we should become Christ's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:99
verses.text: For it is dead itself, and we are dead; and the grounds of its power over us are removed in a twofold way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:100
verses.text: But he is not content with this alone, but also adds the reason of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:101
verses.text: For he has not set down death without special purpose, but brings the cross in again, which had wrought these things, and in this way too he puts us under an engagement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:102
verses.text: For ye have not been freed merely, he means, but it was through the Lord's death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:103
verses.text: For he says,  "Ye are become dead to the Law by the Body of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:104
verses.text: Now it is not on this only he grounds his exhortation, but also on the superiority of this second husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:105
verses.text: And so he proceeds: "that ye should be married to another, even to Him Who is raised from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:106
verses.text: Then to prevent their saying, If we do not choose to live with another husband, what then? For the Law does not indeed make an adulteress of the widow who lives in a second marriage, but for all that it does not force her to live in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:107
verses.text: Now that they may not say this, he shows that from benefits already conferred, it is binding on us to choose it: and this he lays down more clearly in other passages, where he says, "Ye are not your own;" and, "Ye are bought with a price;" and, "Be not ye the servants of men" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:108
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:109
verses.text: , ; vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:110
verses.text: ); and again, "One died for all, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto Him which died for them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:111
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:112
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:113
verses.text: ) This is then what he here alludes to in the words, "By the Body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:114
verses.text: And next he exhorts to better hopes, saying, "That we should bring forth fruit unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:115
verses.text: For then, he means, ye brought forth fruit unto death, but now unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:116
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:117
verses.text: "For when we were in the flesh, the motions of sins, which were by the Law, did work in our members to bring forth fruit unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:118
verses.text: You see then the gain to be got from the former husband! And he does not say when we were in the Law, so in every passage shrinking from giving a handle to heretics; but "when we were in the flesh," that is, in evil deeds, in a carnal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:119
verses.text: What he says then is, not that they were in the flesh before, but now they went about without any bodies; but by saying what he does, he neither says that the Law is the cause of sins, nor yet frees it from odium.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:120
verses.text: For it held the rank of a bitter accuser, by making their sins bare: since that, which enjoins more to him who is not minded to obey at all, makes the offence greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:121
verses.text: And this is why he does not say, the "motions of sins" which were produced by the Law, but which "were through the Law" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:122
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:123
verses.text: ), without adding any "produced," but simply "through the Law," that is to say, which through the Law were made apparent, were made known.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:124
verses.text: Next that he might not accuse the flesh either; he does not say which the members wrought, but "which did work (or were wrought) in our members," to show that the origin of the mischief was elsewhere, from the thoughts which wrought in us, not from the members which had them working in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:125
verses.text: For the soul ranks as a performer, and the fabric of the flesh as a lyre, sounding as the performer obliges it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:126
verses.text: So the discordant tune is to be ascribed not to the latter, but to the former sooner than to the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:127
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:128
verses.text: "But now," he says, "we are delivered from the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:129
verses.text: (κατηργήθημεν, "made of no effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:130
verses.text: )  See how he again in this place spares the flesh and the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:131
verses.text: For he does not say that the Law was made of no effect, or that the flesh was made of no effect, but that we were made of no effect (i-e:, were delivered).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:132
verses.text: And how were we delivered? Why by the old man, who was held down by sin, being dead and buried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:133
verses.text: For this is what he sets forth in the words, "being dead to that, wherein we were held".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:134
verses.text: As if he had said, the chain by which we were held down was deadened and broken through, so that that which held down, namely sin, held down no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:135
verses.text: But do not fall back or grow listless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:136
verses.text: For you have been freed with a view to being servants again, though not in the same way, but "in newness of spirit, and not in the oldness of the letter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:137
verses.text: Now what does he mean here? for it is necessary to disclose it here, that when we come upon the passage, we may not be perplexed with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:138
verses.text: When then Adam sinned (he means), and his body became liable to death and sufferings, it received also many physical losses, and the horse became less active and less obedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:139
verses.text: But Christ, when He came, made it more nimble for us through baptism, rousing it with the wing of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:140
verses.text: And for this reason the marks for the race, which they of old time had to run, are not the same as ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:141
verses.text: Since then the race was not so easy as it is now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:142
verses.text: For this reason, He desires them to be clear not from murder only, as He did them of old time, but from anger also; nor is it adultery only that He bids them keep clear of, but even the unchaste look; and to be exempt not from false swearing only, but even from true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:143
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:144
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:145
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:146
verses.text: ) And with their friends He orders them to love their enemies also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:147
verses.text: And in all other duties, He gives us a longer ground to run over, and if we do but obey, threatens us with hell, so showing that the things in question are not matters of free-will offering for the combatants, as celibacy and poverty are, but are binding upon us absolutely to fulfil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:148
verses.text: For they belong to necessary and urgent requisites, and the man who does not do them is to be punished to the utmost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:149
verses.text: This is why He said, "Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:150
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:151
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:152
verses.text: ) But he that does not see the kingdom, shall certainly fall into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:153
verses.text: For this cause Paul too says, "Sin shall not have dominion over you, because ye are not under the Law, but under grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:154
verses.text: And here again, "that ye should serve in newness of spirit, and not in the oldness of the letter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:155
verses.text: For it is not the letter that condemneth, that is the old Law, but the Spirit that helpeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:156
verses.text: And for this reason among the ancients, if any were found practising virginity, it was quite astonishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:157
verses.text: But now the thing is scattered over every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:158
verses.text: And death in those times some few men did with difficulty despise, but now in villages and cities there are hosts of martyrs without number, consisting not of men only, but even of women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:159
verses.text: And next having done with this, he again meets an objection which is rising, and as he meets it, gives confirmation to his own object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:160
verses.text: And so he does not introduce the solution of it as main argument, but by way of opposing this; that by the exigency of meeting it, he may get a plea for saying what he wishes, and make his accusation not so unpalatable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:161
verses.text: Having then said, "in the newness of the Spirit, and not in the oldness of the letter," he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:162
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:163
verses.text: "What then? is the Law sin? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:164
verses.text: Even before this he had been saying, that "the motions of sins, which were by the Law did work in our members" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:165
verses.text: ): and, "sin shall have no dominion over you, for ye are not under the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:166
verses.text: (vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:167
verses.text: ) And that "where no law is, there is no transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:168
verses.text: (iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:169
verses.text: ) And, "but the Law came in, that the offence might abound" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:170
verses.text: ); and, "the Law worketh wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:171
verses.text: (iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:172
verses.text: ) Now as all these things seem to bring the Law into disrepute, in order to correct the suspicion arising from them, he supposes also an objection, and says, "What then, is the Law sin? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:173
verses.text: Before the proof he uses this adjuration to conciliate the hearer, and by way of soothing any who was troubled at it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:174
verses.text: For so, when he had heard this, and felt assured of the speaker's disposition, he would join with him in investigating the seeming perplexity, and feel no suspicions of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:175
verses.text: Wherefore he has put the objection, associating the other with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:176
verses.text: Hence, he does not say, What am I to say? but "What shall we say then?" As though a deliberation and a judgment were before them, and a general meeting called together, and the objection came forward not of himself, but in the course of discussion, and from real circumstances of the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:177
verses.text: For that the letter killeth, he means, no one will deny, or that the Spirit giveth life ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:178
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:179
verses.text: ); this is plain too, and nobody will dispute it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:180
verses.text: If then these are confessedly truths, what are we to say about the Law? that "it is sin? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:181
verses.text: Explain the difficulty then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:182
verses.text: Do you see how he supposes the opponent to be present, and having assumed the dignity of the teacher, he comes to the explaining of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:183
verses.text: Now what is this? Sin, he says, the Law is not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:184
verses.text: "Nay, I had not known sin, but by the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:185
verses.text: Notice the reach of his wisdom! What the Law is not, he has set down by way of objection, so that by removing this, and thereby doing the Jew a pleasure, he may persuade him to accept the less alternative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:186
verses.text: And what is this? Why that "I had not known sin, but by the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:187
verses.text: For I had not known lust, except the Law had said, Thou shalt not covet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:188
verses.text: Do you observe, how by degrees he shows it to be not an accuser of sin only, but in a measure its producer? Yet not from any fault of its own, but from that of the froward Jews, he proves it was, that this happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:189
verses.text: For he has taken good heed to stop the mouths of the Manichees, that accuse the Law; and so after saying, "Nay, I had not known sin, but by the Law;" and, "I had not known lust, except the Law had said, Thou shalt not covet;" he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:190
verses.text: "But sin, taking occasion by the commandment, wrought in me all manner of concupiscence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:191
verses.text: Do you see how he has cleared it of all blame? For "sin," he says, "taking occasion by the commandment," it was, and not the Law, that increased the concupiscence, and the reverse of the Law's intent was brought about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:192
verses.text: This came of weakness, and not of any badness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:193
verses.text: For when we desire a thing, and then are hindered of it, the flame of the desire is but increased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:194
verses.text: Now this came not of the Law; for it hindered us ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:195
verses.text: endeavored) of itself to keep us off from it; but sin, that is, thy own listlessness and bad disposition, used what was good for the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:196
verses.text: But this is no fault in the physician, but in the patient who applies the medicine wrongly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:197
verses.text: For the reason of the Law being given was, not to inflame concupiscence, but to extinguish it, though the reverse came of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:198
verses.text: Yet the blame attaches not to it, but to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:199
verses.text: Since if a person had a fever, and wanted to take cold drink when it was not good for him, and one were not to let him take his fill of it, and so increase his lust after this ruinous pleasure, one could not deservedly be found fault with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:200
verses.text: For the physician's business is simply prohibiting it, but the restraining himself is the patient's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:201
verses.text: And what if sin did take occasion from it? Surely there are many bad men who by good precepts grow in their own wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:202
verses.text: For this was the way in which the devil ruined Judas, by plunging him into avarice, and making him steal what belonged to the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:203
verses.text: However it was not the being entrusted with the bag that brought this to pass, but the wickedness of his own spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:204
verses.text: And Eve, by bringing Adam to eat from the tree, threw him out of Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:205
verses.text: But neither in that case was the tree the cause, even if it was through it that the occasion took place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:206
verses.text: But if he treats the discussion about the Law with somewhat of vehemence, do not feel surprise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:207
verses.text: For Paul is making a stand against the present exigency, and suffers not his language to give a handle even to those that suspected otherwise, but takes great pains to make the present statement correct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:208
verses.text: Do not then sift what he is now going on to say ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:209
verses.text: "here saying") by itself, but put beside it the purpose by which he is led on to speak of these things, and reckon for the madness of the Jews, and their vigorous spirit of contention, which as he desires earnestly to do away with, he seems to bear violently (πολὺς πνεἵν) against the Law, not to find fault with it, but to unnerve their vigor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:210
verses.text: For if it is any reproach to the Law that sin taketh occasion by it, this will be found to be the case in the New Testament also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:211
verses.text: For in the New Testament there are thousands of laws, and about many more ("far more," Field) important matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:212
verses.text: And one may see the same come to pass there also, not with regard to covetousness (lust, as v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:213
verses.text: ) only, but to all wickedness generally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:214
verses.text: For He says, "if I had not come and spoken unto them, they had not had sin," (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:215
verses.text: ) Here then sin finds a footing in this fact, and so the greater punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:216
verses.text: And again when Paul discourseth about grace, he says, "Of how much sorer punishment, suppose ye, shall he be counted worthy, who hath trodden under foot the Son of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:217
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:218
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:219
verses.text: ) Has not then the worse punishment its origin from hence, from the greater benefit? And the reason why he says the Greeks were without excuse was, because being honored with the gift of reason, and having gotten a knowledge of the beauty of the creation, and having been placed in a fair way for being led by it to the Creator, they did not so use the wisdom of God, as it was their duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:220
verses.text: Seest thou that to the wicked in all cases occasions of greater punishment result from good things? But we shall not in this accuse the benefits of God, but rather upon this even admire them the more: but we shall throw the blame on the spirit of those who abuse the blessings to contrary purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:221
verses.text: Let this then be our line with regard to the Law also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:222
verses.text: But this is easy and feasible—the other is what is a difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:223
verses.text: How is it that he says "I had not known lust except the Law had said, Thou shalt not covet?" Now if man had not known lust, before he received the Law, what was the reason for the flood, or the burning of Sodom? What does he mean then? He means vehement lust: and this is why he did not say, lust, but "all manner of concupiscence," intimating, in that, its vehemency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:224
verses.text: And what, it will be said, is the good of the Law, if it adds to the disorder? None; but much mischief even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:225
verses.text: Yet the charge is not against the Law, but the listlessness of those who received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:226
verses.text: For sin wrought it, though by the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:227
verses.text: But this was not the purpose of the Law, nay, the very opposite, Sin then became stronger, he says, and violent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:228
verses.text: But this again is no charge against the Law but against their obstinacy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:229
verses.text: "For without the Law sin is dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:230
verses.text: That is, was not so ascertainable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:231
verses.text: For even those before the Law knew that they had sinned, but they came to a more exact knowledge of it after the giving of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:232
