verses.text: And for this reason they were liable to a greater accusation: since it was not the same thing to have nature to accuse them, and besides nature the Law, which told them distinctly every charge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:233
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:234
verses.text: "For I was alive without the Law once".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:235
verses.text: When, pray, was that? Before Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:236
verses.text: See how he sets himself to show that it, both by the things it did, and the things it did not do, weighed down human nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:237
verses.text: For when "I was alive without the Law," he means, I was not so much condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:238
verses.text: "But when the commandment came, sin revived, and I died".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:239
verses.text: This seems indeed to be an accusing of theLaw.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:240
verses.text: But if any one will look closely at it, it will be seen to be even an encomium of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:241
verses.text: For it did not give existence to sin that before was not, but only pointed out what had escaped notice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:242
verses.text: And this is even a praise of the Law, if at least before it they had been sinning without perceiving it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:243
verses.text: But when this came, if they gained nothing besides from it, at all events this they were distinctly made acquainted with, the fact that they had been sinning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:244
verses.text: And this is no small point, with a view to getting free from wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:245
verses.text: Now if they did not get free, this has nothing to do with the Law; which framed everything with a view to this end, but the accusation lies wholly against their spirit, which was perverse beyond all supposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:246
verses.text: For what took place was not the natural thing,—their being injured by things profitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:247
verses.text: And this is why he says "And the commandment, which was ordained to life, I found to be unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:248
verses.text: He does not say, "it was made," or "it brought forth" death, but "was found," so explaining the novel and unusual kind of discrepancy, and making the whole fall upon their own pate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:249
verses.text: For if, he says, you would know the aim of it, it led to life, and was given with this view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:250
verses.text: But if death was the issue of this, the fault is with them that received the commandment, and not of this, which was leading them to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:251
verses.text: And this is a point on which he has thrown fresh light by what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:252
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:253
verses.text: "For sin taking occasion by the commandment deceived me, and by it slew me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:254
verses.text: You observe how he everywhere keeps to sin, and entirely clears the Law of accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:255
verses.text: And so he proceeds as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:256
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:257
verses.text: "Wherefore the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:258
verses.text: But, if ye be so minded, we will bring before you the language of those who wrest these declarations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:259
verses.text: For this will make our own statements clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:260
verses.text: For there are some that say, that he is not here saying what he does of the Law of Moses, but some take it of the law of nature; some, of the commandment given in Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:261
verses.text: Yet surely Paul's object everywhere is to annul this Law, but he has not any question with those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:262
verses.text: And with much reason; for it was through a fear and a horror of this that the Jews obstinately opposed grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:263
verses.text: But it does not appear that he has ever called the commandment in Paradise "Law" at all; no, nor yet any other writer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:264
verses.text: Now to make this plainer from what he has really said, let us follow out his words, retracing the argument a little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:265
verses.text: Having then spoken to them about strictness of conversation, he goes on to say, "Know ye not, brethren, how that the Law hath dominion over a man as long as he liveth? Wherefore ye are become dead to the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:266
verses.text: Therefore if these things are said about the natural law, we are found to be without the natural law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:267
verses.text: And if this be true, we are more senseless than the creatures which are without reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:268
verses.text: Yet this is not so, certainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:269
verses.text: For with regard to the law in Paradise, there is no need to be contentious, lest we should be taking up a superfluous trouble, by entering the lists against things men have made up their minds upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:270
verses.text: In what sense then does he say, "I should not have known sin but by the Law?" He is speaking, not of absolute want of knowledge, but of the more accurate knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:271
verses.text: For if this were said of the law of nature, how would what follows suit? "For I was alive," he says, "without the Law once".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:272
verses.text: Now neither Adam, nor any body else, can be shown ever to have lived without the law of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:273
verses.text: For as soon as God formed him, He put into him that law of nature, making it to dwell by him as a security to the whole kind (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:274
verses.text: Nature, see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:275
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:276
verses.text: And besides this, it does not appear that he has anywhere called the law of nature a commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:277
verses.text: But this he calls as well a commandment, and that "just and holy," as a "spiritual law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:278
verses.text: But the law of nature was not given to us by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:279
verses.text: For barbarians, as well as Greeks and other men, have this law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:280
verses.text: Hence it is plain, that it is the Mosaic Law that he is speaking of above, as well as afterwards, and in all the passages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:281
verses.text: For this cause also he calls it holy, saying, "Wherefore the Law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:282
verses.text: For even though the Jews have been unclean since the Law, and unjust and covetous, this does not destroy the virtue of the Law, even as their unbelief doth not make the faith of God of none effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:283
verses.text: So from all these things it is plain, that it is of the Law of Moses that he here speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:284
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:285
verses.text: "Was then that which is good made death unto me? God forbid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:286
verses.text: But sin that it might appear sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:287
verses.text: ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:288
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:289
verses.text: ἡ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:290
verses.text: )  That is, that it might be shown what great evil sin is, namely, a listless will, an inclinableness to the worse side, the actual doing ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:291
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:292
verses.text: this clause), and the perverted judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:293
verses.text: For this is the cause of all the evils; but he amplifies it by pointing out the exceeding grace of Christ, and teaching them what an evil He freed the human race from, which, by the medicines used to cure it, had become worse, and was increased by the preventives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:294
verses.text: Wherefore he goes on to say: "That sin, by the commandment, might become exceeding sinful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:295
verses.text: Do you see how these things are woven together everywhere? By the very means he uses to accuse sin, he again shows the excellency of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:296
verses.text: Neither is it a small point which he has gained by showing what an evil sin is, and unfolding the whole of its poison, and bringing it to view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:297
verses.text: For this is what he shows, by saying, "that sin by the commandment might become exceeding sinful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:298
verses.text: That is, that it may be made clear what an evil sin is, what a ruinous thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:299
verses.text: And this is what was shown by the commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:300
verses.text: Hereby he also shows the preëminence of grace above the Law, the preëminence above, not the conflict with, the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:301
verses.text: For do not look to this fact, that those who received it were the worse for it; but consider the other, that the Law had not only no design of drawing wickedness out to greater lengths, but even seriously aimed at hewing down what already existed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:302
verses.text: But if it had no strength, give to it indeed a crown for its intention, but adore more highly the power of Christ, which abolished, cut away: and plucked up the very roots an evil so manifold and so hard to be overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:303
verses.text: But when you hear me speak of sin, do not think of it as a substantial power, but evil doing, as it comes upon men and goes from them continually, and which, before it takes place, has no being, and when it has taken place, vanishes again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:304
verses.text: This then was why the Law was given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:305
verses.text: Now no law is ever given to put an end to things natural, but in order to correct a way of acting purposely wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:306
verses.text: And this the lawgivers that are without too are aware of, and all mankind in general.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:307
verses.text: For it is the evils from viciousness alone that they are for setting right, and they do not undertake to extirpate those allotted us along with our nature; since this they cannot do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:308
verses.text: For things natural remain unalterable (Arist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:309
verses.text: Eth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:310
verses.text: b.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:311
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:312
verses.text: ), as we have told you frequently in other discourses also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:313
verses.text: And so let us leave these contests, and again practise ourselves in exhortation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:314
verses.text: Or rather, this last part belongs to those contests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:315
verses.text: For if we cast out wickedness, we should bring virtue in also: and by these means we shall clearly teach that wickedness is no natural evil, and shall be able easily to stop the mouths of them that enquire for the origin of evil, not by means of words only, but of actions also, since we share the same nature with them, but are freed from their wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:316
verses.text: For let us not be looking at the laboriousness of virtue, but at the possibility of succeeding in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:317
verses.text: But if we be in earnest, it will be at once light and palatable to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:318
verses.text: But if you tell me of the pleasure of vice, tell out its end too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:319
verses.text: For it issueth in death, even as virtue leadeth us to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:320
verses.text: Or if you think fit let us rather scrutinize them both even before their end; for we shall see that vice has a great deal of pain attached to it, and virtue great pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:321
verses.text: For what pray is so painful as a bad conscience? or what more pleasing than a good hope? For there is nothing, assuredly there is nothing, which is used to cut us so deep, and press so hard on us, as the expectation of evil: nothing that so keeps us up, and all but gives us wings, as a good conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:322
verses.text: And this we may get a knowledge of even by what takes place before our eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:323
verses.text: For they that dwell in a prison, and are in expectation of sentence against them, let them have the enjoyment of luxury repeated beyond count, live a more afflicting life than those that go a begging by the by-roads, yet with nothing upon their consciences to trouble them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:324
verses.text: For the expectation of a dreadful end will not let them perceive those pleasures which they have in their hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:325
verses.text: And why do I speak of prisoners? Why, as for those that are living out of prison, and have a good fortune, yet have a bad conscience about them, handicraftsmen that work for their bread, and spend the whole day amid their labor, are in a far better plight than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:326
verses.text: And for this reason too we say, How miserable the gladiators are (though seeing them as we do in taverns, drunken, luxurious, gormandizing), and call them the most miserable of men, because the calamity of the end which they must expect is too great to admit of comparison with that pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:327
verses.text: Now if to them a life of this sort seems to be pleasing, remember what I am continually telling you, that it is no such marvel that a man who lives in vice should not flee from the misery and pain of vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:328
verses.text: For see how a thing so detestable as that, yet seems to be delectable to those who practice it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:329
verses.text: Yet we do not on this account say, how happy they are, for this is just the very reason why we think them pitiable, because they have no notion of the evils they are amongst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:330
verses.text: And what would you say of adulterers, who for a little pleasure undergo at once a disgraceful slavery, and a loss of money, and a perpetual fear (Hor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:331
verses.text: Sat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:332
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:333
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:334
verses.text: –), and in fact the very life of a Cain, or rather one that is even much worse than his; filled with fears for the present, and trembling for the future, and suspecting alike friend and foe, and those that know about it, and those that know nothing? Neither when they go to sleep are they quit of this struggle, their bad conscience shaping out for them dreams that abound with sundry terrors, and in this way horrifying them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:335
verses.text: Far otherwise is the chaste man, seeing he passes the present life unshackled and at full liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:336
verses.text: Weigh then against the little pleasure, the sundry fluctuations of these terrors, and with the short labor of continency, the calm of an entire life; and you will find the latter hath more of pleasantness than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:337
verses.text: But as for the man that is set upon plundering and laying hands upon other men's goods, tell me if he has not to undergo countless pains in the way of running about, fawning upon slaves, freemen, doorkeepers; alarming and threatening, acting shamelessly, watching, trembling, in agony, suspecting everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:338
verses.text: Far otherwise is the man that holds riches in contempt, for he too enjoys pleasure in abundance, and lives with no fear, and in perfect security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:339
verses.text: And if any one were to go through the other instances of vice, he would find much trouble, and many rocks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:340
verses.text: But what is of greater importance is, that in the case of virtue the difficulties come first, and the pleasant part afterwards, so the trouble is even thus alleviated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:341
verses.text: But in the case of vice, the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:342
verses.text: After the pleasure, the pains and the punishments, so that by these besides the pleasure is done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:343
verses.text: For as he who waits for the crown, perceives nothing of present annoyance, so he that has to expect the punishments after the pleasures has no power of gathering in a gladness that is unalloyed, since the fear puts everything in confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:344
verses.text: Or rather if any one were to scrutinize the thing with care, even before the punishment which follows upon these things, he would find that even at the very moment when vice is boldly entered upon, a great deal of pain is felt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:345
verses.text: And, if you think fit, let us just examine this in the case of those who plunder other men's goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:346
verses.text: Or those who in any way get together money, and setting aside the fears, and dangers, and trembling, and agony, and care, and all these things, let us suppose the case of a man, who has got rich without any annoyance, and feels sure about maintaining his present fortune (which he has no means of doing, still for all that let it be assumed for argument's sake).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:347
verses.text: What sort of pleasure then is he to gather in from having so much about him? On the contrary, it is just this very thing that will not let him be glad-hearted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:348
verses.text: For as long as ever he desires other things besides, he is still upon the rack.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:349
verses.text: Because desire gives pleasure at the time it has come to a stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:350
verses.text: If thirsty, for instance, we feel refreshed, when we have drunk as much as we wish; but so long as we keep thirsty, even if we were to have exhausted all the fountains in the world, our torment were but growing greater; even if we were to drink up ten thousand rivers, our state of punishment were more distressing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:351
verses.text: And thou also, if thou wert to receive the goods of the whole world, and still to covet, wouldest make thy punishment the greater, the more things thou hadst tasted of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:352
verses.text: Fancy not then, that from having gathered a great sum together thou shalt have aught of pleasure, but rather by declining to be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:353
verses.text: But if thou covetest to be rich thou wilt be always under the scourge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:354
verses.text: For this is a kind of love that does not reach its aim; and the longer journey thou hast gone, the further off thou keepest from the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:355
verses.text: Is not this a paradox then, a derangement, a madness in the extreme? Let us then forsake this first of evils, or rather let us not even touch this covetousness at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:356
verses.text: Yet, if we have touched it, let us spring away from its first motions (προοιμίων).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:357
verses.text: For this is the advice the writer of the Proverbs gives us, when he speaks about the harlot: "Spring away," he says, "tarry not, neither go thou near to the door of her house" (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:358
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:359
verses.text: ): this same thing I would say to you about the love of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:360
verses.text: For if by entering gradually you fall into this ocean of madness, you will not be able to get up out of it with ease, and as if you were in whirlpools, struggle as often as ever you may, it will not be easy for you to get clear; so after falling into this far worse abyss of covetousness, you will destroy your own self, with all that belongs to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:361
verses.text: (Acts viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:362
verses.text: ) And so my advice is that we be on our watch against the beginning, and avoid little evils, for the great ones are gendered by these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:363
verses.text: For he who gets into a way of saying at every sin, This matters nothing! will by little and little ruin himself entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:364
verses.text: At all events it is this which has introduced vice; which has opened the doors to the robber ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:365
verses.text: devil), which has thrown down the walls of cities, this saying at each sin, "This matters nothing!" Thus in the case of the body too, the greatest of diseases grow up, when trifling ones are made light of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:366
verses.text: If Esau had not first been a traitor to his birthright, he would not have become unworthy of the blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:367
verses.text: If he had not rendered himself unworthy of the blessings, he would not have had the desire of going on to fratricide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:368
verses.text: If Cain had not fallen in love with the first place, but had left that to God, he would not have had the second place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:369
verses.text: Again, when he had the second place, if he had listened to the advice, he would not have travailed with the murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:370
verses.text: Again, if after doing the murder he had come to repentance, when God called him, and had not answered in an irreverent way, he would not have had to suffer the subsequent evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:371
verses.text: But if those before the Law did owing to this listlessness come to the very bottom of misery, only consider what is to become of us, who are called to a greater contest, unless we take strict heed unto ourselves, and make speed to quench the sparks of evil deeds before the whole pile is kindled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:372
verses.text: Take an instance of my meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:373
verses.text: Are you in the habit of false swearing? do not stop at this only, but away with all swearing, and you will have no further need of trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:374
verses.text: For it is far harder for a man that swears to keep from false swearing, than to abstain from swearing altogether.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:375
verses.text: Are you an insulting and abusive person? a striker too? Lay down as a law for yourself not to be angry or brawl in the least, and with the root the fruit also will be gotten rid of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:376
verses.text: Are you lustful and dissipated? Make it your rule again not even to look at a woman (Job xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:377
verses.text: ), or to go up into the theatre, or to trouble yourself with the beauty of other people whom you see about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:378
verses.text: For it is far easier not even to look at a woman of good figure, than after looking and taking in the lust, to thrust out the perturbation that comes thereof, the struggle being easier in the preliminaries (προοιμίοις).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:379
verses.text: Or rather we have no need of a struggle at all if we do not throw the gates open to the enemy, or take in the seeds of mischief (κακίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:380
verses.text: And this is why Christ chastised the man who looks unchastely upon a woman (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:381
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:382
verses.text: ), that He might free us from greater labor, before the adversary became strong, bidding us cast him out of the house while he may be cast out even with ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:383
verses.text: For what need to have superfluous trouble, and to get entangled with the enemies, when without entanglement we may erect the trophy, and before the wrestling seize upon the prize? For it is not so great a trouble not to look upon beautiful women, as it is while looking to restrain one's self.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:384
verses.text: Or rather the first would be no trouble at all, but immense toil and labor comes on after looking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:385
verses.text: Since then this trouble is less (most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:386
verses.text: add, "to the incontinent"), or rather there is no labor at all, nor trouble, but the greater gain, why do we take pains to plunge into an ocean of countless evils? And farther, he who does not look upon a woman, will overcome such lust not only with greater ease, but with a higher purity, as he on the other hand who does look, getteth free with more trouble, and not without a kind of stain, that is, if he does get free at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:387
verses.text: For he that does not take a view of the beautiful figure, is pure also from the lust that might result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:388
verses.text: But he who lusteth to look, after first laying his reason low, and polluting it in countless ways, has then to cast out the stain that came of the lust, that is, if he do cast it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:389
verses.text: This then is why Christ, to prevent our suffering in this way, did not prohibit murder only, but wrath; not adultery only, but an unchaste look even: not perjury only, but all swearing whatsoever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:390
verses.text: Nor does he make the measure of virtue stop here, but after having given these laws, He proceeds to a still greater degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:391
verses.text: For after keeping us far away from murder, and bidding us to be clear of wrath, He bids us be ready even to suffer ill, and not to be prepared to suffer no more than what he who attacks us pleases, but even to go further, and to get the better of his utmost madness by the overflowingness of our own Christian spirit (τἥς οἱκείας φιγοσοφίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:392
verses.text: For what He says is not, "If a man smite thee on thy right cheek, bear it nobly and hold thy peace;" but He adds to this the yielding to him the other too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:393
verses.text: For He says, "Turn to him the other also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:394
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:395
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:396
verses.text: ) This then is the brilliant victory, to yield him even more than what he wishes, and to go beyond the bounds of his evil desire by the profuseness of one's own patient endurance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:397
verses.text: For in this way you will put a stop to his madness, and also receive from the second act again the reward of the first, besides putting a stop to wrath against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:398
verses.text: See you, how in all cases it is we that have it in our power not to suffer ill, and not they that inflict it? Or rather it is not the not suffering ill alone, but even the having benefits (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:399
verses.text: conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:400
verses.text: παθεἵν εὖ, so  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:401
verses.text: ) done us that we have in our own power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:402
verses.text: And this is the truest wonder, that we are so far from being injured, if we be right-minded, that we are even benefited, and that too by the very things that we suffer unjustly at the hands of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:403
verses.text: Reflect then; has such an one done you an affront? You have the power of making this affront redound to your honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:404
verses.text: For if you do an affront in return, you only increase the disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:405
verses.text: But if you bless him that did you the affront, you will see that all men give you victory, and proclaim your praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:406
verses.text: Do you see how by the things wherein we are wronged, we get good done unto us if we be so minded? This one may see happening in the case of money matters, of blows, and the same in everything else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:407
verses.text: For if we requite them with the opposite, we are but twining a double crown about us, one for the ills we have suffered, as well as one for the good we are doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:408
verses.text: Whenever then a person comes and tells you that "such an one has done you an affront, and keeps continually speaking ill of you to everybody," praise the man to those who tell you of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:409
verses.text: For thus even if you wish to avenge yourself, you will have the power of inflicting punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:410
verses.text: For those who hear you, be they ever so foolish, will praise you, and hate him as fiercer than any brute beast, because he, without being at all wronged, caused you pain, but you, even when suffering wrong, requited him with the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:411
verses.text: And so you will have it in your power to prove that all that he said was to no purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:412
verses.text: For he who feels the tooth of slander, gives by his vexation a proof that he is conscious of the truth of what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:413
verses.text: But he who smiles at it, by this very thing acquits himself of all suspicion with those who are present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:414
verses.text: Consider then how many good things you cull together from the affair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:415
verses.text: First, you rid yourself of all vexation and trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:416
verses.text: Secondly (rather this should come first), even if you have sins, you put them off, as the Publican did by bearing the Pharisee's accusation meekly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:417
verses.text: Besides, you will by this practice make your soul heroic (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:418
verses.text: philosophic), and will enjoy endless praises from all men, and will divest yourself of any suspicion arising from what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:419
verses.text: But even if you are desirous of taking revenge upon the man, this too will follow in full measure, both by God's punishing him for what he has said, and before that punishment by thy heroic conduct standing to him in the place of a mortal blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:420
verses.text: For there is nothing that cuts those who affront us so much to the heart, as for us who are affronted to smile at the affront.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:421
verses.text: As then from behaving with Christian heroism so many honors will accrue to us, so from being little-minded just the opposite will befall us in everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:422
verses.text: For we disgrace ourselves, and also seem to those present to be guilty of the things mentioned, and fill our soul with perturbation, and give our enemy pleasure, and provoke God, and add to our former sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:423
verses.text: Taking then all this into consideration, let us flee from the abyss of a little mind (μικροψυχίας), and take refuge in the port of patient endurance (μακροθυμίας), that here we may at once "find rest unto our souls" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:424
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 13:425
verses.text: ), as Christ also set forth, and may attain to the good things to come, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:3
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:4
verses.text: "For we know that the Law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold under sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:5
verses.text: After having said that great evils had taken place, and that sin, taking occasion by the commandment, had grown stronger, and the opposite of what the Law mainly aimed at had been the result, and after having thrown the hearer into a great deal of perplexity, he goes on next to give the rationale of these events, after first clearing the Law of any ill suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:6
verses.text: For lest—upon hearing that it was through the commandment that sin took that occasion, and that it was when it came that sin revived, and through it deceived and killed—any one should suppose the Law to be the source of these evils, he first sets forth its defence with considerable advantage, not clearing it from accusation only, but encircling it also with the utmost praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:7
verses.text: And this he lays down, not as granting it for his own part, but as declaring a universal judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:8
verses.text: "For we know," he says, "that the Law is spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:9
verses.text: As if he had said, This is an allowed thing, and self-evident, that it "is spiritual," so far is it from being the cause of sin, or to blame for the evils that have happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:10
verses.text: And observe, that he not only clears it of accusation, but bestows exceeding great praise upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:11
verses.text: For by calling it spiritual, he shows it to be a teacher of virtue and hostile to vice; for this is what being spiritual means, leading off from sin of every kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:12
verses.text: And this the Law did do, by frightening, admonishing, chastening, correcting, recommending every kind of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:13
verses.text: Whence then, was sin produced, if the teacher was so admirable? It was from the listlessness of its disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:14
verses.text: Wherefore he went on to say, "but I am carnal;" giving us a sketch now of man, as comporting himself in the Law, and before the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:15
verses.text: "Sold under sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:16
verses.text: Because with death (he means) the throng of passions also came in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:17
verses.text: For when the body had become mortal, it was henceforth a necessary thing for it to receive concupiscence, and anger, and pain, and all the other passions, which required a great deal of wisdom (φιλοσοφίας) to prevent their flooding us, and sinking reason in the depth of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:18
verses.text: For in themselves they were not sin, but, when their extravagancy was unbridled, it wrought this effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:19
verses.text: Thus (that I may take one of them and examine it as a specimen) desire is not sin: but when it has run into extravagance, being not minded to keep within the laws of marriage, but springing even upon other men's wives; then the thing henceforward becomes adultery, yet not by reason of the desire, but by reason of its exorbitancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:20
verses.text: And observe the wisdom of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:21
verses.text: For after praising the Law, he hastens immediately to the earlier period, that he may show the state of our race, both then and at the time it received the Law, and make it plain how necessary the presence of grace was, a thing he labored on every occasion to prove.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:22
verses.text: For when he says, "sold under sin," he means it not of those who were under the Law only, but of those who had lived before the Law also, and of men from the very first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:23
verses.text: Next he mentions the way in which they were sold and made over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:24
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:25
verses.text: "For that which I do, I know not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:26
verses.text: What does the "I know not" mean?—I am ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:27
verses.text: And when could this ever happen? For nobody ever sinned in ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:28
verses.text: Seest thou, that if we do not receive his words with the proper caution, and keep looking to the object of the Apostle, countless incongruities will follow? For if they sinned through ignorance, then they did not deserve to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:29
verses.text: As then he said above, "for without the Law sin is dead," not meaning that they did not know they were sinning, but that they knew indeed, but not so distinctly; wherefore they were punished, but not so severely: and again; "I should not have known lust;" not meaning an entire ignorance of it, but referring to the most distinct knowledge of it; and said, that it also "wrought in me all manner of concupiscence," not meaning to say that the commandment made the concupiscence, but that sin through the commandment introduces an intense degree of concupiscence; so here it is not absolute ignorance that he means by saying, "For what I do, I know not;" since how then would he have pleasure in the law of God in his inner man? What then is this, "I know not?" I get dizzy, he means, I feel carried away, I find a violence done to me, I get tripped up without knowing how.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:30
verses.text: Just as we often say, Such an one came and carried me away with him, without my knowing how; when it is not ignorance we mean as an excuse, but to show a sort of deceit, and circumvention, and plot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:31
verses.text: "For what I would, that I do not: but what I hate, that I do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:32
verses.text: How then canst thou be said not to know what thou art doing? For if thou willest the good, and hatest the evil, this requires a perfect knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:33
verses.text: Whence it appears that he says, "that I would not," not as denying free will, or as adducing any constrained necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:34
verses.text: For if it was not willingly, but by compulsion, that we sinned, then the punishments that took place before would not be justifiable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:35
verses.text: But as in saying "I know not," it was not ignorance he set before us, but what we have said; so in adding the "that I would not," it is no necessity he signifies, but the disapproval he felt of what was done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:36
verses.text: Since if this was not his meaning in saying, "That which I would not, that I do:" he would else have gone on, "But I do what I am compelled and enforced to".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:37
verses.text: For this is what is opposed to willing and power (ἐξουσί& ·).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:38
verses.text: But now he does not say this, but in the place of it he has put the word, "that I hate," that you might learn how when he says, "that I would not," he does not deny the power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:39
verses.text: Now, what does the "that I would not" mean? It means, what I praise not, what I do not approve, what I love not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:40
verses.text: And in contradistinction to this, he adds what follows; "But what I hate, that I do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:41
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:42
verses.text: "If then I do that which I would not, I consent unto the Law, that it is good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:43
verses.text: You see here, that the understanding is not yet perverted, but keeps up its own noble character even during the action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:44
verses.text: For even if it does pursue vice, still it hates it the while, which would be great commendation, whether of the natural or the written Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:45
verses.text: For that the Law is good, is (he says) plain, from the fact of my accusing myself, when I disobey the Law, and hate what has been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:46
verses.text: And yet if the Law was to blame for the sin, how comes it that he felt a delight in it, yet hated what it orders to be done? For, "I consent," he says, "unto the Law, that it is good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:47
verses.text: Ver ,.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:48
verses.text: "Now then it is no more I that do it, but sin that dwelleth in me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:49
verses.text: For I know that in me, that is, in my flesh, dwelleth no good thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:50
verses.text: On this text, those who find fault with the flesh, and contend it was no part of God's creation, attack us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:51
verses.text: What are we to say then? Just what we did before, when discusssing the Law: that as there he makes sin answerable for everything so here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:52
verses.text: For he does not say, that the flesh worketh it, but just the contrary, "it is not I that do it, but sin that dwelleth in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:53
verses.text: But if he does say that "there dwelleth no good thing in it," still this is no charge against the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:54
verses.text: For the fact that "no good thing dwelleth in it," does not show that it is evil itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:55
verses.text: Now we admit, that the flesh is not so great as the soul, and is inferior to it, yet not contrary, or opposed to it, or evil; but that it is beneath the soul, as a harp beneath a harper, and as a ship under the pilot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:56
verses.text: And these are not contrary to those who guide and use them, but go with them entirely, yet are not of the same honor with the artist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:57
verses.text: As then a person who says, that the art resides not in the harp or the ship, but in the pilot or harper, is not finding fault with the instruments, but pointing out the great difference between them and the artist; so Paul in saying, that "in my flesh dwelleth no good thing," is not finding fault with the body, but pointing out the soul's superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:58
verses.text: For this it is that has the whole duty or pilotage put into its hands, and that of playing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:59
verses.text: And this Paul here points out, giving the governing power to the soul, and after dividing man into these two things, the soul and the body, he says, that the flesh has less of reason, and is destitute of discretion, and ranks among things to be led, not among things that lead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:60
verses.text: But the soul has more wisdom, and can see what is to be done and what not, yet is not equal to pulling in the horse as it wishes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:61
verses.text: And this would be a charge not against the flesh only, but against the soul also, which knows indeed what it ought to do, but still does not carry out in practice what seems best to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:62
verses.text: "For to will," he says, "is present with me; but how to perform that which is good, I find not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:63
verses.text: Here again in the words, "I find not," he does not speak of any ignorance or perplexity, but a kind of thwarting and crafty assault made by sin, which he therefore points more clearly out in the next words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:64
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:65
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:66
verses.text: "For the good that I would I do not: but the evil which I would not that I do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:67
verses.text: Now if I do that I would not, it is no more I that do it but sin that dwelleth in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:68
verses.text: Do you see, how he acquits the essence of the soul, as well as the essence of the flesh, from accusation, and removes it entirely to sinful actions? For if the soul willeth not the evil, it is cleared: and if he does not work it himself, the body too is set free, and the whole may be charged upon the evil moral choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:69
verses.text: Now the essence of the soul and body and of that choice are not the same, for the two first are God's works, and the other is a motion from ourselves towards whatever we please to direct it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:70
verses.text: For willing is indeed natural (ἕμφυτον), and is from God: but willing on this wise is our own, and from our own mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:71
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:72
verses.text: "I find then a law, that when I would do good, evil is present with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:73
verses.text: What he says is not very clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:74
verses.text: What then is it that is said? I praise the law, he says, in my conscience, and I find it pleads on my side so far as I am desirous of doing what is right, and that it invigorates this wish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:75
verses.text: For as I feel a pleasure in it, so does it yield praise to my decision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:76
verses.text: Do you see how he shows, that the knowledge of what is good and what is not such is an original and fundamental part of our nature, and that the Law of Moses praises it, and getteth praise from it? For above he did not say so much as I get taught by the Law, but "I consent to the Law;" nor further on that I get instructed by it, but "I delight in" it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:77
verses.text: Now what is "I delight?" It is, I agree with it as right, as it does with me when wishing to do what is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:78
verses.text: And so the willing what is good and the not willing what is evil was made a fundamental part of us from the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:79
verses.text: But the Law, when it came, was made at once a stronger accuser in what was bad, and a greater praiser in what was good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:80
verses.text: Do you observe that in every place he bears witness to its having a kind of intensitiveness and additional advantage, yet nothing further? For though it praises and I delight in it, and wish what is good the "evil is" still "present with me," and the agency of it has not been abolished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:81
verses.text: And thus the Law, with a man who determines upon doing anything good, only acts so far as auxiliary to him, as that it has the same wish as himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:82
verses.text: Then since he had stated it indistinctly, as he goes on he gives a yet more distinct interpretation, by showing how the evil is present, how too the Law is a law to such a person only who has a mind to do what is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:83
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:84
verses.text: "For I delight," he says, "in the law of God after the inward man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:85
verses.text: He means, for I knew even before this what was good, but when I find it set down in writing, I praise it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:87
verses.text: "But I see another law warring against the law of my mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:88
verses.text: Here again he calls sin a law warring against the other, not in respect of good order, but from the strict obedience yielded to it by those who comply with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:89
verses.text: As then it gives the name of master (κύριον Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:90
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:91
verses.text: ; Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:92
verses.text: ) to Mammon, and of god (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:93
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:94
verses.text: ) to the belly, not because of their intrinsically deserving it, but because of the extreme obsequiousness of their subjects; so here he calls sin a law, owing to those who are so obsequious to it, and are afraid to leave it, just as those who have received the Law dread leaving the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:95
verses.text: This then, he means, is opposed to the law of nature; for this is what is meant by "the law of my mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:96
verses.text: And he next represents an array and battle, and refers the whole struggle to the law of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:97
verses.text: For that of Moses was subsequently added over and above: yet still both the one and the other, the one as teaching, the other as praising what was right, wrought no great effects in this battle; so great was the thraldom of sin, overcoming and getting the upper hand as it did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:98
verses.text: And this Paul setting forth, and showing the decided (κατὰ κράτος) victory it had, says, "I see another law warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:99
verses.text: He does not use the word conquering only, but "bringing me into captivity to the law of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:100
verses.text: He does not say the bent of the flesh, or the nature of the flesh, but "the law of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:101
verses.text: That is, the thrall, the power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:102
verses.text: In what sense then does he say, "Which is in my members?" Now what is this? Surely it does not make the members to be sin, but makes them as distinct from sin as possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:103
verses.text: For that which is in a thing is diverse from that wherein it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:104
verses.text: As then the commandment also is not evil, because by it sin took occasion, so neither is the nature of the flesh, even if sin subdues us by means of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:105
verses.text: For in this way the soul will be evil, and much more so too, since it has authority in matters of action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:106
verses.text: But these things are not so, certainly they are not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:107
verses.text: Since neither if a tyrant and a robber were to take possession of a splendid mansion and a king's court, would the circumstance be any discredit to the house, inasmuch as the entire blame would come on those who contrived such an act.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:108
verses.text: But the enemies of the truth, along with their impiety, fall unawares also into great unreasonableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:109
verses.text: For they do not accuse the flesh only, but they also disparage the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:110
verses.text: And yet if the flesh were evil, the Law would be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:111
verses.text: For it wars against the Law, and opposes it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:112
verses.text: If, however, the Law be not good, then the flesh is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:113
verses.text: For it wars and fights against it even by their own account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:114
verses.text: How come they then to assert that both belong to the devil, putting things opposed to each other before us? Do you see, along with their impiety, how great is their unreasonableness also? But such doctrines as these are not the Church's, for it is the sin only that she condemns; and both the Laws which God has given, both that of nature and that of Moses, she says are hostile to this, and not to the flesh; for the flesh she denies to be sin, for it is a work of God's, and one very useful too in order to virtue, if we live soberly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:115
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:116
verses.text: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?"  Do you notice what a great thraldom that of vice is, in that it overcomes even a mind that delighted in the Law? For no one can rejoin, he means, that I hate the Law and abhor it, and so sin overcomes me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:117
verses.text: For "I delight in it, and consent to it," and flee for refuge to it, yet still it had not the power of saving one who had fled to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:118
verses.text: But Christ saved even one that fled from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:119
verses.text: See what a vast advantage grace has! Yet the Apostle has not stated it thus; but with a sigh only, and a great lamentation, as if devoid of any to help him, he points out by his perplexity the might of Christ, and says, "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" The Law has not been able: conscience has proved unequal to it, though it praised what was good, and did not praise it only, but even fought against the contrary of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:120
verses.text: For by the very words "warreth against" he shows that he was marshalled against it for his part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:121
verses.text: From what quarter then is one to hope for salvation?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:122
verses.text: "I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:123
verses.text: Observe how he shows the necessity of having grace present with us, and that the well-doings herein belong alike to the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:124
verses.text: For if it is the Father Whom he thanketh, still the Son is the cause of this thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:125
verses.text: But when you hear him say, "Who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" do not suppose him to be accusing the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:126
verses.text: For he does not say "body of sin," but "body of death:" that is, the mortal body—that which hath been overcome by death, not that which gendered death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:127
verses.text: And this is no proof of the evil of the flesh, but of the marring (ἐπηρείας, thwarting) it has undergone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:128
verses.text: As if any one who was take captive by the savages were to be said to belong to the savages, not as being a savage, but as being detained by them: so the body is said to be of death, as being held down thereby, not as producing it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:129
verses.text: Wherefore also it is not the body that he himself wishes to be delivered from, but the mortal body, hinting, as I have often said, that from its becoming subject to suffering, it also became an easy prey to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:130
verses.text: Why then, it may be said, the thraldom of sin being so great before the times of grace, were men punished for sinning? Because they had such commands given them as might even under sin's dominion be accomplished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:131
verses.text: For he did not draw them to the highest kind of conversation, but allowed them to enjoy wealth, and did not forbid having several wives, and to gratify anger in a just cause, and to make use of luxury within bounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:132
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:133
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:134
verses.text: ) And so great was this condescension, that the written Law even required less than the law of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:135
verses.text: For the law of nature ordered one man to associate with one woman throughout.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:136
verses.text: And this Christ shows in the words, "He which made them at the beginning, made them male and female".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:137
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:138
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:139
verses.text: ) But the Law of Moses neither forbade the putting away of one and the taking in of another, nor prohibited the having of two at once! (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:140
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:141
verses.text: ) And besides this there are also many other ordinances of the Law, that one might see those who were before its day fully performing, being instructed by the law of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:142
verses.text: They therefore who lived under the old dispensation had no hardship done them by so moderate a system of laws being imposed upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:143
verses.text: But if they were not, on these terms, able to get the upper hand, the charge is against their own listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:144
verses.text: Wherefore Paul gives thanks, because Christ, without any rigorousness about these things, not only demanded no account of this moderate amount, but even made us able to have a greater race set before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:145
verses.text: And therefore he says, "I thank my God through Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:146
verses.text: And letting the salvation which all agreed about pass, he goes from the points he had already made good, to another further point, in which he states that it was not our former sins only that we were freed from, but we were also made invincible for the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:147
verses.text: For "there is," he says, "now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:148
verses.text: Yet he did not say it before he had first recalled to mind our former condition again in the words, "So then with the mind I myself serve the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:149
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:150
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:151
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:152
verses.text: "There is therefore no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:153
verses.text: Then as the fact that many fall into sin even after baptism presented a difficulty (ἀντέπιπτεν), he consequently hastened to meet it, and says not merely "to them that are in Christ Jesus," but adds, "who walk not after the flesh;" so showing that all afterward comes of our listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:154
verses.text: For now we have the power of walking not after the flesh, but then it was a difficult task.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:155
verses.text: Then he gives another proof of it by the sequel, in the words,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:156
verses.text: "For the law of the Spirit of life hath made me free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:157
verses.text: It is the Spirit he is here calling the law of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:158
verses.text: For as he calls sin the law of sin, so he here calls the Spirit the law of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:159
verses.text: And yet he named that of Moses as such, where he says, "For we know that the Law is spiritual".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:160
verses.text: What then is the difference? A great and unbounded one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:161
verses.text: For that was spiritual, but this is a law of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:162
verses.text: Now what is the distinction between this and that? The other was merely given by the Spirit, but this even furnisheth those that receive it with the Spirit in large measure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:163
verses.text: Wherefore also he called it the law of life in contradistinction to that of sin, not that of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:164
verses.text: For when he says, It freed me from the law of sin and death, it is not the law of Moses that he is here speaking of, since in no case does he style it the law of sin: for how could he one that he had called "just and holy" so often, and destructive of sin too? but it is that which warreth against the law of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:165
verses.text: For this grievous war did the grace of the Spirit put a stop to, by slaying sin, and making the contest light to us and crowning us at the outstart, and then drawing us to the struggle with abundant help.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:166
verses.text: Next as it is ever his wont to turn from the Spirit to the Son and the Father, and to reckon all our estate to lean upon the Trinity, so doth he here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:167
verses.text: For after saying, "Who shall deliver me from the body of this death," he pointed at the Father as doing this by the Son, then again at the Holy Spirit along with the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:168
verses.text: "For the law of the Spirit of Life in Christ Jesus hath made me free, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:169
verses.text: Then again, at the Father and the Son;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:170
verses.text: "For what the Law could not do," he saith, "in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:171
verses.text: Again, he seems indeed to be disparaging the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:172
verses.text: But if any one attends strictly, he even highly praises it, by showing that it harmonizes with Christ, and gives preference to the same things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:173
verses.text: For he does not speak of the badness of the Law, but of "what it could not do;" and so again, "in that it was weak," not, "in that it was mischievous, or designing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:174
verses.text: And even weakness he does not ascribe to it, but to the flesh, as he says, "in that it was weak through the flesh," using the word "flesh" here again not for the essence and subsistency itself, but giving its name to the more carnal sort of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:175
verses.text: In which way he acquits both the body and the Law of any accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:176
verses.text: Yet not in this way only, but by what comes next also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:177
verses.text: For supposing the Law to be of the contrary part, how was it Christ came to its assistance, and fulfilled its requisitions, and lent it a helping hand by condemning sin in the flesh? For this was what was lacking, since in the soul the Lord had condemned it long ago.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:178
verses.text: What then? is it the greater thing that the Law accomplished, but the less that the Only-Begotten did? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:179
verses.text: For it was God that was the principal doer of that also, in that He gave us the law of nature, and added the written one to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:180
verses.text: Again, there were no use of the greater, if the lesser had not been supplied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:181
verses.text: For what good is it to know what things ought to be done, if a man does not follow it out? None, for it were but a greater condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:182
verses.text: And so He that hath saved the soul it is, Who hath made the flesh also easy to bridle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:183
verses.text: For to teach is easy, but to show besides a way in which these things were easily done, this is the marvel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:184
verses.text: Now it was for this that the Only-Begotten came, and did not depart before He had set us free from this difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:185
verses.text: But what is greater, is the method of the victory; for He took none other flesh, but this very one which was beset with troubles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:186
verses.text: So it is as if any one were to see in the street a vile woman of the baser sort being beaten, and were to say he was her son, when he was the king's, and so to get her free from those who ill treated her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:187
verses.text: And this He really did, in that He confessed that He was the Son of Man, and stood by it (i-e: the flesh), and condemned the sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:188
verses.text: However, He did not endure to smite it besides; or rather, He smote it with the blow of His death, but in this very act it was not the smitten flesh which was condemned and perished, but the sin which had been smiting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:189
verses.text: And this is the greatest possible marvel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:190
verses.text: For if it were not in the flesh that the victory took place, it would not be so astonishing, since this the Law also wrought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:191
verses.text: But the wonder is, that it was with the flesh (μετὰ σαρκὸς) that His trophy was raised, and that what had been overthrown numberless times by sin, did itself get a glorious victory over it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:192
verses.text: For behold what strange things there were that took place! One was, that sin did not conquer the flesh; another, that sin was conquered, and conquered by it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:193
verses.text: For it is not the same thing not to get conquered, and to conquer that which was continually overthrowing us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:194
verses.text: A third is, that it not only conquered it, but even chastised it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:195
verses.text: For by not sinning it kept from being conquered, but by dying also, He overcame and condemned it, having made the flesh, that before was so readily made a mock of by it, a plain object of fear to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:196
verses.text: In this way then, He at once unnerved its power, and abolished the death by it introduced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:197
verses.text: For so long as it took hold of sinners, it with justice kept pressing to its end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:198
verses.text: But after finding a sinless body, when it had given it up to death, it was condemned as having acted unjustly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:199
verses.text: Do you observe, how many proofs of victory there are? The flesh not being conquered by sin, Its even conquering and condemning it, Its not condemning it barely, but condemning it as having sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:200
verses.text: For after having convicted it of injustice, he proceeds to condemn it, and that not by power and might barely, but even by the rules of justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:201
verses.text: For this is what he means by saying, "for sin condemned sin in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:202
verses.text: As if he had said that he had convicted it of great sin, and then condemned it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:203
verses.text: So you see it is sin that getteth condemned everywhere, and not the flesh, for this is even crowned with honor, and has to give sentence against the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:204
verses.text: But if he does say that it was "in the likeness" of flesh that he sent the Son, do not therefore suppose that His flesh was of a different kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:205
verses.text: For as he called it "sinful," this was why he put the word "likeness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:206
verses.text: For sinful flesh it was not that Christ had, but like indeed to our sinful flesh, yet sinless, and in nature the same with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:207
verses.text: And so even from this it is plain that by nature the flesh was not evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:208
verses.text: For it was not by taking a different one instead of the former, nor by changing this same one in substance, that Christ caused it to regain the victory: but He let it abide in its own nature, and yet made it bind on the crown of victory over sin, and then after the victory raised it up, and made it immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:209
verses.text: What then, it may be said, is this to me, whether it was this flesh that these things happened in? Nay, it concerns thee very much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:210
verses.text: Wherefore also he proceeds:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:211
verses.text: "That the righteousness of the Law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:212
