verses.text: What meaneth this word, righteousness? Why, the end, the scope, the well-doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:213
verses.text: For what was its design, and what did it enjoin? To be without sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:214
verses.text: This then is made good to us (κατώρθωται ἡμἵν) now through Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:215
verses.text: And the making a stand against it, and the getting the better of it, came from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:216
verses.text: But it is for us to enjoy the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:217
verses.text: Then shall we never sin henceforth? We never shall unless we have become exceedingly relaxed and supine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:218
verses.text: And this is why he added, "to them that walk not after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:219
verses.text: For lest, after hearing that Christ hath delivered thee from the war of sin, and that the requisition (δικαίωμα) of the Law is fulfilled in thee, by sin having been "condemned in the flesh," thou shouldest break up all thy defences; therefore, in that place also, after saying, "there is therefore no condemnation," he added, "to them that walk not after the flesh;" and here also, "that the requisition of the Law might be fulfilled in us," he proceeds with the very same thing; or rather, not with it only, but even with a much stronger thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:220
verses.text: For after saying, "that the righteousness of the Law might be fulfilled in us that walk not after the flesh," he proceeds, "but after the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:221
verses.text: So showing, that it is not only binding upon us to keep ourselves from evil deeds, but also to be adorned (κομᾅν) with good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:222
verses.text: For to give thee the crown is His; but it is thine to hold it fast when given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:223
verses.text: For the righteousness of the Law, that one should not become liable to its curse, Christ has accomplished for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:224
verses.text: Be not a traitor then to so great a gift, but keep guarding this goodly treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:225
verses.text: For in this passage he shows that the Font will not suffice to save us, unless, after coming from it, we display a life worthy of the Gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:226
verses.text: And so he again advocates the Law in saying what he does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:227
verses.text: For when we have once become obedient to Christ, we must use all ways and plans so that its righteousness, which Christ fulfilled, may abide in us, and not come to naught.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:228
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:229
verses.text: "For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:230
verses.text: Yet even this is no disparaging of the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:231
verses.text: For so long as it keeps its own place, nothing amiss cometh to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:232
verses.text: But when we let it have its own will in everything, and it passes over its proper bounds, and rises up against the soul, then it destroys and corrupts everything, yet not owing to its own nature, but to its being out of proportion, and the disorder thereupon ensuing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:233
verses.text: "But they that are after the Spirit do mind the things of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:234
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:235
verses.text: "For to be carnally minded is death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:236
verses.text: He does not speak of the nature of the flesh, or the essence of the body, but of being carnally "minded," which may be set right again, and abolished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:237
verses.text: And in saying thus, he does not ascribe to the flesh any reasoning power of its own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:238
verses.text: Far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:239
verses.text: But to set forth the grosser motion of the mind, and giving this a name from the inferior part, and in the same way as he often is in the habit of calling man in his entireness, and viewed as possessed of a soul, flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:240
verses.text: "But to be spiritually minded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:241
verses.text: Here again he speaks of the spiritual mind, in the same way as he says further on, "But He that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the spirit" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:242
verses.text: ); and he points out many blessings resulting from this, both in the present life, and in that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:243
verses.text: For as the evils which being carnally minded introduces, are far outnumbered by those blessings which a spiritual mind affords.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:244
verses.text: And this he points out in the words "life and peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:245
verses.text: The one is in contraposition to the first—for death is what he says to be carnally minded is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:246
verses.text: And the other in contraposition to the following.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:247
verses.text: For after mentioning peace, he goes on,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:248
verses.text: "Because the carnal mind is enmity against God:" and this is worse than death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:249
verses.text: Then to show how it is at once death and enmity; "for it is not subject to the Law of God," he says, "neither indeed can be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:250
verses.text: But be not troubled at hearing the "neither indeed can be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:251
verses.text: For this difficulty admits of an easy solution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:252
verses.text: For what he here names "carnal mindedness" is the reasoning (or "way of thinking," λογισμὸν) that is earthly, gross, and eager-hearted after the things of this life and its wicked doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:253
verses.text: It is of this he says "neither yet can" it "be subject" to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:254
verses.text: And what hope of salvation is there left, if it be impossible for one who is bad to become good? This is not what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:255
verses.text: Else how would Paul have become such as he was? how would the (penitent) thief, or Manasses, or the Ninevites, or how would David after falling have recovered himself? How would Peter after the denial have raised himself up? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:256
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:257
verses.text: ) How could he that had lived in fornication have been enlisted among Christ's fold? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:258
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:259
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:260
verses.text: ) How could the Galatians who had "fallen from grace" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:261
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:262
verses.text: ), have attained their former dignity again? What he says then is not that it is impossible for a man that is wicked to become good, but that it is impossible for one who continues wicked to be subject to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:263
verses.text: Yet for a man to be changed, and so become good, and subject to Him, is easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:264
verses.text: For he does not say that man cannot be subject to God, but, wicked doing cannot be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:265
verses.text: As if he had said, fornication cannot be chastity, nor vice virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:266
verses.text: And this it says in the Gospel also, "A corrupt tree cannot bring forth good fruit" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:267
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:268
verses.text: ), not to bar the change from virtue to vice, but to say how incapable continuance in vice is of bringing forth good fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:269
verses.text: For He does not say that an evil tree cannot become a good one, but that bring forth good fruit it cannot, while it continues evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:270
verses.text: For that it can be changed, He shows from this passage, and from another parable, when He introduces the tares as becoming wheat, on which score also He forbids their being rooted up; "Lest," He says, "ye root up also the wheat with them" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:271
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:272
verses.text: ); that is, that which will spring (γίνεσθαι,  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:273
verses.text: τίκτεσθαι) from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:274
verses.text: It is vice then he means by carnal mindedness, and by spiritual mindedness the grace given, and the working of it discernible in the right determination of mind, not discussing in any part of this passage, a substance and an entity, but virtue and vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:275
verses.text: For that which thou hadst no power to do under the Law, now, he means, thou wilt be able to do, to go on uprightly, and with no intervening fall, if thou layest hold of the Spirit's aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:276
verses.text: For it is not enough not to walk after the flesh, but we must also go after the Spirit, since turning away from what is evil will not secure our salvation, but we must also do what is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:277
verses.text: And this will come about, if we give our souls up to the Spirit, and persuade our flesh to get acquainted with its proper position, for in this way we shall make it also spiritual; as also if we be listless we shall make our soul carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:278
verses.text: For since it was no natural necessity which put the gift into us, but the freedom of choice placed it in our hands, it rests with thee henceforward whether this shall be or the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:279
verses.text: For He, on His part, has performed everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:280
verses.text: For sin no longer warreth against the law of our mind, neither doth it lead us away captive as heretofore, for all that state has been ended and broken up, and the affections cower in fear and trembling at the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:281
verses.text: But if thou wilt quench the light, and cast out the holder of the reins, and chase the helmsman away, then charge the tossing thenceforth upon thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:282
verses.text: For since virtue hath been now made an easier thing (for which cause also we are under far stricter obligations of religious living), consider how men's condition lay when the Law prevailed, and how at present, since grace hath shone forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:283
verses.text: The things which aforetime seemed not possible to any one, virginity, and contempt of death, and of other stronger sufferings, are now in full vigor through every part of the world, and it is not with us alone, but with the Scythians, and Thracians, and Indians, and Persians, and several other barbarous nations, that there are companies of virgins, and clans of martyrs, and congregations of monks, and these now grown even more numerous than the married, and strictness of fasting, and the utmost renunciation of property.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:284
verses.text: Now these are things which, with one or two exceptions, persons who lived under the Law never conceived even in a dream.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:285
verses.text: Since thou seest then the real state of things voiced with a shriller note than any trumpet, let not thyself grow soft and treacherous to so great a grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:286
verses.text: Since not even after the faith is it possible for a listless man to be saved! For the wrestlings are made easy that thou mayest strive and conquer, nor that thou shouldest sleep, or abuse the greatness of the grace by making it a reason for listlessness, so wallowing again in the former mire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:287
verses.text: And so he goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:288
verses.text: "So then they that are in the flesh cannot please God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:289
verses.text: What then? Are we, it will be said, to cut our bodies in pieces to please God, and to make our escape from the flesh? and would you have us be homicides, and so lead us to virtue? You see what inconsistencies are gendered by taking the words literally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:290
verses.text: For by "the flesh" in this passage, he does not mean the body, or the essence of the body, but that life which is fleshly and worldly, and uses self-indulgence and extravagance to the full, so making the entire man flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:291
verses.text: For as they that have the wings of the Spirit, make the body also spiritual, so do they who bound off from this, and are the slaves of the belly, and of pleasure, make the soul also flesh, not that they change the essence of it, but that they mar its noble birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:292
verses.text: And this mode of speaking is to be met with in many parts of the Old Testament also, to signify by flesh the gross and earthly life, which is entangled in pleasures that are not convenient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:293
verses.text: For to Noah He says, "My Spirit shall not always make its abode in these men, because they are flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:294
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:295
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:296
verses.text: as the LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:297
verses.text: give it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:298
verses.text: ) And yet Noah was himself also compassed about with flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:299
verses.text: But this is not the complaint, the being compassed about with the flesh, for this is so by nature, but the having chosen a carnal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:300
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul saith, "But they that are in the flesh cannot please God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:301
verses.text: Then he proceeds:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:302
verses.text: "But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:303
verses.text: Here again, he does not mean flesh absolutely, but such sort of flesh, that which was in a whirl and thraldom of passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:304
verses.text: Why then, it may be said, does he not say so, nor state any difference? It is to rouse the hearer, and to show that he that liveth aright is not even in the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:305
verses.text: For inasmuch as it was in a manner clear to every one that the spiritual man was not in sin, he states the greater truth that it was not in sin alone, that the spiritual man was not, but not even in the flesh was he henceforward, having become from that very moment an Angel, and ascended into heaven, and henceforward barely carrying the body about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:306
verses.text: Now if this be thy reason for disparaging the flesh, because it is by its name that he calls the fleshly life, at this rate you are also for disparaging the world, because wickedness is often called after it, as Christ also said to His disciples, "Ye are not of this world;" and again to His brethren, He says, "The world cannot hate you, but me it hateth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:307
verses.text: (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:308
verses.text: ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:309
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:310
verses.text: ) And the soul too Paul must afterwards be calling estranged from God, since to those that live in error, he gives the name of men of the soul ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:311
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:312
verses.text: , ψυχικὸς A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:313
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:314
verses.text: natural).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:315
verses.text: But this is not so, indeed it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:316
verses.text: For we are not to look to the bare words, but always to the sentiment of the speaker, and so come to a perfectly distinct knowledge of what is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:317
verses.text: For some things are good, some bad, and some indifferent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:318
verses.text: Thus the soul and the flesh belong to things indifferent, since each may become either the one or the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:319
verses.text: But the spirit belongs to things good, and at no time becometh any other thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:320
verses.text: Again, the mind of the flesh, that is, ill-doing, belongs to things always bad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:321
verses.text: "For it is not subject to the law of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:322
verses.text: If then thou yieldest thy soul and body to the better, thou wilt have become of its part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:323
verses.text: If on the other hand thou yield to the worse, then art thou made a partaker of the ruin therein, not owing to the nature of the soul and the flesh, but owing to that judgment which has the power of choosing either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:324
verses.text: And to show that these things are so, and that the words do not disparage the flesh, let us take up the phrase itself again, and sift it more thoroughly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:325
verses.text: "But ye are not in the flesh but in the Spirit," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:326
verses.text: What then? were they not in the flesh, and did they go about without any bodies? What sense would this be? You see that it is the carnal life that he intimates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:327
verses.text: And why did he not say, But ye are not in sin? It is that you may come to know that Christ hath not extinguished the tyranny of sin only, but hath even made the flesh to weigh us down less, and to be more spiritual, not by changing its nature, but rather by giving it wings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:328
verses.text: For as when fire cometh in company with iron, the iron also becomes fire, though abiding in its own nature still; thus with them that believe, and have the Spirit, the flesh henceforth goeth over into that manner of working, and becometh wholly spiritual, crucified in all parts, and flying with the same wings as the soul, such as was the body of him who here speaks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:329
verses.text: Wherefore all self-indulgence and pleasure he made scorn of, and found his self-indulgence in hunger, and stripes, and prisons, and did not even feel pain in undergoing them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:330
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:331
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:332
verses.text: ) And it was to show this that he said, "For our light affliction, which is but for a moment," etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:333
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:334
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:335
verses.text: ) So well had he tutored even the flesh to be in harmony with the spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:336
verses.text: "If so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you" (εἴπερ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:337
verses.text: ) He often uses this "if so be," not to express any doubt, but even when he is quite persuaded of the thing, and instead of "since," as when he says, "If it is a righteous thing," for "seeing it is a righteous thing with God to recompense tribulation to them that trouble you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:338
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:339
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:340
verses.text: ) Again, "Have ye suffered so many things in vain, if it be yet in vain?" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:341
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:342
verses.text: )  "Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:343
verses.text: He does not say, if ye have not, but he brings forward the distressing word, as applied to other persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:344
verses.text: "He is none of His," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:345
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:346
verses.text: "And if Christ be in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:347
verses.text: Again, what is good he applies to them, and the distressing part was short and parenthetic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:348
verses.text: And that which is an object of desire, is on either side of it, and put at length too, so as to throw the other into shade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:349
verses.text: Now this he says, not as affirming that the Spirit is Christ, far from it, but to show that he who hath the Spirit not only is called Christ's, but even hath Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:350
verses.text: For it cannot but be that where the Spirit is, there Christ is also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:351
verses.text: For wheresoever one Person of the Trinity is, there the whole Trinity is present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:352
verses.text: For It is undivided in Itself, and hath a most entire Oneness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:353
verses.text: What then, it may be said, will happen, if Christ be in us? "The body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:354
verses.text: You see the great evils that come of not having the Holy Spirit; death, enmity against God, inability to satisfy His laws, not being Christ's as we should be, the want of His indwelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:355
verses.text: Consider now also what great blessings come of having the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:356
verses.text: Being Christ's, having Christ himself, vying with the Angels (for this is what mortifying the flesh is), and living an immortal life, holding henceforward the earnests of the Resurrection, running with ease the race of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:357
verses.text: For he does not say so little as that the body is henceforward inactive for sin, but that it is even dead, so magnifying the ease of the race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:358
verses.text: For such an one without troubles and labors gains the crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:359
verses.text: Then afterward for this reason he adds also, "to sin," that you may see that it is the viciousness, not the essence of the body, that He hath abolished at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:360
verses.text: For if the latter had been done, many things even of a kind to be beneficial to the soul would have been abolished also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:361
verses.text: This however is not what he says, but while it is yet alive and abiding, he contends, it is dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:362
verses.text: For this is the sign of our having the Son, of the Spirit being in us, that our bodies should be in no respect different from those that lie on the bier with respect to the working of sin (so the mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:363
verses.text: Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:364
verses.text: "of the body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:365
verses.text: The preceding words are slightly corrupt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:366
verses.text: ) But be not affrighted at hearing of mortifying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:367
verses.text: For in it you have what is really life, with no death to succeed it: and such is that of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:368
verses.text: It yieldeth not to death any more, but weareth out death and consumeth it, and that which it receiveth, it keepeth it immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:369
verses.text: And this is why after saying "the body is dead," he does not say, "but the Spirit 'liveth,'" but, "is life," to point out that He (the Spirit) had the power of giving this to others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:370
verses.text: Then again to brace up his hearer, he tells him the cause of the Life, and the proof of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:371
verses.text: Now this is righteousness; for where there is no sin, death is not to be seen either; but where death is not to be seen, life is indissoluble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:372
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:373
verses.text: "But if the Spirit of Him that raised up Jesus from the dead dwell in you, He that raised up our Lord shall also quicken your mortal bodies by His Spirit that dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:374
verses.text: Again, he touches the point of the Resurrection, since this was the most encouraging hope to the hearer, and gave him a security from what had happened unto Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:375
verses.text: Now be not thou afraid because thou art compassed about with a dead body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:376
verses.text: Let it have the Spirit, and it shall assuredly rise again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:377
verses.text: What then, shall the bodies which have not the Spirit not rise? How then must "all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:378
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:379
verses.text: ) or how will the account of hell be trustworthy? For if they that have not the Spirit rise not, there will not be a hell at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:380
verses.text: What then is it which is said? All shall rise, yet not all to life, but some to punishment and some to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:381
verses.text: (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:382
verses.text: ) This is why he did not say, shall raise up, but shall quicken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:383
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:384
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:385
verses.text: ) And this is a greater thing than resurrection, and is given to the just only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:386
verses.text: And the cause of this honor he adds in the words, "By His Spirit that dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:387
verses.text: And so if while here thou drive away the grace of the Spirit, and do not depart with it still safe, thou wilt assuredly perish, though thou dost rise again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:388
verses.text: For as He will not endure then, if He see His Spirit shining in thee, to give thee up to punishment, so neither will He allow them, if He see It quenched, to bring thee into the Bride-chamber, even as He admitted not those virgins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:389
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:390
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:391
verses.text: )  Suffer not thy body then to live in this world, that it may live then! Make it die, that it die not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:392
verses.text: For if it keep living, it will not live: but if it die, then shall it live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:393
verses.text: And this is the case with resurrection in general.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:394
verses.text: For it must die first and be buried, and then become immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:395
verses.text: But this has been done in the Font.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:396
verses.text: It has therefore had first its crucifixion and burial, and then been raised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:397
verses.text: This has also happened with the Lord's Body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:398
verses.text: For that also was crucified and buried ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:399
verses.text: died) and rose again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:400
verses.text: This then let us too be doing: let us keep continually mortifying it in its works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:401
verses.text: I do not mean in its substance—far be it from me—but in its inclinations towards evil doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:402
verses.text: For this is a life too, or rather this only is life, undergoing nothing that is common to man, nor being a slave to pleasures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:403
verses.text: For he who has set himself under the rule of these, has no power even to live through the low spirits, the fears, and the dangers, and the countless throng of ills, that rise from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:404
verses.text: For if death must be expected, he hath died, before death, of fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:405
verses.text: And if it be disease he dreads, or affront, or poverty, or any of the other ills one cannot anticipate, he is ruined and hath perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:406
verses.text: What then can be more miserable than a life of this sort? But far otherwise is he that liveth to the Spirit, for he stands at once above fears and grief and dangers and every kind of change: and that not by undergoing no such thing, but, what is much greater, by thinking scorn of them when they assail him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:407
verses.text: And how is this to be? It will be if the Spirit dwell in us continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:408
verses.text: For he does not speak of any short stay made thereby, but of a continual indwelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:409
verses.text: Hence he does not say "the Spirit which" dwelt, but "which dwelleth in us," so pointing to a continual abiding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:410
verses.text: He then is most truly alive, who is dead to this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:411
verses.text: Hence he says, "The Spirit is life because of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:412
verses.text: And to make the thing clearer, let me bring before you two men, one who is given up to extravagances and pleasures, and the deceitfulness of this life; and the other made dead to all these; and let us see which is more really the living one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:413
verses.text: For let one of these two be very rich and much looked up to, keeping parasites and flatterers, and let us suppose him to spend the whole day upon this, in revelling and drunkenness: and let the other live in poverty, and fasting, and hard fare, and strict rules (φιλοσοφί& ·), and at evening partake of necessary food only; or if you will let him even pass two or three days without food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:414
verses.text: Which then of these two think we ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:415
verses.text: you) is most really alive? Men in general will, I know, reckon the former so, the man that takes his pleasure (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:416
verses.text: σκιρτὥντα, mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:417
verses.text: τρυφὥντα) and squanders his goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:418
verses.text: But we reckon the man that enjoys the moderate fare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:419
verses.text: Now then since it is still a subject of contest and opposition let us go into the houses of them both, and just at the very time too when in your judgment the rich man is living in truest sense, in the very season of self-indulgence, and when we have got in, let us look and see the real condition of each of these men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:420
verses.text: For it is from the actions that it appears which is alive and which dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:421
verses.text: Shall we not find the one among his books, or in prayer and fasting, or some other necessary duty, awake and sober, and conversing with God? but the other we shall see stupid in drunkenness, and in no better condition than a dead man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:422
verses.text: And if we wait till the evening, we shall see this death coming upon him more and more, and then sleep again succeeding to that: but the other we shall see even in the night keeping from wine and sleep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:423
verses.text: Which then shall we pronounce to be most alive, the man that lies in a state of insensibility, and is an open laughing-stock to everybody? or the man that is active, and conversing with God? For if you go up to the one, and tell him something he ought to know, you will not hear him say a word, any more than a dead man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:424
verses.text: But the latter, whether you choose to be in his company at night or by day, you will see to be an angel rather than a man, and will hear him speak wisdom about things in Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:425
verses.text: Do you see how one of them is alive above all men living, and the other in a more pitiable plight even than the dead? And even if he have a mind to stir he sees one thing instead of another, and is like people that are mad, or rather is in a worse plight even than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:426
verses.text: For if any one were to do them any harm, we should at once feel pity for the sufferer, and rebuke the doer of the wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:427
verses.text: But this man, if we were to see a person trample on him, we should not only be disinclined to pity, but should even give judgment against him, now that he was fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:428
verses.text: And will you tell me this is life, and not a harder lot than deaths unnumbered? So you see the self-indulgent man is not only dead, but worse than dead, and more miserable than a man possessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:429
verses.text: For the one is the object of pity, the other of hatred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:430
verses.text: And the one has allowance made him, the other suffers punishment for his madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:431
verses.text: But if externally he is so ridiculous, as having his saliva tainted, and his breath stinking of wine, just consider what case his wretched soul, inhumed as it were in a grave, in such a body as this, is probably in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:432
verses.text: For one may look upon this as much the same as if one were to permit a damsel, comely, chaste, free-born, of good family, and handsome, to be trampled on, and every way insulted by a serving woman, that was savage, and disgustful, and impure; drunkenness being something of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:433
verses.text: And who, being in his senses, would not choose to die a thousand deaths, rather than live a single day in this way? For even if at daylight he were to get up, and seem to be sober from that revelling (or absurd show, κωμῳδίας,  ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:434
verses.text: κώμου) of his, still even then it is not the clear brightness of temperance which he enjoys, since the cloud from the storm of drunkenness still is hanging before his eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:435
verses.text: And even if we were to grant him the clearness of sobriety, what were he the better? For this soberness would be of no service to him, except to let him see his accusers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:436
verses.text: For when he is in the midst of his unseemly deeds, he is so far a gainer in not perceiving those that laugh at him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:437
verses.text: But when it is day he loses this comfort even, and while his servants are murmuring, and his wife is ashamed, and his friends accuse him, and his enemies make sport of him, he knows it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:438
verses.text: What can be more miserable than a life like this, to be laughed at all day by everybody, and when it is evening to do the same unseemly things afresh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:439
verses.text: But what if you would let me put the covetous before you? For this is another, and even a worse intoxication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:440
verses.text: But if it be an intoxication, then it must be a worse death by far than the former, since the intoxication is more grievous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:441
verses.text: And indeed it is not so sad to be drunk with wine as with covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:442
verses.text: For in the former case, the penalty ends with the sufferings (several ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:443
verses.text: "sufferer,") and results in insensibility, and the drunkard's own ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:444
verses.text: But in this case the mischief passes on to thousands of souls, and kindles wars of sundry kinds upon all sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:445
verses.text: Come then and let us put this beside the other, and let us see what are the points they have in common, and in what again this is worse than it, and let us make a comparison of drunkards to-day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:446
verses.text: For with that blissful man, who liveth to the Spirit, let them not be put at all in comparison, but only tried by one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:447
verses.text: And again, let us bring the money-table before you, laden as it is with blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:448
verses.text: What then have they in common, and in what are they like each other? It is in the very nature of the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:449
verses.text: For the species of drunkenness is different, as one comes of wine, the other of money, but its way of affecting them is similar, both being alike possessed with an exorbitant desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:450
verses.text: For he who is drunken with wine, the more glasses he has drunk off, the more he longs for; and he that is in love with money, the more he compasses, the more he kindles the flame of desire, and the more importunate he renders his thirst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:451
verses.text: In this point then they resemble each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:452
verses.text: But in another the covetous man has the advantage (in a bad sense).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:453
verses.text: Now what is this? Why that the other's affection is a natural one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:454
verses.text: For the wine is hot, and adds to one's natural drought, and so makes drunkards thirsty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:455
verses.text: But what is there to make the other man always keep desiring more? how comes it that when he is increased in riches, then he is in the veriest poverty? This complaint then is a perplexing one, and has more of paradox about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:456
verses.text: But if you please, we will take a view of them after the drunkenness also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:457
verses.text: Or rather, there is no such thing as ever seeing the covetous man after his drunkenness, so continual a state of intoxication is he in! Let us then view them both in the state of drunkenness, and let us get a distinct notion which is the most ridiculous, and let us again figure to ourselves a correct sketch of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:458
verses.text: We shall see then the man who dotes with his wine at eventide with his eyes open, seeing no one, but moving about at mere hap-hazard, and stumbling against such as fall in his way, and spewing, and convulsed, and exposing his nakedness in an unseemly manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:459
verses.text: (See Habak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:460
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:461
verses.text: ) And if his wife be there, or his daughter, or his maid-servant, or anybody else, they will laugh at him heartily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:462
verses.text: And now let us bring before you the covetous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:463
verses.text: Here what happens is not deserving of laughter only, but even of a curse, and exceeding wrath, and thunderbolts without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:464
verses.text: At present however let us look at the ridiculous part, for this man as well as the other has an ignorance of all, whether friend or foe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:465
verses.text: And like him too, though his eyes are open, he is blinded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:466
verses.text: And as the former takes all he sees for wine, so does this man take all for money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:467
verses.text: And his spewing is even more disgusting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:468
verses.text: For it is not food that he vomits, but words of abuse, of insolence, of war, of death, that draws upon his own head lightnings without number from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:469
verses.text: And as the body of the drunkard is livid and dissolving, so also is the other's soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:470
verses.text: Or rather, even his body is not free from this disorder, but it is taken even worse, care eating it away worse than wine does (as do anger too and want of sleep), and by degrees exhausting it entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:471
verses.text: And he that is seized with illness from wine, after the night is over may get sober.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:472
verses.text: But this person is always drunken day and night, watching or sleeping, so paying a severer penalty for it than any prisoner, or person at work in the mines, or suffering any punishment more grievous than this, if such there be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:473
verses.text: Is it then life pray, and not death? or rather, is it not a fate more wretched than any death? For death gives the body rest, and sets it free from ridicule, as well as disgrace and sins: but these drunken fits plunge it into all these, stopping up the ears, dulling the eyesight, keeping down the understanding in great darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:474
verses.text: For it will not bear the mention of anything but interest, and interest upon interest, and shameful gains, and odious traffickings, and ungentlemanly and slavelike transactions, barking like a dog at everybody, and hating everybody, averse to everybody, at war with everybody, without any reason for it, rising up against the poor, grudging at the rich, and civil to nobody.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:475
verses.text: And if he have a wife, or children, or friends, if he may not use them all towards getting gain, these are to him more his enemies than natural enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:476
verses.text: What then can be worse than madness of this sort, and what more wretched? when a man is preparing rocks for his own self on every side, and shoals, and precipices, and gulfs, and pits without number, while he has but one body, and is the slave of one belly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:477
verses.text: And if any thrust thee into a state office, thou wilt be a runaway, through fear of expense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:478
verses.text: Yet to thyself thou art laying up countless charges far more distressing than those, enlisting thyself for services not only more expensive, but also more dangerous, to be done for mammon, and not paying this tyrant a money contribution only, nor of bodily labor, torture to the soul, and grief, but even of thy blood itself, that thou mayest have some addition to thy property (miserable and sorrow-stricken man!) out of this barbarous slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:479
verses.text: Do you not see those who are taken day by day to the grave, how they are carried to tombs naked and destitute of all things, unable to take with them aught that is in the house, but bearing what clothes they have about them to the worm? Consider these day by day, and perchance the malady will abate, unless you mean even by such an occasion to be still more mad at the expensiveness of the funeral rites—for the malady is importunate, the disease terrible! This then is why we address you upon this subject at every meeting, and constantly foment your hearing, that at all events by your growing accustomed to such thoughts, some good many come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:480
verses.text: But be not contentious, for it is not only at the Day to come, but even before it, that this manifold malady brings with it sundry punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:481
verses.text: For if I were to tell you of those who pass their days in chains, or of one nailed to a lingering disease, or of one struggling with famine, or of any other thing whatsoever, I could point out no one who suffers so much as they do who love money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:482
verses.text: For what severer evil can befall one, than being hated by all men, than hating all men, than not having kindly feeling towards any, than being never satisfied, than being in a continual thirst, than struggling with a perpetual hunger, and that a more distressing one than what all men esteem such? than having pains day by day, than being never sober, than being continually in worries and harasses? For all these things, and more than these, are what the covetous set their shoulder to; in the midst of their gaining having no perception of pleasure, though scraping to themselves from all men, because of their desiring more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:483
verses.text: But in the case of their incurring a loss, if it be but of a farthing, they think they have suffered most grievously, and have been cast out of life itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:484
verses.text: What language then can put these evils before you? And if their fate here be such, consider also what comes after this life, the being cast out of the kingdom, the pain that comes from hell, the perpetual chains, the outer darkness, the venomous worm, the gnashing of teeth, the affliction, the sore straitening, the rivers of fire, the furnaces that never get quenched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 14:485
verses.text: And gathering all these together, and weighing them against the pleasure of money, tear up now this disease root and branch, that so receiving the true riches, and being set free from this grievous poverty, thou mayest obtain the present blessings, and those to come, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:1
verses.text: Homily XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:3
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:4
verses.text: ,  "Therefore, brethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live after the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:5
verses.text: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die; but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:6
verses.text: After showing how great the reward of a spiritual life is, and that it maketh Christ to dwell in us, and that it quickeneth our mortal bodies, and wingeth them to heaven, and rendereth the way of virtue easier, he next fitly introduces an exhortation to this purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:7
verses.text: "Therefore" we ought "not to live after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:8
verses.text: But this is not what he says, for he words it in a much more striking and powerful way, thus, "we are debtors to the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:9
verses.text: For saying, "we are debtors not to the flesh," indicates this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:10
verses.text: And this is a point he is everywhere giving proof of, that what God hath done for us is not matter of debt, but of mere grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:11
verses.text: But after this, what we do is no longer matter of free-will offering, but of debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:12
verses.text: For when he saith, "Ye are bought with a price, be not ye the servants of men" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:13
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:14
verses.text: ); and when he writes, "Ye are not your own" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:15
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:16
verses.text: ); and again in another passage he calls these selfsame things to their mind, in these words, "If (most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:17
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:18
verses.text: "if") One died for all, then all died that they should not henceforth live unto themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:19
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:20
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:21
verses.text: ) And it is to establish this that he says here also, "We are debtors;" then since he said we are "not" debtors "to the flesh," lest you should again take him to be speaking against the nature of the flesh, he does not leave speaking, but proceeds, "to live after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:22
verses.text: For there are many things which we do owe it, as giving it food, warmth, and rest, medicine when out of health, clothing, and a thousand other attentions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:23
verses.text: To prevent your supposing then that it is this ministration he is for abrogating when he says, "We are not debtors to the flesh," he explains it by saying, "to live after the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:24
verses.text: For the care that I am for abrogating is, he means, that which leadeth to sin, as I should be for its having what is healing to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:25
verses.text: And this he shows further on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:26
verses.text: For when he says, "Make not provision for the flesh," he does not pause at this, but adds, "to fulfil the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:27
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:28
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:29
verses.text: ) And this instruction he gives us here also, meaning, Let it have attention shown it indeed, for we do owe it this, yet let us not live according to the flesh, that is, let us not make it the mistress of our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:30
verses.text: For it must be the follower, not the leader, and it is not it that must regulate our life, but the laws of the Spirit must it receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:31
verses.text: Having then defined this point, and having proved that we are debtors to the Spirit, to show next for what benefits it is that we are debtors, he does not speak of those past (a thing which serves as a most striking proof of his judgment), but those which were to come; although even the former were enough for the purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:32
verses.text: Yet still he does not set them down in the present case, or mention even those unspeakable blessings, but the things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:33
verses.text: For a benefit once for all conferred does not, for the most part, draw men on so much as one which is expected, and is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:34
verses.text: After adding this then, he first uses the pains and ills that come of living after the flesh, to put them in fear, in the following words; "For if ye live after the flesh ye shall die," so intimating to us that deathless death, punishment, and vengeance in hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:35
verses.text: Or rather if one were to look accurately into this, such an one is, even in this present life, dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:36
verses.text: And this we have made clear to you in the last discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:37
verses.text: "But if ye through the Spirit, do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:38
verses.text: You see that it is not the essence of the body whereof we are discoursing, but the deeds of the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:39
verses.text: For he does not say, "if ye through the Spirit do mortify" the essence "of the body," but "the deeds of" it, and these not all deeds, but such as are evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:40
verses.text: And this is plain in what follows: for if ye do this, "ye shall live," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:41
verses.text: And how is it in the nature of things for this to be, if it was all deeds that his language applied to? for seeing and hearing and speaking and walking are deeds of the body; and if we mortify these, we shall be so far from living, that we shall have to suffer the punishment of a manslayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:42
verses.text: What sort of deeds then does he mean us to mortify? Those which tend toward wickedness, those which go after vice, which there is no other way of mortifying save through the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:43
verses.text: For by killing yourself you may put an end to the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:44
verses.text: And this you have no right to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:45
verses.text: But to these (you can put an end) by the Spirit only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:46
verses.text: For if This be present, all the billows are laid low, and the passions cower under It, and nothing can exalt itself against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:47
verses.text: So you see how it is on things to come, as I said before, that he grounds his exhortations to us, and shows that we are debtors not owing to what has been already done only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:48
verses.text: For the advantage of the Spirit is not this only, that He hath set us free from our former sins, but that He rendereth us impregnable against future ones, and counts us worthy of the immortal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:49
verses.text: Then, to state another reward also, he proceeds:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:50
verses.text: "For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:51
verses.text: Now this is again a much greater honor than the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:52
verses.text: And this is why he does not say merely, As many as live by the Spirit of God, but, "as many as are led by the Spirit of God," to show that he would have Him use such power over our life as a pilot doth over a ship, or a charioteer over a pair of horses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:53
verses.text: And it is not the body only, but the soul itself too, that he is for setting under reins of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:54
verses.text: For he would not have even that independent, but place its authority also under the power of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:55
verses.text: For lest through a confidence in the Gift of the Font they should turn negligent of their conversation after it, he would say, that even supposing you receive baptism, yet if you are not minded to be "led by the Spirit" afterwards, you lose the dignity bestowed upon you, and the pre-eminence of your adoption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:56
verses.text: This is why he does not say, As many as have received the Spirit, but, "as many as are led by the Spirit," that is, as many as live up to this all their life long, "they are the sons of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:57
verses.text: Then since this dignity was given to the Jews also, for it says, "I said ye are Gods, and all of you children of the Most High" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:58
verses.text: lxxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:59
verses.text: ); and again, "I have nourished and brought up children" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:60
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:61
verses.text: ); and so, "Israel is My first-born" (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:62
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:63
verses.text: ); and Paul too says, "Whose is the adoption" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:64
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:65
verses.text: )—he next asserts the great difference between the latter and the former honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:66
verses.text: For though the names are the same, he means, still, the things are not the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:67
verses.text: And of these points he gives a clear demonstration, by introducing a comparison drawn both from the persons so advanced (κατορθούντων) and from what was given them, and from what was to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:68
verses.text: And first he shows what they of old had given them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:69
verses.text: What then was this? "A spirit of bondage:" and so he thus proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:70
verses.text: "For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:71
verses.text: Then not staying to mention that which stands in contradistinction to bondage, that is, the spirit of freedom, he has named what is far greater, that of adoption, through which he at the same time brings in the other, saying, "But ye have received the Spirit of adoption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:72
verses.text: But this is plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:73
verses.text: But what the spirit of bondage may be, is not so plain, and there is need of making it clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:74
verses.text: Now what he says is so far from being clear, that it is in fact very perplexing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:75
verses.text: For the people of the Jews did not receive the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:76
verses.text: What then is his meaning here? It is the letter he giveth this name to, for spiritual it was, and so he called the Law spiritual also, and the water from the Rock, and the Manna.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:77
verses.text: "For they did eat," he says, "of the same spiritual meat, and all drank of the same spiritual drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:78
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:79
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:80
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:81
verses.text: ) And to the Rock he gives this name, when he says, "For they drank of that spiritual Rock which followed them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:82
verses.text: Now it is because all the rites then wrought were above nature that he calls them spiritual, and not because those who then partook of them received the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:83
verses.text: And in what sense were those letters, letters of bondage? Set before yourself the whole dispensation, and then you will have a clear view of this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:84
verses.text: For recompenses were with them close at hand, and the reward followed forthwith, being at once proportionate, and like a kind of daily ration given to domestic servants, and terrors in abundance came to their height before their eyes, and their purifications concerned their bodies, and their continency extended but to their actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:85
verses.text: But with us it is not so, since the imagination even and the conscience getteth purged out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:86
verses.text: For He does not say, "Thou shalt do no murder," only, but even thou shalt not be angry: so too, it is not, "Thou shalt not commit adultery," but thou shalt not look unchastely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:87
verses.text: So that it is not to be from fear of present punishment, but out of desire towards Himself, that both our being habitually virtuous, and all our single good deeds are to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:88
verses.text: Neither doth he promise a land flowing with milk and honey, but maketh us joint-heir with the Only-Begotten, so making us by every means stand aloof from things present, and promising to give such things especially as are worth the acceptance of men made sons of God, nothing, that is, of a sensible kind or corporeal, but spiritual all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:89
verses.text: And so they, even if they had the name of sons, were but as slaves; but we as having been made free, have received the adoption, and are waiting for Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:90
verses.text: And with them He discoursed through the intervention of others, with us by Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:91
verses.text: And all that they did was through the impulse of fear, but the spiritual act through a coveting and a vehement desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:92
verses.text: And this they show by the fact of their overstepping the commandments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:93
verses.text: They, as hirelings and obstinate persons, so never left murmuring: but these do all for the pleasing of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:94
verses.text: So too they blasphemed when they had benefits done them: but we are thankful at being jeoparded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:95
verses.text: And if there be need of punishing both of us upon our sinning, even in this case the difference is great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:96
verses.text: For it is not on being stoned and branded and maimed by the priests, as they were, that we are brought round.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:97
verses.text: But it is enough for us to be cast out from our Father's table, and to be out of sight for certain days.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:98
verses.text: And with the Jews the honor of adoption was one of name only, but here the reality followed also, the cleansing of Baptism, the giving of the Spirit, the furnishing of the other blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:99
verses.text: And there are several other points besides, which go to show our high birth and their low condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:100
verses.text: After intimating all these then by speaking of the Spirit, and fear, and the adoption, he gives a fresh proof again of having the Spirit of adoption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:101
verses.text: Now what is this? That "we cry, Abba, Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:102
verses.text: And how great this is, the initiated know (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:103
verses.text: Cyr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:104
verses.text: Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:105
verses.text: Cat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:106
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:107
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:108
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:109
verses.text: ), being with good reason bidden to use this word first in the Prayer of the initiated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:110
verses.text: What then, it may be said, did not they also call God Father? Dost thou not hear Moses, when he says, "Thou desertedst the God that begot thee?" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:111
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:112
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:113
verses.text: ) Dost thou not hear Malachi reproaching them, and saying, that "one God formed you," and there is "one Father of you all?" (Mal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:114
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:115
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:116
verses.text: ) Still, if these words and others besides are used, we do not find them anywhere calling God by the name, or praying in this language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:117
verses.text: But we all, priests and laymen, rulers and ruled, are ordered to pray herein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:118
verses.text: And this is the first language we give utterance to, after those marvellous throes, and that strange and unusual mode of labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:119
verses.text: If in any other instances they so called Him, that was only of their own mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:120
verses.text: But those in the state of grace do it through being moved by the in-working of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:121
verses.text: For as there is a Spirit of Wisdom, after which they that were unwise became wise, and this discloses itself in their teaching: and a Spirit of Power there is, whereby the feeble raised up the dead, and drove out devils; a Spirit also of the gift of healing, and a Spirit of prophecy, and a Spirit of tongues, so also a Spirit of adoption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:122
verses.text: And as we know the Spirit of prophecy, in that he who hath it foretelleth things to come, not speaking of his own mind, but moved by the Grace; so too is the Spirit of adoption, whereby he that is gifted with it calleth God, Father, as moved by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:123
verses.text: Wishing to express this as a most true descent, he used also the Hebrew tongue, for he does not say only, "Father," but "Abba, Father," which name is a special sign of true-born children to their fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:124
verses.text: After mentioning then the diversity resulting from their conversation, that resulting from the grace which had been given, and that from their freedom, he brings forward another demonstration of the superiority which goes with this adoption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:125
verses.text: Now of what kind is this?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:126
verses.text: "The Spirit Itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:127
verses.text: For it is not from the language merely, he says, that I make my assertion, but from the cause out of which the language has its birth; since it is from the Spirit suggesting it that we so speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:128
verses.text: And this in another passage he has put into plainer words, thus: "God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into our hearts, crying, Abba Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:129
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:130
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:131
verses.text: ) And what is that, "Spirit beareth witness with spirit?" The Comforter, he means, with that Gift, which is given unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:132
verses.text: For it is not of the Gift alone that it is the voice, but of the Comforter also who gave the Gift, He Himself having taught us through the Gift so to speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:133
verses.text: But when the "Spirit beareth witness" what farther place for doubtfulness? For if it were a man, or angel, or archangel, or any other such power that promised this, then there might be reason in some doubting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:134
verses.text: But when it is the Highest Essence that bestoweth this Gift, and "beareth witness" by the very words He bade us use in prayer, who would doubt any more of our dignity? For not even when the Emperor elects any one, and proclaims in all men's hearing the honor done him, does anybody venture to gainsay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:136
verses.text: "And if children, then heirs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:137
verses.text: Observe how he enhances the Gift by little and little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:138
verses.text: For since it is a possible case to be children, and yet not become heirs (for it is not by any means all children that are heirs), he adds this besides—that we are heirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:139
verses.text: But the Jews, besides their not having the same adoption as we, were also cast out from the inheritance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:140
verses.text: For "He will miserably destroy those wicked men, and will let out the vineyard to other husbandmen" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:141
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:142
verses.text: ): and before this, He said that "many shall come from the East and from the West, and shall sit down with Abraham, but the children of the Kingdom shall be cast out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:143
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:144
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:145
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:146
verses.text: ) But even here he does not pause, but sets down something even greater than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:147
verses.text: What may this be then? That we are heirs of God; and so he adds, "heirs of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:148
verses.text: And what is more still, that we are not simply heirs, but also "joints heirs with Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:149
verses.text: Observe how ambitious he is of bringing us near to the Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:150
verses.text: For since it is not all children that are heirs, he shows that we are both children and heirs; next, as it is not all heirs that are heirs to any great amount, he shows that we have this point with us too, as we are heirs of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:151
verses.text: Again, since it were possible to be God's heir, but in no sense "joint heir with" the Only-Begotten, he shows that we have this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:152
verses.text: And consider his wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:153
