verses.text: For after throwing the distasteful part into a short compass, when he was saying what was to become of such as "live after the flesh," for instance, that they "shall die," when he comes to the more soothing part, he leadeth forth his discourse into a large room, and so expands it on the recompense of rewards, and in pointing out that the gifts too are manifold and great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:154
verses.text: For if even the being a child were a grace unspeakable, just think how great a thing it is to be heir! But if this be great, much more is it to be "joint heir".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:155
verses.text: Then to show that the Gift is not of grace only, and to give at the same time a credibility to what he says, he proceeds, "If so be that we suffer with Him, that we may be also glorified together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:156
verses.text: If, he would say, we be sharers with Him in what is painful, much more shall it be so in what is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:157
verses.text: For He who bestowed such blessings upon those who had wrought no good, how, when He seeth them laboring and suffering so much, shall he do else than give them greater requital? Having then shown that the thing was a matter of return, to make men give credit to what was said, and prevent any from doubting, he shows further that it has the virtue of a gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:158
verses.text: The one he showed, that what was said might gain credit even with those that doubted, and that the receivers of it might not feel ashamed as being evermore receiving salvation for nought; and the other, that you might see that God outdoeth the toils by His recompenses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:159
verses.text: And the one he has shown in the words, "If so be that we suffer with Him, that we may be also glorified together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:160
verses.text: But the other in proceeding to add;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:161
verses.text: "The sufferings of the present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:162
verses.text: εἰς) us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:163
verses.text: In what went before, he requires of the spiritual man the correcting of his habits (Mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:164
verses.text: and  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:165
verses.text: passions), where he says, "Ye are not debtors to live after the flesh," that such an one, for instance, should be above lust, anger, money, vainglory, grudging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:166
verses.text: But here having reminded them of the whole gift, both as given and as to come, and raised him up aloft with hopes, and placed him near to Christ, and showed him to be a joint-heir of the Only-Begotten; he now leads him forth with confidence even to dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:167
verses.text: For to get the better of the evil affections in us, is not the same thing with bearing up under those trials, scourges, famine, plunderings, bonds, chains, executions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:168
verses.text: For these last required much more of a noble and vigorous spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:169
verses.text: And observe how he at once allays and rouses the spirit of the combatants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:170
verses.text: For after he had shown that the rewards were greater than the labors, he both exhorts to greater efforts, and yet will not let them be elated, as being still outdone by the crowns given in requital.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:171
verses.text: And in another passage he says, "For our light affliction, which is but for a moment, worketh a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:172
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:173
verses.text: ): it being the deeper sort of persons he was then speaking to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:174
verses.text: Here, however, he does not allow that the afflictions were light; but still he mingles comfort with them by the compensation which good things to come afford, in the words, "For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared," and he does not say, with the rest (ἄνεσιν) that is to come, but what is much greater, "with the glory which is to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:175
verses.text: For it does not follow, that where rest is there is glory; but that where glory is there is rest, does follow: then as he had said that it is to come, he shows that it already is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:176
verses.text: For he does not say, that which is to be, but "which shall be revealed in us," as if already existing but unrevealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:177
verses.text: As also in another place he said in clearer words, "Our life is hid with Christ in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:178
verses.text: Be then of a good heart about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:179
verses.text: For already hath it been prepared, and awaiteth thy labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:180
verses.text: But if it vexes you that it is yet to come, rather let this very thing rejoice you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:181
verses.text: For it is owing to its being great and unutterable, and transcending our present condition, that it is stored up there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:182
verses.text: And so he has not put barely "the sufferings of this present time," but he speaks so as to show that it is not in quality only, but in quantity also, that the other life has the advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:183
verses.text: For these sufferings, whatever they are, are attached to our present life; but the blessings to come reach themselves out over ages without end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:184
verses.text: And since he had no way of giving a particular description of these, or of putting them before us in language, he gives them a name from what seems to be specially an object of desire with us, "glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:185
verses.text: For the summit of blessings and the sum of them, this seems to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:186
verses.text: And to urge the hearer on in another way also, he gives a loftiness to his discourse by the mention of the creation, gaining two points by what he is next saying, the contempt of things present, and the desire of things to come, and a third beside these, or rather the first, is the showing how the human race is cared for on God's part and in what honor He holds our nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:187
verses.text: And besides this, all the doctrines of the philosophers, which they had framed for themselves about this world, as a sort of cobweb or child's mound, he throws down with this one doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:188
verses.text: But that these things may stand in a clearer light, let us hear the Apostle's own language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:189
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:190
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:191
verses.text: "For the earnest expectation of the creation waiteth," he says, "for the revelation of the sons of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:192
verses.text: For the creation was made subject to vanity, not willingly, but by reason of him who hath subjected the same in hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:193
verses.text: And the meaning is something of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:194
verses.text: The creation itself is in the midst of its pangs, waiting for and expecting these good things whereof we have just now spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:195
verses.text: For "earnest expectation" (ἀποκαραδοκία, looking out) implies expecting intensely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:196
verses.text: And so his discourse becomes more emphatic, and he personifies this whole world as the prophets also do, when they introduce the floods clapping their hands, and little hills leaping, and mountains skipping, not that we are to fancy them alive, or ascribe any reasoning power to them, but that we may learn the greatness of the blessings, so great as to reach even to things without sense also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:197
verses.text: The very same thing they do many times also in the case of afflicting things, since they bring in the vine lamenting, and the wine too, and the mountains, and the boardings of the Temple howling, and in this case too it is that we may understand the extremity of the evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:198
verses.text: It is then in imitation of these that the Apostle makes a living person of the creature here, and says that it groaneth and travaileth: not that he heard any groan conveyed from the earth and heaven to him, but that he might show the exceeding greatness of the good things to come; and the desire of freedom from the ills which now pervaded them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:199
verses.text: "For the creature was made subject to vanity, not willingly, but by reason of him who hath subjected the same".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:200
verses.text: What is the meaning of, "the creation was made subject to vanity?" Why that it became corruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:201
verses.text: For what cause, and on what account? On account of thee, O man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:202
verses.text: For since thou hast taken a body mortal and liable to suffering, the earth too hath received a curse, and brought forth thorns and thistles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:203
verses.text: But that the heaven, when it is waxen old along with the earth, is to change afterwards to a better portion (λἥξιν v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:204
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:205
verses.text: ) hear from the Prophet in his words; "Thou, O Lord, from the beginning hast founded the earth, and the heavens are the work of Thy hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:206
verses.text: They shall perish, but thou shalt endure; and they all shall wax old as doth a garment, and as a cloak shalt Thou fold them up, and they shall be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:207
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:208
verses.text: cii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:209
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:210
verses.text: ) Isaiah too declares the same, when he says, "Look to the heaven above, and upon the earth beneath, for the heavens are as a firmament of smoke, and the earth shall wax old like a garment, and they that dwell therein shall perish in like manner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:211
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:212
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:213
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:214
verses.text: Now you see in what sense the creation is "in bondage to vanity," and how it is to be freed from the ruined state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:215
verses.text: For the one says, "Thou shalt fold them up as a garment, and they shall be changed;" and Isaiah says, "and they that dwell therein shall perish in like manner," not of course meaning an utter perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:216
verses.text: For neither do they that dwell therein, mankind, that is, undergo such an one, but a temporary one, and through it they are changed into an incorruptible ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:217
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:218
verses.text: ) state, and so therefore will the creature be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:219
verses.text: And all this he showed by the way, by his saying "in like manner" ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:220
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:221
verses.text: ), which Paul also says farther on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:222
verses.text: At present, however, he speaks about the bondage itself, and shows for what reason it became such, and gives ourselves as the cause of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:223
verses.text: What then? Was it harshly treated on another's account? By no means, for it was on my account that it was made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:224
verses.text: What wrong then is done it, which was made for my sake, when it suffereth these things for my correction? Or, indeed, one has no need to moot the question of right and wrong at all in the case of things void of soul and feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:225
verses.text: But Paul, since he had made it a living person, makes use of none of these topics I have mentioned, but another kind of language, as desiring to comfort the hearer with the utmost advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:226
verses.text: And of what kind is this? What have you to say? he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:227
verses.text: It was evil intreated for thy sake, and became corruptible; yet it has had no wrong done it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:228
verses.text: For incorruptible will it be for thy sake again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:229
verses.text: This then is the meaning of "in hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:230
verses.text: But when he says, it was "not willingly" that it was made subject, it is not to show that it is possessed of judgment that he says so, but that you may learn that the whole is brought about by Christ's care, and this is no achievement of its own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:231
verses.text: And now say in what hope?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:232
verses.text: "That the creature itself also shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:233
verses.text: Now what is this creation? Not thyself alone, but that also which is thy inferior, and partaketh not of reason or sense, this too shall be a sharer in thy blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:234
verses.text: For "it shall be freed," he says, "from the bondage of corruption," that is, it shall no longer be corruptible, but shall go along with the beauty given to thy body; just as when this became corruptible, that became corruptible also; so now it is made incorruptible, that also shall follow it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:235
verses.text: And to show this he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:236
verses.text: (εἰς) "Into the glorious liberty of the children of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:237
verses.text: That is, because of their liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:238
verses.text: For as a nurse who is bringing up a king's child, when he has come to his father's power, does herself enjoy the good things along with him, thus also is the creation, he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:239
verses.text: You see how in all respects man takes the lead, and that it is for his sake that all things are made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:240
verses.text: See how he solaces the struggler, and shows the unspeakable love of God toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:241
verses.text: For why, he would say, dost thou fret at thy temptations? thou art suffering for thyself, the creation for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:242
verses.text: Nor does he solace only, but also shows what he says to be trustworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:243
verses.text: For if the creation which was made entirely for thee is "in hope," much more oughtest thou to be, through whom the creation is to come to the enjoyment of those good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:244
verses.text: Thus men ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:245
verses.text: fathers) also when a son is to appear at his coming to a dignity, clothe even the servants with a brighter garment, to the glory of the son; so will God also clothe the creature with incorruption for the glorious liberty of the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:246
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:247
verses.text: "For we know that the whole creation groaneth and travaileth in pain together until now".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:248
verses.text: Observe, how he shames the hearer, saying almost, Be not thou worse than the creation, neither find a pleasure in resting in things present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:249
verses.text: Not only ought we not to cling to them, but even to groan over the delay of our departure hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:250
verses.text: For if the creation doth this, much more oughtest thou to do so, honored with reason as thou art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:251
verses.text: But as this was not yet enough to force their attention, he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:252
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:253
verses.text: "And not only they, but ourselves also, which have the first-fruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:254
verses.text: That is, having had a taste of the things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:255
verses.text: For even if any should be quite stone hard, he means what has been given already is enough to raise him up, and draw him off from things present, and to wing him after things to come in two ways, both by the greatness of the things that are given, and by the fact that, great and numerous as they are, they are but first-fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:256
verses.text: For if the first-fruits be so great that we are thereby freed even from our sins, and attain to righteousness and sanctification, and that those of that time both drave out devils, and raised the dead by their shadow (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:257
verses.text: ), or garments (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:258
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:259
verses.text: ), consider how great the whole must be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:260
verses.text: And if the creation, devoid as it is of mind and reason, and though in ignorance of these things, yet groaneth, much more should we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:261
verses.text: Next, that he may give the heretics no handle, or seem to be disparaging our present world, we groan, he says, not as finding fault with the present system, but through a desire of those greater things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:262
verses.text: And this he shows in the words, "Waiting for the adoption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:263
verses.text: What dost thou say, let me hear? Thou didst insist on it at every turn, and didst cry aloud, that we were already made sons, and now dost thou place this good thing among hopes, writing that we must needs wait for it? Now it is to set this right by the sequel that he says, "to wit, the redemption of our body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:264
verses.text: That is, the perfect glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:265
verses.text: Our lot indeed is at present uncertainty to our last breath, since many of us that were sons have become dogs and prisoners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:266
verses.text: But if we decease with a good hope, then is the gift unmovable, and clearer, and greater, having no longer any change to fear from death and sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:267
verses.text: Then therefore will the grace be secure, when our body shall be freed from death and its countless ailments (or passions).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:268
verses.text: For this is full redemption (ἀπολύτρωσις), not a redemption only, but such, that we shall never again return to our former captivity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:269
verses.text: For that thou mayest not be perplexed at hearing so much of glory without getting any distinct knowledge of it, he partially exposes to thy view the things to come, setting before thee the change of thy body (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:270
verses.text: changing thy body), and along with it the change of the whole creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:271
verses.text: And this he has put in a clearer light in another passage, where he says, "Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto His glorious Body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:272
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:273
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:274
verses.text: ) And in another place again he writes and says, "But when this mortal shall have put on immortality, then shall be brought to pass the saying that is written, Death is swallowed up in victory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:275
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:276
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:277
verses.text: ) But to show, that with the corruption of the body the constitution of the things of this life will also come to an end, he wrote again elsewhere, "For the fashion of this world passeth away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:278
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:279
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:280
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:281
verses.text: "For we are saved by hope," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:282
verses.text: Now since he had dwelt upon the promise of the things to come, and this seemed to pain the weaker hearer, if the blessings are all matter of hope; after proving before that they are surer than things present and visible, and discoursing at large on the gifts already given, and showing that we have received the first fruits of those good things, lest we should seek our all in this world, and be traitors to the nobility that faith gives us, he says, "For we are (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:283
verses.text: were) saved by hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:284
verses.text: And this is about what he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:285
verses.text: We are not to seek our all in this life, but to have hope also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:286
verses.text: For this is the only gift that we brought in to God, believing Him in what He promised shall come, and it was by this way alone we were saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:287
verses.text: If then we lose this hope, we have lost all that was of our own contributing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:288
verses.text: For I put you this question, he would say, Wert thou not liable for countless sins? wert thou not in despair? wert thou not under sentence? were not all out of heart about thy salvation? What then saved thee? It was thy hoping in God alone, and trusting to Him about His promises and gifts, and nothing besides hadst thou to bring in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:289
verses.text: If it was this then that saved thee, hold it fast now also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:290
verses.text: For that which afforded thee so great blessings, to a certainty will not deceive thee in regard to things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:291
verses.text: For in that it found thee dead, and ruined, and a prisoner, and an enemy, and yet made thee a friend, and a son, and a freeman, and righteous, and a joint-heir, and yielded such great things as no one ever expected even, how, after such munificence and attachment, will it betray thee in what is to follow? Say not to me, hopes again! expectations again! faith again! For it is in this way thou wert saved from the beginning, and this dowry was the only one that thou didst bring in to the Bridegroom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:292
verses.text: Hold it then fast and keep it: for if thou demandest to have everything in this world, thou hast lost that well-doing of thine, through which thou didst become bright, and this is why he proceeds to say, "But hope that is seen is not hope; for what a man seeth, why doth he yet hope for?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:293
verses.text: —"But if we hope for that we see not, then do we with patience wait for it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:294
verses.text: That is, if thou art to be looking for everything in this world, what need is there for hope? What is hope then? It is feeling confidence in things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:295
verses.text: What great demand then doth God make upon thee, since He Himself giveth thee blessings quite entire from His own stores? One thing only, hope, He asks of thee, that thou too mayest have somewhat of thine own to contribute toward thy salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:296
verses.text: And this he intimates in what he proceeds with: "For if we hope for that we see not, then do we with patience wait for it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:297
verses.text: As then God crowneth him that undergoes labors, and hardnesses, and countless toils, so doth He him that hopeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:298
verses.text: For the name of patience belongs to hard work and much endurance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:299
verses.text: Yet even this He hath granted to the man that hopeth, that He might solace the wearied soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:300
verses.text: And then to show that for this light task we enjoy abundant aid, he proceeds:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:301
verses.text: "Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:302
verses.text: For the one point is thy own, that of patience, but the other comes of the Spirit's furnishings, Who also cherisheth (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:303
verses.text: anointeth) thee unto this hope, and through it again lighteneth thy labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:304
verses.text: Then that thou mightest know that it is not in thy labors only and dangers that this grace standeth by thee, but even in things the most easy seemingly, it worketh with thee, and on all occasions bears its part in the alliance, he proceeds to say,  "For we know not what we should pray for as we ought".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:305
verses.text: And this he said to show the Spirit's great concern about us, and also to instruct them not to think for certainty that those things are desirable which to man's reasonings appear so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:306
verses.text: For since it was likely that they, when they were scourged, and driven out, and suffering grievances without number, should be seeking a respite, and ask this favor of God, and think it was advantageous to them, by no means (he says) suppose that what seem blessings to you really are so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:307
verses.text: For we need the Spirit's aid even to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:308
verses.text: So feeble is man, and such a nothing by himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:309
verses.text: For this is why he says, "For we know not what we should pray for as we ought".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:310
verses.text: In order that the learner might not feel any shame at his ignorance, he does not say, ye know not, but, "we know not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:311
verses.text: And that he did not say this merely to seem moderate, he plainly shows from other passages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:312
verses.text: For he desired in his prayers unceasingly to see Rome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:313
verses.text: Yet the time when he obtained it was not at once when he desired it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:314
verses.text: And for "the thorn" that was given him "in the flesh" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:315
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:316
verses.text: ), that is the dangers, he often besought God, and was entirely unsuccessful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:317
verses.text: And so was Moses, who in the Old Testament prays to see Palestine (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:318
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:319
verses.text: ), and Jeremiah when he made supplication for the Jews (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:320
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:321
verses.text: ), and Abraham when he interceded for the people of Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:322
verses.text: "But the Spirit Itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:323
verses.text: This statement is not clear, owing to the cessation of many of the wonders which then used to take place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:324
verses.text: Wherefore I must needs inform you of the state of things at that time, and in this way the rest of the subject will be cleared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:325
verses.text: What therefore was the state of things then? God did in those days give to all that were baptized certain excellent gifts, and the name that these had was spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:326
verses.text: For "the spirits of the Prophets," it says, "are subject to the prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:327
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:328
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:329
verses.text: ) And one had the gift of prophecy and foretold things to come; and another of wisdom, and taught the many; and another of healings, and cured the sick; and another of miracles, and raised the dead; another of tongues, and spoke different languages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:330
verses.text: And with all these there was also a gift of prayer, which also was called a spirit, and he that had this prayed for all the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:331
verses.text: For since we are ignorant of much that is profitable for us and ask things that are not profitable, the gift of prayer came into some particular person of that day, and what was profitable for all the whole Church alike, he was the appointed person to ask for in behalf of all, and the instructor of the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:332
verses.text: Spirit then is the name that he gives here to the grace of this character, and the soul that receiveth the grace, and intercedeth to God, and groaneth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:333
verses.text: For he that was counted worthy of such grace as this, standing with much compunction, and with many mental groanings falling before God, asked the things that were profitable for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:334
verses.text: And of this the Deacon of the present day is a symbol when he offers up the prayers for the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:335
verses.text: This then is what Paul means when he says, "the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings that cannot be uttered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:336
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:337
verses.text: "But He that searcheth the hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:338
verses.text: You see that it is not about the Comforter that he is speaking, but about the spiritual heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:339
verses.text: Since if this were not so, he ought to have said, "He that searcheth" the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:340
verses.text: But that thou mayest learn that the language is meant of a spiritual man, who has the gift of prayer, he proceeds, "And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit," that is, of the spiritual man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:341
verses.text: "Because he maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:342
verses.text: Not (he means) that he informs God as if ignorant, but this is done that we may learn to pray for proper things, and to ask of God what is pleasing to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:343
verses.text: For this is what the "according to God" is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:344
verses.text: And so this was with a view to solace those that came to Him, and to yield them excellent instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:345
verses.text: For He that furnished the gifts, and gave besides blessings without number, was the Comforter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:346
verses.text: Hence it says, "all these things worketh one and the self-same Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:347
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:348
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:349
verses.text: ) And it is for our instruction that this takes place, and to show the love of the Spirit, it condescendeth even to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:350
verses.text: And it is from this that the person praying getteth heard, because the prayer is made "according to the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:351
verses.text: You see from how many points he instructs them in the love that was shown them and the honor that was done them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:352
verses.text: And what is there that God hath not done for us? The world He hath made corruptible for us, and again for us incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:353
verses.text: He suffered His Prophets to be ill-treated for our sake, sent them into captivity for us, let them fall into the furnace, and undergo ills without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:354
verses.text: Nay, He made them prophets for us, and the Apostles also He made for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:355
verses.text: He gave up for us His Only-Begotten, He punisheth the devil for us, He hath seated us on the Right Hand, He was reproached for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:356
verses.text: "For the reproaches of them that reproached thee," it says, "fell upon me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:357
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:358
verses.text: lxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:359
verses.text: ) Yet still, when we are drawing back after so great favor, He leaveth us not, but again entreats, and on our account inciteth others to entreat for us, that He may show us favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:360
verses.text: And so it was with Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:361
verses.text: For to him He says, "Let Me alone, that I may blot them out" (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:362
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:363
verses.text: ), that He might drive him upon supplicating on their behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:364
verses.text: And now He doth the same thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:365
verses.text: Hence He gave the gift of prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:366
verses.text: But this He doth, not as Himself standing in need of entreaty, but that we might not, from being saved without effort (ἁπλὥς), grow indifferent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:367
verses.text: For this cause it is on account of David, and of this person and that, He often says, that He is reconciled with them, to establish again this very thing, that the reconciliation may be with all due formality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:368
verses.text: Still He would have looked more loving toward man, if it had not been through this and the other prophet, but of Himself, that He told them that He ceased to be wroth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:369
verses.text: But the reason of His not holding to that point was, that this ground of reconciliation might not become an occasion for listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:370
verses.text: Wherefore to Jeremiah also He said, "Pray not for this people, for I will not hear thee" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:371
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:372
verses.text: ), not as wishing to stop his praying (for He earnestly longeth for our salvation), but to terrify them: and this the prophet also seeing did not cease praying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:373
verses.text: And that you may see that it was not through a wish to turn him from it, but to shame them that He said this, hear what it says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:374
verses.text: "Seest thou not what these are doing?" (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:375
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:376
verses.text: , not verbally from LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:377
verses.text: ) And when He says to the city "Though thou wash thee with nitre, and take thee much soap (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:378
verses.text: herb), yet thou art stained before Me" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:379
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:380
verses.text: ), it is not that He may cast them into despair that He so speaks, but that He may rouse them to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:381
verses.text: For as in the case of the Ninevites, by giving the sentence without limitation, and holding out no good hope, He scared them the more, and led them to repentance, so He doth here also, both to rouse them, and to render the prophet more venerated, that in this way at least they may hear him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:382
verses.text: Then, since they kept on in a state of incurable madness, and were not to be sobered even by the rest being carried away, he first exhorts them to remain there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:383
verses.text: But when they kept not up to this, but deserted to Egypt, this indeed He allowed them, but requires of them not to desert to irreligion as well as to Egypt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:384
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:385
verses.text: xliv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:386
verses.text: ) But when they did not comply in this either, He sendeth the prophet along with them, so that they might not after all suffer total wreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:387
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:388
verses.text: ) For since they did not follow Him when He called, He next followeth them to discipline them, and hinder their being hurried further into vice, and as a father full of affection does a child who takes all treatment in the same peevish way, conducting him about everywhere with himself, and following him about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:389
verses.text: This was the reason why He sent not Jeremiah only into Egypt, but also Ezekiel into Babylon, and they did not refuse to go.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:390
verses.text: For when they found their Master love the people exceedingly, they continued themselves to do so likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:391
verses.text: Much as if a right-minded servant were to take compassion upon an intractable son when he saw his father grieving and lamenting about him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:392
verses.text: And what was there that they did not suffer for them? They were sawn asunder, they were driven out, they were reproached, they were stoned, they underwent numberless grievances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:393
verses.text: And after all this they would run back to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:394
verses.text: Samuel, for instance, ceased not to mourn for Saul, miserably insulted as he was by him, and injured irreparably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:395
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:396
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:397
verses.text: ) Still he held none of these things in remembrance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:398
verses.text: And for the people of the Jews, Jeremiah has composed Lamentations in writing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:399
verses.text: And when the general of the Persians had given him liberty to dwell securely, and with perfect freedom, wherever he pleased, he preferred above dwelling at home the affliction of the people, and their hard durance in a strange land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:400
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:401
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:402
verses.text: ) So Moses left the palace and the sort of living herein, and hasted to be among their calamities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:403
verses.text: And Daniel abode for twenty days following without food, pinching himself with the most severe fast, that he might reconcile God to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:404
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:405
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:406
verses.text: ) And the three Children too, when in the furnace, and so fierce a fire, put up a supplication for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:407
verses.text: For it was not on their account that they were grieved, as they were saved; but since they considered that then was the time for the greatest boldness of speech, they consequently prayed in their behalf; hence too they said, "In a contrite heart and an humble spirit let us be accepted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:408
verses.text: (Song.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:409
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:410
verses.text: ) For them Joshua also rent his garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:411
verses.text: (Josh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:412
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:413
verses.text: ) For them Ezekiel too wailed and lamented when he saw them cut down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:414
verses.text: (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:415
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:416
verses.text: ) And Jeremy said, "Let me alone, I will weep bitterly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:417
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:418
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:419
verses.text: ) And before this, when he did not venture openly to pray for a remittance of their sad estate, he sought for some limited period, when he says, "How long, O, Lord?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:420
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:421
verses.text: ) For full of affectionateness is the whole race of the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:422
verses.text: Wherefore also St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:423
verses.text: Paul saith, "Put on therefore, as the elect saints of God, bowels of mercy, kindness, humbleness of mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:424
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:425
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:426
verses.text: ) You see the strict propriety of the word, and how he would have us continually merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:427
verses.text: For he does not say, "show mercy" only, but put it on, that like as our garment is always with us, so may mercy be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:428
verses.text: And he does not say merely mercy, but "bowels of mercy," that we may imitate the natural affection of relations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:429
verses.text: But we do just the contrary, and if any one comes to ask a single penny of us, we insult them, abuse them, call them impostors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:430
verses.text: Dost thou not shudder, man, and blush to call him an impostor for bread? Why even supposing such an one is practising imposture, he deserves to be pitied for it, because he is so pressed with famine as to put on such a character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:431
verses.text: This then is a reproach to our cruelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:432
verses.text: For since we had not the heart to bestow with readiness, they are compelled to practise a great many arts, so as to put a cheat off upon our inhumanity, and to soften down our harshness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:433
verses.text: Now if it was gold and silver that he asked of thee, then there would be some reason in thy suspicions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:434
verses.text: But if it is necessary food that he comes to thee for, why be showing thyself wise so unseasonably, and take so over exact an account of him, accusing him of idleness and sloth? For if we must talk in this way, it is not others but ourselves that we ought to address.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:435
verses.text: When therefore thou art going to God to ask forgiveness for thy sins, then call these words to mind, and thou wilt know thou deservest to have these things said to thee by God, much more than the poor man by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:436
verses.text: And yet God hath never said such words to thee as "Stand off, since thou art an impostor, always coming to church and hearing My laws, but when abroad, setting gold, and pleasure (ἐπιθυμίαν), and friendship, and in fact anything above My commandments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:437
verses.text: And now thou makest thyself humble, but when thy prayers are over thou art bold, and cruel, and inhuman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:438
verses.text: Get thee hence, therefore, and never come to Me any more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:439
verses.text: Yet this, and more than this, we deserve to have said to us; but still He never did reproach us in any such way, but is long-suffering and fulfils everything on His own part, and gives us more than we ask for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:440
verses.text: Calling this to mind then, let us relieve the poverty of those that beg of us, and if they do impose upon us, let us not be over exact about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:441
verses.text: For such a salvation is it that we ourselves require, one with pardon, with kindness (φιλανθρωπίας), with much mercy along with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:442
verses.text: For it is not possible, it certainly is not, if our estate were searched into strictly, that we should ever be saved, but we must needs be punished and brought to ruin altogether.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:443
verses.text: Let us not then be bitter judges of others lest we also get a strict account demanded of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:444
verses.text: For we have sins that are too great to plead any excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:445
verses.text: And therefore let us show more mercy towards those who have committed inexcusable sins, that we also may lay up for ourselves the like mercy beforehand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:446
verses.text: And yet be as large-hearted as we may, we shall never be able to contribute such love toward man as we stand in need of at the hand of a God that loveth man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:447
verses.text: How then is it other than monstrous, when we are in need of so many things ourselves, to be over exact with our fellow servants, and do all we can against ourselves? For thou dost not in this way so much prove him unworthy of thy liberality, as thyself of God's love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:448
verses.text: For he that deals over exactly with his fellow servant, will be the more sure to find the like treatment at God's hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:449
verses.text: Let us not speak against ourselves, but even if they come out of idleness or wilfulness, let us bestow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:450
verses.text: For we also do many sins through wilfulness, or rather we do them all through wilfulness, and yet God doth not presently call us to punishment, but gives us a set time for penance, nurturing us day by day, disciplining us, teaching us, supplying us with all other things, that we too may emulate this mercy of His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:451
verses.text: Let us then quell this cruelty, let us cast out this brutal spirit, as benefiting thereby ourselves rather than others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:452
verses.text: For to these we give money, and bread, and clothing, but for ourselves we are laying up beforehand very great glory, and such as there is no putting into words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:453
verses.text: For we receive again our bodies incorruptible, and are glorified together and reign together with Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:454
verses.text: And how great this is we shall see from hence—or rather there is no means of making us see it clearly now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:455
verses.text: But to start from our present blessings, and to get from them at least some kind of scanty notice of it, I will endeavor so far as I may be able to put before you what I have been speaking of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:456
verses.text: Tell me then, if when you were grown old, and were living in poverty, and any one were to promise suddenly to make you young, and to bring you to the very prime of life, and to render you very strong, and preëminently beautiful, and were to give you the kingdom of the whole earth for a thousand years, a kingdom in the state of the deepest peace, what is there that you would not choose to do, and to suffer to gain this promise? ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:457
verses.text: and Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:458
verses.text: Mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:459
verses.text: object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:460
verses.text: ) See then, Christ promises not this, but much more than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:461
verses.text: For the distance between old age and youth is not to be compared with the difference of corruption and incorruption, nor that of a kingdom and poverty to that of the present glory and the future, but the difference is that of dreams and a reality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:462
verses.text: Or rather I have yet said nothing to the purpose, since there is no language capable of setting before you the greatness of the difference between things to come and things present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:463
verses.text: And as for time, there is no place for the idea of difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:464
verses.text: For what mode is there for a man to compare with our present state a life that hath no limit? And as for the peace it is as far removed from any present peace, as peace is different from war; and for the incorruption, it is as much better as a clear pearl is than a clod of clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:465
verses.text: Or rather, say as great a thing as one may, nothing can put it before you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:466
verses.text: For were I even to compare the beauty of our bodies then to the light of the sunbeam, or the brightest lightning, I shall not yet be saying aught that is worthy of that brilliancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:467
verses.text: Now for such things as these what money so much that it were not worth the while to give up? what bodies, or rather what souls is it not worth one's while to give up? At present if any one were to lead thee into the palace, and in presence of all were to give thee an opportunity of conversing with the king, and make thee sit at his table, and join in his fare, thou wouldest call thyself the happiest of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:468
verses.text: But when you are to go up to Heaven, and stand by the King of the universe Himself, and to vie with angels in brightness, and to enjoy even that unutterable glory, do you hesitate whether you ought to give up money? whereas if you had to put off life itself, you ought to leap and exult, and mount on wings of pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:469
verses.text: But you, that you may get an office (ἀρχὴν), as a place to pillage from (for call a thing of this sort gain, I cannot), put all you have to hazard, and after borrowing of others, will, if need be, pawn your wife and children too without hesitation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:470
verses.text: But when the kingdom of Heaven is set before you, that office (ἀρχἥς) which hath none to supersede you in it, and God bids you take not a part of a corner of the earth, but the whole of Heaven entirely, are you hesitating, and reluctant, and gaping after money, and forgetful that if the parts of that Heaven which we see are so fair and delightful, how greatly so must the upper Heaven be, and the Heaven of Heaven? But since we have as yet no means of seeing this with our bodily eyes, ascend in thy thought, and standing above this Heaven, look up unto that Heaven beyond this, into that height without a bound, into that Light surcharged with awe, into the crowds of the Angels, into the endless ranks of Archangels, into the rest of the incorporeal Powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:471
verses.text: And then lay hold again of the image (cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:472
verses.text: Plat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:473
verses.text: Rep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:474
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:475
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:476
verses.text: ) thereof we have, after coming down from above, and make a sketch of the estate of a king with us, as his men in gold armor, and his pairs of white mules proudly decked with gold, and his chariots set with jewels and his snow-like cushions (στρωμνὴν Poll.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:477
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:478
verses.text: ), and the spangles that flutter about the chariot, and the dragons shaped out in the silken hangings, and the shields with their gold bosses, and the straps that reach up from these to the rim of them through so many gems, and the horses with the gilded trappings and the gold bits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:479
verses.text: But when we see the king we immediately lose sight of all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:480
verses.text: For he alone turns our eyes to him, and to the purple robe, and the diadem, and the throne, and the clasp, and the shoes, all that splendor of his appearance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:481
verses.text: After gathering all these things together then with accuracy, then again remove your thoughts from these things to things above, and to that awful day in which Christ is coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:482
verses.text: For then you will not see any pairs of mules, nor golden chariots, nor dragons and shields, but things that are big with a mighty awe, and strike such amazement that the very incorporeal Powers are astonished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:483
verses.text: For the "powers of the Heavens," He says, "shall be shaken".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:484
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:485
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:486
verses.text: ) Then is the whole Heaven thrown open, and the gates of those concaves unfold themselves, and the Only-begotten Son of God cometh down, not with twenty, not with a hundred men for His body-guard, but with thousands, ten thousands of Angels and Archangels, Cherubim and Seraphim, and other Powers, and with fear and trembling shall everything be filled, whiles the earth is bursting itself up, and the men that ever were born, from Adam's birth up to that day, are rising from the earth, and all are caught up; ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:487
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:488
verses.text: ) when Himself appears with such great glory as that the sun, and the moon, and all light whatever, is cast into the shade, being outshone by that radiance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:489
verses.text: What language is to set before us that blessedness, brightness, glory? Alas! my soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:490
verses.text: For weeping comes upon me and great groaning, as I reflect what good things we have fallen from, what blessedness we are estranged from.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:491
verses.text: For estranged we are (I am now speaking of my own case still), unless we do some great and astonishing work; speak not then of hell to me now, for more grievous than any hell is the fall from this glory, and worse than punishments unnumbered the estrangement from that lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:492
verses.text: But still we are gaping after this present world, and we take not thought of the devil's cunning, who by little things bereaves us of those great ones, and gives us clay that he may snatch from us gold, or rather that he may snatch Heaven from us, and showeth us a shadow that he may dispossess us of the reality, and puts phantoms before us in dreams (for such is the wealth of this world), that at daybreak he may prove us the poorest of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:493
verses.text: Laying these things to heart, late though it be, let us fly from this craft, and pass to the side of things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:494
verses.text: For we cannot say that we were ignorant how exposed to accidents the present life is, since things every day din in our ears more loudly than a trumpet, the worthlessness, the ridiculousness, the shamefulness, the dangers, the pitfalls, of the present scene.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:495
verses.text: What defence then shall we have to set up for pursuing things so subject to hazards, and laden with shame, with so much eagerness, and leaving things unfailing, which will make us glorious and bright, and giving our whole selves up to the thraldom of money? For the slavery to these things is worse than any bondage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:496
verses.text: And this they know who have been counted worthy to obtain their freedom from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:497
verses.text: That ye then may also feel this goodly liberty, burst the bonds asunder, spring out of the snare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:498
verses.text: And let there be no gold lying by in your houses, but that which is more precious than millions of money, alms and love to man, for your treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:499
verses.text: For this gives us boldness toward God, but the other covers us with deep shame, and causes the devil to bear hard (σφοδρὸν πνεἵν) upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:500
verses.text: Why then arm thy enemy, and make him stronger? Arm thy right hand against him, and transfer all the splendor of thy house into thy soul, and stow away all thy fortune in thy mind, and instead of a chest and a house, let heaven keep thy gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:501
verses.text: And let us put all our property about our own selves; for we are much better than the walls, and more dignified than the pavement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:502
verses.text: Why then do we, to the neglect of our own selves, waste all our attention upon those things, which when we are gone we can no longer reach, and often even while we stay here we cannot keep hold of, when we might have such riches as to be found not in this life only, but also in that, in the easiest circumstances? For he who carries about his farms and house and gold upon his soul, wherever he appears, appears with all this wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:503
verses.text: And how is this possible to be effected? one may ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:504
verses.text: It is possible, and that with the utmost ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:505
verses.text: For if you transfer them to Heaven by the poor man's hand, you will transfer them entire into your own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:506
verses.text: And if death should afterwards come upon thee, no one will take them from thee, but thou wilt depart to be rich in the next world too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:507
verses.text: This was the kind of treasure Tabitha had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:508
verses.text: Hence it was not her house that proclaimed her wealth, nor the walls, nor the stones, nor the pillars, but the bodies of widows furnished with dress, and their tears that were shed, and death that played the runaway, and life that came back again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:509
verses.text: Let us also make unto ourselves such-like treasures, let us build up for ourselves such-like houses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:510
verses.text: In this way we shall have God for our Fellow-worker, and we ourselves shall be workers together with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:511
verses.text: For Himself brought the poor from not being into being, and you will prevent them, after they have been brought into life and being, from perishing with hunger and other distress, by tending them and setting them upright, staying up the Temple of God in every quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:512
verses.text: What can be equal to this in respect both of utility and of glory? Or if as yet you have not gained any clear notion of the great adornment He bestowed upon thee when He bade thee relieve poverty, consider this point with thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:513
verses.text: If He had given thee so great power, that thou wert able to set up again even the Heaven if it were falling, wouldest thou not think the thing an honor far too great for thee? See now He hath held thee worthy of a greater honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:514
verses.text: For that which in His esteem is more precious than the Heavens, He hath trusted thee to repair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:515
verses.text: For of all things visible there is nothing in God's esteem equal to man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:516
verses.text: For Heaven and earth and sea did He make for him, and finds more pleasure in dwelling with him than in the Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:517
verses.text: And yet we, though with a knowledge of this, bestow no attention nor forethought upon the temples of God; but leaving them in a neglected state, we provide houses splendid and large for ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:518
verses.text: This is why we are devoid of all good things, and greater beggars than the poorest poor, because we pride ourselves in these houses which we cannot take away with us when we go hence, and leave those alone which we might move away along with our own selves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:519
verses.text: For the bodies of the poor after dissolution must needs rise again; and God, Who hath given this charge, will bring them forth, and praise those who have taken care of them, and treat such with regard (θαυμάσεται), because when they were on the point of falling to ruin at one time by starvation, at another by nakedness and cold, these repaired them by all means in their power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:520
verses.text: But still, even with all these praises set before us, we loiter yet, and decline undertaking this honorable charge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:521
verses.text: And Christ indeed hath not where to lodge, but goeth about a stranger, and naked, and hungry, and you set up houses out of town, and baths, and terraces, and chambers without number, in thoughtless vanity; and to Christ you give not even a share of a little hut, while for daws and vultures you deck out upper chambers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:522
verses.text: What can be worse than such insanity as this? What more grievous than such madness? for madness it is in the last stage of it, or rather one has no name to suit it, use whatever one may.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:523
verses.text: Yet still if we be so minded, it is possible to beat off the disorder, tenacious as it is; and not possible only, but even easy; and not easy merely, but even easier is it to get rid of this pest than of the sufferings of the body, since the Physician is so much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:524
verses.text: Let us then draw Him to ourselves, and invite Him to aid us in the attempt, and let us contribute our share, good-will, I mean, and energy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:525
verses.text: For He will not require anything further, but if He can meet with this only, He will confer all that is His part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 15:526
verses.text: Let us then contribute our share, that in this world we may enjoy a genuine health, and may attain to the good things to come, by the grace and love towards man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:1
verses.text: Homily XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:3
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:4
verses.text: "And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:5
verses.text: Here he seems to me to have mooted this whole topic with a view to those who were in danger; or, rather, not this only, but also what was said a little before this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:6
verses.text: For the words, "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us;" and those, that "the whole creation groaneth;" and the saying, that "we are saved by hope;" and the phrase, "we with patience wait for;" and that, "we know not what we should pray for as we ought;" are all of them said to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:7
verses.text: For he instructs them not to choose just what they may think, themselves, to be useful, but what the Spirit may suggest; for many things that seem to one's self profitable, do sometimes even cause much harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:8
verses.text: Quiet, for instance, and freedom from dangers, and living out of fear, seemed to be advantageous for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:9
verses.text: And what wonder if they did to them, since to the blessed Paul himself this seemed to be so? still he came afterwards to know that the opposite to all these are the things advantageous, and when he came to know it, he was content.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:10
verses.text: So he that besought the Lord thrice to be freed from hazards, when once he heard Him say, "My grace is sufficient for thee, for My Power is perfected in weakness" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:11
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:12
verses.text: , ), was afterwards delighted at being persecuted, and insulted, and having irreparable ills done him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:13
verses.text: For, "I glory," he says, "in persecutions, in insults" (Eng.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:14
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:15
verses.text: reproaches), "in necessities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:16
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:17
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:18
verses.text: ) And this was his reason for saying, "For we know not what we should pray for as we ought".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:19
verses.text: And he exhorted all men to give up these matters to the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:20
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit is very mindful of us, and this is the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:21
verses.text: Having then cheered them by all methods, he proceeds to what we have heard to-day, putting forward a reason strong enough to reclaim them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:22
verses.text: For he says, "we know that all things work together for good to them that love God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:23
verses.text: Now when he speaks of "all things," he mentions even the things that seem painful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:24
verses.text: For should even tribulation, or poverty, or imprisonment, or famines, or deaths, or anything else whatsoever come upon us, God is able to change all these things into the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:25
verses.text: For this is quite an instance of His unspeakable power, His making things seemingly painful to be lightsome to us, and turning them into that which is helpful to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:26
verses.text: And so he does not say, that "them that love God," no grievance approacheth, but, that it "works together for good," that is to say, that He useth the grievous things themselves to make the persons so plotted against approved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:27
verses.text: And this is a much greater thing than hindering the approach of such grievances, or stopping them when they have come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:28
verses.text: And this is what He did even with the furnace at Babylon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:29
verses.text: For He did not either prevent their falling into it, or extinguish the flame after those saints were cast into it, but let it burn on, and made them by this very flame greater objects of wonder, and with the Apostles too He wrought other like wonders continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:30
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:31
verses.text: Mark xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:32
verses.text: ) For if men who have learnt to be philosophic can use the things of nature to the opposite of their intention, and appear even when living in poverty in easier circumstances than the rich, and shine through disgrace: much more will God work for those that love Him both these and also greater things by far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:33
verses.text: For one needs only one thing, a genuine love of Him, and all things follow that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:34
verses.text: As then things seemingly harmful do good to these, so do even things profitable harm those who love Him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:35
verses.text: For instance, the exhibition of miracles and wisdom in His teaching only injured the Jews, as did the rightness of doctrine; and for the former they called Him a possessed person (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:36
verses.text: ), for the other one that would be equal to God (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:37
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:38
verses.text: ): and because of the miracles (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:39
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:40
verses.text: , ), they even went about to kill Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:41
verses.text: But the thief when crucified, when nailed to the Cross, and reviled, and suffering ills unnumbered, not only was not hurt, but even gained the greatest good therefrom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:42
verses.text: See how for those who love God all things work together for good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:43
