verses.text: After mentioning then this great blessing, one which far exceeds man's nature, since to many this seemed even past belief, he draws a proof of it from past blessings, in these words, "to them who are called according to His purpose".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:44
verses.text: Now consider, he means, from the calling, for instance, what I have just said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:45
verses.text: Why then did He not from the first call all? or why not Paul himself as soon as the rest? Does it not seem that the deferring was harmful? But it was still by the event shown to be for the best.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:46
verses.text: The purpose he here mentions, however, that he might not ascribe everything to the calling; since in this way both Greeks and Jews would be sure to cavil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:47
verses.text: For if the calling alone were sufficient, how came it that all were not saved? Hence he says, that it is not the calling alone, but the purpose of those called too, that works the salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:48
verses.text: For the calling was not forced upon them, nor compulsory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:49
verses.text: All then were called, but all did not obey the call.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:50
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:51
verses.text: "For whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate to be conformed to the Image of His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:52
verses.text: See what superb honor! for what the Only-begotten was by Nature, this they also have become by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:53
verses.text: And still he was not satisfied with this calling of them conformed thereto, but even adds another point, "that He might be the first-born".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:54
verses.text: And even here he does not come to a pause, but again after this he proceeds to mention another point, "Among many brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:55
verses.text: So wishing to use all means of setting the relationship in a clear light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:56
verses.text: Now all these things you are to take as said of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:57
verses.text: For according to the Godhead He is Only-begotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:58
verses.text: See, what great things He hath given unto us! Doubt not then about the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:59
verses.text: For he showeth even upon other grounds His concern for us by saying, that things were fore-ordered in this way from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:60
verses.text: For men have to derive from things their conceptions about them, but to God these things have been long determined upon, and from of old He bare good-will toward us (πρὸς ἡμἅς διέκειτο), he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:61
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:62
verses.text: "Moreover whom He did predestinate, them He also called; and whom He called, them He also justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:63
verses.text: Now He justified them by the regeneration of the laver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:64
verses.text: "And whom He justified, them He also glorified" by the gift, by the adoption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:65
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:66
verses.text: "What shall we then say to these things?"  As if he should say, Let me then hear no more about the dangers and the malicious devices from every quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:67
verses.text: For even if some disbelieve the things to come, still they have not a word to say against the good things that have already taken place; as, for instance, the friendship of God towards thee from the first, the justifying, the glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:68
verses.text: And yet these things He gave thee by means seemingly distressing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:69
verses.text: And those things which you thought to be disgracing, the Cross, scourges, bonds, these are what have set the whole world aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:70
verses.text: As then by what Himself suffered, though of aspect forbidding in man's eye, even by these He effected the liberty and salvation of the whole race; so also is He wont to do in regard to those things which thou endurest, turning thy sufferings unto glory and renown for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:71
verses.text: "If God be for us, who can be against us?"  Why, it may be said, who is there that is not against us? Why the world is against us, both kings and peoples, both relations and countrymen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:72
verses.text: Yet these that be against us, so far are they from thwarting us at all, that even without their will they become to us the causes of crowns, and procurers of countless blessings, in that God's wisdom turneth their plots unto our salvation and glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:73
verses.text: See how really no one is against us! For it was this which gave new lustre to Job, the fact that the devil was in arms against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:74
verses.text: For the devil moved at once friends against him, his wife against him, and wounds, and servants, and a thousand other machinations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:75
verses.text: And it turned out that none of them was against him on the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:76
verses.text: And yet this was no great thing to him, though it was great in itself, but what is a far greater thing is, that it turned out that they were all for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:77
verses.text: For since God was for him, even things seemingly against him all became for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:78
verses.text: And this happened with the Apostles also, inasmuch as both the Jews, and they of the Gentiles, and false brethren, and rulers, and peoples, and famines, and poverty, and ten thousand things were against them; and yet nothing was against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:79
verses.text: For the things which made them the most bright and conspicuous, and great in the sight both of God and of men, were these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:80
verses.text: Just reflect then what a word Paul hath uttered about the faithful, and those who are truly (ἀκριβὥς) crucified, such as not even the Emperor with his diadem can achieve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:81
verses.text: For against him there are abundance of barbarians that arm themselves, and of enemies that invade, and of bodyguards that plot, and of subjects many that oftentimes are ever and anon rebelling, and thousands of other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:82
verses.text: But against the faithful who taketh good heed unto God's laws, neither man, nor devil, nor aught besides, can stand! For if you take away his money, you have become the procurer of a reward to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:83
verses.text: If you speak ill of him, by the evil report he gains fresh lustre in God's sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:84
verses.text: If you cast him into starvation, the more will his glory and his reward be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:85
verses.text: If (what seems the most severe stroke of all) you give him over to death, you are twining a crown of martyrdom about him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:86
verses.text: What then is equivalent to this way of life, being that against which nothing can be done, but even they that seem to devise mischief are no less of service to him than benefactors? This is why he says, "If God be for us, who can be against us?" Next, not being satisfied with what he had already said, the greatest sign of His love for us, and that which he always is dwelling over, that he sets down here also; I mean, the slaying of His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:87
verses.text: For He did not only justify us, he means, and glorify us, and make us conformed to that Image, but not even His Son did He spare for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:88
verses.text: And therefore he proceeds to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:89
verses.text: "He that spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how shall He not with Him also freely give us all things?"  And here the words he uses are high-wrought (μεθ᾽ ὑτερβολἥς) and exceedingly warm, to show his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:90
verses.text: How then is He to neglect us, in whose behalf "He spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all?" For reflect what goodness it is not to spare even His own Son, but to give Him up, and to give Him up for all, and those worthless, and unfeeling, and enemies, and blasphemers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:91
verses.text: "How then shall He not with Him also freely give us all things? What he means then is much as follows; If He gave His own Son, and not merely gave Him, but gave Him to death, why doubt any more about the rest, since thou hast the Master? why be dubious about the chattels, when thou hast the Lord? For He that gave the greater thing to His enemies, how shall He do else than give the lesser things to His friends?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:92
verses.text: "Who shall lay anything to the charge of God's elect?"  Here he is against those who say, that faith is no profit, and will not believe the complete change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:93
verses.text: (i-e: in baptism see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:94
verses.text: ) And see how swiftly he stops their mouths, by the worthiness of Him that elected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:95
verses.text: He does not say, "Who shall lay anything to the charge of God's" servants? or of God's faithful ones? but "of God's elect?" And election is a sign of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:96
verses.text: For if when a horse-breaker has selected colts fit for the race, no one can find fault with them, but he would get laughed at who should find fault; much more when God selecteth souls are they that "lay any charge against" them deserving of laughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:97
verses.text: "It is God that justifieth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:98
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:99
verses.text: "Who is He that condemneth?  He does not say, it is God that forgave our sins, but what is much greater, "It is God that justifieth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:100
verses.text: For when the Judge's sentence declares us just, and a Judge such as that too, what signifieth the accuser? Hence neither is it right to fear temptations, for God is for us, and hath shown it by what He hath done; nor again Jewish triflings, for He has both elected and justified us, and the wondrous thing is that it was also by the death of His Son that He did so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:101
verses.text: Who then is to condemn us, since God crowns us, and Christ was put to death for us, and not only was put to death, but also after this intercedeth for us?  For, "It is Christ," he says, "that died, yea rather, that is risen from the dead, Who is at the right hand of God, Who also maketh intercession for us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:102
verses.text: For though seen now in His own dignity, He hath not left caring for us, but even "maketh intercession for us," and still keepeth up the same love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:103
verses.text: For He was not contented with being put to death alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:104
verses.text: And this is a sign for the most part of very great love, to be doing not only what falls to His lot, but also to address Another on this behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:105
verses.text: For this is all he meant to signify by the interceding, using a way of speaking better suited to man, and more condescending, that he might point out love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:106
verses.text: Since unless we take the words, "He spared not," also with the same understanding, many inconsistencies will come of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:107
verses.text: And that you may see that such is the point he is aiming at, after first saying, that He "is at the Right Hand," he next proceeds to say, that He "maketh intercession for us," when he had shown an equality of honor and rank, so that hence it may appear that the Intercession is not a sign of inferiority, but of love only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:108
verses.text: For being Life itself (αὐτοζωή) (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:109
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:110
verses.text: ), and a Well of good things of every kind, and with the same power as the Father, both to raise up the dead and to quicken them, and do all besides that He doth, how could He need to be a suppliant in order to help us? (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:111
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:112
verses.text: ) He that of His own power set free those who were given over and condemned, even from that condemnation; and made them righteous, and sons, and led them to the very highest honors, and brought to pass things which had never been hoped for: how should He, after having achieved all this, and having shown our nature on the King's throne, require to be a suppliant to do the easier things? (Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:113
verses.text: ; Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:114
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:115
verses.text: ; Rev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:116
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:117
verses.text: ) You see how it is shown by every argument, that there is no other reason for his having mentioned intercession, save to show the warmth and vigorousness of His love for us; for the Father also is represented to us as beseeching men to be reconciled to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:118
verses.text: "For we are ambassadors of Christ, as though God did beseech you by us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:119
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:120
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:121
verses.text: ) Still, though God beseecheth, and men are "ambassadors in Christ's stead" to men, we do not understand on that account anything done unworthy of that dignity; but one thing only do we gather from all that is told us, namely, the intenseness of the love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:122
verses.text: This then let us do here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:123
verses.text: If then the Spirit even "maketh intercession for us with groanings that cannot be uttered," and Christ died and intercedeth for us, and the Father "spared not His own Son" for thee, and elected thee, and justified thee, why be afraid any more? Or why tremble when enjoying such great love, and having such great interest taken in thee? In this way then, after showing His great providence over us from the first, he afterwards brings out what comes next in a bold style, and does not say, ye ought also to love Him, but, as if grown enthusiastic at this unspeakable Providence over us, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:124
verses.text: "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ?"  And he does not say of God, so indifferent is it to him whether he mentions the Name of Christ or of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:125
verses.text: "Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?" Observe the blessed Paul's judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:126
verses.text: For he does not mention the things that we are daily getting taken by, love of money and desire of glory and the thraldom of anger, but things that are far more enthralling than these, and of power to put a force upon nature itself, and to wrench open the sternness of the resolution many times even against our will, are what he puts down here, tribulations and distresses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:127
verses.text: For even if the things mentioned are easy to tell up, still each single word has in it thousands of lines of temptation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:128
verses.text: For when he says, tribulation, he mentions prisons and bonds, and calumnies, and banishments, and all the other hardships, so in one word running through an ocean of dangers without stint, and exhibiting to us, in fact by a single word, all the evils that men meet with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:129
verses.text: Yet still he dares them all! Wherefore he brings them forward in the shape of questions, as if it was incontrovertible that nothing could move a person so beloved, and who had enjoyed so much providence over him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:130
verses.text: Then that this might not seem as if he had forgotten himself, he brings in the Prophet also, who declared this before, a long while ago and saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:131
verses.text: "For Thy sake we are killed all the day long, we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:132
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:133
verses.text: xliv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:134
verses.text: )  That is, we are exposed to all to be evil entreated of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:135
verses.text: But yet against so many and so great dangers and these recent horrors, the object of our conflicts is given as a sufficient consolation, or rather not sufficient only, but even much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:136
verses.text: For it is not for men, nor for any other of the things of this life that we suffer, but for the King (he says) of the universe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:137
verses.text: But this is not the only crown, for he encircles them with another besides, and that varied and manifold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:138
verses.text: Since then, as they were men they could not have deaths without number to undergo, he shows that in this way the prize is none the less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:139
verses.text: For even if by nature it were fated to die once, by choice God hath granted us to suffer this every day, if we be so minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:140
verses.text: Whence it is plain that we shall depart with as many crowns as we have lived days, or rather with many more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:141
verses.text: For it is possible in a day to die not once alone or twice, but many times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:142
verses.text: For he who is always ready unto this, keeps continually receiving a full reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:143
verses.text: This then is what the Psalmist (Προφήτης) hints at, when he says, "all the day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:144
verses.text: And for this reason the Apostle also brought him before them to rouse them up the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:145
verses.text: For if, he means, those in the old dispensation, who had the land as their reward, and the other things which come to a close along with this life, did so look down upon the present life and the temptations and dangers of it, what pardon should we find if we deal so languidly after the promise of Heaven, and the Kingdom above, and its unutterable blessings, so as not to come even up to the same measure as they? And this he does not say indeed, but leaves it to his hearers' consciences, and is satisfied with the quotation alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:146
verses.text: He shows too that their bodies become a sacrifice, and that we must not be disturbed or troubled at God having so ordered it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:147
verses.text: And he exhorts them in other ways besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:148
verses.text: For to prevent any from saying that he is merely philosophizing here before having any experience of realities, he adds, "we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter," meaning the daily deaths of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:149
verses.text: You see his courage and his goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:150
verses.text: For as they, he means, when slaughtered make no resistance, so neither do we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:151
verses.text: But since the feebleness of the mind of man, even after so great things, was afraid of the multitude of temptations, see how he again rouses the hearer, and gives him a lofty and exulting spirit, by saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:152
verses.text: "Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him that loved us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:153
verses.text: For what is indeed wonderful is this, not that we are conquerors only, but that we are so by the very things meant as plots against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:154
verses.text: And we are not merely conquerors, but we are "more than conquerors," that is, are so with ease, without toil and labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:155
verses.text: For without undergoing the real things, by only setting our mind aright, we raise our trophies against our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:156
verses.text: And with good reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:157
verses.text: For it is God that striveth together with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:158
verses.text: Do not then be doubtful, if though beaten we get the better of our beaters, if driven out we overcome our persecutors, if dying we put the living to fight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:159
verses.text: For when you take the power and also the love of God into account, there is nothing to prevent these wondrous and strange things from coming to pass, and that victory the most advantageous should shine upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:160
verses.text: For they did not merely conquer, but in a wondrous way, and so that one might learn that those who plotted against them had a war not against men, but against that invincible Might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:161
verses.text: See the Jews then with these among them, and at a loss quite, and saying, "What are we to do to these men?" (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:162
verses.text: ) For it is marvellous indeed, that though they had hold of them and had got them liable to their courts, and imprisoned them and beat them, they were yet at a loss and in perplexity, as they got overcome by the very things whereby they expected to conquer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:163
verses.text: And neither kings nor people, nor ranks of demons, nor the devil himself, had power to get the better of them, but were all overcome at a very great disadvantage, finding that all they planned against them became for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:164
verses.text: And therefore he says, "we are more than conquerors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:165
verses.text: For this was a new rule of victory for men to prevail by their adversaries, and in no instance to be overcome, but to go forth to these struggles as if they themselves had the issue in their own hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:166
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:167
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:168
verses.text: "For I am persuaded, that neither death nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:169
verses.text: These are great things here mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:170
verses.text: But the reason we do not enter into them is, because we have not so great love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:171
verses.text: Yet still though they are great, as he wished to show that they were nothing beside the love wherewith he was loved of God; after it he then places his own, lest he should seem to be saying great things about himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:172
verses.text: And what he says is somewhat of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:173
verses.text: Why speak, he means, of things present, and evils inherited in this life? For even if a person were to tell me of things to come, and of powers; of things, such as death and life; of powers, such as angels and archangels, and all the superior orders of beings; even these would be little to me compared with the love of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:174
verses.text: For even if a person were to threaten me with that future death to which there is no death, to separate me from Christ, nor if he promised the life without end, would I agree to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:175
verses.text: Why mention kings here below and consuls? and this one or that? for if you tell me of angels, or all the powers above, or all existing things, or all that are to come, they are all small to me, both those in the earth, and those in heaven, and those under the earth, and those above heaven, compared to this charm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:176
verses.text: Then as though these were not enough to set before them the strong desire which he had, he gives a being to others again of like magnitude, and says, "nor any other creation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:177
verses.text: And what he means is nearly this, even if there were any other creation as great as the visible, and as great as the intelligible, none of them could part me from that love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:178
verses.text: This he says not as if the Angels attempted it, or the other Powers, far from it, but as wishing to show quite to the utmost the charm he had toward Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:179
verses.text: For Christ he loved not for the things of Christ, but for His sake the things that were His, and to Him alone he looked, and one thing he feared, and that was falling from his love for Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:180
verses.text: For this thing was in itself more dreadful than hell, as to abide in it was more desirable than the Kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:181
verses.text: What then should we now deserve, when he is found not to esteem even the things in Heaven as compared with the desire for Christ, and we set more store by things of mire and clay than by Christ? And he out of desire of Him would take up with falling into hell, and being banished from the Kingdom, if the choice between the two were put to him: but we are not even above the present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:182
verses.text: Are we worthy then to touch his very shoes, when we have come to be so far short of his largeness of mind? For he for Christ's sake does not think anything even of a kingdom; but we think slightingly of Himself, but things of His we make great account of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:183
verses.text: And would it were of things of His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:184
verses.text: But now it is not even this; but with a Kingdom held out to us, we let that alone, and keep pursuing shadows and dreams all our days.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:185
verses.text: And yet God in His love toward man and exceeding gentleness, hath done the same as if an affectionate father should, on his son's becoming disinclined to a continual stay with him, manage to bring this about in another way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:186
verses.text: For since we have not the right feeling of desire after Him, He keeps putting divers other things before us, so as to hold us to Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:187
verses.text: Yet not even for this do we abide with Him, but we keep springing off to childish playthings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:188
verses.text: Not so Paul, but like a noble spirited child, who is open and attached to his father, he seeks only after the Father's presence, and other things he sets not so much store by; or rather, it is much more than a child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:189
verses.text: For he does not value the Father and things that are His at the same rate, but when he looks to the Father, he counts them nothing, but would choose rather to be chastised and beaten, so he was with Him, than to be apart from Him and indulge his ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:190
verses.text: Let us then shudder, all of us that do not even feel above money for the sake of Christ, or rather such of us as do not feel above it for our own sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:191
verses.text: For it was Paul alone who suffered in good earnest all things for Christ's sake, not for the sake of the kingdom, or his own honor, but owing to his affection to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:192
verses.text: But as for us, neither Christ nor the things of Christ draw us from the things of this life; but as serpents, or snakes, or swine, or even as all of them at once, so do we keep dragging on in the mire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:193
verses.text: For wherein are we better than those brutes, when with so many and such great examples before us we still keep bowing down, and have not the heart to look up to Heaven for ever so little a time? Yet did God give up even His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:194
verses.text: But thou wilt not so much as share thy bread with Him, Who was given up for thee, Who was slain for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:195
verses.text: The Father for thy sake spared not Him, and this too when He was indeed His Son, but thou doest not look upon Him even when pining with starvation, and this too when thou shouldest but spend of His own, and spend it too for thy own good! What can be worse than such a breach of law as this? He was given up for thee, He was slain for thee, He goeth about in hunger for thee, it is of His own thou shouldest give, that thou mayest thyself get the gain, and still thou dost not give! What sort of stone is there than which these are not more senseless, who in despite of such great inducements, continue in this diabolical cruel-heartedness? For He was not satisfied even with death and the Cross only, but He took up with becoming poor also, and a stranger, and a beggar, and naked, and being thrown into prison, and undergoing sickness, that so at least He might call thee off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:196
verses.text: If thou wilt not requite Me, He says, as having suffered for thee, show mercy on Me for My poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:197
verses.text: And if thou are not minded to pity Me for My poverty, do for My disease be moved, for My imprisonment be softened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:198
verses.text: And if even these things make thee not charitable, for the easiness of the request comply with Me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:199
verses.text: For it is no costly gift I ask, but bread and lodging, and words of comfort; but if even after this thou still continuest unsubdued, still for the Kingdom's sake be improved for the rewards which I have promised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:200
verses.text: Hast thou then no regard even for these? yet still for very nature's sake be softened at seeing Me naked, and remember that nakedness wherewith I was naked on the Cross for thee; or, if not this, yet that wherewith I am now naked through the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:201
verses.text: I was then bound for thee, nay, still am so for thee, that whether moved by the former ground or the latter, thou mightest be minded to show some pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:202
verses.text: I fasted for thee, again I am hungry for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:203
verses.text: I was athirst when hanging on the Cross, I am athirst also through the poor, that by the former as also by the latter I may draw thee to Myself, and make thee charitable to thine own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:204
verses.text: Hence also of thee that owest Me the requital of benefits without number, I make not demand as of one that oweth, but crown thee as one that favoreth Me, and a kingdom do I give thee for these small things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:205
verses.text: For I do not say so much as put an end to My poverty, or give Me riches, and yet I did become poor for thee; yet still I ask for bread and clothing, and a small solace for My hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:206
verses.text: And if I be thrown into prison, I do not insist upon thy loosing My bonds and setting Me free, but one thing only do I seek after, that thou wouldest visit Me, Who was (or am) bound for thee, and I shall have received favor enough, and for this only will I give thee Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:207
verses.text: And yet I delivered thee from most galling bonds, but for Me it is quite enough, if thou wilt but visit Me when in prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:208
verses.text: For I am able indeed to crown thee even without all this; yet I would fain be a debtor to thee, that the crown may give thee some feeling of confidence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:209
verses.text: This is why, though I am able to support Myself, I come about begging, and stand beside thy door, and stretch out Mine hand, since My wish is to be supported by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:210
verses.text: For I love thee exceedingly, and so desire to eat at thy table, which is the way with those that love a person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:211
verses.text: And I glory (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:212
verses.text: ) in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:213
verses.text: And when the whole world are spectators, then am I to herald thee forth, and in the hearing of all men to display thee as My supporter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:214
verses.text: Yet we, when we are supported by any one, feel ashamed, and cover our faces; but He, as loving us exceedingly, even if we hold our peace, will then tell out what we did with much praise, and is not ashamed to say, that when Himself was naked we clothed Him, and fed Him when hungry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:215
verses.text: Let us then lay all these things to heart, and not be contented with passing mere praises upon them, but let us even accomplish what I have been speaking of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:216
verses.text: For what is the good of these applauses and clamors? I demand one thing only of you, and that is the display of them in real action, the obedience of deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:217
verses.text: This is my praise, this your gain, this gives me more lustre than a diadem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 16:218
verses.text: When you have left the Church then, this is the crown that you should make for me and for you, through the hand of the poor; that both in the present life we may be nourished with a goodly hope, and after we have departed to the life to come, we may attain to those good things without number, to which may all of us attain by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:1
verses.text: Homily XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:3
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:4
verses.text: "I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:5
verses.text: Did I not seem yesterday to you to have spoken some great and exorbitant things of Paul's love toward Christ? And great indeed they were, too great for any words to express.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:6
verses.text: Yet what you have heard to-day are as far above those things, as those things were above ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:7
verses.text: And yet I did not think they could be exceeded, still when I came to what has been read to-day it did appear far more glorious than the whole of the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:8
verses.text: And that he was aware of this himself he shows by his exordium.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:9
verses.text: For as on the point of entering upon greater things than those, and therefore liable to be disbelieved by the generality, he first uses a strong asseveration about the matter he is going to speak of; which many are in the habit of doing when they are going to say somewhat which is not believed by the generality, and about which they feel the utmost certainty in their own minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:10
verses.text: Hence he says, "I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, and my conscience beareth witness,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:11
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:12
verses.text: "That I have a great heaviness and continual sorrow in my heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:13
verses.text: For I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:14
verses.text: What sayest thou, O Paul? from Christ, thy beloved One, from Whom neither kingdom nor hell, nor things visible nor intelligible, nor another world as great, would separate thee, is it from Him that thou wouldst now be accursed? What has happened? Hast thou changed, hast thou given over that love? No, he replies, fear not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:15
verses.text: Rather I have even made it more intense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:16
verses.text: How then is it that thou wouldest fain be accursed, and seekest a separation, and a removal to such a distance, that after it there is no possibility of finding a more distant one? Because I love Him exceedingly, he may reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:17
verses.text: How, pray, and in what manner? For the things seem a riddle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:18
verses.text: Or rather, if you will, let us learn what the curse is, and then we will question him upon these points, and shall understand this unspeakable and extraordinary love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:19
verses.text: What then is the curse? Hear his own words, "If any man love not our Lord Jesus Christ, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:20
verses.text: (anathema,  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:21
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:22
verses.text: ) That is, let him be set apart from all, removed from all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:23
verses.text: For as in the case of a thing dedicated (ἀνάθημα), which is set apart for God, no one would venture so much as to touch it with his hand or even to come near it; so too with a man who is put apart from the Church, in cutting him off from all, and removing him as far off as possible, he calls him by this name (ἀνάθεμα) in a contrary sense, thus with much fear denouncing to all men to keep apart from him, and to spring away from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:24
verses.text: For the thing set apart, no one, from respect of it, ventures to come near to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:25
verses.text: But from him who is cut off, all men separate themselves from a very opposite feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:26
verses.text: And so the separation is the same, and both the one and the other are equally removed from the generality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:27
verses.text: Still, the mode of separation is not the same, but in this case it is the opposite to what it is in that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:28
verses.text: For from the one they keep back as being dedicated to God; from the other as being estranged from God, and broken off from the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:29
verses.text: This then is what Paul means when he says, "I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:30
verses.text: And he does not say merely that I could be willing, but using a stronger term, he says even, "I could wish" (or pray ηὐχόμην).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:31
verses.text: But if what he says trouble you in your (ἀσθενέστερον) feebleness, consider the real state of the case, not only that he wished to be separated, but also the cause for which he wished it, and then you will see the greatness of his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:32
verses.text: For he even circumcised (Timothy, Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:33
verses.text: ), and we pay no attention to what was done, but to the intention of it, and the cause of it, and hence we wonder at him the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:34
verses.text: And he not only circumcised a person, but he even shaved himself and sacrificed (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:35
verses.text: ; Acts xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:36
verses.text: ), and yet surely we do not therefore assert him to be a Jew, but upon this very score to be perfectly free from Judaizing, and clear of it, and a genuine worshipper of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:37
verses.text: As then when you see him circumcising and sacrificing, you do not therefore condemn him as Judaizing, but upon this very score have the best reason for crowning him as quite an alien to Judaism; thus when thou seest him to have become desirous of being accursed, do not therefore be troubled, but upon this very ground give him the loudest praise, when thou knowest the cause why he wishes this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:38
verses.text: For if we do not look narrowly into the causes, we shall call Elijah a manslayer, and Abraham not a manslayer only, but a murderer of his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:39
verses.text: And Phinees and Peter we shall implead for murder likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:40
verses.text: Nor is it in the case of the saints alone, but also of the God of the universe, that he who does not keep to this rule, will be suspecting sundry unbecoming things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:41
verses.text: Now to prevent this happening in all cases of the kind, let us bring together both the cause, and the intention, and the time, and all that makes in behalf of what is so done, and in this way let us investigate the actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:42
verses.text: And this we must do now also in the case of this blessed soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:43
verses.text: Now what is the cause? It is Jesus Himself Who is so beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:44
verses.text: And yet he does not say for Him; for what he says is, I would wish that I were accursed from Him for my brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:45
verses.text: And this comes of his humbleness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:46
verses.text: For he has no wish to make himself conspicuous, as if he were saying something great, and doing Christ a favor in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:47
verses.text: Wherefore also he said "my kinsmen," that he may conceal his high aim (πλεονέκτημα).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:48
verses.text: Since to see that he wished it all for Christ's sake, just hear what comes next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:49
verses.text: After speaking of kinsmen then, he proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:50
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:51
verses.text: "To whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the Law, and the service of God,and the promises; whose are the father's, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, Who is over all, God blessed for ever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:52
verses.text: And what is this? one asks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:53
verses.text: For if with a view to the belief of others he was willing to become accursed, he ought to have also wished for this in the Gentiles' behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:54
verses.text: But if he wishes it in the Jews' behalf only, it is a proof that he did not wish it for Christ's sake, but for his own relationship to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:55
verses.text: But in fact if he had prayed for the Gentiles only, this would not have been equally clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:56
verses.text: But since it is for the Jews only, it is a clear proof that it is only for Christ's glory that he is thus earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:57
verses.text: And I am aware that what I am saying will seem a paradox to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:58
verses.text: Still if ye do not make a disturbance, I will presently endeavor to make it clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:59
verses.text: For what he has said he has not said nakedly; but since all were talking and accusing God, that after being counted worthy of the name of sons, and receiving the Law, and knowing Him beyond all men, and enjoying such great glory, and serving him beyond the whole world, and receiving the promises, and being from fathers who were His friends, and what was the greatest thing of all, having been forefathers of Christ Himself (for this is the meaning of the words, "of whom, as concerning the flesh, Christ came"), they are now cast out and disgraced; and in their place are introduced men who had never known Him, of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:60
verses.text: Now since they said all this, and blasphemed God, Paul hearing it, and being cut to the heart, and vexed for God's glory's sake, wished that he were accursed, had it been possible, so that they might be saved, and this blasphemy be put a stop to, and God might not seem to have deceived the offspring of those to whom He promised the gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:61
verses.text: And that you may see that it was in sorrow for this, that the promise of God might not seem to fall to the ground, which said to Abraham, "I will give this land to thee and to thy seed," that he uttered this wish, he proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:62
verses.text: "Not as though the word of God had taken none effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:63
verses.text: To show that he had courage (Mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:64
verses.text: and  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:65
verses.text: wished) to bear all these things for the word of God, that is, the promise made to Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:66
verses.text: For as Moses seemed to be pleading for the Jews, yet was doing everything for God's glory (for he says, "Lest they say, Because He was not able to save them, He led them forth to destroy them in the wilderness" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:67
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:68
verses.text: ); stay Thy wrath), so also does Paul, That they may not say (he means) that the promise of God has fallen to the ground, and He has disappointed us of that He vouched to us, and this word has not issued in deed, I could wish to be accursed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:69
verses.text: This then was why he did not speak of the Gentiles (for to them no promises had been made by Him, nor had they worshipped Him, wherefore neither did any blaspheme Him on their account), but it was for the Jews who had both received the promise, and had also been brought into closer connection with Him than others, that he expressed this wish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:70
verses.text: Do you see, that if he had expressed it for the Gentiles, he would not have been shown to be doing this so purely for Christ's glory? But since he was willing to become accursed in the Jews' behalf, then it was most evidenced that it was for Christ's sake only that he desired this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:71
verses.text: And for this cause he says,  "To whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the service of God, and the promises".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:72
verses.text: For the Law, he means, which speaks of Christ, comes from thence, and all the covenants made with them, and Himself came from them, and the Fathers who received the promises were all from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:73
verses.text: Yet still the opposite has resulted, and they have fallen from all their good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:74
verses.text: Hence, he means, I am vexed, and if it were possible to be separated from the company about Christ, and to be made an alien, not from the love of Him (that be far from him; for even all this he was doing through love), but from all that enjoyment and glory, I would accept that lot, provided my Master were not to be blasphemed, that He might not have to hear some saying, that it has been all for stage-effect; He promises to one, and gives to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:75
verses.text: He was sprung from one race, He saved another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:76
verses.text: It was to the forefathers of the Jews that He made the promises, and yet He has deserted their descendants, and put men, who never at any time knew Him, into their good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:77
verses.text: They labored in the practice of the Law, and reading the Prophets, while men who have come but yesterday from heathen altars and images have been set up above them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:78
verses.text: What foresight is there in all this? Now that these things may not be said of my Master, he means, even if they are said unjustly, I would willingly lose even the kingdom and that glory unutterable, and any sufferings would I undergo, as considering it the greatest consolation possible no longer to hear Him Whom I so long for, so blasphemed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:79
verses.text: But if you be still against allowing this explanation, just reflect that many fathers have at many times taken up with thus much for their children, and have chosen to be separated from them, and rather to see them in honor, considering their honor dearer to them than their company.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:80
verses.text: But since we are so short of love like this (Bacon, N.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:81
verses.text: O.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:82
verses.text: Aph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:83
verses.text: lib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:84
verses.text: , §), we cannot even form an idea of what is here meant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:85
verses.text: For there be some that are so wholly unworthy even to hear the name of Paul, and that stand at such an interval and distance from that vehemency of his, as to fancy that he says this of temporal death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:86
verses.text: Who I should say were as ignorant of Paul, as the blind of the sun's rays, or even much more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:87
verses.text: For he that died daily, and set before him dangers thick as a snow-storm, and then said, "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine?" and still unsatisfied with what he had said, and after going above the heaven and the heaven of heavens, and running through the Angels and Archangels, and all the higher orders of beings, and taking in at once things present, things to come, things visible, things intelligible, things grievous, and things good, that were on either part, and leaving nothing out at all, yet not even thus satiated, but even bodying forth another non-existing creation, how should he, by way of saying some great thing after all those things, make mention of a temporal death? It is not so, surely it is not! But such a notion is that of worms nestling in their dunghill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:88
verses.text: For had he said this, in what sense would he be wishing himself accursed from Christ? For death (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:89
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:90
verses.text: ) of that sort would have joined him more closely with the band of Christ, and made him enjoy that glory the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:91
verses.text: Yet some there are who venture to say things different from these, even more ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:92
verses.text: It was not then, they say, death that he wished to have, but to be a treasure, a thing set apart, of Christ's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:93
verses.text: And who even of the most worthless and indolent that would not wish for this? And in what way was this likely to be in his kinsmen's behalf? Let us then leave these fables and trifles (for it is no more worth while making a reply to these things than to children babbling at play), and let us go back again to the words themselves, luxuriating in this very ocean of love, and fearlessly swimming there in every direction, and reflecting upon the unspeakable flame of love—or rather say what one may, one shall say nothing worthy the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:94
verses.text: For there is no ocean so wide, no flame so intense, as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:95
verses.text: And no language can set it forth as it deserves, but he alone knew it who in good earnest gained it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:96
verses.text: And now let me bring the words themselves before you again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:97
verses.text: "For I could wish that I myself were accursed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:98
verses.text: What does the "I myself" mean? It means I that have been a teacher ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:99
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:100
verses.text: ) of all, that have gathered together countless good deeds, that am waiting for countless crowns, that desired Him so much, as to value His love above all things, who all my days am burning for Him, and hold all things (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:101
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:102
verses.text: ) of second importance to the love of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:103
verses.text: For even being loved by Christ was not the only thing he cared for, but loving Him exceedingly also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:104
verses.text: And this last he cared most for (τούτου μάλιστα ἦν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:105
verses.text: So it was that he looked to this only, and took all things light-heartedly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:106
verses.text: For he kept one aim in view in all circumstances, the fulfilling of this excellent love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:107
verses.text: And this he wishes for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:108
verses.text: But since things were not to take this course, nor he to become accursed, he next attempts to go into a defence against the charges, and so to bring what was bruited abroad by all before them as to overthrow it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:109
verses.text: And before he openly enters into his defence against these, he first lays down some seeds of it beforehand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:110
verses.text: For when he says, "to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the giving of the Law, and the service of God, and the promises," he does but say that God willed them indeed to be saved, and this he showed by His former dealings, and by Christ's having sprung from them, and by what He promised to the Fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:111
verses.text: But they out of their own untreatable temper thrust the benefit away from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:112
verses.text: And this is also the reason of his setting down such things as set forth God's gift, not such as were encomiums upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:113
verses.text: For the adoption came of His grace, and so too the glory, and the promises, and the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:114
verses.text: After taking all these things then into consideration, and reflecting how earnest God along with His Son, had been for their salvation, he lifts up his voice aloud, and says, "Who is blessed forever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:115
verses.text: So himself offering up thanksgiving for all men unto the Only-Begotten of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:116
verses.text: What, he says, if others do blaspheme? Still we who know His mysteries, and His unspeakable Wisdom, and great Providence over us, know well that it is not to be blasphemed, but to be glorified, that He is worthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:117
verses.text: Still not satisfied with being himself conscious of it, he endeavors next to use arguments, and to use a sharper way of speech against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:118
verses.text: And he does not direct his aim at them, without first divesting them of a suspicion they had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:119
verses.text: Lest then he should seem to be addressing them as enemies, further on he says "Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they might be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:120
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:121
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:122
verses.text: ) And here, along with other remarks, he so ordered things, as not to seem to be saying what he was going to say out of enmity against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:123
verses.text: Hence he does not decline calling them even kinsmen and brothers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:124
verses.text: For even if it was for Christ's sake that he said what he did, still he is for drawing (ἐπισπἅται) their mind to him also, and paves his way to what he has to say, and quits himself of all suspicion owing to what had to be said against them, and then he at last goes into the subject most of them were looking for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:125
verses.text: For many, as I have already stated, wanted to know what was the reason why they who had received the promise fell short of it, while those who had even never heard of it were saved before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:126
verses.text: Therefore, to clear up this difficulty, he brings forward the answer before the objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:127
verses.text: For to prevent any from saying, What? Art thou more thoughtful for God's glory than God is for His own? And does He need thy aid that His word may not fall to the ground? In reply to these things he says, I spoke this not as if God's Word had fallen to the ground, but to show my love for Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:128
verses.text: For as things have had this issue, we are in no want of words in God's behalf, or of showing that stand His promise did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:129
verses.text: God said to Abraham, "To thee and to thy seed will I give the land".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:130
verses.text: And, "In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:131
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:132
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:133
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:134
verses.text: ) Let us see then, he says, of what sort this seed is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:135
verses.text: For it is not all that are from him that are his seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:136
verses.text: Whence he says, "For they are not all Israel that are of (or from) Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:138
verses.text: "Neither, because they are the seed of Abraham, are they all children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:139
verses.text: Now when you come to know of what kind the seed of Abraham is, you will see that the promise is given to his seed, and know that the word hath not fallen to the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:140
verses.text: Of what kind, pray, is the seed then? It is no saying of mine, he means, but the Old Testament itself explains itself by saying as follows, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:141
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:142
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:143
verses.text: ) What is, "In Isaac?" Explain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:144
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:145
verses.text: "That is, they which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise, these are counted for the seed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:146
verses.text: And observe the judgment and depth of Paul's mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:147
verses.text: For in interpreting, he does not say, "they which are the children of the flesh, these are not" the children of Abraham, but, "the children of God:" so blending the former things with the present, and showing that even Isaac was not merely Abraham's son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:148
verses.text: And what he means is something of this sort: as many as have been born as Isaac was, they are sons of God, and of the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:149
verses.text: And this is why he said, "in Isaac shall thy seed be called".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:150
verses.text: That one may learn that they who are born after the fashion of Isaac, these are in the truest sense Abraham's children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:151
verses.text: In what way was Isaac born then? Not according to the law of nature, not according to the power of the flesh, but according to the power of the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:152
verses.text: What is meant then by the power of "the promise?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:153
verses.text: "At this time will I come, and Sarah shall have a son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:154
verses.text: This promise then and word of God it was that fashioned Isaac, and begat him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:155
verses.text: For what if a womb was its instrument and the belly of a woman? Since it was not the power of the belly, but the might of the promise that begat the child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:156
verses.text: Thus are we also gendered by the words of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:157
verses.text: Since in the pool of water it is the words of God which generate and fashion us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:158
verses.text: For it is by being baptized into the Name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost that we are gendered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:159
verses.text: And this birth is not of nature, but of the promise of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:160
verses.text: (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:161
verses.text: ; Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:162
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:163
verses.text: ; James i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:164
verses.text: ;  Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:165
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:166
verses.text: ) For as after first foretelling the birth of Isaac, He then accomplished it; so ours also He had announced before, many ages ago by all the Prophets, and afterwards brought it to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:167
verses.text: You know how great He has set it forth as being, and how, as He promised a great thing, He furnished it with abundant ease! (Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:168
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:169
verses.text: , etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:170
verses.text: ) But if the Jews were to say, that the words, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called," mean this, that those born of Isaac should be reckoned to him for a seed, then the Edomites too, and all those people, ought to be denominated his sons, since their forefather Esau was a son of his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:171
verses.text: But now so far are they from being called sons, that they are the greatest possible aliens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:172
verses.text: You see then that it is not the children of the flesh that are the children of God, but that even in nature itself the generation by means of baptism from above was sketched out beforehand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:173
verses.text: And if you tell me of the womb, I in return have to tell you of the water.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:174
verses.text: But as in this case all is of the Spirit, so in the other all was of promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:175
verses.text: For the womb was more chilled than any water owing to barrenness and to old age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:176
verses.text: Let us then gain accurate knowledge of our own nobility, and display a life worthy of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:177
verses.text: For in it is nothing fleshly or earthy: hence neither let there be in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:178
verses.text: For it was neither sleep, nor the will of the flesh (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:179
verses.text: ), nor embraces, nor the madness of desire, but "God's love toward man," which wrought the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:180
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:181
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:182
verses.text: ) And as in that case it was when the age was past hope, so in this also it was when the old age of sins had come over us, that Isaac suddenly sprang up in youth, and we all became the children of God, and the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:183
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:184
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:185
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:186
verses.text: "And not only this; but when Rebecca also had conceived by one, even by our father Isaac".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:187
verses.text: The subject in question was an important one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:188
verses.text: Hence he turns to several arguments, and endeavors by all means to solve the difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:189
verses.text: For if it was at once strange and new for them to be cast out after so great promises, it is much more strange that we even should come into their good things, who did not expect anything of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:190
verses.text: And the case was the same as if a king's son, who had promises made him that he should succeed to the power he had, were to be cast into the level of disreputable men, and in his place a condemned man, and one laden with evils unnumbered, after being taken out of prison, were to come into the power, which properly was the other's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:191
verses.text: For he means, what have you to say? that the son is unworthy? Well, but so is this man unworthy, and much more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:192
verses.text: Hence he ought either to have been punished along with the former, or to have been honored along with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:193
verses.text: Now it was something of this sort which befel the Jews and the Gentiles, or something far more strange than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:194
verses.text: Now that all were unworthy, he has shown above, where he says, "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:195
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:196
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:197
verses.text: ) But the new thing is, that when all were unworthy, the Gentiles were saved alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:198
verses.text: And beside this there is another difficulty that some one may start, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:199
verses.text: If God had no intention of fulfilling the promises to them, why make them at all? For men who know not the future, and are many times deceived, do promise even the undeserving that they shall have their largesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:200
verses.text: But He Who knoweth beforehand things to come as well as things present, and hath a clear knowledge that they will make themselves undeserving of the promises, and therefore will not receive any of the things specified,—why should He promise at all? Now what is Paul's way of meeting all this? It is by showing what the Israel is to whom He made the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:201
verses.text: For when this has been shown, there is at the same time demonstrated the fact that the promises were all fulfilled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:202
verses.text: And to point this out he said, "For they are not all Israel that are of Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:203
verses.text: And this is why he does not use the name of Jacob, but that of Israel, which was a sign of the virtue of that just man, and of a gift from above, and of having seen God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:204
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:205
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:206
verses.text: ) Yet, "all," he says, "have sinned, and come short of the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:207
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:208
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:209
verses.text: ) Now if all have sinned, how come some to be saved, and some to perish? It is because all were not minded to come to Him, since for His part all were saved, for all were called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:210
verses.text: However, he does not set this down yet awhile, but meets it from an advantageous position, and from other examples, by bringing before them another question, and as in the former case meets a difficulty very great, by another difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:211
verses.text: For when he was discussing how by Christ being justified all the rest enjoyed that righteousness, he brought in Adam's case, saying, "For if by one man's offence death reigned, much more they which receive abundance of grace shall reign in life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:212
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:213
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:214
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:215
verses.text: And the case of Adam, indeed, he does not clear up, but from it he clears up His (or his own), and shows that it was more reasonable that He Who died in their behalf should have power over them at His will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:216
verses.text: For that when one had sinned all should be punished, does not seem to be so very reasonable to most men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:217
verses.text: But that when One had done aright all should be justified, is at once more reasonable and more suited to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:218
verses.text: Yet still he has not solved the difficulty he raised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:219
