verses.text: For the more obscure that point remained, the more the Jew was put to silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:220
verses.text: And the difficulty of his position passed over to the other, and this become clearer from it (Mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:221
verses.text: and  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:222
verses.text: "than that").

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:223
verses.text: So in this passage also, it is by raising other difficulties that he meets the questions raised, inasmuch as it was against Jews that he was contending.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:224
verses.text: Hence he takes no pains to solve the examples which he has brought before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:225
verses.text: For he was not answerable for them as in the fight against the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:226
verses.text: But from them he makes his own subject throughout clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:227
verses.text: Why do you feel surprised, he means, that some of the Jews were saved, and some not saved at this time? Why of old, in the patriarch's times, one may see this happening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:228
verses.text: For why was Isaac only called the seed, and yet he was the father of Ishmael also, and of several others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:229
verses.text: "But he was of a mother that was a slave".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:230
verses.text: And what has this to do with his father? Still I will not be captious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:231
verses.text: Let this son be set aside on his mother's account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:232
verses.text: What are we to say of those sprung from Keturah? were they not free, and from a mother that was free? How came they not to be honored with the same preference as Isaac? And why do I speak of these? for Rebecca was even Isaac's only wife, and bearing two children she bore them both to Isaac; still those so born, though of the same father, and the same mother, and the fruit of the same labor, being both of one father and one mother, and twins besides, yet did not enjoy the same lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:233
verses.text: And yet here you have no mother's slavery to account for it, as in Ishmael's case, nor can you say that one was begotten of this womb and the other of a different one, as in the case of Keturah and Sarah, since in this case they had the same hour in common to them for their birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:234
verses.text: This was why Paul then, in order to give a clearer example, says that this happened not in Isaac's case only, "but when Rebecca also had conceived by one, even by our father Isaac".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:235
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:236
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:237
verses.text: "For the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works, but of him that calleth, it was said unto her, the elder shall serve the younger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:238
verses.text: As it is written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:239
verses.text: What was the cause then why one was loved and the other hated? why was it that one served, the other was served? It was because one was wicked, and the other good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:240
verses.text: And yet the children being not yet born, one was honored and the other condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:241
verses.text: For when they were not as yet born, God said, "the elder shall serve the younger".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:242
verses.text: With what intent then did God say this? Because He doth not wait, as man doth, to see from the issue of their acts the good and him who is not so, but even before these He knoweth which is the wicked and which not such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:243
verses.text: And this took place in the Israelites' case also, in a still more wonderful way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:244
verses.text: Why, he says, do I speak of Esau and of Jacob, of whom one was wicked and the other good? For in the Israelites' case, the sin belonged to all, since they all worshipped the calf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:245
verses.text: Yet notwithstanding some had mercy shown them, and others had not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:246
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:247
verses.text: "For I will have mercy, He says, on whom I will have mercy, and I will show compassion on whom I will show compassion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:248
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:249
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:250
verses.text: )  This one may see also in the case of those who are punished, for what would you say of Pharaoh who was punished, and had to pay so heavy a penalty? You say he was hardened and disobedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:251
verses.text: Was he then alone such, and not even one person else? How came he then to be so severely punished? Why even in the case of the Jews did he call that a people which was no people, or again, why not count all worthy of equal honor? "For if they be" (it says) "as the sand of the sea, yet shall a remnant be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:252
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:253
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:254
verses.text: ) And why is it to be only a remnant? You see what difficulty he has filled the subject with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:255
verses.text: And with great propriety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:256
verses.text: For when you have power to throw your adversary into perplexity, do not at once bring forward the answer, because if he be found himself responsible for the same ignorance, why take unnecessary dangers upon yourself? Why make him more bold, by drawing it all upon yourself? Now tell me, O thou Jew, that hast so many perplexing questions, and art unable to answer any of them, how thou comest to annoy us on account of the call of the Gentiles? I, however, have a good reason to give you why the Gentiles were justified and ye were cast out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:257
verses.text: And what is the reason? It is that they are of faith, ye of the works of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:258
verses.text: And it is owing to this obstinacy of yours that ye have in every way (Mar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:259
verses.text: and several mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:260
verses.text: all) been given up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:261
verses.text: For, "they being ignorant of God's righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:262
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:263
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:264
verses.text: ) The clearing up then of the whole passage, to give the whole sense summarily, is here brought out by that blessed person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:265
verses.text: But that this may be clearer, let us investigate the things he says also one by one; this knowing, that what the blessed Paul aimed at was, to show by all that he said that God only knoweth who are worthy, and no man whatever knoweth, even if he seem to know ever so well, but that in this sentence of his there are sundry aberrations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:266
verses.text: For He that knoweth the secrets of the hearts, He only knoweth for a certainty who deserve a crown, and who punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:267
verses.text: Hence it is that many of those, by men esteemed good, He convicts and punishes, and those suspected to be bad He crowns, after showing it not to be so; thus forming his sentence not after the judgment of us slaves, but after his own keen and uncorrupt decision, and not waiting for the issue of actions to look at the wicked and him who is not so therefrom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:268
verses.text: But that we may not make the subject more obscure, again let us go to the very words of the Apostle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:269
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:270
verses.text: "And not only this, but when Rebecca also had conceived by one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:271
verses.text: I might, he implies, have mentioned the children by Keturah besides, but I do not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:272
verses.text: But to gain the victory from a vantage ground it is those born of one and the same father, and mother too, that I bring forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:273
verses.text: For they were both sprung from Rebecca, and from Isaac the true-born, the elect, the son honored above all, of whom He said, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called," who became "the father of us all;" but if he was our father, then should his sons have been our fathers; yet it was not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:274
verses.text: You see how this happens not in Abraham's case only, but also in that of his son himself, and how it is faith and virtue in all cases that is conspicuous, and gives the real relationship its character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:275
verses.text: For hence we learn that it is not only from the manner of birth, but owing to their being worthy of the father's virtue, that the children are called children of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:276
verses.text: For if it were only owing to the manner of the birth, then ought Esau to have enjoyed the same as Jacob did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:277
verses.text: For he also was from a womb as good as dead, and his mother was barren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:278
verses.text: Yet this was not the only thing required, but the character too, which fact contributes no common amount of practical instruction for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:279
verses.text: And he does not say that one is good and another bad, and so the former was honored; lest this kind of argument should be wielded against him, "What, are those of the Gentiles good men rather than those of the circumcision?" For even supposing the truth of the matter was so, still he does not state it yet, as that would have seemed to be vexatious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:280
verses.text: But it is upon God's knowledge that he has cast the whole, and this no one would venture to gainsay, though he were ever so frantic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:281
verses.text: "For the children being not yet born," he says, "it was said unto her, The elder shall serve the younger".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:282
verses.text: And he shows that noble birth after the flesh is of no avail, but we must seek for virtue of soul, which even before the works of it God knoweth of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:283
verses.text: For "the children," he says, "being not yet born, nor having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, it was said unto her that the elder shall serve the younger:" for this was a sign of foreknowledge, that they were chosen from the very birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:284
verses.text: That the election made according to foreknowledge, might be manifestly of God, from the first day He at once saw and proclaimed which was good and which not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:285
verses.text: Do not then tell me that thou hast read the Law (he means) and the Prophets, and hast been a servant for such a long time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:286
verses.text: For He that knoweth how to assay the soul, knoweth which is worthy of being saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:287
verses.text: Yield then to the incomprehensibleness of the election.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:288
verses.text: For it is He alone Who knoweth how to crown aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:289
verses.text: How many, for instance, seemed better than St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:290
verses.text: Matthew; to go by the exhibition of works then visible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:291
verses.text: But He that knoweth things undeclared, and is able to assay the mind's aptitude, knew the pearl though lying in the mire, and after passing by others, and being well pleased with the beauty of this, He elected it, and by adding to the noble born free-will grace from Himself, He made it approved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:292
verses.text: For if in the case of these arts which are perishable, and indeed in other matters, those that are good judges do not use the grounds on which the uninstructed form their decision, in selecting out of what is put before them; but from points which they are themselves well aware of, they many times disparage that which the uninstructed approve, and decide upon what they disparage: and horse-breakers often do this with horses, and so the judges of precious stones, and workmen in other arts: much more will the God that loveth man, the infinite Wisdom, Who alone hath a clear knowledge of all things, not allow of man's guesses, but will out of His own exact and unfailing Wisdom pass his sentence upon all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:293
verses.text: Hence it was that He chose the publican, the thief, and the harlot; but dishonored priests, and elders, and rulers, and cast them out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:294
verses.text: And this one may see happening in the martyrs' case also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:295
verses.text: Many accordingly of those who were utterly cast aside, have in the time of trial been crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:296
verses.text: And, on the other hand, some that have been held great ones by many have stumbled and fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:297
verses.text: Do not then call the Creator to account, nor say, Why is it that one was crowned and another punished? For He knoweth how to do these things with exactness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:298
verses.text: Whence also he says, "Jacob have I loved, and Esau have I hated".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:299
verses.text: That it was with justice, you indeed know from the result: but Himself even before the result knew it clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:300
verses.text: For it is not a mere exhibition of works that God searcheth after, but a nobleness of choice and an obedient temper (γνώμην εὐγνώμονα) besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:301
verses.text: For a man of this kind, if he should ever sin through some surprise, will speedily recover himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:302
verses.text: And if he should even stay long haply in a state of vice, he will not be overlooked, but God Who knoweth all things will speedily draw him out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:303
verses.text: And so he that is herein corrupted, even if he seem to do some good things, will perish, in that he doth this with an ill intention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:304
verses.text: Hence even David, after committing murder and adultery, since he did this as being carried away by surprise, and not from habitual practice of wickedness, speedily washed it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:305
verses.text: The Pharisee, however, who had not perpetrated any such crime (Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:306
verses.text: ), but even had good deeds besides to boast of, lost all by the bad spirit he had chosen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:307
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:308
verses.text: "What shall we say then? Is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:309
verses.text: Hence there is no such thing in the case of us and the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:310
verses.text: And then he goes on with another thing, a more clear than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:311
verses.text: And of what sort is it?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:312
verses.text: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:313
verses.text: Here again he adds force to the objection by dividing it in two and meeting it, and starting another fresh difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:314
verses.text: But to make what I have said clearer, one must needs explain it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:315
verses.text: God, he means, said that "the elder shall serve the younger," before the travail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:316
verses.text: What then? "Is God unrighteous?" By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:317
verses.text: Now listen to what follows also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:318
verses.text: For in that case the virtue or the vice, might be the decisive thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:319
verses.text: But here there was one sin on which all the Jews joined, that of the molten calf, and still some were punished, and some were not punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:320
verses.text: And this is why He says, "I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:321
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:322
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:323
verses.text: : observe context.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:324
verses.text: ) For it is not thine to know, O Moses, he means, which are deserving of My love toward man, but leave this to Me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:325
verses.text: But if Moses had no right to know, much less have we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:326
verses.text: And this is why he did not barely quote the passage, but also called to our minds to whom it was said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:327
verses.text: For it is Moses, he means, that he is speaking to, that at least by the dignity of the person he might make the objector modest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:328
verses.text: Having then given a solution of the difficulties raised, he divides it in two, by bringing forward another objection besides, as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:329
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:330
verses.text: "So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that showeth mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:331
verses.text: For the Scripture saith unto Pharaoh, Even for this same purpose have I raised thee up, that I might show my power in thee, and that my name might be declared throughout all the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:332
verses.text: As then in the one case, he means, some were saved and some were punished, so here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:333
verses.text: This man was reserved for this very purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:334
verses.text: And then he again urges the objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:335
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:336
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:337
verses.text: "Therefore He hath mercy on whom He will have mercy, and whom He will He hardeneth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:338
verses.text: Thou wilt say then unto me, Why doth he then find fault? For who hath resisted His will?"  See what pains he takes to embarrass the subject in every way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:339
verses.text: And the answer he does not produce forthwith, it being a useful thing not to do so, but he first stops the disputant's mouth, saying as follows,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:340
verses.text: "Nay but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God?"  This he does to take down the objector's unseasonable inquisitiveness, and excessive curiosity, and to put a check upon it, and teach him to know what God is, and what man, and how incomprehensible His foreknowledge is, and how far above our reason, and how obedience to Him in all points is binding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:341
verses.text: So when he has made this preparatory step in his hearer, and has hushed and softened down his spirit, then with great felicity he introduces the answer, having made what he says easy of admittance with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:342
verses.text: And he does not say, it is impossible to answer questions of this kind, but that ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:343
verses.text: No, but what? that) it is presumptuous to raise them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:344
verses.text: For our business is to obey what God does, not to be curious even if we do not know the reason of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:345
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "Who art thou that repliest against God?" You see how very light he makes of him, how he bears down his swelling spirit! "Who art thou?" art thou a sharer of His power? (compare Job xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:346
verses.text: ) nay, art thou sitting in judgment upon God? Why in comparison with Him thou canst not have a being even! nor this or that sort of being, but absolutely none! For the expression, "who art thou?" doth much more set him at naught than "thou art nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:347
verses.text: And he takes other ways of showing further his indignation in the question, and does not say, "Who art thou that" answerest "God?" but, "that repliest against," that is, that gainsayest, and that opposest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:348
verses.text: For the saying things ought to be so, and ought not to be so, is what a man does that "replieth against".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:349
verses.text: See how he scares them, how he terrifies them, how he makes them tremble rather than be questioning and curious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:350
verses.text: This is what an excellent teacher does; he does not follow his disciples' fancy everywhere, but leads them to his own mind, and pulls up the thorns, and then puts the seed in, and does not answer at once in all cases to the questions put to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:351
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:352
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:353
verses.text: "Shall the thing formed say to Him that formed it, Why hast Thou made me thus? Hath not the potter (Read Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:354
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:355
verses.text: –) power, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honor, and another unto dishonor?"  Here it is not to do away with free-will that he says this, but to show, up to what point we ought to obey God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:356
verses.text: For in respect of calling God to account, we ought to be as little disposed to it as the clay is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:357
verses.text: For we ought to abstain not from gainsaying or questioning only, but even from speaking or thinking of it at all, and to become like that lifeless matter, which followeth the potter's hands, and lets itself be drawn about anywhere he may please.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:358
verses.text: And this is the only point he applied the illustration to, not, that is, to any enunciation of the rule of life, but to the complete obedience and silence enforced upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:359
verses.text: And this we ought to observe in all cases, that we are not to take the illustrations quite entire, but after selecting the good of them, and that for which they were introduced, to let the rest alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:360
verses.text: As, for instance, when he says, "He couched, he lay down as a lion;" (Numb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:361
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:362
verses.text: ) let us take out the indomitable and fearful part, not the brutality, nor any other of the things belonging to a lion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:363
verses.text: And again, when He says, "I will meet them as a bereaved bear" (Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:364
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:365
verses.text: ), let us take the vindictiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:366
verses.text: And when he says, "our God is a consuming fire" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:367
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:368
verses.text: ; and Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:369
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:370
verses.text: ), the wasting power exerted in punishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:371
verses.text: So also here must we single out the clay, the potter, and the vessels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:372
verses.text: And when he does go on to say, "Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honor, and another unto dishonor?" do not suppose that this is said by Paul as an account of the creation, nor as implying a necessity over the will, but to illustrate the sovereignty and difference of dispensations; for if we do not take it in this way, divers incongruities will follow, for if here he were speaking about the will, and those who are good and those not so, He will be Himself the Maker of these, and man will be free from all responsibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:373
verses.text: And at this rate, Paul will also be shown to be at variance with himself, as he always bestows chief honor upon free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:374
verses.text: There is nothing else then which he here wishes to do, save to persuade the hearer to yield entirely to God, and at no time to call Him to account for anything whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:375
verses.text: For as the potter (he says) of the same lump makes what he pleaseth, and no one forbids it; thus also when God, of the same race of men, punisheth some, and honoreth others, be not thou curious nor meddlesome herein, but worship only, and imitate the clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:376
verses.text: And as it followeth the hands of the potter, so do thou also the mind of Him that so ordereth things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:377
verses.text: For He worketh nothing at random, or mere hazard, though thou be ignorant of the secret of His Wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:378
verses.text: Yet thou allowest the other of the same lump to make divers things, and findest no fault: but of Him you demand an account of His punishments and honors, and will not allow Him to know who is worthy and who is not so; but since the same lump is of the same substance, you assert that there are the same dispositions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:379
verses.text: And, how monstrous this is! And yet not even is it on the potter that the honor and the dishonor of the things made of the lump depends, but upon the use made by those that handle them, so here also it depends on the free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:380
verses.text: Still, as I said before, one must take this illustration to have one bearing only, which is that one should not contravene God, but yield to His incomprehensible Wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:381
verses.text: For the examples ought to be greater than the subject, and than the things on account of which they are brought forward, so as to draw on the hearer better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:382
verses.text: Since if they were not greater and did not mount far above it, he could not attack as he ought, and shame the objectors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:383
verses.text: However, their ill-timed obstinacy he silenced in this way with becoming superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:384
verses.text: And then he introduces his answer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:385
verses.text: Now what is the answer?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:386
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:387
verses.text: "What if God, willing to show His wrath, and to make His power known, endured with much long-suffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction: and that He might make known the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy, which He had afore prepared unto glory, even us, whom He hath chosen, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:388
verses.text: What he means is somewhat as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:389
verses.text: Pharaoh was a vessel of wrath, that is, a man who by his own hard-heartedness had kindled the wrath of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:390
verses.text: For after enjoying much long-suffering, he became no better, but remained unimproved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:391
verses.text: Wherefore he calleth him not only "a vessel of wrath," but also one "fitted for destruction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:392
verses.text: That is, fully fitted indeed, but by his own proper self.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:393
verses.text: For neither had God left out aught of the things likely to recover him, nor did he leave out aught of those that would ruin him, and put him beyond any forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:394
verses.text: Yet still, though God knew this, "He endured him with much long-suffering," being willing to bring him to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:395
verses.text: For had He not willed this, then He would not have been thus long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:396
verses.text: But as he would not use the long-suffering in order to repentance, but fully fitted himself for wrath, He used him for the correction of others, through the punishment inflicted upon him making them better, and in this way setting forth His power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:397
verses.text: For that it is not God's wish that His power be so made known, but in another way, by His benefits, namely, and kindnesses, he had shown above in all possible ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:398
verses.text: For if Paul does not wish to appear powerful in this way ("not that we should appear approved," he says, "but that ye should do that which is honest,") ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:399
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:400
verses.text: ), much less doth God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:401
verses.text: But after that he had shown long-suffering, that He might lead to repentance, but he did not repent, He suffered him a long time, that He might display at once His goodness and His power, even if that man were not minded to gain anything from this great long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:402
verses.text: As then by punishing this man, who continued incorrigible, He showed His power, so by having pitied those who had done many sins but repented, He manifested His love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:403
verses.text: But it does not say, love towards man, but glory, to show that this is especially God's glory, and for this He was above all things earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:404
verses.text: But in saying, "which He had afore prepared unto glory," he does not mean that all is God's doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:405
verses.text: Since if this were so, there were nothing to hinder all men from being saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:406
verses.text: But he is setting forth again His foreknowledge, and doing away with the difference between the Jews and the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:407
verses.text: And on this topic again he grounds a defence of his statement, which is no small one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:408
verses.text: For it was not in the case of the Jews only that some men perished, and some were saved, but with the Gentiles also this was the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:409
verses.text: Wherefore he does not say, all the Gentiles, but, "of the Gentiles," nor, all the Jews, but, "of the Jews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:410
verses.text: As then Pharaoh became a vessel of wrath by his own lawlessness, so did these become vessels of mercy by their own readiness to obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:411
verses.text: For though the more part is of God, still they also have contributed themselves some little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:412
verses.text: Whence he does not say either, vessels of well-doing, or vessels of boldness (παρρησίας), but "vessels of mercy," to show that the whole is of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:413
verses.text: For the phrase, "it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth," even if it comes in the course of the objection, still, were it said by Paul, would create no difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:414
verses.text: Because when he says, "it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth," he does not deprive us of free-will, but shows that all is not one's own, for that it requires grace from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:415
verses.text: For it is binding on us to will, and also to run: but to confide not in our own labors, but in the love of God toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:416
verses.text: And this he has expressed elsewhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:417
verses.text: "Yet not I, but the grace which was with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:418
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:419
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:420
verses.text: ) And he well says, "Which He had afore prepared unto glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:421
verses.text: For since they reproached them with this, that they were saved by grace, and thought to make them ashamed, he far more than sets aside this insinuation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:422
verses.text: For if the thing brought glory even to God, much more to them through whom God was glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:423
verses.text: But observe his forbearance, and unspeakable wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:424
verses.text: For when he had it in his power to adduce, as an instance of those punished, not Pharaoh, but such of the Jews as had sinned, and so make his discourse much clearer, and show that where there were the same fathers, and the same sins, some perished, and some had mercy shown them, and persuade them not to be doubtful-minded, even if some of the Gentiles were saved, while the Jews were perishing; that he might not make his discourse irksome, the showing forth of the punishment he draws from the foreigner, so that he may not be forced to call them "vessels of wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:425
verses.text: But those that obtained mercy he draws from the people of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:426
verses.text: And besides, he also has spoken in a sufficient way in God's behalf, because though He knew very well that the nation was fitting itself as a vessel of destruction, still He contributed all on His part, His patience, His long-suffering, and that not merely long-suffering, but "much long-suffering;" yet still he was not minded to state it barely against the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:427
verses.text: Whence then are some vessels of wrath, and some of mercy? Of their own free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:428
verses.text: God, however, being very good, shows the same kindness to both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:429
verses.text: For it was not those in a state of salvation only to whom He showed mercy, but also Pharaoh, as far as His part went.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:430
verses.text: For of the same long-suffering, both they and he had the advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:431
verses.text: And if he was not saved, it was quite owing to his own will: since, as for what concerneth God, he had as much done for him as they who were saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:432
verses.text: Having then given to the question that answer which was furnished by facts, in order to give his discourse the advantage of other testimony in its favor, he introduces the prophets also making the same declarations aforetime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:433
verses.text: For Hosea, he says, of old put this in writing, as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:434
verses.text: "I will call them My people, which were not My people; and her beloved, which was not beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:435
verses.text: Here to prevent their saying, that you are deceiving us here with specious reasoning, he calls Hosea to witness, who crieth and saith, "I will call them My people, who were not My people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:436
verses.text: (Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:437
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:438
verses.text: ) Who then are the not-people? Plainly, the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:439
verses.text: And who the not-beloved? The same again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:440
verses.text: However, he says, that they shall become at once people, and beloved, and sons of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:441
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:442
verses.text: "For even they shall be called," he says, "the children of the living God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:443
verses.text: But if they should assert that this was said of those of the Jews who believed, even then the argument stands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:444
verses.text: For if with those who after so many benefits were hard-hearted and estranged, and had lost their being as a people, so great a change was wrought, what is there to prevent even those who were not estranged after being taken to Him, but were originally aliens, from being called, and, provided they obey, from being counted worthy of the same blessings? Having then done with Hosea, he does not content himself with him only, but also brings Isaiah in after him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:445
verses.text: sounding in harmony with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:446
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:447
verses.text: "For Esaias," he says, "crieth concerning Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:448
verses.text: That is, speaks out boldly, and uses no dissimulation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:449
verses.text: Why then lay a charge against us, when they afore declared the same thing with more than trumpet's loudness? And what does Isaiah cry? "Though the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:450
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:451
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:452
verses.text: )  Do you see that he too does not say that all are to be saved, but that those that are worthy shall? For I regard not the multitude, he means, nor does a race diffused so far distress me, but those only do I save that yield themselves worthy of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:453
verses.text: And he does not mention the "sand of the sea" without a reason, but to remind them of the ancient promise whereof they had made themselves unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:454
verses.text: Why then are you troubled, as though the promise had failed, when all the Prophets show that it is not all that are to be saved? Then he mentions the mode of the salvation also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:455
verses.text: Observe the accuracy of the Prophet, and the judgment of the Apostle, what a testimony he has cited, how exceedingly apposite! For it not only shows us that those to be saved are some and not all, but also adds the way they are to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:456
verses.text: How then are they to be saved, and how will God count them worthy of the benefit?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:457
verses.text: "He will finish the work, and cut it short in righteousness," he says, "because a short work will the Lord make upon the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:458
verses.text: (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:459
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:460
verses.text: )  What he means then is somewhat of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:461
verses.text: There is no need of fetching a circuit, and of trouble, and the vexation of the works of the Law, for the salvation is by a very short way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:462
verses.text: For such is faith, it holds salvation in a few short words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:463
verses.text: "For if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and believe in thine heart that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:464
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:465
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:466
verses.text: ) Now you see what this, "the Lord shall make a short word (LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:467
verses.text: lit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:468
verses.text: ) upon earth," is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:469
verses.text: And what is indeed wonderful is, that this short word carries with it not salvation only, but also righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:470
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:471
verses.text: "And as Esaias said before, Except the Lord of Sabaoth had left us a seed, we had been as Sodoma, and had been made like unto Gomorrha".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:472
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:473
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:474
verses.text: )  Here again he shows another thing, that not even those few were saved from their own resources.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:475
verses.text: For they too would have perished, and met with Sodom's fate, that is, they would have had to undergo utter destruction (for they (of Sodom) were also destroyed root and branch, and left not even the slightest remnant of themselves,) and they too, he means, would have been like these, unless God had used much kindness to them, and had saved them by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:476
verses.text: And this happened also in the case of the visible captivity, the majority having been taken away captive and perished, and some few only being saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:477
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:478
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:479
verses.text: "What shall we say then? That the Gentiles, which followed not after righteousness, have attained to righteousness, even the righteousness which is by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:480
verses.text: But Israel, which followed after the law of righteousness, hath not attained to the law of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:481
verses.text: Here at last is the clearest answer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:482
verses.text: For since he had used a proof as well from facts ("for they are not all Israel that are of Israel") as from the case of the forefathers Jacob and Esau, and from the prophets Hosea and Isaiah, he further gives the most decisive answer, after first adding to the perplexity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:483
verses.text: The points discussed, then, are two; one that the Gentiles attained, and the other that they attained it without following after it, that is, without taking pains about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:484
verses.text: And again in the Jews' case also there are two difficulties of the same kind; one that Israel attained not, the other that, though they took pains, they attained not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:485
verses.text: Whence also his use of words is more emphatical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:486
verses.text: For he does not say that they had, but that they "attained to righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:487
verses.text: For what is especially new and unusual is, that they who followed after it attained not, but they which followed not after it attained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:488
verses.text: And he seems to be indulging them by saying, "followed after".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:489
verses.text: But afterwards he strikes the blow home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:490
verses.text: For since he had a strong answer to give them, he had no fear of making the objection a little harsher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:491
verses.text: Hence he doth not speak of faith either, and the righteousness ensuing thereon, but shows that before the faith even, on their own ground they were worsted and condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:492
verses.text: For thou, O Jew, he says, hast not found even the righteousness which was by the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:493
verses.text: For thou hast transgressed it, and become liable to the curse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:494
verses.text: But these that came not through the Law, but by another road, have found a greater righteousness than this, that, namely, which is of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:495
verses.text: And this he had also said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:496
verses.text: "For if Abraham was justified by works, he hath whereof to glory, but not before God" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:497
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:498
verses.text: ): so showing that the other righteousness was greater than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:499
verses.text: Before, then, I said that there were two difficulties, but now they have even become three questions: that the Gentiles found righteousness, and found it without following after it, and found a greater than that of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:500
verses.text: These same difficulties are again felt in the Jews' case with an opposite view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:501
verses.text: That Israel did not find, and though he took pains he did not find, and did not find even the less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:502
verses.text: Having then thrust his hearer into perplexity, he proceeds to give a concise answer, and tells him the cause of all that is said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:503
verses.text: When then is the cause?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:504
verses.text: "Because they sought it not by faith, but as it were by the works of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:505
verses.text: This is the clearest answer in the passage, which if he had said immediately upon starting, he would not have gained so easy a hearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:506
verses.text: But since it is after many perplexities, and preparations, and demonstrations that he sets it down, and after using countless preparatory steps, he has at last made it more intelligible, and also more easily admitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:507
verses.text: For this he says is the cause of their destruction: "Because it was not by faith, but as it were by the works of the Law," that they wished to be justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:508
verses.text: And he does not say, "by works," but, "as it were by the works of the Law," to show that they had not even this righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:509
verses.text: "For they stumbled at that stumbling-stone;"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:510
verses.text: "As it is written, Behold I lay in Sion a stumbling-stone, and rock of offence: and whosoever believeth on Him shall not be ashamed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:511
verses.text: You see again how it is from faith that the boldness comes, and the gift is universal; since it is not of the Jews only that this is said, but also of the whole human race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:512
verses.text: For every one, he would say, whether Jew, or Grecian, or Scythian, or Thracian, or whatsoever else he may be, will, if he believes, enjoy the privilege of great boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:513
verses.text: But the wonder in the Prophet is that he foretells not only that they should believe, but also that they should not believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:514
verses.text: For to stumble is to disbelieve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:515
verses.text: As in the former passage he points out them that perish and them that are saved, where he says, "If the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, the remnant shall be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:516
verses.text: And, If the Lord of Sabaoth had not left us a seed, we should have been as Sodoma".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:517
verses.text: And, "He hath called not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles;" so here too he implies that some will believe, and some will stumble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:518
verses.text: But stumbling comes of not taking heed, of gaping after other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:519
verses.text: Since then they did give heed to the Law, they stumbled on the stone, "And a stone of stumbling and rock of offence" he calls it from the character and end of those that believe not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:520
verses.text: Is then the language used made plain to you? or does it still want much in clearness? I think indeed that, to those who have been attending, it is easy to get a clear view of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:521
verses.text: But if it has slipped anybody's memory, you can meet in private, and learn what it was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:522
verses.text: And this is why I have continued longer upon this explanatory part of the discourse, that I might not be compelled to break off the continuity of the context, and so spoil the clearness of the statements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:523
verses.text: And for this cause too I will bring my discourse to a conclusion here, without saying anything to you on the more immediately practical points, as I generally do, lest I should make a fresh indistinctness in your memories by saying so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:524
verses.text: It is time now to come to the proper conclusion, by shutting up the discourse with the doxology to the God of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:525
verses.text: Let us then both pause, me that am speaking and you that are hearing, and offer up glory to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 17:526
verses.text: For His is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:1
verses.text: Homily XVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:3
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:4
verses.text: "Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for them is, that they might be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:5
verses.text: He is now going again to rebuke them more vehemently than before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:6
verses.text: Wherefore he again does away with every suspicion of hatred, and makes a great effort beforehand to correct misapprehension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:7
verses.text: Do not then, he says, mind words or accusations, but observe that it is not in any hostile spirit that I say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:8
verses.text: For it is not likely that the same person should desire their salvation, and not desire it only, but even pray for it, and yet should also hate them, and feel aversion to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:9
verses.text: For here he calls his exceeding desire, and the prayer which he makes (εὐδοκίαν), "heart's desire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:10
verses.text: For it is not the being freed from punishment only, but that they may also be saved, that he makes so great a point of, and prays for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:11
verses.text: Nor is it from this only, but also from the sequel that he shows the goodwill that he hath towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:12
verses.text: For from what is open to him, as far as he can, he forces his way, and is contentious to find out some shadow at least of an excuse for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:13
verses.text: And he hath not the power, being overcome by the nature of the facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:14
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:15
verses.text: "For I bear them record," says he, "that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:16
verses.text: Ought not this then to be a ground for pardoning and not for accusing them? For if it is not of man that they are separated, but through zeal, they deserved to be pitied rather than punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:17
verses.text: But observe how adroitly he favors them in the word, and yet shows their unseasonable obstinacy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:18
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:19
verses.text: "For they being ignorant," he says, "of God's righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:20
verses.text: Again the word would lead to pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:21
verses.text: But the sequel to stronger accusation, and such as does away with defence of any kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:22
verses.text: "And going about," he says, "to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:23
verses.text: And these things he says to show, that it was from a petulancy and love of power that they erred, rather than from ignorance, and that not even this righteousness from the deeds of the Law did they establish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:24
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:25
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:26
verses.text: ; John.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:27
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:28
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:29
verses.text: ) For saying "going about to establish" is what one would do to show this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:30
verses.text: And in plain words indeed he has not stated this (for he has not said, that they fell short of both righteousnesses), but he has given a hint of it in a very judicious manner, and with the wisdom so befitting him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:31
verses.text: For if they are still "going about" to establish that, it is very plain that they have not yet established it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:32
verses.text: If they have not submitted themselves to this, they have fallen short of this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:33
verses.text: But he calls it their "own righteousness," either because the Law was no longer of force, or because it was one of trouble and toil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:34
verses.text: But this he calls God's righteousness, that from faith, because it comes entirely from the grace from above, and because men are justified in this case, not by labors, but by the gift of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:35
verses.text: But they that evermore resisted the Holy Ghost, and vexatiously tried to be justified by the Law, came not over to the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:36
verses.text: But as they did not come over to the faith, nor receive the righteousness thereupon ensuing, and were not able to be justified by the Law either, they were thrown out of all resources.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:37
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:38
verses.text: "For Christ is the end of the Law for righteousness to every one that believeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:39
verses.text: See the judgment of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:40
verses.text: For as he had spoken of a righteousness, and a righteousness, lest they of the Jews which believed should seem to have the one but be excluded from the other, and to be accused of lawlessness (for even these there was no less cause to fear about as being still newly come in), and lest Jews should again expect to achieve it, and should say, Though we have not at present fulfilled it, yet we certainly will fulfil it, see what ground he takes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:41
verses.text: He shows that there is but one righteousness, and that has its full issue in this, and that he that hath taken to himself this, the one by faith, hath fulfilled that also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:42
verses.text: But he that rejects this, falls short as well of that also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:43
verses.text: For if Christ be "the end of the Law," he that hath not Christ, even if he seem to have that righteousness, hath it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:44
verses.text: But he that hath Christ, even though he have not fulfilled the Law aright, hath received the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:45
verses.text: For the end of the physician's art is health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:46
verses.text: As then he that can make whole, even though he hath not the physician's art, hath everything; but he that knows not how to heal, though he seem to be a follower of the art, comes short of everything: so is it in the case of the Law and of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:47
verses.text: He that hath this hath the end of that likewise, but he that is without this is an alien from both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:48
verses.text: For what was the object of the Law? To make man righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:49
verses.text: But it had not the power, for no one fulfilled it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:50
verses.text: This then was the end of the Law and to this it looked throughout, and for this all its parts were made, its feasts, and commandments, and sacrifices, and all besides, that man might be justified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:51
verses.text: But this end Christ gave a fuller accomplishment of through faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:52
verses.text: Be not then afraid, he says, as if transgressing the Law in having come over to the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:53
verses.text: For then dost thou transgress it, when for it thou dost not believe Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:54
verses.text: If thou believest in Him, then thou hast fulfilled it also, and much more than it commanded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:55
verses.text: For thou hast received a much greater righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:56
verses.text: Next, since this was an assertion, he again brings proof of it from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:58
verses.text: "For Moses," he says, "describeth the righteousness which is of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:59
verses.text: What he means is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:60
verses.text: Moses showeth us the righteousness ensuing from the Law, what sort it is of, and whence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:61
verses.text: What sort is it then of, and what does it consist in? In fulfilling the commandments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:62
verses.text: "He (R.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:63
verses.text: T.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:64
verses.text: the man), that doeth these things," He says, "shall live by (or in), them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:65
verses.text: (Lev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:66
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:67
verses.text: ) And there is no other way of becoming righteous in the Law save by fulfilling the whole of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:68
verses.text: But this has not been possible for any one, and therefore this righteousness has failed them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:69
verses.text: (διαπέπτωκεν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:70
verses.text: But tell us, Paul, of the other righteousness also, that which is of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:71
verses.text: What is that then, and of what does it consist? Hear the words in which he gives a clear sketch of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:72
verses.text: For after he had refuted the other, he next goes on to this, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:73
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:74
verses.text: "But the righteousness which is of faith speaketh on this wise, Say not in thine heart, Who shall ascend into heaven (that is, to bring Christ down from above): or, Who shall descend into the deep? (that is, to bring up Christ again from the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:75
verses.text: ) But what saith it? The word is nigh thee, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that is, the word of faith which we preach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:76
verses.text: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:77
verses.text: To prevent the Jews then from saying, How came they who had not found the lesser righteousness to find the greater? he gives a reason there was no answering, that this way was easier than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:78
verses.text: For that requires the fulfilment of all things (for when thou doest all, then thou shalt live); but the righteousness which is of faith doth not say this, but what?  "If thou confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and believe in thy heart that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:79
verses.text: Then again that we may not seem to be making it contemptible by showing it to be easy and cheap, observe how he expands his account of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:80
verses.text: For he does not come immediately to the words just given, but what does he say? "But the righteousness which is of faith saith on this wise; Say not in thine heart, Who shall go up into heaven? (that is, to bring Christ down); or, Who shall descend into the deep? (that is, to bring up Christ again from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:81
verses.text: ) For as to the virtue manifested in works there is opposed a listlessness, which relaxeth our labors, and it requireth a very wakeful soul not to yield to it: thus, when one is required to believe, there are reasonings which confuse and make havoc of the minds of most men, and it wants a soul of some vigor to shake them thoroughly off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:82
verses.text: And this is just why he brings the same before one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:83
verses.text: And as he did in Abraham's case, so he does here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:84
verses.text: For having there shown that he was justified by faith, lest he should seem to have gotten so great a crown by a mere chance, as if it were a thing of no account, to extol the nature of faith, he says, "Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:85
verses.text: And being not weak in faith, he considered his own body now dead, and the deadness of Sarah's womb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:86
verses.text: He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God; and being fully persuaded that what He had promised He was able also to perform" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:87
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:88
verses.text: –): so he showed that there is need of vigor, and a lofty soul, that takes in things beyond expectation, and stumbles not at appearances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:89
verses.text: This then he does here also, and shows that it requires a wise mind, and a spirit heavenly (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:90
verses.text: heaven-reaching) and great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:91
verses.text: And he does not say merely, "Say not," but, "Say not in thine heart," that is, do not so much as think of doubting and saying with thyself, And how can this be? You see that this is a chief characteristic of faith, to leave all the consequences of this lower world, and so to seek for that which is above nature, and to cast out the feebleness of calculation, and so to accept everything from the Power of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:92
verses.text: The Jews, however, did not merely assert this, but that it was not possible to be justified by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:93
verses.text: But himself turns even what had taken place to another account, that having shown the thing to be so great, that even after it had taken place it required faith, he might seem with good reason to bestow a crown on these: and he uses the words which are found in the Old Testament, being always at pains to keep quite clear of the charges of love of novelties, and of opposition to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:94
verses.text: For this, which he here says of faith, Moses says to them of the commandment, so showing that they had enjoyed at God's hand a great benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:95
verses.text: For there is no need to say, he means, that one must go up to heaven, or cross a great sea, and then receive the commandments, but things so great and grand hath God made of easy access to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:96
verses.text: And what meaneth the phrase, "The Word is nigh thee?" That is, It is easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:97
verses.text: For in thy mind and in thy tongue is thy salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:98
verses.text: There is no long journey to go, no seas to sail over, no mountains to pass, to get saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:99
verses.text: But if you be not minded to cross so much as the threshold, you may even while you sit at home be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:100
verses.text: For "in thy mouth and in thy heart" is the source of salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:101
verses.text: And then on another score also he makes the word of faith easy, and says, that "God raised Him from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:102
verses.text: For just reflect upon the worthiness of the Worker, and you will no longer see any difficulty in the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:103
verses.text: That He is Lord then, is plain from the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:104
verses.text: And this he said at the beginning even of the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:105
verses.text: "Which was declared to be the Son of God with power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:106
verses.text: by the resurrection from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:107
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:108
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:109
verses.text: ) But that the resurrection is easy too, has been shown even to those who are very unbelieving, from the might of the Worker of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:110
verses.text: Since then the righteousness is greater, and light and easy to receive, is it not a sign of the utmost contentiousness to leave what is light and easy, and set about impossibilities? For they could not say that it was a thing they declined as burdensome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:111
verses.text: See then how he deprives them of all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:112
verses.text: For what do they deserve to have said in their defence, who choose what is burdensome and impracticable, and pass by what is light, and able to save them, and to give them those things which the Law could not give? All this can come only from a contentious spirit, which is in a state of rebellion against God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:113
verses.text: For the Law is galling (ἐπαχθὴς), but grace is easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:114
verses.text: The Law, though they dispute never so much, does not save; Grace yieldeth the righteousness resulting from itself, and that from the Law likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:115
verses.text: What plea then is to rescue them, since they are disposed to be contentious against this, but cling to that to no purpose whatever? Then, since he had made a strong assertion, he again confirms it from the Scripture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:116
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:117
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:118
verses.text: "For the Scripture saith," he proceeds, "Whosoever believeth on Him, shall not be ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:119
verses.text: For there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek; for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:120
verses.text: For whosoever shall call upon the Name of the Lord shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:121
verses.text: You see how he produces witnesses, whether to the faith, or to the confession of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:122
verses.text: For the words, "Every one that believeth," point out the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:123
verses.text: But the words, "Whosoever shall call upon," set forth confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:124
verses.text: Then again to proclaim the universality of the grace, and to lay their boasting low, what he had before demonstrated at length, he here briefly recalls to their memory, showing again that there is no difference between the Jew and the uncircumcised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:125
verses.text: "For there is," he says, "no difference between the Jew and the Greek".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:126
verses.text: And what he had said about the Father, when he was arguing this point, that he says here about the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:127
