verses.text: For as before he said in asserting this, "Is He the God of the Jews only? Is He not of the Gentiles also? Yes, of the Gentiles also: seeing it is one God" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:128
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:129
verses.text: , ):—So he says here also, "For the same Lord over all is rich unto all (and upon all)".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:130
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:131
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:132
verses.text: ) You see how he sets Him forth as exceedingly desiring our salvation, since He even reckons this to be riches to Himself; so that they are not even now to despair, or fancy that, provided they would repent, they were unpardonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:133
verses.text: For He who considereth it as riches to Himself to save us, will not cease to be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:134
verses.text: Since even this is riches, the fact of the gift being shed forth unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:135
verses.text: For since what distresseth him the most was, that they, who were in the enjoyment of a prerogative over the whole world, should now by the faith be degraded from these thrones, and be no wit better off than others, he brings the Prophets in constantly as foretelling, that they would have equal honor with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:136
verses.text: "For whosoever," he says, "believeth on Him shall not be ashamed" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:137
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:138
verses.text: ); and, "Whosoever shall call upon the Name of the Lord shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:139
verses.text: (Joel ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:140
verses.text: ) And the "whosoever" is put in all cases, that they might not say aught in reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:141
verses.text: But there is nothing worse than vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:142
verses.text: For it was this, this most especially, which proved their ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:143
verses.text: Whence Christ also said to them, "How can ye believe, which receive glory one of another, and seek not the glory which cometh of God only?" (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:144
verses.text: ) This, with ruin, exposes men also to much ridicule and before the punishment in the other world involves them in ills unnumbered in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:145
verses.text: And if it seem good, that you may learn this clearly, leaving for the present the heavens which that puts us out of, and the hell which it thrusts us into, let us investigate the whole matter as here before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:146
verses.text: What then can be more wasteful than this? what more disgraceful, or more offensive? For that this disorder is a wasteful one is plain from the people who spend to no purpose whatsoever on theatres, horse-races, and other such irrelevant expenditures: from those that build the fine and expensive houses, and fit up everything in a useless style of extravagance, on which I must not enter in this discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:147
verses.text: But that a person diseased in this way must needs be extravagant, and expensive, and rapacious, and covetous, anybody can see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:148
verses.text: For that he may have food to give the brute, he thrusteth his hand into the substance of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:149
verses.text: And why do I talk of substance? It is not money only but souls also that this fire devoureth, and it worketh not death here only, but also hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:150
verses.text: For vanity is the mother of hell, and greatly kindleth that fire, and the venomous worm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:151
verses.text: One may see that it hath power even over the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:152
verses.text: And what can be worse than this? For the other passions are put an end to by death, but this even after death shows its force, and strives to display its nature even in the dead corpse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:153
verses.text: For when men give orders on their death-bed to raise to them fine monuments, which will waste all their substance, and take pains to lay out beforehand a vast extravagance in their funeral, and in their lifetime insult the poor that come to them for a penny and a single loaf, but when they are dead give a rich banquet to the worm, why seek any more exorbitant thraldom to the disease? From this mischief also irregular loves are conceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:154
verses.text: For there are many whom it is not the beauty of the appearance, nor the desire of lying with her, but the wish to boast that "I have made conquest of such an one," hath even drawn into adultery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:155
verses.text: And why need I mention the other mischiefs that spring of this? For I had rather be long ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:156
verses.text: διηνεκὥς) the slave of ten thousand savages, than of vanity once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:157
verses.text: For even they do not put such commands upon their captives, as this vice lays upon its votaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:158
verses.text: Because it says, Be thou every one's slave, be he nobler or be he lower than thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:159
verses.text: Despise thy soul, neglect virtue, laugh at freedom, immolate thy salvation, and if thou doest any good thing, do it not to please God, but to display it to the many, that for these things thou mayest even lose thy crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:160
verses.text: And if thou give alms, or if thou fast, undergo the pains, but take care to lose the gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:161
verses.text: What can be more cruel than these commands? Hence grudging beareth sway, hence haughtiness, hence covetousness, the mother of evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:162
verses.text: For the swarm of domestics, and the black servants liveried in gold, and the hangers on, and the flatterers, and the silver-tinselled chariots, and the other absurdities greater than these, are not had for any pleasure's sake or necessity, but for mere vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:163
verses.text: Yes, one will say, but that this affliction is an evil, anybody can see; but how we are to keep quite clear of it, this is what you should tell us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:164
verses.text: Well then, in the first place, if you persuade yourself that this disorder is a baneful one, you will have made a very good beginning towards correcting it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:165
verses.text: For when a man is sick, he speedily sends for the physician, if he be first made acquainted with the fact that he is sick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:166
verses.text: But if thou seekest for another way besides to escape from hence, look to God continually, and be content with glory from Him; and if thou find the passion tickling thee, and stirring thee to tell thy well-doings to thy fellow-servants, bethink thyself next, that after telling them thou gainest nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:167
verses.text: Quench the absurd desire, and say to thy soul, Lo, thou hast been so long big with thy own well-doings to tell them, and thou hast not had the courage to keep them to thyself, but hast blabbed them out to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:168
verses.text: What good then hast thou gotten from this? None at all, but loss to the utmost, and avoidance of all that had been gathered together with much labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:169
verses.text: And besides this, consider another thing also, which is, that most men's opinion is perverted, and not perverted only, but that it withers away so soon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:170
verses.text: For supposing they do admire you for the time, when the occasion has gone by they will have forgotten it all, and have taken away from thee the crown God had given, and have been unable to secure to thee that from themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:171
verses.text: And yet if this were abiding, it were a most miserable thing to exchange that for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:172
verses.text: But when even this hath gone, what defence shall we be able to make for betraying the abiding one for the sake of the unabiding one, for losing such blessings for the sake of credit with a few? And indeed even if they who praise were numerous, even for this they were to be pitied, and the more so the more numerous those who do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:173
verses.text: But if thou art surprised at what I have said, hear Christ giving His sentence in this way, "Woe unto you, when all men speak well of you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:174
verses.text: (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:175
verses.text: ) And so indeed it should seem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:176
verses.text: For if in every art you look to the workmen (δημιουργους) in it to be judges of it, how come you to trust the proving of virtue to the many, and not most of all to Him Who knoweth it more surely then any, and is best able to applaud and to crown it? This saying then, let us inscribe both on our walls and our doors and our mind, and let us keep constantly saying to ourselves, "Woe unto us, when all men speak well of us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:177
verses.text: For even they that so speak slander one afterward as a vain person, and fond of honor, and covetous of their good word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:178
verses.text: But God doeth not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:179
verses.text: But when He seeth thee coveting the glory that cometh of Him, then He will praise thee most, and respect (θαυμάσεται om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:180
verses.text: in most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:181
verses.text: ) thee, and proclaim thee conqueror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:182
verses.text: Not so man; but, when he finds thee slavish instead of free, by gratifying thee often by bare words with false praise, he snatches from thee thy true meed, and makes thee more of a menial than a purchased slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:183
verses.text: For those last men get to obey them after their orders, but thou even without orders makest thyself a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:184
verses.text: For thou dost not even wait to hear something from them, but if thou merely knowest wherein thou mayest gratify them, even without their command thou doest all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:185
verses.text: What hell then should we not deserve, for giving the wicked pleasure, and courting their service before they give orders, while we will not hearken to God, even when He every day commands and exhorts us? And yet if thou art covetous of glory and praise, avoid the praise that cometh of men, and then thou wilt attain to glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:186
verses.text: Turn aside from fair speeches, and then thou wilt obtain praises without number both from God and from men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:187
verses.text: For there is no one we are used to give so much glory to, as the man who looks down upon glory, or to praise and respect so much as the man who thinks scorn of getting respected and praised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:188
verses.text: And if we do so, much more will the God of the universe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:189
verses.text: And when He glorifieth thee and praiseth thee, what man can be more justly pronounced blessed? For there is not a greater difference between glory and disgrace, than between the glory from above and that of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:190
verses.text: Or rather, there is a much greater, aye an infinite difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:191
verses.text: For if this, even when it does not get put beside any other, is but a base and uncomely one, when we come to scrutinize it by the other's side, just consider how great its baseness will be found to be! For as a prostitute stands at her place and lets herself out to any one, so are they that be slaves of vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:192
verses.text: Or rather, these be more base than she.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:193
verses.text: For that sort of women do in many instances treat those enamoured of them with scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:194
verses.text: But you prostitute yourself to everybody, whether runaway slaves, or thieves, or cut-purses (for it is of these and such as these that the play-houses that applaud you consist), and those whom as individuals you hold to be nothing worth, when in a body, you honor more than your own salvation and show yourself less worthy of honor than any of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:195
verses.text: For how can you be else than less worthy, when you stand in need of the good word of others, and fancy that you have not enough by yourself, unless you receive the glory that cometh of others? Do you not perceive, pray, beside what I have said, that as you are an object of notice, and known to every body, if you should commit a fault, you will have accusers unnumbered; but if unknown, you will remain in security? Yes, a man may say, but then if I do well I shall have admirers unnumbered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:196
verses.text: Now the fearful thing is, that it is not only when you sin, but even when you do aright, that the disorder of vanity does you mischief, in the former case subverting thousands, in the present bereaving thee entirely of thy reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:197
verses.text: It is then a sad thing, and replete with disgrace of every kind, to be in love with glory even in civil matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:198
verses.text: But when even in spiritual you are in the same plight what excuse is there left remaining for you, when you are not minded to yield God even as much honor as you have yourself from your servants? For even the slave "looketh to the eyes of his master" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:199
verses.text: cxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:200
verses.text: ), and the hireling to his employer, who is to pay him wages, and the disciple to his master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:201
verses.text: But you do just the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:202
verses.text: Having left the God that hired thee, even thy Master, thou lookest to thy fellow-servants; and this knowing that God remembers thy well-doings even after this life, but man only for the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:203
verses.text: And when thou hast spectators assembled in Heaven, thou art gathering together spectators upon earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:204
verses.text: And where the wrestler struggles, there he would be honored; but thou, while thy wrestling is above, art anxious to gain thee a crown below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:205
verses.text: And what can be worse than madness like this? But let us look, if it seem proper, at the crowns also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:206
verses.text: For one is formed by haughtiness, and a second by grudging against another, and a third by dissimulation and flattery, another again by wealth, and another by servile obsequiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:207
verses.text: And like as children at their childish play put crowns of grass upon one another, and many a time laugh at him that is crowned behind his back; thus now also they that pass their praises upon thee, many a time joke by themselves at their putting the grass upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:208
verses.text: And would it were grass only! But now the crown is laden with much mischief, and ruins all our well-doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:209
verses.text: Taking then the vileness of it into consideration, flee from the damage entailed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:210
verses.text: For how many would you have to praise you? A hundred? or twice, or thrice, or four times as many? Or rather, if you please, put them at ten times or twenty times as many, and let there be two or four thousand, or if you will, even ten thousand to applaud you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:211
verses.text: Still these be no better than so many daws cawing from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:212
verses.text: Or rather taking the assemblage of the angels into consideration, these will seem more vile than even worms, and their good word of not so much solidity as a cobweb, or a smoke, or a dream.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:213
verses.text: Hear then how Paul, who saw through these things thoroughly, is so far from seeking after them, that he even deprecates them, in the words, "But God forbid that I should glory, save in the cross of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:214
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:215
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:216
verses.text: ) This glory then be thou also emulous of, that thou mayest not provoke the Master, because in so doing thou art insulting God, and not thyself alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:217
verses.text: For if thou even wert a painter, and hadst some pupil, and he were to omit showing thee his practice of the art, but set forth his painting publicly just to any body that chanted to observe it, thou wouldest not take it quietly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:218
verses.text: But if this even with thy fellow-servants were an insult, how much more with the Master! But if you have a mind to learn on other grounds to feel scorn for the thing, be of a lofty mind, laugh at appearances, increase thy love of real glory, be filled with a spiritual temper, say to thy soul as Paul did, "Knowest thou not that we shall judge angels?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:219
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:220
verses.text: ) and having by this roused it up, go on to rebuke it, and say, Thou that judgest the angels, wilt thou let thyself be judged of off-scourings, and be praised with dancers, and mimics, and gladiators, and horse-drivers? For these men do follow after applause of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:221
verses.text: But do thou poise thy wing high above the din of these, and emulate that citizen of the wilderness, John, and learn how he was above regarding the multitude, and did not turn him to look at flatterers, but when he saw all the dwellers in Palestine poured forth about him, and wondering, and astonished at him, he was not puffed up with such honor as this, but rose up against them, and discoursing to his great concourse as if to one youth, he thus rebuked them and said, "Ye serpents, ye generation of vipers!" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:222
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:223
verses.text: ) Yet it was for him that they had run together, and left the cities, in order to see that holy personage, and still none of these things unnerved him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:224
verses.text: For he was far above glory, and free from all vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:225
verses.text: So also Stephen, when he saw the same people again, not honoring him, but mad upon him, and gnashing their teeth, being lifted above their wrath, said, "Ye stiff-necked and uncircumcised in heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:226
verses.text: (Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:227
verses.text: ) Thus also Elias, when those armies were present, and the king, and all the people, said, "How long halt ye upon both your hips?" ( Kings xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:228
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:229
verses.text: true sense of "halt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:230
verses.text: ) But we flatter all, court all, with this servile obsequiousness buying their honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:231
verses.text: Wherefore all things are turned upside down, and for this favor the business of Christianity is betrayed, and everything neglected for the opinion of the generality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:232
verses.text: Let us then banish this passion, and then we shall have a right notion of liberty, and of the haven, and the calm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:233
verses.text: For the vain man is ever like persons in a storm, trembling, and fearing, and serving a thousand masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:234
verses.text: But he that is clear of this thraldom, is like men in havens, enjoying a liberty untainted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:235
verses.text: Not so that person, but as many acquaintances as he has, so many masters has he, and he is forced to be a slave to all of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:236
verses.text: How then are we to get free from this hard bondage? It is by growing enamoured of another glory, which is really glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:237
verses.text: For as with those that are enamoured of persons, the sight of some handsomer one doth by its being seen take them off from the first: so with those that court the glory which cometh from us men, the glory from heaven, if it gleameth on them, has power to lead them off from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:238
verses.text: Let us then look to this, and become thoroughly acquainted with it, that by feeling admiration of its beauty, we may shun the hideousness of the other, and have the benefit of much pleasure by enjoying this continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:239
verses.text: Which may we all attain to by the grace and love toward man, etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:240
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:241
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 18:242

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:1
verses.text: Homily XVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:2
verses.text: "How then shall they call on Him in Whom they have not believed? and how shall they believe in Him of Whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher? and how shall they preach except they be sent? as it is written".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:3
verses.text: Here again he takes from them all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:4
verses.text: For since he had said, "I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge," and that "being ignorant of God's righteousness, they submitted not themselves" to it: he next shows, that for this ignorance itself they were punishable before God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:5
verses.text: This he does not say indeed so, but he makes it good by carrying on his discourse in the way of question, and so convicting them more clearly, by framing the whole passage out of objections and answers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:6
verses.text: But look further back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:7
verses.text: The Prophet, saith he, said, "Whosoever shall call upon the Name of the Lord shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:8
verses.text: Now somebody might say perhaps, "But how could they call upon Him Whom they had not believed? Then there is a question from him after the objection; And why did they not believe? Then an objection again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:9
verses.text: A person certainly may say, And how could they believe, since they had not heard? Yet hear they did, he implies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:10
verses.text: Then another objection again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:11
verses.text: "And how could they hear without a preacher?" Then an answer again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:12
verses.text: Yet preach they did, and there were many sent forth for this very purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:13
verses.text: And whence does it appear that these are those persons sent? Then he brings the prophet in next, who says, "How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things!" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:14
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:15
verses.text: ) You see how by the kind of preaching he points out the preachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:16
verses.text: For there was nothing else that these men went about telling everywhere, but those unspeakable good things, and the peace made by God with men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:17
verses.text: And so by disbelieving, it is not we, he implies, whom you disbelieve, but Isaiah the prophet, who spake many years ago, that we were to be sent, and to preach, and to say what we do say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:18
verses.text: If the being saved, then, came of calling upon Him, and calling upon Him from believing, and believing from hearing, and hearing from preaching, and preaching from being sent, and if they were sent, and did preach, and the prophet went round with them to point them out, and proclaim them, and say that these were they whom they showed of so many ages ago, whose feet even they praised because of the matter of their preaching; then it is quite clear that the not believing was their own fault only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:19
verses.text: And that because God's part had been fulfilled completely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:20
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:21
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:22
verses.text: "But they have not all obeyed the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:23
verses.text: For Esaias saith, Lord, who hath believed our report? So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:24
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:25
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:26
verses.text: )  Since they pressed him with another objection again to this effect, that if these were the persons sent upon the mission by God, all ought to have hearkened to them: observe Paul's judgment, and see how he shows that this very thing which made the confusion, did in fact do away with confusion and embarrassment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:27
verses.text: What offends you, O Jew, he would say, after so great and abundant evidence, and demonstration of the points? that all did not submit to the Gospel? Why this very thing, when taken along with the others, is of force to certify thee of the truth of my statements, even in that some do not believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:28
verses.text: For this too the prophet foretold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:29
verses.text: Notice his unspeakable wisdom too; how he shows more than they were looking for, or expected him to have to say in reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:30
verses.text: For what is it that you say? he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:31
verses.text: Is it that all have not believed the Gospel? Well! Isaiah foretold this too from of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:32
verses.text: Or rather, not this only, but even much more than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:33
verses.text: For the complaint you make is Why did not all believe? But Isaiah goes further than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:34
verses.text: For what is it he says? "Lord, who hath believed our report?" Then since he had rid himself of this embarrassment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:35
verses.text: by making the Prophet a bulwark against them, he again keeps to the line he was before upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:36
verses.text: For as he had said that they must call upon Him, but that they who call must believe, and they who believe must hear first, but they who are to hear must have preachers, and the preachers be sent, and as he had shown that they were sent, and had preached; as he is going to bring in another objection again, taking occasion first of another quotation from the Prophet, by which he had met the objection a little back, he thus interweaves it, and connects it with what went before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:37
verses.text: For since he had produced the Prophet as saying, "Lord, who hath believed our report" (ἀκοᾕ)? he happily seizes on the quotation, as proving what he says, "So then faith cometh by hearing" (ἀκοἥς).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:38
verses.text: And this he makes not a mere naked statement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:39
verses.text: But as the Jews were forever seeking a sign, and the sight of the Resurrection, and were gaping after the thing much; he says, Yet the Prophet promised no such thing, but that it was by hearing that we were to believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:40
verses.text: Hence he makes this good first, and says, "so then faith cometh by hearing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:41
verses.text: And then since this seemed a mean thing to say, see how he elevates it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:42
verses.text: For he says, I was not speaking of mere hearing, nor of the need of hearing men's words and believing them, but I mean a great sort of hearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:43
verses.text: For the hearing is "by the word of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:44
verses.text: They were not speaking their own, but they were telling what they learnt from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:45
verses.text: And this is a higher thing than miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:46
verses.text: For we are equally bound to believe and to obey God, whether speaking or working miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:47
verses.text: Since both works and miracles come of His words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:48
verses.text: For both the heaven and everything else was established in this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:49
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:50
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:51
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:52
verses.text: ) After showing then that we ought to believe the prophets, who always speak God's words, and not to look after anything more, he proceeds next to the objection I mentioned, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:53
verses.text: "But I say, Have they not heard?"  What, he means, if the preachers were sent, and did preach what they were bid, and these did not hear? Then comes a most perfect reply to the objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:54
verses.text: "Yes, verily, their sound went into all the earth, and their words unto the ends of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:55
verses.text: What do you say? he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:56
verses.text: They have not heard? Why the whole world, and the ends of the earth, have heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:57
verses.text: And have you, amongst whom the heralds abode such a long time, and of whose land they were, not heard? Now can this ever be? Sure if the ends of the world heard, much more must you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:58
verses.text: Then again another objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:59
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:60
verses.text: "But I say, Did not Israel know?"  For what if they heard, he means, but did not know what was said, nor understand that these were the persons sent? Are they not to be forgiven for their ignorance? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:61
verses.text: For Isaiah had described their character in the words, "How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel of peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:62
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:63
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:64
verses.text: ) And before him the Lawgiver himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:65
verses.text: Hence he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:66
verses.text: "First Moses saith, I will provoke you to jealousy by them that are no people, and by a foolish nation I will anger you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:67
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:68
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:69
verses.text: )  And so they ought even from him to have been able to distinguish the preachers, not from the fact of these disbelieving only, not from the fact of their preaching peace, not from the fact of their bringing the glad tidings of those good things, not from the word being sown in every part of the world, but from the very fact of their seeing their inferiors, those of the Gentiles, in greater honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:70
verses.text: For what they had never heard, nor their forefathers, that wisdom did these on a sudden embrace (ἑφιλοσόφουν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:71
verses.text: And this was a mark of such intense honor, as should gall them, and lead them to jealousy, and to recollection of the prophecy of Moses, which said, "I will provoke you to jealousy by them that are no people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:72
verses.text: For it was not the greatness of the honor alone that was enough to throw them upon jealousy, but the fact too that a nation had come to enjoy these things which was of so little account that it could hardly be considered a nation at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:73
verses.text: "For I will provoke you to jealousy, by them which are no nation, and by a foolish nation will I anger you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:74
verses.text: For what more foolish than the Greeks (Heathen, see pp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:75
verses.text: , )? or what of less account? See how by every means God had given from of old indications and clear signs of these times, in order to remove their blindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:76
verses.text: For it was not any little corner in which the thing was done, but in land, and in sea, and in every quarter of the globe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:77
verses.text: And they saw those in the enjoyment of countless blessings now, who had formerly been objects of their contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:78
verses.text: One should consider then that this is that people of which Moses said, "I will provoke you to jealousy by them that are no people, and by a foolish nation will I anger you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:79
verses.text: Was it Moses only then that said this? No, for Isaiah also after Him saith so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:80
verses.text: And this is why Paul said, "First Moses," to show that a second will come who says the same things in a clearer and plainer way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:81
verses.text: As then he says above, that Esaias crieth, so too here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:82
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:83
verses.text: "But Esaias is very bold, and saith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:84
verses.text: Now what he means is something of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:85
verses.text: He put a violence on himself, and was ambitious to speak, not some thing veiled over, but to set things even naked before your eyes, and choosing rather to run (Origen in loc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:86
verses.text: ) into dangers from being plain spoken, than by looking to his own safety, to leave you any shelter for your impenetrableness; although it was not the manner of prophecy to say this so clearly; but still to stop your mouths most completely, he tells the whole beforehand clearly and distinctly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:87
verses.text: The whole! what whole? Why your being cast out, and also their being brought in; speaking as follows, "I was found of them that sought Me not, I was made manifest of them that asked not after Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:88
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:89
verses.text: lxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:90
verses.text: ) Who then are they that sought not? who they that asked not after Him? Clearly not the Jews, but they of the Gentiles, who hitherto had not known Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:91
verses.text: As then Moses gave their characteristic mark in the words, "no people" and "a foolish nation," so here also he takes the same ground to point them out from, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:92
verses.text: their extreme ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:93
verses.text: And this was a very great blame to attach to the Jews, that they who sought Him not found Him, and they who sought Him lost Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:94
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:95
verses.text: "But unto Israel He saith, All the day long have I stretched forth My hands unto a disobedient and gainsaying people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:96
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:97
verses.text: lxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:98
verses.text: )  Observe now that difficulty, which so many make a subject of question, is discovered laid up from of old in the words of the Prophet, and with a clear solution to it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:99
verses.text: And what is this? You heard Paul say before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:100
verses.text: "What shall we say then? That the Gentiles which followed not after righteousness have attained unto righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:101
verses.text: But Israel which followed after the law of righteousness hath not attained to the law of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:102
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:103
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:104
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:105
verses.text: ) This Esaias also says here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:106
verses.text: For to say, "I was found of them that sought me not, I was made manifest unto them which asked not after me," is the same with saying, "that the Gentiles which followed not after righteousness have attained unto righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:107
verses.text: Then to show that what was happening was not of God's grace only, but also of the temper of those who came to Him, as also the casting off of the others came of the disputatiousness of those who disobeyed, hear what he proceeds with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:108
verses.text: "But to Israel He saith, All the day long have I stretched forth My hands to a disobedient and gainsaying people;" here meaning by the day the whole period of the former dispensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:109
verses.text: But the stretching out of the hands, means calling and drawing them to Him, and inviting them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:110
verses.text: Then to show that the fault was all their own, he says "to a disobedient and gainsaying people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:111
verses.text: You see what a great charge this is against them! For they did not obey Him even when He invited them, but they gainsaid Him, and that when they saw Him doing so, not once or twice or thrice, but the whole period.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:112
verses.text: But others who had never known Him, had the power to draw Him to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:113
verses.text: Not that he says they themselves had the power to do it, but to take away lofty imaginings even from those of the Gentiles, and to show that it was His grace that wrought the whole, He says, I was made manifest, and I was found.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:114
verses.text: It may be said, Were they then void of everything? By no means, for the taking of the things found, and the getting a knowledge of what was manifested to them, was what they contributed themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:115
verses.text: Then to prevent these saying, But why wast Thou not made manifest to us also? he sets down what is more than this, that I not only was made manifest, but I even continue with My hands stretched out, inviting them, and displaying all the concern of an affectionate father, and a mother that is set on her child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:116
verses.text: See how he has brought us a most lucid answer to all the difficulties before raised, by showing that it was from their own temper that ruin had befallen them, and that they are wholly undeserving of pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:117
verses.text: For though they had both heard and understood what was said, still not even then were they minded to come to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:118
verses.text: And what is far more, He did not cause them to hear these things and to understand them only, but a thing which hath more force to rouse them up and draw them to Him, when they were disobedient and gain-saying, He added to the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:119
verses.text: Now what is this? It is His exasperating them, and making them jealous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:120
verses.text: For ye know the domineering might of the passion, and how great the power is which jealousy is naturally possessed of for bringing all disputatiousness to an end, and rousing those who have grown remiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:121
verses.text: And why need one say this of man when in brutes without reason, and children before they are of full age, the power it shows is so great? For a child often will not submit to its father when it is called, but continues obstinate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:122
verses.text: But when another child has notice taken of it, then it even though not called comes to its father's bosom, and what calling could not do, provoking to jealousy will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:123
verses.text: This then God also did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:124
verses.text: For He not only called and stretched out His hands, but stirred up in them the feeling of jealousy also, by bringing those far inferior to them (a thing which makes men excessively jealous) not into their good things, but (what was a much stronger step, and makes the feeling even more domineering,) into much greater good things, and of greater necessity than theirs, and such as they had never even fancied in a dream.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:125
verses.text: But still they did not submit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:126
verses.text: What pardon then do they deserve who exhibit such excessive obstinacy? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:127
verses.text: Yet this he does not say himself, but leaves it to the consciences of his hearers, to gather it from the conclusion of what he had stated, and again also confirms it by what he goes on to in his usual wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:128
verses.text: And this he did also above, by introducing objections both in the case of the Law (see on Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:129
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:130
verses.text: , pp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:131
verses.text: , I) and of the people, which presented an accusation beyond the true one; and then in the answer, which was to overthrow this, yielding as much as he pleased, and as the case allowed, so as to make what he was saying not unwelcome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:132
verses.text: And this he doth here, writing as follows:  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:133
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:134
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:135
verses.text: "I say then, Hath God cast away His people whom He foreknew? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:136
verses.text: And he introduces the form a person would use in doubt, as though taking occasion from what had been said, and after making this alarming statement, by the denial of it he causes the sequel to be allowed with readiness; and what by all the former arguments he had been laboring to show that he makes good here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:137
verses.text: What then is this? That even if there be but a few saved, the promise yet stands good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:138
verses.text: This is why he does not merely say "people," but "people which He foreknew".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:139
verses.text: Then proceeding with the proof that the "people" were not cast off, "For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:140
verses.text: I, he says, the instructor, the preacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:141
verses.text: Now since this seemed contrary to what was said before in the words, "Who hath believed our report?" and, "All the day long have I stretched forth My hands to a disobedient and gainsaying people;" and, "I will provoke you to jealousy by them which are no people;" he was not satisfied with the deprecation, nor with having said, "God forbid," but makes it good by taking it up again and saying, "God hath not cast away His people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:142
verses.text: But this is not a confirmation, men may say, but an assertion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:143
verses.text: Observe then the confirmation, both the first, and that which follows it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:144
verses.text: For the first is that he was himself of that race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:145
verses.text: But He would not, if on the point of casting them off, have chosen from them him to whom He entrusted all the preaching, and the affairs of the world, and all mysteries, and the whole economy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:146
verses.text: This then is one proof, but the next, after it, is his saying, that "people whom He foreknew," that is, who He knew clearly were suited to it, and would receive the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:147
verses.text: (Pococke on Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:148
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:149
verses.text: See Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:150
verses.text: ; iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:151
verses.text: ; xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:152
verses.text: ) For three, five, even ten thousand were believers from among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:153
verses.text: And so to prevent any from saying, Art thou the people, then? And because thou hast been called, hath the nation been called? he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:154
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:155
verses.text: "He hath not cast off His people, whom He foreknew".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:156
verses.text: As though he said, I have with me three, five, or ten thousand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:157
verses.text: What then? has the people come to be three, five, or ten thousand? that seed that compared with the stars of heaven for multitude, or the sand of the sea? Is this the way you deceive us and put a cheat upon us, by making the whole people thyself and the few that are with thee; and didst thou inflate us with idle hopes, and say that the promise has been fulfilled, when all are lost, and the salvation comes down to a few? This is all bombast and vanity! we cannot away with such sophistry as this! Now, that they may not say this, see how in the sequel he proceeds to the answer, not giving the objection indeed, but before it grounding the answer to it upon ancient history.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:158
verses.text: What then is the answer?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:159
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:160
verses.text: "Wot ye not," he says, "what the Scripture saith of Elias? how he (so most; mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:161
verses.text: Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:162
verses.text: who) maketh intercession to God against Israel, saying, Lord, they have killed Thy prophets, and digged down Thine altars; and I am left alone, and they seek my life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:163
verses.text: But what saith the answer of God unto him? I have reserved to Myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to the image of Baal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:164
verses.text: Even so then at this present time also, there is a remnant according to the election of grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:165
verses.text: What he means is nearly this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:166
verses.text: "God hath not cast off His people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:167
verses.text: For had He done so, He would have admitted none of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:168
verses.text: But if He did admit some, He hath not cast them off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:169
verses.text: Still it is said, if He had not cast off, He would have admitted all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:170
verses.text: This does not follow; since in Elijah's time the part to be saved had come down to "seven thousand:" and now also there are probably many that believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:171
verses.text: But if you do not know who they are, this is no wonder, for that prophet, who was so great and good a man, did not know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:172
verses.text: But God ordered things for Himself when even the prophet knew them not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:173
verses.text: But consider his judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:174
verses.text: Now in proving what was before him, he covertly augments the charge against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:175
verses.text: For this is why he gave the whole passage, that he might parade before them their untowardness, and show that they had been so from of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:176
verses.text: For if he had not wished this, but had directed his whole attention to prove that the people lay in the few, he would have said that even in Elijah's time, seven thousand were left.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:177
verses.text: But now he reads to them the passage further back, as having been throughout at pains to show that it was no strange thing that they did with Christ, and the Apostles, but their habitual practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:178
verses.text: For to prevent their saying that it was as a deceiver we put Christ to death, and as impostors that we persecute the Apostles, he brings forward the text which says, "Lord, they have killed Thy prophets, and digged down thine altars".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:179
verses.text: ( Kings xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:180
verses.text: ) Then in order not to make his discourse galling to them, he attaches another reason to the bringing forward of the text.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:181
verses.text: For he quotes it not as if it was on purpose to accuse them, but as if intent upon showing some other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:182
verses.text: And he leaves them without any excuse even by what had before been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:183
verses.text: For observe how strong the accusation is even from the person speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:184
verses.text: For it is neither Paul, nor Peter, nor James, nor John, but one whom they held in the greatest estimation, the chief of the Prophets, the friend of God, a man who had been so very zealous in their behalf as even to be given up to hunger for them, who even to this day hath never died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:185
verses.text: What then doth this man say? "Lord, they have killed Thy prophets, and digged down Thine altars; and I am left alone, and they seek my life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:186
verses.text: What could be more brutal cruelty than this? For when they should have besought pardon for the offences they had already committed, they were minded even to kill him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:187
verses.text: And all these things put them quite beyond pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:188
verses.text: For it was not during the prevalence of the famine, but when the season was favorable, and their shame was done away, and the devils (i-e: false gods) had been put to shame, and the power of God had been shown, and the king had bowed beneath it, that they committed these audacities, passing from murder to murder, and making away with their teachers, and such as would bring them to a better mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:189
verses.text: What then could they have to say to this? Were they too deceivers? Were they too impostors? Did they not know whence they were either? But they distressed you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:190
verses.text: Yes, but they also told you goodly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:191
verses.text: But what of the altars? the altars too did not surely distress you? Did they too exasperate you? See of what obstinacy, of what insolence they were ever yielding proofs! This is why in another passage too Paul says, when writing to the Thessalonians, "Ye also have suffered like things of your own countrymen, even as they have of the Jews, who both killed the Lord, and their own prophets, and have persecuted us, and please not God, and are contrary to all men ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:192
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:193
verses.text: , ); which is what he says here too, that they both digged down the altars, and killed the prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:194
verses.text: But what saith the answer of God unto him? "I have reserved to Myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to the image of Baal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:195
verses.text: ( Kings xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:196
verses.text: ) And what has this to do with the present subject? some may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:197
verses.text: It hath a great deal to do with the present subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:198
verses.text: For he shows here that it is the worthy that God useth to save even if the promise be made to the whole nation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:199
verses.text: And this he pointed out above when he said, "Though the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:200
verses.text: And, "Except the Lord of Sabaoth had left us a seed, we should have become as Sodoma".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:201
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:202
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:203
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:204
verses.text: ) And he points it out from this passage also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:205
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds to say, "Even so then at this present time also, there is a remnant according to the election of grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:206
verses.text: Observe that each word maintains its own rank, showing at once God's grace, and the obedient temper of them that receive salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:207
verses.text: For by saying election, he showed the approval of them, but by saying grace, he showed the gift of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:208
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:209
verses.text: "And if by grace, then it is no more of works, otherwise grace is no more grace: but if it be of works, then is it no more grace, otherwise work is no more work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:210
verses.text: He again springs upon the disputatiousness of the Jews, in what has just been quoted; and on this ground bereaves them of excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:211
verses.text: For you cannot, he means, so much as say, that the Prophets called indeed, and God invited, and the state of things cried aloud, and the provoking to jealousy was enough to draw us to Him, but what was enjoined was grievous, and this is why we could not draw nigh, since we had a display of works demanded of us, and laborious well-doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:212
verses.text: For you cannot even say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:213
verses.text: For how should God have demanded this of you, when this would just throw His grace into the shade? And this he said out of a wish to show that He was most desirous that they might be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:214
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:215
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:216
verses.text: ) For not only would their salvation be easily brought about, but it was also God's greatest glory to display His love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:217
verses.text: Why then are you afraid of drawing nigh, since you have no works demanded of you? Why are you bickering and quarrelsome, when grace is before you, and why keep putting me the Law forward to no purpose whatsoever? For you will not be saved by that, and will mar this gift also; since if you pertinaciously insist on being saved by it, you do away with this grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:218
verses.text: Then that they might not think this strange, having first taken those seven thousand; he said that they were saved by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:219
verses.text: For when he says, "Even so then at this present time also there is a remnant according to the election of grace;" he shows that they also were saved by grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:220
verses.text: And not hereby only, but likewise by saying, "I have reserved unto Myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:221
verses.text: For this is the language of One Who showeth that He Himself was the chief Contributor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:222
verses.text: And if by grace, it will be said, how came we all not to be saved? Because ye would not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:223
verses.text: For grace, though it be grace, saves the willing, not those who will not have it, and turn away from it, who persist in fighting against it, and opposing themselves to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:224
verses.text: Observe how throughout the point he is proving is, "Not as though the Word of God had taken none effect," by showing that the worthy were those to whom the promise came, and that these, few though they be, may yet be the people of God; and indeed he had stated it in the beginning of the Epistle with much force, where he says, "For what if some did not believe" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:225
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:226
verses.text: ), and did not even stop at this, but proceeded, "Yea, let God be true, and every man a liar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:227
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:228
verses.text: ) And here again he confirms it another way, and shows the force of grace, and that always the one were being saved, the other perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:229
verses.text: Let us then give thanks, that we belong to them that are being saved, and not having been able to save ourselves by works, were saved by the gift of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:230
verses.text: But in giving thanks, let us not do this in words only, but in works and actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:231
verses.text: For this is the genuine thanksgiving, when we do those things whereby God is sure to be glorified, and flee from those from which we have been set free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:232
verses.text: For if we, after insulting the King, instead of being punished have been honored, and then go and insult Him afresh, since we are detected in the utmost ingratitude, we should with justice have to suffer the utmost punishment, one greater far than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:233
verses.text: For the former insolence did not show us so ungrateful as that committed after honor and much attention shown us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:234
verses.text: Let us then flee those things from which we have been set free, and not give thanks with our mouths only, lest it be said of us also, "This people honoreth Me with their lips, but with their heart is far from Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:235
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:236
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:237
verses.text: ) For how is it else than unseemly, when the "heavens declare the glory of God" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:238
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:239
verses.text: ), and thou, for whom the heavens were made that glorify Him, doest such things that through thee the God that made thee is blasphemed? It is for this that not only he that blasphemeth, but thyself also, wilt be liable to punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:240
verses.text: For the heavens also do not glorify God by sending forth a voice but by putting others upon doing it at the sight of them, and yet they are said "to declare the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:241
verses.text: Thus too they that furnish a life to be wondered at, even though they hold their peace, yet glorify God, when others through them glorify Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:242
verses.text: For He is not so much reverenced because of the heaven, as of a spotless life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:243
verses.text: When then we are discoursing with the Gentiles, we cite ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:244
verses.text: read or point to the reading, "let us not cite") not the heavens before them, but the men, whom though they were in worse plight than brutes, He hath persuaded to be the Angels' competitors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:245
verses.text: And we ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:246
verses.text: "let us") stop their mouths by speaking of this change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:247
verses.text: For far better than the heaven is man, and a soul brighter than their beauty may he possess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:248
verses.text: For it, though visible for so long a time, did not persuade much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:249
verses.text: But Paul, after preaching a short time, drew the whole world unto him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:250
verses.text: (St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:251
verses.text: Aug.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:252
verses.text: on Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:253
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:254
verses.text: ) For he possessed a soul no less than the heaven, which was able to draw all men unto him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:255
verses.text: Our soul is not a match even for the earth: but his is equal to the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:256
verses.text: That stands indeed keeping to its own boundary and rule; but the loftiness of his soul transcended all the heavens, and conversed with Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:257
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:258
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:259
verses.text: ; Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:260
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:261
verses.text: , etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:262
verses.text: ) And the beauty of it was so great, that even God heraldeth it forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:263
verses.text: For the stars did the angels marvel at when they were made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:264
verses.text: (Job xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:265
verses.text: ) But this He marvelled at when He saith, "He is a chosen vessel unto Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:266
verses.text: (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:267
verses.text: ) And this Heaven doth a cloud many times overshadow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:268
verses.text: But Paul's soul no temptation overshadowed but even in storms he was clearer to the sight than the hard sky (σταθερἅς μεσημβρίας) at noon, and shone constantly as it had done before the clouds came on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:269
verses.text: For the Sun who shone in him sent not forth such rays as to be over-clouded by the concourse of temptations, but even then shone forth the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:270
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "My grace is sufficient for thee, for My Strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:271
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:272
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:273
verses.text: ) Let us then strive to be like him, and then even to what we are this heaven will be as nothing, if we wish it, nor yet the sun, nor the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:274
verses.text: For these are for us, and not we for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:275
verses.text: Let us show that we are worthy of having had these made for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:276
verses.text: For if we be found unworthy of these, how shall we be worthy a kingdom? For indeed all that live so as to blaspheme God are unworthy to see the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:277
verses.text: They who blaspheme Him are unworthy to enjoy the creatures who glorify Him: since even a son who insulteth his father is unworthy to be waited upon by the approved servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:278
verses.text: Hence these will enjoy glory, and that great glory; but we shall have to undergo punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:279
verses.text: How miserable then will it be for the creation which was made for thee to be fashioned "according to the glorious liberty of the children of God," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:280
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:281
verses.text: ) but for us who were made children of God, through our much listlessness, to be sent away to destruction and hell, for whose sake the creation shall enjoy that great festal time? Now to keep this from coming to pass, let such of us as have a pure soul keep it still such, or rather let us make its brightness more intense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:282
verses.text: And let those of us that have a soiled one, not despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:283
verses.text: For "if" (he says) "your sins be as purple, I will make them white as snow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:284
verses.text: And if they be as scarlet, I will make them white as wool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:285
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:286
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:287
verses.text: ) But when it is God that promiseth, doubt not, but do those things whereby thou mayest draw to thee these promises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:288
verses.text: Are they unnumbered, the fearful and outrageous acts done by thee? And what of this? For hitherto thou art not gone away into the grave where no man shah confess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:289
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:290
verses.text: xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:291
verses.text: ; Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:292
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:293
verses.text: ) Hitherto the arena (θέατρον) is not broken up for thee, but thou art standing within the line, and thou art able even by a struggle at the last to recover all thy defeats.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:294
verses.text: Thou art not yet come to where the rich man was, for thee to hear it said, "there is a gulf betwixt you and us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:295
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:296
verses.text: ) The Bridegroom is not yet at hand, that one should fear to give you of his oil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:297
verses.text: Still canst thou buy and store up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:298
verses.text: And there is not one yet to say, "Not so; lest there be not enough for us and and you" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:299
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:300
verses.text: ); but there are many that sell, the naked, the hungry, the sick, the imprisoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:301
verses.text: Give food to these, clothing to those, visit the sick, and the oil will come more than from fountains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:302
verses.text: The day of account is not here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:303
verses.text: Use the time as need be, and make deductions from the debts, and to him that oweth "an hundred measures of oil, say, Take thy bill and write fifty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:304
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:305
verses.text: ) And with money, and with words, and with every other thing do in like manner, imitating that steward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:306
verses.text: And advise this to thyself, and also to thy relatives, for thou hast still the power of saying so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:307
verses.text: Thou art not yet come to the necessity of calling in another in their behalf, but thou hast power to give advice at once to thyself and to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:308
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:309
verses.text: ) But when thou art gone away thither, neither of these things wilt thou have it in thy power to do at need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:310
verses.text: And with good reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:311
verses.text: For thou who hast had so long a period fixed thee, and neither done thyself good, nor any else, how when thou art under the Judge's hands shalt thou be able to obtain this grace? Putting all these things together then, let us cling fast to our own salvation, and not lose the opportunity of this life present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:312
verses.text: For it is possible, it is, even at our last breath to please God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:313
verses.text: It is possible to gain approval by thy last will, not indeed in such way as in our lifetime, still it is possible.
