verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:314
verses.text: How, and in what way? If thou leavest Him among thine heirs, and givest Him also (καὶ αὐτᾥ) a portion of thine whole estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:315
verses.text: Hast thou not fed Him in thy lifetime? At all events when departed, when thou art no longer owner, give Him a share of thy goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:316
verses.text: He is loving unto man, He doth not deal niggardly by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:317
verses.text: It is a mark to be sure of a greater desire, and so it will be more rewarded, to feed Him in thy lifetime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:318
verses.text: But if thou hast not done this, at all events do the next best thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:319
verses.text: Leave Him joint-heir (see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:320
verses.text: ) with thy children, and if thou art dilatory over this, bethink thyself that His Father made thee joint-heir with Him, and break down thy inhuman spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:321
verses.text: For what excuse wilt thou have if thou dost not even make Him a sharer with thy children, who made thee share the Heaven, and was slain for thee? And yet all that ever He did, He did not in repayment of a debt, but as bestowing a favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:322
verses.text: But you after so great benefits, have been made a debtor as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:323
verses.text: And yet, though things are so, it is as if receiving a favor, not as demanding payment of a debt, that He crowneth thee; and this too when what He is to receive is His own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:324
verses.text: Give then thy money, which is now no longer of any use to thee, and of which thou art no longer owner; and He will give thee a Kingdom which shall be of service to thee perpetually, and with it will bestow also the things of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:325
verses.text: For if He be made the joint heir of thy children, He doth lighten their orphanage for them, do away with plots against them, beat off insults, stop the mouths of pettifoggers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:326
verses.text: And if they themselves be unable to stand up for their bequeathments, He will Himself stand up, and not let them be broken through.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:327
verses.text: But if He do even allow this, then He makes up of Himself all that was ordered in the will with still greater liberality, because He has been but mentioned in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:328
verses.text: Leave Him then thine heir.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:329
verses.text: For it is to Him that thou art upon the point of going.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:330
verses.text: He will be thy Judge Himself in the trial for all that hath been done here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:331
verses.text: But there are some so miserable and pinched, that though they have no children, still they have not the courage to do this, but approve of giving that they have to hangers on, and to flatterers, and to this person and to that, sooner than to Christ, Who hath done them so great benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:332
verses.text: And what can be more unreasonable than this conduct? For if one were to compare men of this cast to asses, aye, or to stones, one shall not still be saying anything tantamount to their unreasonableness and senselessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:333
verses.text: Nor could one find a similitude to put before you their madness and dementedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:334
verses.text: For what pardon shall they obtain for not having fed Him in their lifetime, who, even when they are on the point of departing to Him, have not the inclination to give Him but a trifle out of those goods, of which they are no longer the owners, but are of such an inimical and hostile disposition, as not even to give Him a share in what is useless to themselves? Do you not know how many of mankind have not even been counted worthy to obtain an end of this kind, but have been snatched off suddenly? But thee doth God empower to give orders to thy kindred, and to speak with them about thy property, and set all that is in thy house in order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:335
verses.text: What defence then wilt thou have to set up, when even after receiving this favor from Him, thou hast treacherously given up the benefit, and art standing as it were in diametrical opposition to thy forefathers in the faith? For they even in their lifetime sold all, and brought it to the Apostle's feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:336
verses.text: But thou, even at thy death, dost not give any share to them that need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:337
verses.text: What is the better part, and gives one much boldness, is to remedy poverty in one's lifetime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:338
verses.text: But if thou hast not been minded to do this, at all events do upon thy death-bed some noble act.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:339
verses.text: For this is not what a strong love for Christ would do, yet still it is an act of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:340
verses.text: For if thou wilt not have the high place with the Lambs, still even to be after them at all is no light thing, and so not to be placed with the goats nor on the left hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:341
verses.text: But if thou wilt not do even this, what plea is to rescue thee, when neither the fear of death nor thy money having become henceforth of no use to thee, nor the leaving of safety behind thee to thy children, nor the laying up of much pardon there against the time to come, will make thee merciful to man? Wherefore I advise, as the best thing, that in your lifetime you give the larger half of your goods to the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:342
verses.text: But if there be any of so narrow a soul as not to have the heart to do so, at all events let them by necessity become merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:343
verses.text: For when you were living as if there were no death, then you clung close to your goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:344
verses.text: But now since you have learnt that you are to die, at least now give over your opinion, and deliberate about your affairs as one that must die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:345
verses.text: Or rather as one that ought to enjoy immortal life for evermore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:346
verses.text: For if what I am going to say be distasteful, and big with horror, still it must be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:347
verses.text: Reckon with thy slaves the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:348
verses.text: Art thou giving thy slaves liberty? Give Christ liberty from famine, from distress, from imprisonment, from nakedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:349
verses.text: Art thou horrified at the words? Is it not then more horrible when thou dost not even thus much? And here the word makes thy blood curdle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:350
verses.text: But when thou art gone to that world, and hast to hear things far more grievous than these, and seest the tortures which are incurable, what wilt thou say? To whom wilt thou flee for refuge? Whom wilt thou call to thy alliance and assistance? Will it be Abraham? He will not hearken to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:351
verses.text: Or those virgins? They will not give thee of their oil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:352
verses.text: Thy father then or thy grandfather? But none even of these, if he be ever so holy, will have it in his power to reverse that sentence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 19:353
verses.text: Weighing then all these things, to Him Who alone is Lord to blot out the bill against thee and to quench that flame, to Him make prayer and supplication, and propitiate Him, by now feeding Him and clothing Him continually: that in this world thou mayest depart with a good hope, and when thou art there thou mayest enjoy eternal blessings, which may we all attain to by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:1
verses.text: Homily XIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:3
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:4
verses.text: "What then?Israel hath not obtained that, which he seeketh for; but the election hath obtained it and the rest were blinded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:5
verses.text: He had said that God did not cast off His people; and to show in what sense He had not cast them off, he takes refuge in the Prophets again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:6
verses.text: And having shown by them that the more part of the Jews were lost, that he might not seem to be again bringing forward an accusation of his own, and to make his discourse offensive, and to be attacking them as enemies, he takes refuge in David and Isaiah, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:7
verses.text: "According as it is written, God hath given them the spirit of slumber".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:8
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:9
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:10
verses.text: )  Or rather we should go back to the beginning of his argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:11
verses.text: Having then mentioned the state of things in Elijah's time, and shown what grace is, he proceeds, "What then? Israel hath not obtained that which he seeketh for".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:12
verses.text: Now this is as much what an accuser would say, as what one who was putting a question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:13
verses.text: For the Jew, he means, is inconsistent with himself when he seeketh for righteousness, which he will not accept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:14
verses.text: Then to leave them with no excuse, he shows, from those who have accepted it, their unfeeling spirit, as he says, "But the election hath obtained it," and they are the condemnation of the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:15
verses.text: And this is what Christ says, "But if I by Beelzebub cast out devils, by whom do your children cast them out? Wherefore they shall be your judges".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:16
verses.text: (Luke xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:17
verses.text: ) For to prevent any one from accusing the nature of the thing, and not their own temper, he points out those who had obtained it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:18
verses.text: Hence he uses the word with great propriety, to show at once the grace from above and the zeal of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:19
verses.text: For it is not to deny free-will that he speaks of their having "obtained" (as by chance, Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:20
verses.text: ἐπέτυχε) it, but to show the greatness of the good things, and that the greater part was of grace, though not the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:21
verses.text: For we too are in the habit of saying, "so and so chanced to get" (same word), "so and so met with," when the gain has been a great one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:22
verses.text: Because it is not by man's labors, but by God's gift, that the greater part was brought about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:23
verses.text: "And the rest was blinded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:24
verses.text: See how he has been bold enough to tell with his own voice the casting off of the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:25
verses.text: For he had indeed spoken of it already, but it was by bringing the prophets in as accusers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:26
verses.text: But from this point he declares it in his own person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:27
verses.text: Still even here he is not content with his own declaration, but brings Isaiah the prophet in again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:28
verses.text: For after saying, "were blinded," he proceeds; "according as it is written, God hath given them the spirit of slumber".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:29
verses.text: Now whence came this blinding? He had indeed mentioned the causes of it before, and turned it all upon their own heads, to show that it was from their unseasonable obstinacy that they had to bear this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:30
verses.text: And now he speaks of it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:31
verses.text: For when he says, "Eyes that they should not see, and ears that they should not hear," he is but finding fault with their contentious spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:32
verses.text: For when they had "eyes to see" the miracles, and were possessed of "ears to hear" that marvellous Teaching, they never used these as were fitting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:33
verses.text: And the "He gave," do not imagine to mean here an agency, but a permission only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:34
verses.text: But "slumber" (καταάνυξις lit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:35
verses.text: piercing) is a name he here gives to the habit of soul inclinable to the worse, when incurably and unchangeably so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:36
verses.text: For in another passage David says, "that my glory may sing unto Thee, and I may not be put to slumber" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:37
verses.text: xxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:38
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:39
verses.text: ): that is, I may not alter, may not be changed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:40
verses.text: For as a man who is hushed to slumber in a state of pious fear would not easily be made to change his side; so too he that is slumbering in wickedness would not change with facility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:41
verses.text: For to be hushed to slumber here is nothing else but to be fixed and riveted to a thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:42
verses.text: In pointing then to the incurable and unchangeable character of their spirit, he calls it "a spirit of slumber".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:43
verses.text: Then to show that for this unbelief they will be most severely punished, he brings the Prophet forward again, threatening the very things which in the event came to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:44
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:45
verses.text: "Let their table be made a snare, and a trap, and a stumbling-block".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:46
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:47
verses.text: lxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:48
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:49
verses.text: )  That is, let their comforts and all their good things change and perish, and let them be open to attack from any one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:50
verses.text: And to show that this is in punishment for sins that they suffer this, he adds, "and a recompense unto them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:52
verses.text: "Let their eyes be darkened that they may not see, and bow Thou down their back alway".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:53
verses.text: Do these things then still require any interpreting? Are they not plain even to those ever so senseless? And before our words, the very issue of facts has anticipated us in bearing witness to what was said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:54
verses.text: For at what time have they ever been so open to attacks? at what time such an easy prey? at what time hath He so "bowed down their backs?" At what time have they been set under such bondage? And what is more, there is not to be any unloosing from these terrors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:55
verses.text: And this the prophet hath also hinted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:56
verses.text: For he does not say only, "bow Thou down their back," but, "forever bow Thou down".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:57
verses.text: But if thou art disposed to dispute, O Jew, about the issue, from what hath gone before learn also the present case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:58
verses.text: Thou didst go down to Egypt; and two hundred years passed, and God freed thee speedily from that bondage, and that though thou wert irreligious, and wentest a whoring with the most baneful whoredom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:59
verses.text: Thou wast freed from Egypt, and thou didst worship the calf, thou didst sacrifice thy sons to Baalpeor, thou didst defile the temple, thou didst go after every sort of vice, thou didst grow not to know nature itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:60
verses.text: The mountains, the groves, the hills, the springs, the rivers, the gardens didst thou fill with accursed sacrifices, thou didst slay the prophets, didst overthrow the altars, didst exhibit every excess of wickedness and irreligion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:61
verses.text: Still, after giving thee up for seventy years to the Babylonians, He brought thee back again to thy former freedom, and gave thee back the temple, and thy country, and thy old form of polity and there were prophets again, and the gift of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:62
verses.text: Or rather, even in the season of thy captivity thou wast not deserted, but even there were Daniel, and Ezekiel, and in Egypt Jeremiah, and in the desert Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:63
verses.text: After this thou didst revert to thy former vice again, and wast a reveller (ἐξεβακχεύθης  Macc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:64
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:65
verses.text: ), therein, and didst change thy manner of life (πολιτείαν to the Grecian in the time of Antiochus the impious Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:66
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:67
verses.text: ;  Macc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:68
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:69
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:70
verses.text: But even then for a three years and a little over only were ye given up to Antiochus, and then by the Maccabees ye raised those bright trophies again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:71
verses.text: But now there is nothing of the sort, for the reverse hath happened throughout.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:72
verses.text: And this is ground for the greatest surprise, as the vices have ceased, and the punishment hath been increased, and is without any hope of a change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:73
verses.text: For it is not seventy years only that have passed away, nor a hundred, nor yet twice as many but three hundred, and a good deal over, and there is no finding even a shadow of a hope of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:74
verses.text: And this though ye neither are idolaters, nor do the other audacious acts ye did before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:75
verses.text: What then is the cause? The reality hath succeeded to the type, and grace hath shut out the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:76
verses.text: And this the prophet foretelling from of old said, "And ever bow Thou down their back".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:77
verses.text: See the minuteness of prophecy, how it foretells their unbelief, and also points out their disputatiousness, and shows the judgment which should follow, and sets forth the endlessness of the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:78
verses.text: For as many of the duller sort, through unbelief in what was to come to pass, wished to see things to come by the light of things present, from this point of time God gave proof of His power on either part, by lifting those of the Gentiles who believed, above the heaven, but bringing down such of the Jews as believed not to the lowest estate of desolation, and giving them up to evils not to be ended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:79
verses.text: Having then urged them severely both about their not believing, and about what they had suffered and were yet to suffer, he again allays what he had said by writing as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:80
verses.text: "I say then, Have they stumbled, that they should fall? God forbid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:81
verses.text: When he has shown that they were liable to evils without number, then he devises an allayment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:82
verses.text: And consider the judgment of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:83
verses.text: The accusation he had introduced from the prophets, but the allayment he makes come from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:84
verses.text: For that they had sinned greatly, he would say, none will gainsay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:85
verses.text: But let us see if the fall is of such kind as to be incurable, and quite preclude their being set up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:86
verses.text: But of such kind it is not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:87
verses.text: You see how he is attacking them again, and under the expectation of some allayment he proves them guilty of confessed sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:88
verses.text: But let us see what even by way of allayment he does devise for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:89
verses.text: Now what is the allayment? "When the fulness of the Gentiles," he says, "shall have come in, then shall all Israel be saved," at the time of his second coming, and the end of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:90
verses.text: Yet this he does not say at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:91
verses.text: But since he had made a hard onset upon them, and linked accusations to accusations, bringing prophets in after prophets crying aloud against them, Isaiah, Elijah, David, Moses, Hosea, not once or twice, but several times; lest in this way he should both by driving these into despair, make a wall to bar their access to the faith, and should further make such of the Gentiles as believed unreasonably elated, and they also by being puffed up should take harm in matter of their faith, he further solaces them by saying, "But rather through their fall salvation is come unto the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:92
verses.text: But we must not take what is here said literally, but get acquainted with the spirit and object of the speaker, and what he aimed to compass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:93
verses.text: Which thing I ever entreat of your love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:94
verses.text: For if with this in our minds we take up what is here said, we shall not find a difficulty in any part of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:95
verses.text: For his present anxiety is to remove from those of the Gentiles the haughtiness which might spring in them from what he had said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:96
verses.text: For in this way they too were more likely to continue unshaken in the faith, when they had learnt to be reasonable, as also those of the Jews were, when quit of despair, more likely to come with readiness to grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:97
verses.text: Having regard then to this object of his, let us so listen to all that is said on this passage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:98
verses.text: What does he say then? And whence does he show that their fall was not irremediable, nor their rejection final? He argues from the Gentiles, saying as follows:  "Through their fall salvation is come unto the Gentiles, for to provoke them to jealousy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:99
verses.text: This language is not his own only, but in the Gospels too the parables mean this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:100
verses.text: For He who made a marriage feast for His Son, when the guests would not come, called those in the highways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:101
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:102
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:103
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:104
verses.text: And He who planted the Vineyard, when the husbandmen slew the Heir, let out His Vineyard to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:105
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:106
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:107
verses.text: , etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:108
verses.text: ) And without any parable, He Himself said, "I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the House of Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:109
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:110
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:111
verses.text: ) And to the Syrophoenician woman, when she persevered, He said somewhat further besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:112
verses.text: "It is not meet," He says, "to take the children's bread, and cast it to the dogs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:113
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:114
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:115
verses.text: ) And Paul to those of the Jews that raised a sedition, "It was necessary that the word of God should first have been spoken unto you: but seeing ye judge yourselves unworthy, lo, we turn unto the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:116
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:117
verses.text: ) And throughout it is clear that the natural course of things was this, that they should be the first to come in, and then those of the Gentiles; but since they disbelieved, the order was reversed; and their unbelief and fall caused these to be brought in first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:118
verses.text: Hence it is that he says, "through their fall salvation is come to the Gentiles, for to provoke them to jealousy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:119
verses.text: But if he mentions what the course of things issued in, as if the chief design of Providence, do not feel surprised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:120
verses.text: For he wishes to solace their down-stricken souls, and his meaning is about this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:121
verses.text: Jesus came to them; they did not receive Him, though He did countless miracles, but crucified Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:122
verses.text: Hence He drew the Gentiles to Him, that the honor they had, by cutting them to the heart for their insensibility might at least out of a moroseness against others persuade them to come over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:123
verses.text: For they ought to have been first admitted, and then we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:124
verses.text: And this was why he said, "For it is the power of God unto salvation unto every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:125
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:126
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:127
verses.text: ) But as they had started off, we the last became first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:128
verses.text: See then how great honors he gathers for them even from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:129
verses.text: One that he says, we were then called, when they were not willing; a second that he says, the reason of our being called was not that we only might be saved, but that they also, growing jealous at our salvation, might become better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:130
verses.text: What does he say then? that if it were not for the Jews' sake, we should not have been called and saved at all? We should not before them, but in the regular order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:131
verses.text: Wherefore also when He was speaking to the disciples, He did not say barely, "Go to the lost sheep of the House of Israel" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:132
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:133
verses.text: ), but, "Go rather to the sheep," to show that to those parts also they must come after these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:134
verses.text: And Paul again saith not, "It was necessary that the word of God should have been spoken unto you," but "should first have been spoken unto you" (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:135
verses.text: ), to show that in the second place it must be to us also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:136
verses.text: And this was both done and said, that they might not be able, shameless though they were, to pretend that they were overlooked, and that was why they did not believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:137
verses.text: This then was why Christ, though he knew all things before, yet came to them first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:138
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:139
verses.text: "Now if the fall of them be the riches of the world, and the diminishing of them the riches of the Gentiles, how much more their fulness?"  Here he is speaking to gratify them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:140
verses.text: For even if these had fallen a thousand times, the Gentiles would not have been saved unless they had shown faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:141
verses.text: As the Jews likewise would not have perished unless they had been unbelieving and disputatious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:142
verses.text: But as I said, he is solacing them now they are laid low, giving them so much the more ground to be confident of their salvation if they altered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:143
verses.text: For if when they stumbled, he says, so many enjoyed salvation, and when they were cast out so many were called, just consider what will be the case when they return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:144
verses.text: But he does not put it thus, When they return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:145
verses.text: Now he does not say "how much more their" return, or their altering, or their well-doing, but "how much more their fulness," that is, when they are all about coming in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:146
verses.text: And this he said to show that then also grace and God's gift will do the larger part, or almost the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:147
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:148
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:149
verses.text: "For I speak to you Gentiles; inasmuch as I am the Apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office; if by any means I may provoke to emulation them which are my flesh, and might save some of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:150
verses.text: Again he endeavors much to get himself clear of untoward suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:151
verses.text: And he seems to be blaming the Gentiles, and to be humbling their conceits, yet he gives a gentle provocation to the Jew also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:152
verses.text: And indeed he goes round about seeking to veil and allay this great ruin of theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:153
verses.text: But he finds no means of doing it, owing to the nature of the facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:154
verses.text: For from what he had said, they deserved but the greater condemnation, when those who were far short of them had taken the good things prepared for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:155
verses.text: This is why then he passes from the Jews to those of the Gentiles, and puts in between his discourse the part about them, as wishing to show that he is saying all these things in order to instruct them to be reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:156
verses.text: For I praise you, he means, for these two reasons; one, because I am necessitated to do so as being your commissioned minister; the other, that through you I may save others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:157
verses.text: And he does not say, my brethren, my kinsmen; but, "my flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:158
verses.text: And next, when pointing out their disputatious spirit, he does not say, "if by any means I may" persuade, but, "provoke to jealousy and save;" and here again not all, but, "some of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:159
verses.text: So hard were they! And even amid his rebuke he shows again the Gentiles honored, for they are causes of their salvation, and not in the same way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:160
verses.text: For they became purveyors of blessings to them through unbelief, but these to the Jews by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:161
verses.text: Hence the estate of the Gentiles seems to be at once equal and superior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:162
verses.text: For what wilt thou say, O Jew? that if we had not been cast out, he would not have been called so soon? This the man of the Gentiles may say too, If I had not been saved, thou wouldest not have been moved to jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:163
verses.text: But if thou wouldest know wherein we have the advantage, I save thee by believing, but it is by stumbling that thou hast afforded us an access before thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:164
verses.text: Then perceiving again that he had touched them to the quick, resuming his former argument, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:165
verses.text: "For if the casting away of them be the reconciling of the world, what shall the receiving of them be but life from the dead?"  Yet this again condemns them, since, while others gained by their sins, they did not profit by other men's well doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:166
verses.text: But if he asserts that to be their doing which necessarily happened, be not surprised: since (as I have said several times) it is to humble these, and to exhort the other, that he throws his address into this form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:167
verses.text: For as I said before, if the Jews had been cast away a thousand times over, and the Gentiles had not shown faith, they would never have been saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:168
verses.text: But he stands by the feeble party, and gives assistance to the distressed one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:169
verses.text: But see also even in his favors to them, how he solaces them in words only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:170
verses.text: "For if the casting away of them be the reconciling of the world," (and what is this to the Jews?) "what shall the receiving of them be but life from the dead?" Yet even this was no boon to them, unless they had been received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:171
verses.text: But what he means is to this effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:172
verses.text: If in anger with them He gave other men so great gifts, when He is reconciled to them what will He not give? But as the resurrection of the dead was not by the receiving of them, so neither now is our salvation through them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:173
verses.text: But they were cast out owing to their own folly, but it is by faith that we are saved, and by grace from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:174
verses.text: But of all this nothing can be of service to them, unless they show the requisite faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:175
verses.text: Yet doing as he is wont, he goes on to another encomium, which is not really one, but which only seems to be, so imitating the wisest physicians, who give their patients as much consolation as the nature of the sickness allows them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:176
verses.text: And what is it that he says?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:177
verses.text: "For if the first-fruits be holy, the lump also is holy; and if the root be holy, so are the branches;"  So calling in this passage by the names of the first-fruit and root Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, the prophets, the patriarchs, all who were of note in the Old Testament; and the branches, those from them who believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:178
verses.text: Then since the fact met him that many had disbelieved, observe how he undermines (ὑποτέμνεται, see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:179
verses.text: ) it again, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:180
verses.text: "And if some of the branches be broken off".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:181
verses.text: And yet above thou didst say that the more part perished, and a few were saved only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:182
verses.text: How came it then that speaking of those that perished, thou hast used a "some," which is indicative of fewness? It is not, he replies, in opposition to myself, but out of a desire to court and recover those that are distressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:183
verses.text: Observe how in the whole of the passage one finds him working at this object, the wish to solace them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:184
verses.text: And if you deny it, many contradictions will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:185
verses.text: But let me beg you to notice his wisdom, how while he seems to be speaking for them, and devising a solace for them, he aims a secret blow at them, and shows that they are devoid of all excuse, even from the "root," from the "first-fruit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:186
verses.text: For consider the badness of the branches, which, when they have a sweet root, still do not imitate it; and the faultiness of the lump, when it is not altered even by the first-fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:187
verses.text: "And if some of the branches were broken off".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:188
verses.text: However, the greater part were broken off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:189
verses.text: Yet, as I said, he wishes to comfort them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:190
verses.text: And this is why it is not in his own person, but in theirs, that he brings in the words used, and even in this gives a secret stroke at them, and shows them to have fallen from being Abraham's kinsmen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:191
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:192
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:193
verses.text: ) For what he was desirous of saying was, that they had nothing in common with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:194
verses.text: (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:195
verses.text: ) For if the root be holy, and these be not holy, then these are far away from the root.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:196
verses.text: Then under the appearance of solacing the Jews, he again by his accusation smiteth them of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:197
verses.text: For after saying, "And if some of the branches were broken off," he proceeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:198
verses.text: "And thou being a wild olive wert grafted in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:199
verses.text: For the less esteem the man of the Gentiles is of, the more the Jew is vexed at seeing him enjoy his goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:200
verses.text: And to the other, the disgrace of the little esteem he was of, is nothing to the honor of the change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:201
verses.text: And consider his skilfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:202
verses.text: He does not say, "thou wert" planted "in," but "thou wert grafted in," by this again cutting the Jew to the heart, as showing that the Gentile man was standing in his own tree, and himself lying on the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:203
verses.text: Wherefore he does not stop even here, nor after he had spoken of grafting in does he leave off (and yet in this he declared the whole matter), but still he dwells over the prosperous state of the Gentile, and enlarges upon his fair fame in the words, "And with them partakest of the root and fatness of the olive tree".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:204
verses.text: And he seems indeed to have viewed him in the light of an addition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:205
verses.text: But he shows that he was no whit the worse on that account, but in possession of everything, that the branch which had come up out of the root had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:206
verses.text: Lest then on hearing the words, "and thou wert grafted in," thou shouldest suppose him to be lacking when compared with the natural branch, see how he makes him equal to it by saying, that "with them thou partakest of the root and fatness of the olive:" that is, hast been put into the same noble rank, the same nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:207
verses.text: Then in rebuking him, and saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:208
verses.text: "Boast not against the branches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:209
verses.text: He seems indeed to be comforting the Jew, but points out his vileness and extreme dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:210
verses.text: And this is why he says not, "boast not," but, "boast not against" do not boast against them so as to sunder them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:211
verses.text: For it is into their place that ye have been set, and their goods that ye enjoy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:212
verses.text: Do you observe how he seems to be rebuking the one, while he is sharp upon the other?  "But if thou boast," he says, "thou bearest not the root, but the root thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:213
verses.text: Now what is this to the branches that are cut off? Nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:214
verses.text: For, as I said before, while seeming to devise a sort of weak shadow of consolation, and in the very midst of his aiming at the Gentile, he gives them a mortal blow; for by saying, "boast not against them," and, "if thou boast, thou bearest not the root," he has shown the Jew that the things done deserved boasting of, even if it was not right to boast, thus at once rousing him and provoking him to faith, and smiting at him, in the attitude of an advocate, and pointing out to him the punishment he was undergoing, and that other men had possession of what were their goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:215
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:216
verses.text: "Thou wilt say then," he goes on, "The branches were broken off that I might be grafted in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:217
verses.text: Again he establishes, by way of objection, the opposite to the former position, to show that what he said before, he had not said as directly belonging to the subject, but to draw them to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:218
verses.text: For it was no longer by their fall that salvation came to the Gentiles, nor was it their fall that was the riches of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:219
verses.text: Nor was it by this that we were saved, because they had fallen, but the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:220
verses.text: And he shows that the providence in regard to the Gentiles was a main object, even though he seems to put what he says into another form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:221
verses.text: And the whole passage is a tissue of objections, in which he clears himself of the suspicion of hatred, and makes his language such as will be acceptable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:222
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:223
verses.text: "Well," he praises what they said, then he alarms them again by saying, "Because of unbelief they were broken off, and thou art grafted in by faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:224
verses.text: So here another encomium, and for the other party an accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:225
verses.text: But he again lays their pride low by proceeding to say, "be not high-minded, but fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:226
verses.text: For the thing is not matter of nature, but of belief and unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:227
verses.text: And he seems to be again bridling the Gentile, but he is teaching the Jew that it is not right to cling to a natural kinsmanship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:228
verses.text: Hence he goes on with, "Be not high-minded," and he does not say, but be humble, but, fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:229
verses.text: For haughtiness genders a contempt and listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:230
verses.text: Then as he is going into all the sorrows of their calamity, in order to make the statement less offensive, he states it in the way of a rebuke given to the other as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:231
verses.text: "For if God spared not the natural branches," and then he does not say, neither will He spare thee, but "take heed, lest He also spare not thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:232
verses.text: So paring (ὑποτεμνόμενος) away the distasteful from his statement, representing the believer as in the struggle, he at once draws the others to him, and humbles these also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:233
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:234
verses.text: "Behold therefore the goodness and severity of God: on them which fell, severity; but toward thee, goodness, if thou continue in His goodness: otherwise thou also shalt be cut off".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:235
verses.text: And he does not say, Behold thy well doing, behold thy labors, but, "Behold the goodness of God" toward man, to show that the whole comes of grace from above, and to make us tremble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:236
verses.text: For this reason for boasting should make thee to fear: since the Lord (δεσπότης) hath been good unto thee, do thou therefore fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:237
verses.text: For the blessings do not abide by thee unmovable if thou turnest listless, as neither do the evils with them, if they alter; "For thou also," he says, "unless thou continue in the faith, wilt be cut off".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:238
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:239
verses.text: "And they also, if they abide not in unbelief, shall be grafted in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:240
verses.text: For it was not God that cut them off, but they have broken themselves off and fallen, and he did well to say have broken themselves off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:241
verses.text: For He hath never yet so (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:242
verses.text: conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:243
verses.text: ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:244
verses.text: corr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:245
verses.text: οὗτος) cast them off, though they have sinned so much and so often.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:246
verses.text: You see what a great thing a man's free choice is, how great the efficacy of the mind is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:247
verses.text: For none of these things is immutable, neither thy good nor his evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:248
verses.text: You see too how he raises up even him in his despondency, and humbles the other in his confidence; and do not thou be faint at hearing of severity, nor thou be confident at hearing of goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:249
verses.text: The reason why He cut thee off in severity was, that thou mightest long to come back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:250
verses.text: The reason why He showed goodness to thee was, that thou mightest continue in (he does not say the faith, but) His goodness, that is, if thou do things worthy of God's love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:251
verses.text: For there is need of something more than faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:252
verses.text: You see how he suffers neither these to lie low, nor those to be elated, but he also provokes them to jealousy, by giving through them a power to the Jew to be set again in this one's place, as he also had first taken the other's ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:253
verses.text: And the Gentile he put in fear by the Jews, and what had happened to them, lest they should feel elated over it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:254
verses.text: But the Jew he tries to encourage by what had been afforded to the Greek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:255
verses.text: For thou also, he says, wilt be cut off if thou growest listless, (for the Jew was cut off), and he will be grafted in if he be earnest, for thou also wast grafted in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:256
verses.text: But it is very judicious in him to direct all he says to the Gentile, as he is always in the habit of doing, correcting the feeble by rebuking the stronger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:257
verses.text: This he does in the end of this Epistle too, when he is speaking of the observance of meats.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:258
verses.text: Then, he grounds this on what had already happened, not upon what was to come only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:259
verses.text: And this was more likely to persuade his hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:260
verses.text: And as he means to enter on consecutiveness of reasonings, such as could not be spoken against, he first uses a demonstration drawn from the power of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:261
verses.text: For if they were cut off, and cast aside, and others took precedence of them in what was theirs, still even now despair not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:262
verses.text: "For God is able," he says, "to graft them in again," since He doeth things beyond expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:263
verses.text: But if thou wishest for things to be in order, and reasons to be consecutive, you have from yourselves a demonstration which more than meets your wants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:264
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:265
verses.text: "For if thou wert cut out of the olive tree, which is wild by nature, and were grafted contrary to nature into a good olive tree, how much more shall these, which be the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:266
verses.text: If then faith was able to do what was contrary to nature, much more will it that which is according to nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:267
verses.text: For if this person, who was cut off from those by nature his fathers, came contrary to nature unto Abraham, much more wilt thou be able to recover thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:268
verses.text: For the Gentile's evil lot is according to nature (he being by nature a wild olive), and the good contrary to nature (it being contrary to nature for him to be grafted into Abraham), but thy lot on the contrary is the good by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:269
verses.text: For it is not upon another root, as the Gentile, but on thine own that thou art to be fixed if thou art minded to come back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:270
verses.text: What then dost thou deserve, when after the Gentile had been able to do what was contrary to nature, thou art not able to do that which is according to nature, but hast given up even this? Then as he had said "contrary to nature," and, "wert grafted in," that you may not suppose the Jew to have the advantage, he again corrects this by saying that he also is grafted in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:271
verses.text: "How much more shall these," says he, "which be the natural branches be grafted into their own olive-tree?" And again, "God is able to graft them in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:272
verses.text: And before this he says, that if they "abide not still in unbelief, they shall be also grafted in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:273
verses.text: And when you hear that he keeps speaking of "according to nature," and "contrary to nature," do not suppose that he means the nature that is unchangeable, but he tells us in these words of the probable and the consecutive, and on the other hand of the improbable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:274
verses.text: For the good things and the bad are not such as are by nature, but by temper and determination alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:275
verses.text: And consider also how inoffensive he is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:276
verses.text: For after saying that thou also wilt be cut off, if thou dost not abide in the faith, and these will be grafted in, if they "abide not still in unbelief," he leaves that of harsh aspect, and insists on that of kindlier sound, and in it he ends, putting great hopes before the Jews if they were minded not to abide so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:277
verses.text: Wherefore he goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:278
verses.text: "For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise your own conceits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:279
verses.text: Meaning by mystery here, that which is unknown and unutterable, and hath much of wonder and much of what one should not expect about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:280
verses.text: As in another passage too he says, "Behold, I tell you a mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:281
verses.text: We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:282
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:283
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:284
verses.text: ) What then is the mystery?  "That blindness in part hath happened unto Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:285
verses.text: Here again he levels a blow at the Jew, while seeming to take down the Gentile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:286
verses.text: But his meaning is nearly this, and he had said it before, that the unbelief is not universal, but only "in part".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:287
verses.text: As when he says, "But if any hath caused grief, he hath not grieved me, but in part" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:288
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:289
verses.text: ): And, so here too he says what he had said above, "God hath not cast off His people whom He foreknew" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:290
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:291
verses.text: ): and again, "What then? Have they stumbled that they should fall? God forbid" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:292
verses.text: ): This then he says here also; that it is not the whole people that is pulled up, but many have already believed, and more are likely to believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:293
verses.text: Then as he had promised a great thing, he adduces the prophet in evidence, speaking as follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:294
verses.text: Now it is not for the fact of a blindness having happened that he quotes the passage (for every one could see that), but that they shall believe and be saved, he brings Isaiah to witness, who crieth aloud and saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:295
verses.text: "There shall come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:296
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:297
verses.text: lix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:298
verses.text: )  Then to give the mark that fixes its sense to salvation, to prevent any one from drawing it aside and attaching it to times gone by, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:299
verses.text: "For this is my covenant unto them, when I shall take away their sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:300
verses.text: Not when they are circumcised, not when they sacrifice, not when they do the other deeds of the Law, but when they attain to the forgiveness of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:301
verses.text: If then this hath been promised, but has never yet happened in their case, nor have they ever enjoyed the remission of sins by baptism, certainly it will come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:302
verses.text: Hence he proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:303
verses.text: "For the gifts and calling of God are without repentance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:304
verses.text: And even this is not all he says to solace them, for he uses what had already come about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:305
verses.text: And what came in of consequence, that he states as chiefly intended, putting it in these words,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:306
verses.text: "As concerning the Gospel, they are enemies for your sakes: but as touching the election, they are beloved for the fathers' sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:307
verses.text: That the Gentile then might not be puffed up, and say, "I am standing, do not tell me of what would have been, but what has been," he uses this consideration to bring him down, and says, "As concerning the Gospel, they are enemies for your sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:308
verses.text: For when you were called they became more captious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:309
verses.text: Nevertheless God hath not even now cut short the calling of you, but He waiteth for all the Gentiles that are to believe to come in, and then they also shall come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:310
verses.text: Then he does them another kind favor, by saying, "As touching election, they are beloved for the fathers sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:311
verses.text: And what is this? for wherein they are enemies, punishment is theirs: but wherein they are beloved, the virtue of their ancestors has no influence on them, if they do not believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:312
verses.text: Nevertheless, as I said, he ceaseth not to solace them with words, that he may bring them over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:313
verses.text: Wherefore by way of fresh proof for his former assertion, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:314
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:315
verses.text: "For as ye in times past have not believed God, yet have now obtained mercy through their unbelief; even so have these also now not believed, that through your mercy they may also obtain mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:316
verses.text: For God hath concluded them all in unbelief, that He might have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:317
verses.text: He shows here that those of the Gentiles were called first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:318
verses.text: Then, as they would not come, the Jews were elected, and the same result occurred again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:319
verses.text: For when the Jews would not believe, again the Gentiles were brought over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:320
verses.text: And he does not stop here, nor does he draw the whole to a conclusion at their rejection, but at their having mercy shown them again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:321
verses.text: See how much he gives to those of the Gentiles, as much as he did to the Jews before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:322
verses.text: For when ye, he would say, "in times past did not obey," being of the Gentiles, then the Jews came in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:323
verses.text: Again, when these did not obey, ye have come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:324
verses.text: However, they will not perish forever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:325
verses.text: "For God hath concluded them all in unbelief," that is, hath convinced them, hath shown them disobedient; not that they may remain in disobedience, but that He may save the one by the captiousness of the other, these by those and those by these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:326
verses.text: Now consider; ye were disobedient, and they were saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:327
verses.text: Again, they have been disobedient, and ye have been saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:328
verses.text: Yet ye have not been so saved as to be put away again, as the Jews were, but so as to draw them over through jealousy while ye abide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:329
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:330
verses.text: "Oh, the depth of the riches, both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments!"  Here after going back to former times, and looking back to God's original dispensation of things whereby the world hath existed up to the present time, and having considered what special provision He had made for all occurrences, he is stricken with awe, and cries aloud, so making his hearers feel confident that certainly that will come to pass which he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:331
verses.text: For he would not have cried aloud and been awe-struck, unless this was quite sure to come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:332
verses.text: That it is a depth then, he knows: but how great, he knows not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:333
verses.text: For the language is that of a person wondering, not of one that knew the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:334
verses.text: But admiring and being awe-struck at the goodliness, so far forth as in him lay, he heralds it forth by two intensitive words, riches and depth, and then is awestruck at His having had both the will and the power to do all this, and by opposites effecting opposites.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:335
verses.text: "How unsearchable are His judgments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:336
verses.text: For they are not only impossible to be comprehended, but even to be searched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:337
verses.text: "And His ways past finding out;" that is, His dispensations for these also are not only impossible to be known, but even to be sought into.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:338
verses.text: For even I, he means, have not found out the whole, but a little part, not all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:339
verses.text: For He alone knoweth His own clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:340
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:341
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:342
verses.text: "For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been His counsellor? Or who hath first given to Him, and it shall be recompensed unto him again?"  What he means is nearly this: that though He is so wise, yet He has not His Wisdom from any other, but is Himself the Fountain of good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:343
verses.text: And though He hath done so great things, and made us so great presents, yet it was not by borrowing from any other that He gave them, but by making them spring forth from Himself; nor as owing any a return for having received from him, but as always being Himself the first to do the benefits; for this is a chief mark of riches, to overflow abundantly, and yet need no aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:344
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds to say, "For of Him, and through Him, and to Him, are all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:345
verses.text: Himself devised, Himself created, Himself worketh together (Vulg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:346
verses.text: συγκρατεἵ, mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:347
verses.text: συγκροτεἵ ).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:348
verses.text: For He is rich, and needeth not to receive from another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:349
verses.text: And wise, and needeth no counsellor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:350
verses.text: Why speak I of a counsellor? To know the things of Him is no one able, save Himself alone, the Rich and Wise One.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:351
verses.text: For it is proof of much riches that He should make them of the Gentiles thus well supplied; and of much wisdom that He should constitute the inferiors of the Jews their teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:352
verses.text: Then as he was awe-struck he offers up thanksgiving also in the word, "To Whom be glory forever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:353
verses.text: For when he tells of any great and unutterable thing of this kind, he ends in wonder with a doxology.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:354
verses.text: And this he does in regard to the Son also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:355
verses.text: For in that passage also he went on to the very same thing that he does here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:356
verses.text: "Of whom is Christ according to the flesh, Who is over all God blessed forever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:357
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:358
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:359
verses.text: )  Him then let us also imitate, and let us glorify God in all things, by a heedful way of life, and let us not feel confidence in the virtues of our ancestry, knowing the example that has been made of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:360
verses.text: For this is not, certainly it is not, the relationship of Christians, for theirs is the kinsmanship of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:361
verses.text: So the Scythian becometh Abraham's son: and his son on the other hand more of an alien to him than the Scythian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:362
verses.text: Let us not then feel confidence in the well-doings of our fathers (most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:363
verses.text: "of others"), but if you have a parent who is a marvel even, fancy not that this will be enough to save you, or to get you honor and glory, unless you have the relationship of character to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:364
verses.text: So too if you have a bad one, do not think that you will be condemned on this account, or be put to shame if at least you order your own doings aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:365
verses.text: For what can be less honorable than the Gentiles? still in faith they soon became related to the Saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:366
verses.text: Or what more nearly connected than the Jews? Yet still by unbelief they were made aliens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:367
verses.text: For that relationship is of nature and necessity, after which we are all relations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:368
verses.text: For of Adam we all sprung, and none can be more a relation than another, both as regards Adam and as regards Noah, and as regards the earth, the common mother of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:369
verses.text: But the relationship worthy of honors, is that which does distinguish us from the wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:370
verses.text: For it is not possible for all to be relations in this way, but those of the same character only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:371
verses.text: Nor do we call them brothers who come of the same labor with ourselves, but those who display the same zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:372
verses.text: In this way Christ giveth men the name of children of God, and so on the other hand children of the devil, and so too children of disobedience, of hell, and of perdition likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:373
verses.text: So Timothy was Paul's son from goodness and was called "mine own son" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:374
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:375
verses.text: ): but of his sister's son we do not know even the name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:376
verses.text: And yet the one was by nature related to him, and still that availed him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:377
verses.text: But the other being both by nature and country far removed from him (as being a native of Lystra), still became most nearly related.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:378
verses.text: Let us then also become the sons of the Saints, or rather let us become even God's sons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:379
verses.text: For that it is possible to become sons of God, hear what he says, "Be ye therefore perfect, as your father which is in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:380
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:381
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:382
verses.text: ) This is why we call Him Father in prayer, and that not only to remind ourselves of the grace, but also of virtue, that we may not do aught unworthy of such a relationship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:383
verses.text: And how it may be said is it possible to be a son of God? by being free from all passions, and showing gentleness to them that affront and wrong us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:384
verses.text: For thy Father is so to them that blaspheme Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:385
verses.text: Wherefore, though He says various things at various times, yet in no case does He say that ye may be like your Father, but when He says, "Pray for them that despitefully use you, do good to them that hate you" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:386
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:387
verses.text: ), then He brings in this as the reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:388
verses.text: For there is nothing that brings us so near to God, and makes us so like Him, as this well-doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:389
verses.text: Therefore Paul also, when he says, "Be ye followers of God" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:390
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:391
verses.text: ), means them to be so in this respect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:392
verses.text: For we have need of all good deeds, chiefly however of love to man and gentleness, since we need so much of His love to man ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:393
verses.text: For we commit many transgressions every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:394
verses.text: Wherefore also we have need to show much mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:395
verses.text: But much and little is not measured by the quantity of things given, but by the amount of the givers' means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:396
verses.text: Let not then the rich be high-minded, nor the poor dejected as giving so little, for the latter often gives more than the former.
