verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:397
verses.text: We must not then make ourselves miserable because we are poor, since it makes alms-giving the easier for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:398
verses.text: For he that has got much together is seized with haughtiness, as well as a greater affection to that (or "lust beyond that") he has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:399
verses.text: But he that hath but a little is quit of either of these domineering passions: hence he finds more occasions for doing well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:400
verses.text: For this man will go cheerfully into a prison-house, and will visit the sick, and will give a cup of cold water.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:401
verses.text: But the other will not take upon him any office of this sort, as pampered up (φλεγμαίνων) by his riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:402
verses.text: Be not then out of heart at thy poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:403
verses.text: For thy poverty makes thy traffic for heaven the easier to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:404
verses.text: And if thou have nothing, but have a compassionating soul, even this will be laid up as a reward for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:405
verses.text: Hence too Paul bade us "weep with them that weep" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:406
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:407
verses.text: ), and exhorted us to be to prisoners as though bound with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:408
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:409
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:410
verses.text: ) For it is not to them that weep only that it yieldeth some solace that there be many that compassionate them, but to them who are in other afflicting circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:411
verses.text: For there are cases where conversation has as much power to recover him that is cast down as money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:412
verses.text: For this then God exhorts us to give money to them that ask, not merely with a view to relieve their poverty, but that He may teach us to compassionate the misfortunes of our neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:413
verses.text: For this also the covetous man is odious, in that he not only disregards men in a beggared state, but because he gets himself trained (ἀλείφεται) for cruelty and great inhumanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:414
verses.text: And so he that, for their sakes, thinks little of money, is even on this account an object of love, that he is merciful and kind to man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:415
verses.text: And Christ, when He blesseth the merciful, blesseth and praiseth not those only that give the alms of money, but those also who have the will to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:416
verses.text: Let us then be so inclinable to mercy, and all other blessings will follow, for he that hath a spirit of love and mercy, if he have money, will give it away, or if he see any in distress, will weep and bewail it; if he fall in with a person wronged, will stand up for him; if he sees one spitefully entreated, will reach out his hand to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:417
verses.text: For as he has that treasure-house of blessings, a loving and merciful soul, he will make it a fountain for all his brethren's needs, and will enjoy all the rewards that are laid up with God (Field with  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:418
verses.text: τᾥ θεᾥ).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:419
verses.text: That we then may attain to these, let us of all things frame our souls accordingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:420
verses.text: For so, while in this world, we shall do good deeds without number, and shall enjoy the crowns to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 20:421
verses.text: To which may we all attain by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:1
verses.text: Homily XX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:3
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:4
verses.text: "I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:5
verses.text: After discoursing at large upon the love of God toward man, and pointing out His unspeakable concern for us, and unutterable goodness, which cannot even be searched into, he next puts it forward with a view of persuading those who have received the benefit to exhibit a conversation worthy of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:6
verses.text: And though he is so great and good a person, yet he does not decline beseeching them, and that not for any enjoyment he was likely to get himself, but for that they would have to gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:7
verses.text: And why wonder that he does not decline beseeching, where he is even putting God's mercies before them? For since, he means, it is from this you have those numberless blessings, from the mercies of God, reverence them, be moved to compassion by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:8
verses.text: For they themselves take the attitude of suppliants, that you would show no conduct unworthy of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:9
verses.text: I entreat you then, he means, by the very things through which ye were saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:10
verses.text: As if any one who wished to make a person, who had had great kindnesses done him, show regard, was to bring him the benefactor himself as a suppliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:11
verses.text: And what dost thou beseech? let me hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:12
verses.text: "That ye would present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:13
verses.text: For when he had said sacrifice, to prevent any from thinking he bade them kill themselves, he forthwith added (Greek order) "living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:14
verses.text: Then to distinguish it from the Jewish, he calls it "holy, acceptable to God, your reasonable service".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:15
verses.text: For theirs was a material one, and not very acceptable either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:16
verses.text: Since He saith, "Who hath required this at your hands?" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:17
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:18
verses.text: ) And in sundry other passages He clearly throws them aside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:19
verses.text: For it was not this, but this with the other, that He looked to have presented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:20
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "The sacrifice of praise shall glorify Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:21
verses.text: And again, "I will praise the name of my God with a song, and this shall please him better than a bullock that putteth forth horns and hoofs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:22
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.text: ) and proceeds with, "Offer unto God a sacrifice of praise, and pay thy vows unto the Most High".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:29
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:30
verses.text: ) So Paul also here bids us "present our bodies a living sacrifice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:31
verses.text: And how is the body, it may be said, to become a sacrifice? Let the eye look upon no evil thing, and it hath become a sacrifice; let thy tongue speak nothing filthy, and it hath become an offering; let thine hand do no lawless deed, and it hath become a whole burnt offering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:32
verses.text: Or rather this is not enough, but we must have good works also: let the hand do alms, the mouth bless them that cross one, and the hearing find leisure evermore for lections of Scripture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:33
verses.text: For sacrifice allows of no unclean thing: sacrifice is a first-fruit of the other actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:34
verses.text: Let us then from our hands, and feet, and mouth, and all other members, yield a first-fruit unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:35
verses.text: Such a sacrifice is well pleasing, as that of the Jews was even unclean, for, "their sacrifices," it says, "are unto them as the bread of mourning".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:36
verses.text: (Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:37
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:38
verses.text: ) Not so ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:39
verses.text: That presented the thing sacrificed dead: this maketh the thing sacrificed to be living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:40
verses.text: For when we have mortified our members, then we shall be able to live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:41
verses.text: For the law of this sacrifice is new, and so the sort of fire is a marvellous one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:42
verses.text: For it needeth no wood or matter under it; but our fire liveth of itself, and doth not burn up the victim, but rather quickeneth it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:43
verses.text: This was the sacrifice that God sought of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:44
verses.text: Wherefore the Prophet saith, "The sacrifice of God is a broken spirit".

verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:48
verses.text: Nevertheless, in a contrite heart and an humble spirit let us be accepted".

Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:51
verses.text: ) And observe how great the exactness wherewith he useth each word.

verses.text: ) your bodies as a sacrifice, but "present" (παραστήσατε see below) them, as if he had said, never more have any interest in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:56
verses.text: Ye have given them up to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:57
verses.text: For even they that furnish (same word) the war-horses have no further interest in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:58
verses.text: And thou too hast presented thy members for the war against the devil and for that dread battle-array.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:59
verses.text: Do not let them down to selfish appliances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:60
verses.text: And he shows another thing also from this, that one must make them approved, if one means to present them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:61
verses.text: For it is not to any mortal being that we present them, but to God, the King of the universe; not to war only, but to have seated thereon the King Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:62
verses.text: For He doth not refuse even to be seated upon our members, but even greatly desireth it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:63
verses.text: And what no king who is but our fellow-servant would choose to do, that the Lord of Angels chooseth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:64
verses.text: Since then it is both to be presented (i-e: as for a King's use) and is a sacrifice, rid it of every spot, since if it have a spot, it will no longer be a sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:65
verses.text: For neither can the eye that looks lecherously be sacrificed, nor the hand be presented that is grasping and rapacious, nor the feet that go lame and go to play-houses, nor the belly that is the slave of self-indulgence, and kindleth lusts after pleasures, nor the heart that hath rage in it, and harlots' love, nor the tongue that uttereth filthy things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:66
verses.text: Hence we must spy out the spots on our body upon every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:67
verses.text: For if they that offered the sacrifices of old were bid to look on every side, and were not permitted to offer an animal "that hath anything superfluous or lacking, or is scurvy, or scabbed" (Lev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:68
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:69
verses.text: , ), much more must we, who offer not senseless animals, but ourselves, exhibit more strictness, and be pure in all respects, that we also may be able to say as did Paul, "I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:70
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:71
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:72
verses.text: ) For he was purer than any sacrifice, and so he speaks of himself as "ready to be offered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:73
verses.text: But this will be brought about if we kill the old man, if we mortify our members that are upon the earth, if we crucify the world unto ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:74
verses.text: In this way we shall not need the knife any more, nor altar, nor fire, or rather we shall want all these, but not made with the hands, but all of them will come to us from above, fire from above, and knife also, and our altar will the breadth of Heaven be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:75
verses.text: For if when Elijah offered the visible sacrifice, a flame, that came down from above consumed the whole water, wood, and stones, much more will this be done upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:76
verses.text: And if thou hast aught in thee relaxed and secular, and yet offerest the sacrifice with a good intention, the fire of the Spirit will come down, and both wear away that worldliness, and perfect (so Field: mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:77
verses.text: "carry up") the whole sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:78
verses.text: But what is "reasonable (λογικὴ) service?" It means spiritual ministry, conversation according to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:79
verses.text: As then he that ministereth in the house of God, and officiateth, of whatever sort he may be, then collects himself (συστέλλεται Ezech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:80
verses.text: xliv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:81
verses.text: ), and becomes more dignified; so we ought to be minded all our whole life as serving and ministering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:82
verses.text: And this will be so, if every day you bring Him sacrifices ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:83
verses.text: "thyself as a sacrifice"), and become the priest of thine own body, and of the virtue of thy soul; as, for example, when you offer soberness, when alms-giving, when goodness and forbearance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:84
verses.text: For in doing this thou offerest "a reasonable service" (or worship, λατρείαν), that is, one without aught that is bodily, gross, visible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:85
verses.text: Having then raised the hearer by the names bestowed, and having shown that each man is a priest of his own flesh by his conversation, he mentions also the way whereby we may compass all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:86
verses.text: What then is the way?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:87
verses.text: "And be not fashioned after this world; but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:88
verses.text: For the fashion of this world is grovelling and worthless, and but for a time, neither hath ought of loftiness, or lastingness, or straightforwardness, but is wholly perverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:89
verses.text: If then thou wouldest walk upright (or aright ὀρθὰ), figure not thyself after the fashion of this life present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:90
verses.text: For in it there is nought abiding or stable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:91
verses.text: And this is why he calls it a fashion (σχἥμα); and so in another passage, "the fashion of this world passeth away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:92
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:93
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:94
verses.text: ) For it hath no durability or fixedness, but all in it is but for a season; and so he calls it this age (or world, Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:95
verses.text: αἰ& ·ν), hereby to indicate its liableness to misfortune, and by the word fashion its unsubstantialness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:96
verses.text: For speak of riches, or of glory, or beauty of person, or of luxury, or of whatever other of its seemingly great things you will, it is a fashion only, not reality, a show and a mask, not any abiding substance (ὑπόστασις).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:97
verses.text: But "be not thou fashioned after this, but be transformed," he says, "by the renewing of your mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:98
verses.text: He says not change the fashion, but "be transformed" (μεταμορφοὕ), to show that the world's ways are a fashion, but virtue's not a fashion, but a kind of real form, with a natural beauty of its own, lacking not the trickeries and fashions of outward things, which no sooner appear than they go to nought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:99
verses.text: For all these things, even before they come to light, are dissolving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:100
verses.text: If then thou throwest the fashion aside, thou wilt speedily come to the form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:101
verses.text: For nothing is more strengthless than vice, nothing so easily wears old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:102
verses.text: Then since it is likely that being men they would sin every day, he consoles his hearer by saying, "renew thyself" from day to day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:103
verses.text: This is what we do with houses, we keep constantly repairing them as they wear old, and so do thou unto thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:104
verses.text: Hast thou sinned to-day? hast thou made thy soul old? despair not, despond not, but renew it by repentance, and tears (Hilary on Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:105
verses.text: cxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:106
verses.text: ), and confession, and by doing of good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:107
verses.text: And never fail of doing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:108
verses.text: And how are we to do this?  "That ye may prove (things more expedient (διαφέροντα), and know) what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:109
verses.text: Either he means by this, be renewed, that ye may learn what is more expedient for you, and what the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:110
verses.text: Or rather, that ye can get so renewed if ye learn the things expedient, and what God may will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:111
verses.text: For if thou see this, and know how to distinguish the nature of things, thou art in possession of the whole way of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:112
verses.text: And who, it may be said, is ignorant of what is expedient, and what is the will of God? They that are flurried with the things of this world, they that deem riches an enviable thing, they that make light of poverty, they that follow after power, they that are gaping after outward glory, they that think themselves great men when they raise fine houses, and buy costly sepulchres, and keep herds of slaves, and carry a great swarm of eunuchs about with them; these know not what is expedient for them, or what the will of God is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:113
verses.text: For both of these are but one thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:114
verses.text: For God willeth what things are expedient for us, and what God willeth, that is also expedient for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:115
verses.text: What then are the things which God willeth? to live in poverty, in lowliness of mind, in contempt of glory; in continency, not in self-indulgence; in tribulation, not in ease; in sorrow, not in dissipation and laughter; in all the other points whereon He hath given us laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:116
verses.text: But the generality do even think these things of ill omen; so far are they from thinking them expedient, and the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:117
verses.text: This then is why they never can come near even to the labors for virtue's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:118
verses.text: For they that do not know so much even as what virtue may be, but reverence vice in its place, and take unto their bed the harlot instead of the modest wife, how are they to be able to stand aloof from the present world? Wherefore we ought above all to have a correct estimate of things, and even if we do not follow after virtue, to praise virtue, and even if we do not avoid vice, to stigmatize vice, that so far we may have our judgments uncorrupted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:119
verses.text: For so as we advance on our road, we shall be able to lay hold on the realities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:120
verses.text: This then is why he also bids you be renewed, "that ye may prove what is the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:121
verses.text: But here he seems to me to be attacking the Jews too, who cling to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:122
verses.text: For the old dispensation was a will of God, yet not the ultimate purpose, but allowed owing to their feebleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:123
verses.text: But that which is a perfect one, and well-pleasing, is the new conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:124
verses.text: So too when he called it "a reasonable service," it was to set it in contrast with that other (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:125
verses.text: note p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:126
verses.text: ) that he gave it such a name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:127
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:128
verses.text: "For I say, through the grace given unto me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think, but to think soberly, according as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:129
verses.text: After saying above, "I beseech you by the mercies," here he says again, "by the grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:130
verses.text: Observe the teacher's lowliness of mind, observe a spirit quite subdued! He means to say that he is in no respect worthy to be trusted in such an exhortation and counsel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:131
verses.text: But at one time he takes the mercies of God along with him, at another His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:132
verses.text: It is not my word, he would say, that I am speaking, but one from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:133
verses.text: And he does not say, For I say unto you by the wisdom of God, or, for I say unto you by the Law given of God, but, "by the grace," so reminding them continually of the benefits done them, so as to make them more submissive, and to show that even on this account, they were under an obligation to obey what is here said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:134
verses.text: "To every man that is among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:135
verses.text: Not to this person and to that merely, but to the governor and to the governed, to the slave and to the free, to the unlearned and to the wise, to the woman and to the man, to the young and to the old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:136
verses.text: For the Law is common to all as being the Lord's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:137
verses.text: And by this he likewise makes his language inoffensive, setting the lessons he gives to all, even to such as do not come under them, that those who do come under them may with more willingness accept such a reproof and correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:138
verses.text: And what dost thou say? Let me hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:139
verses.text: "Not to think more highly than he ought to think".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:140
verses.text: Here he is bringing before us the mother of good deeds, which is lowliness of mind, in imitation of his own Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:141
verses.text: For as He, when He went up into the mountain, and was going to give a tissue of moral precepts, took this for his first beginning, and made this the foundation, in the words, "Blessed are the poor in spirit" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:142
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:143
verses.text: ); so Paul too, as he has now passed from the doctrinal parts to those of a more practical kind, has taught us virtue in general terms, by requiring of us the admirable sacrifice; and being on the point of giving a more particular portrait of it, he begins from lowliness of mind as from the head, and tells us, "not to think more highly of one's self than one ought to think," (for this is His will), (many mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:144
verses.text: om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:145
verses.text: for etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:146
verses.text: ), "but to think soberly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:147
verses.text: But what he means is about this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:148
verses.text: We have received wisdom not that we should use it to make us haughty, but to make us sober-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:149
verses.text: And he does not say in order to be lowly in mind, but in order to sobriety, meaning by sobriety (σωφροσύνη) here not that virtue which contrasts with lewdness, nor the being free from intemperance, but being sober and healthful in mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:150
verses.text: And the Greek name of it means keeping the mind safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:151
verses.text: To show then that he who is not thus modest (μετριάζοντα), cannot be sober either, that is, cannot be staid and healthful minded (because such an one is bewildered, and out, of his wits, and is more crazed than any madman), he calls lowliness of mind, soberness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:152
verses.text: "According as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:153
verses.text: For since having gifts given them had made many unreasonably elated, both with these and with the Corinthians, see how he lays open the cause of the disease, and gradually removes it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:154
verses.text: For after saying that we should think soberly, he proceeds, "according as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith," meaning here the gift by faith: and by using the word "dealt," he solaces him who had the less, and humbles him who had the greater share.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:155
verses.text: For if God dealt it, and it is no achievement of thine, why think highly of thyself? But if any one says that faith here does not mean the gift, this would only the more show that he was humbling the vain boasters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:156
verses.text: For if that which is the cause of the gift (so Field with most mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:157
verses.text: : Vulg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:158
verses.text: "If the faith by which miracles are wrought is the cause of the gift"), that faith by which miracles are wrought, be itself from God, on what ground dost thou think highly of thyself? If He had not come, or been incarnate, then the things of faith would not have fared well either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:159
verses.text: And it is from hence that all the good things take their rise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:160
verses.text: But if it is He that giveth it, He knoweth how He dealeth it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:161
verses.text: For He made all, and taketh like care of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:162
verses.text: And as His giving came of His love towards man, so doth the quantity which He giveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:163
verses.text: For was He Who had shown His goodness in regard to the main point, which is the giving of the gift, likely to neglect thee in regard to the measure? For had He wished to do thee dishonor, then He had not given them at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:164
verses.text: But if to save thee and to honor thee was what He had in view (and for this He came and distributed such great blessings), why art thou confounded and disturbed, and abusest thy wisdom to foolishness, making thyself more disgraceful than one who is by nature so? For being foolish by nature is no ground of complaint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:165
verses.text: But being foolish through wisdom, is at once bereaving one's self of excuse, and running into greater punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:166
verses.text: Such then are those, who pride themselves upon their wisdom, and fall into the excess of recklessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:167
verses.text: For recklessness of all things makes a person a fool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:168
verses.text: Wherefore the Prophet calls the barbarian by this name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:169
verses.text: But "the fool," he says, "shall speak folly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:170
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:171
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:172
verses.text: ) But that you may see the folly of him from his own words, hear what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:173
verses.text: "Above the stars of heaven will I place my throne, and I will be like the Most High".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:174
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:175
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:176
verses.text: ) "I will take hold of the world as a nest, and as eggs that are left will I take them away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:177
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:178
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:179
verses.text: ) Now what can be more foolish than these words? And every instance of haughty language immediately draws on itself this reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:180
verses.text: And if I were to set before you every expression of them that are reckless, you would not be able to distinguish whether the words are those of a reckless man or a fool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:181
verses.text: So entirely the same is this failing and that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:182
verses.text: And another of a strange nation says again, "I am God and not man" (Ezech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:183
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:184
verses.text: ); and another again, Can God save you, or deliver you out of my hand?" (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:185
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:186
verses.text: ) And the Egyptian too, "I know not the Lord, neither will I let Israel go".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:187
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:188
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:189
verses.text: ) And the foolish body in the Psalmist is of this character, who hath "said in his heart, There is no God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:190
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:191
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:192
verses.text: ) And Cain, "Am I my brother's keeper?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:193
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:194
verses.text: ) Can you now distinguish whether the words are those of the reckless or those of the fool? For recklessness going out of due bounds, and being a departure from reason (whence its name recklessness, ἀπόνοια), maketh men both fools and vainglorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:195
verses.text: For likewise, "the beginning of wisdom is the fear of the Lord" (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:196
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:197
verses.text: ), so then the beginning of folly is surely not knowing the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:198
verses.text: If then knowing be wisdom, and not knowing Him folly, and this ignorance come of haughtiness (ὑπερηφανία), (for the beginning of haughtiness is the not knowing of the Lord), then is haughtiness the extreme of folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:199
verses.text: Such was Nabal, if not to Godward, at least toward man, having become senseless from his recklessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:200
verses.text: But he afterwards died of fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:201
verses.text: For when any falleth from the measure of wisdom, he becomes at once a coward and bold (θρασυδειλοὶ Ar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:202
verses.text: Eth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:203
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:204
verses.text: ), his soul having been made feeble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:205
verses.text: For as the body when it loseth its proper tone having become out of condition, is a prey to any disease, thus too the soul when it hath lost its greatness of nature and lowly-mindedness, having gotten any feeble habit (ἕξιν), becomes fearful, as well as bold and unreasonable, and loses its powers of self-consciousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:206
verses.text: And he that has lost these, how is he to know things above himself? For as he that is seized with a frenzy, when he has so lost them, knoweth not even what is right before him; and the eye, when it is dimmed, darkeneth all the other members; so doth it happen with this recklessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:207
verses.text: Wherefore these are more miserable than the mad, or than those silly by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:208
verses.text: For like them they stir laughter, and like them they are ill-tempered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:209
verses.text: And they are out of their wits as the others are, but they are not pitied as they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:210
verses.text: And they are beside themselves, as are these, but they are not excused, as are these, but are hated only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:211
verses.text: And while they have the failings of either, they are bereaved of the excuse of either, being ridiculous not owing to their words only, but to their whole appearance also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:212
verses.text: For why, pray, dost thou stiffen up thy neck? or why walk on tiptoe? why knit up thy brows? why stick thy breast out? Thou canst not make one hair white or black, (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:213
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:214
verses.text: ) and thou goest with as lofty gait as if thou couldest command everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:215
verses.text: No doubt thou wouldest like to have wings, and not go upon the earth at all! No doubt thou wouldest wish to be a prodigy! For hast thou not made thyself prodigious now, when thou art a man and triest to fly? or rather flying from within, and bloated in every limb? What shall I call thee to quit thee of thy recklessness? Shall I call thee ashes, and dust, and smoke, and pother? I have described thy worthlessness to be sure, but still I have not laid hold of the exact image I wanted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:216
verses.text: For I want to put their bloatedness before me, and all its emptiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:217
verses.text: What image am I to find then which will suit with all this? To me it seems to be like tow in a blaze.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:218
verses.text: For it seems to swell when lighted, and to lift itself up; but when it is submitted to a slight touch of the hand, it all tumbles down, and turns out to be more worthless than the veriest ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:219
verses.text: Of this sort are the souls of these men; that empty inflatedness of theirs even the commonest attack may humble and bring down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:220
verses.text: For he that behaves recklessly must of necessity be a thoroughly feeble person, since the height he has is not a sound one, but even as bubbles are easily burst, so are these men easily undone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:221
verses.text: But if thou dost not believe, give me a bold reckless fellow, and you will find him more cowardly than a hare even at the most trivial circumstance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:222
verses.text: For as the flame that rises from dry sticks is no sooner lighted than it becomes dust, but stiff logs do not by their nature easily kindle up, and then keep up their flame a long time burning; so souls that be stern and firm are not easily kindled or extinguished; but these men undergo both of these in a single moment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:223
verses.text: Since then we know this, let us practise humble-mindedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:224
verses.text: For there is nothing so powerful as it, since it is stronger even than a rock and harder than adamant, and places us in a safety greater than that of towers and cities and walls, being too high for any of the artillery of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:225
verses.text: As then recklessness makes men an easy prey even to ordinary occurrences, being, as I was saying, easier broken than a bubble, and rent more speedily than a spider's web, and more quickly dissolved than a smoke; that we then may be walking upon the strong rock, let us leave that and take to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 21:226
verses.text: For thus in this life present we shall find rest, and shall in the world to come have every blessing, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:1
verses.text: Homily XXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:3
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:4
verses.text: ,  "For as we have many members in one body, and all members have not the same office; so we, being many, are one body in Christ, and every one members one of another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:5
verses.text: Again he uses the same ensample as he does to the Corinthians, and that to allay the same passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:6
verses.text: For great is the power of the medicine, and the force of this illustration for the correcting of this disease of haughtiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:7
verses.text: Why (he means) dost thou think highly of thyself? Or why again does another utterly despise himself? Are we not all one body, both great and small? When then we are in the total number but one, and members one of another, why dost thou by thy haughtiness separate thyself? Why dost thou put thy brother to shame? For as he is a member of thee, so art thou also of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:8
verses.text: And it is on this score that your claims to honor are so equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:9
verses.text: For he has stated two things that might take down their haughty spirit: one that we are members one of another, not the small of the great only, but also the great of the small; and another, that we are all one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:10
verses.text: Or rather there are three points, since he shows that the gift was one of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:11
verses.text: "Therefore be not high-minded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:12
verses.text: For it was given thee of God; thou didst not take it, nor find it even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:13
verses.text: Hence too, when he touches upon the gifts, he does not say that one received more, and another less, but what? different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:14
verses.text: For his words are, "having then gifts," not less and greater, but, "differing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:15
verses.text: And what if thou art not appointed to the same office, still the body is the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:16
verses.text: And beginning with gifts, he ends with a good deed ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:17
verses.text: pl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:18
verses.text: ); and so after mentioning prophecy, and ministry, and the like, he concludes with mercy, diligence, and succor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:19
verses.text: Since then it was likely that some would be virtuous, yet not have prophecy, he shows how that this too is a gift, and a much greater one than the other (as he shows in the Epistle to the Corinthians), and so much the greater, as that one has a reward, the other is devoid of a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:20
verses.text: For the whole is matter of gift and grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:21
verses.text: Wherefore he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:22
verses.text: "Having then gifts differing according to the grace of God that is given unto us, whether prophecy, let us prophesy according to the proportion of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:23
verses.text: Since then he had sufficiently comforted them, he wishes also to make them vie with each other, and labor more in earnest, by showing that it is themselves that give the grounds for their receiving more or less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:24
verses.text: For he says indeed that it is given by God (as when he says, "according as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith;" and again, "according to the grace given unto us") (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:25
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:26
verses.text: ), that he may subdue the haughty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:27
verses.text: But he says also that the beginnings lie with themselves, to rouse the listless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:28
verses.text: And this he does in the Epistle to the Corinthians also, to produce both these emotions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:29
verses.text: For when he saith, "covet earnestly the gifts," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:30
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:31
verses.text: ), he shows that they were themselves the cause of the differences in what was given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:32
verses.text: But when he says, "Now all these things worketh one and the selfsame Spirit, dividing to every man severally as he will" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:33
verses.text: ), he is proving that those who have received it ought not to be elated, so using every way open to him to allay their disorder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:34
verses.text: And this he does here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:35
verses.text: And again, to rouse those who have fallen drowsy, he says, "Whether prophecy, let us prophesy according to the proportion of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:36
verses.text: For though it is a grace, yet it is not poured forth at random, but framing its measure according to the recipients, it letteth as much flow as it may find the vessel of faith that is brought to be capable of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:37
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:38
verses.text: "Or ministry, let us wait on our ministering".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:39
verses.text: Here he names a comprehensive thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:40
verses.text: For the Apostleship even is called a ministry, and every spiritual work is a ministry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:41
verses.text: This is indeed a name of a peculiar office (viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:42
verses.text: the diaconate); however, it is used in a general sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:43
verses.text: "Or he that teacheth, on teaching".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:44
verses.text: See with what indifference he places them, the little first and the great afterwards, again giving us the same lesson, not to be puffed up or elated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:45
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:46
verses.text: "Or he that exhorteth, on exhortation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:47
verses.text: And this is a species of teaching too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:48
verses.text: For "if ye have any word of exhortation," it says, "speak unto the people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:49
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:50
verses.text: ) Then to show that it is no great good to follow after virtue unless this is done with the proper rule, he proceeds, "He that giveth" (μεταδιδοὺς, imparteth), "let him do it with simplicity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:51
verses.text: For it is not enough to give, but we must do it with munificence also, for this constantly answereth to the name of simplicity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:52
verses.text: Since even the virgins had oil, still, since they had not enough, they were cast out from everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:53
verses.text: "He that defendeth" (A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:54
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:55
verses.text: ruleth, προἵστάμενος,) "with diligence;" for it is not enough to do undertake the defence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:56
verses.text: "He that showeth mercy, with cheerfulness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:57
verses.text: For it is not enough to show mercy, but it behooves us to do it with a largeness and an ungrudging spirit, or rather not with an ungrudging, but even with a cheerful and rejoicing one, for not grudging does not amount to rejoicing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:58
verses.text: And this same point, when he is writing to the Corinthians also, he insisted very strongly upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:59
verses.text: For to rouse them to such largeness he said, "He that soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly, and he which soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:60
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:61
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:62
verses.text: ) But to correct their temper he added, "Not grudgingly or of necessity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:63
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:64
verses.text: ) For both the shower of mercy ought to have, both ungrudgingness and pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:65
verses.text: And why dost thou bemoan thyself of giving alms? (Aristot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:66
verses.text: Eth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:67
verses.text: N.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:68
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:69
verses.text: and iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:70
verses.text: ) Why dost thou grieve at showing mercy, and lose the advantage of the good deed? For if thou grievest thou dost not do mercy, but art cruel and inhuman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:71
verses.text: For if thou grievest, how shalt thou be able to raise up him that is in sorrow? For it is much if he suspects no ill, even, when thou art giving with joyfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:72
verses.text: For since nothing seems to men such a disgrace as to be receiving from others, unless by an exceedingly cheerful look thou removest the suspicion, and showest that thou art receiving rather than giving, thou wilt even cast down the receiver rather than raise him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:73
verses.text: This is why he says, "He that showeth mercy, with cheerfulness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:74
verses.text: For who that is receiving a kingdom, is of sad countenance? Who that is receiving pardon for his sins continueth of dejected look? Mind not then the expenditure of the money; but the increase that comes of that expenditure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:75
verses.text: For if he that soweth rejoiceth though sowing with uncertainty of return, much more should he do so that farms the Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:76
verses.text: For in this way, even though thou give but little, thou wilt be giving much; even as how much soever thou givest with a sad countenance, thou wilt have made thy much a little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:77
verses.text: Thus the widow outweighed many talents by the two mites, for her spirit was large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:78
verses.text: And how is it possible, it may be said, for one that dwells with poverty in the extreme, and empties forth his all, to do this with a ready mind? Ask the widow, and thou wilt hear the way, and wilt know that it is not poverty that makes narrow circumstances, but the temper of a man that effects both this and its opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:79
verses.text: For it is possible even in poverty to be munificent (μεγαλόψυχον), and in riches to be niggardly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:80
verses.text: Hence in giving he looks for simplicity, and in showing mercy for cheerfulness, and in patronizing for diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:81
verses.text: For it is not with money only that he wishes us to render every assistance to those in want, but both with words, and deeds, and in person, and in every other way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:82
verses.text: And after mentioning the chief kind of aiding (προστασίαν), that which lies in teaching, namely, and that of exhorting (for this is a more necessary kind, in that it nurtures the soul), he proceeds to that by way of money, and all other means; then to show how these may be practised aright, he bringeth in the mother of them, love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:83
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:84
verses.text: For, "Let love be without dissimulation," he says,  If thou hast this, thou wilt not perceive the loss of thy money, the labor of thy person, the toil of thy words, thy trouble, and thy ministering, but thou wilt bear all courageously, whether it be with person, or money, or word, or any other thing whatsover, that thou art to assist thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:85
verses.text: As then he doth not ask for giving only, but that with simplicity, nor aiding, but that with diligence, nor alms, but that with cheerfulness; so even love too he requires not alone, but that without dissimulation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:86
verses.text: Since this is what love is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:87
verses.text: And if a man have this, everything else follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:88
verses.text: For he that showeth mercy does so with cheerfulness (for he is giving to himself): and he that aideth, aideth with diligence; for it is for himself he is aiding: and he that imparteth doth this with largeness; for he is bestowing it on himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:89
verses.text: Then since there is a love even for ill things, such as is that of the intemperate, that of those who are of one mind for money, and for plunder's sake, and for revels and drinking clubs, he clears it of all these, by saying, "Abhor (ἀποστυγοὕντες) that which is evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:90
verses.text: And he does not speak of refraining from it, but of hating it, and not merely hating it, but hating it exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:91
verses.text: For this word ἀπὸ is often of intensive force with him, as where he speaks of "earnest expectation, looking out for," (complete) "redemption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:92
verses.text: For since many who do not evil things still have a desire after them, therefore he says, "Abhor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:93
verses.text: For what he wants is to purify the thought, and that we should have a mighty enmity, hatred and war against vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:94
verses.text: For do not fancy, he means, because I said, "Love one another," that I mean you to go so far as to coöperate even in bad actions with one another; for the law that I am laying down is just the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:95
verses.text: Since it would have you an alien not from the action only, but even from the inclination towards vice; and not merely an alien from this same inclination, but to have an excessive aversion and hatred of it too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:96
verses.text: And he is not content with only this, but he also brings in the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:97
verses.text: "Cleave to that which is good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:98
verses.text: He does not speak of doing only, but of being disposed too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:99
verses.text: For this the command to "cleave to" it indicates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:100
verses.text: So God, when He knit the man to the woman, said, "For he shall cleave to his wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:101
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:102
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:103
verses.text: ) Then he mentions reasons why we ought to love one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:104
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:105
verses.text: "Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:106
verses.text: Ye are brethren, he means, and have come of the same pangs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:107
verses.text: Hence even on this head you ought to love one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:108
verses.text: And this Moses said to those who were quarrelling in Egypt, "Ye are brethren, why do ye wrong one to another?" (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:109
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:110
verses.text: ) When then he is speaking of those without, he says, "If it be possible, as much as in you lieth, live peaceably with all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:111
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:112
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:113
verses.text: ) But when he is speaking of his own, he says, "Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:114
verses.text: For in the other case he requires abstinence from quarrelling, and hatred, and aversion: but here loving too, and not merely loving, but the loving of relatives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:115
verses.text: For not only must one's "love be without dissimulation," but intense also, and warm, and glowing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:116
verses.text: Because, to what purpose would you love without fraud, and not love with warmth? Whence he says, "kindly affectioned one towards another, that is, be friends, and warm ones too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:117
verses.text: Do not wait to be loved by another, but leap at it thyself, and be the first to begin it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:118
verses.text: For so wilt thou reap the wages of his love also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:119
verses.text: Having mentioned the reason then why we ought to love one another, he tells us also the way in which the affection may grow unchangeable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:120
verses.text: Whence he proceeds, "In honor preferring one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:121
verses.text: For this is the way that affection is produced, and also when produced abideth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:122
verses.text: And there is nothing which makes friends so much, as the earnest endeavor to overcome one's neighbor in honoring him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:123
verses.text: For what he had mentioned before comes of love, and love of honor, as honor does too of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:124
verses.text: Then that we may not honor only, he looks for something besides, when he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:125
verses.text: "Not backward in zeal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:126
verses.text: For this also gendereth love when with honor we also show a readiness to protect: as there is nothing that makes men beloved so much as honor and forethought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:127
verses.text: For to love is not enough, but there must be this also: or rather this also comes of loving, as also loving has its warmth from this, and they are confirmative one of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:128
verses.text: For there are many that love in mind, yet reach not forth the hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:129
verses.text: And this is why he uses every means to build up love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:130
verses.text: And how are we to become "not backward in zeal?"  "Fervent in spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:131
verses.text: See how in every instance he aims after higher degrees; for he does not say "give" only, but "with largeness;" nor "rule," but do it "with diligence;" nor "show mercy," but do it "with cheerfulness;" nor "honor," but "prefer one another;" nor "love," but do it "without dissimulation;" nor refrain from "evil" things, but "hate" them; nor hold to "what is good," but "cleave" to it; nor "love," but to do it "with brotherly affection;" nor be zealous, but be so without backwardness; nor have the "Spirit," but have it "fervent," that is, that ye may be warm and awakened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:132
verses.text: For if thou hast those things aforesaid, thou wilt draw the Spirit to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:133
verses.text: And if This abide with thee, It will likewise make thee good for those purposes, and all things will be easy from the Spirit and the love, while thou art made to glow from both sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:134
verses.text: Dost thou not see the bulls (Hannibal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:135
verses.text: ap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:136
verses.text: Liv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:137
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:138
verses.text: ) that carry a flame upon their back, how nobody is able to withstand them? So thou also wilt be more than the devil can sustain, if thou takest both these flames.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:139
verses.text: "Serving the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:140
verses.text: For it is possible to serve God in all these ways; in that whatever thou doest to thy brother passes on to thy Master, and as having been Himself benefited, He will reckon thy reward accordingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:141
verses.text: See to what height he has raised the spirit of the man that worketh these things! Then to show how the flame of the Spirit might be kindled, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:142
verses.text: "Rejoicing in hope, patient in tribulation, continuing instant in prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:143
verses.text: For all these things are fuel for that fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:144
verses.text: For when he had required the expenditure of money and the labor of the person, and ruling, and zeal, and teaching, and other laborious occupations, he again supplies the wrestler with love, with the Spirit, through hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:145
verses.text: For there is nothing which makes the soul so courageous and venturesome for anything as a good hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:146
verses.text: Then even before the good things hoped for, he gives another reward again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:147
verses.text: For since hope is of things to come, he says, "patient in tribulation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:148
verses.text: And before the things to come, in this life present thou wilt gain a great good (see on Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:149
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:150
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:151
verses.text: ) from tribulation, that of becoming hardy and tried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:152
verses.text: And after this he affords them another help, when he says, "continuing instant in prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:153
verses.text: When therefore love maketh things easy, and the Spirit assisteth, and hope lighteneth, and tribulation maketh thee tried and apt for bearing everything nobly, and thou hast along with these another very great weapon, to wit, "prayer" and the aidances that come of prayer, what further grievousness can there be in what he is enjoining? Surely none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:154
verses.text: You see how in every way he gives the wrestler firm footing and shows that the injunctions are perfectly easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:155
verses.text: Consider again how he vindicates almsgiving, or rather not almsgiving absolutely, but that to the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:156
verses.text: For above when he says, "he that showeth mercy with cheerfulness," he makes us open-handed to everybody.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:157
verses.text: Here, however, it is in behalf of the faithful that he is speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:158
verses.text: And so he proceeds to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:159
verses.text: "Sharing with the necessity (χρείαις, al.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:160
verses.text: μνείαις, memories) of the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:161
verses.text: He does not say, Bestow upon, but "share with the necessity of the saints," to show that they receive more than they give, that it is a matter of merchandise, because it is a community.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:162
verses.text: Do you bring in money? They bring you in boldness toward God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:163
verses.text: "Given to (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:164
verses.text: pursuing) hospitality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:165
verses.text: He does not say doing it, but "given" to it, so to instruct us not to wait for those that shall ask it, and see when they will come to us, but to run to them, and be given to finding them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:166
verses.text: Thus did Lot, thus Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:167
verses.text: For he spent the whole day upon it, waiting for this goodly prey, and when he saw it, leaped upon it, and ran to meet them, and worshipped upon the ground, and said, "My Lord, if now I have found favor in Thy sight, pass not away from Thy servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:168
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:169
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:170
verses.text: ) Not as we do, if we happen to see a stranger or a poor man, knitting our brows, and not deigning even to speak to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:171
verses.text: And if after thousands of entreaties we are softened, and bid the servant give them a trifle, we think we have quite done our duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:172
verses.text: But he did not so, but assumed the fashion of a suppliant and a servant, though he did not know who he was going to take under his roof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:173
verses.text: But we, who have clear information that it is Christ Whom we take in, do not grow gentle even for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:174
verses.text: But he both beseeches, and entreats, and falls on his knees to them, yet we insult those that come to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:175
verses.text: And he indeed did all by himself and his wife, whereas we do it not even by our attendants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:176
verses.text: But if you have a mind to see the table that he set before them, there too you will see great bounteousness, but the bounteousness came not from excess of wealth, but of the riches of a ready will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:177
verses.text: Yet how many rich persons were there not then? Still none did anything of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:178
verses.text: How many widows were there in Israel? Yet none showed hospitality to Elijah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:179
verses.text: How many wealthy persons again were there not in Elisha's day? But the Shunamite alone gathered in the fruits of hospitality; as did Abraham also, whom beside his largeness and ready mind it is just especially to admire, on this ground, that when he had no knowledge who they were that had come, yet he so acted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:180
verses.text: Do not thou then be curious either: since for Christ thou dost receive him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:181
verses.text: And if thou art always so scrupulous, many a time wilt thou pass by a man of esteem, and lose thy reward from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:182
verses.text: And yet he that receiveth one that is not of esteem, hath no fault found with him, but is even rewarded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:183
verses.text: For "he that receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet, shall receive a prophet's reward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:184
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:185
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:186
verses.text: ) But he who out of this ill-timed scrupulousness passeth one that should be admired, shall even suffer punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:187
verses.text: Do not then busy thyself with men's lives and doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:188
verses.text: For this is the very extreme of niggardliness, for one loaf to be exact about a man's entire life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:189
verses.text: For if this person be a murderer, if a robber, or what not, does he therefore seem to thee not to deserve a loaf and a few pence? And yet thy Master causeth even the sun to rise upon him! And dost thou judge him unworthy of food even for a day? I will put another case to you besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:190
verses.text: Now even if you were positively certain that he were laden with countless iniquities, not even then wouldest thou have an excuse for depriving him of this day's sustenance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:191
verses.text: For thou art the servant of Him Who said, "Ye know not what spirit ye are of".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:192
verses.text: (Luke ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:193
verses.text: ) Thou art servant to Him Who healed those that stoned Him, or rather Who was crucified for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:194
verses.text: And do not tell me that he killed another, for even if he were going to kill thee thyself, even then thou shouldest not neglect him when starving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:195
verses.text: For thou art a disciple of Him Who desired the salvation even of them that crucified Him Who said upon the Cross itself, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:196
verses.text: (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:197
verses.text: ) Thou art the servant of Him Who healed him that smote Him, Who upon the Cross itself crowned the man who had scorned Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:198
verses.text: And what can equal this? For both the robbers at first scorned Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:199
verses.text: Still to one of these He opened Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:200
verses.text: And He bewails those who were upon the point of killing Him, and is troubled and confounded at seeing the traitor, not because He was going to be crucified, but because he was lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:201
verses.text: He was troubled then as having foreknowledge of the hanging, and the punishment after the hanging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:202
verses.text: And though He knelt his wickedness, He bore with him to the last hour, and thrust not away the traitor, but even kissed him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:203
verses.text: Thy Master kisseth, and with His lips receiveth him who was on the very point of shedding His precious Blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:204
verses.text: And dost thou count the poor not worthy even of a loaf, and reverencest not the Law which Christ laid down? Now by this He shows that we ought not to turn aside, not only from the poor, but not even from those that would lead us away to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:205
verses.text: Do not tell me then, that so and so hath done me grievous mischief, but just consider what Christ did near the Cross itself, wishing to amend by His kiss the traitor by whom He was on the point of being betrayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:206
verses.text: And see with how much power to shame him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:207
verses.text: For He says, "Judas, betrayest thou the Son of Man with a kiss?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:208
verses.text: ) Who is there He would not have softened? who is there that this address would not have made yielding? What beast? what adamant? yet not that wretched man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:209
verses.text: Do not then say, that such an one murdered such an one, and that is why I turn aside from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:210
verses.text: For even if he were upon the point of thrusting a sword down into thee, and to plunge his hand into thy neck itself, kiss this very right hand! since even Christ kissed that mouth which wrought His death! And therefore do not thou either hate, but bewail and pity him that plotteth against thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:211
verses.text: For such an one deserveth pity at our hands, and tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:212
