verses.text: For we are the servants of Him Who kissed even the traitor (I will not leave off dwelling over that continually), and spoke words unto him more gentle than the kiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:213
verses.text: For He did not even say, O thou foul and villanous traitor, is this the sort of recompense thou returnest us for so great a benefit? But in what words? "Judas;" using his own name, which is more like a person bemoaning, and recalling him, than one wroth at him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:214
verses.text: And he does not say, thy Teacher, thy Master, and Benefactor, but, "the Son of Man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:215
verses.text: For though He were neither Teacher nor Master, yet is it with One Who is so gently, so unfeignedly affected towards thee, as even to kiss thee at the time of betrayal, and that when a kiss too was the signal for the betrayal; is it with Him that thou playest the traitor's part? Blessed art Thou, O Lord! What lowliness of mind, what forbearance hast Thou given us ensamples of! And to him He so behaved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:216
verses.text: But to those who came with staves and swords to Him, was it not so too? What can be more gentle than the words spoken to them? For when He had power to demolish them all in an instant, He did nothing of the kind, but as expostulating (ἐντρεπτικὥς), addressed them in the words, "Why, are ye come out as against a thief with swords and staves?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:217
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:218
verses.text: ) And having cast them down backwards (John xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:219
verses.text: ), as they continued insensible, He of His own accord gave Himself up next, and forbore while He saw them putting manacles upon His holy hands, while He had the power at once to confound all things, and overthrow them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:220
verses.text: But dost thou even after this deal fiercely with the poor? And even were he guilty of ten thousand sins, want and famine were enough to soften down a soul ever so blunted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:221
verses.text: But thou standest brutalized, and imitating the rage of lions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:222
verses.text: Yet they never taste of dead bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:223
verses.text: But thou, while thou seest him a very corpse (τεταριχευμένον lit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:224
verses.text: salter, or, a mummy) for distresses, yet leapest upon him now that he is down, and tearest his body by thine insults, and gatherest storm after storm, and makest him as he is fleeing to the haven for refuge to split upon a rock, and bringest a shipwreck about more distressing than those in the sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:225
verses.text: And how wilt thou say to God, Have mercy upon me, and ask of Him remission of sins, when thou art insolent to one who hath done no sin, and callest him to account for this hunger and great necessity, and throwest all the brute beasts into the shade by thy cruelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:226
verses.text: For they indeed by the compulsion of their belly lay hold of the food needful for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:227
verses.text: But thou, when nothing either thrusts thee on or compels thee, devourest thy brother, bitest, and tearest him, if not with thy teeth, yet with words that bite more cuttingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:228
verses.text: How then wilt thou receive the sacred Host (προσφορὰν), when thou hast empurpled thy tongue in human gore? how give the kiss of peace, with mouth gorged with war? Nay, how enjoy every common nourishment, when thou art gathering so much venom? Thou dost not relieve the poverty, why make it even more grinding? thou dost not lift up him that is fallen, why throw him down also? thou dost not remove despondency, why even increase it? thou givest no money, why use insulting words besides? Hast thou not heard what punishment they suffer that feed not the poor? to what vengeance they are condemned? For He says, "Depart to the fire prepared for the devil and his angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:229
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:230
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:231
verses.text: ) If then they that feed not are so condemned, what punishment are they to suffer, who besides not feeding, even insult? What punishment shall they undergo? what hell? That we kindle not so great evils against ourselves, whiles we have it in our power, let us correct this evil complaint also, and put a bridle on the tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:232
verses.text: And let us be so far from insulting, as even to invite them, both by words and actions, that by laying up much mercy for ourselves, we may obtain the blessings promised us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 22:233
verses.text: Which God grant that we may all attain unto by the grace and love towards man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:1
verses.text: Homily XXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:3
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:4
verses.text: " Bless them which persecute you; bless, and curse not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:5
verses.text: After teaching them how they ought to be minded towards one another, and after joining the members closely into one, he next proceeds to lead them forth to the battle without, which he makes easier as from this point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:6
verses.text: For as he who hath not managed things well with those of his own side, will find more difficulty in arranging affairs with strangers, so he, that has practised himself duly among these, will with the more ease have the advantage of those without also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:7
verses.text: Hence then Paul also as he goes on in his journey, after the one places the other, and says, "Bless them that persecute you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:8
verses.text: He did not say, be not spiteful or revengeful, but required something far better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:9
verses.text: For that a man that was wise might do, but this is quite an angel's part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:10
verses.text: And after saying "bless," he proceeds, "and curse not," lest we should do both the one and the ether, and not the former only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:11
verses.text: For they that persecute us are purveyors of a reward to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:12
verses.text: But if thou art sober-minded, there will be another reward after that one, which thou wilt gain thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:13
verses.text: For he will yield thee that for persecution, but thou wilt yield thyself the one from the blessing of another, in that thou bringest forth a very great sign of love to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:14
verses.text: For as he that curseth his persecutor, showeth that he is not much pleased at suffering this for Christ, thus he that blesseth showeth the greatness of his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:15
verses.text: Do not then abuse him, that thou thyself mayest gain the greater reward, and mayest teach him that the thing is matter of inclination, not of necessity, of holiday and feast, not of calamity or dejection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:16
verses.text: For this cause Christ Himself said, "Rejoice when men speak all manner of evil against you falsely".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:17
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:18
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:19
verses.text: ) Hence too it was that the Apostles returned with joy not from having been evil spoken of only, but also at having been scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:20
verses.text: (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:21
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:22
verses.text: ) For besides what I have mentioned, there will be another gain, and that no small one, that you will make, both the abashing of your adversaries hereby, and instructing of them by your actions that you are travelling to another life; for if he see thee joyous, and elevated, (πτερούμενον) from suffering ill, he will see clearly from the actions that thou hast other hopes greater than those of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:23
verses.text: So that if thou dost not so, but weepest and lamentest, how is he to be able to learn from that that thou art tarrying for any other life? And besides this, thou wilt compass yet another thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:24
verses.text: For provided he see thee not vexed at the affronts done thee, but even blessing him, he will leave harassing thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:25
verses.text: See then how much that is good comes from this, both a greater reward for thyself and a less temptation, and he will forbear persecuting thee, and God too will be glorified: and to him that is in error thy endurance will be instruction in godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:26
verses.text: For this reason it was not those that insult us only, but even those that persecute us and deal despitefully with us, that he bade us requite with the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:27
verses.text: And now he orders them to bless, but as he goes on, he exhorts them to do them good in deeds also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:28
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:29
verses.text: "Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and weep with them that weep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:30
verses.text: Since it is possible to bless and not to curse, and yet not to do this out of love, he wishes us to be penetrated with the warmth of friendship throughout.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:31
verses.text: And this is why he goes on in these words, that we are not only to bless, but even feel compassion for their pains and sufferings, whenever we happen to see them fallen into trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:32
verses.text: Yes, it will be said, but to join in the sorrows of mourners one can see why he ordered them, but why ever did he command them the other thing, when it is no such great matter? Aye, but that requires more of a high Christian temper, to rejoice with them that do rejoice, than to weep with them that weep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:33
verses.text: For this nature itself fulfils perfectly: and there is none so hard-hearted as not to weep over him that is in calamity: but the other requires a very noble soul, so as not only to keep from envying, but even to feel pleasure with the person who is in esteem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:34
verses.text: And this is why he placed it first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:35
verses.text: For there is nothing that ties love so firmly as sharing both joy and pain one with another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:36
verses.text: Do not then, because thou art far from difficulties thyself, remain aloof from sympathizing too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:37
verses.text: For when thy neighbor is ill-treated, thou oughtest to make the calamity thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:38
verses.text: Take share then in his tears, that thou mayest lighten his low spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:39
verses.text: Take share in his joy, that thou mayest make the joy strike deep root, and fix the love firmly, and be of service to thyself rather than to him in so doing, by thy weeping rendering thyself merciful, and by thy feeling his pleasure, purging thyself of envy and grudging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:40
verses.text: And let me draw your attention to Paul's considerateness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:41
verses.text: For he does not say, Put an end to the calamity, lest thou shouldest say in many cases (or perchance πολλάκις) that it is impossible: but he has enjoined the easier task, and that which thou hast in thy power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:42
verses.text: For even if thou art not able to remove the evil, yet contribute tears, and thou wilt take the worst half away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:43
verses.text: And if thou be not able to increase a man's prosperity, contribute joy, and thou wilt have made a great addition to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:44
verses.text: Therefore it is not abstaining from envy only, but what is a much greater thing that he exhorts us to, namely, joining in the pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:45
verses.text: For this is a much greater thing than not envying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:46
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:47
verses.text: "Be of the same mind one towards another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:48
verses.text: Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:49
verses.text: Here again he insists much upon lowliness of mind, the subject he had started this exhortation with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:50
verses.text: For there was a probability of their being full of high-mindedness, both on account of their city (see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:51
verses.text: ), and from sundry other causes; he therefore keeps drawing off (ὑποσύρει,  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:52
verses.text: ὐπορύττει) the morbid matter, and lowers the inflammation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:53
verses.text: For there is nothing that makes such schisms in the Churches as vanity does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:54
verses.text: And what does he mean by, "Be of the same mind one towards another?" Has a poor man come into thy house? Be like him in thy bearing, do not put on any unusual pompous air on account of thy riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:55
verses.text: There is no rich and poor in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:56
verses.text: Be not then ashamed of him because of his external dress, but receive him because of his inward faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:57
verses.text: And if thou seest him in sorrow, do not disdain to comfort him, nor if thou see him in prosperity, feel abashed at sharing his pleasure, and being gladdened with him, but be of the same mind in his case, that thou wouldest be of in thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:58
verses.text: For it says, "Be of the same mind one towards another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:59
verses.text: For instance, if thou thinkest thyself a great man, therefore think him so likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:60
verses.text: Dost thou suspect that he is mean and little? Well then, pass this same sentence upon thyself, and cast aside all unevenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:61
verses.text: And how is this to be? By thy casting aside that reckless temper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:62
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds: "Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:63
verses.text: That is, bring thyself down to their humble condition, associate with them, walk with them, do not be humbled in mind only, but help them also, and reach forth thy hand to them, not by means of others, but in thine own person, as a father taking care of a child, as the head taking care of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:64
verses.text: As he says in another place, "being bound with them that are in bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:65
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:66
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:67
verses.text: ) But here he means by those of low estate not merely the lowly-minded, but those of a low rank, and which one is apt to think scorn of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:68
verses.text: "Be not wise in your own conceits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:69
verses.text: This is, do not think that you can do for yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:70
verses.text: Because the Scripture saith in another place besides, "Woe to them that are wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:71
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:72
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:73
verses.text: ) And by this again, he secretly draws off recklessness, and reduces conceit and turgidity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:74
verses.text: For there is nothing that so elates men and makes them feel different from other people, as the notion that they can do by themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:75
verses.text: Whence also God hath placed us in need one of another, and though thou be wise thou wilt be in need of another: but if thou think that thou art not in need of him, thou wilt be the most foolish and feeble of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:76
verses.text: For a man of this sort bares himself of all succor, and in whatever error he may run into, will not have the advantage either of correction or of pardon, and will provoke God by his recklessness, and will run into many errors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:77
verses.text: For it is the case, aye, and often too, that a wise man does not perceive what is needful, and a man of less shrewdness hits upon somewhat that is applicable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:78
verses.text: And this happened with Moses and his father-in-law, and with Saul and his servant, and with Isaac and Rebecca.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:79
verses.text: Do not then suppose that you are lowered by needing another man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:80
verses.text: For this exalts you the more, this makes you the stronger, and the brighter too, and the more secure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:82
verses.text: "Recompense to no man evil for evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:83
verses.text: For if thou findest fault with another who plots against thee, why dost thou make thyself liable to this accusation? If he did amiss how comest thou not to shun imitating him? And observe how he puts no difference here but lays down one law for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:84
verses.text: For he does not say, "recompense not evil" to the believer, but to "no man," be he heathen, be he contaminated, or what not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:85
verses.text: "Provide things honest in the sight of all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:87
verses.text: "If it be possible, as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:88
verses.text: This is that: "let your light shine before men" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:89
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:90
verses.text: ), not that we are to live for vanity, but that we are not to give those who have a mind for it a handle against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:91
verses.text: Whence he says also in another place, "Give none offence, neither to the Jews, nor to the Gentiles, nor to the Church of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:92
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:93
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:94
verses.text: ) And in what follows he limits his meaning well, by saying, "If it be possible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:95
verses.text: For there are cases in which it is not possible, as, for instance, when we have to argue about religion, or to contend for those who are wronged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:96
verses.text: And why be surprised if this be not universally possible in the case of other persons, when even in the case of man and wife he broke through the rule? "But if the unbelieving depart, let him depart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:97
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:98
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:99
verses.text: ) And his meaning is nearly as follows: Do thine own part, and to none give occasion of war or fighting, neither to Jew nor Gentile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:100
verses.text: But if you see the cause of religion suffering anywhere, do not prize concord above truth, but make a noble stand even to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:101
verses.text: And even then be not at war in soul, be not averse in temper, but fight with the things only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:102
verses.text: For this is the import of "as much as in you lieth, be at peace with all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:103
verses.text: But if the other will not be at peace, do not thou fill thy soul with tempest, but in mind be friendly (φίλος, several mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:104
verses.text: φιλόσοφος) as I said before, without giving up the truth on any occasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:105
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:106
verses.text: "Dearly beloved, avenge not yourselves, but rather give place unto wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:107
verses.text: For it is written, Vengeance is mine; I will repay, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:108
verses.text: Unto what wrath? To the wrath of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:109
verses.text: Now since what the injured man desires most to see is, himself having the pleasure of revenge, this very thing he gives him in full measure, that if thou dost not avenge thyself, he means, God will be thy avenger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:110
verses.text: Leave it then to Him to follow up thy wrongs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:111
verses.text: For this is the force of "give place unto wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:112
verses.text: Then to give further comfort, he brings the quotation forward also, and after winning him more throughly to himself in this way, he demands more Christian heroism (φιλοσόφιάν) of him, and says:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:113
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:114
verses.text: "If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him to drink; for in so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:115
verses.text: Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:116
verses.text: Why, he means, am I telling you that you must keep peace? For I even insist upon your doing kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:117
verses.text: For he says, "give him to eat, and give him to drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:118
verses.text: Then as the command he gave was a very difficult and a great one, he proceeds: "for in so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:119
verses.text: And this he said both to humble the one by fear, and to make the other more ready-minded through hope of a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:120
verses.text: For he that is wronged, when he is feeble, is not so much taken with any goods of his own as with the vengeance upon the person who has pained him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:121
verses.text: For there nothing so sweet as to see an enemy chastised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:122
verses.text: What he is longing for, then, that he gives him first, and when he has let the venom go, then he again gives advice of a higher tone, saying, "Be not overcome of evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:123
verses.text: For he knew that if the enemy were a very brute, he would not continue an enemy when he had been fed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:124
verses.text: And if the man injured be of ever so little a soul, still when feeding him and giving him to drink, he will not himself even have any farther craving for his punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:125
verses.text: Hence, out of confidence in the result of the action, he does not simply threaten, but even dwells largely upon the vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:126
verses.text: For he did not say, "thou shalt take vengeance" but, "thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:127
verses.text: Then he further declares him victor, by saying, "be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:128
verses.text: And he gives a kind of gentle hint, that one is not to do it with that intention, since cherishing a grudge still would be "being overcome of evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:129
verses.text: But he did not say it at once, as he did not find it advisable yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:130
verses.text: But when he had disburdened the man of his anger, then he proceeded to say, "overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:131
verses.text: Since this would be a victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:132
verses.text: For the combatant is rather then the conqueror, not when he brings himself under to take the blows, but when he withdraws himself, and makes his antagonist waste his strength upon the air.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:133
verses.text: And in this way he will not be struck himself, and will also exhaust the whole of the other's strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:134
verses.text: And this takes place in regard to affronts also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:135
verses.text: For when you do affronts in return, you have the worse, not as overcome (so  ms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:136
verses.text: νικηθεὶς, Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:137
verses.text: κινηθεὶς) by a man, but what is far more disgraceful, by the slavish passion of anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:138
verses.text: But if you are silent, then you will conquer, and erect a trophy without a fight, and will have thousands to crown you, and to condemn the slander of falsehood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:139
verses.text: For he that replies, seems to be speaking in return as if stung.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:140
verses.text: And he that is stung, gives reason to suspect that he is conscious of being guilty of what is said of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:141
verses.text: But if you laugh at it, by your laughing you do away with the sentence against you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:142
verses.text: And if you would have a clear proof of what has been said, ask the enemy himself, when he is most vexed? when you are heated, and insult him in return? or when you laugh at him as he insults you? and you will be told the last rather.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:143
verses.text: For he too is not so much pleased with not being insulted in return, as he is vexed because his abuse was not able to gain any hold upon you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:144
verses.text: Did you never see men in a passion, how they make no great account of their own wounds, but rush on with much violence, and are worse than very wild boars for seeking the hurt of their neighbor, and look to this alone, and are more given to this than to being on their guard against getting harmed? When therefore thou deprivest him of that he desires most, thou bereavest him of everything, by holding him thus cheap, and showing him to be easy to be despised, and a child rather than a man; and thou indeed hast gained the reputation of a wise man, and him dost thou invest with the character of a noisome beast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:145
verses.text: This too let us do when we are struck, and when we wish to strike, let us abstain from striking again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:146
verses.text: But, would you give a mortal blow? "Turn to him the other cheek also" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:147
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:148
verses.text: ), and thou wilt smite him with countless wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:149
verses.text: For they that applaud, and wonder at thee, are more annoying to him than men to stone him would be; and before them, his conscience will condemn him, and will exact the greatest punishment of him, and so he will go off with a confused look as if he had been treated with the utmost rigor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:150
verses.text: And if it is the estimation of the multitude that you look for, this too you will have in larger share.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:151
verses.text: And in a general way we have a kind of sympathy with those who are the sufferers; but when we also see that they do not strike (several mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:152
verses.text: resist, ἀντιπίπτοντας) in return, but even give themselves up to it, we not only pity them, but even feel admiration for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:153
verses.text: Here then I find reason to lament, that we who might have things present, if we listened to Christ's Law as we should, and also attain to things to come, are cast out of both by not paying attention to what has been told us, but giving ourselves to unwarranted philosophising about them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:154
verses.text: For He has given us laws upon all these points for our good, and has shown us what makes us have a good name, what brings us to disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:155
verses.text: And if it was likely to have proved His disciples ridiculous, He would not have enjoined this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:156
verses.text: But since this makes them the most notable of men namely, the not speaking ill, when we have ill spoken of us; the not doing ill when we have ill done us; this was His reason for enjoining it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:157
verses.text: But if this be so, much more the speaking of good when we have ill spoken of us, and the praising of those that insult us, and the doing good to those that plot against us, will make us so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:158
verses.text: This then was why He gave these laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:159
verses.text: For He is careful for His own disciples, and knowing well what it is that maketh little or great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:160
verses.text: If then He both careth and knoweth, why dost thou quarrel with Him, and wish to go another road? For conquering by doing ill is one of the devil's laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:161
verses.text: Hence in the Olympic games which were celebrated to him it is so that all the competitors conquer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:162
verses.text: But in Christ's race this is not the rule about the prize, for, on the contrary, the law is for the person smitten, and not for the person smiting, to be crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:163
verses.text: For such is the character of His race, it has all its regulations the other way; so that it is not in the victory only, but also in the way of the victory, that the marvel is the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:164
verses.text: Now when things which on the other side are signs of a victory, on this side he showeth to be productive of defeat, this is the power of God, this the race of Heaven, this the theatre of Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:165
verses.text: I know that ye are warmed thoroughly now, and are become as soft as any wax, but when ye have gone hence ye will spew it all out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:166
verses.text: This is why I sorrow, that what we are speaking of, we do not show in our actions, and this too though we should be greatest gainers thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:167
verses.text: For if we let our moderation be seen, we shall be invincible to any man; and there is nobody either great or small, who will have the power of doing us any hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:168
verses.text: For if any one abuseth thee, he has not hurt thee at all, but himself severely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:169
verses.text: And if again he wrong thee, the harm will be with the person who does the wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:170
verses.text: Did you never notice that even in the courts of law those who have had wrong done them are honored, and stand and speak out with entire freedom, but those who have done the wrong, are bowed down with shame and fear? And why do I talk of evil-speaking (Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:171
verses.text: conj.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:172
verses.text: and  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:173
verses.text: κακηγορίαν) and of wrong? For were he even to whet his sword against thee, and to stain his right hand in thy life-blood (εἰς τὸν λαιμὸν, as p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:174
verses.text: ), it is not thee that he hath done any harm to, but himself that he hath butchered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:175
verses.text: And he will witness what I say who was first taken off thus by a brother's hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:176
verses.text: For he went away to the haven without a billow, having gained a glory that dieth not away; but the other lived a life worse than any death, groaning, and trembling, and in his body bearing about the accusation of what he had done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:177
verses.text: Let us not follow after this then, but that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:178
verses.text: For he that hath ill done him, has not an evil that taketh up its constant abode with him, since he is not the parent of it; but as he received it from others, he makes it good by his patient endurance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:179
verses.text: But he that doeth ill, hath the well of the mischief in himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:180
verses.text: Was not Joseph in prison, but the harlot that plotted against him in a fine and splendid house? Which then wouldest thou wish to have been? And let me not hear yet of the requital, but examine the things that had taken place by themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:181
verses.text: For in this way thou wilt rate Joseph's prison infinitely above the house with the harlot in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:182
verses.text: For if you were to see the souls of them both, you would find the one full of enlargement and boldness, but that of the Egyptian woman in straitness, shame, dejection, confusion, and great despondency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:183
verses.text: And yet she seemed to conquer; but this was no real victor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:184
verses.text: Knowing all this then, let us fit ourselves for bearing ills, even that we may be freed from bearing ills, and may attain to the blessings to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 23:185
verses.text: Which that we may all attain to, God grant, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:1
verses.text: Homily XXIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:3
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:4
verses.text: "Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:5
verses.text: Of this subject he makes much account in other epistles also, setting subjects under their rulers as household servants are under their masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:6
verses.text: And this he does to show that it was not for the subversion of the commonwealth that Christ introduced His laws, but for the better ordering of it, and to teach men not to be taking up unnecessary and unprofitable wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:7
verses.text: For the plots that are formed against us for the truth's sake are sufficient and we have no need to be adding temptations superfluous and unprofitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:8
verses.text: And observe too how well-timed his entering upon this subject is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:9
verses.text: For when he had demanded that great spirit of heroism, and made men fit to deal either with friends or foes, and rendered them serviceable alike to the prosperous and those in adversity and need, and in fact to all, and had planted a conversation worthy of angels, and had discharged anger, and taken down recklessness, and had in every way made their mind even, he then introduces his exhortation upon these matters also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:10
verses.text: For if it be right to requite those that injure us with the opposite, much more is it our duty to obey those that are benefactors to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:11
verses.text: But this he states toward the end of his exhortation, and hitherto does not enter on these reasonings which I mention, but those only that enjoin one to do this as a matter of debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:12
verses.text: And to show that these regulations are for all, even for priests, and monks, and not for men of secular occupations only, he hath made this plan at the outset, by saying as follows: "let every soul be subject unto the higher powers," if thou be an Apostle even, or an Evangelist, or a Prophet, or anything whatsoever, inasmuch as this subjection is not subversive of religion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:13
verses.text: And he does not say merely "obey," but "be subject".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:14
verses.text: And the first claim such an enactment has upon us, and the reasoning that suiteth the faithful, is, that all this is of God's appointment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:15
verses.text: "For there is no power," he says, "but of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:16
verses.text: What say you? it may be said; is every ruler then elected by God? This I do not say, he answers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:17
verses.text: Nor am I now speaking about individual rulers, but about the thing in itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:18
verses.text: For that there should be rulers, and some rule and others be ruled, and that all things should not just be carried on in one confusion, the people swaying like waves in this direction and that; this, I say, is the work of God's wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:19
verses.text: Hence he does not say, "for there is no ruler but of God;" but it is the thing he speaks of, and says, "there is no power but of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:20
verses.text: And the powers that be, are ordained of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:21
verses.text: Thus when a certain wise man saith, "It is by the Lord that a man is matched with a woman" (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:22
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:23
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:24
verses.text: ), he means this, God made marriage, and not that it is He that joineth together every man that cometh to be with a woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:25
verses.text: For we see many that come to be with one another for evil, even by the law of marriage, and this we should not ascribe to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:26
verses.text: But as He said Himself, "He which made them at the beginning, made them male and female, and said, For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and they twain shall be one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:27
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:28
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:29
verses.text: , ; Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:30
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:31
verses.text: ) And this is what that wise man meant to explain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:32
verses.text: For since equality of honor does many times lead to fightings, He hath made many governments and forms of subjection; as that, for instance, of man and wife, that of son and father, that of old men and young, that of bond and free, that of ruler and ruled, that of master and disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:33
verses.text: And why are you surprised in the case of mankind, when even in the body He hath done the same thing? For even here He hath not made all parts of equal honor, but He hath made one less and another greater, and some of the limbs hath He made to rule and some to be ruled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:34
verses.text: And among the unreasoning creatures one may notice this same principle, as amongst bees, amongst cranes, amongst herds of wild cattle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:35
verses.text: And even the sea itself is not without this goodly subordination; for there too many of the clans are ranged under one among the fishes, and are led thus as an army, and make long expeditions from home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:36
verses.text: For anarchy, be where it may, is an evil, and a cause of confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:37
verses.text: After having said then whence governments come, he proceeds, "Whosoever therefore resisteth the power, resisteth the ordinance of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:38
verses.text: See what he has led the subject on to, and how fearful he makes it, and how he shows this to be a matter of debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:39
verses.text: For lest the believers should say, You are making us very cheap and despicable, when you put us, who are to enjoy the Kingdom of Heaven, under subjection to rulers, he shows that it is not to rulers, but to God again that he makes them subject in doing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:40
verses.text: For it is to Him, that he who subjects himself to authorities is obedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:41
verses.text: Yet he does not say this—for instance that it is God to Whom a man who listens to authorities is obedient—but he uses the opposite case to awe them, and gives it a more precise form by saying, that he who listeneth not thereto is fighting with God, Who framed these laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:42
verses.text: And this he is in all cases at pains to show, that it is not by way of favor that we obey them, but by way of debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:43
verses.text: For in this way he was more likely to draw the governors who were unbelievers to religion, and the believers to obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:44
verses.text: For there was quite a common report in those days (Tert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:45
verses.text: Ap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:46
verses.text: , , ), which maligned the Apostles, as guilty of a sedition and revolutionary scheme, and as aiming in all they did and said at the subversion of the received institutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:47
verses.text: When then you show our common Master giving this in charge to all His, you will at once stop the mouths of those that malign us as revolutionists, and with great boldness will speak for the doctrines of truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:48
verses.text: Be not then ashamed, he says, at such subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:49
verses.text: For God hath laid down this law, and is a strong Avenger of them if they be despised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:50
verses.text: For it is no common punishment that He will exact of thee, if thou disobey, but the very greatest; and nothing will exempt thee, that thou canst say to the contrary, but both of men thou shalt undergo the most severe vengeance, and there shall be no one to defend thee, and thou wilt also provoke God the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:51
verses.text: And all this he intimates when he says,  "And they that resist shall receive to themselves damnation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:52
verses.text: Then to show the gain of the thing after the fear, he uses reasons too to persuade them as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:53
verses.text: "For rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:54
verses.text: For when he has given a deep wound, and stricken them down, he again uses gentler treatment, like a wise physician, who applies soothing medicines, and he comforts them, and says, why be afraid? why shudder? For does he punish a person that is doing well? Or is he terrible to a person who lives in the practice of virtue? Wherefore also he proceeds, "Wilt thou then not be afraid of the power? Do that which is good, and thou shall have praise of the same".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:55
verses.text: You see how he has made him friends (ᾥκείωσεν) with the ruler, by showing that he even praises him from his throne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:56
verses.text: You see how he has made wrath unmeaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:58
verses.text: "For he is the minister of God to thee for good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:59
verses.text: So far is he from terrifying thee, he says, that he even praises thee: so far from being a hindrance to thee, that he even works with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:60
verses.text: When then thou hast his praise and his succor, how is it that thou art not in subjection to him? For he maketh virtue easier for thee in other ways also, by chastising the wicked, by benefiting and honoring the good, and by working together with the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:61
verses.text: Whence too he has even given him the name of "Minister".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:62
verses.text: And consider: I give you counsel to be sober-minded, and he, by the laws, speaks the same language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:63
verses.text: I exhort you not to be rapacious and grasping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:64
verses.text: And he sits in judgment in such cases, and so is a worker together with us, and an assistant to us, and has been commissioned by God for this end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:65
verses.text: Hence there are both reasons for reverencing him, both because he was commissioned by God, and because it was for such an object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:66
verses.text: "But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:67
verses.text: It is not then the ruler that maketh the fear, but our own wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:68
verses.text: "For he beareth not the sword in vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:69
verses.text: You see how he hath furnished him with arms, and set him on guard like a soldier, for a terror to those that commit sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:70
verses.text: "For he is the minister of God to execute wrath, a revenger upon him that doeth evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:71
verses.text: Now lest you should start off at hearing again of punishment, and vengeance, and a sword, he says again that it is God's law he is carrying out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:72
verses.text: For what if he does not know it himself? yet it is God that hath so shaped things (οὕτως ἐτύπωσεν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:73
verses.text: If then, whether in punishing, or in honoring, he be a Minister, in avenging virtue's cause, in driving vice away, as God willeth, why be captious against him, when he is the cause of so many good doings, and paves the way for thine too? since there are many who first practised virtue through the fear of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:74
verses.text: For there are a duller sort, whom things to come have not such a hold upon as things present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:75
verses.text: He then who by fear and rewards gives the soul of the majority a preparatory turn towards its becoming more suited for the word of doctrine, is with good reason called "the Minister of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:77
verses.text: "Wherefore ye must needs be subject, not only for wrath but also for conscience sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:78
verses.text: What is the meaning of, "not only for wrath?" It means not only because thou dost resist God by not being subject, nor only because thou art procuring great evils for thyself, both from God and the rulers, but also because he is a benefactor to thee in things of the greatest importance, as he procures peace to thee, and the blessings of civil institutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:79
verses.text: For there are countless blessings to states through these authorities; and if you were to remove them, all things would go to ruin, and neither city nor country, nor private nor public buildings, nor anything else would stand, but all the world will be turned upside down, while the more powerful devour the weaker.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:80
verses.text: And so even if some wrath were not to follow man's disobedience, even on this ground thou oughtest to be subject, that thou mayest not seem devoid of conscience and feeling towards the benefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:82
verses.text: "For, for this cause pay ye tribute also; for they are God's ministers, attending continually on this very thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:83
verses.text: Without going one by one into the benefits done to states by the rulers, as that of good order and peace, the other services, as regarding the soldiery, and those over the public business, he shows the whole of this by a single case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:84
verses.text: For that thou art benefited by him, he means, thou bearest witness thyself, by paying him a salary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:85
verses.text: Observe the wisdom and judgment of the blessed Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:86
verses.text: For that which seemed to be burdensome and annoying—the system of imposts—this he turns into a proof of their care for men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:87
verses.text: What is the reason, he means, that we pay tribute to a king? It is not as providing for us? And yet we should not have paid it unless we had known in the first instance that we were gainers from this superintendence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:88
verses.text: Yet it was for this that from of old all men came to an agreement that governors should be maintained by us, because to the neglect of their own affairs, they take charge of the public, and on this they spend their whole leisure, whereby our goods also are kept safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:89
verses.text: After saying then what the external goods are, he again averts to the former line of argument (for in this way he was more likely to attract the believer to him), and he shows again that this is God's decree, and on it he makes his advice rest finally, in these words, "they are God's ministers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:90
verses.text: Then to show the pains they take, and their hard life, he proceeds,  "Waiting continually upon this very thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:91
verses.text: For this is their life, this their business, that thou mayest enjoy peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:92
verses.text: Wherefore in another Epistle, he bids them not only be subject, but also "pray" in their behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:93
verses.text: And as showing there too that the advantage was common to all, he adds, "that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:94
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:95
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:96
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:97
verses.text: ) For it is in no small degree that they contribute to the settled state of the present life, by keeping guard, beating off enemies, hindering those who are for sedition in the cities, putting an end to differences among any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:98
verses.text: For do not tell me of some one who makes an ill use of the thing, but look to the good order that is in the institution itself, and you will see the great wisdom of Him who enacted this law from the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:100
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:101
verses.text: "Render therefore to all their dues; tribute to whom tribute, custom to whom custom, fear to whom fear, honor to whom honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:102
verses.text: Owe (or ye owe) no man anything, but to love one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:103
verses.text: He still keeps upon the same line, bidding them pay them not money only, but honor and fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:104
verses.text: And how is it when he said above, "Wilt thou not be afraid of the power? do that which is good;" that he here says "render fear?" He does it meaning exceeding honor, and not the fear which comes from a bad conscience, which he alluded to before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:105
verses.text: And it is not "give," that he says, but "render" (or "give back," ἀπόδοτε), and then adds to it, the "dues".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:106
verses.text: For it is not a favor that you confer by so doing, since the thing is matter of due.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:107
verses.text: And if you do it not, you will be punished as obstinate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:108
verses.text: Do not suppose that you are lowering yourself, and detracting from the dignity of your own philosophy, if you rise up at the presence of a ruler, or if you uncover your head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:109
verses.text: For if he laid these laws down at that time, when the rulers were Gentiles, much more ought this to be done with them now they are believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:110
verses.text: But if you mean to say, that you are entrusted with greater privileges, be informed that this is not thy time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:111
verses.text: For thou art a stranger and a sojourner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:112
verses.text: A time will be when thou shalt appear brighter than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:113
verses.text: Now thy "life is hid with Christ in God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:114
verses.text: When Christ shall appear, then shall ye also appear with Him in glory" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:115
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:116
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:117
verses.text: ) Seek not then in this life of accidents thy change, but even if thou hast to be with fear in a ruler's presence, do not think that this is unworthy thy noble birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:118
verses.text: For so God willeth, that the ruler who has his place marked by Him, should have his own power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:119
verses.text: And when he who is conscious of no evil in himself, stands with fear in the judge's presence, much more will he who doth evil things be affrighted, and thou in this way wilt be the more respected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:120
verses.text: For it is not from honoring that the lowering of self comes but from dishonoring him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:121
verses.text: And the ruler will treat thee with greater respect, and he will glorify thy Master owing to this, even if he be an unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:122
verses.text: "Owe no man anything, but to love one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:123
verses.text: Again he has recourse to the mother of good deeds, and the instructress of the things spoken of, who is also productive of every virtue, and says that this is a debt also, not however such as the tribute or the custom, but a continuous one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:124
verses.text: For he does not wish it ever to be paid off, or rather he would have it always rendered, yet never fully so, but to be always owing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:125
verses.text: For this is the character of the debt, that one keeps giving and owing always.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:126
verses.text: Having said then how he ought to love, he also shows the gain of it, saying,  "For he that loveth another hath fulfilled the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:127
verses.text: And do not, pray, consider even this a favor; for this too is a debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:128
verses.text: For thou owest love to thy brother, through thy spiritual relationship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:129
verses.text: And not for this only, but also because "we are members one of another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:130
verses.text: And if love leave us, the whole body is rent in pieces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:131
verses.text: Love therefore thy brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:132
verses.text: For if from his friendship thou gainest so much as to fulfil the whole Law, thou owest him love as being benefited by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:133
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:134
verses.text: "For this, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness, and any other commandment, is briefly comprehended in this saying, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:135
verses.text: He does not say merely it is fulfilled, but "it is briefly comprehended," that is, the whole work of the commandments is concisely and in a few words completed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:136
verses.text: For the beginning and the end of virtue is love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:137
verses.text: This it has for its root, this for its groundwork, this for its summit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:138
verses.text: If then it be both beginning and fulfilment, what is there equal to it? But he does not seek love merely, but intense love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:139
verses.text: For he does not say merely "love thy neighbor," but, "as thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:140
verses.text: Hence also Christ said that "the Law and the Prophets hang upon" it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:141
verses.text: And in making two kinds of love, see how He has raised this! For after saying that the first commandment is, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God," He added a second; and He did not stay, but added, "like unto it; Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:142
verses.text: What can be equal to this love to man, or this gentleness? That when we were at infinite distance from Him, He brings the love to us into comparison with that toward Himself, and says that "is like unto this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:143
verses.text: Hence then, to put the measures of either as nearly the same, of the one He says, "with all thy heart, and with all thy soul," but of this towards one's neighbor, He says, "as thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:144
verses.text: But Paul said, that when this did not exist even the other was of no great profit to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:145
verses.text: As then we, when we are fond of any one, say, if you love him, then you love me; so He also to show this saith, "is like unto it;" and to Peter, "If thou lovest Me, feed My sheep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:146
verses.text: (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:147
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:148
verses.text: "Love worketh no ill to his neighbor, therefore love is the fulfilling of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:149
verses.text: Observe how it has both virtues, abstinence from evils (for it "worketh no ill," he says), and the working of good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:150
verses.text: "For it is," he says, "the fulfilling (or filling up) of the Law;" not bringing before us instruction only on moral duties in a concise form, but making the accomplishment of them easy also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:151
verses.text: For that we should become acquainted with things profitable to us was not all that he was careful for (which is the Law's care), but also with a view to the doing of them it brought us great assistance; accomplishing not some part of the commandments, but the whole sum of virtue in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:152
verses.text: Let us then love one another, since in this way we shall also love God, Who loveth us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:153
verses.text: For in the case of men, if you love a man's beloved, he that loveth him is contentious at it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:154
verses.text: But here He deemeth thee worthy to share His love, and hateth thee when thou sharest not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:155
verses.text: For man's love is laden with envy and grudging; but God's is free from all passion, whence also He seeketh for those to share His love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:156
verses.text: For He says, love thou with Me, and then thyself also will I love the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:157
verses.text: You see the words of a vehement lover! If thou love My beloved, then will I also reckon Myself to be greatly beloved of thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:158
verses.text: For He vehemently desireth our salvation, and this He showed from of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:159
verses.text: Now hear what He saith when He was forming the man, "Let Us make man in Our Image:" and again, "Let Us make an help meet for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:160
verses.text: It is not good for him to be alone".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:161
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:162
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:163
verses.text: ) And when he had transgressed, He rebuked him, observe how gently; and He does not say, Wretch! thou very wretch! after receiving so great benefits, hast thou after all trusted to the devil? and left thy Benefactor, to take up with the evil spirit? But what saith He? "Who told thee that thou art naked, unless thou hast eaten of the Tree, from which alone I commanded thee not to eat?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:164
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:165
verses.text: ) As if a father were to say to a child, who was ordered not to touch a sword, and then disobeyed and got wounded, "How camest thou wounded? Thou camest so by not listening to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:166
verses.text: You see they are the words of a friend rather than a master, of a friend despised, and not even then forsaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:167
verses.text: Let us then imitate Him, and when we rebuke, let us preserve this moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:168
verses.text: For even the woman He also rebuketh again with the same gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:169
verses.text: Or rather what He said was not so much rebuke as admonition and correction, and security against the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:170
verses.text: This is why He saith nothing to the serpent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:171
verses.text: For he was the designer of the mischiefs, and had it not in his power to put off the accusation on any one else, wherefore He punished him severely: and even here He did not come to a pause, but made the earth also to share in the curse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:172
verses.text: But if He cast them out of paradise, and condemned them to labor, even for this we ought to adore and reverence Him the most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:173
verses.text: For since self-indulgence issues in listlessness, He trenches upon the pleasure by building a fort of pain against listlessness, that we may return to the love of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:174
verses.text: And what of Cain's case? Doth he not meet with the same gentleness? For being by him also insulted, He doth not reproach (same word as insult) in return, but entreats, (or comforts) him, and says, "Why is thy countenance fallen?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:175
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:176
verses.text: ) And yet what he had done allowed of no excuse whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:177
verses.text: And this the younger brother shows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:178
verses.text: But still even then He doth not rebuke him: but what saith He? "Hast thou sinned: keep peace;" "do so no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:179
verses.text: "To thee shall his turning be, and thou shalt rule over him" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:180
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:181
verses.text: ), meaning his brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:182
verses.text: "For if thou art afraid, lest for this sacrifice," He means, "I should deprive thee of the preëminence of the first-born, be of good cheer, for the entire command over him do I put into thy hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:183
verses.text: Only be thou better, and love him that hath done thee no wrong; for I have an interest in you both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:184
verses.text: And what maketh Me most glad is, that ye be not at variance one with another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:185
verses.text: For as a devoted mother, so doth God do and plan everything to keep one from being torn from another; but that you may get a clearer view, by an example, of my meaning, call to your mind, pray, Rebecca in her trouble, and running about everywhere, when the elder son was at enmity with the younger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:186
verses.text: For if she loved Jacob, still she did not feel averse to Esau.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:187
verses.text: And therefore she said, Lest by any means "I be deprived of both of you, my children, in one day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:188
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:189
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:190
verses.text: ) Therefore also God upon that occasion said, "Thou hast sinned: be at peace: unto thee shall his turning be" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:191
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:192
verses.text: ), so repressing the murder beforehand, and aiming at the peace of them both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:193
verses.text: But when he had murdered him, He did not even then bring His care for him to a close, but again answers the fratricide in gentle terms, saying, "Where is thy brother Abel?" that even now, if he would, he might make a full confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:194
verses.text: But he struggled in defence of his former misdeeds, with a greater and sadder shamelessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:195
verses.text: But even then God doth not leave him, but again speaks the language of an iujured and despised lover, and says, "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:196
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:197
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:198
verses.text: ) And again He rebukes the earth with the murderer, turning His wrath off to it, and saying, "Cursed be the earth, which opened her mouth to receive thy brother's blood" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:199
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:200
verses.text: ); and doing like those who lament (ἀνακαλοὕντας), as David also did when Saul was fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:201
verses.text: For he made an address to the mountains which received him as he died, in the words, "Ye mountains of Gilboa, let there fall on you neither rain nor dew, because there were the shields of the mighty cast away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:202
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:203
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:204
verses.text: ) And thus God also, as though singing some solitary dirge (μονῳδίαν), saith, "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto Me; and now art thou cursed from the earth, which hath opened her mouth to receive thy brother's blood from thy hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:205
verses.text: And this He said to humble his fiery passion, and to persuade him to love him at least now he was gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:206
verses.text: Hast thou extinguished his life? He would say; why dost thou not now extinguish the hatred also? But what doth He do? He loveth both the one and the other, since He made them both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:207
verses.text: What then? doth ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:208
verses.text: will) He let the murderer go unpunished? Nay, he would but have grown worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:209
verses.text: Will He punish him then? Nay, He hath more tenderness than a father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:210
verses.text: See then how He at once punisheth and also displays, even in this, His love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:211
verses.text: Or rather, He doth not so much as punish, but only corrects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:212
verses.text: For He doth not kill him, but only fetters him with trembling, that he may divest himself of the crime, that so at least he may come back to a natural tenderness for the other, and that so at last he may make a truce with him now he hath gone; for He were fain he should not go away to the other world in enmity with him that was deceased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:213
verses.text: This is the way wherein they that love, when in doing acts of kindness they meet with no love in return, are led on to be vehement and to threaten, not with their will indeed, but led by their love to do this: that at least in this way they may win over those that scorn them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:214
verses.text: Yet affection of this sort is one of compulsion, and still this even solaces them, through the vehemency of their love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:215
verses.text: And so punishment itself comes from affection, since unless pained at being hated, they would not choose to punish either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:216
verses.text: Now observe, how this is what Paul says to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:217
