verses.text: For "who is he" (says he) "that maketh me glad, but the same which is made sorry by me?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:218
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:219
verses.text: ) And so when he is going to the full extent of punishment, then he shows his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:220
verses.text: Thus the Egyptian woman too, from her vehement love, as vehemently punished Joseph: and she indeed did so for mischief, the love being unchaste; but God for good, since the love was worthy of Him who loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:221
verses.text: This is why He does not refuse even to condescend to grosser words, and to speak the names of human passions, and to call Himself jealous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:222
verses.text: For "I am a jealous God" (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:223
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:224
verses.text: ), He saith, that you may learn the intenseness of the love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:225
verses.text: Let us then love Him as He would have us: for He sets great store thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:226
verses.text: And if we turn away, He keepeth inviting us, and if we will not be converted, He chasteneth us through His affection, not through a wish to exact punishment of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:227
verses.text: And see what He saith in Ezekiel to the city that was beloved, yet had despised Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:228
verses.text: "I will bring thy lovers against thee, and will deliver thee into their hands, and they shall stone thee, and shall slay thee, and My jealousy shall be taken away from thee, and I will rest, and I will not trouble Myself any more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:229
verses.text: (From Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:230
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:231
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:232
verses.text: ) What more than this could a vehement lover have said, when despised by his beloved, and after all again ardently loving her? For God doeth everything that He may be loved by us, and owing to this He spared not even His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:233
verses.text: But we are unbending, and savage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:234
verses.text: Yet let us become gentle at last, and love God as we ought to love Him, that we may with pleasure enjoy virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:235
verses.text: For if any that hath a beloved wife does not perceive any of the vexations that come day by day, He that loveth with this divine and pure love, only consider what great pleasure he will have to enjoy! For this is, indeed it is, the kingdom of Heaven; this is fruition of good things, and pleasure, and cheerfulness, and joy, and blessedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:236
verses.text: Or rather, say as many things as I may, I shall still be unable to give you any such representation of it as should be, but the trial of it alone can give a knowledge of this goodly thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:237
verses.text: Wherefore also the Prophet saith, "Delight thyself in the Lord" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:238
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:239
verses.text: ), and, "Taste and see that the Lord is gracious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:240
verses.text: (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:241
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:242
verses.text: ) Let us then be persuaded, and indulge ourselves in His love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:243
verses.text: For in this way we shall both see His Kingdom even from out of this life, and shall be living the life of Angels, and while we abide on earth, we shall be in as goodly a condition as they that dwell in heaven; and after our departing hence, shall stand the brightest of beings by the judgment-seat of Christ, and shall enjoy that glory unutterable, which may we all attain unto, by the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 24:244
verses.text: For to Him is the glory forever, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:1
verses.text: Homily XXIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:3
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:4
verses.text: "And that, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:5
verses.text: Since he had given them what commands were fitting, he again thrusts them on to the performance of good works, in consideration of what was pressing upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:6
verses.text: For the time of judgment, he means, is at the doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:7
verses.text: So too he wrote to the Corinthians also, "The remaining time is short".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:8
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:9
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:10
verses.text: ) And to the Hebrews again, "For yet a little while, and He that shall come will come, and will not tarry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:11
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:12
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:13
verses.text: ) But in those cases it was to cheer those in trouble, and to solace the toils of their closely successive temptations, that he said those things: but in the passage before us he does it to rouse those that are asleep, this language being useful to us for both the purposes: and what is that which he says, "Now it is high time to awake out of sleep?" It is, that near is the Resurrection, near the awful Judgment, and the day that burneth as a furnace, near.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:14
verses.text: Henceforward then we must be free from our listlessness; "for now is our salvation nearer than when we believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:15
verses.text: You see how he puts the Resurrection now close by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:16
verses.text: For as the time advances, he means, the season of our present life is wasting away, and that of the life to come waxes nearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:17
verses.text: If then thou be prepared, and hast done all whatsoever He hath commanded, the day is salvation to thee ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:18
verses.text: and Cat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:19
verses.text: σωτηρία σοι); but if the contrary, not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:20
verses.text: For the present however, it is not upon alarming grounds that he exhorts them, but upon kindly ones, thus also to untie them from their fellow-feeling for the things of this present world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:21
verses.text: Then since it was not unlikely, that in the beginning of their early endeavors they would be most earnest, in that their desire was then at its full vigor, but that as the time went on, the whole of their earnestness would wither down to nothing; he says that they ought however to be doing the reverse, not to get relaxed as time went on, but to be the more full of vigor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:22
verses.text: For the nearer the King may be at hand, the more ought they to get themselves in readiness; the nearer the prize is, the more wide awake ought they to be for the contest, since even the racers do this, when they are upon the end of the course, and towards the receiving of the prize, then they rouse themselves up the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:23
verses.text: This is why he said, "Now is our salvation nearer than when we believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:24
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:25
verses.text: "The night is far spent, the day is at hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:26
verses.text: If then this is upon ending, and the latter is drawing near, let us henceforth do what belongs to the latter, not to the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:27
verses.text: For this is what is done in the things of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:28
verses.text: And when we see the night pressing on towards the morning, and hear the swallow twittering, we each of us awake our neighbor, although it be night still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:29
verses.text: But so soon as it is actually departing, we hasten one another, and say It is day now! and we all set about the works of the day, dressing, and leaving our dreams, and shaking our sleep thoroughly off, that the day may find us ready, and we may not have to begin getting up, and stretching ourselves, when the sunlight is up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:30
verses.text: What then we do in that case, that let us do here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:31
verses.text: Let us put off imaginings, let us get clear of the dreams of this life present, let us lay aside its deep slumber, and be clad in virtue for garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:32
verses.text: For it is to point out all this that he says,  "Let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armor of light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:33
verses.text: Yes, for the day is calling us to battle-array, and to the fight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:34
verses.text: Yet fear not at hearing of array and arms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:35
verses.text: For in the case of the visible suit of armor, to put it on is a heavy and abhorred task.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:36
verses.text: But here it is desirable, and worth being prayed for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:37
verses.text: For it is of Light the arms are! Hence they will set thee forth brighter than the sunbeam, and giving out a great glistening, and they place thee in security: for they are arms, and glittering do they make thee: for arms of light are they! What then, is there no necessity for thee to fight? yea, needful is it to fight, yet not to be distressed and toil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:38
verses.text: For it is not in fact war, but a solemn dance and feast-day, such is the nature of the arms, such the power of the Commander.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:39
verses.text: And as the bridegroom goes forth with joyous looks from his chamber, so doth he too who is defended with these arms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:40
verses.text: For he is at once soldier and bridegroom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:41
verses.text: But when he says, "the day is at hand," he does not even allow it to be but near, but puts it even now beside us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:42
verses.text: For he says,  "Let us walk becomingly," (A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:43
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:44
verses.text: honestly, in this sense) "as in the day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:45
verses.text: For day it already is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:46
verses.text: And what most people insist upon very much in their exhortations, that he also uses to draw them on, the sense of the becoming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:47
verses.text: For they had a great regard to the esteem of the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:48
verses.text: And he does not say, walk ye, but let us walk, so making the exhortation free from anything grating, and the reproof gentle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:49
verses.text: "Not in rioting and drunkenness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:50
verses.text: Not that he would forbid drinking, but the doing it immoderately; not the enjoying of wine, but doing it to excess (μετά παροινίας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:51
verses.text: As also the next thing he states likewise with the same measure, in the words,  "Not in chambering and wantonness;" for here also he does not prohibit the intercourse of the sexes, but committing fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:52
verses.text: "Not in strife and envying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:53
verses.text: It is the deadly kind of passions then that he is for extinguishing, lust, namely, and anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:54
verses.text: Wherefore it is not themselves only, but even the sources of them that he removes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:55
verses.text: For there is nothing that so kindles lust, and inflames wrath, as drunkenness, and sitting long at the wine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:56
verses.text: Wherefore after first saying, "not in rioting and drunkenness," then he proceeded with, "not in chambering and wantonness, not in strife and envying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:57
verses.text: And even here he does not pause, but after stripping us of these evil garments, hear how he proceeds to ornament us, when he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:58
verses.text: "But put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:59
verses.text: He no longer speaks of works, but he rouses them to greater things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:60
verses.text: For when he was speaking of vice, he mentioned the works of it: but when of virtue, he speaks not of works, but of arms, to show that virtue putteth him that is possessed of it into complete safety, and complete brightness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:61
verses.text: And even here he does not pause, but leading his discourse on to what was greater, a thing far more awestriking; he gives us the Lord Himself for a garment, the King Himself: for he that is clad with Him, hath absolutely all virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:62
verses.text: But in saying, "Put ye on," he bids us be girt about with Him upon every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:63
verses.text: As in another place he says, "But if Christ be in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:64
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:65
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:66
verses.text: ) And again, "That Christ may dwell in the inner man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:67
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:68
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:69
verses.text: , , al.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:70
verses.text: punct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:71
verses.text: ) For He would have our soul to be a dwelling for Himself, and Himself to be laid round about us as a garment, that He may be unto us all things both from within and from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:72
verses.text: For He is our fulness; for He is "the fulness of Him that filleth all in all" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:73
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:74
verses.text: ): and the Way, and the Husband, and the Bridegroom;—for "I have espoused you as a chaste virgin to one husband," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:75
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:76
verses.text: ): and a root, and drink, and meat, and life;—for he says, "I live, yet not I, but Christ liveth in me;" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:77
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:78
verses.text: ) and Apostle, and High-Priest, and Teacher, and Father, and Brother, and Joint-heir, and sharer of the tomb and Cross;—for it says, "We were buried together with Him," and "planted together in the likeness of His Death" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:79
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:80
verses.text: , ): and a Suppliant;—"For we are ambassadors in Christ's stead" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:81
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:82
verses.text: ): and an "Advocate to the Father;"—for "He also maketh," it says, "intercession for us:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:83
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:84
verses.text: ) and house and inhabitant;—for He says, "He that abideth in Me and I in Him" (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:85
verses.text: ): and a Friend; for, "Ye are My friends" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:86
verses.text: ): and a Foundation, and Corner-stone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:87
verses.text: And we are His members and His heritage, and building, and branches, and fellow-workers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:88
verses.text: For what is there that He is not minded to be to us, when He makes us cleave and fit on to Him in every way? And this is a sign of one loving exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:89
verses.text: Be persuaded then, and rousing thee from sleep, put Him on, and when thou hast done so, give thy flesh up to His bridle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:90
verses.text: For this is what he intimates in saying,  "And make not provision for the flesh, to fulfil the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:91
verses.text: For as he does not forbid drinking, but drinking to excess, not marrying, but doing wantonness; so too he does not forbid making provision for the flesh either, but doing so with a view "to fulfil the lusts thereof," as, for instance, by going beyond necessaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:92
verses.text: For that he does bid make provision for it, hear from what he says to Timothy, "Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake, and thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:93
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:94
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:95
verses.text: ) So here too he is for taking care of it, but for health, and not wantonness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:96
verses.text: For this would cease to be making provision for it, when you were lighting up the flame, when you were making the furnace powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:97
verses.text: But that you may form a clearer notion what "making provision" for it "to fulfil the lusts thereof" is, and may shun such a provision, just call to mind the drunken, the gluttonous, those that pride themselves in dress, those that are effeminate, them that live a soft and relaxed life, and you will see what is meant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:98
verses.text: For they do everything not that they may be healthy, but that they may be wanton and kindle desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:99
verses.text: But do thou, who hast put on Christ, prune away all those things, and seek for one thing only, to have thy flesh in health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:100
verses.text: And to this degree do make provision for it, and not any further, but spend all thy industry on the care of spiritual things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:101
verses.text: For then you will be able to rouse yourself out of this sleep, without being weighed down with these manifold desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:102
verses.text: For the present life is a sleep, and the things in it are no way different from dreams.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:103
verses.text: And as they that are asleep often speak and see things other than healthful, so do we also, or rather we see much worse even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:104
verses.text: For he that doeth anything disgraceful or says the like in a dream, when he is rid of his sleep, is rid of his disgrace, also, and is not to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:105
verses.text: But in this case it is not so, but the shame, and also the punishment, are immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:106
verses.text: Again, they that grow rich in a dream, when it is day are convicted of having been rich to no purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:107
verses.text: But in this case even before the day the conviction often comes upon them, and before they depart to the other life, those dreams have flown away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:108
verses.text: Let us then shake off this evil sleep, for if the day find us sleeping, a deathless death will succeed, and before that day we shall be open to the attacks of all the enemies that are of this world, both men and devils: and if they be minded to undo us, there is nobody to hinder them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:109
verses.text: For if there were many watching, then the danger would not be so great; since however, one perhaps there is, or two, who have lighted a candle, and would be as it were watching in the depth of night, while men were sleeping; therefore now we have need of much sleeplessness, much guardedness, to prevent our falling into the most irremediable evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:110
verses.text: Doth it not now seem to be broad daylight? do we not think that all men are awake and sober? yet still (and perhaps you will smile at what I say, still say it I will) we seem all of us like men sleeping and snoring in the depth of night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:111
verses.text: And if indeed an incorporeal being could be seen, I would show you how most men are snoring, and the devil breaking through walls, and butchering us as we lie, and stealing away the goods within, doing everything fearlessly, as if in profound darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:112
verses.text: Or rather, even if it be impossible to see this with our eyes, let us sketch it out in words, and consider how many have been weighed down by evil desires, how many held down by the sore evil of wantonness, and have quenched the light of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:113
verses.text: Hence it comes that they see one thing instead of another, hear one thing instead of another, and take no notice of any of the things here told them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:114
verses.text: Or if I am mistaken in saying so, and thou art awake, tell me what has been doing here this day, if thou hast not been hearing this as a dream.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:115
verses.text: I am indeed aware that some can tell me (and I do not mean this of all); but do thou who comest under what has been said, who hast come here to no purpose, tell me what Prophet, what Apostle hath been discoursing to us to-day? and on what subjects? And thou wouldest not have it in thy power to tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:116
verses.text: For thou hast been talking a great deal here, just as in a dream, without hearing the realities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:117
verses.text: And this I would have said to the women too, as there is a great deal of sleeping amongst them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:118
verses.text: And would it were sleep! For he that is asleep says nothing either good or bad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:119
verses.text: But he that is awake as ye are puts forth many a word even for mischief on his own head, telling his interest, casting up his creditor accounts, calling to memory some barefaced bargaining, planting the thorns thick in his own soul, and not letting the seed make even ever so little advance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:120
verses.text: But rouse thyself, and pull these thorns up by the roots, and shake the drunkenness off: for this is the cause of the sleep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:121
verses.text: But by drunkenness I mean, not that from wine only, but from worldly thoughts, and with them that from wine also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:122
verses.text: (See p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:123
verses.text: ) And this advice I am giving not to the rich only, but the poor too, and chiefly those that club together for social parties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:124
verses.text: For this is not really indulgence or relaxation, but punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:125
verses.text: For indulgence lies not in speaking filthy things, but in talking solemnly, in being filled, not being ready to burst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:126
verses.text: But if thou thinkest this is pleasure, show me the pleasure by the evening! Thou canst not! And hitherto I say nothing of the mischiefs it leads to, but at present have only been speaking to you of the pleasure that withers away so quickly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:127
verses.text: For the party is no sooner broken up, than all that went for mirth is flown away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:128
verses.text: But when I come to mention the spewing, and the headaches, and the numberless disorders, and the soul's captivity, what have you to say to all this? Have we any business, because we are poor, to behave ourselves unseemly too? And in saying this I do not forbid your meeting together, or taking your suppers at a common table, but to prevent your behaving unseemly, and as wishing indulgence to be really indulgence, and not a punishment, nor a vengeance, or drunkenness and revelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:129
verses.text: Let the Gentiles (ἑλληνες) see that Christians know best how to indulge, and to indulge in an orderly way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:130
verses.text: For it says, "Rejoice in the Lord with trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:131
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:132
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:133
verses.text: ) But how then can one rejoice? Why, by saying hymns, making prayers, introducing psalms in the place of those low songs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:134
verses.text: Thus will Christ also be at our table, and will fill the whole feast with blessing, when thou prayest, when thou singest spiritual songs, when thou invitest the poor to partake of what is set before thee, when thou settest much orderliness and temperance over the feast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:135
verses.text: So thou wilt make the party a Church, by hymning, in the room of ill-timed shouts and cheers, the Master of all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:136
verses.text: And tell me not, that another custom has come to prevail, but correct what is thus amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:137
verses.text: "For whether ye eat," it says, "or whether ye drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:138
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:139
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:140
verses.text: ) For from banquets of that sort you have evil desires, and impurities, and wives come to be in disrepute, and harlots in honor among you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:141
verses.text: Hence come the upsetting of families and evils unnumbered, and all things are turned upside down, and ye have left the pure fountain, and run to the conduit of mire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:142
verses.text: For that an harlot's body is mire, I do not enquire of any one else but of thine own self that wallowest in the mire, if thou dost not feel ashamed of thyself, if thou dost not think thyself unclean after the sin is over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:143
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you flee fornication, and the mother of it, drunkenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:144
verses.text: Why sow where reaping is impossible, or rather even if thou dost reap, the fruit brings thee great shame? For even if a child be born, it at once disgraces thyself, and has itself had injustice done it in being born through thee illegitimate and base.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:145
verses.text: And if thou leave it never so much money, both the son of an harlot, and that of a servant-maid, is disreputable at home, disreputable in the city, disreputable in a court of law: disreputable too wilt thou be also, both in thy lifetime, and when dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:146
verses.text: For if thou have departed even, the memorials of thy unseemliness abide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:147
verses.text: Why then bring disgrace upon all these? Why sow where the ground makes it its care to destroy the fruit? where there are many efforts at abortion? where there is murder before the birth? for even the harlot thou dost not let continue a mere harlot, but makest her a murderess also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:148
verses.text: You see how drunkenness leads to whoredom, whoredom to adultery, adultery to murder; or rather to a something even worse than murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:149
verses.text: For I have no name to give it, since it does not take off the thing born, but prevent its being born.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:150
verses.text: Why then dost thou abuse the gift of God, and fight with His laws, and follow after what is a curse as if a blessing, and make the chamber of procreation a chamber for murder, and arm the woman that was given for childbearing unto slaughter? For with a view to drawing more money by being agreeable and an object of longing to her lovers, even this she is not backward to do, so heaping upon thy head a great pile of fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:151
verses.text: For even if the daring deed be hers, yet the causing of it is thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:152
verses.text: Hence too come idolatries, since many, with a view to become acceptable, devise incantations, and libations, and love-potions, and countless other plans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:153
verses.text: Yet still after such great unseemliness, after slaughters, after idolatries, the thing seems to many to belong to things indifferent, aye, and to many that have wives too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:154
verses.text: Whence the mingle (φορυτὸς) of mischief is the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:155
verses.text: For sorceries are applied not to the womb that is prostituted, but to the injured wife, and there are plottings without number, and invocations of devils, and necromancies, and daily wars, and truceless fightings, and home-cherished jealousies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:156
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul, after saying, "not in chamberings and wantonness," proceeds, "not in strife and envying," as knowing the wars that result therefrom; the upsetting of families, the wrongs done to legitimate children, the other ills unnumbered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:157
verses.text: That we may then escape from all these, let us put on Christ, and be with Him continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:158
verses.text: For this is what putting Him on is; never being without Him, having Him evermore visible in us, through our sanctification, through our moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:159
verses.text: So we say of friends, such an one is wrapped up (ἐνεδύσατο) in such another, meaning their great love, and keeping together incessantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:160
verses.text: For he that is wrapped up in anything, seems to be that which he is wrapped in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:161
verses.text: Let then Christ be seen in every part of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:162
verses.text: And how is He to be seen? If thou doest His deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:163
verses.text: And what did He do? "The Son of Man," He says, "hath not where to lay His head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:164
verses.text: (Luke ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:165
verses.text: ) This do thou also aim after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:166
verses.text: He needed the use of food, and He fared upon barley loaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:167
verses.text: He had occasion to travel, and there were no horses or beast of burden anywhere, but He walked so far as even to be weary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:168
verses.text: He had need of sleep, and He lay "asleep upon the pillow in the fore (πρύμνῃ, here πρώρας) part of the ship".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:169
verses.text: (Mark iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:170
verses.text: ) There was occasion for sitting down to meat, and He bade them lie down upon the grass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:171
verses.text: And His garments were cheap; and often He stayed alone, with no train after Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:172
verses.text: And what He did on the Cross, and what amidst the insults, and all, in a word, that He did, do thou learn by heart (καταμαθὼν) and imitate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:173
verses.text: And so wilt thou have put on Christ, if thou "make no provision for the flesh to fulfil the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:174
verses.text: For the thing has no real pleasure, since these lusts gender again others more keen, and thou wilt never find satisfaction, but wilt only make thee one great torment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:175
verses.text: For as one who is in a continual thirst, even if he have ten thousand fountains hard by him, gets no good from this, as he is not able to extinguish the disorder, so is he that liveth continually in lusts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:176
verses.text: But if thou keep to what is necessary, thou wilt never come to have this fear, but all those things will go away, as well drunkenness as wantonness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:177
verses.text: Eat then only so much as to break thy hunger, have only so much upon thee as to be sheltered, and do not curiously deck thy flesh with clothing, lest thou ruin it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:178
verses.text: For thou wilt make it more delicate, and wilt do injury to its healthfulness, by unnerving it with so much softness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:179
verses.text: That thou mayest have it then a meet vehicle for the soul, that the helmsman may be securely seated over the rudder, and the soldier handle his arms with ease, thou must make all parts to be fitly framed together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:180
verses.text: For it is not the having much, but requiring little, that keeps us from being injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:181
verses.text: For the one man is afraid even if he is not wronged: this other, even if he be wronged, is in better case than those that have not been wronged, and even for this very thing is in the better spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:182
verses.text: Let the object of our search be then, not how we can keep any one from using us spitefully, but how even if he wish to do it, he may be without the power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:183
verses.text: And this there is no other source whence to obtain, save by keeping to necessaries, and not coveting anything more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 25:184
verses.text: For in this way we shall be able to enjoy ourselves here, and shall attain to the good things to come, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:1
verses.text: Homily XXV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:3
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:4
verses.text: ,  "Him that is weak in the faith receive ye, but not to doubtful disputations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:5
verses.text: For one believeth that he may eat all things; another, who is weak, eateth herbs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:6
verses.text: I Am aware that to most what is here said is a difficulty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:7
verses.text: And therefore I must first give the subject of the whole of this passage, and what he wishes to correct in writing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:8
verses.text: What does he wish to correct then? There were many of the Jews which believed, who adhered of conscience to the Law, and after their believing, still kept to the observance of meats, as not having courage yet to quit the service of the Law entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:9
verses.text: Then that they might not be observed if they kept from swine's flesh only, they abstained in consequence from all flesh, and ate herbs only, that what they were doing might have more the appearance of a fast than of observance of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:10
verses.text: Others again were farther advanced, (τελειότεροι) and kept up no one thing of the kind, who became to those, who did keep them, distressing and offensive, by reproaching them, accusing them, driving them to despondency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:11
verses.text: Therefore the blessed Paul, out of fear lest, from a wish to be right about a trifle, they should overthrow the whole, and from a wish to bring them to indifferency about what they ate, should put them in a fair way for deserting the faith, and out of a zeal to put everything right at once, before the fit opportunity was come, should do mischief on vital points, so by this continual rebuking setting them adrift from their agreement in (ὁμολογίας εἰς) Christ, and so they should remain not righted in either respect: observe what great judgment he uses and how he concerns himself with both interests with his customary wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:12
verses.text: For neither does he venture to say to those who rebuke, Ye are doing amiss, that he may not seem to be confirming the other in their observances; nor again, Ye are doing right, lest he should make them the more vehement accusers: but he makes his rebuke to square with each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:13
verses.text: And in appearance he is rebuking the stronger, but he pours forth all he has to say against the other in his address to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:14
verses.text: For the kind of correction most likely to be less grating is, when a person addresses some one else, while he is striking a blow at a different person, since this does not permit the person rebuked to fly into a passion, and introduces the medicine of correction unperceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:15
verses.text: See now with what judgment he does this, and how well-timed he is with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:16
verses.text: For after saying, "make not provision for the flesh to fulfil the lusts thereof," then he proceeds to the discussion of these points, that he might not seem to be speaking in defence of those who were the rebukers, and were for eating of anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:17
verses.text: For the weaker part ever requires more forethought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:18
verses.text: Wherefore he aims his blow against the strong, immediately saying as follows, "Him that is weak in the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:19
verses.text: You see one blow immediately given to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:20
verses.text: For by calling him weak (ἀσθενοὕντα), he points out that he is not healthy (ἄρρωστον).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:21
verses.text: Then he adds next, "receive," and point out again that he requires much attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:22
verses.text: And this is a sign of extreme debility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:23
verses.text: "Not to doubtful disputations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:24
verses.text: See, he has laid on a third stripe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:25
verses.text: For here he makes it appear that his error is of such a nature, that even those who do not transgress in the same manner, and who nevertheless admit him to their affection, and are earnestly bent upon curing him, are at doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:26
verses.text: You see how in appearance he is conversing with these, but is rebuking others secretly and without giving offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:27
verses.text: Then by placing them beside each other, one he gives encomiums, the other accusations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:28
verses.text: For he goes on to say, "One believeth that he may eat all things," commending him on the score of his faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:29
verses.text: "Another who is weak, eateth herbs," disparaging this one again, on the score of his weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:30
verses.text: Then since the blow he had given was deadly (καιρίαν, used hyperbolically), he comforts him again in these words,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:31
verses.text: "Let not him that eateth, despise him that eateth not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:32
verses.text: He does not say, let him alone, nor does he say, do not blame him, nor yet, do not set him right; but do not reproach him, do not "despise" him, to show they were doing a thing perfectly ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:33
verses.text: But of this he speaks in other words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:34
verses.text: "Let not him which eateth not, judge him that eateth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:35
verses.text: For as the more advanced made light of these, as of little faith, and falsely healed, and spurious, and still Judaizers, so they too judged these as law-breakers, or as given to gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:36
verses.text: And of these it is likely that many were of the Gentiles too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:37
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds, for God hath received him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:38
verses.text: But in the other's case he does not say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:39
verses.text: And yet to be despised was the eater's share, as a glutton, but to be judged, his that did not eat, as of little faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:40
verses.text: But he has made them change places, to show that he not only does not deserve to be despised, but that he can even despise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:41
verses.text: But do I condemn him? he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:42
verses.text: By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:43
verses.text: For this is why he proceeds, "for God hath received him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:44
verses.text: Why then speakest thou to him of the law, as to a transgressor? "For God hath received him:" that is, has shown His unspeakable grace about him, and hath freed him from all charges against him; then again he turns to the strong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:45
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:46
verses.text: "Who art thou that judgest another man's servant?"  Whence it appears that they too judged, and did not despise only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:47
verses.text: "To his own Master he standeth or falleth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:48
verses.text: See here is another stroke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:49
verses.text: And the indignation seems to be against the strong man, and he attacks him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:50
verses.text: When he says, "Yea, he shall be holden up," he shows that he is still wavering, and requireth so much attention as to call in God as a physician for this, "for God," he says, "is able to make him stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:51
verses.text: And this we say of things we are quite in despair about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:52
verses.text: Then, that he may not despair he both gives him the name of a servant when he says, "Who art thou that judgest another man's servant?" And here again he secretly attacks him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:53
verses.text: For it is not because he does things worthy to exempt him from being judged, that I bid you not judge him, but because he is Another's servant, that is, not thine, but God's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:54
verses.text: Then to solace him again he does not say, "falleth," but what? "standeth or falleth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:55
verses.text: But whether it be the latter or the former, either of these is the Master's concernment, since the loss also goes to Him, if he does fall, as the riches too, if he stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:56
verses.text: And this again if we do not attend to Paul's aim in not wishing them to be rebuked before a fitting opportunity, is very unworthy of the mutual care becoming for Christians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:57
verses.text: But (as I am always saying) we must examine the mind with which it is spoken, and the subject on which it is said and the object he would compass when he says it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:58
verses.text: But he makes them respectful by no slight motive, when he says this: for what he means is, if God, Who undergoeth the loss, hitherto doth nothing, how can you be else than ill-timed and out of all measure exact, when you seize on (ἄγκων, throttle) him and annoy him?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:59
verses.text: "One man esteemeth one day above another, another esteemeth every day alike".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:60
verses.text: Here he seems to me to be giving a gentle hint about fasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:61
verses.text: For it is not unlikely that some who fasted were always judging those who did not, or among the observances it is likely that there were some that on fixed days abstained, and on fixed days did not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:62
verses.text: Whence also he says, "Let every man be fully persuaded in his own mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:63
verses.text: And in this way he released those who kept the observances from fear, by saying that the thing was indifferent, and he removed also the quarrelsomeness of those who attacked them, by showing that it was no very desirable (or urgent, περισπούδαστον) task to be always making a trouble about these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:64
verses.text: Yet it was not a very desirable task, not in its own nature, but on account of the time chosen, and because they were novices in the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:65
verses.text: For when he is writing to the Colossians, it is with great earnestness that he forbids it, saying, "Beware lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the traditions of men, after the elements of the world, and not after Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:66
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:67
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:68
verses.text: , see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:69
verses.text: ) And again, "Let no man judge you in meat or in drink" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:70
verses.text: ), and, "let no man beguile you of your reward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:71
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:72
verses.text: ) And when writing to the Galatians with great precision, he exacts of them Christian spirit and perfectness in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:73
verses.text: But here he does not use this vehemency, because the faith was lately planted in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:74
verses.text: Let us therefore not apply the phrase, "Let every man be persuaded in his own mind," to all subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:75
verses.text: For when he is speaking of doctrines, hear what he says, "If any one preacheth unto you any gospel other than that ye have received, let him be accursed" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:76
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:77
verses.text: ), "even" if it be "an angel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:78
verses.text: And again, "I fear lest by any means as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:79
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:80
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:81
verses.text: ) And in writing to the Philippians, he says, "Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers, beware of the concision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:82
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:83
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:84
verses.text: ) But with the Romans, since it was not yet the proper time for setting things of this sort right, "Let every man," he says, "be fully persuaded in his own mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:85
verses.text: For he had been speaking of fasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:86
verses.text: It was to clear away the vanity of the others and to release these from fear then, that he said as follows:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:87
verses.text: "He that regardeth the day, regardeth it unto the Lord; and he that regardeth not the day, to the Lord he doth not regard it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:88
verses.text: And, "He that eateth, eateth to the Lord, for he giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:89
verses.text: He still keeps to the same subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:90
verses.text: And what he means is about this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:91
verses.text: The thing is not concerned with fundamentals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:92
verses.text: For the thing requisite is, if this person and the other are acting for God's sake, the thing requisite is (these words are repeated  mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:93
verses.text: ), if both terminate in thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:94
verses.text: For indeed both this man and that give thanks to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:95
verses.text: If then both do give thanks to God, the difference is no great one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:96
verses.text: But let me draw your notice to the way in which here also he aims unawares a blow at the Judaizers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:97
verses.text: For if the thing required be this, the "giving of thanks," it is plain enough that he which eateth it is that "giveth thanks," and not "he which eateth not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:98
verses.text: For how should he, while he still holds to the Law? As then he told the Galatians, "As many of you as are justified by the Law are fallen from grace" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:99
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:100
verses.text: ); so here he hints it only, but does not unfold it so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:101
verses.text: For as yet it was not time to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:102
verses.text: But for the present he bears with it (see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:103
verses.text: ): but by what follows he gives it a further opening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:104
verses.text: For where he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:105
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:106
verses.text: "For none of us liveth unto himself, and no man dieth unto himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:107
verses.text: For whether we live, we live unto the Lord; and whether we die, we die unto the Lord," by this too he makes the same clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:108
verses.text: For how can he that liveth unto the Law, be living unto Christ? But this is not the only thing that he effects by this, he also holds back the person who was in so much haste for their being set right, and persuades him to be patient, by showing that it is impossible for God to despise them, but that in due time He will set them right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:109
verses.text: What is the force then of "none of us liveth to himself?" It means, We are not free, we have a Master who also would have us live, and willeth not that we die, and to whom both of these are of more interest than to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:110
verses.text: For by what is here said he shows that he hath a greater concern for us than we have ourselves, and considereth more than we do, as well our life to be wealth, as our death to be a loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:111
verses.text: For we do not die to ourselves alone, but to our Master also, if we do die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:112
verses.text: But by death here he means that from the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:113
verses.text: However, this were enough to convince us that He taketh care for us, in that it is to Him we live, and to Him we die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:114
verses.text: Still he is not satisfied with saying this, but proceeds further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:115
verses.text: For after saying, "Whether we live, therefore, or die, we are the Lord's," and passing from that death to the physical one, that he may not give an appearance of harshness to his language, he gives another very great indication of His care for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:116
verses.text: Now of what kind is this?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:117
verses.text: "For to this end Christ both died, and rose, and revived, that He might be Lord both of the dead and living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:118
verses.text: And so let us at least convince thee, that He is thoughtful for our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:119
verses.text: For had He not had this great care for us, where were the need of the Dispensation (or Incarnation, οἰκονομίας)? He then that hath shown so much anxiety about our becoming His, as to take the form of a servant, and to die, will He despise us after we have become so? This cannot be so, assuredly it cannot! Nor would He choose to waste so much pains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:120
verses.text: "For to this end (he says) he also died," as if any one were to say, Such an one will not have the heart to despise his servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:121
verses.text: For he minded his own purse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:122
verses.text: (Cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:123
verses.text: Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:124
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:125
verses.text: ) For indeed we are not so much in love with money, as is He with our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:126
verses.text: Wherefore it was not money, but His own Blood that He gave as bail for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:127
verses.text: And for this cause He would not have the heart to give them up, for whom He had laid down so great a price.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:128
verses.text: See too how he shows that His power also is unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:129
verses.text: For he says, "to this end He both died and revived, that He might be Lord both of the dead and the living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:130
verses.text: And above he said, "for whether we live or die, we are His".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:131
verses.text: See what a wide extended Mastery! see what unconquerable might! see what exact providence over us! For tell me not, he means, of the living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:132
verses.text: Even for the departed He taketh care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:133
verses.text: But if He doth of the departed, it is quite plain that He doth of the living also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:134
verses.text: For He hath not omitted any point for this Mastery, making out for Himself more claims than men do, and especially beside all other things in order to take care of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:135
verses.text: For a man puts down money, and for this clings strongly to his own slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:136
verses.text: But He Himself paid down His death; and the salvation of one who was purchased at so great a price, and the Mastery over whom He had gained with so much anxiety and trouble, He is not likely to count of no value.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:137
verses.text: But this he says to make the Judaizer abashed, and to persuade him to call to mind the greatness of the benefit, and how that when dead he had come to be alive, and that there was nothing that he gained from the Law, and how that it would be the last degree of unfeelingness, to leave Him Who had shown so much care toward him, and run away back to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:138
verses.text: After attacking him then sufficiently, he relaxes again, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:139
verses.text: "But why dost thou judge thy brother? or why dost thou set at nought thy brother?"  And so he seems to be setting them upon a level, but from that he has said, he shows that the difference between them is great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:140
verses.text: First then by the appellation of "brother" he does away with disputatiousness, and then also by calling that awful day to their mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:141
verses.text: For after saying, "Why dost thou set at nought thy brother?" he proceeds, "For we shall all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:142
verses.text: And he seems indeed to be again rebuking the more advanced in saying this, but he is putting the mind of the Judaizer to confusion by not only calling for his reverence to the benefit that had been done him, but also making him afraid of the punishment to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:143
verses.text: "For we shall all," he says, "stand before the judgment-seat of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:144
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:145
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:146
verses.text: "For it is written, As I live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow to Me, and every tongue shall confess to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:147
verses.text: So then every one of us shall give account of himself to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:148
verses.text: See how he again puts his mind into confusion, while he seems to be rebuking the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:149
verses.text: For he intimates some such thing, as if he had said, How does it affect you? Are you to be punished for him? But this he does not say, but hints at it by putting it in a milder form, and saying, "For we shall all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ:" and, "So then every one of us shall give account of himself to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:150
verses.text: And he introduces the prophet in witness of the subjection of all to Him, yea a subjection extended even to those in the Old Testament, and of all absolutely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:151
verses.text: For he does not barely say every one shall worship, but "shall confess," that is, shall given an account of what he has done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:152
verses.text: Be in anxiety then as seeing the Master of all sitting on his judgment-seat, and do not make schisms and divisions in the Church, by breaking away from grace, and running over to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:153
verses.text: For the Law also is His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:154
verses.text: And why say I so of the Law? Even those in the Law and those before the Law are His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:155
verses.text: And it is not the Law that will demand an account of thee, but Christ, of thee and of all the human race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:156
verses.text: See how he has released us from the fear of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:157
verses.text: Then that he may not seem to be saying this to frighten them for the occasion, but to have come to it in the course he had proposed himself, he again keeps to the same subject, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:158
verses.text: "Let us not therefore judge one another any more: but judge this rather, that no man put a stumbling-block or an occasion to fall in his brother's way".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:159
verses.text: This does not apply to one less than the other: wherefore it may well fit with both, both the advanced man that was offended at the observance of meats, and the unadvanced that stumbled at the vehement rebuke given him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:160
verses.text: But consider, I pray you, the great punishment we shall suffer, if we give offence at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:161
verses.text: For if in a case where the thing was against law, yet, as they rebuked unseasonably, he forbade their doing it, in order that a brother might not be made to offend and stumble; when we give an offence without having anything to set right even, what treatment shall we deserve? For if not saving others be a crime (and that it is so, he who buried the talent proves), what will be the effect of giving him offence also? But what if he gives himself the offence, you may say, by being weak? Why this is just why thou oughtest to be patient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:162
verses.text: For if he were strong, then he would not require so much attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:163
verses.text: But now, since he is of the feebler sort, he does on this ground need considerable care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:164
verses.text: Let us then yield him this, and in all respects bear his burdens, as it is not of our own sins only that we shall have to give an account, but for those also wherein we cause others to offend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:165
verses.text: For if that account, were even by itself hard to pass, when these be added too, how are we to be saved? And let us not suppose, that if we can find accomplices in our sins, that will be an excuse; as this will prove an addition to our punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:166
verses.text: Since the serpent too was punished more than the woman, as was the woman likewise more than the man ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:167
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:168
verses.text: ); and Jezebel also was punished more severely than Ahab, who had seized the vineyard; for it was she that devised the whole matter, and caused the king to offend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:169
verses.text: ( Kings xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:170
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:171
verses.text: ) And therefore thou, when thou art the author of destruction to others, wilt suffer more severely than those who have been subverted by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:172
verses.text: For sinning is not so ruinous as leading others also into the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:173
verses.text: Wherefore he speaks of those who "not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:174
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:175
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:176
verses.text: ) And so when we see any sinning, let us, so far from thrusting them on, even pull them back from the pit of iniquity, that we may not have to be punished for the ruin of others besides ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:177
verses.text: And let us be continually in mind of the awful judgment-seat, of the stream of fire, of the chains never to be loosed, of the darkness with no light, the gnashing of teeth, and the venomous worm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:178
verses.text: "Ah, but God is merciful!" Are these then mere words? and was not that rich man punished for despising Lazarus? Are not the foolish virgins cast out of the Bride-chamber? Do not they who did not feed Him go away into "the fire prepared for the devil?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:179
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:180
verses.text: ) Will not he that hath soiled garments be "bound hand and foot" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:181
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:182
verses.text: ), and go to ruin? Will, not he that demanded the hundred pence to be paid, be given over to the tormentors? Is not that said of the adulterers true, that "their worm shall not die, nor their fire be quenched?" (Mark ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:183
verses.text: ) Are these but mere threats then? Yea, it is answered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:184
verses.text: And from what source pray dost thou venture to make such an assertion, and that too when thou passest judgment of thine own opinion? Why, I shall be able to prove the contrary, both from what He said, and from what He did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:185
verses.text: (See John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:186
verses.text: ) For if you will not believe by the punishments that are to come, at least believe by those that have happened already.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:187
verses.text: For what have happened, and have come forth into reality, surely are not threats and words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:188
verses.text: Who then was it that flooded the whole world, and affected that baleful wreck, and the utter destruction of our whole race! Who was it that after this hurled those thunders and lightnings upon the land of Sodom? Who that drowned all Egypt in the sea? Who that consumed the six hundred thousand men in the wilderness? Who that burnt up the synagogue of Abiram? Who that bade the earth open her mouth for the company of Core and Dathan, and swallow them up? Who that carried off the threescore and ten thousand at one sweep in David's time? Shall I mention also those that were punished individually! Cain, who was given up to a continual vengeance? (the son of) Charmi, who was stoned with his whole family? Or him, that suffered the same thing for gathering sticks on the sabbath? The forty children who were consumed by those beasts, and obtained no pardon even on the score of their age? And if you would see these same things even after the times of grace, just consider what great suffering the Jews had, how the women ate their children, some roasting them, and some consuming them in other ways: how after being given up to irremediable famine, and wars varied and severe, they threw all previous catastrophes into the shade by the exceeding greatness of their own calamities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:189
verses.text: For that it was Christ Who did these things unto them, hear Him declaring as much, both by parables, and clearly and explicitly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:190
verses.text: By parables, as when He says, "But those that would not that I should reign over them, bring hither and slay them" (Luke xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:191
verses.text: ); and by that of the vineyard, and that of the marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:192
verses.text: But clearly and explicitly, as when He threatens that they shall fall by the edge of the sword, and shall be led away captive into the nations, and there shall be upon the earth "distress of nations with perplexity, at the roaring of the sea and waves; men's hearts failing them for fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:193
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:194
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:195
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:196
verses.text: ) "And there shall be tribulation, such as there never was, no, nor ever shall be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:197
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:198
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:199
verses.text: ) And what a punishment Ananias too and Sapphira suffered, for the theft of a few pieces of money, ye all know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:200
verses.text: Seest thou not the daily calamities also? Or have these too not taken place? Seest thou not now men that are pining with famine? those that suffer elephantiasis, or are maimed in body? those that live in constant poverty, those that suffer countless irreparable evils? Now then will it be reasonable for some to be punished, and some not? For if God be not unjust (and unjust He is not), thou also wilt assuredly suffer punishment, if thou sinnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:201
verses.text: But if because He is merciful He doth not punish, then ought not these either to have been punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:202
verses.text: But now because of these words of yours, God even here punisheth many, that when ye believe not the words of the threatening, the deeds of vengeance ye may at least believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:203
verses.text: And since things of old do not affright you so much, by things which happen in every generation, He correcteth those that in every generation are growing listless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:204
verses.text: And what is the reason, it may be said, why He doth not punish all here? That He may give the others an interval for repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:205
verses.text: Why then does He not take vengeance upon all in the next world? It is lest many should disbelieve in His providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:206
verses.text: How many robbers are there who have been taken, and how many that have left this life unpunished? Where is the mercy of God then? it is my turn now to ask of thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:207
verses.text: For supposing no one at all had vengeance taken upon him, then you might have taken refuge in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:208
verses.text: But now that some are punished, and some are not, though they be the worse sinners, how can it be reasonable that there be not the same punishments for the same sins? How can those punished appear to be else than wronged? What reason is there then why all are not punished here? Hear His own defence for these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:209
verses.text: For when some had died by the falling of a tower on them: He said to those who raised a question upon this, "Suppose ye that they were sinners above all men? I tell you nay, but except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish" (Luke xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:210
verses.text: , ); so exhorting us not to feel confident when others suffer punishment, and we ourselves, though we have committed many transgressions, do not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:211
verses.text: For except we change our conduct, we assuredly shall suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:212
verses.text: And how, it may be said, is it that we are to be punished without end for sinning a short time here? how, I ask, is it that in this world, those who in a short moment of time have done one murder, are condemned to constant punishment in the mines? "But it is not God that does this," it may be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:213
