verses.text: How then came He to keep the man with a palsy for thirty and eight years in so great punishments? For that it was for sins that He punished him, hear what He says, "Behold, thou art made whole, sin no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:214
verses.text: (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:215
verses.text: ) Still it is said, he found a release.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:216
verses.text: But the case is not so with the other life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:217
verses.text: For that there, there will never be any release, hear from His own mouth, "Their worm will not die, nor their fire be quenched".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:218
verses.text: (Mark ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:219
verses.text: ) And "these shall go into everlasting life, but these into everlasting punishment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:220
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:221
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:222
verses.text: ) Now if the life be eternal, the punishment is eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:223
verses.text: Seest thou not how severely He threatened the Jews? Then have the things threatened come to pass, or were those that were told them a mere talk? "One stone shall not remain upon another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:224
verses.text: (Luke xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:225
verses.text: ) And has it remained? But what, when He says, "There shall be tribulation such as hath not been?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:226
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:227
verses.text: ) Has it not come then? Read the history of Josephus, and thou wilt not be able to draw thy breath even, at only hearing what they suffered for their doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:228
verses.text: This I say, not that I may pain you, but that I may make you secure, and lest by having humored you overmuch, I should but make a way for the endurance of sorer punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:229
verses.text: For why, pray, dost thou not deem it right thou shouldest be punished for sinning? Hath He not told thee all beforehand? Hath He not threatened thee? not come to thy aid? not done things even without number for thy salvation's sake? Gave He thee not the laver of Regeneration, and forgave He not all thy former sins? Hath He not after this forgiveness, and the laver, also given thee the succor of repentance if thou sin? Hath He not made the way to forgiveness of sins, even after all this, easy to thee? Hear then what He hath enjoined: "If thou forgive thy neighbor, I also will forgive thee" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:230
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:231
verses.text: ), He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:232
verses.text: What hardship is there in this? "If ye judge the cause of the fatherless, and see that the widow have right, come and let us converse together," He saith, "and if your sins be as purple, I will make them white as snow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:233
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:234
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:235
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:236
verses.text: ) What labor is there here? "Tell thy sins, that thou mayest be justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:237
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:238
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:239
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:240
verses.text: ) What hardship is there in this? "Redeem thy sins with alms".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:241
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:242
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:243
verses.text: ) What toilsomeness is there in this? The Publican said, "Be merciful to me a sinner," and "went down home justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:244
verses.text: (Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:245
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:246
verses.text: ) What labor is it to imitate the Publican? And wilt thou not be persuaded even after this that there is punishment and vengeance? At that rate thou wilt deny that even the devil is punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:247
verses.text: For, "Depart," He says, "into the fire prepared for the devil and his angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:248
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:249
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:250
verses.text: ) Now if there be no hell, then neither is he punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:251
verses.text: But if he is punished, it is plain that we shall also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:252
verses.text: For we also have disobeyed, even if it be not in the same way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:253
verses.text: And how comest thou not to be afraid to speak such daring things? For when thou sayest that God is merciful, and doth not punish, if He should punish he will be found in thy case to be no longer merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:254
verses.text: See then unto what language the devil leadeth you? And what are the monks that have taken up with the mountains, and yield examples of such manifold self-denial, to go away without their crown? For if the wicked are not to be punished, and there is no recompense made to any one, some one else will say, perhaps, that neither are the good crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:255
verses.text: Nay, it will be said, For this is suitable with God, that there should be a kingdom only, and not a hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:256
verses.text: Well then, shall the whoremonger, and the adulterer, and the man who hath done evils unnumbered, enjoy the same advantages with the man who has exhibited soberness and holiness, and Paul is to stand with Nero, or rather even the devil with Paul? For if there be no hell and yet there will be a Resurrection of all, then the wicked will attain to the same good things! And who would say this? Who even of men that were quite crazed? or rather, which of the devils even would say this? For even they confess that there is a hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:257
verses.text: Wherefore also they cried out and said, "Art Thou come hither to torment us before the time?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:258
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:259
verses.text: )  How then comest thou not to fear and tremble, when even the devils confess what thyself art denying? Or how is it that thou dost not see who is the teacher of these evil doctrines? For he who deceived the first man, and under the pretext of greater hopes, threw them out even of the blessings they had in possession, he it is who now suggests the saying and fancying of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:260
verses.text: And for this reason he persuades some to suspect there is no hell, that he may thrust them into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:261
verses.text: As God on the other hand threateneth hell, and made hell ready, that by coming to know of it thou mightest so live as not to fall into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:262
verses.text: And yet if, when there is a hell, the devil persuades thee to these things, how came the devils to confess it, if it did not exist, whose aim and desire it is that we should not suspect anything of the kind, that through fearlessness we might become the more listless, and so fall with them into that fire? How then (it will be said) came they to confess it? It was through their not bearing the compulsion laid upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:263
verses.text: Taking all these things into consideration then, let those who talk in this way leave off deceiving both themselves and others since even for these words of theirs they will be punished for detracting (διασύροντες) from those awful things, and relaxing the vigor of many who are minded to be in earnest, and do not even do as much as those barbarians, for they, though they were ignorant of everything, when they heard that the city was to be destroyed, were so far from disbelieving, that they even groaned, and girded themselves with sackcloth, and were confounded, and did not cease to use every means until they had allayed the wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:264
verses.text: (Jonah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:265
verses.text: ) But dost thou, who hast had so great experience of facts and of teaching, make light of what is told thee? The contrary then will be thy fate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:266
verses.text: For as they through fear of the words had not to undergo the vengeance in act, so thou who despisest the threatening by words, wilt have to undergo the punishment in very deed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:267
verses.text: And if now what thou art told seems a fable to thee, it will not, however, seem so when the very things convince thee, in that Day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:268
verses.text: Have you never noticed what He did even in this world? How when He met with two thieves, He counted them not worthy of the same estate, but one He led into the Kingdom, and the other He sent away into Hell? And why speak I of a robber and murderer? For even the Apostle He did not spare, when he had become a traitor, but even when He saw him rushing to the halter, and hanging, and bursting asunder in the midst (for he did "burst asunder, and all his bowels gushed out") (Acts i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:269
verses.text: ), still when He foresaw all these things, He let him suffer all the same, giving thee from the present a proof of all that is in the other world also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:270
verses.text: Do not then cheat yourselves, through being persuaded of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:271
verses.text: These devices are his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 26:272
verses.text: For if both judges, and masters, and teachers, and savages, respect the good, and punish the evil, with what reason is the contrary to be the case with God, while the good man and he who is not so are deemed worthy of the same estate? And when will they leave off their wickedness? For they who now are expecting punishment, and are amongst so many terrors, those from the judges and from the laws, and yet do not for this depart from iniquity; when on their departing this life they are to lay aside even this fear, and are not only not to be cast into hell, but are even to obtain a kingdom; when will they leave doing wickedly? Is this then mercy, pray? to add to wickedness, to set up rewards for iniquity, to count the sober and the unchastened, the faithful and the irreligious, Paul and the devil, to have the same deserts? But how long am I to be trifling? Wherefore I exhort you to get you free from this madness, and having grown to be your own masters, persuade your souls to fear and to tremble, that they may at once be saved from the hell to come, and may, after passing the life in this world soberly, attain unto the good things to come by the grace and love towards man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:1
verses.text: Homily XXVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:3
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:4
verses.text: "I know, and am persuaded by (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:5
verses.text: in) the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing unclean of itself, but to him that esteemeth anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:6
verses.text: After first rebuking the person who judgeth his brother, and moving him to leave off this reproaching, he then explains himself further upon the doctrinal part, and instructs in a dispassionate tone the weaker sort, displaying in this case too a great deal of gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:7
verses.text: For he does not say he shall be punished, nor anything of the sort, but merely disburdens him of his fears in the matter, and that with a view to his being more easily persuaded with what he tells him; and he says, "I know, and am persuaded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:8
verses.text: And then to prevent any of those who did not trust him (or "believe," τὥν οὐ πιστὥν) saying, And what is it to us if thou art persuaded? for thou art no trustworthy evidence to be set in competition with so great a law, and with oracles brought down from above, he proceeds, "in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:9
verses.text: That is, as having learned from Him, as having my confidence from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:10
verses.text: The judgment then is not one of the mind of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:11
verses.text: What is it that thou art persuaded of and knowest? Tell us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:12
verses.text: "That there is nothing unclean of itself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:13
verses.text: By nature, he says, nothing is unclean but it becomes so by the spirit in which a man uses it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:14
verses.text: Therefore it becomes so to himself only, and not to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:15
verses.text: "For to him that esteemeth anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:16
verses.text: What then? Why not correct thy brother, that he may think it not unclean? Why not with full authority call him away from this habit of mind and conception of things, that he may never make it common? My reason is, he says, I am afraid to grieve him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:17
verses.text: Wherefore he proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:18
verses.text: "But if thy brother be grieved with thy meat, now walkest thou not charitably".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:19
verses.text: You see how far, for the present, he goes in affection for him, showing that he makes so great account of him, that with a view not to grieve him he does not venture even to enjoin things of great urgency, but by yieldingness would rather draw him to himself, and by charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:20
verses.text: For even when he has freed him of his fears, he does not drag him and force him, but leaves him his own master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:21
verses.text: For keeping a person from meats is no such matter as overwhelming with grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:22
verses.text: You see how much he insists upon charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:23
verses.text: And this is because he is aware that it can do everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:24
verses.text: And on this ground he makes somewhat larger demand upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:25
verses.text: For so far he says from its being proper for them to distress you at all, they ought even, if need be, not to hesitate at condescending to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:26
verses.text: Whence he proceeds to say, "Destroy not him with thy meat, for whom Christ died".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:27
verses.text: Or dost thou not value thy brother enough even to purchase his salvation at the price of abstinence from meats? And yet Christ refused not to become a slave, nor yet to die for him; but thou dost not despise even food, that thou mayest save him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:28
verses.text: And yet with it all Christ was not to gain all, yet still He died for all; so fulfilling His own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:29
verses.text: But art thou aware that by meat thou art overthrowing him in the more important matters, and yet makest a disputing? And him who is the object of such care unto Christ, dost thou consider so contemptible, and dishonor one whom He loveth? Yet He died not for the weak only, but even for an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:30
verses.text: And wilt not thou refrain from meats even, for him that is weak? Yet Christ did what was greatest even, but thou not even the less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:31
verses.text: And He was Master, thou a brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:32
verses.text: These words then were enough to tongue-tie him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:33
verses.text: For they show him to be of a little spirit, and after having the benefit of great things from God, not to give in return even little ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:34
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:35
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:36
verses.text: "Let not then your good be evil spoken of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:37
verses.text: For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:38
verses.text: By their "good," he means here either their faith, or the hope of rewards hereafter, or the perfectness of their religious state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:39
verses.text: For it is not only that you fail to profit your brother, he means, but the doctrine itself, and the grace of God, and His gift, you cause to be evil spoken of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:40
verses.text: Now when thou fightest, when thou quarrellest, when thou art vexatious, when thou makest schism in the Church, and reproachest thy brother, and art distant with him, those that are without will speak evil of you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:41
verses.text: And so good is so far from coming of this, that just the opposite is the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:42
verses.text: For your good is charity, love of the brotherhood, being united, being bound together, living at peace, living in gentleness (ἐπιεικείας).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:43
verses.text: He again, to put an end to his fears and the other's disputatiousness, says, "For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:44
verses.text: Is it by these, he means, that we are to be approved? As he says in another passage too, "Neither if we eat are we the better, neither if we eat not are we the worse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:45
verses.text: And he does not need any proof, but is content with stating it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:46
verses.text: And what he says is this, If thou eatest, does this lead thee to the Kingdom? And this was why, by way of satirizing them as mightily pleased with themselves herein, he said, not "meat" only, but "drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:47
verses.text: What then are the things that do bring us here? "Righteousness, and peace, and joy," and a virtuous life, and peace with our brethren (whereto this quarrelsomeness is opposed), the joy from unanimity, which this rebuking puts an end to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:48
verses.text: But this he said not to one party only, but to both of them, it being a fit season for saying it to both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:49
verses.text: Then as he had mentioned peace and joy, but there is a peace and joy over bad actions also, he adds, "in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:50
verses.text: Since he that ruins his brother, hath at once subverted peace, and wronged joy, more grievously than he that plunders money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:51
verses.text: And what is worse is, that Another saved him, and thou wrongest and ruinest him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:52
verses.text: Since then eating, and the supposed perfect state, does not bring in these virtues, but the things subversive of them it does bring in, how can it be else than right to make light of little things, in order to give firmness to great ones? Then since this rebuking took place in some degree out of vanity, he proceeds to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:53
verses.text: "For he that in these things serveth Christ, is acceptable to God, and approved of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:54
verses.text: For they will not admire thee so much for thy perfect state, as all will for peace and amity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:55
verses.text: For this is a goodly thing, that all will have the benefit of, but of that not one even will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:56
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:57
verses.text: "Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, and things wherewith one may edify one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:58
verses.text: This applies to the other, that he may grow peaceable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:59
verses.text: But the other to the latter too, that he may not destroy his brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:60
verses.text: Still he has made both apply to either again, by saying, "one another," and showing that without peace it is not easy to edify.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:61
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:62
verses.text: "For meat destroy not the work of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:63
verses.text: Giving this name to the salvation of a brother, and adding greatly to the fears, and showing that he is doing the opposite of that he desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:64
verses.text: For thou, he says, art so far from building up as thou intendest, that thou dost even destroy, and that a building too not of man but of God, and not for any great end either, but for a trivial thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:65
verses.text: For it was "for meat," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:66
verses.text: Then lest so many indulgences should confirm the weaker brother in his misconception, he again becomes doctrinal, as follows,  "All things indeed are pure, but it is evil for that man who eateth with offence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:67
verses.text: Who does it, that is, with a bad conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:68
verses.text: And so if you should force him, and he should eat, there would be nothing gained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:69
verses.text: For it is not the eating that maketh unclean, but the intention with which a man eats.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:70
verses.text: If then thou dost not set that aright, thou hast done all to no purpose, and hast made things worse: for thinking a thing unclean is not so bad as tasting it when one thinks it unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:71
verses.text: Here then you are committing two errors, one by increasing his prejudice through your quarrelsomeness, and another by getting him to taste of what is unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:72
verses.text: And so, as long as you do not persuade him, do not force him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:74
verses.text: "It is good neither to eat flesh, nor to drink wine, nor anything whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:75
verses.text: Again, he requires the greater alternative, that they should not only not force him, but even condescend to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:76
verses.text: For he often did this himself also, as when he circumcised (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:77
verses.text: ), when he was shorn (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:78
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:79
verses.text: ), when he sacrificed that Jewish sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:80
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:81
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:82
verses.text: , see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:83
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:84
verses.text: And he does not say to the man "do so," but he states it in the form of a sentiment to prevent again making the other, the weaker man, too listless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:85
verses.text: And what are his words? "It is good not to eat flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:86
verses.text: And why do I say flesh? if it be wine, or any other thing of the sort besides, which gives offence, refrain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:87
verses.text: For nothing is so important as thy brother's salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:88
verses.text: And this Christ shows us, since He came from Heaven, and suffered all that He went through, for our sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:89
verses.text: And let me beg you to observe, how he also drives it home upon the other, by the words "stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:90
verses.text: And do not tell me (he means) that he is so without reason but, that thou hast power to set it right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:91
verses.text: For the other has a sufficient claim to be helped in his weakness, and to thee this were no loss, not being a case of hypocrisy (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:92
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:93
verses.text: ), but of edification and economy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:94
verses.text: For if thou force him, he is at once destroyed, and will condemn thee, and fortify himself the more in not eating.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:95
verses.text: But if thou condescend to him, then he will love thee, and will not suspect thee as a teacher, and thou wilt afterwards gain the power of sowing imperceptibly in him the right views.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:96
verses.text: But if he once hate thee, then thou hast closed the entrance for thy reasoning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:97
verses.text: Do not then compel him, but even thyself refrain for his sake, not refraining from it as unclean, but because he is offended, and he will love thee the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:98
verses.text: So Paul also advises when he says, "It is good not to eat flesh," not because it was unclean, but because the brother is offended and is weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:100
verses.text: "Hast thou faith? have it to thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:101
verses.text: Here he seems to me to be giving a gentle warning to the more advanced on the score of vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:102
verses.text: And what he says is this, Dost thou wish to show me that thou art perfect, and fully furnished? Do not show it to me, but let thy conscience suffice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:103
verses.text: And by faith, he here means that concerned not with doctrines, but with the subject in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:104
verses.text: For of the former it says, "With the mouth confession is made unto salvation" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:105
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:106
verses.text: ); and, "Whosoever shall deny Me before men, him will I also deny".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:107
verses.text: (Luke ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:108
verses.text: ) For the former by not being confessed, ruins us; and so does this by being confessed unseasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:109
verses.text: "Happy is he that condemneth not himself in the thing which he alloweth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:110
verses.text: Again he strikes at the weaker one, and gives him (i-e: the stronger) a sufficient crown, in that of his conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:111
verses.text: Even if no man see, that is, thou art able to be happy in thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:112
verses.text: For after saying, "Have it to thyself," to prevent his thinking this a contemptible tribunal, he tells him this is better to thee than the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:113
verses.text: And if all accuse thee, and thou condemn not thyself, and thy conscience lay no charge against thee, thou art happy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:114
verses.text: But this is a statement he did not make to apply to any person whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:115
verses.text: For there are many that condemn not themselves, and yet are great transgressors: and these are the most miserable of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:116
verses.text: But he still keeps to the subject in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:117
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:118
verses.text: "And he that doubteth is condemned if he eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:119
verses.text: Again, it is to exhort him to spare the weaker, that he says this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:120
verses.text: For what good is it if he eat in doubt, and condemn himself? For I approve of him, who both eateth, and doeth it not with doubting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:121
verses.text: See how he induces him not to eating only, but to eating with a good conscience too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:122
verses.text: Then he mentions likewise the reason why he is condemned continuing in these words,  "Because he eateth not of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:123
verses.text: Not because it is unclean, but because it is not of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:124
verses.text: For he did not believe that it is clean, but though unclean he touched it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:125
verses.text: But by this he shows them also what great harm they do by compelling men, and not persuading them, to touch things which had hitherto appeared unclean to them, that for this at all events they might leave rebuking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:126
verses.text: "For whatsoever is not of faith is sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:127
verses.text: For when a person does not feel sure, nor believe that a thing is clean, how can he do else than sin? Now all these things have been spoken by Paul of the subject in hand, not of everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:128
verses.text: And observe what care he takes not to offend any; and he had said before, "If thy brother be grieved with thy meat, now walkest thou not charitably".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:129
verses.text: But if one should not grieve him, much less ought one to give him offence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:130
verses.text: And again, "For meat destroy not the work of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:131
verses.text: For if it were a grievous act of iniquity to throw down a Church, much more so is it to do so to the spiritual Temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:132
verses.text: Since a man is more dignified than a Church: for it was not for walls that Christ died, but for these temples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:133
verses.text: Let us then watch our own conduct on all sides, and afford to no one ever so little handle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:134
verses.text: For this life present is a race-course and we ought to have thousands of eyes (Hilary in Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:135
verses.text: cxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:136
verses.text: ) on every side, and not even to fancy that ignorance will be an adequate excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:137
verses.text: For there is such a thing, there certainly is, as being punished for ignorance, when the ignorance is inexcusable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:138
verses.text: Since the Jews too were ignorant, yet not ignorant in an excusable way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:139
verses.text: And the Gentiles were ignorant, but they are without excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:140
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:141
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:142
verses.text: ) For when thou art ignorant of those things which it is not possible to know, thou wilt not be subject to any charge for it: but when of things easy and possible, thou wilt be punished with the utmost rigor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:143
verses.text: Else if we be not excessively supine, but contribute our own share to its full amount, God will also reach forth His hand unto us in those things which we are ignorant of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:144
verses.text: And this is what Paul said to the Philippians likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:145
verses.text: "If in anything ye be otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:146
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:147
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:148
verses.text: ) But when we are not willing to do even what we are masters of, we shall not have the benefit of His assistance in this either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:149
verses.text: And this was the case with the Jews too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:150
verses.text: "For this cause," He says, "speak I unto them in parables, because seeing they see not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:151
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:152
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:153
verses.text: ) In what sense was it that seeing they saw not? They saw devils cast out, and they said, He hath a devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:154
verses.text: They saw the dead raised, and they worshipped not, but attempted to kill Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:155
verses.text: But not of this character was Cornelius.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:156
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:157
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:158
verses.text: ) For this reason then, when he was doing the whole of his duty with sincerity, God added unto him that which was lacking also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:159
verses.text: Say not then, how came God to neglect such and such a one who was no formalist (ἄπλαστος) and a good man, though a Gentile? For in the first place no man can possibly know for certain whether a person is no formalist, but He only who "formed (πλάσαντι) the hearts severally".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:160
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:161
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:162
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:163
verses.text: ) And then there is this to be said too, that perchance (πολλάκις) such an one was neither thoughtful nor earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:164
verses.text: And how, it may be said, could he, as being very uninformed? (ἄπλαστος.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:165
verses.text: ) Let me beg you to consider then this simple and single-hearted man, and take notice of him in the affairs of life, and you will see him a pattern of the utmost scrupulousness, such that if he would have shown it in spiritual matters he would not have been overlooked: for the facts of the truth are clearer than the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:166
verses.text: And wherever a man may go, he might easily lay hold of his own salvation, if he were minded, that is, to be heedful, and not to look on this as a by-work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:167
verses.text: For were the doings shut up into Palestine, or in a little corner of the world? Hast thou not heard the prophet say, "All shall know Me from the least even to the greatest?" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:168
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:169
verses.text: ; Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:170
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:171
verses.text: ) Do not you see the things themselves uttering the truth? How then are these to be excused, seeing as they do the doctrine of the truth spread far and wide, and not troubling themselves, or caring to learn it? And dost thou require all this, it is asked, of a rude savage? Nay not of a rude savage only, but of any who is more savage than men of the present day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:172
verses.text: For why is it, pray, that in matters of this world he knows how to answer when he is wronged, and to resist when he has violence done him, and do and devise everything to prevent his ever having his will thwarted even in the slightest degree; but in spiritual concerns he has not used this same judgment? And when a man worships a stone, and thinks it a god, he both keeps feasts to it, and spends money on it, and shows much fear towards it, and in no case becomes listless from his simpleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:173
verses.text: But when he has to seek to the very and true God, do you then mention singleness and simpleness to me? These things are not so, assuredly they are not! For the complaints are those of mere listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:174
verses.text: For which do you think the most simple and rude, those in Abraham's day or those now? (Josh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:175
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:176
verses.text: ) Clearly the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:177
verses.text: And when that it was easiest to find religion out now or then? Clearly now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:178
verses.text: For now the Name of God is proclaimed even by all men, and the Prophets have preached, the things come to pass, the Gentiles been convinced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:179
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:180
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:181
verses.text: ; Judges xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:182
verses.text: ) But at that day the majority were still in an uninstructed state, and sin was dominant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:183
verses.text: And there was no law to instruct, nor prophets, nor miracles, nor doctrine, nor multitude of men acquainted with it, nor aught else of the kind, but all things then lay as it were in a deep darkness, and a night moonless and stormy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:184
verses.text: And yet even then that wondrous and noble man, though the obstacles were so great, still knew God and practised virtue, and led many to the same zeal; and this though he had not even the wisdom of those without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:185
verses.text: For how should he, when there were no letters even yet invented? Yet still he brought his own share in, and God joined to bring in what was lacking to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:186
verses.text: For you cannot say even this, that Abraham received his religion from his fathers, because he (Terah, see Josh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:187
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:188
verses.text: ) was an idolater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:189
verses.text: But still, though he was from such forefathers and was uncivilized, and lived among uncivilized people, and had no instructor in religion, yet he attained to a knowledge of God, and in comparison with all his descendants, who had the advantage both of the Law and the Prophets, he was so much more illustrious as no words can express.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:190
verses.text: Why was it then? It was because in things of this world he did not give himself any great anxiety, but in things of the spirit he applied his whole attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:191
verses.text: (In Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:192
verses.text: Hom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:193
verses.text: , etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:194
verses.text: ) And what of Melchizedek? was not he also born about those times, and was so bright as to be called even a priest of God? (In Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:195
verses.text: Hom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:196
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:197
verses.text: ) For it is impossible in the extreme, that the sober-minded (νήφοντα) should ever be overlooked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:198
verses.text: And let not these things be a trouble to us, but knowing that it is the mind with which in each case the power lies, let us look to our own duties, that we may grow better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:199
verses.text: Let us not be demanding an account of God or enquire why He let such an one alone, but called such an one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:200
verses.text: For we are doing the same as if a servant that had given offence were to pry into his master's housekeeping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:201
verses.text: Wretched and miserable man, when thou oughtest to be thoughtful about the account thou hast to give, and how thou wilt reconcile thy master, dost thou call him to account for things that thou art not to give an account of, passing over those things of which thou art to give a reckoning? What am I to say to the Gentile? he asks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:202
verses.text: Why, the same that I have been saying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:203
verses.text: And look not merely to what thou shalt say to the Gentile, but also to the means of amending thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:204
verses.text: When he is offended by examining into thy life, then consider what thou wilt say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:205
verses.text: For if he be offended, thou wilt not be called to a reckoning for him, but if it be thy way of life by which he is injured, thou wilt have to undergo the greatest danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:206
verses.text: When he seeth thee philosophizing about the kingdom, and fluttering at the things of this life, and at once afraid about hell, and trembling at the calamities of this life, then lay it to mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:207
verses.text: When he sees this, and accuses thee, and says, If thou art in love with the Kingdom, how is it thou dost not look down upon the things of this life? If thou art expecting the awful judgment, why dost thou not despise the terrors of this world? If thou hopest for immortality, why dost thou not think scorn of death? When he says this, be thou anxious what defence thou wilt make.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:208
verses.text: When he sees thee trembling at the thought of losing thy money, thee that expectest the heavens, and exceedingly glad about a single penny, and selling thy soul again for a little money, then lay it to mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:209
verses.text: For these are the things, just these, that make the Gentiles stumble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:210
verses.text: And so, if thou art thoughtful about his salvation, make thy defence on these heads, not by words, but by actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:211
verses.text: For it is not through that question that anybody ever blasphemed God, but through men's bad lives it is, that there are thousands of blasphemies in all quarters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:212
verses.text: Set him right then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:213
verses.text: For the Gentile will next ask thee, How am I to know that God's commands are feasible? For thou that art of Christian extraction, and hast been brought up in this fine religion, dost not do anything of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:214
verses.text: And what will you tell him? You will be sure to say, I will show you others that do; monks that dwell in the deserts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:215
verses.text: And art thou not ashamed to confess to being a Christian, and yet to send to others, as unable to show that you display the temper of a Christian? For he also will say directly, What need have I to go to the mountains, and to hunt up the deserts? For if there is no possibility for a person who is living in the midst of cities to be a disciple, this is a sad imputation on this rule of conduct, that we are to leave the cities, and run to the deserts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:216
verses.text: But show me a man who has a wife, and children, and family, and yet pursueth wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:217
verses.text: What are we then to say to all this? Must we not hang down our heads, and be ashamed? For Christ gave us no such commandment; but what? "Let your light shine before men" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:218
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:219
verses.text: ), not mountains, and deserts, and wildernesses, and out-of-the-way places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:220
verses.text: And this I say, not as abusing those who have taken up with the mountains, but as bewailing those that dwell in cities, because they have banished virtue from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:221
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you let us introduce the discipline they have there here also, that the cities may become cities indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:222
verses.text: This will improve the Gentile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:223
verses.text: This will free him from countless offences.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:224
verses.text: And so if thou wouldest set him free from scandal, and thyself enjoy rewards without number, set thy own life in order, and make it shine forth upon all sides, "that men may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 27:225
verses.text: For so we also shall enjoy that unutterable and great glory, which God grant that we may all attain to, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:1
verses.text: Homily XXVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:3
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:4
verses.text: –  "Now to Him that is of power to stablish you according to my Gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ according to the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret since the world began, but now is made manifest, and (mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:5
verses.text: τεwhich Sav.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:6
verses.text: omits) by the Scriptures of the Prophets, according to the commandment of the verlasting God, made known to all nations for the obedience of faith: to God only wise, to Him be glory through Jesus Christ our Lord, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:7
verses.text: It is always a custom with Paul to conclude his exhortation with prayers and doxologies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:8
verses.text: For he knows that the thing is one of no slight importance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:9
verses.text: And it is out of affectionateness and caution that he is in the habit of doing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:10
verses.text: For it is the character of a teacher devoted to his children, and to God, not to instruct them in words only, but by prayer too to bring upon his teaching the assistance which is from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:11
verses.text: And this he does here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:12
verses.text: But the connection is as follows: "To Him that is of power to stablish you, be glory for ever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:13
verses.text: For he again clings to those weak brethren, and to them he directs his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:14
verses.text: For when he was rebuking, he made all share his rebuke; but now, when he is praying, it is for these that he wears the attitude of a suppliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:15
verses.text: And after saying, "to stablish," he proceeds to give the mode of it, "according to my Gospel;" and this was what one would do to show that as yet they were not firmly fixed, but stood, though with wavering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:16
verses.text: Then to give a trustworthiness to what he says, he proceeds, "and the preaching of Jesus Christ;" that is, which He Himself preached.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:17
verses.text: But if He preached it, the doctrines are not ours, but the laws are of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:18
verses.text: And afterwards, in discussing the nature of the preaching, He shows that this gift is one of much benefit, and of much honor; and this he first proves from the person of the declarer thereof, and then likewise from the things declared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:19
verses.text: For it was glad tidings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:20
verses.text: Besides, from His not having made aught of them known to any before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:21
verses.text: And this he intimates in the words, "according to the revelation of the mystery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:22
verses.text: And this is a sign of the greatest friendliness, to make us share in the mysteries, and no one before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:23
verses.text: "Which was kept secret since the world began, but now is made manifest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:24
verses.text: For it had been determined long ago, but was only manifested now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:25
verses.text: How was it made manifest? "By the Scriptures of the Prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:26
verses.text: Here again he is releasing the weak person from fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:27
verses.text: For what dost thou fear? is it lest thou depart from the Law? This the Law wishes, this it foretold from of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:28
verses.text: But if thou pryest into the cause of its being made manifest now, thou art doing a thing not safe to do, in being curious about the mysteries of God, and calling Him to account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:29
verses.text: For we ought not with things of this nature to act as busybodies, but to be well pleased and content with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:30
verses.text: Wherefore that he might himself put a check upon a spirit of this sort, he adds, "according to the commandment of the everlasting God, for the obedience of faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:31
verses.text: For faith requires obedience, and not curiosity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:32
verses.text: And when God commands, one ought to be obedient, not curious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:33
verses.text: Then he uses another argument to encourage them, saying "made known to all nations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:34
verses.text: That is, it is not thou alone but the whole world that is of this Creed, as having had not man, but God for a Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:35
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "through Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:36
verses.text: But it was not only made known, but also confirmed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:37
verses.text: Now both are His work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:38
verses.text: And on this ground too the way it is to be read is, "Now to Him that is of power to stablish you through Jesus Christ;" and, as I was saying, he ascribes them both to Him; or rather, not both of these only, but the glory belonging (or ascribed, Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:39
verses.text: τὴν εἰς) to the Father also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:40
verses.text: And this too is why he said, "to Whom be glory forever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:41
verses.text: And he uses a doxology again through awe at the incomprehensibleness of these mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:42
verses.text: For even now they have appeared, there is no such thing as comprehending them by reasonings, but it is by faith we must come to a knowledge of them, for in no other way can we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:43
verses.text: He well says, "To the only wise God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:44
verses.text: For if you will only reflect how He brought the nations in, and blended them with those who in olden time had wrought well, how He saved those who were desperate, how He brought men not worthy of the earth up to heaven, and brought those who had fallen from the present life into that undying and unalterable life, and made those who were trampled down by devils to vie with Angels, and opened Paradise, and put a stop to all the old evils, and this too in a short time and by an easy and compendious way, then wilt thou learn His wisdom;—when thou seest that which neither Angels nor Archangels knew, they of the Gentiles learnt on a sudden through Jesus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:45
verses.text: ( mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:46
verses.text: add "then wilt thou know His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:47
verses.text: ) Right then is it to admire His wisdom, and to give Him glory! But thou keepest dwelling over little things, still sitting under the shadow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:48
verses.text: And this is not much like one that giveth glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:49
verses.text: For he who has no confidence in Him, and no trust in the faith, does not bear testimony to the grandeur of His doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:50
verses.text: But he himself offers glory up in their behalf, in order to bring them also to the same zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:51
verses.text: But when you hear him say, "to the only wise God," think not that this is said in disparagement of the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:52
verses.text: For if all these things whereby His wisdom is made apparent were done (or made, see John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:53
verses.text: ) by Christ, and without Him no single one, it is quite plain that he is equal in wisdom also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:54
verses.text: What then is the reason of his saying "only?" To set Him in contrast with every created being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:55
verses.text: After giving the doxology then, he again goes from prayer to exhortation, directing his discourse against the stronger, and saying as follows:  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:56
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:57
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:58
verses.text: "We then that are strong, ought"—it is "we ought," not "we are so kind as to".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:59
verses.text: What is it we ought to do?—"to bear the infirmities of the weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:60
verses.text: See how he has roused their attention by his praises, not only by calling them powerful, but also by putting them alongside of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:61
verses.text: And not by this only, but by the advantage of the thing he again allures them, and by its not being burdensome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:62
verses.text: For thou, he says, art powerful, and art no whit the worse for condescending.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:63
verses.text: But to him the hazard is of the last consequence, if he is not borne with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:64
verses.text: And he does not say the infirm, but the "infirmities of the weak," so drawing him and bending him to mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:65
verses.text: As in another place too he says, "Ye that are spiritual restore such an one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:66
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:67
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:68
verses.text: ) Art thou become powerful? Render a return to God for making thee so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:69
verses.text: But render it thou wilt if thou settest the weakness of the sickly right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:70
verses.text: For we too were weak, but by grace we have become powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:71
verses.text: And this we are to do not in this case only, but also in the case of those who are weak in other respects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:72
verses.text: As, for instance, if any be passionate, or insolent, or has any such like failing bear with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:73
verses.text: And how is this to be? Listen to what comes next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:74
verses.text: For after saying "we ought to bear," he adds, "and not to please ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:76
verses.text: "Let every one of us please his neighbor for his good to edification".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:77
verses.text: But what he says is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:78
verses.text: Art thou powerful? Let the weak have trial of thy power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:79
verses.text: Let him come to know thy strength; please him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:80
verses.text: And he does not barely say please, but for his good, and not barely for his good, lest the advanced person should say, See I am drawing him to his good! but he adds, "to edification".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:81
verses.text: And so if thou be rich or be in power, please not thyself, but the poor and the needy, because in this way thou wilt at once have true glory to enjoy, and be doing much service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:82
verses.text: For glory from things of the world soon flies away, but that from things of the Spirit is abiding, if thou do it to edification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:83
verses.text: Wherefore of all men he requires this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:84
verses.text: For it is not this and that person that is to do it, but "each of you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:85
verses.text: Then since it was a great thing he had commanded them, and had bidden them even relax their own perfectness in order to set right the other's weakness; he again introduces Christ, in the following words:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:86
verses.text: "For even Christ pleased not Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:87
verses.text: And this he always does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:88
verses.text: For when he was upon the subject of alms, he brought Him forward and said, "Ye know the grace of the Lord, that though He was rich, yet for our sakes he became poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:89
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:90
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:91
verses.text: ) And when he was exhorting to charity, it was from Him that he exhorted in the words "As Christ also loved us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:92
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:93
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:94
verses.text: ) And when he was giving advice about bearing shame and dangers, he took refuge in Him and said, "Who for the joy that was set before Him endured the Cross, despising the shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:95
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:96
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:97
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:98
verses.text: So in this passage too he shows how He also did this, and how the prophet proclaimed it from of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:99
verses.text: Wherefore also he proceeds:  "The reproaches of them that reproached Thee fell upon Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:100
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:101
verses.text: lxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:102
verses.text: ) But what is the import of, "He pleased not Himself?" He had power not to have been reproached, power not to have suffered what He did suffer, had He been minded to look to His own things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:103
verses.text: But yet He was not so minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:104
verses.text: But through looking to our good He neglected His own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:105
verses.text: And why did he not say, "He emptied Himself?" (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:106
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:107
verses.text: ) It is because this was not the only thing he wished to point out, that He became man, but that He was also ill-treated, and obtained a bad reputation with many, being looked upon as weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:108
verses.text: For it says, "If Thou be the Son of God, come down from the Cross".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:109
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:110
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:111
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:112
verses.text: And, "He saved others, Himself He cannot save".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:113
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:114
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:115
verses.text: Hence he mentions a circumstance which was available for his present subject, and proves much more than he undertook to do; for he shows that it was not Christ alone that was reproached, but the Father also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:116
verses.text: "For the reproaches of them that reproached Thee fell," he says, "upon Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:117
verses.text: But what he says is nearly this, What has happened is no new or strange thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:118
verses.text: For they in the Old Testament who came to have a habit of reproaching Him, they also raved against His Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:119
verses.text: But these things were written that we should not imitate them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:120
verses.text: And then he supplies (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:121
verses.text: anoints) them for a patient endurance of temptations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:122
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:123
verses.text: "For whatsoever things were written aforetime," he says, "were written for our learning, that we, through patience and comfort of the Scriptures, might have hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:124
verses.text: That is, that we might not fall away, (for there are sundry conflicts within and without), that being nerved and comforted by the Scriptures, we might exhibit patience, that by living in patience we might abide in hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:125
verses.text: For these things are productive of each other, patience of hope, and hope of patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:126
verses.text: And both of them are brought about by the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:127
verses.text: Then he again brings his discourse into the form of prayer, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:128
verses.text: "Now the God of patience and consolation grant you to be like-minded one towards another, according to Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:129
verses.text: For since he had given his own advice, and had also urged the example of Christ, he added the testimony of the Scriptures also, to show that with the Scripture Himself giveth patience also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:130
verses.text: And this is why he said, "Now the God of patience and consolation grant you to be like-minded one towards another, according to Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:131
verses.text: For this is what love would do, be minded toward another even as toward himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:132
verses.text: Then to show again that it is not mere love that he requires, he adds, "according to Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:133
verses.text: And this he does, in all places, because there is also another sort of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:134
verses.text: And what is the advantage of their agreeing?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:135
verses.text: "That ye may with one mind," he says, "and one mouth, glorify God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:136
verses.text: He does not say merely with one mouth, but bids us do it with one will also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:137
verses.text: See how he has united the whole body into one, and how he concludes his address again with a doxology, whereby he gives the utmost inducement to unanimity and concord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:138
verses.text: Then again from this point he keeps to the same exhortation as before, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:139
verses.text: "Wherefore receive ye one another, as Christ also received us, to the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:140
verses.text: The example again is as before, and the gain unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:141
verses.text: For this is a thing that doth God especial glory, the being closely united.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:142
verses.text: And so if even against thy will (Field "being grieved for His sake," after Savile, but against mss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:143
verses.text: ) and for His sake, thou be at variance with thy brother, consider that by putting an end to thine anger thou art glorifying thy Master, and if not on thy brother's account, for this at all events be reconciled to him: or rather for this first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:144
verses.text: For Christ also insists upon this upon all possible grounds, and when addressing His Father he said, "By this shall all men know that Thou hast sent Me, if they be one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:145
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:146
verses.text: )  Let us obey then, and knit ourselves to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:147
verses.text: For in this place it is not any longer the weak, but all that he is rousing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:148
verses.text: And were a man minded to break with thee, do not thou break also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:149
verses.text: Nor give utterance to that cold saying, "Him I love that loveth me; if my right eye does not love me, I tear it out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:150
verses.text: For these are satanical sayings, and fit for publicans, and the little spirit of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:151
verses.text: But thou that art called to a greater citizenship, and are enrolled in the books of Heaven, art liable to greater laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:152
verses.text: Do not speak in this way, but when he is not minded to love thee, then display the more love, that thou mayest draw him to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:153
verses.text: For he is a member; and when by any force a member is sundered from the body, we do everything to unite it again, and then pay more attention to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:154
verses.text: For the reward is the greater then, when one draws to one a person not minded to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:155
verses.text: For if He bids us invite to supper those that cannot make us any recompense, that what goes for recompense may be the greater, much more ought we to do this in regard to friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:156
verses.text: Now he that is loved and loveth, does pay thee a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:157
verses.text: But he that is loved and loveth not, hath made God a debtor to thee in his own room.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:158
verses.text: And besides, when he loves thee he needs not much pains; but when he loves thee not, then he stands in need of thy assistance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:159
verses.text: Make not then the cause for painstaking a cause for listlessness; and say not, because he is sick, that is the reason I take no care of him (for a sickness indeed the dulling of love is), but do thou warm again that which hath become chilled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:160
verses.text: But suppose he will not be warmed, "what then?" is the reply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:161
verses.text: Continue to do thy own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:162
verses.text: "What if he grow more perverse?" He is but procuring to thee so much greater return, and shows thee so much the greater imitator of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:163
verses.text: For if the loving one another was to be the characteristic of disciples ("For hereby," He says, "shall all men know that ye are My disciples, if ye love one another"), (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:164
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:165
verses.text: ) consider how great an one loving one that hates us must be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:166
verses.text: For thy Master loved those that hated Him, and called them to Him; and the weaker they were, the greater the care He showed them; and He cried and said, "They that are whole need not a physician, but they that are sick".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:167
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:168
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:169
verses.text: ) And He deemed publicans and sinners worthy of the same table with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:170
verses.text: And as great as was the dishonor wherewith the Jewish people treated Him, so great was the honor and concern He showed for them, yea, and much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:171
verses.text: Him do thou also emulate: for this good work is no light one, but one without which not even he that is a martyr can please God much, as Paul says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:172
verses.text: Say not then, I get hated, and that is why I do not love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:173
verses.text: For this is why thou oughtest to love most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:174
verses.text: And besides, it is not in the nature of things for a man who loves to be soon hated, but brute as a person may be, he loves them that love him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:175
verses.text: For this He says the heathens and the publicans do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:176
verses.text: (Matt.
