verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:177
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:178
verses.text: ) But if every one loves those that love him, who is there that would not love those who love while they are hated? Display then this conduct, and cease not to use this word, "Hate me as much as you may, I will not leave off loving thee," and then thou wilt humble his quarrelsomeness, and cast out all coldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:179
verses.text: For this disorder comes either from excessive heat (φλεγμονἥς, inflammation), or from coldness; but both of these is the might of love wont to correct by its warmth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:180
verses.text: Did you never see those who indulge a base love beaten, spit upon, called names, ill-treated in a thousand ways by those fornicatresses? What then? Do the insults break off this love? In no wise: they even kindle it the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:181
verses.text: And yet they who do these things, besides being harlots, are of a disreputable and low grade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:182
verses.text: But they who submit to it, have often illustrious ancestors to count up, and much other nobility to boast of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:183
verses.text: Yet still none of these things break the tie, nor keep them aloof from her whom they love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:184
verses.text: And are we not ashamed then to find what great power the love of the devil (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:185
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:186
verses.text: ) and the demons hath, and not to be able to display as much in the love according to God? Dost thou not perceive that this is a very great weapon against the devil? Do you not see, that that wicked demon stands by, dragging to himself the man thou hatest, and desiring to snatch away the member? And dost thou run by, and give up the prize of the conflict? For thy brother, lying between you, is the prize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:187
verses.text: And if thou get the better, thou receivest a crown; but if thou art listless, thou goest away without a crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:188
verses.text: Cease then to give utterance to that satanical saying, "if my eye hates me, I cannot see it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:189
verses.text: For nothing is more shameful than this saying, and yet the generality lay it down for a sign of a noble spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:190
verses.text: But nothing is more ignoble than all this, nothing more senseless, nothing more foolish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:191
verses.text: Therefore I am indeed quite grieved that the doings of vice are held to be those of virtue, that looking down on men, and despising them, should seem to be honorable and dignified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:192
verses.text: And this is the devil's greatest snare, to invest iniquity with a good repute, whereby it becomes hard to blot out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:193
verses.text: For I have often heard men taking credit to themselves at their not going near those who are averse to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:194
verses.text: And yet thy Master found a glory in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:195
verses.text: How often do not men despise (διέπτυσαν) Him? how often show aversion to Him? Yet He ceaseth not to run unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:196
verses.text: Say not then that "I cannot bear to come near those that hate me," but say, that "I cannot bear to despise (διαπτύσαι) those that despise me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:197
verses.text: This is the language of Christ's disciple, as the other is of the devil's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:198
verses.text: This makes men honorable and glorious, as the other doth shameful and ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:199
verses.text: It is on this ground we feel admiration for Moses, because even when God said, "Let Me alone, that I may destroy them in Mine anger," (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:200
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:201
verses.text: ) he could not bear to despise those who had so often shown aversion to him, but said, "If thou wilt forgive them their trespass, forgive it; else blot out me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:202
verses.text: (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:203
verses.text: ) This was owing to his being a friend of God, and a copyer of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:204
verses.text: And let us not pride ourselves in things for which we ought to hide our faces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:205
verses.text: Nor let us use the language of these lewd fellows, that are the scum of men, I know how to scorn (καταπτύσαι, spit at) thousands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:206
verses.text: But even if another use it, let us laugh him down, and stop his mouth for taking a delight in what he ought to feel ashamed of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:207
verses.text: What say you, pray, do you scorn a man that believes, whom when unbelieving Christ scorned not? Why do I say scorned not? Why He had such love towards him, when he was vile and unsightly, as even to die for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:208
verses.text: He then so loved, and that such a person, and do you now, when he has been made fair and admirable, scorn him; now he is made a member of Christ, and hath been made thy Master's body? Dost thou not consider what thou art uttering, nor perceive what thou art venturing to do? He hath Christ as a Head, and a Table, and a Garment, and Life, and Light, and a Bridegroom, and He is everything to him, and dost thou dare to say, "this fellow I despise?" and not this only, but thousands of others along with him? Stay thee, O man, and cease from thy madness; get to know thy brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:209
verses.text: Learn that these be words of unreasonableness, and frenzy, and say on the contrary, though he despise me ten thousand times, yet will I never stand aloof from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:210
verses.text: In this way thou wilt both gain thy brother, and wilt live to the glory of God, and wilt share the good things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 28:211
verses.text: To which God grant that we may all attain, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:1
verses.text: Homily XXVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:3
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:4
verses.text: "Now I say that Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:5
verses.text: Again, he is speaking of Christ's concern for us, still holding to the same topic, and showing what great things He hath done for us, and how "He pleased not Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:6
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:7
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:8
verses.text: ) And besides this, there is another point which he makes good, that those of the Gentiles are debtors to a larger amount unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:9
verses.text: And if to a larger amount, then they ought to bear with the weak among the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:10
verses.text: For since he had spoken very sharply to such, lest this should make these elated, he humbles their unreasonableness, by showing that it was by "promise made to the fathers" that they had the good things given them, while they of the Gentiles had them out of pity and love toward man only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:11
verses.text: And this is the reason of his saying, "And that the Gentiles might glorify God for his mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:12
verses.text: But that what is said may be made plainer, it is well to listen once more to the words themselves, that you may see what Christ's having been made "a Minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers," means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:13
verses.text: What then is that which is stated? There had been a promise made to Abraham, saying, "Unto thee will I give the earth, and to thy seed, and in thy seed shall all the nations be blessed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:14
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:15
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:16
verses.text: ; xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:17
verses.text: ) But after this, they of the seed of Abraham all became subject to punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:18
verses.text: For the Law wrought wrath unto them by being transgressed, and thenceforward deprived them of that promise made unto the fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:19
verses.text: Therefore the Son came and wrought with the Father, in order that those promises might come true, and have their issue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:20
verses.text: For having fulfilled the whole Law in which He also fulfilled the circumcision, and having by it, and by the Cross, freed them from the curse of the transgression, He suffered not this promise to fall to the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:21
verses.text: When then he calls Him "a Minister of the circumcision," he means this, that by having come and fulfilled the Law, and been circumcised, and born of the seed of Abraham, He undid the curse, stayed the anger of God, made also those that were to receive the promises fit for them, as being once for all freed from their alienation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:22
verses.text: To prevent then these accused persons from saying, How then came Christ to be circumcised and to keep the whole Law? he turns their argument to the opposite conclusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:23
verses.text: For it was not that the Law might continue, but that He might put an end to it, and free thee from the curse thereof, and set thee entirely at liberty from the dominion of that Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:24
verses.text: For it was because thou hadst transgressed the Law, that He fulfilled it, not that thou mightest fulfil it, but that He might confirm to thee the promises made unto the fathers, which the Law had caused to be suspended, by showing thee to have offended, and to be unworthy of the inheritance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:25
verses.text: And so thou also art saved by grace, since thou wast cast off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:26
verses.text: Do not thou then bicker, nor perversely cling to the Law at this unsuitable time, since it would have cast thee also out of the promise, unless Christ had suffered so many things for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:27
verses.text: And He did suffer these, not because thou wast deserving of salvation, but that God might be true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:28
verses.text: And then that this might not puff up him of the Gentiles, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:29
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:30
verses.text: "And that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:31
verses.text: But what he means is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:32
verses.text: Those of the Jews would have had promises, even though they were unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:33
verses.text: But thou hadst not this even, but wast saved from love towards man alone, even if, to put it at the lowest, they too would not have been the better for the promises, unless Christ had come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:34
verses.text: But yet that he might amalgamate (or temper, κεράσῃ) them and not allow them to rise up against the weak, he makes mention of the promises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:35
verses.text: But of these he says that it was by mercy alone that they were saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:36
verses.text: Hence they are the most bound to glorify God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:37
verses.text: And a glory it is to God that they be blended together, be united, praise with one mind, bear the weaker, neglect not the member that is broken off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:38
verses.text: Then he adds testimonies, in which he shows that the man of the Jews ought to blend himself with those of the Gentiles; and so he says, "As it is written, For this cause I will confess to Thee among the Gentiles, O Lord, and will sing unto Thy Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:39
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:40
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:41
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:42
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:43
verses.text: "And, rejoice, ye Gentiles, with His people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:44
verses.text: And, Praise the Lord, all ye Gentiles" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:45
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:46
verses.text: ); "and let all people laud Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:47
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:48
verses.text: cxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:49
verses.text: ) "And, There shall be a root of Jesse, and He that shall rise to reign over the Gentiles, in Him shall the Gentiles trust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:50
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:51
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:52
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:53
verses.text: )  Now all these quotations he has given to show that we ought to be united, and to glorify God; and also, to humble the Jew, that he may not lift himself up over these, since all the prophets called these, as well as to persuade the man of the Gentiles to be lowly, by showing him that he had a larger grace to answer for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:54
verses.text: Then he concludes his argument with a prayer again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:55
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:56
verses.text: "Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:57
verses.text: That is, that ye may get clear of that heartlessness (ἀθυμίας) towards one another, and may never be cast down by temptations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:58
verses.text: And this will be by your abounding in hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:59
verses.text: Now this is the cause of all good things, and it comes from the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:60
verses.text: But it is not simply from the Spirit, but on condition of our contributing our part also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:61
verses.text: This is why he says, "in believing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:62
verses.text: For this is the way for you to be filled with joy, if ye believe, if ye hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:63
verses.text: Yet he does not say if ye hope, but, "if ye abound in hope," so as not to find comfort in troubles only, but even to have joy through the abundance of faith and hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:64
verses.text: And in this way, ye will also draw the Spirit to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:65
verses.text: In this way, when He is come ye will continually keep to all good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:66
verses.text: For just as food maintaineth our life, and by this ruleth the body, so if we have good works, we shall have the Spirit; and if we have the Spirit, we shall also have good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:67
verses.text: As also, on the other hand, if we have no works, the Spirit flieth away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:68
verses.text: But if we be deserted by the Spirit, we shall also halt in our works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:69
verses.text: For when this hath gone, the unclean one cometh: this is plain from Saul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:70
verses.text: For what if he doth not choke us as he did him, still he strangles us in some other way by wicked works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:71
verses.text: We have need then of the harp of David, that we may charm our souls with the divine songs, both these, and those from good actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:72
verses.text: Since if we do the one only, and while we listen to the charm, war with the charmer by our actions, as he did of old ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:73
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:74
verses.text: ); the remedy will even turn to judgment to us, and the madness become the more furious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:75
verses.text: For before we heard, the wicked demon was afraid lest we should hear it and recover.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:76
verses.text: But when after hearing it even, we continue the same as we were, this is the very thing to rid him of his fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:77
verses.text: Let us sing then the Psalm of good deeds, that we may cast out the sin that is worse than the demon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:78
verses.text: For a demon certainly will not deprive us of heaven, but doth in some cases even work with the sober-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:79
verses.text: But sin will assuredly cast us out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:80
verses.text: For this is a demon we willingly receive, a self-chosen madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:81
verses.text: Wherefore also it hath none to pity it or to pardon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:82
verses.text: Let us then sing charms over a soul in this plight, as well from the other Scriptures, as also from the blessed David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:83
verses.text: And let the mouth sing, and the mind be instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:84
verses.text: Even this is no small thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:85
verses.text: For if we once teach the tongue to sing, the soul will be ashamed to be devising the opposite of what this singeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:86
verses.text: Nor is this the only good thing that we shall gain, for we shall also come to know many things which are our interest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:87
verses.text: For he discourseth to thee both of things present, and things to come, and of things seen, and of the invisible Creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:88
verses.text: And if thou wouldest learn about the Heaven, whether it abideth as it is or shall be changed, he gives thee a clear answer, and will say, "The heavens shall wax old as doth a garment, and as a vesture shalt thou fold them up, O God, and they shall be changed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:89
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:90
verses.text: cii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:91
verses.text: ) And if thou wishest to hear of the form of them again, thou shalt hear, "That spreadeth forth the Heaven like a curtain" (δέρριν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:92
verses.text: And if thou be minded to know further about the back of them, he will tell thee again, "that covereth His upper chambers with waters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:93
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:94
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:95
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:96
verses.text: ) And even here he does not pause, but will likewise discourse with thee on the breadth and height, and show thee that these are of equal measure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:97
verses.text: For, "As far as the east," he says, "is from the west, so far hath He set our iniquities from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:98
verses.text: Like as the heaven's height above the earth, so is the Lord's mercy upon them that fear Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:99
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:100
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:101
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:102
verses.text: ) But if thou wouldest busy thyself with the foundation of the earth, even this he will not hide from thee, but thou shalt hear him singing and saying, "He hath founded it upon the seas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:103
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:104
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:105
verses.text: ) And if of earthquakes thou art desirous to know, whence they come, he will free thee from this difficulty also, by saying, "That looketh upon the earth, and maketh it tremble".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:106
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:107
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:108
verses.text: ) And if thou enquire the use of the night, this too mayest thou learn, and know from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:109
verses.text: For "therein all the beasts of the forest do move".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:110
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:111
verses.text: ) And in what way the mountains are for use, he will tell thee, "The high mountains are for the stags".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:112
verses.text: And why there are rocks, "The rocks are a refuge for the porcupines".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:113
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:114
verses.text: ) Why are there trees yielding no fruit? learn from him, for "there the sparrows build their nests".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:115
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:116
verses.text: ) Why are there fountains in the wildernesses? hear, "that by them the fowls of the heaven dwell, and the wild beasts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:117
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:118
verses.text: ) Why is there wine? not that thou mayest drink only (for water is of a nature to suffice for this), but that thou mayest be gladdened also, "For wine maketh glad the heart of man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:119
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:120
verses.text: ) And by knowing this you will know how far the use of wine is allowable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:121
verses.text: Whence are the fowls and the wild beasts nourished? thou wilt hear from his words, "All these wait upon Thee, to give them their meat in due season".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:122
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:123
verses.text: ) If thou sayest, For what purpose are the cattle? he will answer thee, that these also are for thee, "That causeth the grass," he says, "to grow for the cattle, and the green herb for the service (or retinue)of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:124
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:125
verses.text: ) What is the use of the moon? hear him saying, "He made the moon for seasons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:126
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:127
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:128
verses.text: ) And that all things seen and those not seen are made, is a thing that he has also clearly taught us by saying, "Himself spake, and they were made, He commanded, and they were created".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:129
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:130
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:131
verses.text: ) And that there is an end of death, this he also teaches when he says, "God shall deliver my soul from the hand of hell when He shall receive me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:132
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:133
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:134
verses.text: ) Whence was our body made? he also tells us; "He remembereth that we are dust" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:135
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:136
verses.text: ); and again, whither goeth it away? "It shall return to its dust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:137
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:138
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:139
verses.text: ) Why was this universe made? For thee: "For thou crownest him with glory and honor, and settest him over the works of Thy hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:140
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:141
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:142
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:143
verses.text: ) Have we men any community with the Angels? This he also tells us, saying as follows, "Thou hast made him a little lower than the Angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:144
verses.text: Of the love of God, "Like as a father pitieth his own children, even so is the Lord merciful to them that fear Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:145
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:146
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:147
verses.text: ) And of the things that are to meet us after our present life, and of that undisturbed condition, he teacheth, "Return unto thy rest, O my soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:148
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:149
verses.text: cxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:150
verses.text: ) Why the Heaven is so great, this he will also say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:151
verses.text: For it is because "the heavens declare the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:152
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:153
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:154
verses.text: ) Why day and night were made,—not that they may shine and give us rest only, but also that they may instruct us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:155
verses.text: "For there are no speeches nor words, the sounds of which (i-e: day and night) are not heard".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:156
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:157
verses.text: ) How the sea lies round about the earth, this too thou wilt learn from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:158
verses.text: "The deep as a garment is the envelopment thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:159
verses.text: For so the Hebrew has it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:160
verses.text: But having a sample in what I have mentioned, ye will have a notion of all the rest besides, the things about Christ, about the resurrection, about the life to come, about the resting, about punishment, about moral matters, all that concerns doctrines, and you will find the book filled with countless blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:161
verses.text: And if you fall into temptations, you will gain much comfort from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:162
verses.text: If you fall into sins even, you will find countless remedies stored up here, or if into poverty or tribulation, you will see many havens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:163
verses.text: And if thou be righteous thou wilt gain much security hence, and if a sinner much relief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:164
verses.text: For if thou be just and art ill-treated, thou wilt hear him say, "For Thy sake are we killed all the day long, we are counted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:165
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:166
verses.text: xliv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:167
verses.text: ) "All these things have come upon us, and yet have we not forgotten Thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:168
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:169
verses.text: ) And if thy well-doings make thee high, thou wilt hear him say, "Enter not into judgment with Thy servant, for in Thy sight shall no man living be justified" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:170
verses.text: cxliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:171
verses.text: ), and thou wilt be straightway made lowly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:172
verses.text: And if thou be a sinner, and hast despaired of thyself, thou wilt hear him continually singing, "To-day, if ye will hear His voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:173
verses.text: xcv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:174
verses.text: , ), and thou wilt be stayed up speedily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:175
verses.text: And if thou have a crown even on thy head, and art high-minded, thou wilt learn that "a king is not saved by a great host, neither shall a giant be saved by the greatness of his might" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:176
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:177
verses.text: ): and thou wilt find thyself able to be reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:178
verses.text: If thou be rich, and in reputation, again thou wilt hear him singing, "Woe to them that trust in their own might, and boast themselves in the multitude of their riches," (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:179
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:180
verses.text: ) And, "As for man, his days are as grass" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:181
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:182
verses.text: ), And "His glory shall not go down with him, after him" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:183
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:184
verses.text: ): and thou wilt not think any of the things upon the earth are great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:185
verses.text: For when what is more splendid than all, even glory and power, is so worthless, what else of things on earth is worth accounting of? But art thou in despondency? Hear him saying, "Why art thou so sorrowful, O my soul, and why dost thou so disturb me? Trust in God, for I will confess unto Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:186
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:187
verses.text: xlii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:188
verses.text: ) Or dost thou see men in honor who deserve it not? "Fret not thyself at them that do wickedly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:189
verses.text: For as the grass shall they be dried up, and as the green herb shall they soon fall away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:190
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:191
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:192
verses.text: , ) Dost thou see both righteous and sinners punished? be told that the cause is not the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:193
verses.text: For "many" he says, "are the plagues of sinners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:194
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:195
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:196
verses.text: ) But in the case of the righteous, he does not say plagues, but, "Many are the troubles of the righteous, but the Lord delivereth them out of them all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:197
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:198
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:199
verses.text: ) And again, "The death of the sinner is evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:200
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:201
verses.text: ) And, "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:202
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:203
verses.text: cxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:204
verses.text: ) These things do thou say continually: by these be instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:205
verses.text: For every single word of this has in it an indiscoverable ocean of meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:206
verses.text: For we have been just running over them only: but if you were minded to give these passages accurate investigation, you will see the riches to be great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:207
verses.text: But at present it is possible even by what I have given, to get cleared of the passions that lie on you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:208
verses.text: For since he forbids our envying, or being grieved, or despondent out of season, or thinking that riches are anything, or tribulation, or poverty, or fancying life itself to be anything, he frees thee from all passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:209
verses.text: So for this let us give thanks to God, and let us have our treasure always in hand, "that by patience and comfort of the Scriptures we may have hope" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:210
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:211
verses.text: ), and enjoy the good things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:212
verses.text: Which God grant that we may all attain, by the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 29:213
verses.text: By Whom and with Whom, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:1
verses.text: Homily XXIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:3
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:4
verses.text: "And I myself also am persuaded of you, my brethren, that ye also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, able also to admonish one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:5
verses.text: (So most: S.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:6
verses.text: Chrys.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:7
verses.text: "others".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:8
verses.text: )  He had said, "Inasmuch as I am the Apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:9
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:10
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:11
verses.text: ) He had said, "Take heed lest He also spare not thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:12
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:13
verses.text: ) He had said, "Be not wise in your own conceits" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:14
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:15
verses.text: ); and again, "Why dost thou judge thy brother?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:16
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:17
verses.text: ) And, "Who art thou that judgest another man's servant?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:18
verses.text: ) And several other like things besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:19
verses.text: Since then he had often made his language somewhat harsh, he now speaks kindly (θεραπεύει).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:20
verses.text: And what he said in the beginning, that he doth in the end also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:21
verses.text: At the beginning he said, "I thank my God for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:22
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:23
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:24
verses.text: ) But here he says, "I am persuaded that ye also are full of goodness, being able also to admonish others;" and this is more than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:25
verses.text: And he does not say, I have heard, but, "I am persuaded," and have no need to hear, from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:26
verses.text: And, "I myself," that is, I that rebuke, that accuse you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:27
verses.text: That "ye are full of goodness," this applies to the exhortation lately given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:28
verses.text: As if he said, It was not as if you were cruel, or haters of your brethren, that I gave you that exhortation, to receive, and not to neglect, and not to destroy "the work of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:29
verses.text: For I am aware that "ye are full of goodness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:30
verses.text: But he seems to me here to be calling their virtue perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:31
verses.text: And he does not say ye have, but "ye are full of".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:32
verses.text: And the sequel is with the same intensitives: "filled with all knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:33
verses.text: For suppose they had been affectionate, but yet did not know how to treat those they loved properly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:34
verses.text: This was why he added, "all knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:35
verses.text: Able to admonish others," not to learn only, but also to teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:36
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:37
verses.text: "Nevertheless, I have written the more boldly unto you in some sort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:38
verses.text: Observe the lowly-mindedness of Paul, observe his wisdom, how he gave a deep cut in the former part, and then when he had succeeded in what he wished, how he uses much kindliness next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:39
verses.text: For even without what he has said, this very confession of his having been bold were enough to unstring their vehemency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:40
verses.text: And this he does in writing to the Hebrews also, speaking as follows, "But, beloved, I am persuaded better things of you, and things which belong unto salvation, though we thus speak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:41
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:42
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:43
verses.text: ) And to the Corinthians again, "Now I praise you, brethren, that ye remember me in all things, and keep the ordinances, as I delivered them to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:44
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:45
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:46
verses.text: ) And in writing to the Galatians he says, "I have confidence in you, that ye will be none otherwise minded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:47
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:48
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:49
verses.text: ) And in all parts of his Epistles one may find this to be frequently observed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:50
verses.text: But here even in a greater degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:51
verses.text: For they were in a higher rank, and there was need to bring down their fastidious spirit, not by astringents only, but by laxatives also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:52
verses.text: For he does this in different ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:53
verses.text: Wherefore he says in this place too, "I have written the more boldly unto you," and with this even he is not satisfied, but has added, "in some sort," that is, gently; and even here he does not pause, but what does he say? "As putting you in mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:54
verses.text: And he does not say as teaching, nor simply putting in mind, (ἀναμιμνήσκων) but he uses a word (ἐπαναμιμνήσκων) which means putting you in mind in a quiet way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:55
verses.text: Observe the end falling in with the introduction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:56
verses.text: For as in that passage he said, "that your faith is made known in all the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:57
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:58
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:59
verses.text: ) So in the end of the Epistle also, "For your obedience hath reached unto all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:60
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:61
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:62
verses.text: ) And as in the beginning he wrote, "For I long to see you, that I may impart unto you some spiritual gift, to the end that ye may be established; that is, that I may be comforted together with you" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:63
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:64
verses.text: , ); so here also he said, "As putting you in mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:65
verses.text: And having come down from the seat of the master, both there and here, he speaks to them as brethren and friends of equal rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:66
verses.text: And this is quite a Teacher's duty, to give his address that variety which is profitable to the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:67
verses.text: See then how after saying, "I have written the more boldly," and, "in some sort," and, "as putting you in mind," he was not satisfied even with these, but making his language still more lowly, he proceeds:  "Because of the grace that is given me of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:68
verses.text: As he said at the beginning, "I am a debtor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:69
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:70
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:71
verses.text: ) As if he had said, I have not snatched at the honor for myself, neither was I first to leap forward to it, but God commanded this, and this too according unto grace, not as if He had separated me for this office because I deserved it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:72
verses.text: Do not ye then be exasperated, since it is not I that raise myself up, but it is God that enjoins it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:73
verses.text: And as he there says, "whom I serve in the Gospel of His Son" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:74
verses.text: ), so also here, after saying, "because of the grace given unto me by God," he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:75
verses.text: "That I should be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, ministering (ἱερουργοὕντα) the Gospel of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:76
verses.text: For after his abundant proof of his statements, he draws his discourse to a more lofty tone, not speaking of mere service, as in the beginning, but of service and priestly ministering (λειτουργίαν καί ὶερουργίαν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:77
verses.text: For to me this is a priesthood, this preaching and declaring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:78
verses.text: This is the sacrifice I bring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:79
verses.text: Now no one will find fault with a priest, for being anxious to offer the sacrifice without blemish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:80
verses.text: And he says this at once to elevate (πτερὥν) their thoughts, and show them that they are a sacrifice, and in apology for his own part in the matter, because he was appointed to this office.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:81
verses.text: For my knife, he says, is the Gospel, the word of the preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:82
verses.text: And the cause is not that I may be glorified, not that I may appear conspicuous, but that the "offering up (προσφορὰ) of the Gentiles may be acceptable, being sanctified by the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:83
verses.text: That is, that the souls of those that are taught by me, may be accepted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:84
verses.text: For it was not so much to honor me, that God led me to this pitch, as out of a concern for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:85
verses.text: And how are they to become acceptable? In the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:86
verses.text: For there is need not only of faith, but also of a spiritual way of life, that we may keep the Spirit that was given once for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:87
verses.text: For it is not wood and fire, nor altar and knife, but the Spirit that is all in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:88
verses.text: For this cause, I take all means to prevent that Fire from being extinguished, as I have been also enjoined to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:89
verses.text: Why then do you speak to those that need it not? This is just the reason why I do not teach you, but put you in mind, he replies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:90
verses.text: As the priest stands by stirring up the fire, so I do, rousing up your ready-mindedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:91
verses.text: And observe, he does not say, "that the offering up of" you "may be" etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:92
verses.text: but "of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:93
verses.text: But when he says of the Gentiles, he means the whole world, the land, and the whole sea, to take down their haughtiness, that they might not disdain to have him for a teacher, who was putting himself forth (τεινόμενον) to the very end of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:94
verses.text: As he said in the beginning, "as among the other Gentiles also, I am a debtor to Greeks, and also to barbarians, to wise, and to foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:95
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:96
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:97
verses.text: , , see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:98
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:99
verses.text: "I have therefore whereof I may glory, through Jesus Christ, in those things which pertain to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:100
verses.text: Inasmuch as he had humbled himself exceedingly, he again raised his style, doing this also for their sakes, lest he should seem to become readily an object of contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:101
verses.text: And while he raises himself, he remembers his own proper temper, and says, "I have therefore whereof to glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:102
verses.text: I glory, he means, not in myself, not in our zeal, but in the "grace of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:103
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:104
verses.text: "For I will not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ hath not wrought by me, to make Gentiles obedient by word and deed, through mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:105
verses.text: And none, he means, can say that my words are a mere boast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:106
verses.text: For of this priestly ministry of mine, the signs that I have, and the proofs of the appointment too, are many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:107
verses.text: Not the long garment (ποδήρης) and the bells as they of old, nor the mitre and the turban (κίδαρις), but signs and wonders, far more awful than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:108
verses.text: Nor can it be said that I have been entrusted indeed with the charge, but yet have not executed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:109
verses.text: Or rather, it is not I that have executed, but Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:110
verses.text: Wherefore also it is in Him that I boast, not about common things, but about spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:111
verses.text: And this is the force of, "in things which pertain to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:112
verses.text: For that I have accomplished the purpose for which I was sent, and that my words are not mere boast, the miracles, and the obedience of the Gentiles show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:113
verses.text: "For I will not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ hath not wrought by me, to make the Gentiles obedient by word and deed, through signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:114
verses.text: See how violently he tries to show that the whole is God's doing, and nothing his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:115
verses.text: For whether I speak anything, or do anything, or work miracles, He doth all of them, the Holy Spirit all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:116
verses.text: And this he says to show the dignity of the Holy Spirit also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:117
verses.text: See how these things are more wondrous and more awful than those of old, the sacrifice, the offering, the symbols.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:118
verses.text: For when he says, "in word and deed, through mighty signs and wonders," he means this, the doctrine, the system (φιλοσοφίαν) relating to the Kingdom, the exhibition of actions and conversation, the dead that were raised, the devils that were cast out, and the blind that were healed, and the lame that leaped, and the other marvellous acts, all whereof the Holy Spirit wrought in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:119
verses.text: Then the proof of these things (since all this is yet but an assertion) is the multitude of the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:120
verses.text: Wherefore he adds, "So that from Jerusalem, and round about unto Illyricum, I have fully preached the Gospel of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:121
verses.text: Count up then cities, and places, and nations, and peoples, not those under the Romans only, but those also under barbarians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:122
verses.text: For I would not have you go the whole way through Phoenicia, and Syria, and the Cilicians, and Cappadocians, but reckon up also the parts behind, the country of the Saracens, and Persians, and Armenians, and that of the other savage nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:123
verses.text: For this is why he said, "round about," that you might not only go through the direct high road, but that you should run over the whole, even the southern part of Asia in your mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:124
verses.text: And as he ran over miracles thick as snow, in a single word, by saying, "through mighty signs and wonders," so he has comprehended again endless cities, and nations, and peoples, and places, in this one word "round about".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:125
verses.text: For he was far removed from all boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:126
verses.text: And this, he said on their account, so that they should not be conceited about themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:127
verses.text: And at the beginning he said, that "I might have some fruit amongst you also, even as among other Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:128
verses.text: But here he states the compulsion of his priesthood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:129
verses.text: For as he had spoken in a sharper tone, he shows also by it his power more clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:130
verses.text: This is why he there only says, "even as among other Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:131
verses.text: But here he insists on the topic fully, so that the conceit may be pruned away on all grounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:132
verses.text: And he does not merely say, preached the Gospel, but "have fully preached the Gospel of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:133
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:134
verses.text: "Yea, so have I strived to preach the Gospel, not where Christ was named".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:135
verses.text: See here another preeminence; that he had not only preached the Gospel to so many, and persuaded them, but he did not even go to those who had become disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:136
verses.text: So far was he from thrusting himself upon other men's disciples, and from doing this for glory's sake, that he even made it a point to teach those who had not heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:137
verses.text: For neither does he say where they were not persuaded, but "where Christ was not even named," which is more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:138
verses.text: And what was the reason why he had this ambition? "Lest I should build," he says, "upon another man's foundation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:139
verses.text: This he says to show himself a stranger to vanity, and to instruct them that it was not from any love of glory, or of honor from them, that he came to write, but as fulfilling his ministry, as perfecting his priestly duty, as loving their salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:140
verses.text: But he calls the foundation of the Apostles "another man's," not in regard to the quality of the person, or the nature of preaching, but in regard to the question of reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:141
verses.text: For it was not that the preaching was that of another man, but so far as it went to another man's reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:142
verses.text: For the reward of the labors of others was, to this man, another man's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:143
verses.text: Then he shows that a prophecy was fulfilled also saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:144
verses.text: "As it is written, To whom He was not spoken of, they shall see, and they that have not heard shall understand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:145
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:146
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:147
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:148
verses.text: )  You see he runs to where the labor is more, the toil greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:149
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:150
verses.text: "For which cause also I have been much hindered from coming to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:151
verses.text: Observe again, how he makes the end of the like texture with the introduction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:152
verses.text: For while he was quite at the beginning of the Epistle, he said, "Oftentimes I purpose to come unto you, but was let hitherto".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:153
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:154
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:155
verses.text: ) But here he gives the cause also by which he was let, and that not once, but twice even, aye, and many times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:156
verses.text: For as he says there, "oftentimes I purposed to come to you," so here too, "I have been much (or often, τὰ πολλὰ) hindered from coming to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:157
verses.text: Now it is a thing which proves a very strong desire, that he attempted it so often.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:158
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:159
verses.text: "But now having no more place in these parts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:160
verses.text: See how he shows that it was not from any coveting of glory from them, that he both wrote and was also coming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:161
verses.text: "And having a great desire to come to you these many years,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:162
verses.text: "Whensoever I take my journey into Spain, I trust to see you in my journey; and to be brought on my way thitherward by you, if first I be somewhat filled with your company,"  For that he might not seem to be holding them very cheap, by saying, Since I have not anything to do, therefore I am coming to you, he again touches on the point of love by saying, "I have a great desire, these many years, to come unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:163
verses.text: For the reason why I desire to come, is not because I am disengaged, but that I may give birth to that desire wherewith I am travailing so long.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:164
verses.text: Then that this again should not puff them up, consider how he lowers them by saying, "Whensoever I take my journey into Spain, I trust to see you in my journey".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:165
verses.text: For this was why he stated this, that they should not be high-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:166
verses.text: For what he wants is to show his love, and at the same time to prevent them from being dainty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:167
verses.text: And so he places this close on the other, and uses things confirmative of either alternately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:168
verses.text: For this reason again that they might not say, Do you make us a by-object of your journey? he adds, "and to be brought on my way thitherward by you: that is, that you may be my witnesses that it is not through any slight of you, but by force of necessity, that I run by you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:169
verses.text: But as this is still distressing, he heals it over more carefully, by saying, "If I be first somewhat filled with your company".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:170
verses.text: For by his saying, "in my journey," he shows that he did not covet their good opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:171
verses.text: But by saying "be filled," that he was eager for their love, and not only was eager for it, but exceedingly so; and this is why he does not say "be filled," but be "somewhat" so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:172
verses.text: That is, no length of time can fill me or create in me a satiety of your company.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:173
verses.text: See how he shows his love, when even though in haste he doth not rise up until he be filled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:174
verses.text: And this is a sign of his great affectionateness, that he uses his words in so warm a way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:175
verses.text: For he does not say even I will see, but "shall be filled," imitating thus the language of parents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:176
verses.text: And at the beginning he said, "that I might have some fruit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:177
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:178
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:179
verses.text: ) But here that I may be "filled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:180
verses.text: And both these are like a person who is drawing others to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:181
verses.text: For the one was a very great commendation of them, if they were likely to yield him fruit from their obedience; and the other, a genuine proof of his own friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:182
verses.text: And in writing to the Corinthians he thus says, "That ye may bring me on my journey whithersoever I go" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:183
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:184
verses.text: ), so in all ways exhibiting an unrivalled love to his disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:185
verses.text: And so at the beginning of all his Epistles it is with this he starts, and at the end in this he concludes again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:186
verses.text: For as an indulgent father doth an only and true born son, so did he love all the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:187
verses.text: Whence it was that he said, "Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is offended, and I burn not?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:188
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:189
verses.text: )  For before everything else this is what the teacher ought to have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:190
verses.text: Wherefore also to Peter Christ saith, "If thou lovest Me, feed My sheep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:191
verses.text: (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:192
verses.text: ) For he who loveth Christ loveth also His flock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:193
verses.text: And Moses too did He then set over the people of the Jews, when he had shown a kindly feeling towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:194
verses.text: And David in this way came to be king, having been first seen to be affectionately-minded towards them; so much indeed, though yet young, did he grieve for the people, as to risk his life for them, when he killed that barbarian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:195
verses.text: But if he said, "What shall be done to the man that killeth this Philistine?" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:196
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:197
verses.text: ; ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:198
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:199
verses.text: ) he said it not in order to demand a reward, but out of a wish to have confidence placed in himself, and to have the battle with him delivered to his charge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:200
verses.text: And therefore, when he came to the king after the victory, he said nothing of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:201
verses.text: And Samuel too was very affectionate; whence it was that he said, "But God forbid that I should sin in ceasing to pray unto the Lord for you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:202
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:203
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:204
verses.text: ) In like way Paul also, or rather not in like way, but even in a far greater degree, burned towards all his subjects (τὥν ἀρχομένων).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:205
verses.text: Wherefore he made his disciples of such affection towards himself, that he said, "If were possible, ye would have pulled out your eyes and given them to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:206
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:207
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:208
verses.text: ) On this ground too it is, that God charges the teachers of the Jews above all things with this, saying, "Oh shepherds of Israel, do shepherds feed themselves? do they not feed the flock?" (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:209
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:210
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:211
verses.text: ) But they did the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:212
verses.text: For he says, "Ye eat the milk, and clothe you with the wool, and ye kill them that are fed, but ye feed not the flock".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:213
verses.text: And Christ, in bringing out the rule for the fittest Pastor, said, "The good shepherd layeth down his life for his sheep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:214
verses.text: (John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:215
verses.text: ) This David did also, both on sundry other occasions, and also when that fearful wrath from above came down upon the whole people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:216
verses.text: For while all were being slain he said, "I the shepherd have sinned, I the shepherd have done amiss, and these the flock what have they done?" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:217
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:218
verses.text: ) And so in the choice of those punishments also, he chose not famine, nor flight before enemies, but the pestilence sent by God, whereby he hoped to place all the others in safety, but that he should himself in preference to all the rest be carried off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:219
verses.text: But since this was not so, he bewails, and says, "On me be Thy Hand:" or if this be not enough, "on my father's house" also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:220
verses.text: "For I," he says, "the shepherd have sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:221
verses.text: As though he had said, that if they also sinned, I was the person who should suffer the vengeance, as I corrected them not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:222
verses.text: But since the sin is mine also, it is I who deserve to suffer the vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:223
verses.text: For wishing to increase the crime he used the name of "Shepherd".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:224
verses.text: Thus then he stayed the wrath, thus he got the sentence revoked! So great is the power of confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:225
verses.text: "For the righteous is his own accuser first".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:226
verses.text: So great is the concern and sympathy of a good Pastor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:227
verses.text: For his bowels were writhed at their falling, as when one's own children are killed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:228
verses.text: And on this ground he begged that the wrath might come upon himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:229
verses.text: And in the beginning of the slaughter he would have done this, unless he had seen it advancing and expected that it would come to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:230
verses.text: When therefore he saw that this did not happen, but that the calamity was raging among them, he no longer forebore, but was touched more than for Amnon his first-born.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:231
verses.text: For then he did not ask for death, but now he begs to fall in preference to the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:232
verses.text: Such ought a ruler to be and to grieve rather at the calamities of others than his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:233
verses.text: Some such thing he suffered in his son's case likewise, that you might see that he did not love his son more than his subjects, and yet the youth was unchaste, and an ill-user of his father (πατραλοίας), and still he said, "Would that I might have died for thee!" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:234
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:235
verses.text: ) What sayest thou, thou blessed one, thou meekest of all men? Thy son was set upon killing thee, and compassed thee about with ills unnumbered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:236
verses.text: And when he had been removed, and the trophy was raised, dost thou then pray to be slain? Yea, he says, for it is not for me that the army has been victorious, but I am warred against more violently than before, and my bowels are now more torn than before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:237
verses.text: These however were all thoughtful for those committed to their charge, but the blessed Abraham concerned himself much even for those that were not entrusted to him, and so much so as even to throw himself amongst alarming dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:238
verses.text: For when he did what he did, not for his nephew only, but for the people of Sodom also, he did not leave driving those Persians before him until he had set them all free: and yet he might have departed after he had taken him, yet he did not choose it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:239
verses.text: For he had the like concern for all, and this he showed likewise by his subsequent conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:240
verses.text: When then it was not a host of barbarians that was on the point of laying siege to them, but the wrath of God that was plucking their cities up from the foundations, and it was no longer the time for arms, and battle, and array, but for supplication; so great was the zeal he showed for them, as, if he himself had been on the point of perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:241
verses.text: For this reason he comes once, twice, thrice, aye and many times to God, and finds a refuge (i-e: an excuse) in his nature by saying, "I am dust and ashes" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:242
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:243
verses.text: ): and since he saw that they were traitors to themselves, he begs that they may be saved for others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:244
verses.text: Wherefore also God said, "I will hide not from Abraham My servant that thing which I am about to do" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:245
verses.text: ), that we might learn how loving to man the righteous is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:246
verses.text: And he would not have left off beseeching, unless God had left off first (so he takes v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:247
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:248
verses.text: And he seems indeed to be praying for the just, but is doing the whole for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:249
verses.text: For the souls of the Saints are very gentle and, loving unto man, both in regard to their own, and to strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:250
verses.text: And even to the unreasoning creatures they extend their gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:251
verses.text: Wherefore also a certain wise man said, "The righteous pitieth the souls of his cattle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:252
verses.text: But if he doth those of cattle, how much more those of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:253
verses.text: But since I have mentioned cattle, let us just consider the shepherds of the sheep who are in the Cappadocian land, and what they suffer in kind and degree in their guardianship of unreasoning creatures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:254
verses.text: They often stay for three days together buried down under the snows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:255
