verses.text: And those in Libya are said to undergo no less hardships than these, ranging about for whole months through that wilderness, dreary as it is, and filled with the direst wild beasts (θηρία may include serpents).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:256
verses.text: Now if for unreasonable things there be so much zeal, what defense are we to set up, who are entrusted with reasonable souls, and yet slumber on in this deep sleep? For is it right to be at rest, and in quiet, and not to be running about everywhere, and giving one's self up to endless deaths in behalf of these sheep? Or know ye not the dignity of this flock? Was it not for this that thy Master took endless pains, and afterwards poured forth His blood? And dost thou seek for rest? Now what can be worse than these Shepherds? Dost thou not perceive, that there stand round about these sheep wolves much more fierce and savage than those of this world? Dost thou not think with thyself, what a soul he ought to have who is to take in hand this office? Now men that lead the populace, if they have but common matters to deliberate on, add days to nights in watching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:257
verses.text: And we that are struggling in heaven's behalf sleep even in the daytime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:258
verses.text: And who is now to deliver us from the punishment for these things? For if the body were to be cut in pieces, if to undergo ten thousand deaths, ought one not to run to it as to a feast? And let not the shepherds only, but the sheep also hear this; that they may make the shepherds the more active minded, that they may the more encourage their good-will: I do not mean by anything else but by yielding all compliance and obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:259
verses.text: Thus Paul also bade them, saying, "Obey them which have the rule over you, and submit yourselves: for they watch for your souls as they that must give account".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:260
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:261
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:262
verses.text: ) And when he says, "watch," he means thousands of labors, cares and dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:263
verses.text: For the good Shepherd, who is such as Christ wisheth for, is contending, before countless witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:264
verses.text: For He died once for him; but this man ten thousand times for the flock, if, that is, he be such a shepherd as he ought to be; for such an one can die every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:265
verses.text: (See on Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:266
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:267
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:268
verses.text: ) And therefore do ye, as being acquainted with what the labor is, coöperate with them, with prayers, with zeal, with readiness, with affection, that both we may have to boast of you, and you of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:269
verses.text: For on this ground He entrusted this to the chief of the Apostles, who also loved Him more than the rest; after first asking him if He was loved by him, that thou mayest learn that this before other things, is held as a proof of love to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:270
verses.text: For this requireth a vigorous soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:271
verses.text: This I have said of the best shepherds; not of myself and those of our days, but of any one that may be such as Paul was, such as Peter, such as Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:272
verses.text: These then let us imitate, both the rulers of us and the ruled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:273
verses.text: For the ruled may be in the place of a shepherd to his family, to his friends, to his servants, to his wife, to his children: and if we so order our affairs we shall attain to all manner of good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 30:274
verses.text: Which God grant that we may all attain unto, by the grace and love toward man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:1
verses.text: Homily XXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:3
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:4
verses.text: –  "But now I go unto Jerusalem to minister unto the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:5
verses.text: For it has pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the poor saints which are at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:6
verses.text: It hath pleased them verily, and their debtors they are".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:7
verses.text: Since he had said that I have no longer "more place in these parts," and, "I have a great desire, these many years, to come unto you," but he still intended to delay; lest it should be thought that he was making a jest of them, he mentions the cause also why he still puts it off, and he says, that "I am going unto Jerusalem," and is apparently giving the excuse for the delay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:8
verses.text: But by means of this he also makes good another object, which is the exhorting of them to alms, and making them more in earnest about it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:9
verses.text: Since if he had not been minded to effect this, it had sufficed to say, "I am going unto Jerusalem".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:10
verses.text: But now he adds the reason of his journey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:11
verses.text: "For I go," says he, "to minister to the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:12
verses.text: And he dwells over the subject, and enters into reasonings, and says that they "are debtors," and that, "if the Gentiles have been made partakers of their spiritual things, their duty is also to minister unto them in carnal things," that they might learn to imitate these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:13
verses.text: Wherefore also there is much reason to admire his wisdom for devising this way of giving the advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:14
verses.text: For they were more likely to bear it in this way than if he had said it in the form of exhortation; as then he would have seemed to be insulting them, if, with a view to incite them, he had brought before them Corinthians and Macedonians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:15
verses.text: Indeed, this is the ground on which he does incite the others as follows, saying, "Moreover, brethren, we do you to wit of the grace of God bestowed on the Churches in Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:16
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:17
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:18
verses.text: ) And again he incites the Macedonians by these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:19
verses.text: "For your zeal," he says, "hath provoked very many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:20
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:21
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:22
verses.text: ) And by the Galatians in like manner he does this, as when he says, "As I have given order to the Churches of Galatia, even so do ye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:23
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:24
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:25
verses.text: ) But in the case of the Romans he does not do so, but in a more covert way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:26
verses.text: And he does this also in regard to the preaching, as when he says, "What? came the word of God out from you? or came it unto you only?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:27
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:28
verses.text: ) For there is nothing so powerful as emulation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:29
verses.text: And so he often employs it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:30
verses.text: For elsewhere too he says," "And so ordain I in all the Churches;" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:31
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:32
verses.text: ); and again, "As I teach everywhere in every Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:33
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:34
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:35
verses.text: ) And to the Colossians he says, "that the Gospel increaseth and bringeth forth fruit in all the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:36
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:37
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:38
verses.text: ) This then he does here also in the case of alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:39
verses.text: And consider what dignity there is in his expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:40
verses.text: For he does not say, I go to carry alms, but "to minister" (διακονὥν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:41
verses.text: But if Paul ministers, just consider how great a thing is doing, when the Teacher of the world undertakes to be the bearer, and when on the point of travelling to Rome, and so greatly desiring them too, he yet prefers this to that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:42
verses.text: "For it hath pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia," that is, it meets their approbation, their desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:43
verses.text: "A certain contribution".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:44
verses.text: And, he does not say alms, but "contribution" (κοινωνίαν).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:45
verses.text: And the "certain" is not used without a meaning, but to prevent his seeming to reproach these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:46
verses.text: And he does not say the poor, merely, but the "poor saints," so making his recommendation twofold, both that from their virtue and that from their poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:47
verses.text: And even with this alone he was not satisfied, but he adds, "they are their debtors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:48
verses.text: Then he shows how they are debtors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:49
verses.text: For if, he says, "the Gentiles have been made partakers of their spiritual things, their debt (A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:50
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:51
verses.text: duty) is also to minister unto them in carnal things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:52
verses.text: But what he means is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:53
verses.text: It was for their sakes that Christ came.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:54
verses.text: To them it was that all the promises were made, to them of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:55
verses.text: Of them Christ came.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:56
verses.text: (Wherefore also it said, "Salvation is of the Jews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:57
verses.text: ) (John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:58
verses.text: ) From them were the Apostles, from them the Prophets, from them all good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:59
verses.text: In all these things then the world was made a partaker.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:60
verses.text: If then, he says, ye have been made partakers in that which is greater, and when it was for them that the banquet was prepared, ye have been brought in to enjoy the feast that was spread (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:61
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:62
verses.text: ), according to the Parable of the Gospel, ye are debtors also to share your carnal things with them, and to impart to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:63
verses.text: But he does not say to share, but "to minister" (λειτουργἥσαι), so ranking them with ministers (διακόνων), and those that pay the tribute to kings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:64
verses.text: And he does not say in your carnal things, as he did in "their spiritual things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:65
verses.text: For the spiritual things were theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:66
verses.text: But the carnal belonged not to these alone, but were the common property of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:67
verses.text: For he bade money to be held to belong to all, not to those who were its possessors only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:68
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:69
verses.text: "When therefore I have performed this, and have sealed unto them this fruit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:70
verses.text: That is, when I have laid it up as it were in the royal treasuries, as in a place secure from robbers and danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:71
verses.text: And he does not say alms, but "fruit" again, to show that those who gave it were gainers by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:72
verses.text: "I will come by you into Spain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:73
verses.text: He again mentions Spain to show his forwardness (ἀόκνον) and warmth towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:75
verses.text: "And I am sure that, when I come unto you, I shall come in the fulness of the blessing of the Gospel of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:76
verses.text: What is the force of, "In the fulness of the blessing?" Either he speaks of alms (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:77
verses.text: money), or generally of good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:78
verses.text: For blessing is a name he very commonly gives to alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:79
verses.text: As when he says, "As a blessing and not as covetousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:80
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:81
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:82
verses.text: ) And it was customary of old for the thing to be so called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:83
verses.text: But as he has here added "of the Gospel," on this ground we assert that he speaks not of money only, but of all other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:84
verses.text: As if he had said, I know that when I come I shall find you with the honor and freshness of all good deeds about you, and worthy of countless praises in the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:85
verses.text: And this is a very striking mode of advice, I mean this way of forestalling their attention by encomiums.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:86
verses.text: For when he entreats them in the way of advice, this is the mode of setting them right that he adopts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:87
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:88
verses.text: "Now I beseech you, brethren, for the Lord Jesus Christ's sake, and for the love of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:89
verses.text: Here he again puts forward Christ and the Spirit, and makes no mention whatever of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:90
verses.text: And I say this, that when you find him mentioning the Father and the Son, or the Father only, you may not despise either the Son or the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:91
verses.text: And he does not say the Spirit, but "the love of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:92
verses.text: For as Christ loved the world, and as the Father doth, so doth the Spirit also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:93
verses.text: And what is it that thou beseechest us, let me hear? "To strive together with me in your prayers to God for me,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:94
verses.text: "That I may be delivered from them that do not believe in Judea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:95
verses.text: A great struggle then lies before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:96
verses.text: And this too is why he calls for their prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:97
verses.text: And he does not say that I may be engaged in it, but "I may be delivered," as Christ commanded, to "pray that we enter not into temptation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:98
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:99
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:100
verses.text: ) And in saying this he showed, that certain evil wolves would attack them, and those who were wild beasts rather than men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:101
verses.text: And out of this he also found grounds for another thing, namely, for showing that he with good reason took the office of ministering to the Saints, if, that is, the unbelievers were in such force that he even prayed to be delivered from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:102
verses.text: For they who were amongst so many enemies, were in danger of perishing by famine also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:103
verses.text: And therefore there was absolute need of aid coming (or "of his going") from other quarters to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:104
verses.text: "And that my service which I have for Jerusalem may be accepted of the Saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:105
verses.text: That is, that my sacrifice may be accepted, that with cheerfulness they may receive what is given them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:106
verses.text: See how he again exalts the dignity of those who were to receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:107
verses.text: Then he asks for the prayer of so great a people in order to what was sent being received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:108
verses.text: And by this he shows another point also, that to have given alms does not secure its being accepted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:109
verses.text: For when any one gives it constrainedly, or out of unjust gains, or for vanity, the fruit of it is gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:110
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:111
verses.text: "That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:112
verses.text: As he had said at the beginning, "If by any means now at length I might have a prosperous journey, by the will of God, to come unto you" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:113
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:114
verses.text: ); so here again he takes refuge in the same Will, and says that this is why I press on and wish to be delivered from them, that I may see you shortly, and that with pleasure, without bringing any load of heaviness from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:115
verses.text: "And may with you be refreshed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:116
verses.text: See how he again shows unassumingness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:117
verses.text: For he does not say, I may teach you, and give you a lesson, but that, "I may with you be refreshed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:118
verses.text: And yet he was the very man engaged in the striving and conflict.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:119
verses.text: In what sense then does he say "that I may be refreshed with you (συναναπαύσωμαι)?" It is to gratify them on this point too, and to make them the more cheerful by making them sharers of his crown, and to show that they too struggle and labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:120
verses.text: Then, as was always his custom to do, he adds prayer after the exhortation, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:121
verses.text: "Now the God of peace be with you all, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:122
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:123
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:124
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:125
verses.text: "I commend unto you Phebe our sister, which is a deaconess (A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:126
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:127
verses.text: servant) of the church which is at Cenchrea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:128
verses.text: See how many ways he takes to give her dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:129
verses.text: For he has both mentioned her before all the rest, and called her sister.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:130
verses.text: And it is no slight thing to be called the sister of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:131
verses.text: Moreover he has added her rank, by mentioning her being "deaconess".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:132
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:133
verses.text: "That ye receive her in the Lord, as becometh saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:134
verses.text: (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:135
verses.text: "the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:136
verses.text: )  That is, for the Lord's sake, that she may enjoy honor among you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:137
verses.text: For he that receives a person for the Lord's sake, though it be no great one that he receives, yet receives him with attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:138
verses.text: But when it is a saint, consider what attention he ought to have shown him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:139
verses.text: And this is why he adds, "as becometh saints," as such persons ought to be received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:140
verses.text: For she has two grounds for her having attention shown her by you, both that of her being received for the Lord's sake, and that of her being a saint herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:141
verses.text: And "that ye assist her in whatsoever business she hath need (or "asks," χρήζῃ) of you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:142
verses.text: You see how little he burdens them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:143
verses.text: For he does not say, That ye despatch, but that ye contribute your own part, and reach out a hand to her: and that "in whatsoever business she hath need".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:144
verses.text: Not in whatsoever business she may be, but in such as she may ask of you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:145
verses.text: But she will ask in such things as lie in your power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:146
verses.text: Then again there comes a very great praise of her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:147
verses.text: "For she hath been a succorer of many and of myself also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:148
verses.text: See his judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:149
verses.text: First come the encomiums, then he makes an exhortation intervene, and then again gives encomiums, so placing on each side of the needs of this blessed woman her praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:150
verses.text: For how can the woman be else than blessed who has the blessing of so favorable a testimony from Paul, who had also the power to render assistance to him who had righted the whole world? For this was the summit of her good deeds, and so he placed it the last, as he says, "and of myself also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:151
verses.text: But what does the phrase "of myself also" convey? Of the herald of the world, of him who hath suffered so much, of him who is equal to assisting tens of thousands (μυρίοις ἀρκοὕντος).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:152
verses.text: Let us then imitate, both men and women, this holy woman and her that followeth, with her husband also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:153
verses.text: And who are they?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:154
verses.text: "Greet," he says, "Priscilla and Aquila, my helpers in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:155
verses.text: To the excellence of these St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:156
verses.text: Luke also bears witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:157
verses.text: Partly when he says that Paul "abode with them, for by their occupation they were tent-makers" (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:158
verses.text: ); and partly when he points out the woman as receiving Apollos, and instructing him in the way of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:159
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:160
verses.text: ) Now these are great things, but what Paul mentions are greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:161
verses.text: And what does he mention? In the first place he calls them "helpers," to point out that they had been sharers of his very great labors and dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:162
verses.text: Then he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:163
verses.text: "Who for my life have laid down their own necks".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:164
verses.text: You see they are thoroughly furnished martyrs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:165
verses.text: For in Nero's time it is probable that there were thousands of dangers, at the time as he even commanded all Jews to be removed from Rome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:166
verses.text: (Acts viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:167
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:168
verses.text: "Unto whom not only I give thanks, but also all the Churches of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:169
verses.text: Here he hints at their hospitality, and pecuniary assistance, holding them in admiration because they had both poured forth their blood, and had made their whole property open to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:170
verses.text: You see these were noble women, hindered no way by their sex in the course of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:171
verses.text: And this is as might be expected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:172
verses.text: "For in Christ Jesus there is neither male nor female".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:173
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:174
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:175
verses.text: ) And what he had said of the former, that he said also of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:176
verses.text: For of her also he had said, "she hath been a succorer of many, and of myself also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:177
verses.text: So too of this woman "not only I give thanks, but also all the Churches of the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:178
verses.text: Now that in this he might not seem to be a flatterer, he also adduces a good many more witnesses to these women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:179
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:180
verses.text: "Likewise greet the Church that is in their house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:181
verses.text: For she had been so estimable as even to make their house a Church, both by making all in it believers, and because they opened it to all strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:182
verses.text: For he was not in the habit of calling any houses Churches, save where there was much piety, and much fear of God deeply rooted in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:183
verses.text: And on this ground he said to the Corinthians also, "Salute Aquila and Priscilla, with the Church that is in their house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:184
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:185
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:186
verses.text: ) And when writing about Onesimus, "Paul unto Philemon, and to the beloved Apphia, and to the Church that is in their house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:187
verses.text: (Philem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:188
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:189
verses.text: ) For it is possible for a man even in the married state to be worthy of being looked up to, and noble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:190
verses.text: See then how these were in that state and became very honorable, and yet their occupation was far from being honorable; for they were "tent-makers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:191
verses.text: Still their virtue covered all this, and made them more conspicuous than the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:192
verses.text: And neither their trade nor their marriage (συζυγία cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:193
verses.text: Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:194
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:195
verses.text: ) was any hurt to them, but the love which Christ required of them, that they exhibited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:196
verses.text: "For greater love hath no man than this, He says, that a man lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:197
verses.text: (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:198
verses.text: ) And that which is a proof of being a disciple, they achieve, since they took up the Cross and followed Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:199
verses.text: For they who did this for Paul, would much rather have displayed their fortitude in Christ's behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:200
verses.text: Let rich and poor both hear all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:201
verses.text: For if they who lived from their labor, and were managers of a workshop, exhibited such profuseness as to be of service to many Churches; what pardon can they expect, who are rich, and yet neglect the poor? For they were not sparing even of their blood for the sake of God's will, but thou art sparing even of scanty sums, and many times sparest not thine own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:202
verses.text: But in regard to the teacher were they so, and not so with regard to the disciples? Nay even this cannot be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:203
verses.text: For "the churches of the Gentiles," he says, "thank them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:204
verses.text: And yet they were of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:205
verses.text: But still they had such a clear (εἰλικρινὥς) faith, as to minister unto them also with all willingness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:206
verses.text: Such ought women to be, not adorning themselves with "broidered hair, or gold, or costly array" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:207
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:208
verses.text: ), but in these good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:209
verses.text: For what empress pray, was so conspicuous or so celebrated as this wife of the tent-maker? she is in everybody's mouth, not for ten or twenty years, but until the coming of Christ, and all proclaim her fame for things such as adorn far more than any royal diadem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:210
verses.text: For what is greater or so great, as to have been a succorer of Paul? at her own peril to have saved the teacher of the world? And consider: how many empresses there are that no one speaks of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:211
verses.text: But the wife of the tent-maker is everywhere reported of with the tent-maker (meaning perhaps St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:212
verses.text: Paul); and the width that the sun sees over, is no more of the world than what the glory of this woman runneth unto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:213
verses.text: Persians, and Scythians, and Thracians, and they who dwell in the uttermost parts of the earth, sing of the Christian spirit of this woman, and bless it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:214
verses.text: How much wealth, how many diadems and purples would you not be glad to venture upon obtaining such a testimony? For no one can say either, that in dangers they were of this character, and lavish with their money, and yet neglected the preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:215
verses.text: For he calls them "fellow-workers and helpers" on this ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:216
verses.text: And this "chosen vessel" (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:217
verses.text: ) does not feel ashamed to call a woman his helper but even finds an honor in doing so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:218
verses.text: For it is not the sex (φίσει) that he minds, but the will is what he honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:219
verses.text: What is equal to this ornament? Where now is wealth overflowing on every side? and where the adorning of the person? and where is vainglory? Learn that the dress of woman is not that put about the body, but that which decorates the soul, which is never put off, which does not lie in a chest, but is laid up in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:220
verses.text: Look at their labor for the preaching, the crown in martyrdom, the munificence in money, the love of Paul, the charm (φίλτρον) they found in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:221
verses.text: Compare with this thine own estate, thy anxiety about money, thy vying with harlots (i-e: in dress), thy emulating of the grass, and then thou wilt see who they were and who thou art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:222
verses.text: Or rather do not compare only, but vie with this woman, and after laying aside the burdens of grass (χλόης), (for this is what thy costly dressing is), take thou the dress from heaven, and learn whence Priscilla became such as she was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:223
verses.text: How then did they become so? For two years they entertained Paul as a guest: (Probably Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:224
verses.text: ) and what is there that these two years may not have done for their souls? What am I to do then, you will say because I have not Paul? If thou be minded thou mayest have him in a truer sense than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:225
verses.text: For even with them the sight of Paul was not what made them of such a character, but the words of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:226
verses.text: And so, if thou be so minded, thou shalt have both Paul, and Peter, and John, and the whole choir of the Prophets, with the Apostles, associating with thee continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:227
verses.text: For take the books of these blessed ones, and hold a continual intercourse with their writings, and they will be able to make thee like the tent-maker's wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:228
verses.text: And why speak I of Paul? For if thou wilt, thou mayest have Paul's Master Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:229
verses.text: For through Paul's tongue even He will discourse with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:230
verses.text: And in another way again thou wilt be able to receive this Person, when thou receivest the saints, even when thou tendest those that believe on Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:231
verses.text: And so even after their departure thou wilt have many memorials of piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:232
verses.text: For even the table at which the saint ate, and a seat on which he sat, and the couch on which he lay knoweth how to pierce him that received him; even after his departure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:233
verses.text: How then, think you, was that Shunamite pierced at entering the upper chamber where Elisha abode, when she saw the table, the couch on which the holy man slept; and what religiousness must she have felt come from it? For had this not been so, she would not have cast the child there when dead, if she had not reaped great benefit from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:234
verses.text: For if so long time after upon entering in where Paul abode, where he was bound, where he sat and discoursed, we are elevated, and find ourselves starting off from the places to that memory (so Field: Vulg.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:235
verses.text: "the memory of that day"); when the circumstances were still fresher, what must those have been likely to feel, who had religiously entertained him? Knowing all this then, let us receive the Saints, that the house may shine, that it may be freed from choking thorns, that the bedchamber may become a haven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:236
verses.text: And let us receive them, and wash their feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:237
verses.text: Thou art not better than Sarah, nor more noble, nor more wealthy, though thou be an empress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:238
verses.text: For she had three hundred and eighteen homeborn servants, at a time when to have two servants even was to be wealthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:239
verses.text: And why do I mention the three hundred and eighteen servants? She had become possessed of the whole world in her seed and in the promises, she had the "friend of God" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:240
verses.text: xli.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:241
verses.text: ; James ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:242
verses.text: ) for her husband, God Himself as a Patron, a thing greater than any kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:243
verses.text: And yet, though she was in so illustrious and honorable estate, this woman kneaded the flour, and did all the other servant's offices, and stood by them as they banqueted too in the rank of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:244
verses.text: Thou art not of nobler birth than Abraham, who yet did the part of domestics after his exploits after his victories, after the honor paid him by the king of Egypt, after driving out the kings of the Persians, and raising the glorious trophies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:245
verses.text: And look not to this; that in appearance the Saints that lodge with thee are but poor, and as beggars, and in rags many times, but be mindful of that voice which says, "Inasmuch as ye have done it to the least of these, ye have done it unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:246
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:247
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:248
verses.text: ) And, "Despise not one of these little ones, because their angels do always behold the face of My Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:249
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:250
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:251
verses.text: ) Receive them then with readiness of mind, bringing as they do ten thousand blessings to thee, through the greeting of peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:252
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:253
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:254
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:255
verses.text: ) And after Sarah, reflect upon Rebecca also, who both drew water and gave to drink, and called the stranger in, trampling down all haughtiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:256
verses.text: However, through this, great were the rewards of hospitality she received! And thou, if thou be so minded, wilt receive even greater than those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:257
verses.text: For it will not be the fruit of children only that God will give thee, but the heaven, and the blessings there, and a freedom from hell, and a remission of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:258
verses.text: For great, yea, very great, is the fruit of hospitality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:259
verses.text: (Luke xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:260
verses.text: ) Thus too Jethro, and that though he was a foreigner, gained for a relation him who with so great power commanded the sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:261
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:262
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:263
verses.text: ; Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:264
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:265
verses.text: ) For his daughters too drew into his net this honorable prey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:266
verses.text: (Num.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:267
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:268
verses.text: ) Setting then thy thoughts upon these things, and reflecting upon the manly and heroic temper of those women, trample upon the gorgeousness of this day, the adornments of dress, the costly jewelry, the anointing with perfumes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:269
verses.text: And have done with those wanton and delicate airs, and that mincing walk, and turn all this attentiveness unto the soul, and kindle up in thy mind a longing for the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:270
verses.text: For should but his love take hold of thee, thou wilt discern the mire and the clay, and ridicule the things now so admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:271
verses.text: For it is not even possible for a woman adorned with spiritual attainments to be seeking after this ridiculousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:272
verses.text: Having then cast this aside, which wives of the lewder sort of men, and actresses, and singers, have so much ambition in, clothe thee with the love of wisdom, with hospitality, with the succoring of the Saints, with compunction, with continual prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:273
verses.text: These be better than cloth of gold, these more stately than jewels and than necklaces, these both make thee of good repute among men, and bring thee great reward with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:274
verses.text: This is the dress of the Church, that of the playhouses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:275
verses.text: This is worthy of the heaven, that, of horses and mules; that is put even round dead corpses, this shineth in a good soul alone wherein Christ dwelleth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 31:276
verses.text: Let this then be the dress for us to acquire, that we also may have our praise sung everywhere, and be well-pleasing to Christ, by Whom and with Whom, etc, Amen.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:1
verses.text: Homily XXXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:3
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:4
verses.text: "Salute my well-beloved Epenetus, who is the first-fruits of Achaia unto Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:5
verses.text: I Think that many even of those who have the appearance of being extremely good men, hasten over this part of the Epistle as superfluous, and having no great weight in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:6
verses.text: And I think that the same befalls them in regard to the genealogy that is in the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:7
verses.text: For because it is a catalogue of names, they think they cannot get any great good from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:8
verses.text: Yet the gold founders' people are careful even about the little fragments; while these pass over even such great cakes of gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:9
verses.text: That this then may not befall them, what I have already said were enough to lead them off from their listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:10
verses.text: For that the gain even from this is no contemptible one, we have shown even from what was said on a former occasion, when we lifted up your soul by means of these addresses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:11
verses.text: We will endeavor then to-day also to mine in this same place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:12
verses.text: For it is possible even from bare names to find a great treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:13
verses.text: If, for instance, you were shown why Abraham was so called, why Sarah, why Israel, why Samuel, you would find even from this a great many real subjects of research.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:14
verses.text: And from times too, and from places, you may gather the same advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:15
verses.text: For the good man waxes rich even from these; but he that is slothful, does not gain even from the most evident things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:16
verses.text: Thus the very name of Adam teaches us no small wisdom, and that of his son, and of his wife, and most of the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:17
verses.text: For names serve to remind us of several circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:18
verses.text: They show at once God's benefits and women's thankfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:19
verses.text: For when they conceived by the gift of God, it was they who gave these names to the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:20
verses.text: But why are we now philosophizing about names, while meanings so important are neglected, and many do not so much as know the very names of the sacred books? Still even then we ought not to recede from an attention to things of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:21
verses.text: For "thou oughtest," He says, "to have put My money to the exchangers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:22
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:23
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:24
verses.text: ) And therefore though there be nobody that listens to it, let us do our part, and show that there is nothing superfluous, nothing added at random in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:25
verses.text: For if these names had no use, they would not then have been added to the Epistle, nor would Paul have written what he has written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:26
verses.text: But there are some even so low-minded, and empty, and unworthy of Heaven, as not to think that names only, but whole books of the Bible are of no use, as Leviticus, Joshua, and more besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:27
verses.text: And in this way many of the simple ones have been for rejecting the Old Testament, and advancing on in the way, that results from this evil habit of mind, have likewise pruned away many parts of the New Testament also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:28
verses.text: But of these men, as intoxicated and living to the flesh, we do not make much account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:29
verses.text: But if any be a lover of wisdom, and a friend to spiritual entertainments, let him be told that even the things which seem to be unimportant in Scripture, are not placed there at random and to no purpose, and that even the old laws have much to profit us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:30
verses.text: For it says, "All these things are types (A.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:31
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:32
verses.text: ensamples) and are written for our instruction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:33
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:34
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:35
verses.text: ) Wherefore to Timothy too he says, "Give heed to reading, to exhortation" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:36
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:37
verses.text: ), so urging him to the reading of the old books, though he was a man with so great a spirit in him, as to be able to drive out devils, and to raise the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:38
verses.text: Let us now keep on with the subject in hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:39
verses.text: "Salute my well-beloved Epenetus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:40
verses.text: It is worth learning from this how he distributes to each the different praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:41
verses.text: For this praise is no slight one, but even very great, and a proof of great excellence in him, that Paul should hold him beloved, Paul who had no idea of loving by favor, and not by cool judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:42
verses.text: Then another encomium comes, "Who is the first-fruits of Achaia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:43
verses.text: For what he means is, either that he leaped forward before any one else, and became a believer (and this were no slight praise), or that he displayed more religious behavior than any other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:44
verses.text: And on this account after saying, "who is the first-fruits of Achaia," he does not hold his peace, but to prevent your suspecting it to be a glory of the world's, he added, "unto Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:45
verses.text: Now if in civil matters, he that is first seemeth to be great and honorable, much more so in these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:46
verses.text: As then it was likely that they were of low extraction, he speaks of the true noble birth and preëminency, and gives him his honors from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:47
verses.text: And he says, that he "is the first-fruits," not of Corinth only, but of the whole nation, as having become as it were a door, and an entrance to the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:48
verses.text: And to such, the reward is no small one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:49
verses.text: For such an one will reap much recompense also from the achievements of others, in that he too contributed much toward them by beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:50
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:51
verses.text: "Greet Mary, who bestowed much labor on us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:52
verses.text: How is this? a woman again is honored and proclaimed victorious! Again are we men put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:53
verses.text: Or rather, we are not put to shame only, but have even an honor conferred upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:54
verses.text: For an honor we have, in that there are such women amongst us, but we are put to shame, in that we men are left so far behind by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:55
verses.text: But if we come to know whence it comes, that they are so adorned, we too shall speedily overtake them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:56
verses.text: Whence then is their adorning? Let both men and women listen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:57
verses.text: It is not from bracelets, or from necklaces, nor from their eunuchs either, and their maid-servants, and gold-broidered dresses, but from their toils in behalf of the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:58
verses.text: For he says, "who bestowed much labor on us," that is, not on herself only, nor upon her own advancement, (see p.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:59
verses.text: ) (for this many women of the present day do, by fasting, and sleeping on the floor), but upon others also, so carrying on the race Apostles and Evangelists ran.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:60
verses.text: In what sense then does he say, "I suffer not a woman to teach?" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:61
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:62
verses.text: ) He means to hinder her from publicly coming forward ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:63
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:64
verses.text: ), and from the seat on the bema, not from the word of teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:65
verses.text: Since if this were the case, how would he have said to the woman that had an unbelieving husband, "How knowest thou, O woman, if thou shalt save thy husband?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:66
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:67
verses.text: ) Or how came he to suffer her to admonish children, when he says, but "she shall be saved by child-bearing if they continue in faith, and charity, and holiness, with sobriety?" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:68
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:69
verses.text: ) How came Priscilla to instruct even Apollos? It was not then to cut in sunder private conversing for advantage that he said this, but that before all, and which it was the teacher's duty to give in the public assembly; or again, in case the husband be believing and thoroughly furnished, able also to instruct her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:70
verses.text: When she is the wiser, then he does not forbid her teaching and improving him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:71
verses.text: And he does not say, who taught much, but "who bestowed much labor," because along with teaching (τοὓ λόγου) she performs other ministries besides, those in the way of dangers, in the way of money, in the way of travels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:72
verses.text: For the women of those days were more spirited than lions, sharing with the Apostles their labors for the Gospel's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:73
verses.text: In this way they went travelling with them, and also performed all other ministries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:74
verses.text: And even in Christ's day there followed Him women, "which ministered unto Him of their substance" (Luke viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:75
verses.text: ), and waited upon the Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:77
verses.text: "Salute Andronicus and Junia my kinsmen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:78
verses.text: This also looks like an encomium.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:79
verses.text: And what follows is much more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:80
verses.text: And what sort is this of? "And my fellow-prisoners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:81
verses.text: For this is the greatest honor, the noble proclamation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:82
verses.text: And where was Paul a prisoner, that he should call them "my fellow-prisoners?" A prisoner indeed he had not been, but he had suffered things worse than prisoners, in being not an alien only to his country and his family, but in wrestling with famine and continual death, and thousands of other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:83
verses.text: For of a prisoner the only misfortune is this, that he is separated from his relations, and often has to be a slave instead of being free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:84
verses.text: But in this case one may mention temptations thick as snow-flakes, which this blessed person underwent by being carried and taken about, scourged, fettered, stoned, shipwrecked, with countless people plotting against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:85
verses.text: And captives indeed have no further foe after they are led away, but they even experience great care from those who have taken them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:86
verses.text: But this man was continually in the midst of enemies, and saw spears on every side, and sharpened swords, and arrays, and battles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:87
verses.text: Since then it was likely that these shared many dangers with him, he calls them fellow-captives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:88
verses.text: As in another passage also, "Aristarchus my fellow-prisoner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:89
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:90
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:91
verses.text: ) Then another praise besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:92
verses.text: "Who are of note among the Apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:93
verses.text: And indeed to be apostles at all is a great thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:94
verses.text: But to be even amongst these of note, just consider what a great encomium this is! But they were of note owing to their works, to their achievements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:95
verses.text: Oh! how great is the devotion (φιλοσοφία) of this woman, that she should be even counted worthy of the appellation of apostle! But even here he does not stop, but adds another encomium besides, and says, "Who were also in Christ before me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:96
verses.text: For this too is a very great praise, that they sprang forth and came before others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:97
verses.text: But let me draw your attention to the holy soul, how untainted it is by vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:98
verses.text: For after glory such as his in kind and degree, he sets others before himself, and does not hide from us the fact of his having come after them, nor is ashamed of confessing this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:99
verses.text: And why art thou surprised at his not being ashamed of this, when he shunneth not even to parade before men his former life, calling himself "a blasphemer, and a persecutor?" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:100
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:101
verses.text: ) Since then he was not able to set them before others on this score, he looked out himself, who had come in after others, and from this he did find means of bestowing a praise upon them by saying, "Who were in Christ before me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:102
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:103
verses.text: "Greet Amplias my beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:104
verses.text: Here again he passes encomiums upon his person by his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:105
verses.text: For the love of Paul was for God, carrying countless blessings with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:106
verses.text: For if being loved by the king is a great thing, what a great encomium must it be to be beloved by Paul? For if he had not acquired great virtue, he would not have attracted his love? Since as for those who live in vice and transgressions he is accustomed (οἶδε) not only to abstain from loving them, but even to anathematize them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:107
verses.text: As when he says, "If any man love not the Lord Jesus, let him be accursed" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:108
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:109
verses.text: ); and, "If any man preach any other gospel unto you than that ye have received, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:110
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:111
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:112
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:113
verses.text: "Salute Urbane, my helper in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:114
verses.text: This is a greater encomium than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:115
verses.text: For this even comprehends that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:116
verses.text: "And Stachys, my beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:117
verses.text: This again is an honor of the same kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:118
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:119
verses.text: "Salute Apelles, approved in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:120
verses.text: There is no praise like this, being unblamable, and giving no handle in the things of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:121
verses.text: For when he says, "approved in Christ," he includes the whole list of virtues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:122
verses.text: And on what ground does he nowhere say my Lord such an one, my Master this? It is because these encomiums were greater than those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:123
verses.text: For those are mere titles of rank (τιμἥς), but these are of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:124
verses.text: And this same honor he paid them not at random, or as addressing several of inferior virtue with the high and great characters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:125
verses.text: For so far as he is addressing, and that too one along with another, and in the same letter, he honors them all alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:126
verses.text: But by stating the praises particularly to each, he sets before us the virtue peculiar to each; so as neither to give birth to envy by honoring one and dishonoring another, nor to work in them listlessness and confusion, by giving them all the same dignity, though they did not deserve the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:127
verses.text: See now how he again comes to the admirable women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:128
verses.text: For after saying, "Salute them which are of Aristobulus' household,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:129
verses.text: "Salute Herodion my kinsman; greet them which be of the household of Narcissus;"  Who, it is likely, were not so worthy as the afore-mentioned, on which account also he does not mention them all by name even, and after giving them the encomium which was suited to them, that of being faithful, (and this the meaning of,)  "Which are in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:130
verses.text: He again reverts to the women, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:131
verses.text: "Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, who labor in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:132
verses.text: And in regard to the former woman, he says that "she bestowed labor upon you," but of these that they are still laboring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:133
verses.text: And this is no small encomium, that they should be in work throughout, and should not only work, but labor even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:134
verses.text: But Persis he calls beloved too, to show that she is greater than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:135
verses.text: For he says, "Salute my beloved Persis".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:136
verses.text: And of her great laborings he likewise bears testimony, and says, "which labored much in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:137
verses.text: So well does he know how to name each after his deserts, so making these more eager by not depriving them of any of their dues, but commending even the slightest preëminence, and making the others more virtuous, and inciting them to the same zeal, by his encomiums upon these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:138
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:139
verses.text: "Salute Rufus, chosen in the Lord, and his mother and mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:140
verses.text: Here again the good things are without any drawback, since the son and the mother are each of such a character, and the house is full of blessing, and the root agreeth with the fruit; for he would not have simply said, "his mother and mine," unless he had been bearing testimony to the woman for great virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:141
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:142
verses.text: "Salute Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermas, Patrobas, Hermes, and the brethren which are with them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:143
verses.text: Here do not be looking to how he starts them without any encomium, but how he did not reckon them, though far inferior, as it seems, to all, unworthy of being addressed by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:144
verses.text: Or rather even this is no slight praise that he even calls them brethren, as also those that are after them he calls saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:145
verses.text: For he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:146
verses.text: "Salute Philologus, and Julius, and Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints which are with them;"  Which was the greatest dignity, and unspeakable height of honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:147
verses.text: Then to prevent any jealousy rising from his addressing one in one way and another in another, and some by name and some with no distinction, and some with more points of praise, and some with fewer, he again mingles them in the equality of charity, and in the holy kiss, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:148
verses.text: "Salute one another with an holy kiss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:149
verses.text: To cast out of them, by this salutation, all arguing that confused them, and all grounds for little pride; that neither the great might despise the little, nor the little grudge at the greater, but that haughtiness and envy might be more driven away, when this kiss soothed down and levelled every one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:150
verses.text: And therefore he not only bids them salute in this way, but sends in like manner to them the greeting from the Churches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:151
verses.text: For "there salute you," he says, not this or that person individually, but all of you in common,  "The Churches of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:152
verses.text: You see that they are no small gains that we earn from these addresses, and what treasures we should have passed hastily over, unless in this part of the Epistle also we had examined it with accuracy, such, I mean, as was in our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:153
verses.text: So if there be found any man of wisdom and spiritual, he will dive even deeper, and find a greater number of pearls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:154
verses.text: But since some have often made it a question wherefore it was that in this Epistle he addressed so many, which thing he has not done in any other Epistle, we might say that it is owing to his never having seen the Romans yet, that he does this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:155
verses.text: And yet one may say, "Well, he had not seen the Colossians either, and yet he did not do anything of the kind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:156
verses.text: But these were more honorable than others, and had come thither from other cities, as to a safer and more royal city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:157
verses.text: Since then they were living in a foreign country, and they needed much provision for security, and some of them were of his acquaintance, but some too were there who had rendered him many important services, he with reason commends them by letters; for the glory of Paul was then not little, but so great, that even from his sending them letters, those who had the happiness to have an Epistle to them, gained much protection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:158
verses.text: For men not only reverenced him, but were even afraid of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:159
verses.text: Had this not been so, he would not have said, who had been "a succorer of many, and of myself also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:160
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:161
verses.text: ) And again, "I could wish that myself were accursed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:162
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:163
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:164
verses.text: ) And to Philemon he wrote and said, "as Paul the aged, and a prisoner of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:165
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:166
verses.text: ) And to the Galatians, "Behold, I Paul say unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:167
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:168
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:169
verses.text: ) And, "Ye received me even as Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:170
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:171
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:172
verses.text: ) And writing to the Corinthians he said, "Now some are puffed up, as though I would not come unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:173
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:174
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:175
verses.text: ) And again, "These things I have in a figure transferred to myself and to Apollos, that ye might learn in us not to think of men above that which is written".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:176
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:177
verses.text: ) Now from all these passages it is clear that all had a great opinion of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:178
verses.text: Wishing then that they should feel on easy terms, and be in honor, he addressed each of them, setting forth their praise to the best advantage he might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:179
verses.text: For one he calls beloved, another kinsman, another both, another fellow-prisoner, another fellow-worker, another approved, another elect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:180
verses.text: And of the women one he addresses by her title, for he does not call her servant of the Church in an undefined way (because if this were so he would have given Tryphena and Persis this name too), but this one as having the office of deaconess, and another as helper and assistant, another as mother, another from the labors she underwent, and some he addresses from the house they belonged to, some by the name of Brethren, some by the appellation of Saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:181
verses.text: And some he honors by the mere fact of addressing them, and some by addressing them by name, and some by calling them first-fruits, and some by their precedence in time, but more than all, Priscilla and Aquila.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:182
verses.text: (τοὺς περὶ Πρ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:183
verses.text: κ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:184
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:185
verses.text: ) For even if all were believers, still all were not alike, but were different in their merits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:186
verses.text: Wherefore to lead them all to greater emulation, he keeps no man's encomiums concealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:187
verses.text: For when they who labor more, do not receive the greater reward also, many become more listless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:188
verses.text: On this ground even in the kingdom, the honors are not equal, nor among the disciples were all alike, but the three were preëminent above the rest.
