verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:189
verses.text: And among these three again there was a great difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:190
verses.text: For this is a very exact method observed by God even to the last.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:191
verses.text: Hence, "one star differeth from another star in glory," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:192
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:193
verses.text: ), it says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:194
verses.text: And yet all were Apostles and all are to sit on twelve thrones, and all left their goods, and all companied with Him; still it was the three He took.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:195
verses.text: And again, to these very three, He said it was possible (ἐγχωρεῖν) that some might even be superior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:196
verses.text: "For to sit," He says, "on My right hand and on My left, is not mine to give, save to those for whom it is prepared".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:197
verses.text: (Mark x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:198
verses.text: ) And He sets Peter before them, when He says, "Lovest thou Me more than these?" (John xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:199
verses.text: ) And John too was loved even above the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:200
verses.text: For there shall be a strict examination of all, and if thou be but little better than thy neighbor, if it be even an atom, or anything ever so little, God will not overlook even this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:201
verses.text: And this even from of old one might see coming out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:202
verses.text: For even Lot was a righteous man, yet not so, as was Abraham; and Hezekiah again, yet not so as was David: and all the prophets, yet not so as was John.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:203
verses.text: Where then are they who with all this great exactness in view, yet will not allow that there is a hell? For if all the righteous are not to enjoy the same lot, if they exceed others even a little ("for one star," it says, "differeth from another star in glory,") ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:204
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:205
verses.text: ), how are sinners to be in the same lot with the righteous? Such a confusion as this even man would not make, much less God! But if ye will, I will show you that even in the case of sinners, arguing from existing facts, there is this distinction, and exact just judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:206
verses.text: Now consider; Adam sinned, and Eve sinned, and both transgressed, yet they were not equally sinful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:207
verses.text: And therefore neither were they equally punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:208
verses.text: For the difference was so great that Paul said, "Adam was not deceived but the woman being deceived was in the transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:209
verses.text: And yet the deceit was one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:210
verses.text: But still God's searching examination pointed out a difference so great, as that Paul should make this assertion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:211
verses.text: Again, Cain was punished, but Lamech, who committed a murder after him, did not suffer near so great a punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:212
verses.text: And yet this was a murder, and that was a murder, and that so much the worse, because even by the example he had not become the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:213
verses.text: But since the one neither killed his brother after exhortation, nor needed an accuser, nor shrunk from answering when God questioned him, but even without any accuser both pleaded again himself, and condemned himself more severely, he obtained pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:214
verses.text: But the other as having done the opposite was punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:215
verses.text: See with what exactness God sifteth the facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:216
verses.text: For this reason He punished those in the flood in one way, and those in Sodom in another; and the Israelites again, both those in Babylon, and those in Antiochus' time, in different ways: so showing that He keeps a strict account of our doings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:217
verses.text: And these were slaves for seventy years, and those for four hundred, but others again ate their children, and underwent countless other more grievous calamities, and even in this way were not freed, either they or those that were burnt alive in Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:218
verses.text: "For it shall be more tolerable," He says, "for the land of Sodom and Gomorrha, than for that city".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:219
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:220
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:221
verses.text: ) For if He hath no care for us, either when we sin or when we do aright, perhaps there will be some reason in saying that there is no punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:222
verses.text: But since He is so exceedingly urgent about our not sinning, and adopts so many means to keep us in the right, it is very plain that He punisheth the wicked, and also crowneth those that do right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:223
verses.text: But let me beg you to consider the unfairness of the generality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:224
verses.text: For they find fault with God because He so often long-suffering, overlooks so many that are impious, impure, or violent, without now suffering punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:225
verses.text: Again, if He threaten to punish them in the other world, they are vehement and pressing in their accusations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:226
verses.text: And yet if this be painful, they ought to accept and admire the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:227
verses.text: But alas the folly! the unreasonable and asinine spirit! alas the sin-loving soul, that gazes after vice! For it is from this that all these opinions have their birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:228
verses.text: And so if they who utter these things should be minded to lay hold upon virtue, they will presently find themselves satisfied concerning hell also, and will not doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:229
verses.text: And where (it is said) and in what place is this hell? For some fablers say that it is in the valley of Josaphat, thus drawing that which was said about a certain by-gone war, to apply to hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:230
verses.text: But the Scripture does not say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:231
verses.text: But in what place, pray, will it be? Somewhere as I think at least quite out of the pale of this world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:232
verses.text: For as the prisons and mines are at a great distance from royal residences, so will hell be somewhere out of this world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:233
verses.text: Seek we not then to know where it is, but how we may escape it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:234
verses.text: Neither yet because God doth not punish all here, therefore disbelieve things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:235
verses.text: For merciful and long-suffering He is: that is why he threatens, and does not cast us into it forthwith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:236
verses.text: For "I desire not," He says, "the death of a sinner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:237
verses.text: (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:238
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:239
verses.text: ) But if there is no death of a sinner, the words are but idle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:240
verses.text: And I know indeed that there is nothing less pleasant to you than these words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:241
verses.text: But to me nothing is pleasanter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:242
verses.text: And would it were possible at our dinner, and our supper, and our baths, and everywhere, to be discoursing about hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:243
verses.text: For we should not then feel the pain at the evils in this world, nor the pleasure of its good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:244
verses.text: For what would you tell me was an evil? poverty? disease? captivity? maiming of the body? Why all these things are sport compared to the punishment there, even should you speak of those who are tormented with famine all their life long; or those who are maimed from their earliest days, and beg, even this is luxury compared to those other evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:245
verses.text: Let us then continually employ ourselves with talking about these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:246
verses.text: For to remember hell prevents our falling into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:247
verses.text: Dost thou not hear St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:248
verses.text: Paul saying, "Who shall suffer everlasting punishment from the face of the Lord?" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:249
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:250
verses.text: ) Dost thou not hear what Nero's character was, whom Paul even calls the Mystery of Antichrist? For "the mystery of iniquity," he says, "already worketh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:251
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:252
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:253
verses.text: ) What then? Is Nero to suffer nothing? Is Antichrist to suffer nothing? or the Devil nothing? Then he will always be Antichrist, and so the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:254
verses.text: For from mischief they will not leave off, unless they be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:255
verses.text: "Yea," you say, "but that there is a hell everybody sees.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:256
verses.text: But the unbelievers only are to fall into it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:257
verses.text: What is the reason, pray? It is because the believers acknowledge their Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:258
verses.text: And what is this to the purpose? when their life is impure, they will on this ground be punished more severely than the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:259
verses.text: "For as many as have sinned without law shall also perish without law: but as many as have sinned in the law shall be judged by the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:260
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:261
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:262
verses.text: ) And, "The servant that knew his master's will, and did it not, shall be beaten with many stripes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:263
verses.text: (Luke xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:264
verses.text: ) But if there is no such thing as giving an account of one's life, and all this is said in a loose way then neither will the Devil have vengeance taken upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:265
verses.text: For he too knows God, and far more than men too, and all the demons know Him, and tremble, and own He is their Judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:266
verses.text: If then there is no giving an account of our life, nor of evil deeds, then will they also clean escape.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:267
verses.text: These things are not so, surely they are not! Deceive not yourselves, beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:268
verses.text: For if there is no hell, how are the Apostles to judge the twelve tribes of Israel? How cometh Paul to say, "Know ye not that we shall judge Angels? how much more things of this life?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:269
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:270
verses.text: ) How came Christ to say, "The men of Nineveh shall arise and condemn this generation" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:271
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:272
verses.text: ); and, "It shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:273
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:274
verses.text: ) Why then make merry with things that are no subjects for merriment? Why deceive thyself and put cheats upon thy reason (παραλογίζῃ, om.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:275
verses.text: τὴν ψυχήνσου)? Why fight with the love of God toward man? For it was through this that He prepared it, and threatened, that we might not be cast into it, as having by this fear become better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:276
verses.text: And thus he that does away with speaking on these subjects doth nothing else than thrust us into it, and drive us thither by this deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:277
verses.text: Slacken not the hands of them then that labor for virtue, nor make the listlessness of them that sleep greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:278
verses.text: For if the many be persuaded that there is no hell, when will they leave off vice? Or when will right be seen? I do not say between sinners and righteous men, but between sinners and sinners? For why is it that one is punished here, and another not punished, though he does the same sins, or even far worse? For if there be no hell, you will having nothing to say in defence of this to those who make it an objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:279
verses.text: Wherefore my advice is, that we leave off this trifling, and stop the mouths of those that are gainsayers upon these subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:280
verses.text: For there will be an exact searching into the smallest things, both in the way of sins and in the way of good deeds, and we shall be punished for unchaste looks, and for idle words, and for mere reproachful words, and for drunkenness we shall render an account, as even for a cup of cold water we shall receive a reward, and a sigh only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:281
verses.text: (Eccl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:282
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:283
verses.text: ) For it says, "Set a mark upon the foreheads of the men that sigh and that cry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:284
verses.text: (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:285
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:286
verses.text: ) How then darest thou to say that He, who with so great exactness will search into our doings, threatened hell in bare words, and lightly? Do not, I beseech you, do not with these vain hopes destroy thyself and those that are persuaded by thee! For if thou disbelievest our words, make enquiry of Jews and Gentiles, and all heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:287
verses.text: And all of them as with one mouth will answer that a judgment there shall be, and a retribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:288
verses.text: And are men not enough? Ask the devils themselves, and thou wilt hear them cry, "Why hast thou come thither to torment us before the time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:289
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:290
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 32:291
verses.text: ) And putting all this together persuade thy soul not to trifle idly, lest by experience thou come to know there is a hell, but from this thou mayest be sobered, and so able to escape those tortures, and attain to the good things to come; whereof may we all partake by the grace and love towards man, etc.

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:1
verses.text: Homily XXXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:2
verses.text: Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:3
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:4
verses.text: ,  "Now I beseech you, brethren, mark them which cause divisions and offences contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned, and avoid them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:5
verses.text: For they that are such serve not our Lord Jesus Christ, but their own belly; and by good words and fair speeches deceive the hearts of the simple".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:6
verses.text: Again an exhortation, and prayer after the exhortation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:7
verses.text: For after telling them to "mark them which cause divisions," and not to listen to them, he proceeds, "And the God of peace shall bruise Satan under your feet shortly:" and, "The grace of our Lord be with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:8
verses.text: And notice how gently too he exhorts them: doing it not in the character of a counsellor, but that of a servant, and with much respect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:9
verses.text: For he calls them brethren, and supplicates them likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:10
verses.text: For, "I beseech you, brethren," (he says).

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:11
verses.text: Then he also puts them on the defensive by showing the deceitfulness of those who abused them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:12
verses.text: For as though they were not at once to be discerned, he says, "I beseech you to mark," that is, to be exceedingly particular about, and to get acquainted with, and to search out thoroughly—whom, pray? why, "those that cause divisions and offences, contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:13
verses.text: For this is, if anything the subversion of the Church, the being in divisions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:14
verses.text: This is the devil's weapon, this turneth all things upside-down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:15
verses.text: For so long as the body is joined into one, he has no power to get an entrance, but it is from division that the offence cometh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:16
verses.text: And whence is division? From opinions contrary to the teaching of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:17
verses.text: And whence come opinions of this sort? From men's being slaves to the belly, and the other passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:18
verses.text: For "such," he says, "serve not the Lord, but their own belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:19
verses.text: And so there would be no offence, there would be no division, unless some opinion were thought of contrary to the doctrine of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:20
verses.text: And this he here points out by saying, "contrary to the doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:21
verses.text: And he does not say which we have taught, but "which ye have learned," so anticipating them, and showing that they were persuaded of and had heard them and received them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:22
verses.text: And what are we to do to those who make mischief in this way? He does not say have a meeting and come to blows, but "avoid them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:23
verses.text: For if it was from ignorance or error that they did this, one ought to set them right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:24
verses.text: But if they sin willingly, spring away from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:25
verses.text: And in another place too he says this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:26
verses.text: For he says, "Withdraw from every brother that walketh disorderly" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:27
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:28
verses.text: ): and in speaking to Timothy about the coppersmith, he gives him the like advice, and says, "Of whom be thou ware also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:29
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:30
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:31
verses.text: ) Then also to lash (κωμῳδὥν) those who dare to do such things, he mentions also the reason of their devising this division.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:32
verses.text: "For they that are such," he says, "serve not our Lord Christ, but their own belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:33
verses.text: And this he said too when he wrote to the Philippians, "Whose god is their belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:34
verses.text: (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:35
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:36
verses.text: ) But here he appears to me to intimate those of the Jews, whom he ever uses particularly to find fault with as gluttonous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:37
verses.text: For in writing to Titus too, he said of them, "Evil beasts, slow bellies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:38
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:39
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:40
verses.text: , see v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:41
verses.text: ) And Christ also blames them on this head: "Ye devour widows' houses" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:42
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:43
verses.text: ), He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:44
verses.text: And the Prophets accuse them of things of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:45
verses.text: For, "My beloved," He says, "hath waxen fat and gross, and hath kicked" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:46
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:47
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:48
verses.text: Wherefore also Moses exhorted them, and said, "When thou hast eaten and drunken and art full, remember the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:49
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:50
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:51
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:52
verses.text: ) And in the Gospels, they who say to Christ, "What sign showest thou unto us?" (John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:53
verses.text: ) pass over everything else, and remember the manna.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:54
verses.text: So do they everywhere appear to be possessed with this affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:55
verses.text: How then comest thou not to be ashamed at having slaves of the belly for thy teachers, when thou art a brother of Christ? Now the ground of the error is this, but the mode of attack is again a different disorder, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:56
verses.text: flattery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:57
verses.text: For it is by "fair speeches," he says, "that they deceive the hearts of the simple".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:58
verses.text: For their attention reaches only to words; but their meaning is not such, for it is full of fraud.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:59
verses.text: And he does not say that they deceive you, but "the hearts of the simple".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:60
verses.text: And even with this he was not satisfied, but with a view to making this statement less grating, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:61
verses.text: "For your obedience is come abroad unto all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:62
verses.text: This he does, not to leave them free to be shameless, but to win them beforehand with encomiums, and the number of his witnesses, to arrest their attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:63
verses.text: For neither is it I alone that am the witness, but the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:64
verses.text: And he does not say for your understanding, but, "your obedience:" that is, their compliance, which was evidence of much meekness in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:65
verses.text: "I am glad therefore on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:66
verses.text: And this is no small encomium too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:67
verses.text: Then, after the praise, admonition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:68
verses.text: For lest, after liberating them from any charges against them, he should make them the more listless, as not being observed; he gives them another hint in the words,  "I would have you wise unto that which is good, and simple concerning evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:69
verses.text: You see then how he attacks them again, and that without their suspecting it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:70
verses.text: For this looks like intimating that some of them were apt to be led astray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:71
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:72
verses.text: "And the God of peace shall bruise Satan under your feet shortly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:73
verses.text: For since he had spoken of those who "caused divisions and offences among them," he has mentioned "the God of peace" also, that they might feel hopeful about the riddance of these evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:74
verses.text: For he that rejoiceth in this (i-e:, peace) will put an end to that which makes havoc of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:75
verses.text: And he does not say, will subject, but "will bruise" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:76
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:77
verses.text: ), which is a stronger expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:78
verses.text: And not those people only, but also him who was the general over them herein, Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:79
verses.text: And not "will bruise" merely, but "under your feet," so that they may obtain the victory themselves, and become noble by the trophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:80
verses.text: And the time again is made a ground of comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:81
verses.text: For he adds, "shortly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:82
verses.text: And this was prayer and prophecy as well at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:83
verses.text: "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:84
verses.text: That greatest weapon; that impregnable wall; that tower unshaken! For he reminds them of the grace, that he may give them the more alacrity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:85
verses.text: Because if ye have been freed from the ills more grievous by far, and freed by grace only, much more will ye be freed from the lesser, now ye have become friends too, and contribute your own share likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:86
verses.text: You see how he neither puts prayer without works, nor works without prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:87
verses.text: For after giving them credit for their obedience, than he prays; to show that we need both, our own part as well as God's part, if we are to be duly saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:88
verses.text: For it was not before only, but now too, even though we be great and in high esteem, we need grace from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:89
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:90
verses.text: "Timotheus my work-fellow saluteth you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:91
verses.text: Observe the customary encomiums again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:92
verses.text: "And Lucius, and Jason, and Sosipater my kinsmen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:93
verses.text: This Jason Luke also mentions, and sets before us his manliness also, when he says, that "they drew" him "to the rulers of the city, crying," etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:94
verses.text: (Acts xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:95
verses.text: ) And it is likely that the others too were men of note.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:96
verses.text: For he does not mention relations barely, unless they were also like him in religiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:98
verses.text: "I Tertius, who wrote this Epistle, salute you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:99
verses.text: This too is no small encomium, to be Paul's amanuensis.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:100
verses.text: Still it is not to pass encomiums on himself that he says this, but that he might attach a warm love to him on their part, for this ministration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:101
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:102
verses.text: "Gaius mine host (ξένος), and of the whole Church, saluteth you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:103
verses.text: See what a crown he has framed for him by bearing witness to such great hospitality in him, and brought in the entire Church into this man's house! For by the word ξένον, used here, he means a host, not a guest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:104
verses.text: But when you hear that he was Paul's host, do not admire him for his munificence only, but also for his strictness of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:105
verses.text: For except he were worthy of Paul's excellency, he would never have lodged there, since he, who took pains to go beyond many of Christ's commands, would never have trespassed against that law, which bids us be very particular about who receive us, and about lodging with "worthy" persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:106
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:107
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:108
verses.text: ) "Erastus, the chamberlain of the city, salutes you, and Quartus a brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:109
verses.text: There is a purpose in his adding "the chamberlain of the city," for as he wrote to the Philippians, "They of Caesar's household salute you" (Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:110
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:111
verses.text: ), that he might show that the Gospel had taken a hold upon great folk, so here too he mentions the title with a view to the same object, and to show that, to the man who gives heed, neither riches are a hindrance, nor the cares of government, nor anything else of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:113
verses.text: "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:114
verses.text: See what we ought to begin and to end with everywhere! For in this he laid the foundation of the Epistle, and in this he putteth on the roof, at once praying for the mother of all good things for them, and calling the whole of his loving-kindness to their mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:115
verses.text: For this is the best proof of a generous teacher, to benefit his learners not by word only, but likewise by prayer, for which cause also one said, "But let us give ourselves continually to prayers, and to the ministry of the word".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:116
verses.text: (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:117
verses.text: )  Who is there then to pray over us, since Paul hath departed? These who are the imitators of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:118
verses.text: Only let us yield ourselves worthy of such intercession (συνηγορίας), that it may not be that we hear Paul's voice here only, but that hereafter, when we are departed, we may be counted worthy to see the wrestler of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:119
verses.text: Or rather, if we hear him here, we shall certainly see him hereafter, if not as standing near him, yet see him we certainly shall, glistening near the Throne of the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:120
verses.text: Where the Cherubim sing the glory, where the Seraphim are flying, there shall we see Paul, with Peter, and as a chief and leader of the choir of the Saints, and shall enjoy his generous love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:121
verses.text: For if when here he loved men so, that when he had the choice of departing and being with Christ, he chose to be here, much more will he there display a warmer affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:122
verses.text: I love Rome even for this, although indeed one has other grounds for praising it, both for its greatness, and its antiquity, and its beauty, and its populousness, and for its power, and its wealth, and for its successes in war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:123
verses.text: But I let all this pass, and esteem it blessed on this account, that both in his lifetime he wrote to them, and loved them so, and talked with them whiles he was with us, and brought his life to a close there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:124
verses.text: Wherefore the city is more notable upon this ground, than upon all others together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:125
verses.text: And as a body great and strong, it hath as two glistening eyes the bodies of these Saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:126
verses.text: Not so bright is the heaven, when the sun sends forth his rays, as is the city of Rome, sending out these two lights into all parts of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:127
verses.text: From thence will Paul be caught up, from thence Peter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:128
verses.text: Just bethink you, and shudder (φρίξατε) at the thought of what a sight Rome will see, when Paul ariseth suddenly from that deposit, together with Peter, and is lifted up to meet the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:129
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:130
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:131
verses.text: ) What a rose will Rome send up to Christ! (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:132
verses.text: xxxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:133
verses.text: ) what two crowns will the city have about it! what golden chains will she be girded with! what fountains possess! Therefore I admire the city, not for the much gold, not for the columns, not for the other display there, but for these pillars of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:134
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:135
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:136
verses.text: ) Would that it were now given me to throw myself round (περιχυθἥναι) the body of Paul, and be riveted to the tomb, and to see the dust of that body that "filled up that which was lacking" after "Christ" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:137
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:138
verses.text: ), that bore "the marks" (στίγματα,) (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:139
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:140
verses.text: ) that sowed the Gospel everywhere yea, the dust of that body through which he ran to and fro everywhere! the dust of that body through which Christ spoke, and the Light shone forth more brilliant than any lightning, and the voice started out, more awful than any thunder to the devils! through which he uttered that blessed voice, saying, "I could wish that myself were accursed, for my brethren" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:141
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:142
verses.text: ), through which he spake "before kings, and was not ashamed!" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:143
verses.text: cxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:144
verses.text: ) through which we come to know Paul through which also Paul's Master! Not so awful to us is the thunder, as was that voice to the demons! For if they shuddered at his clothes (Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:145
verses.text: ), much more did they at his voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:146
verses.text: This led them away captive, this cleansed out the world, this put a stop to diseases, cast out vice, lifted the truth on high, had Christ riding upon it, and everywhere went about with Him; and what the Cherubim were, this was Paul's voice, for as He was seated upon those Powers, so was He upon Paul's tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:147
verses.text: For it had become worthy of receiving Christ, by speaking those things only which were acceptable to Christ, and flying as the Seraphim to height unspeakable! for what more lofty than that voice which says, "For I am persuaded that neither Angels, nor Principalities, nor Powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:148
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:149
Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:150
verses.text: ) What pinions doth not this discourse seem to thee to have? what eyes? (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:151
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:152
verses.text: ) It was owing to this that he said, "for we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:153
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:154
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:155
verses.text: ) Owing to this did the devils flee not only at hearing him speak, but even at seeing his garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:156
verses.text: This is the mouth, the dust whereof I would fain see, through which Christ spake the great and secret things, and greater than in His own person, (for as He wrought, so He also spake greater things by the disciples,) through which the Spirit gave those wondrous oracles to the world! For what good thing did not that mouth effect? Devils it drave out, sins it loosed, tyrants it muzzled, philosophers' mouths it stopped, the world it brought over to God, savages it persuaded to learn wisdom, all the whole order of the earth it altered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:157
verses.text: Things in Heaven too it disposed what way it listed ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:158
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:159
verses.text: , ), binding whom it would, and loosing in the other world, "according unto the power given unto it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:160
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:161
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:162
verses.text: ) Nor is it that mouth only, but the heart too would fain see the dust of, which a man would not do wrong to call the heart of the world, and a fountain of countless blessings, and a beginning, and element of our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:163
verses.text: For the spirit of life was furnished out of it all, and was distributed through the members of Christ, not as being sent forth by arteries, but by a free choice of good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:164
verses.text: This heart was so large, as to take in entire cities, and peoples, and nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:165
verses.text: "For my heart" he says, "is enlarged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:166
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:167
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:168
verses.text: ) Yet even a heart thus large, did this very charity that enlarged it many a time straiten and oppress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:169
verses.text: For he says, "Out of much affliction (θλίψεως) and anguish (συνοχἥς) of heart I wrote unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:170
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:171
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:172
verses.text: ) I were desirous to see that heart even after its dissolution, which burned at each one that was lost, which travailed a second time with the children that had proved abortions (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:173
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:174
verses.text: ), which saw God, ("for the pure in heart," He says, "shall see God,") (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:175
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:176
verses.text: ) which became a Sacrifice, ("for a sacrifice to God is a contrite heart,") (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:177
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:178
verses.text: ) which was loftier than the heavens, which was wider than the world, which was brighter than the sun's beam, which was warmer than fire, which was stronger than adamant, which sent forth rivers, ("for rivers," it says, "of living water shall flow out of his belly,") (John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:179
verses.text: ) wherein was a fountain springing up, and watering, not the face of the earth, but the souls of men, whence not rivers only, but even fountains of tears, issued day and night, which lived the new life, not this of ours, (for "I live," he says, "yet not I, but Christ liveth in me," (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:180
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:181
verses.text: ) so Paul's heart was His heart, and a tablet of the Holy Spirit, and a book of grace); which trembled for the sins of others, (for I fear, he says, lest by any means "I have bestowed labor upon you in vain; (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:182
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:183
verses.text: ) lest as the serpent beguiled Eve; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:184
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:185
verses.text: ) lest when I come I should find you not such as I would;") (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:186
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:187
verses.text: ) which both feared for itself, and was confiding too, (for I fear, he says, "lest by any means after having preached to others I myself should be a castaway," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:188
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:189
verses.text: ) And, "I am persuaded that neither angels nor powers shall be able to separate us;") (alluding to Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:190
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:191
verses.text: ) which was counted worthy to love Christ as no other man loved Him: which despised death and hell, yet was broken down by brothers' tears, (for he says, "what mean ye to weep and to break mine heart?") (Acts xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:192
verses.text: ) which was most enduring, and yet could not bear to be absent from the Thessalonians by the space of an hour! ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:193
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:194
verses.text: ; iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:195
verses.text: ) Fain would I see the dust of hands that were in a chain, through the imposition of which the Spirit was furnished, through which the divine writings were written, (for "behold how large a letter I have written unto you with mine own hand:" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:196
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:197
verses.text: ) and again, "The salutation of me Paul with mine own hand,") ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:198
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:199
verses.text: ) of those hands at the sight of which the serpent "fell off into the fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:200
verses.text: (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:201
verses.text: ) Fain would I see the dust of those eyes which were blinded gloriously, which recovered their sight again for the salvation of the world; which even in the body were counted worthy to see Christ, which saw earthly things, yet saw them not, which saw the things which are not seen, which saw not sleep, which were watchful at midnight, which were not effected as eyes are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:202
verses.text: I would also see the dust of those feet, which ran through the world and were not weary; which were bound in the stocks when the prison shook, which went through parts habitable or uninhabited, which walked on so many journeys.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:203
verses.text: And why need I speak of single parts? Fain would I see the tomb, where the armor of righteousness is laid up, the armor of light, the limbs which now live, but which in life were made dead; and in all whereof Christ lived, which were crucified to the world, which were Christ's members, which were clad in Christ, were a temple of the Spirit, an holy building, "bound in the Spirit," (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:204
verses.text: ) riveted to the fear of God, which had the marks of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:205
verses.text: This body is a wall to that City, which is safer than all towers, and than thousands of battlements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:206
verses.text: And with it is that of Peter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:207
verses.text: For he honored him while alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:208
verses.text: For he "went up to see Peter," (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:209
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:210
verses.text: ) and therefore even when departed grace deigned to give him the same abode with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:211
verses.text: Fain would I see the spiritual Lion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:212
verses.text: For as a lion breathing (Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:213
verses.text: sending,) (Cant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:214
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:215
verses.text: ) forth fire (πὕρ ἀφιεὶς) upon the herds of foxes, so rushed he upon the clan of demons and philosophers, and as the burst of some thunderbolt, was borne down into the host of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:216
verses.text: (Luke xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:217
verses.text: ) For he did not even come to set the battle in array against him, since he feared so and trembled at him, as that if he saw his shadow, and heard his voice, he fled even at a distance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:218
verses.text: And so did he deliver over to him the fornicator, though at a distance, and again snatched him out of his hands ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:219
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:220
verses.text: ;  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:221
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:222
verses.text: , ); and so others also, that they might be taught "not to blaspheme".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:223
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:224
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:225
verses.text: ) And consider how he sent forth his own liegemen against him, rousing them, suppling them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:226
verses.text: And at one time he says to the Ephesians, "We wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities and powers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:227
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:228
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:229
verses.text: ) Then too he puts our prize in heavenly places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:230
verses.text: For we struggle not for things of the earth, he says, but for Heaven, and the things in the Heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:231
verses.text: And to others, he says, "Know ye not that we shall judge Angels? how much more the things of this life?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:232
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:233
verses.text: ) Let us then, laying all this to heart, stand nobly; for Paul was a man, partaking of the same nature with us, and having everything else in common with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:234
verses.text: But because he showed such great love toward Christ, he went up above the Heavens, and stood with the Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:235
verses.text: And so if we too would rouse ourselves up some little, and kindle in ourselves that fire, we shall be able to emulate that holy man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:236
verses.text: For were this impossible, he would never have cried aloud, and said, "Be ye imitators of me, as I am of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:237
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:238
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Book of Romans 33:239
verses.text: ) Let us not then admire him only, or be struck with him only, but imitate him, that we too may, when we depart hence, be counted worthy to see him, and to share the glory unutterable, which God grant that we may all attain to by the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom, and with Whom, be glory to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, now and evermore, Amen.
